What do i do then?! God dammit
I've been on Vyvanse for about 2+ years now, and I've tested varying levels of dosage + taking other pills alongside it (with my psychiatrist's aid and approval), so I wanna add my two cents of my learned experiences.   Disclaimers:  - I'm biologically female. ADHD and meds, by extensio,n work VERY differently depending on biological sex. I do not know how it works for men, I only know that the menstrual cycle is a bitch that makes my life very difficult taking medication. - I am ALSO Autistic. Unfortunately, stimulants are proven to be a 50/50 gamble for AuDHDers. I'm lucky that they work... sort of. But they will never work as well for me as someone who has had ADHD only. - I'm Australian, so I can't comment on how pharmacies and shit work in the US of A.  So for dosages, I dabbled with the (20mg), (40mg), (50mg), and (30mg).  - 20mg: two weeks. Felt fucking great, but I'd crash several hours before bed. Not ideal. - 40mg: Finally started to really work, but I noticed a lot of... odd things happening. I was absolutely getting the Good Shit with the Vyvanse Focus Mode (which, as stated in the video, is a double-edged sword), but I noticed I was getting... irritable. Moody. I'd get sensory overload faster. I felt like I was becoming less pleasant company. And I still wasn't getting the focus I actually wanted. Confused, I'd asked to go up to the 50mg because I was still getting energy crashes, and my psychiatrist agreed. - 50mg: Spoiler alert. This was a mistake. I was on 50mg for nearly a year, and it was NOT good. It started GREAT. PERFECT. I had never felt so productive or functional in my life. But I became utterly inflexible with my routines, would pick fights with anyone who stopped me from working, would hear noises nobody else could hear because my senses were dialled up to 100, started developing extremely unhealthy obsessions that would steal my time away instead of work, AND I developed severe breathing issues towards the end. The worst part is: I was scared to lower my dose. My psychiatrist had wanted to lower my dose several times over the year, but I was so adverse until it was MY idea that I suffered for a year without needing to. - 30mg (what I take NOW): This is my golden level. My standard. It is far from perfect, but it's the best balance I've found between not taking meds and taking too many meds. That being said, let me elaborate more on how my medication actually works now, because this needs context.  As a bio female, I suffer from rises and drops in Estrogen. Estrogen has DOPAMINE. Dopamine is very important for ADHD people - we need it badly, we never absorb it as well as other people, and we're useless if it's too low. When Estrogen rises, you get BIG dopamine, and that feels fucking great. When dopamine drops, though, you get withdrawal and become a shell of a person who's tired and depressed. Unfortunately, the relationship between ADHD, Dopamine, Estrogen, and the menstrual cycle for women is a severely under-researched issue because many idiots in the medical field still think women can't have ADHD, and periods and cycles are also woefully under-researched. There is no proper medical fix because of this, so a lot of this stuff is trial and error for me, making little adjustments in meds and making lifestyle changes.  That said, I have two versions of my meds schedule: normal/high Estrogen, and low Estrogen.  NORMAL SCHEDULE: - 30mg Vyvanse: Taken once, first thing in the morning. This is the main player, the stimulant. It is not only a Central Nervous System drug, but it also contains a bit of dopamine and other helpful chemicals to aid the ADHD brain. VERY IMPORTANT TIPS ABOUT VYVANSE: You need to eat within two hours for it to work properly, so don't skip breakfast. You also don't want to drink coffee too soon after Vyvanse because coffee is also a stimulant - I like to wait two hours after taking Vyvanse to drink coffee. It's different for everyone. - Propranolol (propranolol hydrochloride) 10mg: Traditionally a drug used for heart issues, migraines, and a bunch of other shit, mine is specifically a very low dose recommended for anxiety. It also helps a minor tremor I have in my hands. Initially, when I took this drug, it made me sleepy and I hated that, but I eventually adjusted and now it's a godsend. I take it once a day, usually 1 hour after I wake up. Despite its usefulness and ability to be taken up to four times a day, I can only take it once a day; otherwise it will make my blood pressure too low because I have a sedentary lifestyle. - Epilim (sodium valproate) 100mg: If Vyvanse is the main player, Epilim is the production crew that keeps the show from falling apart. Traditionally used to treat epilepsy, Epilim is also used as a minor mood stabilising drug in treatment for bipolar disorder (something I was once mistakenly diagnosed with. Fun fact: it's extremely common for women with Autism or ADHD to be misdiagnosed with mood disorders like Bipolar or BPD for being "overly emotional." Medical misogyny sucks.) However, my psychiatrist informed me that very recent studies have shown that a SMALL dosage of Epilim, while taken with stimulants is the key to making Autistic people not crash on while on Stimulants. So now, I take crushable tablets of epilim: 100mg cut in half each day - the first 50mg half is taken roughly an hour after Vyvanse, and the second 50mg half is taken 6 hours later (I set a timer). The craziest thing I've noticed about Epilim is when I miss my afternoon pills - if I forget to take Epilim for whatever reason, I crash out HARD emotionally and it's ALWAYS because I forgot my Epilim. If I take my Epilim, I am so very chill.  LOW ESTROGEN SCHEDULE (take for 4-5 days straight): - 40mg Vyvanse: Because of my lower dopamine, I increase my dosage to give me a fighting chance to battle my dopamine withdrawl. So far it's worked very good when combined with active, productive days to keep the dopamine generating, but my sleep is pretty restless at night.  - Propranolol (propranolol hydrocloride) 10mg: exactly the same. - Epilim (sodium valproate) 50mg + 100mg: Epilim is also adjusted. Usually, when I take the 40 of Vyvanse, I start happy and get more burnt out as the day goes. So, I take the 50 Epilim as per usual in the morning, but 6 hours later, I double the dose at take the 100mg pill whole. This tends to make me a little more tired and mellow (compared to the hyperactive energy of early day 40 Vyvanse), but it's integral to avoiding some moritfying episode of bursting into tears because a cricket has been chirping at me for 4 hours straight.  IMPORTANT TAKEAWAYS: - This is what works for me at this current time. It is not perfect. It will not work for everyone. But the reason I sat my ass down to write this all out is to prove that people CAN find strategies to battle their issues... it might just take a lot of trial and error. For example, if my meds schedule starts to fall apart at any point, my doc and I have discussed using a specific type of anti-depressant to treat ADHD because it gives dopamine/seratonin. I haven't tried it yet and will only do that if I have to, because for now I feel stable enough to make due with an imperfect but helpful medical cocktail. - Number 1 piece of advice: you NEED a GOOD psychiatrist. I'm being so for real here - a genuinely awesome psychiatrist while change your life in ways eight years of therapy never had. You need someone who's flexible, open-minded, keeps up with current research, and is willing to experiment. I lucked out by getting recommended mine from a psychologist and he's the only good psychiatrist I've ever had. My psychiatrist is neurodivergent, which helps a LOT. Please do not settle for a bad doctor, you'll get nowhere. - I absolutely still have issues with focus. 30mg Vyvanse tends to feel "normal" and I do have to plan my days better. Limiting distractions you know are giving you the wrong dopamine helps. Changing up environment and routine also helps, even if that sometimes feels like an imposible thing to do. I focus way better on 40mg, but it's better for me to take 30mg normally so I can still feel the "magic" of the 40 for the few days I have it and actually need it. - For other women, I personally wouldn't take higher Vyvanse dosages during your period, but that's just me. Give your body a chance to rest, please. - ALSO FOR WOMEN, birth control can REALLY fuck with your ADHD. Like BADLY. Please read up on it and talk to your doctor/gynecologist/psychiatrist, especially if you're suffering from depression or anxiety, because it might be the hormones from birth control. - Do I still suffer breathing issues? Fortunately, I don't. Or, more specific, I very rarely do. When I *do* have breathing issues, it is because of a source - chemical household cleaning supplies (I swapped to more natural stuff), my cat's litter box (changed the litter type and moved it to the other side of the house for distance), shower mold, smoke outside, bad ventilation, etc. There's usually almost always a solution for the problem and I don't have to suffer weeks on end feeling like my lungs are going to fucking give out even when my doctors tell me there's nothing wrong with my body.  Apologies this is so long, but hopefully it helps somebody. And hopefully YouTube doesn't instantly delete it either lmao.

I have adhd and when I‚Äôm doing something ill get lost in thought and snap back and realize its done and working
I think the thing with medication is that it's viewed as this magic pill that will solve your problems, when in reality it just helps make things easier. Best way I can put it is imagine fighting a dark souls boss. Shit is hard and you're gonna die a ton and it feels like you're banging your head into a brick wall until something happens. ADHD medication is literally just a buff. The boss is still hard af and you have to do all the work of fighting a souls boss, and the buff won't fix your skill issue, but it can make the issue easier to deal with.
I got diagnosed about a year ago (I'm 32yo) I'm taking meds (methylphenidate 54mg), someday I don't take it, somedays I do, somedays i use them the way your not supposed to. Overall the effect on life is positive, actually reflecting back while typing, it's really positive. The biggest thing for me is to be able to "relax your brain" with the meds, it feels like I can finally control them. I am still a little concerned about the long term side effects but for now, I only wish I would have got diagnosed earlier.    overall life before meds: everything I ever started, I couldn't finish; school, army, couldn't hold a job.   overall life with meds: I still don't finish everything, but I do finish A LOT more, I got a degree (this is 50/50 since I got the meds while getting that degree). I now have my own business, don't forget stuff AS MUCH (I still forget quite a lot tho).    + the "silence in your head" + productivity   - if you take it too late, you lose some sleep         (+but if you have bad sleep and wake up tired, the meds wakes you up)
If you have not tried it, try Elvance, it's the only type that has worked for me.

I've been off vyvanse for a while now, but I got off it for the exact same reasons. You get hyperfocused on whatever it is you're thinking about 1hr or so after you take it.   Then the side effects come along, shortness of breath and fast pulse for me. They didn't get worse, but the positive effects dwindled if I didn't take breaks... Except when I took breaks I was like a brainless lifeless husk.   Wife and I talked about it and I quit taking them, didn't even go back to my psych lol.   Thing about ADHD is, it gets better with age as your prefrontal cortex develops (which can happen well into one's 20s). It's also much easier to live with once you're aware of it and can feel better about it and actively try to adapt strategies that overcome your weaknesses, ie notes, calendars and alarms. Routine and habits. All these things help me function.

just a heads up that vyvanse is also essentially meth if we are gonna go with the "adderall as meth" comparison. its just dextroamphetamine with a lysine molecule attached to make it release slower. this is what makes it smoother and feel a bit different, but vyvanse and adderall are much closer than meth and adderall.

I got diagnosed with ADHD (combined type, unfortunately) at 19. I was on Adderall until my psych office at the time suddenly just. Stopped doing outpatient with no warning??? And then literally nobody else was willing to prescribe a ‚ú®scary controlled substance‚ú® because I wasn't a misbehaving small child in a public school classroom.  I only just got back on Proper Attention Deficit Hyperactive Disorder Medication‚Ñ¢ in the past three months. I am now 29. I had been self meditating with a frankly medically unwise amount of caffeine for almost the entirety of that decade in the meantime. Unfortunately there are things in Monster specifically that can make OCD worse so that was an entirely different story.  Anyways I am now on methylphenidate (generic for Concerta) 36mg and it's a game-changer. It's not perfect, but it's enough for me to start the process of trying to get things done more reliably.  Unfortunately it's taken so long that the adjustment of the neural pathways by the medication long-term is almost impossible, so I'm probably going to need this stuff to function for the rest of my life. üòê

I take vyvanse and this focus struggle is absolutely spot on. That‚Äôs the reason why you need to develope a structure and productivity systems that are tailored to you.  With out taking meds my productivity is either interest based or urgency based. So those just work. If I take Vyvanse I can stay in that focus loop and go deep. But if I wanted to be productive and precise with my focus I need lists of things to do and a functional calander and functional project management systems that work to structure my tasks well. I can‚Äôt just do this in my head it needs to be written down and sorted. Without the meds these plans never worked but with vyvanse they generally become useful to me.

We still can‚Äôt do as much as fast as neurotypical people (‚Äúaverage Alex‚Äù) can.  It would still be great to get some help.  It is still highly likely that we will struggle quite noticeably because nobody is interested in helping anyone else consistently.  It just isn‚Äôt AS bad. ü´§

smoke sativa stupid
I personally had a rough time with Vyvanse. It made me _extremely_  anxious, and because it‚Äôs slow acting, it lasted almost the whole day. I‚Äôve also tried Wellbutrin and Quelbree (both non-stimulants that still help with ADHD), both of which stopped working after about 3-5 days. I‚Äôve been on Adderall for about 15 years, and while it‚Äôs had its ups and downs, it seems to be helping me limp along at least. I‚Äôve just taken the ‚ÄúI only focus on what I find interesting at the moment‚Äù in stride and have somewhat learned to redirect my laser focus onto something I need to do.
His description of what adderall feels like is eerily accurate for me. If I‚Äôm not medicated, and I try and do something, my brain will bring up a slightly different task, and then another, and another, and so on and so forth.  It also made it so that when I try to do something that I don‚Äôt want to do, my brain simply refuses to do it. Not that it‚Äôs hard, like I physically can‚Äôt do it. However when I started taking aderall, it was like night and day.  Suddenly, I could think about one thing for minutes on end. This sometimes worked too well. I‚Äôd be doing something for one class, then I‚Äôd get another assignment. My brain would not stop working on the first one until it was finished, no matter how long the first assignment took. This inevitably lead to me writing a 4 page essay, only to realise that I was writing it on the wrong topic. To sum it all up, normal people get distracted sometimes to do other valuable things. Aderall makes it so that you cannot get distracted.
MEDS ARE USELESS IF YOU DON'T ALSO TRAIN URSELF TO BE USEFUL ON THEM
I'm 36 and finally tried medication for the first time half a year ago (I take something called Elvanse which I thiiiink in the US might be that Vyvance you talked about) and while it really helped/helps me, it was veeeery surreal at first, felt like getting super high the first day and it's definitely not something like a magical cure that turns you into that super productive being you always wanted to be. Its more like a file system for your thoughts or at least that's how I experience it so I can definitely agree with your description. There's still that part of you that HAS to learn how to control your newfound ability to concentrate and target those specific things you need to get done. Trust me I have those unproductive days, too. It's almost like it takes you by the hand and gives you that sensation of "yeah well I can actually do this shit" but it won't turn you into something new. This realization was a little disappointing at first, but I've come to appreciate it because I still feel like it's me doing it, not the drug. What I also like about it is the fact that after taking it for a while, even though I see the change it makes in me during a workday, I don't feel like I'm taking a drug that's really hard on my body, if you know what I mean? Oh, and another HUGE bonus: when I take the medication, my dark thoughts simply disappear thanks to the continuous and steady release of dopamine. Yay. I think our different experiences just show that it's absolutely necessary to try different things and find out what works for YOU. Don't let anyone talk you into taking medication that may not be the best fit for your personal ADHD characteristics. No reputable psychiatrist would push you to take a medication that you feel is not right for you. Don't be afraid to talk about symptoms and side effects. With this attitude, you will find the right thing for you. Keep up the good work, and oh, look, a squirrel...

This is maybe an unpopular opinion, but I believe in many cases, stopping your medication isn't so bad - it's just that it is *EXTREMELY* bad in some cases, and the general recommendation "never stop taking your meds without talking to your doctor first" is based around the idea that it's probably too complex to explain to patients under which circumstances quitting your medication is ok, and when it's bad but acceptable, and when it is absolutely a terrible idea.

Vyvanse had to work a very spesific way for me. If I took too much at once i would just feel intense with little to no benefit and then I would crash.  My solution to this was to divide the dosage over the day. So 20mg in the morning. 20mg in the middle if the day. This gave me steady effect that helped me in more ways than just focus. It suddently became effectively an anti-depressant. This has permanently rewired my brain such that I can feel confident even when off my meds.

I had the same experience with Vivance. Gave me hyper focus to the max and made me feel Sick. Like SICK sick. Went to the doctor, the dose was too high! I was overdosing on it, but at the standard dose that is usually good for other people. Apparently this can happen sometimes, different brains need different dosages. Dialed back my dose until it was seriously tiny, so now we‚Äôre micro dosing i guess but it finally worked for me! I think this is a common problem people with ADHD have, finding not only the right medication but also the dose that works specifically for you can take time and be difficult. So some people prefer to just go without it.

When I was in high school they were throwing me on and off all different kinds of ADHD medications, all of which gave me severe side effects but one of which gave me permanent neurological tics. Kind of like very mild tourettes.
Dude you just need behavioral therapy in combination with your meds.  Some people got 'the plan' inside them and just need the meds to make it possible to realize it. Other people don't and that's okay. It's a new world with meds and it's completely legit to need some help navigating that.  You need to reflect on your behavioral patterns. Things that used to serve you, as distraction or that were soothing (like doomscrolling, youtube, food, drugs, whatever), quite possibly will not serve you in this 'new world'. More so they will hinder you.  Anyone whose spend some years on this earth living with (undiagnosed) ADHD has developed their own coping mechanisms. Of course we don't identify them as such, to us it's 'just how life is' and what we do to get through the day, what we do to survive. And that's kind of legit because what else are we supposed to do in that situation. Especially since 'that situation' isn't something that we are able to change (when undiagnosed we of course think it has to be possible to change that situation, to function normally, to 'just do it' and we must be just too stupid, too lazy, too unwillig.. but that's another story).  With meds we are given access to change our perceived destiny. The meds won't change it for us, but the meds give us the opportunity to put our hand on the wheel of our life. And you've got to take that opportunity for it to mean anything. Sounds cheesy but you gotta stop coping and surviving and allow yourself to start living. And of course that is a process and takes time and a lot of self reflection. Because there is fear, there is, founded by years of life experience, the believe that 'I can't trust myself' - 'no matter how much I want; I won't, I can't' and it is only human to seek safety in what we know when we feel unsafe. But with meds you've gotta give yourself the benefit of the doubt, you've gotta allow yourself to think 'but what if afterall now I CAN?' or if that seems to far fetched, atleast allow yourself to act and plan  accordingly.  Its not helpful to take your meds and then proceed to do like you've done for years. Don't take your meds and then put a screen in your face and get lost in there.  Take your meds and live! Do the things you've always wanted to be able to do, try those things again that before were too exhausting to sustain and be open to be surprised by yourself. Like I said, it's absolutely legit to not know where/how to start, how to set up your day to day for your success. But there is help for that.  One thing I can say for certain tho is that screens, the internet, social media, gaming, tv and all that is poison for your mind in that scenario. You can still watch your vids or shows or scroll through insta once the day is done, if you don't want to miss it completely.  I know this video is a few years old and you probably won't read my comment. I just know from personal experience what a tremendous gift those meds can be with the right strategy, and I would love love to share that gift with anyone who needs it.  If you do read my comment, feel free to reach out if you want!

Oh man, getting started on the taskbis the hardest part of ADHD, even with meds. I find it's a huge help to have an outside voice to keep me in check. I've even started arranging little "productivity playdates" with my other neurodivergent friend, where we just go to each other's house and work on a task we've been meaning to do but have been avoiding. We don't need to chat, or have an agenda, it's literally just sitting silently in a room together getting work done but sometimes asking along the way "Hey, you done with that thing yet?", just to keep each other accountable. It's AMAZING. 10/10, recommended

6:54 I think it's because your body wasn't used to the strain your brain was on. It was trying hard to keep up, but wasn't getting enough nutrients to fill it. The mind and body are linked, but one's external (physical), and the other is internal (mental). They have to be in sync for everything to work. Basically...you may just be outta shape, and the medicine gave you too much energy for your brain only.
I think the solution to a malady of the mind is a melody. Mnemonic echoing sound, distorts the noise, and it gives your brain something interesting to focus on to puzzle and parse out, because music is numbers and binary and math. The foundation of creation meeting your mind i.e., imagination. Take your time. So long as it gets done EVENTUALLY, it's chill. You're fine. And everything is going to be okay. That's my two cents.

That "Adderall is basically meth" thing goes around, but it's not. It's not that. (Desoxyn is that.) Amphetamine and dextroamphetamine are amphetamines, but they are not n-methylamphetamine. Psychoactive drugs can be drastically altered by small changes. Serotonin and melatonin are both tryptamines and remarkably close structurally, but of course they serve very distinct functions in the brain.  So if anyone reading this is working with a psychiatrist to find a medication, don't rule out Adderall just for being meth. Because it's not. Work with your doctor, and I wish you the best luck in finding a medication and dosage that meets your needs.

I don't think ADHD people are not productive (Having diagnosed ADHD myself). Productivity equals products built/projects done/whatever per time unit. However, this also means that in time units, we are not active, that we are not producing anything. So in absolute terms, you are right about it. However, in terms of time units we actually do work, we are far more productive because we simply don't have this kind of attention span normal people have. So in order for us to fullfil a job, we have to be automatically *more* productive to keep up our work even though we work only for a fragment of time for real than other people do. Of course, this doesn't apply to everyone, but it is something I and others who have the same condition have experienced.
Yeah I tried to explain to my family multiple times that this condition has worsened as I've gotten older. And that a lot of my frustration comes from people inattentiveness to detail but that stems largely from the fact I CAN'T STOP SEEING AND HEAR EVERYTHING ALL THE TIME and my brain every now and then goes "Shut your eyes and breathe for ten minutes so I can catch the fuck up!" and I just kinda lock up or I get so overloaded with 50 different pieces of information but only about 2% of the information for every piece and as the next thing comes in I'm trying to figure out which progress bar it applies to and while I'm doing that next piece comes in and the next and it piles up and basically overloads my mental buffer.  Also to make a list and then be ready for me to confirm it slowly because if you say "Go get me some milk thistle" my brain goes immediately "Do you want the raw herb? Where do I get it if you do want the raw herb? Does this come in pill form? Where is it in pill form? Can I go to any pharmacy or do I go to a fancy supplement store? Whats an acceptable price for it and whats too much? Whats the level of importance on this if I don't find it at the first place do you need it direly or do I just come home?" and while all that shit and more goes throuygh my brain they're trying to tell me the next 4-5 things on the list and I'm like "WAIT I haven't even finished processing MILK THISTLE yet I have a lot of questions!"  It sucks the meds are so expensive, since I changed locations and jobs to one that SAID they had benefits but then were like "yeah it's just $600/month out of your pocket for the insurance "we provide"".. dirtbags.. anyway I can't afford them anymore so I just deal with it but it makes me seem like a very irritable person when it's really that my brain is just running like a cpu racing at 95% and any new thing could tip me over the line into freeze-up mode.

Okay so my brother and my dad have ADHD, and I'm pretty sure I have some symptoms of it. I don't think it's full-blown ADHD, but these are the symptoms I have, if anyone could alert me to whether I actually have it or not. - I often get distracted on my way to tasks, for example, I'll be cleaning my desk and then see that my nightstand is really dirty, so the next thing I know i'm cleaning my nightstand instead. This happens for big and small tasks. - I have a big problem with procrastination, and almost never get things done before the deadline. I find myself watching youtube all day instead of schoolwork (I'm doing online homeschool) - I don't have an inner monologue a lot, but when I do it is all over the place, and whenever I pray I have to refocus on my prayer around 5 times every time, because I start thinking about other things - I always have to be moving, and if i'm not fidgeting I am WAY more distractable, my thoughts trailing away unless i'm bouncing my leg, or toying with something with my fingers. These are the things i've noticed, although i've always been fine in school, getting good enough grades. Anyone got any ideas?

I think a huge part of ADHD management/treatment is routine WITH SOME FLEXIBILITY. Keyword: SOME. trying to get too locked in to a rigid routine without breathing room is too constricting, even when medicated, and it can cause me to go off the rails. like "this is miserable, might as well have fun while being miserable instead". but having a guideline of how my day should go with like. planned pockets of free time. helps my brain a lot. planned unproductivity if you will? definitely seems to help. and trying to intersperse physical activities with mental ones helps me focus and prevent mental fatigue

7:20 It's actually ok if you decide to go cold turkey and stop taking vyvanse if you're done with it. I think he's saying to never do this because I know that with most other ADHD meds, you would have to be weened off the medication slowly so that you won't go through violent withdrawals, but the unique thing about vyvanse is that you don't have to take it every day and only need to take it as needed. For me, I would take vyvanse basically every day for school, but when summer time comes around and finals are over, I go cold turkey and chill and just save my meds for whenever I need to do work.

bro I was watching this video and blowing my nose for like 3 minutes and remembered I was taking my allergy medicine üò≠
On Vyvanse now, my interests have changed and I get into rambling internet arguments a lot more than before, so I think I'll talk to my doctor about going back to generic Focalin (Dexmethylphenidate). I'm not sure if it's the Vyvanse's fault, or the fact that every pill I've taken has been non-extended-release, yet the Vyvanse only comes in extended release form, therefore for a 12 hour pill I'm getting a thinner dose than a smaller amount of the immediate-release pill that only lasts about 4 hours?  I dunno, but the Focalin worked for about 10 years until I upped my dosage and ended up coughing every night to the point I couldn't sleep (dehydration affecting the back of my throat or something? I dunno). Anyway, I moved onto Adderall XR, and I actually have no clue why I switched after that as I have no memory of it, then Vyvanse, which works a bit, but I'm on 40 mg, take 4-6 hours to 'wake up' and stop being lethargic, then argue on the internet pointlessly and MAYBE get some work done starting around 11pm.  The Focalin just seems like a warm jacket in comparison, but with a bit of flexibility with dosage and timing; guess I'll see if it works.

I took Ritalin for about 10 years. At first, it worked really well, and I was able to focus on one thing and study normally. But over time, I stopped eating almost entirely and began to develop depression. When I changed doctors, he recommended that I get an eye test. It turned out that I have a misalignment in my eyes and simply needed glasses. I've been wearing the glasses for a year now, and the ADHD symptoms have almost completely disappeared. I think the remaining symptoms are just a matter of habit.

But I guess that comes from the fact, that it has to metabolised before the effects start to hit ü§î  Oh and by the way, D-Amphetamin, L-Amphetamin or their combination ‚Äòregular‚Äô Amphetamin is not ‚Äúeffectively Meth‚Äù üòÖ   Methamphetamin is a derivative of Amphetamin, sure. ADHD meds are not for everyone and don‚Äôt let this video deter you from trying them as EVERYONE will have different reactions to them.  Also adhd meds can be affected by the following   - what task you decide to focus on for the day  - if you don‚Äôt eat and drink enough meds will be less effective  - if your running on low sleep (6 hours or less) meds will actually be less effective and sometimes heighten symptoms of sleep deprivation  - not eating healthy can affect meds  - burnout can effect meds  - and I also noticed that if I take adhd meds while anxious it will very ironically make me focus more on my anxiety  - also NEVER EVER EVER EVER EVER EEEEVER MIX ADHD MEDS AND CAFFEINE your heart is already elevated by the adhd meds don‚Äôt add caffeine to the mix.

sounds like you didn't have appropriate psycho education alongside your medication. A psychiatrist is also supposed to help you set up habit patterns that trick you into being on the right task. I think fixating on ADHD medication being the "fix" is what caused your problems.  They're a tool to help facilitate some things getting done so that there is less overwhelming you in general. The "fix" is understanding behaviour patterns and building up long term habits that don't rely on executive function.

05:21 autistic individuals join the chat
This might be a little late but, in case it helps anyone, try switching to Dexedrine. Adderall (amphetamine) is a mix of its D-isomer and L-isomer (dextroamphetamine and levoamphetamine), the kick you feel during the day is the D-isomer, which lasts 3-5 hours, and the rest is the L-isomer (weaker and has more adverse side effects). Vyvanse is like an extended release of the D-isomer only, which lasts 10-12 hours. The constant release of a stimulant throughout the day combined with other factors like insomnia could explain why your body ends up feeling so exhausted. Dexedrine is just the D-isomer alone (dextroamphetamine), which doesn't last very long so you would manually take it throughout the day. If you wake up late or forget to take your meds, it's not an issue because it wont cause sleep deprivation later on. If it's the evening and you need to drive but your meds have worn off, taking dexedrine wouldn't completely ruin your night of sleep and would help you focus. You can take it as needed and it's not as big of a commitment as longer-acting medication. You're not on it constantly so it wouldn't exhaust your body the same way Vyvanse would. You also have multiple opportunities to correct what you end up hyperfocusing on during the day.
ADHD is interesting but exhausting at the same time.

It‚Äôs all about finding which med is helping you specifically to get your brain chemistry rebalanced to the way it should be. Right dose, medication etc. If your dose is too high then it‚Äôs likely you‚Äôre being overly medicated. Then it pretty much turns you into a zombie because it‚Äôs relaxing you too much lol.

Bit of a long comment coming up, because I like analyzing myself and writing it out makes that easier and I might as well share it if I'm taking the time to type it out anyway.  So I'm pretty sure I have ADHD. I don't know if that's *all* I have, but it's the only thing I can identify at the moment.  When I was younger, I used to think I might have OCD because I have weird compulsions that my brain makes me do. I later came to the conclusion this was not OCD because I could technically not do these things, it just made by brain a bit... uncomfy for a second. Like hearing nails on a chalkboard for a second and then it goes away.  For example: while playing games, if I go down a spiral staircase in a game like... idk FFVII (7), I would have to stop partway down and reverse the spin of my character in place... because my character had spun around too many times in one direction and that bothered me so I needed to balance it out. Not *actually* balance it out, just enough spins until my brain felt satisfied, getting rid of that discomforting feeling in my brain and, I guess, giving a slight dopamine hit or something and then I'd go back down and it would keep doing it until the fucking spiral staircase _stopped._  I don't have to do that so much anymore which I think I know why and I'll explain in a moment.  Another was that I would have to take a single finger or object over one eye's line of sight (NOT both) and then do it over the other one in a mirrored symmetrical pattern. Blinking one eye and then the other also accomplished the same result, but I rarely thought to ever do that so I almost never actually did.  Symmetry seemed to be a similar problem for both of these strange issues.  I believe the reason I don't do these things anymore isn't because I don't get the compulsions, because I do when I think of them... it's just that I rarely think of them anymore for some reason. Stress exacerbates these problems, which I guess can bring about OCD symptoms more as well, which again is what always made me think I had that. I now get different compulsions. One compulsion, to be specific...  I count. I count everything. Specifically, I count every "separate" part (color) of anything. When watching a movie or TV show I'll count the parts of a person. Their pupil (black), iris (whatever eye color they have; heterochromia counts twice because they're two different colors), the sclera of the eye (white), their skin (red, yellow, black and white, "they are precious in his siiight"), their hair color and maybe their eyebrows/facial hair too because different shades of the same color or different due to dyeing, their shirt, their undershirt, their pants, the slight tone shift on their pants if they have like jeans where the dye is a bit darker in the seams or something, their shoes, their socks because it's a different kind of white from the sclera which is a more clear and clean white from a distance at least...  Anyway. Yeah, I at least don't have to move my hands for this one or stop what I'm doing in a game to adjust my fucked up brain, but I seem to have less focus than I ever did before because even while browsing the internet or watching videos on my PC, I'm still counting the different colors of my browser. The YouTube logo's red, the Brave browser's orange, the Windows logo's blue, the different shades of black on my night mode YouTube page... _everything._  I often wonder if a medicated person doesn't have to deal with this shit, but I don't even know if anyone else has this problem. Looking it up now, it's a symptom of OCD, and it certainly feels like something that's harder for me to control than my previous afflictions, but I still don't believe it's severe enough to call it OCD. I can stop doing it. I can look away and distract myself, but what if that's like... ADHD and OCD combating each other. OCD is a fixation on something and ADHD is a constantly shifting focus until I hyperfixate on something else?  ...maddening. I wish I could fully understand myself. I get endlessly fascinated by the topic of my mind and trying to learn more about what might be going on in my head, comparing to other people with ADHD or even OCD and other conditions, but I don't really feel like I've made all that much progress recently.  At least I can pull myself away from all of my insanity with the help of video games and music. There is nothing to help me focus better than a fun game. Checklist games (open-world titles with collectibles, for example) are a godsend for me. Go here, grab that, max health is low, go do that to get a higher health, bored now? Go get some new clothes, those are fun. What's the story? Should go do more of that. 50% of the way done, cool, okay, more clothes.  They're so good at taking my wandering attentions and focusing them on things I enjoy so it doesn't feel overwhelming. It can be a problem, though, because as a kid I'd get too invested and wouldn't be able to pull apart from it for even a moment without getting angry or frustrated. I see that same behavior in my father with his weird chess obsession and how angry he gets when *anything* interferes with it and I sometimes wonder if he has the same condition, but unlike him, I cannot sit and play the same thing endlessly every day. I would get bored. I have hundreds of games to explore and while I will come back to my favorites on a 2-year (and rarely one-year) cycle, I am always interested in something new to excite me and feed that craving for the unknown and exotic. I need something new. I imagine a large part of the reason I can even return to the things I love is because I forget what it feels like, forget details, or outright forget the plot of a game's story and that means it's something new to discover again.  WOW this turned into a big rant. I'm supposed to be in bed and I stayed up like an hour past. I thought I had gotten better about not doing that, but well... I haven't. Not enough anyway.

Self-diagnosing isn't generally a good thing, but in the case of ADHD, it's something you really should know you have so you can learn to work around it or use it to your benefit. Gonna be honest with you, Nord, and everyone here. I know you have to make money, but there is absolutely no reason to get Nord or its VPN. Nord itself is like malware, once its there its almost impossible to completely remove without a PC Reset. Windows Defender (and its Mac equivalent) have become so well-made that there is absolutely no reason to use a 3rd party anti-virus. There is absolutely no reason to spend 40+ dollars a month on a service when Windows itself provides it (for free). It just immediately feels like a scam when someone tries to advertise Nord to me. If you all are REALLY concerned about malware on your pc, get the free version of malwarebytes, run a scan, and uninstall it. Otherwise, there's no reason to buy any 3rd party anti-virus. (Nord is known with the PC community to be ONE OF THE WORST anyways).

One thing i have to say as someone who had both Adderall and Vyvanse, those issues also appear, but both have the same issues you listed. So when it comes to physical tasks like house work, I go to the Library and not in an environment where cleaning can be done. And for the hyperfocus on one thing, I see that as a win because I can crank out assignments 8-10 hours straight sometimes, just literqlly dont get side tracked. The last thing is feeling fatigue with vyvanse, this happens to me when I used to take it everyday, now I only do it 6 days a week so I can have a break from stimulants and relax. I highly suspect that I have ADHD. I don't have a diagnosis yet, because M O N E E. But, if I ever do get a diagnosis, I don't plan on taking meds.  Adderall wouldn't work for me because for some reason I don't like the thought of not being like this for too long, which eliminates extended release, and I need to be able to focus and do work throughout school, which likely eliminates instant release. And, Ritalin apparently puts you in spectator mode.
Medication isnt the right fit for everyone! It's important to listen to your body - and in general with ADHD meds stopping cold turkey is totally fine! My psych often encourages "drug holidays" where if I want I can just not take my meds on the weekend, on vacation, etc. she encourages paying attention to my body, mood, and patterns, and taking or not taking the medication based off my preference. Some days I wanna just be chill and distractible haha.  However, I do want to add - it can take some time to find the meds and dose that work for you; there's more options besides the two you tried, and it sounds like your vyvanse does was way too high. If anyone else is trying to figure out meds, communicate regularly with your med professionals and be patient with yourself ü©∑

Just call your pharmacy if your having side effects and are unsure about if it's safe to stop or not. They aren't doctors, but the pharmacist can inform you of any risks for stopping a medication early. There are some psych meds, and even some ADHD meds that you DON'T want to stop without tapering off so it's usually safer to ask someone with experience to be safe.

Sir, you are changing lives. Thank you for this.
I have been taking ADHD medication for nearly a decade now, and I can say from personal experience, it takes about 5 years to find the right combination of medication that "clicks" for you. Having a psychiatrist who can help you develop your treatment plan is crucial to finding the right medication, or balance of medications that works for you. Medicine is trial and error. It's takes time, patience, and unfortunately money...  I am currently taking Methylphenidate and Atomoxetine to manage my ADHD. Atomoxetine works in a completely different way from Adderall. Atomoxitine inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine, where as Adderall just increases amounts of norepinephrine in the brain. Essentially, Atomoxitine makes more effecient use of the norepinephrine, thus helping to regulate neuron synapses better. Atomoxetine is also NOT A STIMULANT, so it's great for people who have horrible side effects from stimulant medications, or a history of substance abuse.  I hope all of this was helpful, and I hope all of us will one day be able to receive the care that we need for our brains so we can live our best lives!

This is pretty much my own experience... (I've been medicated on Ritalin/ Methylphenidate and actual Amphetamin...) Some of the meds work really fine to gain motivation and focus, but I also tend to laser focus on the wrong/ or simply irrelevant things... and then after a while I also feel like the medication is draining me. Amphetamin was better then Methylphenidate for a while, because Methylphenidate seems to also cause or intensify social anxiety or isolation. I also stopped taking the meds. At the moment I surrendered in a way... I spend my days just doing whatever comes to mind... but I realized that I can really get things done at night. When the lights are off and everyone else is asleep and I don't get messages or calls all the time I can really focus on important tasks and work stuff much better. Youtube is still running on a second screen all the time, but I can get things done, when the day is through.

The benefit of ADHD is the true ability to multitask and split attention. Probably why it naturally survives as a condition similar to psychopathy. Instead of focusing on one thing, do multiple always. The problem with getting medicated after adolescence is that you've already habituated bad behaviour, so while the meds can take an edge off the symptoms, you will default to the bad habits you've built. The meds don't fix you're problems, they just open the gate to being able to fix them.
For my ADHD, I take Foquest. It definitely feels similar to Vivance (and if they are the same thing well, my knowledge on pills is practically non-existent) I find that if I take my pills to early then I'm immediately expected to learn something and have it stick in my brain, my brain just goes 'sorry kid, we aren't keeping this info in here' when I kinda need said info to stick. And once I'm doing something I enjoy, like drawing, I can sit for hours getting a drawing JUST how I want it and all of a sudden its like 8pm when just a few minutes ago it was 6pm or 1pm. Give me something that I enjoy doing when I'm medicated and time seems to fly by.
there actually isnt much litterature that says its necessarily bad to skip meds some days, some people just take it as they need, some studies even suggest cycling throughout the week can have better effects, and some neurologists support this, but its still not researched enough to say conclusively, my psychiatrist just said to take it as I see fit, with prescribed dosage obviously.
1 year later and i still miss that cow
I noticed that medication by itself is significantly less helpful than medication in conjunction with self discipline. With ADHD, every day is like a SNES Mortal Kombat fight on ultra-hard, but with no lifebars so the harder you try to keep yourself on-task, the more you exhaust yourself so you just learn to give up. Giving up becomes a habit and because you know that you have a diagnosis, you fall into the groove and start allowing progress to be someone else's responsibility. Adderall, specifically, was an interesting experience, but it works well for me because I actually find joy in what I do. What I decided to do for myself is give myself unproductive days, which is where I don't take meds in exchange for productive days, where taking meds becomes a promise that I will complete a specific task. Once I complete the task, then I can goof off. Adults are still kids in a lot of ways. Our behaviors are still improved with guidance, but because adults don't have adults, that guidance must come from the adult you make for yourself.

In. My years of watching YouTube, I have never seen a youtuber say to unsubscribe. You are the first.
This was super helpful for me and I‚Äôve revisited this now, especially as I‚Äôve now trialled a few different types.   One thing to mention is that adderal and vyvanse have dexamfetamine in them, which not only keeps more dopamine and norepinephrine around in your synapses (as does methylphenidate or the brand name Ritalin), but it actively pushes these out. You get more focus, but potentially more side effects (I did).   So if you ever wanted to go back to meds, maybe Ritalin or methylphenidate is a final one to try?
I describe the Vyvanse experience to my friends who have been on it for less time than me as "Latching" it's like a ritual of learning what to do in the 30 minutes-1 hour leading up to the start of the effects in order to optimize your day.   I started assigning myself more nebulous tasks to focus on, such as "do chores until these 2 YouTube videos (usually like 1 1/2 hour podcasts or something) have finished." Then I start the task like 5-10 mins before the meds usually kick in and then I'm able to kinda game the focus by making it about doing as much as possible in a predefined duration rather than trying to think of things on a task by task basis.  That way, all my productive tasks are latched onto the YouTube videos rather than being independent things for me to hyper focus on.  Works pretty well for me, it's a weird thing to explain so I hope y'all are able to get it with the example I gave! ADHD meds are just generally super flexible and feel like they need the right mindset in order to get the most out of them.

from my experience this is wrong, it's not a bunch of people talking in your head, i feel like this is a massive misconception with people diagnosed with adhd that shouldn't be.  like said below tangents are the real scenario, i could never stay on topic when my brain was relating so many other things to the subjects that have sometimes very little in common yet i would find an avenue to relate them, making it very hard for the people around me to understand my points. intern making me very frustrated.  It's important to know, if you didn't have any symptoms as a child, there's a good chance you have developed ADD from things like social media, and i truly believe medication is not right for these people, and is making their development even harder on themselves.  If you did things like leave all your homework until the last day or never did it at all,  were constantly out of your seat, trying finding something that interested you rather then the bland sheet of paper Infront of you, but excelled at sports that is a good "indication" you have it.  something i don't see talked about very much is smart phones, using a smart phone is almost unbearable to me because of the million different functions and apps so even at 30 with 12 years of experience with smart phones i find myself getting lost and frustrated looking for apps/features that i must use for both work related task and leisure.  although i am on the "severe" side being kicked out of multiple schools when i was younger, i think this is one of the best indication you have adhd and should be more researched because i see this quiet a lot with people that say they have adhd yet can know where everything in their phone is before they even unlock it, and claim medication isn't working for them, that is absolutely unfathomable to me.

Honestly I miss my medication but I don‚Äôt miss the sideeffects. They were highly unpleasant and painful even. And they put a serious strain on my heart, so my psychiatrist asked me to stop taking them.
Way too much focus with vyvanse and those unwanted and unbearable side effects, also being stuck in doing the physical and less cognitive intensive tasks with adderall.  Those things are literally the most common and most easily noticeable effects of ‚Äúhigh dosage‚Äù. You just needed to adjust your dosage. Also you can try methylphenidate based meds because they‚Äôre only dopamine reuptake inhibitors instead of being dopamine reuptake inhibitors and causing your brain to produce more dopamine at the same time lime amphetamine ones  (adderall, vyvanse etc.)   In this way, you get to focus not everything but the things that you usually find very boring and actually necessary to do.  Don‚Äôt give up on meds just now. Talk to your doctor and adjust your dosage. If that fails too, try methylphenidate based meds. If even that didn‚Äôt worked, try atomoxetine based meds. I found out for me the best combination is methylphenidate & atomoxetine.  If none of those works for you, drink green or white tea. (White tea is the same thing as the green tea but it‚Äôs way more pure and pristine so I would strongly recommend white tea.)   Also the side effects that are comes from any types of stimulants, green or white tea is the best solution I‚Äôve ever accorded by now. The best solution that doesn‚Äôt effects the drug‚Äôs intended effects and reduces the unwanted side effects significantly.   Also don‚Äôt use any of those drugs while your stomach is empty. Always try to use them after a meal. Drink a lot of water. Also one of the most important thing if not the most important thing is working out while you‚Äôre not on meds or when they wear off like in the morning or before bed.   Those are mostly the recommendations for a healthy body but believe me they‚Äôre directly effecting the drug‚Äôs activity and efficiency in your system I mean I‚Äôm not trying to tell you that you need to get healthier, no. Those are the things that I tried and worked like a charm for stimulants.  While on stimulants, keep your limbs warm, try to not too much caught up on your phone or pc. I mean go and walk around a bit, maybe do some in-place running (it‚Äôs just running without going anywhere)  Don‚Äôt forget to move your head, look anything else but screen in every 10-20 minutes, especially outside will be nice.   The main purpose here is to get your brain comfortable and make your bloodstream healthier.

I have severe adhd, my medication is dexmethylphenidate, it might help you.
ADHD just makes you more energetic as a child (age 5 - 11) before your brain starts to mature and you hit the teenage years, I was diagnosed with ADHD when I was 5 years old.  I‚Äôm 13 now but seriously, why do people think that ADHD is on par with autism or chemo or even schizo?  It‚Äôs probably because many people with those disorders or disabilities are represented horribly and or, made fun of.  I was actually kinda mistreated in first grade, I spent half of the year in the principals office, they simply labeled me as a ‚ÄúBad kid‚Äù.  They also tried to hold me back in the first grade (keep in mind, this was before I was diagnosed with ADHD).  Though, when I was put on medication, I immediately became a strait A-B student with excellent behavior. (This wore off when I started going to middle school).  Also, ADHD doesn‚Äôt make your IQ lower or cause hallucinations like schizophrenia.  you should treat people with disabilities especially better than those without since I‚Äôve met many people who‚Äôve had Down syndrome, autism, etc,.  Let me tell you, they were the kindest people you‚Äôll encounter, takes patience but if you‚Äôve got that then you‚Äôve probably got someone who‚Äôll stick by your side forever.  Another side effect of having it is that whenever something that bores you such as having to go to school, causes you to become hyperactive like bothering your peers a lot or spinning in one of those office chairs.  I remember the last time I had a serious school meeting (3 weeks ago) I could NOT stop spinning in that office chair, I was also taking tissues and tearing them up into little pieces. My mother had to tell me to stop spinning in the chair thrice since she was also attending the meeting.  ADHD also causes a situation where if you‚Äôre interested in something you become hyper focused on it, it‚Äôs like playing a video game or watching a move, the whole point is for you to..  1. Like the content you‚Äôre viewing (Movies and Games)  2. Focus on said content.  3. Not feel bored by it.  And that‚Äôs it.  ADHD can also affect your attention span significantly, and it can also lead to you being less organized than the average (American) child. (I‚Äôm saying that because I know that there are different averages for different countries and ethnicities).  Example: When I was in the 5th grade (We would store items in our desks and stuff but the teachers would have this annoying pattern where they would say ‚ÄúOkay let‚Äôs do this assignment‚Äù then strait after 5 - 7 minutes they‚Äôd say ‚ÄúOkay class now that you‚Äôre finished, put this assignment in your binder and we‚Äôre going to do another.‚Äù   Rinse and repeat, I obviously didn‚Äôt like it so I just shoved the papers strait into my desk to fetch them later.  Sincerely‚Ä¶  -Someonesaltaccount
Funilly enough it was kinda the opposite for me. When I first started my medicine I got super sick. The first day I slept all day, completley unable to stay awake for more than an hour. But still, something compelled me to continue trying, to stick with it. Over the next few days I would start slowly feeling better until my body had adjusted to the medication. When I looked it up apparently a lot of people go through an adjustment period, mine was just on the more severe side of the spectrum. Anyway, about a week after I stopped feeling bad  I gained the sudden, slight ability, to just....do things. If one task is related to another instead of bouncing around I could just *do* the next task. It's not as effective as I would want it to be but it gives me hope that my symptoms might actually be controlled on another medication. I still have a lot of fatigue, and I have a suspicion that it might be the meds, but we're investigating that.
I am currently using Concerta, which does help me. But previous meds have made me lose hunger so we had to find the right one! Not pushing meds onto you or saying you shouldn‚Äôt do it, I‚Äôm just sharing my story

I have AuDHD, or a way to say Autism and ADHD at the same time, and the things you felt taking the 5-Ants medication is normal for me. I started to take lowest the dose of Ritalin after being diagnosed at 30. Its been like 10 pills, and the learning curve is steep. I can DO STUFF and switch tasks, completing them that day, but creative thinking is shot, and i cant sleep after it wears off. It turns off my ability to zone out, which is how I do creative work and how i relax.  ADHD is fuckin weird. People often dont get it because "how can you not make yourself do things"...
Here is my take on this topic: ADHD is not an illness, you are not sick, stop the self pity journey that will lead you to believe you need a magic pill to be finally free from the chains of ADHD, its a neuro divergence, you are as capable as the next person, we are just not suited for the ideal version of the modern man/woman. My experience with ADHD is this: I have always been different but my parents never considered taking me to a doctor, I was just ‚Äúweird‚Äù but extremely gifted in some areas such as math, building or logical thinking while I struggled in social interaction and making friends. I had to learn how to drive my car. I finished med school with good grades and plenty of recognitions, just after finishing med school i had the money to start medication on my own, i take medication because i like the feeling of a ‚Äúquiet mind‚Äù, it helps me in my journey of self improvement, however when I dont take the medications i dont feel like a monster is coming to get me, its just me. The same me that I always have been and the same me that got me to this point in my life. Keep calm , learn how to sort the challenges of life with the tools you were given.
I'm taking Atomoxetine right now. Hopefully I'll be able to feel better in the next month when it actually takes effect but it's supposed to do what adderall does but more gradually, naturally changing your serotonin and dopamine levels over time so that you can feel "normal". I pray it works well.
Fellow ADHD person here. Have been on both Adderall and Vyvanse. If you are reacting like that to Vyvanse, go and get your heart checked out. My doc did a full cardiac check before I went on it because if you have some sort of heart condition, it can cause issues exactly like you described.
I tried Vivance and it made me feel like not me anymore. I got so used to the routines I built to account for my ADHD that not needing to do those routines anymore on the meds threw me off so I stopped. Meds are advertised as a cure all a lot of the time and they really aren't.

Not lost on me: The irony of how many times I've had to rewind parts of this video because I've drifted off to thinking about my own experience with ADHD. I'm 2 minutes 10 seconds in. I'll just go pop the pill rn.
Vyvanse onwards part is how I am daily *facepalm* (I'm medicated on it), really need to get better at realising where my attention is directed in the moment.  ON BREATHING ISSUES: I have experienced something like that at times, but never linked it to the medication as it came in much later. The breathing issues would come when I had been my most physically inactive and sleep deprived, and after getting back into basketball its gone away completely even when lacking sleep. Something to exercise the respiratory system was the thing that worked. I was doing bouldering and weight/resistance training while the breathing issues were occurring, and though my heart would be beating hard at times from the effort exerted, it didn't exercise my lungs enough. So if you want to get back on vyvanse, try doing a cardio-intensive hobby and see how you go. Cardio is much better for adhd-brains as well when it comes to maintaining focus!

Vyvanse felt to me like life's difficulty went from hard to normal. For me the first days gave me a headaches and dry mouth, but it goes away. Now If I go a few days without it it's like the world turns into chaos. I've been recommended to take them every day, even on days off. It make a difference even doing small chores. You think "I should probably do these dishes and pay this bill" and you can just go ahead and do it instead of agonizing over it for days. It's kind of weird to say this but after 15 years in the same job feeling like I was just buzzing around putting out fires I finally found what might be my professional calling. But it's true that you still have to steer your attention, and it helps a lot to build self-knowledge through counseling or whatever works for you. ADHD usually brings along other problems, like anxiety, depression, personality/emotional disorders etc. Especially if you were diagnosed as an adult.

But yeah you build resistance to it and then, it becomes less effective. It‚Äôs better to do it raw and through sheer will power train yourself to focus.
Absolutely do NOT stop long-term medication cold-turkey. Sometimes it's fine. Other times your body freaks out and you have to go to the ER. It depends on what you're taking but every person is different too so it's hard to predict which is why doctors will generally tell you to reduce the dosage gradually before stopping.
I currently take vyvanse and I relate to a lot of what you said about them except for the part where you said "if the meds make me really focused but focused on the wrong thing, they're not working" I belive that the medication is working just as it's supposed to, we just never built the habit of resisting certain things because before the medications certain temptations were practically impossible to resist. What a lot of people don't realize is there are certain things that are now possible with the medications BUT you still have to build the habit for it, which was impossible before. This leads people with adhd to believe that the medication is not working when in reality they just need to put the work in. I know many people with adhd get tired of people telling them to just work hard but with the medications that really is the answer. People with adhd are so used to things either being possible or impossible that once they start medicating they think the medications aren't working because they don't know what it feels like to have a normal range of difficulty and thus don't realize that's what they've unlocked with the medication. Put simply, the medications don't suddenly fix your focus or stop your never-ending train of thoughts, they just make what was previously impossible to learn possible but when you've only ever know that thing to be impossible, it's hard to know what to do next even when it is now possible

I hope this helps someone the way its helped me. I take Methylphenidate (Ritalin) and I find it helpful to take it 30mins before I wake up. I set an alarm, take the pill, go back to sleep and then when i wake up its starting to kick in. It makes it easier start a task mid spike rather than switch tasks mid spike. Something as simple as sending a text or cooking a meal when it starts to kick in can through the plan off. But if you wake up with it already working in your system, you have no ongoing task to pry yourself away from.

About the thing with Adderall making it only easy to do physical tasks: an organization system really helped me with that part. One piece of paper for every project.
So here's the thing about the meds he took: Adderal is a racemic mixture of amphetamine including the R (dextroamphetamine) and S (Levo amphetamine) steroisomers. Like your hands these molecules are mirror images of one another without being super imposable. It's basically speed.  Both the S and R increase the release of dopamine.  They both also increase the release of norepinephrine or noradrenaline which makes you more alert and is typically released in high doses during stressful situations. Levoamphetamine (Cydrill) however releases 10-15 less dopamine compared with the same noradrenaline release in Dextroamphetamine. In other words, to achieve the same amount of dopamine release with levoamphetamine you will have to increase the noradrenaline release 10-15 times more than if you used dextroamphetamine.  Vyvance is is lisdextroamphetamin. It's a prodrug which in the body will become dextroamphetamine. It is what's called enantiomerically pure. There is only the R enantiomere in it and no S enantiomere.  If you want to try a medication that isn't amphetamine for ADHD consider methylphenidate. If I remember correctly research suggests that about 50 percent of people respond about equally well to both amphetamine and methylphenidate (Ritalin). Another 34 per cent responded preferentially to one or the other and 16 responded well to neither.  Research suggests it is better to start with methylphenidate in children and with amphetamine in adults. That maybe why he was put on Adderall first.  I just wanted to note there is a different drug that could very well help.
I wanted to finish the cow video‚Ä¶üò¢
I just got diagnosed with ADHD at 41 years old. I was taking 15mg of Adderall at first, but didn't feel much different. Now I just started taking 25mg and I totally feel that "ability to be able to" now. But I also have improved ability to focus (possibly too much at times, like you mentioned with the Vyvanse, but it hasn't been too disruptive so far). The one thing it hasn't helped is my short term memory issues. Gonna talk to my psychiatrist about it at my next appointment in a few days. ADHD is complicated! Plus I also have anxiety, depression and cptsd... yay... lol... Hoping with therapy and behavior training, I'll be able to get off all my newly started meds in a couple years, but we'll see.

I'm on ritalin for my ADHD personally, it sounds similar to both adderall and vivance described here like its a mix of the two, I can do the things but I have to make sure I'm focusing on the right thing when the meds kick in and there's no interruption. It probably saved a lot of my grades last year from being barely above not failing. I still have the constant train of thought, that train ain't stopping anytime soon, but at least I can do things and maintain focus on the things. Real story, first time I took ritalin and that day I decided to play Stardew Valley, normally I used to only manage 3 or so hours before my interest wore off. Suddenly that day I realised I'd been playing for 8 hours straight and I didn't even fucking notice.
I watched this before I got my medicated, now that I am it has been a big difference, from my understanding Adderall and vyvanse are basically the same thing, key difference is that vyvanse metabolizes into the drug, it needs to process it then it becomes the same drug as Adderall, making it hit slower and evenly. I never had Adderall but I switched to vyvanse from concerta, which is way more different to vyvanse than Adderall, its interesting to note how surreal it is and how the descriptions he made made a lot more sense after I was medicated myself, but also I get major differences, assumabley cuz nobody ever experiences the medication identically anyways, but also cuz I'm autistic

I will say, the thing about ADHD medication is while it definitely helps with keeping on task and focusing, the whole executive function, it doesn't help with discipline. And discipline is also needed, and is what keeps you doing the right things, and forming good habits. Idk who told you that vyvanse was more ''mellow'' it's a different version of the same drug as adderall. That doesn't mean it won't feel or work differently, but they are both made up of dexamphetamine. All I'm saying is that being scared of the idea of a ''drug' often gives people space to spread misinformation and lead you to try other things out of fear rather than, it actually being a good idea. Talked to my psychiatrist and I just started concerta which is a stimulant and holy shit it was so life changing. Tried ADHD meds a couple times. Never had any effect. Don't know if I just don't have ADHD, or if I'm just difficult to medicate.
I started with Concerta and that made me function normally - on a focus base. I had pushed things ahead of me for months, the first day I took Concerta I... just did it all. No distraction, no other thought, just "I need to do my taxes" and 2 hours later the taxes were filed. Unfortunately my heart does not like Concerta, which is why I am now  on Medikinet - appartently that's really similar to Concerta, but comes in far smaller doses. I use Medikinet 5mg in the morning of workdays and over the weekends I go unmedicated to give my heart a break. I would need at least 5 times the dose to achieve halfway normal function across most of the day, but this is what I got and it is SO much better than nothing. That has been working nicely for months now and the first PC game I am developing has become playable this morning. (Still very rough, but I was dancing - at 6'4 and 250+ pounds that would have been a sight if I didn't live alone).

Dont get me started on habits and sleeping. Some people will say, coffee does not work on me. Then every morning theyll drink a cup of coffee, every afternoon drink coffee to fight feeling tired. Its normal to feel tired. Then guess what? youre up all night again and still didnt get any sleep. Trying to fight something as natural as, ‚Äúbeing tired,‚Äù is like trying to tie the sun down because it is shining too bright too early. ITS NORMAL TO FEEL TIRED.    Drink decalf coffee if you like the taste, or drink half calf coffee. Very light coffee as well. This ties into what I said about trying to fight your natural ‚Äúracing thoughts.‚Äù
People are so dellusional. You can be functional and have focus with ADHD. Like any mental illness, if you sleep, exercize, eat right and drink water‚Ä¶ your symptoms are manageable. So many people are convinced that medications are the answer. If you sleep, (which can be difficult) on-time everyday, then you can manage.   One thing someone has with ADHD on their side is alot of energy. So you have more energy then the average person. Use it. Stop throwing the term dopamine out there like that is whats the problem with ADHD. Dopamine is a natural hormone. We may secrete more with ADHD, just the same as we may sweat more. Everything is in excess with someone with ADHD.   Theres also a difference between ADD and ADHD. It seems you were experiencing ADD, and not ADHD . ADD stands for attention deficet disorder. Its different in where hyperactivity is not involved . Hence the term ADHD, which stands for Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder.   Lumping in ADHD with the fact that you may be a heavy procrastinator is absurd. An issue like ADHD is manageable without medications and does not mean you procrastinate.   The only thing accurate about this video is the mind racing aspect. For racing minds you need to let it run its course. Fighting something that your body does naturally is horrible for it‚Ä¶ especially your brain.

Ive been on vyvvanse since i was 10 im 30 now
So my experience with ADHD meds has been unique (like I'm sure it is with everyone, but stay with me).  I have the inattentive type, but strangely my ability to focus wasn't my main issue. Sure, I have trouble focusing on things that I'm not 100% into, but there are things that I can spend all day doing and my mind doesn't wander.  Anyway, it's more like my brain is a bee hive. My thoughts are always super disorganized, I'll set something down and immediately forget where I put it, etc. I started taking Adderall XR about a month and a half ago and my mood and my ability to organize my thoughts has significantly improved. I still forget where I put stuff all the time, but retracing my steps has become so much easier, so when I do forget stuff it doesn't take as long to find it. My 90 day follow-up is in December and we'll either increase my dosage (which is already 40mg, so idk if that would be safe to do) or look at potential alternatives. Trouble is, i don't have insurance, so my meds are completely out of pocket (thank God for GoodRX), and from what I've been told, Vyvanse is crazy expensive, even with insurance, so who knows, maybe we'll try Ritalinü§∑

got an adhd medication ad on this
ADHD diagnosed in adult life is not just neurodevelopmental disorder you can fix by talking meds and it will magically put you in the right path. When you are high functioning person with ADHD and you never knew that's the case, it usually means that during your course of life you learned to function certain way to compensate for the limits of your brain you didn't even fully understand. For the most part it's exhausting and shitty way to live, but it's the only thing you would know at the time and it helped you through school, your job etc. The meds will give you the ability to live differently and reprogram your shitty habits, but you still need to do figure out how to do it. It's like when you have poor eye sight and you finally get the glasses - they will allow you to see, but won't teach you how to read. First you need to find out the meds and the dose that make you feel content, reduce the noise, and help you focus and function with chill. Then you find the therapist that specialize in ADHD with courses including stuff like organizing and prioritizing tasks, avoiding procrastination, fighting the impulses. You need to learn how to function properly so you allocate your new cognitive resources where they are the most needed. Some people manage to sort their shit out so effectively they no longer need meds on the daily basis.

Polish cow.
The ADHD meds you took use amphetamine as the active ingredient. Some people respond poorly to amphetamine medication in the form of constant hyperfocus, rather than having the ability to direct focus willfully with little effort. The really worrisome part is getting cardiovascular effects, like that fatigue, high blood pressure and accelerated heart rate.  You might need to consider a different kind of active ingredient, be it methylphenidate (Ritalin, Concerta, Focalin, Foquest, among others), or one of many non-stimulant compounds suitable for ADHD treatment (guanfacine, clonidine, atomoxetine, bupropion, viloxazine).   And thirdly, there's emphasizing non-medication options, with the caveat that applying these will take a lot more effort and may require some amount of support from others.
I recommend concerta! It‚Äôs helps me focus, get tasks done, sit down and work and pretty much function like a normal living being

As someone who is AuDHD, i loved hearing about this. I have also tried both Adderall and Vyvanse, and both worked for me, just in different ways. I, possibly unhealthily, really felt like Vyvanse worked for me and (this is the unhealthy part) liked how much of an appetite suppressant it was, even at a low dose. However, there was a biggums shortage and everything was backed up so I decided, lets switch to Adderall and hope that works. It did, just not the same way. My productivity increased, but my motivation didn't. I found myself completing more tasks but, yeah the whole sitting down and thinking really hit me and i hadn't thought about it like that until now. If anyone reading this takes something from it, nto all medications are going to work the same way for two different people. Even if you and another person think similarly (like a friend whose always on the same wavelength) your chemistry brain and body-wise will ultimately differ. If a medication doesn't feel right for you, please reach out to your doctor with your concerns and about what to do going forward.
To add to Ice's point about not waiting until it gets really bad: Don't just stick with the first psych you get if they are not the person for you!!
