Complete nonsense. Psych drugs royally F'ed up my mental health, physical health, and life. I booked a psychiatrist because I was sad about my life circumstances of which I convinced myself I was "depressed". I go on Nardil, and it induces a never before seen in 35 years full blown mania in me. Then because of the adverse effects of Nardil, they diagnose me with bipolar. Then I go on other drugs that screw up my memory, and of course I convinced myself now that I was bipolar and depressed. Then I had to switch psychiatrist, and the new one says I have ADHD. Then I get addicted to the adderall, and next thing I know, I am prescribed 60mg daily of instant release adderall. Then I go into a drug induced psychosis for three years, become homeless, get arrested, get hospitalized, lose jobs, and my whole life is completely destroyed and irrecoverable due to my new criminal record. All this happened because I sought help from doctors I thought I could trust, but all that happened was my life was permanently ruined. Now I finally have a clarity I have not experienced in many years, but it is too late. The damage is done.

I like to explain ADHD like when your in a gc with a lot of people and everyone is having a side conversation along with the main conversation and now the text messages start to overlap yours trying to reach the person you're talking to. It sounds easy until someone else's conversation distracts you from yours and suddenly we went from talking about math to what race a calico cat would be if it was human -
During my experience with medicating my ADHD I found it good at first too. I don't remember when I started to take it but I do know when I stopped it changed everything. I was taking Concerta (no I don't know the dosage because it was 14 years ago to this date). I had stopped taking it because it was summer. No more school, but when I went back onto it things started to happen. I lost my appetite, my eagerness, even my creativity and motivation. When I think about it I was different off the mess too. Now my dad said I've been a picky eater but being an 8 years old kid and refusing a slice of pizza was more than enough proof for me. So my dad continues to say I heard it from the side effects the doctor was telling him and thought I was trying to stop taking them until finally we stopped. I regained my appetite... somewhat, my energy was going max overload, and my imagination ran wild far more then ever. It felt like my brain could do 10 things at once but I couldn't focus on any task given to me anymore. Grades fell resulting in me repeating the second grade. I worked hard to focus but every little thing distracted me but that hard work paid off in the end. I still have trouble focusing (I don't think that will ever go away) but I can now control on one thing to work on now. It was a hard up and down hill and struggled desperately so I could get averages of B's and C's. I can now drive too just gotta work on paying more attention on my surroundings. All I'm saying is that if you feel weird after taking meds please consult your doctor. Do not let it wait. Sorry for the long comment. Just wanted to share my experience

My psych started me on Vyvanse, which made me very depressed, only I didn't realize it.  Fortunately, my psych DID recognize it, and eventually convinced me to switch to dextroamphetamine-amphetamine salts.  Which is the generic of adderall, but it's important because sometimes generics have different formulas, and that matters.  Either way, it works much better for me.  I'm still working on training my brain, and I have some new things cropping up that might need addressing, but overall, it's decent.

alright guys about the last part of the video, I'm super glad he made a huge disclaimer about how you're never supposed to go cold turkey on your meds, and even more glad that he didn't get effects from doing it, but as someone who's been through this twice I think y'all need to know how bad it can get  been switching between several different types of antidepressants for the better part of 5 years now, however a failed attempt to slowly taper off them about a year and a half ago led to symptoms returning. now getting back into a different med type brought on side effects that scared me, mostly constant sensation of feeling hot and lethargic, so I didn't wait and cut them off  what happened over the next several months can only be described as torture: the first and most intense symptom was hypersensitivity - EVERYTHING felt like too much, every touch, every sound, every light, it all felt so uncomfortably... icky. then headaches, dizziness, nausea, irritability/aggression, lucid dreaming and nightmares, "brain zaps" that felt like electricity shocking your head and arms, hot flashes, burning sensation in hands and feet, uncomfortable tickling sensation in my legs, and probably the worst of all - an awful burning type of "wave" that passes through your body, mostly along the spine (if you've ever been on the brink of a panic attack and/or passing out it feels EXACTLY like that except nothing happens, it only keeps building up without a release). every online resource told me the feelings should disappear after a couple of weeks, but they only got worse, and a month later my nerves felt so burnt out that even sleeping couldn't help, I was useless, and nobody could help me because physically my body was perfectly fine and no fault could be found  the only remedy to this was to return to my medication and readjust my nervous system, which in itself took at least a month until I could safely say it made a difference. it's been over a year since this all happened and I still feel occasional symptoms on random days so there's no telling if it'll ever go away completely  be careful, y'all, and never go cold turkey
Indeed you might benefit from non-stimulant meds: they work differently but they might also give you side effects. The dose you take must be adjusted, you might need to take it on some days not others, you might also explore other meds which help in combination: my son takes Vyvanse and  Guangacine: vivance will increase your blood pressure and he‚Äôs already got an elevated bp so guanfacine is not only able to lower the bp but also tunes some of his emotional regulation. I too have taken guanfacine at times and it helps with that balance between focus and do the right thing.

For me, I also ended up having to survive unmedicated (failed uni, so it's going well). I initially tried Ritalin, but it ended up making me crash in the early afternoon. Tried taking two per day to strategically keep me at the same level, but all that did was make it impossible to sleep (while also doing nothing for the crash for some reason, it was weird). I was also getting wild mood swings, so I ended up on concerta. Same problem as taking two ritalin per day; I spiked early, it ended up wearing off mid day, but also simultaneously made it hard to sleep that same night. By this point my mood swings were REALLY bad, so I ended up having to take mood stabilizers for two years. I tried a few other meds that I can't remember the names of, but unfortunately due to taking anti-depressants, I couldn't try any of the amphetamine class of drugs. So I'm stuck with the choice of taking the edge off my depression, or taking the edge off my lack of motivation and focus.

I was diagnosed as ADD, but my symptoms as an adult make me realize I might be misdiagnosed ADHD. Can't really afford to go do anything about it, though.  I took many different meds as a kid, none of them worked. I remember Daytrana, which turned my legs to aligator skin lol But the main med I had for ADD was Vyvanse. Vyvanse helped me focus, sure. On everything _but_ work. I ended up hyper focusing on drawing and literally anything but work on the daily. I had no motivation to eat, and I would get absurdly tired when the meds wore off. We decided I'd quit cold turkey in highschool because my mom really disliked the side effects.   Insert me not being prepared to function as my normal self at all. I went from relatively skinny to just barely overweight and -chunky- curvy in a few years because I was so desperate to eat anything. I needed salt, I needed sugar, I needed _anything,_ and my eating schedule got thrown out of whack because I would just eat any food in front of me before lunch because it was too tempting. Any and all focus on both work and drawing left, and my autistic hyperfixation on gaming and transformers returned.   While I've calmed down in the years since, I really hated that feeling of being almost out of control, and being constantly lectured for being incapable if bringing myself to work. I was told my poor memory was because I didn't care about anything, etc.  As an adult I'm tired of forgetting things and feeling like my brain doesn't function, but I mostly have this problem at home and rarely at work.  I want to feel like a functioning person, but I never want to go through med symptoms or the fallout of quitting again.  The overlapping thoughts didn't really bother me until this year when I started having some really unecessary health scares lol. I was fine, but my anxiety attacks and physical symptoms convinced me I was dying.  Other than that, the constant thinking is how I cone up with stories and bew painting ideas, so until this year I had them under control.

idk if you are still paying attention to your comments, but I got you. ADHD meds arent typically supposed to just 'make you focus.' It's a very common misconception because that's how it will affect someone without adhd. If you have adhd, adhd meds help you organize your thoughts. There's so many thoughts going on up there that you cant focus, that's where the meds kick in to organize them for you. They take away the 'cloudy' feeling and it's an unbelievable difference for someone with adhd. It sounds like adderall wasn't that bad, you just have to get going with the work and then the focus will kick in because your thoughts will be more organized. It's just harder to really get started with online activities rather than physical activities.

Adderall is a pretty decent drug, essentially youre trading a couple years of your lifespan for concentration. There are ways to very easily mitigate the health effects such as "medication vacations." Idk, thinking of adderall as street meth is fun in jest, buts its not at all accurate to the actual effect, unless you dose way too high. Just remember that you only need to take it on days you want to really focus in and get stuff done (for example: i usually take mine on the weekends and mon-tuesdays, since thats when im most busy at work usually).

I was in hospital all Christmas and New year's due to my Adderall causing long term pulmonary hypertension - leading to a hole bursting open between the chambers of my heart. This was directly due to the medication causing excess stress on my heart and generalized hypertension.   My blood pressure was 210/160 when I was taken in. I am 24 years old. I now have heart failure and will live the rest of my life with symptoms - why? Because I couldn't accept being my crazy artist ADHD self and wanted to be productive?   I promise you, it wasn't worth it.   The only thing I recommend is trying the medication a few times to understand what it's like to think normally. Then try to mimic that in your day to day life. But even with this there are risks as most ADHD meds are highly addictive.  Please, love your crazy dysfunctional selves. It's not worth shortening your life for.

The greatest creator out there man I need more
Best analogy I've heard in ~30 years with it: Your attention span is like a spot light. Normal people can control the direction of their spotlight as well as change how wide the focus is, broadening or sharpening the beam of this light... People with ADD have a spotlight too but it's direction and focus is not in their control and so it darts back and forth, to and fro seemingly at random.
I also have inattentive ADHD and take Vyvanse. When we started experimenting with it my doctor had me start and a low-ish dose and work my way up, so I tried 20 mg, 30, 40, then 50 over the period of a couple weeks. When I got to 40 I found that it worked, but could be more powerful, so I tried out 50, and felt exactly how you described. I spent three periods of my school day researching how electromagnetic levitation worked. Zero work done. However I only felt that way on 50, so I moved back down to 40 for a while, and eventually gently came back up to 50, with better results. Now I can focus on tasks fine, but without hyperfixating while I'm medicated. Maybe you could try out some lower dosages to see if you still hyperfixate and get those side effects? I say this as a high schooler who's definitely not a doctor or psychiatrist so take it with a grain of salt ig.

It's a habit I've had for as long as I can remember: telling myself a story. it's a story that has always continued, every time I want I add a piece, and I can focus on the thoughts of that story every time I want to fall asleep. When I think of that story I don't think of anything else and strangely I manage to focus on every detail of the environments, faces, words, expressions and movements. Everything else in my daily life becomes so difficult for me to manage, but that story... it gives me relief.

I‚Äôm not a medical professional but for most medications they say ‚Äúif you have shortness of breath‚Äù as a side effect, then to stop taking it immediately. I‚Äôm sure there is some kind of medication out there where it‚Äôs a bad idea to stop immediately (probably diabetic related meds). But for the most part it‚Äôs a smart move to stop taking it and just contact your doctor. Usually you can consult a nurse at the practitioner‚Äôs office who can offer some advice in the meantime.

What‚Äôs the dancing cow song?
Late to the discussion, but I hope this helps anyone stumbling upon it. At 3:57 in the video, they discuss ‚Äúinertia,‚Äù an executive function responsible for starting and stopping tasks. Treating ADHD (with or without stimulants) often involves grappling with this challenge, yet it lacks a distinct label. Instead, it gets lumped under the vague umbrella of ‚Äúfocus,‚Äù which is almost comically ironic. It helps me to think of focus as knowing what direction I need to be going while inertia is my ability to either stay in that direction or change direction as needed. I would guess that OP was dealing with an inertia problem while taking ADHD medication (a pretty common one, imo) where the macro task was "get up and do shit until its done" and they couldn't divert from that. Switching to Vyvanse was the inverse of that inertia - the macro task became "do the thing in front of me until it is done" but both problems are inertia problems. Notably, neither medication were effectively treating the focus problem as I previously defined it, but that is the one area that medication rarely wipes out. Its this area that we usually have to work on ourselves using a myriad of behavioral and cognitive changes, hopefully made possible with the medication letting us actually DO the thing once we figure out WHERE the thing.  When you go your whole life watching how useless it is to know where you need go if you can't ACTUALLY go, you don't exactly build the mental tools required to figure out things like prioritization, scheduling, task management, etc. Every person with ADHD I know, including myself, spent a whole chunk of their life simply dealing with the results of their distractions (for better or worse. This ability to adapt to rapidly shifting directions and following through those changes with little to no planned structure is the boon to balance the curse and would be worth it if our society functioned differently) rather than structuring their future intentions. Medication can be the gas that gets us to GO, but it won't drive the car for us and we are still just as likely to hit a wall if we don't learn how to steer.   Regarding the claim that Adderall is ‚Äòbasically meth,‚Äô it should be noted that Vyvanse is equally "basically meth" since it too is just an amphetamine. Think of it like calling a poodle a ‚Äòdog‚Äô‚Äîbroad terminology doesn‚Äôt mean they‚Äôre all the same. Ritalin by the same logic is "basically bath salts" since they're related in the same way Adderall and Vyvanse are related to meth (as in, technically acting on the same neurotransmitters but by orders of magnitude different in potency, control, and absorption)  Stimulants act swiftly compared to many psychotropic medications, and your body efficiently eliminates them. I‚Äôm concerned that OP didn‚Äôt receive a thorough rundown on safe practices with ADHD stimulant treatment. His later Vyvanse symptoms (though speculative) hint at this oversight. Some providers start patients on slightly higher doses when transitioning from immediate-release drugs to extended-release ones. Vyvanse, in particular, has significantly lower effective doses by weight compared to Adderall XR. My own experience involved going off meds temporarily and then restarting. When this wasn't done, the transition was almost always as jarring as described here and negative side effects were common.  Stimulants weren‚Äôt my sole solution for fitting into society, but they were a godsend for me. It frightened me for a long time because prevailing misconceptions‚Äîfueled by the zeitgeist‚Äîhave created a vast gap between perception and reality. If you‚Äôre wondering why (as I did!), you can attribute it to a small contingent of parents, doctors, and caretakers in the early to late 2000s. They either intentionally overmedicated children or had limited treatment options. Add to that as fuel for a pseudo-satanic panic media frenzy, which led most people to equate ADHD with ‚Äòhyperactive boys‚Äô and assume that medicating them with stimulants was a reckless, cruel, and dangerous shortcut to fixing troublesome asocial behaviors.   With stimulants or without, meds or not, I wish you all the best luck in dealing with the universal human reality of having to drive a water bag made of lukewarm meat using only an unreliable electric soup sloshing around in your skull. You are not, nor ever will be or deserve to be, left to deal with that challenge alone.
It‚Äôs been weird. I have been on and off pharmaceuticals and holistic treatments for ADHD since I was 8. It is a developing science and there are tons of different tools to be able to aid people. For me personally my adhd feels like a separate ‚Äútrack‚Äù in my brain. I‚Äôve got the impulsive adhd line of consciousness that is CONSTANTLY going doing random shit saying random things. But I‚Äôve learned to be able to create another line of thought that IS within my control. It can get a little chaotic as there‚Äôs two lines do thought happening at the same time but it has definitely given me the ability to do the tasks I need to do
Vyvanse is just the prodrug of adderall. It has a functional group (lysine) that makes it inactive, then your red blood cells cleaves that lysine off, and boom active dextroamphetamine
But Vyvanse just breaks down in your system to the same thing (dextroamphetamine) as Adderall. Adderall is 75% dextroamphetamine and 25% levoamphetamine but still, nonetheless, your friend didn't sound very helpful XD. Sorry, got distracted because I'm taking a day off my "meth" meds today

I wasn't diagnosed until my mid to late 20s, and by that time I already had a lot of mechanisms in place.  Adderall works for me, personally, because I'd already thrown a saddle on special-brain, it was just having trouble navigating the less structured terrain of adulthood.  Plus, I already had a long-standing relationship with caffeine which was probably an attempt at unknowing self-medication, so navigating the stronger stimulant was familiar territory.  Note: caffeine is not an effective substitute for actual treatment.  I'm also in that ADHD group that can get sleepy on stimulants.  Sometimes I have a nap after a dose kicks in and if I'm not in bed before my evening dose wears off, I'm going to struggle to get to sleep in a reasonable time.
I got Cognitive behavioral therapy because of the sole reason that meds should be seen as crutches: it's not a fix, it's a tool. You then need to learn how to walk properly with them.

Diagnosed with ADHD when I was 7. Back in the 90s when girls weren't normally diagnosed with it (according to other youtubers, anyways, I don't care enough to fact check, it was just normal to me). My mother had me on so many different kinds of drugs. I even had some that made me hallucinate and a lot of memories I have from childhood weren't real, like being covered in spiders or being attacked by a tiger. Other medication made me a total zombie, hyper focused and unable to think or move or function without commands like a robot and that was her favorite! When I got to be a teenager, the medicine she put me on made me want to off myself. Deeply, dangerously, every hyper focused thought was how to do this action. Finally, I started tossing the pills in the toilet, fooling her into thinking I was taking them. I have never taken ADHD pills since and I'm now in my 30s, married with kids, and I will deal with the symptoms, but I will never subject myself to the horror of medication again. Yes, I'm frustrated with myself a lot, but it's better than what that legal meth does to you! Now my son shows all the same signs, he's my mini me, and I will NEVER subject him to medications. Terrible stuff.

1:07 stop how did you get a video of the inside of my brain????  Edit: Ok wait a minute, after finishing the video, I did not realize ADHD meds did vastly different things. I was started on concerta at age 9, and I continued on the same dose and same med until I was 15, when I finally said "this shit isn't working." So I went back to my psych after 6 years, and we started playing with my meds. We first increased my dose, went from 18mg to eventually 54mg I believe (over the course of a year or so), 54 still wasn't doing much, so we moved to 72mg... and I couldn't handle the side effects anymore (the biggest issue was this feeling that all the thoughts in my head that I didn't have because of them meds hit me at once, making my feel extremely overwhelmed and anxious), so she switched me. Couldn't handle the side effects again on this new med (I don't even remember the name, that was how short a time I was on that one), so she switched me to Vyvanse. I've had the EXACT same experience with Vyvanse. If I'm focused on the right task when they kick in, I'm fine. But if I was playing a video game, researching some random topic, etc. when they kicked in, that is the task I will do ALL DAY (and is happening rn LMAO). I've also had that experience where I can do all the physical things, but find it difficult to sit down and focus on a task that takes brain power and organization.   (Btw, you don't have to listen to any of this next bit, I just like infodumping cuz I have an interest in brains and stuff).  The breathlessness thing could be due to anxiety, because ADHD meds do tend to increase anxiety (in my experience and others I've seen), so it might be worth it to try an anti-anxiety med with it and see if that helps. ADHD meds often increase heart rate, which is why you have to do all that heart testing and bloodwork before you start them, and increased heartrate can manifest other physical symptoms that now make you anxious and further increase your heartrate- So that might be something to look into if you want to give meds another go. There's also non-stimulants, which aren't normally as effective but I don't think they give as much of the heart and respiratory symptoms.  I do recommend executive functioning coaching either way. I started it recently and oh my god- Shit is mind blowing. I've done therapy for YEARS and the past 4 or so years has been primarily for ADHD, and it has not been helpful at all. Most of the time it was like "did you meet your goal this week?" and either "Yes? Good job!" or "No? Dang, better luck then week then," and all the strategies they gave me were the same overused stuff I've heard hundreds of times that don't work ("Use a planner/calendar üòä" "Make a list!" "Clean as you go!"). But exec. coaching is more like "What are you doing well? How can we maintain that progress?" "What didn't go well? What are some new strategies you can use to do better this week?" "What are your goals for the week? How do you achieve them?" and if you can't come up with anything because it feels like you've tried everything, they pull something new out of their magic sleeve for you to try. My coach makes me feel like I'm not failing at anything, even if I didn't finish everything in a week that I wanted to.
I have years of experience with Vyvanse, do not just take it and start watching YouTube, you will become prone to hyper fixation and will not stop watching random slop, you have to start working on stuff while it's kicking in, that way you fixate on what you actually wanted to do and not space flight lol. (proceeds to watch as he does exactly this)

Like if I listen to music while doing two different assignments, I will most likely get progress on both of them if not complete one of em, and worse case scenario I end of scrolling through playlists for a hour looking for new music.

I have autism and adhd and take adhd medication. Mine is a ritalin thats called Methylphenidate.I have had almost no negative side effects since i started. I had a high heart rate a couple weeks ago, but the doctors all said i was fine and it disappeared not long after it started. When i started this medication i noticed i could focus slightly more (not a lot), but i picked up on chores that I‚Äôve neglected for years. This made me very productive and motivated. I'm 44 and finally got my AuDHD diagnosis in February of this year (2024). üéâ   I do not recommend *Strattera.* It was all side effects with little to no benefits for me.  It made me sleepier than I already was, caused bladder retention ( _which didn't go well with being on dieuretics for blood pressure_ ) constipation ( _which at least slowed down my IBS symptoms_ ), and it gave me unrelenting cotton mouth that nothing could alleviate.  *Adderall* at least lets me focus when I need to, and it serves as at least a weekly reset button.  Mind you I'm unemployed, so I don't have to keep too much of a regular schedule, most days, so I'm only taking it on days that I need to attend appointments and get paperwork done.  Your mileage may certainly vary.

ADHD medications can have rlly annoying side effects that can be avoided with a healthier lifestyle, with Ritalin I had problems with breathing and heart pressure, so I started doing physical exercises, and drinking lots of water before taking the medication, and after adapting, the side effects no longer affect me, it is important to remember that side effects can and will be aggravated by a sedentary lifestyle, medications can be very useful if you know how to adapt and balance your habits.

I hate the comparison that adderall is basically just meth, its not. Its far safer than even pharmaceutical grade methamphetamine. Because unlike methamphetamine, adderall is a mixture of amphetamine and dextroamphetamine. Neither one is neurotoxic unlike methamphetamine is. Vyvanse is merely amphetamines with a amino acid tacked onto them which reduces the metabolism of it since your liver has to pry off that amino acid first in order for the amphetamines to do their job.
as soon as you mentioned the concept of feeling like you need to stop but being convinced you needed to continue makes me wonder if it was on its way to making you addicted. i'm on a certain med now that i find it irresponsible to advertise for. it's been doing some good so far, i think. hopefully you either find a way to deal with it or if you try to gamble on meds again, i hope you find one that does you favors.
Medication didn't really "allow" me to focus, but I was already able to focus. I just couldn't focus on things I found boring. Adderall, the medication I took the longest, made it so things were less painfully boring to me so I could do things like school work. Because normally, the boredom of doing something I'm not interested in really is painful in a way. However, adderall also lowers my threshold for interest in things, which is a huge downside. It allows me to focus more on things I'm not interested in, but it lowers my level of passion toward things I enjoy. In other words it made it easier for me to focus and control myself, but harder for me to get excited and elated about things. It even made it hard for me to get an appetite, not because I felt nauseous or anything but just because I wasn't interested in food like I normally would be.

I've had a diagnosis for decades, and have tried every medication under the sun for this. You need to look past the brands. Both of the ones you tried are forms of dexamphetamine. It sounds like you need to try methylphenidate (ritalin is the short release, concerta is the extended release. There are pros and cons to both)  You could also look into altering your dose (with professional guidance) which will change the effect.  Be aware though, that it doesn't matter what you take, you do need to work on building good habits. The drugs are like glasses for your brain. They'll sharpen the image, but you still need to open your eyes. Unlike glasses, you will build up a tolerance to them as well, so even if they work initially, they might stop, or lessen.  The best advice I ever got for ADHD was to stop trying to be "normal" and start figuring out what works for you specifically. Treat your life like a puzzle to be solved, and then solve it! WHY can't you focus? Getting distracted by reddit? Look into software that blocks reddit during work hours. Can't focus in the mornings? Work in the evenings. Etc.  I will scream this bit from the rooftops as well. Struggling to get up on time? DISABLE YOUR EXTRA ALARMS! If you have dozens of alarms set, all you're doing is training yourself to sleep through your alarms. Try getting an alarm radio (or an app) that goes off ONCE, but then plays music. MAKE SURE IT STARTS WITH A DIFFERENT SONG every time. If it's the same song, it's just an alarm tone.   Remember: If you have ADHD, variety is your friend. We crave newness.  Best of luck to whoever reads this
Such a captivating upload.
Ok, I know no one will read this bur here it goes anyway: He took Adderall and Vyvanse which are dexamphetamine and lisdexamphetamine. The latter is a little different because the body metabolizes it into the former over time, which means it's slower acting but at tbe end if the day they are both the same stuff. There are other options and the goal for EVERYONE with ADHD should be to find the right drug for you in the right dosage. You make your life way harder than it needs to be if you go at it without medication. It might take a while until you find what works for you but it is definitely worth it.

Stopping stimulant medication without assistance is fine. The worst thing that happens is a withdrawal similar to caffeine. It's not fun to deal with but it won't actually hurt you like stopping other meds.

Your Vyvanse experience, I had with Adderal. I tell people "it's like a laser, it takes every bit of focus i can muster which is usually spread around, and aims it at whatever I happen to be doing when it charges up and turns on." As you said, if you happen to be aiming at the wrong thing when it does, you'll either be super productive or burn the whole day.  Every ADD brain is a little different. Some are hyperactive, some are not, and some of the meds that address the hyperactivity part will KILL the motivation of someone who is not hyperactive (outside of their thoughts of course), which is exactly what we're trying to fix. Keep trying (slowly, it takes weeks to adapt) different solutions. You sound similar to me, so maybe give Straterra a try.  I just started on it but I've had luck with it at least in the short term. Don't give up!

I really don't think "never ever ever stop taking your meds if you're getting terrible side effects and you can't reach your doctor" is necessarily a good idea. Sometimes you really do have to do that, and in your case you did.  It can certainly depend on the medication, and I'd look up the risks of stopping a particular medication, as it can definitely vary depending on what you're taking but there are often just as major of risks with continuing to take a medication that's hurting you so I don't think "never ever do this" is good advice

Stimulants are different then antidepressants. Stimulants are only in your system for the time that they're "active". Most people should have no issues quitting or stopping them cold turkey, unless you're not taking them as prescribed.
One important thing to note about medication and the unfortunate misunderstanding of being medicated, is it doesn't "cure" ADHD. It makes it easier to manage the symptoms of ADHD.

Been on vyvanse for about 8 years now‚Ä¶ not a doctor of course, but sounds like your dosage was way off, I‚Äôm on low dose now and it‚Äôs a Goldilocks. These types of medications are def. Not a ‚Äúmore is better‚Äù type of thing.  That being said, like any medical situation, medication is simply one part of the equation‚Ä¶ better to look at it as a ‚Äúprotocol‚Äù, a series of things that must be done to be considered it a treatment. The symptoms you described are referred to as Vyvanse crash, it would usually hit around the 3/4 mark of the effectiveness of the medicine. I stumbled on this explanation over on r/ADHD. There's a number of workarounds but surprisingly staying hydrated especially at the time of taking the medication is shockingly effective. Hope this helps.
Without my meds my asshole adhd self comes out, I cannot stress how much that 80mg of concerta helps me be a nice and normal person person!
7:23 Edit: Just noticed this video is a year old at this point. Oh well, hopefully this is still good information for others. You are taking stimulant medication, those usually do not need you to taper off when you have only used it for a little while and even for long term usage, that is not a solid rule as these medications affects individuals differently. I myself regularly take breaks from Concerta, never experienced withdrawals and my GP is fully aware I am doing so. It depends on how well you know how the medication affects your body and I have half my lifetime worth of experience with Concerta.  Non-stimulant medication with the exception of Strattera requires tapering off (Strattera remains in the body for so long it tapers itself off). It is also fully justified when you experience such a bad reaction to the medication like you just did.  ADHD medication should ideally feel like putting on glasses. Glasses corrects your vision, ADHD medication should correct the chemical imbalance in your brain. If you experience bad side effects, you are always better off unmedicated.

As a person with crippling ADHD, both off or on meds doesn't seem to affect me anymore. No clue if my TRD is related to my ADHD, but I'm mad jealous of people who were able to do well in school without any meds, as even on meds it was really hard. I'm even more jealous of people who get to "become a person" or "be happy" after taking a pill. After going through dozens of medications, doctors and treatment since I was 6 (several decades ago at this point), life has felt like a massive unrewarding chore. I know it sounds messed up, but I wish there were more people with my ADHD intensity so I could at least have people to relate to. What a drag.

Concerta gud in right dosis
Some unsolicited advice:  I took the exact same path as you and ended up giving up after Vyvanse made me feel like garbage for 2 months straight before cutting cold turkey. I didn't take meds for YEARS after that.   Recently I tried again with focalin, and had similar results to what you had with Adderall, so I switched to a non stimulant, called Straterra (Atomoxetine is the generic). Since I have been on Atomoxetine, I have actually been able to focus, but it does require effort. That being said, the impulse control (what you described as not having the ability to control your attention direction on Vyvanse) improved TREMENDOUSLY. I think this is because my ADHD stems from a lack of norepinephrine (what SNRIs like Atomoxetine treat) rather than a lack of dopamine (what stimulants treat). If this sounds like you, I'd highly recommend trying a non stimulant.   For Atomoxetine or Guanfacine, you might have the nausea side effect especially towards the start, or on a dose increase. They say you can take these meds without food or with food, but unless you want nausea, you should eat something, particularly protein or fat rich foods. Also, avoid only dairy/carbs (so no cereal üò¢). Another option is taking it before bed since these meds build up in your system rather than working upon activation, which is also great for ADHD because if you miss a dose it isn't the end of the world.   Also, I highly recommend a timer cap. It counts up in hours and minutes from the last time you opened the bottle. This was really useful for my forgetfulness, so I always know if I did or didn't take my meds.  Hope this helps someone, good luck!
9/11
Here's my experience with ADHD medication. So I've been taking it since I was a kid, and was taking ritalin. At some point they switched me to concerta but I didn't like it so I got switched back to the ritalin.  I'm fine without it if I'm just spending the day doing nothing, but it definitely helps me focus. Without it I'll act without thinking, like using a knife in a way I could cut myself or walking across the road without checking for cars. Also thinking before I speak. On the flip side, when I was younger I tended to be a bit shy so not taking it helped me to open up to new people rather than quietly sitting in the corner entertaining myself. I'm not a very social person.

A tip for my ADHD homies Vyvanse has worked well for me but I've had a similar issue of locking into whatever I was doing when meds peak - I have improved both the come on and come down by dissolving in water and drinking over a couple hours, much smoother and my life has improved dramatically! Water dissolving only works for some meds make sure to check your info pack and talk to your doc.

All 3 of the people in our house have ADHD and take different meds. We also all have different comorbidities. (other disorders that co-exist at the same time with ADHD) I've been on Vyvanse for a few years and yeah, it can lead to hyper-focus. (ADHDers do it naturally if they find something extremely interesting) I highly recommend journaling to get thoughts out. You begin to see patterns and can decide if what you're busying yourself with is important. It can take time to find a med/dose that works for you. Always consult experts, communicate with them as thoroughly as possible, and remember it's your treatment. Feel free to seek out other options and professionals if you're unhappy.

its so annoying when people say "adderall is meth!" This rumor started because the similarity in the molecular structure, the only difference is a methyl group (CH3) on the benzene ring of the molecule.. But it's metabolized completely differently which causes drastically different outcomes physiologically

As someone who has adhd, it‚Äôs really weird when someone talks about how they can do work or get through a lot of boring office stuff and just focus, when focusing for me is like a different colour outside the human viewable colour spectrum, I really don‚Äôt understand what it is to focus on something that I do not enjoy, yes I can sit and play certain games for hours but to focus on something not enjoyable sounds utterly impossible, I can‚Äôt even comprehend it figuratively. That constant dopamine that feeds into me as I begin task‚Äôs is the only motivation that can really let me finish what ever it is. Sometimes even if I enjoyed it at first, I quickly lose that sensation and will give up or walk away 95% percent of the time. I feel like this is the symptom and minuet  detail that separates real adhd and excuse adhd for attention.

The military really helped me. ADHD needs to be corrected very sternly by parents who understand how to shape your brains reward centers, but it just is not realistic to expect all parents to have the time, energy, or knowledge to do that. The military made it impossible to not develop some form of personal responsibility and organization. It wasnt perfect by any means, but after leaving i was able to restart a life completely on my own away from any support network. I working my way up from scraping by at 28 to a boring regular adult life with 3 cats and a girlfriend at 30. Boring is good, trust me. Boring was the goal.   Only after doing all those things did i restart my medicine at 30. You see the benefits so much more clearly when you have a foundation of good behaviors to work off of. Giving this stuff to kids and saying "good luck dude!" is wasting so much potential good. Especially when those kids are thrown into an education system that is barely equiped to handle regular students let alone anyone that slightly differs from the beaten path.

i just didnt skip the add because im tied
This video's direction has been the gist of both peers and myself. Medication gives you a prism to focus all your beams of energy into a single task for focus among other areas but is only half the solution. You must still apply yourself to point this white beam of focused light at the correct tasks. These amphetamines and the sort help here whether your body can facilitate that or not (You will lose a lot of weight starting out if you forget to eat, and will) and you can begin unwraveling your short reward pathways. But you still have to put that work in.  After long enough the imminent rush of taking and of the big three ADHD medications will fade and you will want to avoid going into withdrawal alike those who take it recreationally would also go through when stopping abruptly. Tolerance builds up and you're in a position where your body is now dependent on the medicine to function. Getting up might be harder and you will definitely realize after a very long day of feeling like a sack of tired shit that oops, you forgot to take it that morning as the routine got broken.  Its a choice and can certainly help especially the first few months of starting stimulant medications. But they're easy to abuse and quietly become a dependency fast. There are plenty of side effects including stomach problems and a severe amplification of existing tics or never before seen ticking, extremely dry skin and issues in the 'monthly cycle'. And the worst: Sleep at the end of the day.  They're amphetamines after all (Even Vyvance but the pro-drug you take is not broken down into an amphetamine until later into the blood stream and yes is overall a slower burn through the day rather than having to remember to take say, Dexamphetamine 2-3 times a day).  Most of my peers had to set alarms for when to eat because it stops hunger pain in its tracks. It becomes scary easy to forget to eat for a day or two in a row. You can lose 22 LBS in a month screwing that up like one of my male friends did.  In my case I got medication in my mid twenties after finally giving up on my last crutch to deal with how life was for me. I have them and at this point I would rather live without the many "eyes closed pretending they're not there" side effects. Any day of the week. But going into withdrawal identically to some of the scariest cases I've seen with some old friends who made the mistake of doing real meth, scares me. And while I will never abuse this medication so many people either do or trade it for the scary stuff. While these prescriptions aren't nearly the same dosage as people doing the nightmare of all drugs (methamphetamine, ADHD medication's scariest and most destructive cousin) recreationally I still fear going into withdrawal from my own poor-man amphetamines here prescribed for my brain.  I do not want to rely on these any more than I have to. And I frequently ask my phychologist to let me ween off onto some of the non-stimulating options. I currently take a combination of both and still want off the stimulants. Its barely... BARELY... worth the side effects and the entire benefit begins to fall off by the time a year has passed, but that was always the goal it's not for a high, its supposed to get saturated in your system. That's when the intended medicated change is expected to begin.

if you get on meds, my biggest recommendation is to tell your doctor literally everything. I had every side effect for the first meds that I was prescribed, and instead of talking to the doctor and changing meds, I said nothing. My sleep patterns have still not recovered and I've been med free for 5 years at this point. Also some of the meds can and will turn you into a zombie. If you don't like the way the meds make you feel, there are so many other options available and you should absolutely figure out which one works best for you.

a little advise from an ADHDer who takes vyvanse or like we europeans call it elvanse for 3 years. was 1 year on ritalin, but my body did a weird one and it had zero effect on me regardless of dosage.  only taking the meds will lead you nowhere. the key is gaining the ability to forcefully make you focus on what's important. usually relying on willpower alone w/o any medication does absolutely nothing. at least for me, but the willpower combined with the focus given by the meds works like a charm. with stimulating ADHD medications it's also not a bad idea to skip a day or more. times when their effect isn't really required. I only take them for work or when some social event is coming up but skip an entire week when I have my vacation leave and stay at home during that time. there is a slight burnout feeling on the days I don't take them, but it never gets severe because of these breaks. there is also no shame in using these days to simply sloth around. recharging is important after all and even neurotypicals can only focus so much before even they get tired.   I can't speak from a solely ADHDer perspective tho, because I also have autism and that brings a whole lot of extra influences into the mix. some that are beneficial and some that are detrimental. but and that's just my personal experience, elvanse's focus effect seem to have beneficial effects in regards to sensory overstimulation. with the meds I am capable to partially drown out the noises around me while I'm at work and I work retail, so *much* noise everywhere. the meds were also the reason why my autism was noticed to begin with. not uncommon for ADHD to cover up the autism.

Funny thing is I cold  turkey Vyvanse too
Its crazy how much medication differs for everyone. When I was first diagnosed I heard from others with ADHD they felt like they lost their personality when treated, so I was anxious to start. I started on Ritalin, and it was honestly one of the best I‚Äôve had happen. Then my tolerance started getting higher so I started taking more and after a while, I started losing the motivation for things. Switched to Vyvanse, became depressed and even more anxious for months, waiting for a switch to happen, and it didn‚Äôt happen so I‚Äôm trying to find more information on it before switching again.   And yet the days I forget to have my medication are the most craziest, foggy days I have but I‚Äôm less anxious. I think its finding what works for you - which I‚Äôm still working on.   But basically, don‚Äôt listen to what others say about what medication is good and bad because of THEIR experience, you‚Äôve got to try stuff out yourself and don‚Äôt be afraid! Im glad this guy pointed this out at the start of the video. If you‚Äôre diagnosed its good to try different methods, and I wish everyone luck :)

I have adhd too

Meditation therapy and learning how to retrain your reward system is essential and underrated. I have symptoms of ADHD (never been formally diagnosed) and I personally decided that my symptoms were not severe enough to go through the headache of drudging through trying to find a medication and psychiatrist that fit me. When I was taking medication for it previously, I did not do well with stimulant medication and found myself jittery even with extended release. However, it did give me an important reference to what a calm and focused brain is *supposed* to feel like. Not even joking, I was so used to just passively thinking of things that I had to adjust to the feeling of having to choose what I wanted to focus on for something as simple as thinking about what I wanted to say to someone. Learning meditative thought leading excercises really helped slow my thoughts down a little bit and helped prevent thought spiraling from happening. Having a set morning routine that energizes you also helps wake your brain up to get it going for the day. Don't forget to celebrate when you finish a task and forgive yourself when you end up having an off-day!

Living with adhd is about having good systems.   Be system oriented. Rather than goal oriented. A consistent system is there to be a crutch and renders the goals irrelevant. Bc you‚Äôll most likely be getting 3/4 of the gratification you hoped for in your day.
The best way to describe ADHD, at least my kind, is motivation deficit disorder. Rather than attention deficit disorder.   If I don‚Äôt enjoy something it‚Äôs unbearable. If I don‚Äôt have a routine to manage my time, I‚Äôll get nothing done. If I like something, I hyper focus on it. At least until I burn out.   Sleeping is also hard, so get a daily routine. Otherwise, time management while having ADHD will make your life chaotic and confusing lol.
I‚Äôm the exact opposite, I can‚Äôt function unless I‚Äôm doing two things at the same time, if I don‚Äôt do multiple things at once, then I can‚Äôt do anything ü•≤

Adderall is Amphetamine, and Vyvanse is Lisdexamfetamine. The difference is that Lisdexamfetamine is amphetamine but with some stuff (a common amino acid) attached. Your body breaks this amino acid off, and you're left with the Amphetamine. The active difference is that Adderall dumps all the amphetamine into your bloodstream all at once, while Vyvanse slowly releases it over the course of about 10 hours. This makes Adderall last about 3-4 hours, and Vyvanse 13-14 hours.
I'Ve been taking Vyvanse for over a year now, and you just made me realize what is "wrong" on the days where I can't seem to focus on what I have to do... It puts so much perspective on this matter for me, thank you!!!
Caffeine helps me with my adhd
My own experience with: Adderall, Ritalin, Strattera, Guanfacine, Vyvanse, and now Dexedrine. Yes.  Quite a journey since 2013 - initial diagnosis out of nowhere. If you lose focus on this message, no worries - understandable üòÜ  To preface, I moved a lot so I had various psychiatrists. With Adderall - it was great for a few years! Until it wasn‚Äôt‚Ä¶ When I moved overseas, Adderall wasn‚Äôt available so I switched to Ritalin with a new doctor which did absolutely nothing for me. Moved back to the states & back to Adderall! But then it wasn‚Äôt working like before. My focus was gone, even that burst of energy too. So the new psych switched me to Strattera‚Ä¶which also wasn‚Äôt effective. Next: Vyvanse. It kinda helped..? I was desperate to figure out the med for me, so when I moved again, I switched again under recommendation by new psych. Guanfacine worked better-ish! But I STILL couldn‚Äôt focus. It would make me lethargic through the day so we added a bit of afternoon immediate release. Eh, worked a tad. I started to think my brain was broken. I just needed to FOCUS (& stop crashing in the afternoon).  I had to move overseas again so I had to choose a diff med (not manufactured there, neither was Adderall). But I thought my brain was broken anyway by this point. The limited list had an option I never heard of before & the only one I haven‚Äôt tried. My psych  recommended it immediately - something I haven‚Äôt heard of: Dexedrine. It apparently used to be *the* med for ADHD before Adderall became a household name by big pharma. I‚Äôve been on it this year and I believe it‚Äôs def the most helpful. It doesn‚Äôt give the kick of jittery energy like Adderall but it really helps me focus. It‚Äôs not perfect but it‚Äôs been the most effective in so many years. Bottom line (if anyone is still reading), the ‚Äúright‚Äù meds may take years to figure out. I found out from my current psych that Adderall‚Äôs effects wear off over time. Also, if one psych isn‚Äôt supporting you in the way you need medically, consider looking elsewhere. Best of luck to all you fellow ADHD‚Äôers!

I‚Äôve been taking Concerta since I was diagnosed with ADHD when I was 6, but my psych recommended that I try Wellbutrin (probably spelled that wrong) because it was proving to work well with the anxiety meds I take and help with the procrastination/lack of motivation piece. I tried it at a small dose and it went well at first, but a few weeks into taking it, things went downhill. I became super emotional, moody, and irritable. Even the smallest, most innocent things that people did around me would irritate me, and it was mostly at home when I was the most irritable. I cried or almost cried multiple times a day for like a week straight over really unimportant things and I stopped taking it cold turkey after a month and started back on a low dose of Concerta. This was back in December and I‚Äôve been back on Concerta since January and I feel so much better. It‚Äôs crazy how one medication works really well for some people but does absolutely nothing, or in some cases, the wrong thing, in other people with the same condition.
Adderall isn't meth.  _Desoxyn_ is meth, and it's freaking incredible. The doses are extremely tiny, and the therapeutic dosage is a fraction of the recreational dosage, which means minimal side effects.   When it kicks in, it's smooth as glass‚Äîthere's no sudden burst of energy or rush like there is with most other ADHD meds. Instead, it ramps up slowly over the course of an hour... and you feel _normal._ No jitteriness, no increased anxiety, nothing.   It lasts about half a day and slowly ramps back down.   There's this unique feeling of _alertness_ while it's in effect. You barely get mentally fatigued.  You are capable of doing everything you want to do, although you'll definitely need therapy to help unlearn the maladaptive behaviors from before being medicated.   I could ramble all day about it, but basically‚Äîask your doctor about it if your other meds aren't working.  Be advised that there have been distribution/supply issues for about a year (it's currently Mid-May of 2024), but those should be resolved entirely by this August.

what you describe with vyvanse is basically what having adhd/hyperfixation periods feels to me
Hey, so 40 year old ADHD guy here. Not sure if anyone will see this, but this is what I've found with my long and often frustrating journey with ADHD.  If you have it, your brain don't work like Neuro Typicals. Period. The harder you try to fit your brain into the box that people without ADHD present to you, the more uncomfortable and frustrating that will be.  However, if you try and figure out your ADHD strengths and how to work with how your brain works, it changes a lot. For example, when I changed from a job that needed complex, yet repetitive tasks, to one that required me to investigate and analyse things on the fly, my interest and focus in my job exploded. ADHD types also work well under pressure, as external pressures (such as heavy time constraints or substantial risk) improve our focus and concentration. We also tend to do well with physical tasks. Where we do pretty bad is in self regulation, repetitive mental tasks and little to no time constraints/pressure.  Think of yourself like a dog person. Easily emotional, easily distracted, generally affable. Like a dog, us ADHD types also need to use our bodies a lot. The burst of endorphins from excercise, cold showers and things like that really helps to bring focus in other tasks. If I have admin to do, I often do some exercise first then tackle the task and for some reason, my dog brain is super on board with that.  There are many parts of ADHD that are frustrating, but I've come to realise there's a lot to love. I'm passionate and emotional in a way many aren't, I'm hugely curious and I learn about literally EVERYTHING. That actually works out great for investigative or analysis roles, as ADHD brains tend not to filter out information and look to absorb it all.  Work to your strengths and avoid trying to force yourself to act like Neuro Typicals and your ADHD Dog brain will thank you.
imGINE being 38 and HAVING ADHD..... NO PILLS/// tHIS ME AND IM LAUGINH ME BUTT OFF!
So the sense that the meds were the problem is this weird superpower I've noticed that myself and several other ADHD brains have. We just sort of... Know... What the problem is. Can't prove it. Can't even point to any clues. But our intuition goes into overdrive and we're usually right about what our body needs. It's weird, but also kind of awesome.
Here in Brazil Adderal is illegal. So the cheapest alternative is Ritalin. I've never took Vyanse (or Whatever, we call it "venvanse" here) And you made me keen to trying it. Although, Venvanse is 10 times the price of Ritalin. Because with Ritalin, I also got the ability to JUST DO things, and it works amazingly well when I have a list of tasks to do. It also helps me in class.  The thing about ADHD and meds, is that THEY ARE NOT CURES to ADHD. They should simply be used as tools to make us more productive when we need to. I take my Ritalin when I need to finish tasks, or before class. But eventually you stop FEELING the effect, but I can see it working still.

Okay, so I've gone on a similar journey with my ADHD meds and I 1000% relate to this vid. Only thing I would add is that the meds only hand a couple tools back to you, it doesn't actually *fix* anything at all. Just gives tools which if not used carefully are just as likely to blow back in your face as not. With Vyvanse, while I have the similar pitfalls of hyperfocusing on the wrong stuff, I also find that it's easier to direct myself as I notice the meds taking affect. Ah meds are kicking in. Time to get started on work stuff. Then switch before the deep focus starts up. If you don't go out of your way to take an active role in re-aiming yourself at the right time to take better advantage of the meds, the meds are just the same kind of crapshoot OP talks about. I know from experience, there are a LOT of learned behaviors from my ADHD over the years unmedicated that can be hard to recognize are safe to unlearn while on my meds. For example: without meds, intentionally and effectively directing oneself away from one task and onto another and holding this new point of attention is HARD. Due to years of trying and failing to do this, that train of thought isn't even entertained anymore. Big trick for me was spending time while on meds introspecting and analyzing my own thought patterns to find points of failure like that and realize oh yeah, that's probs a whole lot easier to do while on meds. I should try to time that better. Idk haha personal experience of it xD
My parents eventually just stopped buying the meds lmao

Try Ritalin
I take Wellbutrin now, used to be on Concerta, and a few others that I can't remember. Concerta had a similar aspect that I had to be doing the task I wanted to do before it kicked in in order to focus on it, if it actually happened at all. After an hour into it though I would just be stuck in my head and unable to move my body to DO things. So I had the essay in my head, but not on paper, and I would forget it as the meds wore off. Wellbutrin has a similar focus effect but it's not a stimulant so it keeps me much calmer (and my heartrate way lower) and keeps me focused on things for about 6-8 hours depending on how burnt out the task makes me. All about balance.

I believe I have ADHD and Autism, but I never got diagnosed in school because my parents sent me to a Lutheran school, and they just said I was built the way god intended. I started on Strattera a couple years ago and the very first thing I noticed when I took it the first time was that, about an hour after I took it, the music in my head stopped. I always had a song stuck in my head, literally constantly. It was something I was barely even aware of by the time I got started on meds because it was such a constant in my life. I took the meds and an hour later my brain just‚Ä¶ quieted down. The music stopped. I started following trains of thought from beginning to end. Something I feel like people don‚Äôt really Get with ADHD is that there is no such thing as ‚Äúlimiting distractions‚Äù. The distractions are me. I am the distraction. Because I am a brain inside of a body and the brain is the reason I am distracted. But since I started taking meds, I now have the ability to filter out distractions in my brain. I can hold focus consistently and I don‚Äôt have to struggle through constant ‚Äúlatching onto that thought, then latching onto this one, then getting back on topic, then latching onto a brand new one, wait what was I doing?‚Äù Meds aren‚Äôt for everyone but good lord am I glad that they are for me.

As somebody who has been on many kinds of medication for ADHD before, this is a good video about it, describing the symptoms of executive dysfunction and distractability really well.  And it does really well at going over the pros and cons of various medications.  My only criticism is that I'd call Adderall (methylphenidate) "diet meth" instead "basically meth."  I'm unfamiliar with real meth, but drawing on my own somewhat negative experiences with Adderall, I'm certain meth's more addictive qualities feel a lot more fun.
I remember when I was little they said I had ADD Not ADHD and they gave me some pills for it that did nothing, and they just got me hopping from pill to pill like a lab rat. and eventually put me on anti depressants it was weird but all the pills did was make me feel like super hollow inside, take away my appetite and make everything kind of have no flavor. and to this day the issue kind of persists I can taste things now and don't feel like a shell of a person but never really know when I'm hungry unless I start shaking. this was like almost 20 years ago and I haven't really trusted medications since
me thinking i have ADHD: therapist: oh ye u many have autism. me: o w-what
It sounds like the problem wasn't "the meds were good until it wasn't" and more that you started with meds that worked, didn't increase the dose, swapped onto meds that kind of helped but wasn't actually a good fit.  I was put onto concerta. I was similar where I could get to doing tasks better, but certain tasks were easier than others. I went up a dose, and it helped me with focusing much more to the point where once I was stable on that dose I went from not being able to look for work properly for 8 full months to cracking down and finding a job in less than two weeks. But there were some blood pressure issues due to being overweight, and even when my BP was in safe levels I knew there was room to improve.  And so, last week I moved up to the third dose, and... oh my god. I felt incredible. My blood pressure was stable, my focus excellent but still able to switch tasks, or if I wanted I would spend literal hours doing something which I knew would not be a waste of time, and I felt calm and level-headed in a way where I could see things far more for what they were. Last week I planned my finances for the entirety of the next year, I improved my excel skills, I had incredibly productive debates, resolved some internal traumas, and had a completely seamless shop for work clothes where I went in, saw what I wanted, and knew I would like it.  If anyone reads this while trying medication or wish to try it at some point: If it makes you productive, keep taking it. If you feel like you can do better, go up a dose, and again if you feel one more will help. If all it does is make you lock onto what you are doing, that is not a good fit, nor if it causes other issues.  On that, if you experience side-effects, figure out why and also check your blood pressure. High blood pressure can be felt if you feel sluggish and grotty, or more obviously your heartbeat is harder than normal. If it is your BP but it isn't a dangerous levels, reduce salt intake and exercise more and that should help bring it down. If it's not blood pressure, stop taking the medication, it could be very dangerous to continue, so please speak to a medical professional asap.  Sorry for long post, but hope it helps if anyone needing advice sees it <3

My boyfriend and me are on different ends on the adhd spectrum. Example if you were to give us both a test. He‚Äôd sit there unable to focus and need longer to get the test done. I‚Äôd blow through the test in 5 seconds to do anything else other than sit still. Always start on a low dosage. Be careful of being over prescribed meds because you either don't know how to self evaluate how your meds are working on you or because you have parents forcing you to take the meds and you don't want to take them so you say they're not working. Did this as a kid, I know bad plan but I didn't realize the consequences of my actions. I was over prescribed adhd meds due to falsely reporting to my doctor, I was given way too much and ended up almost killing myself out of nihilistic depression. I cold turkeyed my meds and thankfully slowly got better but not after doing serious damage to the development of my personality and social skills. Now I'm on a low dosage and take as needed mostly only taking it on days when I have to work because of the shortages. Be safe out there, fully communicate with your doctor, these are serious medications

Loved this video when I first saw it, but I want to clarify a bit of misinformation that is often spouted.   Adderall is an amphetamine, but it is NOT meth. The very slightly different chemical composition does a WORLD of difference in how they affect you. Source: professional chemist.

It‚Äôs not fun advice but it‚Äôs true advice/ hands down best and easiest thing you can do to improve focus is 30min silent meditation daily. You don‚Äôt need to stop your thoughts to do this as many ADHDers assume leading them to believe they ‚Äújust can‚Äôt‚Äù meditate. You sit and observe the thoughts without following them (aka being identified with them), it‚Äôs difficult to return to focusing on your breath instead of following the thoughts at first but that‚Äôs why it works - you‚Äôre literally doing ‚Äúreps‚Äù to strengthen focus every time you do. Just start with 1 min a day, then 5, 10, etc. I worked my way up to 30 min in 2 months and have been doing that - with the occasional day it‚Äôs missed - for a year. It helps. A lot.

I was diagnosed with ADHD at age 9. I was medicated until I was 14. I took Ritalin. The issue I had with it was that it killed my appetite for the entire day once it kicked in, and while I was significantly less hyperactive, my focus wasn‚Äôt much better and I was basically a zombie. So my parents and my psychiatrist decided that it would be best if I stopped. I‚Äôve been unmediated ever since. A few years ago, I started taking a supplement called Focus Factor. It‚Äôs relatively cheap and it helps me a lot with brain fog. I find that even though I still get distracted, it‚Äôs easier for me to redirect back to the task I was working on. Plus there‚Äôs no side effects. Obviously this isn‚Äôt medical advice, but it‚Äôs good to explore all the options

Shoutout Strattera. I was diagnosed with Autism and to a somewhat lesser extent ADHD when I was really young, so I was on that medication for years. In my experiences, medications like Strattera worked great when I was young but was something that started basically ruining my life as I got older.  I don't know if anyone else has had a similar experience, but eventually the "focus" aspect that these medications are supposed to help with, led to me intensely focusing on the wrong things, such as what every person thought of me at any given moment, and non--verbal communication cues that I always took as being negative.  Since getting into some pretty rough drug addiction in University I've had to get back on ADHD meds if at a much lower dose, so I think ultimately the strength of a given medication and where your at developmentally play a huge role.
An important aspect of managing your ADHD is using the techniques that help with habit stacking and also eating despite your lack of hunger cues.
I learned how to properly manage my adhd once I graduated from high school. Sure, I kind of hand a handle on it then, but I had other problems going on then. (getting bullied, failing classes, trying and probably failing to practice self care, etc) I haven't taken medication since I was a child, and I don't know what all my parents had tried with me, or for how long, but I assume, considering they refused to put me on meds again, they tried quite a few. Apparently, taking adhd meds turn me into either a raging psychopath or a depressed, self loathing person. Now, I'm happily engaged to the most wonderful person in the world.  If you have adhd, there is absolutely nothing wrong with you. How you want to handle it is generally up to you.

For me, adderall was a game changer. It helped me focus so I could *do stuff* and even helped smooth over my moods too. Not to where I'm a zombie but just...normal. A good normal! My anger is in better control, I can handle hard situations better, and am more aware of stuff around me.
I have inattentive ADHD and, while I can relate to overlapping thoughts and my brain just not finishing thoughts, I find that my biggest issue is the lack of organization in my brain. Like, to remember what 8+7 is I have to dig it out of a back corner in the section of my brain that is devoted to something completely unrelated. I have to rely on very particular processes which are completely inefficient (counting on hands, subtracting 1 from 8, adding 7+7 and adding 1 back on, etc). My parents wanted me to get really good at math flashcards but i couldnt do it because of the qay my brain was processing and organizing information. It makes my ideas hard to express to other people and is like rooting around in a dark basement for something you know you've seen before and can't remember where you left it.
How did they play 8 different trumpets when they only have 5 mouths...
I gotta admit, the best treatment I got for ADHD was cognitive behavioural therapy.  It taught me how to design my environment and make changes to my life that were ADHD friendly and helped me get tasks done. My therapist strongly believed that if you just threw meds at ADHD but didn't provide a base of CBT you'd encounter problems. Like in this video, one of my problems is that my meds lock me into a task like what happened in this video. Also, if I start with a high dopamine task, like a video, I can't switch to a low dopamine task like writing an email. But if I start my day with something low dopamine I can do boring paperwork. So currently I start my day with a beautiful still picture on YouTube with chill music (like lofi) while my meds kick in and end my day with higher dopamine tasks when my meds wear off. Little adjustments like that make life doable. But just being given meds with no additional support structures is horrible

everyone's journey is different; but be aware that there are now non-stimulant ADHD medications like atomoxetine (Strattera), which some (like me) will tolerate much better. they can also be combined with alpha-2A agonists  (like Clonidine or Guanfacine) to treat different aspects of ADHD (such as rejection-sensitive dysphoria), potentially synergizing to enable a lower dose than either separately.  no medication should be expected to "fix" ADHD (it's just how our brains work). that's why it's important to explore a variety of different practical options: and this includes a variety of different classes of medications, and various doses and combinations of those medications.   it sucks that there's not just a one size fits all cookie cutter approach, but holistic perspective and persistence exploring different options can eventually reveal the right therapeutic regimen for a particular individual.
If you ever have to talk to someone about your meds and the doctor or psyche is busy or away, talk to a pharmacist. They have just as much insight about the meds as the doctors prescribing them and can help you when you need answers as well as any doctor.

This video really forced me to look at myself and realize I‚Äôve been so stuck on the fact that they did work and that I didn‚Äôt want to start from square 1 again and I‚Äôve definitely been lying to myself that it‚Äôs fine‚Ä¶. So even though part of me is kind of annoyed that seeing this video is the reason I‚Äôm most likely gonna have to start over majority of me really just wants to say thank you so much for creating this so I can start getting better and I appreciate you sharing your journey. If anyone else is going through something similar after years of success just know there are tons of factors that can cause a change in your meds ability to work for you from environmental changes to hormones to literally just your brain developing more as you‚Äôve gotten older. It's interesting when people compare these medications to meth (it just goes to show the lack of big picture understanding)  Like where do I start, of course they are comparable to meth because the mechanisms of their action are dopaminergic. Wouldn't get sucked into brand names for medications, they are almost all the same stuff, the biggest distinction would be merely stimulant vs non-stimulant / dopaminergic/adrenergic vs other mechanism.  If you want to have some fun, look at the active ingredients of these ADHD medications. Adderall is a ratio of dextroamphetamine & levoamphetamine enantiomers (fun chemistry term) and act on the body in very similar ways - its more just getting a patent and marketing it than anything overly therapeutically useful.  Vyvanse (this allegedly more mellow med in the vid) is merely a much higher dose of Dextroamphetamine but bound with a lysine amino acid so It has to be processed by the liver before it becomes chemically active in the brain. Ritalin (Methylphenidate) is purely a dopamine reuptake inhibitor similar in mechanism of action to cocaine without some anesthetic effects and Concerta is the same thing - just extended release Ritalin/methylphenidate. Don't be averse to ADHD meds because they are similar to illicit drugs, drugs are just chemicals, neither good or bad.   Methamphetamine itself pretty much acts in the same way as most dextroamphetamine active ingredient medications but more or less acts as a much more potent form. Think of it like comparing morphine to fentanyl. They are neither good nor bad because they are just chemicals but one is much more easier to overdo it on because the potency is so much more higher. They more or less bind to the same receptors but one agonizes (activates) better than the other.  Some people like this potency over others and the slight differences in receptor activation might provide advantages over other medications. Don't call Adderall or Dexies meth when its not, call the medication Desoxyn meth, because it literally is Methamphetamine as a Hydrochloride salt. Neither good or bad, just a chemical with some properties.
Someone who can sit down draw this all out and make a video like this does not have true adhd. Neither do so many children that are being drugged with LITERAL METH.

I dont get le ADHD med stuffz I just ‚ú®üçû‚ú®üçû‚ú®üçû‚ú®üçû‚ú®üçû‚ú®üçû‚ú®üçû‚ú®üçû‚ú®üçû‚ú®üçû‚ú®üçû‚ú®üçû‚ú®üçû‚ú®üçû‚ú®üçû‚ú®üçû‚ú®
TO ALL ADHD PEOPLE - IF YOU FEEL BAD ON YOUR MEDS YOU CAN STOP TAKING THEM ON THE SPOT! Those are not antidepresants (those basen on methylphenidate and amphetamine salts). Nothing bag is going to happen to you, your ADHD will just strike back. Those meds work the same way ibuprofen (painkillers) work, you take a dose, it works for a few hours and stops. Of course if you are taking antidepresants (SSRI, SNRI) meds for ADHD DON'T STOP TAKING THEM BEFORE SPEAKING TO THE DOCTOR. But in case of MPH and AMP if you are not feeling well and cannot reach your doctor - just stop taking them üíñ
I've been on Concerta (initially 18 mg, now 36 mg, and on certain *extra neurospicy days* 54 mg) for around 2 years now and in my experience I feel like it's a combination of Adderall and Vyvanse in the sense that it gives me the ability to do things but also the *focus* to do them. Of course, it's not a perfect medication, it doesn't make you automatically neurotypical (not that you should want that), I still have trouble prioritizing tasks and my brain still cannot comprehend structure. One thing about Concerta that I see as an advantage over Adderall and Vyvanese is the fact that you can (and you should!) stop taking it with 0 side effects afterwards as it's very unlikely to cause addiction. Your brain just goes back to how it was before.  And it's actually recommended to take a 2 day break a week to ensure that your dopamine receptors won't get used to that dosage and make it ineffective (consequently needing to increase the dosage).   Having said all that, even with medication, we have to accept that we're neurodivergent people and our brain will always function differently  than a neurotypical's (which isn't a bad thing!!). So there's just gonna be those days when you do everything right and take your medication and still not be able to function. It's very important to know yourself and your ADHD traits in order to understand how to regulate and accommodate yourself,  as well as being able to express those needs to get accommodations for those around you. For me, this is still a work in progress, as it is for a lot of fellow ADHDers, this is just a little bit of wisdom from my 3 years experience with ADHD research, diagnosis, and medication. If anyone wants more information on Concerta and/or my experience on it, I'm very happy to answer any questions I can!ü§ó

With Vyvanse I had to learn two things so far: 1) It makes me more focused and provides constant energy, but I still have to focus on habits and mechanisms to guide that focus. 2) Keeping an eye on proper food and its timing, as well as drinking a metric f*ckton is vital in keeping my body up to speed (pun intended) and the side effects at bay.  So it might be worth another go, with closer supervision and in conjunction with coaching. :)
