adhd is both over and under diagnosed. i would argue that severity of diagnosis is over estimated. if someone has mild anxiety - you start with therapy and life changes. you (shouldnt) throw meds and xanax at them. same for ADHD. poor focus is not ADHD. not being able to pay attention is not ADHD. Adhd is SO much more than that. lifelong, since childhood, struggles. and dysfunction. getting a 98% when you studied hard but wanted 100% is not ADHD. if you‚Äôre getting A‚Äôs all through college and are in a masters program, you probably don‚Äôt have ADHD. it doesn‚Äôt start out of no where. it causes dysfunction (like failing classes), in multiple areas of life. all medications have risks. idiosyncrasies shouldn‚Äôt be treated.

My biggest realisation when I started taking Concerta was that my awful procrastination isn't something that can be fixed with a magic pill. It's a result of ADHD, yes, but it's also a defense mechanism my brain deploys when it thinks a task is going to be too overwhelming with no reward - which before meds was most things that required prolonged focus over a long amount of time lmao. So now that I'm on meds I need to work on showing my brain that I can, in fact, do tasks like that now without it feeling like I want to bash my head against a wall (I also suspect I have autism which probably plays a role lol). Meds give you the jump start, but years of living with ADHD really messes with your brain in ways that aren't necessarily fixed easily :(

Thank you for sharing your experience. While statistically most ADHD people get a lot of help from stimulant meds, there are of course some who don't or find side effects intolerable.  That said...  Taking Adderall is not the same as taking meth. The chemical structures are very similar, but even small structural differences (in this case, a methyl group) can cause large differences in effects.   Also, while I agree that ideally anyone should speak to their doctor before stopping a medication, doctors that prescribe stimulants for ADHD will often tell you that their half life is short and that you can, in fact, just stop taking it if side effects are intolerable. No tapering/weaning necessary.  There are also non-stimulant medications available to help ADHD, for those that are unaware.   In any case, I wish the video creator well in their journey to manage ADHD.

The meds won‚Äôt solve the decision making and planning, they just enable you to actually do the decision making and planning.  If you don‚Äôt have an organisation system, the meds won‚Äôt help that much. As you say, you‚Äôll spend all day doing things you‚Äôre not supposed to, but with focus.  But what they enable is, there are a lot of organisational tools (like scheduling things in the calendar) that just plain don‚Äôt work with unmediated adhd (at least with mine)‚Ä¶ but do work with meds.  So tldr you need both meds and org skills.

i was diagnosed with adhd as a child by like 7 or 8, though i wasnt the one talking to my doctor, my mother was. the problem here was that i DIDNT have adhd, my parents were very neglectful and did not engage with me as a toddler. this can cause the child apparently to develop some of the symptoms that  are exhibited by those who actually have adhd. see i always could focus, and get things done. i just didnt have enthusiasm to things i hated. my first clue was that all the meds i was put on didnt work, first ritalin, then concerta, and finally adderall. now adderall was the longest running because it looked like it was working, however i was just stoned, like a college kid cramming last minute for a test. once i was in high school and on a raised dosage of 80 mgs (thats high af) i was noticing that i was getting high, like i was on two energy drinks. i had not been taking every day obviously because at my core i knew it wasnt working right, but the lower dosages had "mellowed me out" in way so my parents thought it was working. but really i was just stoned. i only had taken it for maybe the equivalent of a year and a alf since i was 8 by the time i was 17-18. i still got good enough grades because learning most things was always interesting to me, especially sciences and social studies. the thing is because i was starting puberty, my deeply seeded psychological issues from my traumatizing early childhood had surfaced and made me a weird crazy little bastard, who chose to behave normally in public (for the most part) thank god lol i was an extremely intelligent kid and had always been told this by doctors. ex: my parents never taught me how to read and write, i had to learn in kindergarten, but i picked it up so quickly i was reading college level by the third grade. (writing just didnt interest me much but i was pretty good at it) also i had basically theorized and partially sketched out a hydrogen powered engine in my head at the age of 9. (fanciful claim, i know, but its true. it wasnt fully fleshed out but the basic physics, chemistry and engineering concepts were there, had i contacted someone at MIT they could have worked off my ideas and tweeked my concept into reality. i mean its a fully viable technology nowadays, but it resembles my original ideas. i was 9 i wasnt building the fucking thing what im saying is i was smart enough and had learned just enough about chemistry physics to conceptualize how it could efficiently work, i should have gone to college. but now im mainly focusing on biology and ecological sciences, because thats where my passion lies, in the natural world and being able to have our cake and eat it too so to speak (see this is one of the 2 symptoms of add/adhd i exhibit, tangents along with slight audio processing issues like it takes me a second to process what someone has said to me if they tell me something while tons of noise is going on around me, long enough for me to say huh or what? but then i immediatley know what they said so i will respond, "huh?... oh yeah (appropriate to what they said)", not really enough to say i have adhd but it was the late 90s when i was "diagnosed" my mom basically spoke for me/ over me and made some shit up to get me medicated)) my parents had a lot of terrible issues that horribly affected their judgement and parenting choices/ skills. i dont entirely blame them, but it is their fault. i realized i was getting high off my adderall when i took it after not taking it for like a month and i abused it a little bit to get good at the guitar. then i had a horrible heart palpatation that could have been a minor heart attack from stress. and i never took it again. i constantly have ideas popping into my head but they never have really distracted me from doing anything or focusing on anything aside from meditation. i just am able to do things and focus on things while constantly doing other things in the background. i have talked to doctors after high school and they have confirmed i dont have adhd and never had it, i just had a VERY fucked up childhood. if you have kids, teach them the fundamental things, and dont treat them like theyre babies when they reach near the age of 10. make sure theyll be able to function as a mature adult. and dont ignore them, especially when theyre toddlers, just explain things to them in a way that theyll comprehend at their age, if u dont know something dont make shit up, just say you dont know and then try to learn about whatever it is together. but do ignore my terrible grammar and run on sentences.

The meds always have bad side effects. Like getting man breasts.
Its a good video. Not too dissimilar to me....except add about 10 to 15 years of experience going through it.  The point he makes about focus is very important. Meds will help in various ways with that, but not its never assured. No drug exists that will give you consistent focus all the time every time. No. You might get something that works for 5 months, then nothing. Or you get a day. Or an hour. Or 5 mins. Its unpredictable. Focus is not something we can save.  But. Restlessness is another story. When you deal with adhd your entire life and the frustration of always feeling like you need to be doing something else causes enough eternal strife...that's actually where the meds are a huge help.  Having that constant restlessness feeling getting killed is worth the price for me, because meds are excellent at it.  Its still very hard to convince myself to do things that are labelled as "energy intensive". Thats a con. That means doing a mentally challenging thing is going to take tricking myself to start it. I have developed lots of systems to help with that, but all these years later, thats always going to be a problem.  Off the meds heres the perk: i feel smarter. I sleep better. Its easier to convince myself to exercise. Restlessness is out of control, and why i stay medicated.  To be successful with meds you need a few mindsets: it needs to slay restlessness, because thats what its good at. Your dose should be low enough that you barely know its working or not. The cons of it shouldnt outweigh the pros. Eg: ritalin based meds made life easier, but also made my short term memory frustrating (wheres my pencil? Oh. My hand). It shouldn't do things like that. You shouldnt know things are better when youre on meds until youve been off them for awhile and notice that overall, things are worse.  If youre young and taking the meds, any super focus or perks youre getting from it, it will not last. No change in meds or dose will change that. Use that time to really leverage what you get from them. Develop systems to help you convince yourself to do things. Learn who you are and who you arent. Dont lie to yourself and what you're capable of. You can be 150 IQ but it wont matter if youre looking to do something that works against your individual weakness. Find what makes you naturally motivated every single day.

a lesson for anyone struggling with adhd meds, i take something like Adderall but dosed for children cause I'm pretty small, I don't feel any different but I keep taking it anyway cause maybe it will work someday, one day i had an exam that I had to cram for but i was stuck listening to music for some reason, so i did the unthinkable and doubled my own dose! i thought "well, I'm gonna fail if I don't try so what more could go wrong"  and omg do not do this guys!  like i passed the freaking exam but at what cost! i was not holding the wheel at any point that day! a semi-truck could've turned me into an abstract painting on the asphalt and i would've just stood there staring at it! everyone could tell i was high out of my mind that day! the lights were on but nobody was home! insane experience 0/10 do not recommend.
I've been diagnosed and on meds since I wat 7, so 30 years now.   My main recommendation would be, get the dose right. I spent too long under medicated due to stigma around the medication. My life became a lot better once I was on the correct dose. I also spent some time over medicated. That also sucked and sounds like the out of breath experience you described.   Dosage is everything. If I am doing conceptual work I will take a lower dose, and conversely, if I am doing a series of manual jobs or something more mindless I will take a higher one. Also, make sure to take time off the meds. A day a week if you can manage that.    It sounds like we have similar reactions to Vyvance Vs Adaral. I can't do Vyv. It does not last long enough for me and I feel out of breath. Aderal is better but not perfect.   There are also some newer medications out there that could help as off label treatments.   Don't get too put off by a bad first experience. Medication really can change your life pretty massively when you fined the right drug and dose.   Best of luck. And great vid btw.

Like a lot of other things in modern life we try to invent really bad stuff to fix a problem when the solution is just social. But we are so individualistic we'll try anything but that.  In all but the most pathological cases close personal relations with people that care about you like parents, spouses, and other social ties that will give you external guidance and reminders of what you internally forget or get distracted from is ten times more effective.  But we want to be super independent and dont have anyone helping us or god forbid telling us what to do that we'll take meth.

Vyvanse compared to meth? It's dextro attached to aminoacid to prolonge release. Guys don't get your knowledge about meds from yt. Talk to professionals.
I've also experienced the negative symptoms you are talking about after taking Yvanse. However(Im an no medicial professional and anyone having any adverse effects when taking any medications should discuss them with their doctor), I think it might have to do with your neck muscles tensing up from the medicine and from the fact that you can get really focused and sit in one position for hours on end. I actually have had some pretty bad neck problems from working/gaming too much with computers and much of it would be headaches and tension in and around the neck, including chest which would also sometimes lead to the sensation of short breath(Ive done all kinds of test for possible heart conditions). It was something I for the most part fixed, through beind more mindful of how I sit and many many maaaaany exercises and stretches. However, once I started taking Yvanse the problems pretty quickly came back and Ive been able to make them better with the same exercises and stretches Ive used before. Ive talked to other people taking yvanse and tension around neck seems like a pretty normal side-effect.

But meds work differently through the cycle bc of that, even when I‚Äôm careful about my diet, training etc. and‚Ä¶ I just can‚Äôt afford it. I have to be able to do different things at the same day without the fear that something will consume me/I‚Äôll be anxious/have a headache/will focus on the wrong thing. N what could have happened with stopping meds?
I am extremly good in focusing with ADHD (have autism as well) - unfortunatly it only works with stuff I'm interested in. That's a hell of a lot stuff including rather weird things. I would get obsessed with another thing from time to time and get to expert levels within short time. After bringing a jew's harp from Siberia I got obsessed with this instrument and would have almost 60 instruments custom made by turko-mongol shamans from Siberia and Central Asia, ukrainean engineers and indian brass tool makers for instance whom I had to track down, would find a community in Berlin, connect internationally and only two years later I represented my country at the board of the international jew's harp association and had life performance in Berlin radio stations. That's just one example of my many hyperobsessions - while I'm struggeling to pick a broom and sweep the floor/vacuum my carpet for more than a week at this point, an occupation which would take 15 minutes or so. It's really difficult to tell whether I'd rather be neurotypical or neurodiverse because I wouldn't want to give up my extremly quick learning when it comes to stuff I'm interested in while I'm also extremly annoyed to struggle with easiest things such as chores or sometimes even getting out of the bed. And it makes me feel anguish to get constantly told how "intellectual superior" I supposedly am because I have an over-average IQ and for sure know a lot more stuff than the average person but that's not a personal achievement but rather a mere side effect of my conditions - but actually these parameters mean a f‚ò†Ô∏èk all when I experience myself to be incapable of cleaning the floor or sufficiently feeding myself. And then there's the addiction of course: After failing my A-level because I had to quit Ritalin for turning 18 and ADHD only being recognized/Ritalin being approved for minors back then.  I would work low profile jobs which didn't fit my needs in a long shot and would eventually end up shooting heroin/cocaine coctails or smoking the in comparison to shot coke way less strong crack whenever I was too high to still hit a veine and wasted 12 years of my life before I (after 25 clinical cold withdrawals and two failed stationary long term therapies hadn't kept me sober) I finally managed to become clean 6 years ago age 30. I got myself back on track, would learn I was an autist as well, would get prescribed Ritalin again which meanwhile had been approved for adults and started an education in outgoing tourism sales and accounting to finalize my recovery/resocialisation so things turned out well in the end, but without ADHD and a need for Ritalin I probably would have studied and never fallen to addiction - and that's a painful thought for me..

Try modafinil.
Fellow sufferer here. I've spent a lot of time both off and on meds. IMO meds are *A* tool but they shouldn't be your *ONLY* tool. I'd highly encourage people to also try practicing mindfulness meditation (helps you recognize when you're off-task and get yourself back on-task) as well as common-sense things like regular exercise and healthy diet. Also, try your best to create a quiet workspace that is free from distractions. Take your pill and get started on your work so that by the time it kicks in, you're not reading about the moons of Jupiter but are instead getting done whatever tasks you need to do that day! Jupiter can wait until the weekend!

In my experience adderall also tends to focus you on whatever you‚Äôre doing when it kicks in. It helps if you can do it right before or at the start of work or class or some structured thing that can kind of lock you into the right groove for a few minutes. It‚Äôs not impossible to switch gears after the fact, but it‚Äôs kind of like turning the rudder on a cruise ship. Me and my family have known ive had ADHD since i was 3 and then last year i couldn't pay attention at all, i procrastinated a lot, i was not retaining the information, and i got distracted, and now i took medication and now i still do all those things, just a lot less
Ritalin has been a life changer for me. Comes up without being intrusive, in low doses it makes me be able to do stuff without my "flight" instinct kicking in or taking over, in high doses it's as if I'm in a cocoon of serenity surrounded by nothing, my mind is an enigma. I can use caffeine to intensify its effect, but to someone who isn't used to this it can make you feel queasy/sick or be too much. The only downside of Ritalin? Can't have sex on it. It's basically speed, just very pure.
I have spent the last year or so trying to dial in the right medication and the right dose.  Adderall XR  was the first and the pros were good but the cons were pretty bad so I tried several others, including vyvanse and after 4 or 5 different options, I'm going back to Adderall XR with a "micro-dose" of regular Adderall in the afternoon when the XR starts to wear off so I can get through the entire day instead of crashing immediately after work and being a vegetable at home.  I've decided the best description for my ADHD is my brain is filled with dozens of bouncy balls, all bouncing around all day, all the time, from the time I wake up until I can ignore them long enough to fall asleep.  Meds don't get rid of the bouncy balls.  They just reduce the number to something more manageable and they slow them down enough that I can, more often than not, control the trajectory of the bounce so they bounce where and when I want them to.  It's not fool-proof, but it's a really helpful tool for dealing with a world that isn't built for neurospicy people like me.

I used to take Fluoxetine for my ADHD. Low dose, (10 mg) once a day. Very slow burning, and kept me focused throughout the day. Took it for a year and a half, and then weened off. The nice thing is it kinda knocked a few gears back in the right place, so I can focus better now than before taking it, even though I'm not on it currently. Good choice for if you need it long term, and there are little to no side effects.*    *Guys, this is not a professional opinion. Please do not take prescription drugs without prior advice from a medical professional.

Adderall isn't "effectively taking meth(amphetamine)", it's downright taking a mixture of levo- and dextroamphetamine, in other words "ordinary amphetamine". This is not "effectively meth". Methamphetamine =/= amphetamine, even though Americans tend to primarly think of the former when discussing amphetamines.

If your doctor isn't available and you think you are having adverse side effects to a medication, call a pharmacist (especially if you are considering stopping the medication cold turkey) they will have the info needed to inform you of any risks or tell you how to taper off. (This is ESPECIALLY the case with antidepressants (often prescribed for ADHD) and addictive meds (such as stimulant ADHD meds)

Update?
Hoooboy. So the thing here is that it sounds like the vyvanse was working for you. You're noticing the thing with focus but, wow. Did nobody tell you that once you're on the medication: **YOU NEED TO TRAIN YOURSELF TO PICK YOUR FOCUS.** That way you don't get "locked in". That's not the meds fault, that's YOUR brain not being used to the ability to pick focus. As ADHD sufferers we lack multiple executive function skills, and when we are medicated we need to *actively develop and train those skills.* Finally, those exhaustion and tiredness symptoms... Were you eating enough? Drinking enough? Vyvanse and most ADHD meds make you lose more water, AND also depress your appetite. I also went through a stage of being really tired on them and the answer was just "eat more" I started adding cream to my morning breakfast smoothies to give me more energy through the day.  Honestly man sounds like you didn't get the support required to actually have the meds work.
I used to take vivance when I was younger and it would make my under eyes puffy and super sleepy, found out I was allergic to it and then stopped taking adhd meds. After years of no meds I ended up needing anti depressants which was a good substitute in my case.

That's the thing, the meds give you superpowers, like ability to focus and learn so much in an afternoon that nobody else could... but you have no control over on WHAT the focus is geared towards. And that's the crux of ADHD meds. They do HELP but without personal growth and learning about yourself and how your brain behaves, you do not have control. You can hack your brain deliberately with certain techniques to have more control, but you will never ever reach 100% and that's just life on a spectrum.  Learn those techniques and you have better life, but forget even being in full control of your brain. You're just wired that way, try to learn as much about it as possible and how to steer it in directions with better chance, let the meds do the rest.

Although I would warn anyone thinking about self medicating with weed to help with your ADHD to be careful if you are prone to substance abuse, especially because people that have ADHD are more likely to have addictive personalities. Adderall XR (extended release) works MUCH differently than the normal stuff. I had to stop taking it because I was experiencing negative side effects that for me, really weren't worth the trade off. It let me organize my brain enough to where I could get a complete thought out, I could finally remember things that I'd seen and heard, sense of time improved, and I could still get into that busy bee sort of flow state where I could get things done. I was on it for about 10 years at a high dose starting from a young age, and it took a toll on me in other aspects of my life, so I decided to give up on being medicated and see if I could handle things through willpower and careful planning. All in all, I do alright these days. Point being, if I didn't decide for myself that the side effects I was experiencing were so impactful, I'd still be on it. For anyone watching this, it's worth looking into. If you managed to read this wall of text, you probably can go without.

I like that animation where your brain was on the floor spinning
Why did he make this video? 1 Vyvanse is just Adderall with a lysine molecule that requires a catalyst to be metabolized. Both result in a slow, stable increase to your Serotonin level, and is what makes amphetamine complex based stimulant meds different from Meth. The symptoms he described on Vyvanse (hyper focus, shortness of breath, constantly feeling like you just finished jogging) are an indication that his dosage was too high. 2. There is no downside to stopping Adderall or Vyvanse all at once, his warning never to stop taking a medication without consulting a doctor is a bad one. You should never start taking a medication without knowing whether you can stop taking it all at once. 3. Medication is never enough to treat ADHD on its own. If you're going to take meds you need to get the dosage right, but you also need to work on your habits.  For anyone who watched this video, his experience on both Adderall and Vyvanse is typical for someone who is taking the wrong dosage. Too little and you won't be able to mentally focus, too much and you become hyper focused and start to feel exhausted and like you might have a heart attack. Of these two scenarios, the low dosage is by far the better outcome. To be completely clear, he could have had the same outcome on Vyvanse as he had from Adderall, or the same on Adderall as he had on Vyvanse. If he had decreased his Vyvanse dosage he could have been able to improve his personal habits in a way that would allow him to focus and think more clearly.  Improving one's habits is a slow process, which is likely why he jumped to Vyvanse in the first place. I'm going to keep saying this, patients need to inform themselves regarding their own health conditions and disorders. Self-advocacy is extremely important, especially when your condition has been commonly misunderstood by medical professionals for decades. ADHD definitely falls into that category. My honest opinion is he should have simply decreased his Vyvanse dosage by about half, and allowed himself time to build better habits that would allow him to focus properly. Now that he's completely unmedicated, that task is essentially twice as hard.  It is a common mistake of patients to assume that their experiences are unique, and that different medications are dramatically different. There is also a lot of bad information out there regarding different medications, like the claim that Adderall is basically Meth. Adderall and Vyvanse are essentially the same, their release/metabolic mechanisms are the only real difference. Vyvanse is slightly better than Adderall only in that it's release mechanism is more stable and reliable as well as abuse resistant. However, both are Amphetamine complexes, neither of which is synthetic Meth. Meth is also an amphetamine complex, but that's like comparing ethanol to methanol. One gets you drunk, the other is eventually fatal.  This was not what I would call a well researched video, it is extremely subjective and full of confirmation bias. It's extremely important that you self-advocate and self-educate when it comes to having this kind of medical condition. Yes, it's difficult to do that when you have a condition like ADHD, but it's not impossible and it's very much necessary.
Wellbutrin/Bupropion is a non-stimulant if that's a problem for anyone! (I have hypertension, so Adderall gave me a BP of 210/94 and sent me to the ER.) Bupropion removes that barrier between "I should do this thing" and the actual action of getting up/switching focus to do the thing. Granted, a huge portion of my ADHD that it helps with is memory loss, which I know is less common.

I have pretty bad adhd and mainly struggle with executive dysfunction. I've been on ritalin for about 3 months now, and I can actually DO stuff now, but I still struggle with focus because the meds do wear off fast. my psychiatrist is my mother (I know that's bad, but it's convenient), so I can text her anytime I want and receive a reply within minutes or a few hrs, and we have agreed to increase my dose. I take 30mg now, 10 in the morning, 10 around noon, and 10 in the early afternoon, and it helps, but I'm still not sure it's what I need. I'll see how it goes, what I will say is that I can finally go to university after trying and failing for 2 years. maybe I'll try a different medication in a few months, but I think I'm still adjusting so I won't give ritalin up yet. it's the second medication I've tried, the first one was an adhd medication classed as an antidepressant (strattera), and while it did help, it made me incredibly tired. I was sleeping all day, so it made me less productive...I struggle with exhaustion a lot tho, I suspect I might have chronic fatigue syndrome and should probably see a doctor about that.
Hi! I have inattentive ADHD too (and was diagnosed as a young adult) and learning to capitalize on medication is TOUGH. For me, it was as much about ameliorating the side effects as it was capitalizing on the benefits.  One of the big things I wasn‚Äôt expecting was how incredibly important it is for me to eat food, and how tough that can be. If I eat within a couple hours before taking meds, they barely work. If I try to eat once the meds are active, I don‚Äôt feel hungry and I become extremely jittery and anxious, which leads to the kind of aimless productivity discussed in the video.   What I have found DOES work is to take my meds immediately before eating a big fat meal :) that way I get maximum, consistent effects while fully ameliorating the anxiety and jittery feeling! Once I figured this out, I was able to properly dose my meds, and am three years in to a better relationship with my ADHD and feel like I am mostly in control of both the disorder and the medication that helps me manage it!  Curious to hear if anyone else has found food so crucial to managing medication, and also happy to discuss with others! I feel like the process of medicating is really not discussed enough given how brutal the side effects can be for medication :P

I have adhd and autism
you gotta be careful with this stuff, understand it. yes all adhd meds is practically meth, yes at a really low dose It can be a tool. but like you said, the core of the issue is your discipline and habits. without genuinely changing it wont help you. Also it is a stimulant, which means your brain is generating a flow of dopamine, just like when you're eating or using a phone, or watching a show. but this chemically needs to happen in the background while you work, if you do those activities at the same time, you're double dipping, and you're twice as tempted to re engage in that activity when you need to be doing the work (which is only half as rewarding). as being a stimulant, it also increases your heart rate, this means you will need much more water to sustain your body's processes, you were likely severely dehydrated, and meds should be taken as soon as you wake up so that you can fall asleep again in good time. be careful with prescribed drugs! It's just like a drug dealer, except your doctor wears a coat! neither will look out for your personal safety. love you! thank you! glad you're off meds. I definitely encourage you to try meditation. Every day try to use less and less electronics, and engage in less and less rewarding activities. This will rebalance your reward system and allow you productivity, creativity, focus, and discipline. Also exercise! good luck brother.

I am drinking loads of water, make sure you do that, but I take Concerta XL Methylphenidate 36mg Prolonged Release + 10mg instant Release (Whenever I notice the Prolonged release ware off). Been doing me wonders, I still struggle with the work and productivity, similar with you when you were on your meds, but it was worse before the meds. What it also did for me was improving comprehension, attention, emotional regulation and my overall mood. I was expecting to work better, still working better, but not as much as I was hoping, but I definitely feel more in the moment, like I dont feel disconnected or just lost in my head. Overall I do suggest anyone to try the meds for around 3 months to see if it helps, unless you do experience health problems, talk to your doctor. But for me, I'll take it for as long as it helps me.

Adhd medicine is just built differently.
I imagine you have already talked to your Psych by now, but you might look into the non-stimulant medication options. Both meds you tried are stimulant varieties, meaning you take them when you need them, they kick in for ~6-10 hours and then they wear off. They also are SUPER dosage sensitive and dialing that in can take several months worth of appointments if they even work for you. Non-stimulants work on other parts of the neurochemistry that exacerbates ADHD and seeks to help the body in regulating the chemicals it needs on it's own, you typically take these daily and they take a few weeks for your brain chemistry to stabilize. I take Strattera specifically which is a selective Serotonin reuptake inhibitor and a Norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor which reduces the amount of those neuro-transmitters your neurons reuptake. Reuptake is the process through which unused neurotransmitters that are saturating the synaptic juncture are reabsorbed by the axon of the upstream neuron. These meds operate under the premise that your brain is too eager to vacuum up these neurotransmitters or that your neurons are not as sensitive to them as they should be and so they readily saturate the synapse. Serotonin is implicated in a number of neurological disorders, ADHD and Depression being notable examples. Norepinephrine has roles in stabilizing mood, regulating attention and arousal (arousal in the medical sense, this is the ability to feel motivated to do a thing, not specifically physical arousal), and several other jobs. Notably, Norepinephrine is one of the products that our brains turn Dopamine into. So dopamine seeking behavior can be absorbed in individuals who have plenty of dopamine, but a lacking in Norepinephrine as they are trying to force the creation of additional Norepinephrine by flooding their brain with Dopamine.  This is just one example of non-stimulant medications now available for the treatment of ADHD. There are others that work on different principles and people may respond better to some than others. Another thing to consider is comorbidities as well. People who suffer from ADHD are more likely to suffer from a number of other conditions at rates higher than the general population as well. It is possible that you ADHD treatment can be inhibited by the presence of one of these other conditions and that to effectively treat you, you must tackle multiple at a time, or even focus on a condition OTHER than your ADHD at first. Talk to your Psych about this, they should have a better grasp on your situation than a YouTube commentor, but as an example; I ended up requiring both an ADHD medication AND a depression specific medication to see proper results.  Finally, for anyone struggling with these conditions right now and can't seem to find help, PLEASE check your state / regional / county resources. There are often tax-subsidized programs that can partially or completely offset the cost of treatment & medications as your financial situation requires. Not every place has them, but a surprising many do, even in the Southern United States where public funding is notoriously lacking.

when i was first seeking help for my depression, i started a new medication that at first was really helpful. about two days in i got up to go to school and straight up fainted‚Äî which i have a history of, so i shrugged it off and left for class. next day rolls around, i try to get up, and my entire sense of where i was in my space was Gone?? i was wobbly, dizzy, and the more i moved, the more my vision blacked out until i fainted again. at this point i was a bit worried, so i reached out to my psychiatrist and eventually stopped taking them at her recommendation, but not until i had missed nearly a full week of school lol. it slipped by me so easily because they were symptoms i already experienced, just slightly different, so i assumed it was the same thing playing up again when it wasn‚Äôt. i‚Äôm a better medication now (that as a bonus helps with my chronic pain) and it‚Äôs been infinitely better! medication can be a really fickle thing, and in most cases you‚Äôll try several at different dosages before you settle on the one that works best for you. it‚Äôs a really intensive journey tbh, but i feel it‚Äôs worth it to finally level the playing field between myself and my peers :3  while i also have adhd, i‚Äôm not medicated at all (i have a Lot of medical issues and have yet to sort them out enough to consider more medication or help otherwise) this video is pretty on point lol. the hyperfixating on things that aren‚Äôt the tasks needed to be done is SUCH a struggle for me, which is only compounded by suspected autism‚Äî it‚Äôs nothing new to see me cruising paleontology articles instead of doing Literally Anything Else
The animation was soo so fun !  Ive just recently started with my adhd (add actually) medication, not the direct stimulants but the slow releasing ones, or whatever they are called..mine is wellbutrin xl. And, im having a total revolution. I didnt know the hyperactivity in my mind was the root of all the crpp happening in my life. The meds transfered the hyperactivity in the mind to physical activity. I cant believe how productive i can get to be now. Before, i was just thinking too much on anything and everything, so nothing could be done properly and never on time, of course. Or even if its properly done, i was getting so damn exhausted, drained. And i could actually feel my brain was hurting (almost like muscle spasms) at each step. I couldnt have realistic evaluations on stuff i care about because i was just so lost in thought process all the time. Everything felt boring to the detriment, i couldnt even get to enjoy the things there is for entertainment, like book, movies, etc. Im already a highly sensitive person in medical terms-- like im sensitive to sounds, lights, smells, sensations, even the energy around and i even have sensitive teeth lol..so living felt painful, it felt just too much of a burden most of the time, especially during times of heavy stress (like my last 7 years). I had many burnouts bcos of such reasons. I couldnt get to the point of actually solving regular problems, i was just getting lost in the process. I was joking and laughing most of the time (i mean, when i wasnt easily frustrated at something), so nobody, including family, could actually see what i was going through each day. No support system whatsoever. After medication, only now i can think and act straight, can see whats actually important, my mind doesnt feel like losing your way in the middle of a vast forest. This is an actual inability guys..it has nothing to do with being lazy or whatever. Thats like wanting to walk but your muscles just dont let it happen. Or you cant see clearly without glasses. This is the same kind of a physical inability. The problem is...its mostly invisible to the outside. Because its not directly visible, your problems dont make sense to other people and after some point, you yourself also start believing that its a character fault rather than an actual inability. Like, you become convinced you dont get paralysed in thought process most of the time, as though it was all intentional. Anyways...Im soo so grateful i have the right diagnosis for the first time at the age of 35 (before it was only depression and anxiety treatment, which didnt change anything eventually) and there is medication options for this inability -- yes, its totally a kind of inability for me, even though thats not a popular opinion about adhd. Every morning my mind is in the familiar mess and confusion and it feels adrift until the meds kick in. Only after then i start thinking in an organized manner automatically. Only after that i feel like i belong to this world, and able to function as i wish, like everybody else. I hope the researches on neurodiversity improves even more, so that everyone who suffers everyday can reach more great solutions easily.

You need to actually take steps like seeing a psychologist. To do treatments that involve actually changing the way you function, and possibly taking medication while doikg that to help.   Because what you are doing otherwise you are just taking a pill to avoid having to deal with the actual issue. Improvement is possible. Its just not going to be effortless.

Experience for me is kinda similar. Been diagnosed since I was in HS, definitely have the "chain of disparate thoughts" problem. To the point where I can't explain how I got from task A to explanation 13-charlie. Bad mojo. I've tried a handful of different meds over the years, but where I've landed is I *need* them to be productive at work. I'm a software engineer, and I need to be able to corrale  my thoughts and get work done. There's too many interesting problems in my workday to not have a "focus, you fack" button available. But I can't be on meds all the time. I need to take regular breaks, otherwise I get into the other cycles you mentioned. I landed on taking them 4 days a week - monday, tuesday, thursday, friday. Those break days let me do all the weird non-linear big-idea thinking I love, but also give me enough of a lever to keep *most* of my squirrels pulling in the same direction. Taking a break on the weekends resets lots of things for me.   That does limit which drugs I can use. Some of the SNRIs and others you can't just start and stop, but the very low-dose adderall I use my doc thinks is pretty safe to do so. *shrug*, ymmv. In the end, meds are a tool, but you'll need a bunch of others to go with it. For me they helped bridge the gap and get some of my worst habits under control. The single biggest difference between the first time I went to college and flunked out, and the second time I went and finished a BS in 2 years was adding meds to the mix.

I take medicenet it helps a lot
Your friend was goofy af, Vyvanse is also a sister drug to methamphetamine (specifically, it's lisdexamfetamine). With that said, Vyvanse has been my life-saver, been taking it for 7 - 8 years now (started in high school), and I genuinely think I may have not graduated from high school without it. Much less graduate with my bachelor's, nor start my master's.  Edit: I should note that there are some things I've lost from taking Vyvanse, specifically the ability to daydream. I also recently got changed to the generic version of Vyvanse due to the shortage, and for whatever reason, that version of the medication causes me to have an extreme stutter when trying to start sentences (it's very strange). Additionally, in the first six months, I did struggle with a half-life and a moderate crash from Vyvanse, and some tummy issues, but those have all either disappeared or majorly improved with time.  Point is, medication can work for some people. But there are always tradeoffs and often you're not going to just take a medication that works and not have some, at least minor, side effects that inconvenience you. Vyvanse causes me to stutter, and gives me some tummy issues, but that's a reasonable price to me if I can function day-to-day. It's also important to note that you probably won't find a suitable medication the first couple tries. I took at least 3 - 4 medications, maybe more, before trying Vyvanse. Some of them were good at first and then got worse with time, one in particular gave me the stereotypical "I feel like a zombie" symptoms, another made me extremely nauseous, but using what we learned from each medication (because most of them helped my focus, but weren't worth the other issues) we were eventually able to find something that ticked all the boxes with manageable side-effects.
I have ADHD, medicated when I was young.. Thing would cut my appetite and ended up making me a hungry zombie all day that couldn't focus or just didn't have enough nutrients to perform simple tasks. Stopped taking it and felt better and ate more, still couldn't focus. Also went on anti-depression meds, made me feel like shit under a week. Also stopped taking them, never felt better in my whole life. Now every time a doctor tells me to take meds for a ''mental'' problem, I just out right refuse to take them. Honestly if only people knew the pain we go through man
Adhd can be both a blessing and a curse depending. My symptoms worsened in my early 20s, id start on a task and less than a minute i was in another world, task completely forgotten. Then eventually something that was really important to me needed to be worked on. Id get distracted and sometimes it would take 1-2hrs before the thought "hey shouldnt you be focusing on this?" Occurred. As i struggled each day my psych told me not to feel bad about this but when ive noticed ive veered off task, to get back to it before my mind changes again and i "forget". Two weeks of forcing myself to go back, trying to increase the time i focused on it by 1 second at a time,  helped wonders! Now i usually can focus for about 10 mins in one sitting, but the most influental change that happened is when i got distracte, my distractions lasted a few minutes vs hours. I let myself get distracted while i work, but i soon remember that i have to get back on task and return right away. It also involved a trick where i had to think of ways to make my brain interested in what i was doing. Cuz adhd people often have an uncanny ability to focus on things they are "obsessed" about or enioy. Similar to being able to sit down and play a really fun videogame for a while in 1 sitting. Adhd coping mechanisms are not 1 size fits all, but figuring out how to be a lil more self aware and try to hack your strengths to overcome weaknesses pays off more than medication cause youre not risking your health with these controlled substances. Just my two cents and i hope this was explained well enough for at least one person to be able to understand and try. Improvement is gonna be incrimental and not happen overnight, but after a year of constantly trying, its become severily more manageable and has improved many aspects of my life as a fellow with a nonstop million mph brain lol.

i used to take adhd meds in the past. the manual had this table of side effects and how often they would occur. there was the side effect of "sudden death" which was listed under "less than 1 in 10000". the fun part is how there was a category "unknown" as well, which would imply an occurence rate so low they couldn't reliably establish an average occurence rate but no, it was listed under "less than 1 in 10000". every now and then, i just got the manual from the latest box, started reading through the side effects, and there it was again. needless to say, every time i read it i had a good laugh about it and every time my mother got a little bit more worried cause i was laughing about a 1 in 10000 chance of randomly dying.

My personal experience with ADHD is like this metaphor I came up with on a whim:   You‚Äôre in a truck on a freeway. You can go either fast or slow.   If you go slow, you‚Äôll be weaving from lane to lane, whenever you want (whenever you don‚Äôt want, too, but you‚Äôre going nowhere fast.   If you‚Äôre going fast, you‚Äôre getting places, but it‚Äôs tough to steer while speeding, so don‚Äôt expect to change the subject anytime soon.   For me, Adderall is like putting a brick on the accelerator and cutting the brakes.  You‚Äôll be moving real fast, but it takes a ton of finesse to move between lanes without overshooting, so you gotta either be in the right lane when it happens or you better get good at changing lanes under the pressure. At least, if you‚Äôre me.

Gosh your friend is dumb regarding Vyvanse.   Both it and Adderall are Amphetamine, one is just a blend of Dextro and Levo (Adderall) and the other is straight Dextro (Vyvanse; bound to lysine)  You can stop taking those meds whenever, by the way. They're just stimulants, worst that'll happen is you feel exhausted for a day or two.
Almsot like medications just drone out the problem not fix it. There are things that are broken and need to be fixed if that is your entire life better first to figure out if there is anything wrong at all...
It's very clear you need to combine Adderall with the second medication.

Dosage is very important. Being locked in on a single thing all day is not the experience you should get from your meds. That sounds like being really freaking high actually. There are slow release stimulants, that's what I'm on. That might be something to look into. Also different drugs have different effects on different people. Don't stop after trying a single stimulant at a single dose. Be patient. Start at low doses. Have frequent meetings with your medical professional.

I was diagnosed like‚Ä¶ 7 years ago, and I'm still changing meds until this very day. The fact is that I also have anxiety and depression that is a very common ADHD combo, so every time I change a med, BOOOM, everything has to change. And also something very interesting, I sometimes take a med, it doesn't work well, I change. Years later I take that med again, and boom, perfection. I have inattentive ADHD, and I'm in vet uni, so I can't have the luxury to be without meds and go with the dopamine for now. But some things I noticed with the years is that: Constant out of breath feeling? Check your anxiety. Even tho you're not diagnosed with it, anxiety is more part of our lives in a general basis then it is to neurotypical people, specially when you feel that the fucking med is not doing its job, the anxiety kicks in, and as we know that the med also makes us more energetic, energy+anxiety is not a good combo. Another thing is that changing meds from time to time actually helped me, because of the new formula. Like when you change your hair products, the following days It's like you just got out of the hairdresser, but once your hair is used to it, we're back to the normal. OBVIOUSLY that's my experience with my ADHD and my need to take the medicine because my ADHD is really bad. But I'm sure that once not taking them is doable, this shit is going to be thrown out of my window, do a spin and right into the garbage. Meds help but do not erase our ADHD, and as much our ADHD is unique, so is the medicine that works for you at that very moment of your life, and the choice to not take it.

Hello. I‚Äôm a recovered ADHD. I have now got super focus. I can stay focused on 3-5 tasks simultaneously and switch between or operate all of them.  This is actually extremely productive and useful.  I started this journey to focus by counting in the shower. Count to 120 and keep track of how many 120‚Äôs you‚Äôve counted to. You are now tracking 2 tasks. Then at some point you get bored of this task and start trying to count 89 90 91 while also counting a separate set of numbers 27 28 29. So you are effectively holding a pattern in your mind which is advancing at the same tome you‚Äôre focusing on a second count, and tracking the first pattern over a span of time.  Then you get bored and start singing while doing these 3 tasks.  Then you get bored and start singing aloud one song, in your head, another song, and while patterning a count, focusing on a count, and tracking the pattern count. And at this point, you can comfortably hold 3 tasks in the background without needing ‚Äúfocus ‚Äú AND are able to focus ACTUALLY FOCUS on another 2 tasks if needed.  Or you could just try carrying a fucking notebook in your pocket.
It‚Äôs better to live with it and learn to deal with it your own way than to chemically alter you‚Äôre brain and induce other dysfunctions

I know this is a cartoon and you're trying to keep the topic light and entertaining but I still feel the need to state 1. Adderall, ritalin & other stimulant medication perscribed to people with ADHD is chemically different from meth / amphetamines and also doesn't effect the ADHD brain the same way amphetamines do to non-nurodivergent people. 2. Comparing stimulant medication to illicit drugs is very ableistand stigmatising language even when others with ADHD are saying it.

Dont know if you'll see this but have you tried boredom? Sit down for 5-10 doing absolutely nothing till you're bored then try to start the task. Perform this as many times as necessary to get you started on the task. the focus should be greater. Got this info from one of Healthygamergg's videos. Basically your brain deems the important task as boring which doesnt release a lot of dopamine whereas the random and easy task is a quick dopamine hit and the brain wants more of it. Sitting still makes your dopamine levels reduce to the level of the important taskso now you can get it done.

P.R.O.D.U.C.T.I.V.E
From someone that has just (very happily) switched from Concerta to Vyvanse I just want to note that most people will have a preference for either methylphenidate (Ritalin/Concerta) OR amphetamine (Adderall/Vyvanse). Mr. Sandwich unfortunately only tried amphetamine and it‚Äôs very likely that methylphenidate (or a non-stimulant like atomoxetine) would have given very different and much better results. So it is worth talking with your psychiatrist about changing medications if one is not giving good results.   Lastly, if you feel shortness of breath on either of these medications that‚Äôs a serious, dangerous side effect and you need to contact a doctor immediately.

Vyvanse was terrible for me - it just resulted in a daze and lethargy at various doses (I believe this is due to the way it's processed in the body being so dependent upon an individual's digestive tract and ability to separate the lisdexamphetamine into its constituent dextroamphetamine and lysine molecules). Adderall, on the other hand, has been amazing. Not without side-effects but very little else will allow me to get through a whole day with not only focus but ability to switch between tasks.

So adhd is a neurological disorder where the human brain doesn‚Äôt release enough dopamine, dopamine is a chemical that triggers adrenaline or happiness so that‚Äôs why ppl whit adhd always want to do smth bc there brains don‚Äôt release dopamine correctly so when they‚Äôre having fun they‚Äôll be happy for like 3 minutes then they get bored again so that‚Äôs why we always want to do smth. But normal ppl who release dopamine correctly so when they go on a roller coaster or smth they‚Äôre happy and satisfied for 1-2hrs.  I rushed this so pls no help But I hope this helped lol

4:46 the fun thing is that vyvanse is also meth, well amphetamine, adderal is whats called dexamphetamine, works very similar to meth, a central nervous system stimulant, well vyvanse is LISdexamphetamine, which is basically a different compound that is slowly converted to Dexamphetamine through out the day so theyre both meth, or speed more accuratly.  if your curious about non amphetamine alternatives methlyphenidate (ritalin, concerta) and Atomoxetine (Strattera) are both not amphetamines, methlyphenidate is also a central nevrous system stimulant though, and atomoxetine is a selective norepinephrine uptake inhibitor

I was so lucky that the first meds I was put on worked and the only negative side effects I've experienced are dry mouth, dissociation, fatigue, and insomnia, but they only happen when I take the wrong dose or don't take them properly (e.g., I skip a few days, I have fresh orange juice with them, or I don't eat when I take them). I also live in the UK and have other prescriptions so I only have to pay roughly ¬£11 (~$14) a month to pick them up every 28 days, which works great cause then I don't run out (even if I request the script a couple days late). I'm also in my last year of a Psychology degree, specialising in neurodevelopmental disorders, so I know a decent amount about how they should work and other options I have if I stop being able to have them. I always recommended people who have an ADHD diagnosis to at least try meds cause sometimes they just work, and if they don't at least you know you're still doing your best :)

As a pharmacist (who also has ADHD) your description of Adderall vs Vyvanse is.... not really accurate üòÖVyvanse is essentially just longer acting/slower release Adderall. It gets broken down by your body into Adderall, hence it takes longer to kick in. It doesn't have any magical effects that make it better for intellectual focus vs physical tasks.

Adderall isn't meth. It's amphetamine/dextroamphetamine, not methamphetamine...  15mg a day seems to help me massively. I work as a software engineer and can focus no problem.
I took Ritalin and it felt good. Too good. So I started taking it because it felt good. And then it had side effects of making me very tired. So I stopped. Now I am back to square 1 where it takes me 5 hours to start a task that takes 30 minutes to complete.
All this sounds a lot like a bit of a bad approach to ADHD management. Ideally you'd combine the meds with (behavioral) therapy. A somewhat apt comparison might be: the meds are like glasses for someone who's shortsighted. The glasses don't enable you to read (get things done), but they allow you to see the letters at least. The therapy should then help you make habits of behaviors that will enable you to get things done, with the meds kinda being there as training wheels when you have bad days or a challenging environment. I'm kinda mixing the metaphors here. But hey. I'm not on my meds XD
Also, to everyone freaked out about the meth thing. Adderall is in fact meth, though in drastically lower doses then what illegitimate user usually take. In civilized parts of the world (not the US) Adderall is only ever indicated as a second line treatment for ADHD, and should only be prescribed if other forms of treatment don't show the desired effects.  Methylphenidate (Ritalin, Concerta) is NOT meth. They're not even close chemically, and Methylphenidate is considered a lot safer, with drastically lower rates of addiction (basically zero on the slow acting, retarded versions), negligible neurotoxicity, and generally milder side effects. It's pretty worrisome to hear how someone with that diagnosis would be given Adderall as a first line of treatment. My diagnosis took a long time (too long), however, it was very thorough. I had multiple (6) sessions with a professional trained specifically on ADHD diagnosis, plus computer based testing to figure out my exact type of ADHD. Additionally I had a complete bloodwork done, blood pressure, weight - basically everything was checked before I got my first pills. My experience with ADHD medication (Ritalin) have been very good, and completely free of charge - God bless the German healthcare system.

Justice for Lappy.
ADHD here- it sounds like you were having increased anxiety with the second med. That constant breathlessness is what having a panic attack feels like.  It can sometimes take 2-3 weeks for your body to fully adapt to medication. It‚Äôs not as simple as like Tylenol or Motrin which just work- psych meds take time for the body to adjust to, for your brain to adjust to as as they alter your neurochemistry. I‚Äôve tried multiple different medications because I knew I needed to treat my ADHD, and I was prepared to go through the side effects in order to find the right one. Ultimately concerta was perfect for me, it didn‚Äôt mess with my anxiety and I felt like a normal human with the ability to read a page in a book without losing my absolute mind.  But- sometimes medications just aren‚Äôt for people. In that case- I recommend exercising through running in the morning. It‚Äôs almost like letting your lizard brain have its physical activity so you can just let your human brain have the rest of the day- if that makes sense
I‚Äôm a Vyvanse user and it has truly saved me. I‚Äôm using it for work and I‚Äôm currently studying Mandarin Chinese.

Please y'all, understand that everyone responds differently and that there are a lot of options. If you can't deal with meds, you might need to focus more on behavioral support. Or you might try meds and suddenly find yourself functional for the first time in your life and never have a bad side effect. Personally I love my Vyvanse--it took like a year to find the right drug and get the dosage correct, but all of a sudden I'm finally digging myself out of the horrible life-consuming pit that ADHD has had me in for 30 years.  Also don't be scared by the fact that Adderall is chemically pretty close to meth. That's _true_ but you're using it in therapeutic doses designed to treat an issue with your brain. It's not the same as a neurotypical person just doing whatever's available on the street.

As someone who's been getting treated for Combined ADHD for a year and after learning about ADHD for over a year before the diagnosis, I would like to add that Adderall is *NOT METH,* nor is it like it. Meth and Adderall are both amphetamines, aka stimulants. What else is a stimulant? Caffeine, which is the mostly widely-used drug, and is certainly not meth. Adderall is perfectly safe and, in many cases, can decrease cardiovascular stress via weight loss.

You seem like you need to do better research or have a more informed doctor - sorry for bluntness.  Adderal ‚â† meth Adderall = amphetamine Vyvanse = amphetamine + lysine  Taking breaks is beneficial, no tapering necessary.  Concerta, Ritalin, etc = methylphenidate  Amphetamine = Norepinephrine Dopamine Release Agent, spams the Central Nervous system(CNS) with ‚Äòem.  Methylphenidate = Norepinephrine Dopamine Reuptake Inhibitor, CNS starts vetting crowded with ‚Äòem.  Cocaine and Bath Salts are NDRIs.   Calling Adderall ‚ÄòMeth‚Äô is like calling Ritalin ‚ÄòCocaine‚Äô.  Ps. The breathing issues may be related to MAOI toxicity. NAC/Glutathione supplements might‚Äôve helped you with that - as well as just eating enough protein.
I had the EXACT same response to Adderall. I'm on Strattera now and that has been the right fit for ME. But I will warn that you might not think it's helping with ADHD symptoms until you miss a dose lol. I forgot to take my meds one morning after a very stressful day/evening, and I noticed my thoughts overlapping and I was very overwhelmed. These meds very much help my anxiety which is nice.  Another warning for people who start it: it sucked for the first two-three weeks. I had horrible insomnia and I didn't feel like myself. I recommend trying meds for a good couple weeks as LONG AS YOU ARE SAFE. If I chose to stop taking them because of my insomnia and feeling like a zombie I wouldn't have figured out it worked!
Vyvanse is literally Lisdexamfetamine , adderall is dextroamphetamine. They are both chemically similar to meth, but they are not meth. Vyvanse is closer to adderall than adderall is to meth

If someone talks to me while im thinking about another problem .. wiped, like no actual memory at all. I always feel like an idiot but the best way to describe it would be that i actually feel physicly disgusted when i try to do something that i dont want .. i had to quit my first job i ever did cause at some point the thought alone of going to work and doing the same loop of work made me so sick to my stomach that i started to vomit everyday, which in itself is weird cause the second i was at work doing it .. its like the thought alone never existed cause im doing something right now and focused on something .. but it hit me right after getting out of work again which makes me sound batshit crazy ._.  As a kid i also noticed that my brain has like a timeskip button. If i knew that i would have to wait for 2 hours at home cause i locked myself out cause i forgot my key at home .. i would start to walk up and down the entrance and count the bricks at the ground and if im lucky i would get so sucked into it that eventually suddenly my mom would stand next to me and ask me wtf i was doing .. which was sometimes hard cause if my brain noticed that i was actually focusing on having to wait instead of the bricks it would feel like eternal hell where those two hours felt like days ..

ADHD meds (adderall) have helped me so much. I geneuinely don‚Äôt know where I‚Äôd be if I wasn‚Äôt medicated. That being said, it can be really hurtful when people tell you that you‚Äôre annoying or stupid when you‚Äôre not on meds, which I was told by multiple peers. It‚Äôs sad part of taking meds was just getting to receive kind treatment from others.  That being said, I still definitely struggle on medication. A lot. But I realized that being medicated made me a lot happier and has helped me so much. Even on days without school or likewise I still take my meds because I find myself being more organized and being able to focus on things I enjoy as well. I honestly think what‚Äôs most important is whether or not meds are making you happy, y‚Äôknow? Like you said, if the side effects are hurting then it may not be worth it. Sometimes it may take awhile too, bc i struggled a lot with the adjustment
If Adderall was working well and was comfortable for you then it is in that fact a good medication for you. It is not meth. It's the same family, but it is still meaningfully different and might be different for people with adhd.
I don‚Äôt want to offend anyone but do other people have ‚Äúspecial‚Äù abilities bcs of their ADHD like mine is for 5 mins a day I can go into overdrive and I become super smart/strong whatever and the rest of the time I just feel üòêor‚òπÔ∏è.            Or is it just me?
It‚Äôs also extremely important to remember that being on the medication does not mean you are going to magically get better. You still have to work to ensure you are holding yourself accountable where accountability is needed. I‚Äôve discovered that the medication helps me do that and make the right choices, but the pill is not in control of my choices, it‚Äôs in control of correcting and replacing what my brain can‚Äôt do/produce on its own. I am in control of my choices. Everything is always going to have a mundane necessity attached to it. I‚Äôve seen way too many people choose the overly difficult reality of not being medicated with their ADHD which ultimately holds them back from their true potential all because they tried a stimulant and expected it to do all the work, instead of taking it and working to manage the symptoms and take accountability of managing their lives.  You have 2 choices. You can choose the painstaking reality of the fact that your brain can‚Äôt function all because you expected a pill to 100% fix your life, or you can choose to provide your brain the stimulant it needs to function and take responsibility of the little details needed to manage your tasks and day.

In Germany the Neurologist is the doctor for ADHD. The practice here is, that you take your meds for half a year and make a therapy for learning to do the right things. After half a year you stop the meds and kust do the therapy. With that your brain gets a rewiring. Takes time but it works

Misinformation. Vivanse is lisdexamfetamine, adderal is mixed amohetamine salts. Neither is meth.
In the experience of my wife, it is not worth some of the side effects these drugs incur. She couldn't stomach most foods and lost 30lbs in a couple months, and also couldnt sleep for more than 3 hours a night. It is usually better to adjust your life around these kinds of illnesses and find a rhythm that works for you.

As a person working in pharmacy, please if anyone ever has strange symptoms or side effects you are not sure the cause of, you can talk to your pharmacist and they can tell you if it is a known side effect. It is why the pharmacist is there, we try to make sure you know if your drugs are causing adverse reactions that should be addressed.

Vyvanse (Lisdex-Amfetamine) is in most respects exactly the same as adderall, but is an abuse-resistant prodrug. It must bind with Lysine in the patients digestive system in order to become psychoactive, which makes the drug inert via any administration route which bypasses the patient's digestive tract. This also creates the extended release effect, I think; It's been a while since I did my research.

For people with ADHD, here an interesting but effective way of taking Adderall that psychiatrists never want to tell you: take it as needed. Problem solved. :) Take Adderall on days you need to function and do things. Don't take it on days you want to sit down and think. Adderall isn't like antidepressants or antipsychotics which always cause addiction/dependency and need to be in your system for a certain amount of weeks to be fully effective (which is debatable anyways). Adderall is effective specifically on the day you take it and don't need to build it up like other meds so theres actually no danger of stopping or taking it as needed. Adhd medicine shouldnt even be taken everyday becahse it can negatively affect your brain by making it harder for dopamine to be release over a long period of time. So, contrary to psychiatrists who are just going by book and get more money the more drugs they give to their patients, take Adderall AS NEEDED.   Antidepressants and antipsychotics/mood stabilizer should never be quit cold turkey but also you dont have to talk to your doctor about it unless you literally know nothing about medication and don't know how to do things safely. The drugs that 100% cause dependency and addiction like antidepressants have to be tapered off. Psychiatrists have regularly forced people to stay on medicine against their own wishes and to their own detriment. For instance, i know a bipolar taking antidepressants for a few weeks and i told her to immediately stop. She did not listen and harmed her money and other people around her emotionally. Psychiatrists say not to do anything without consulting them but it's also a money and power play. After three weeks of taking antidepressants, she would not have developed a dependency yet and her mania would have subsided within the next couple days. But guess what the doctor told her to do? Stop cold turkey two months later.

Why not take the meds and then set up alarms or routines that will stop you from continuing the same /wrong task all day? That sounds like the real issue. Reprioritizing does not have to all happen internally
@Ice Cream Sandwich But you know that there are MANY other ADHD drugs that could work for your brain specifically?? :/ The meds you tried out were both stimulant meds out of the amphetamine family. You also have stimulant meds of the methylphenidate family. You also have other stimulant-like families (not really stimulants, but they also stimulate your noradrenaline and your dopamine - levels). And you have non-stimulant types of drugs, like clonidine etc...   Amphetamine-like stimulants have more effect on the noradrenaline system than your dopamine system (esp. Vysane that works v√©ry long for about 12-14hours) In contrast, methylphenidate-like stimulants have more effect on the dopamine than on noradrenaline.  So all these ADHD meds work totally different, have different effects. And depending on each person's individual brain, each person can have benefits of other type of drug. One brain will have trouble focussing because of some unbalanced dopamine regulation in that brain, and will need more dopamine stimulation. While another brain will have difficulties focusing because of some noradrenaline disregulation, and needs more noradrenaline stimulation.  That's why you have to keep on searching what works for you personally.  And importantly: don't forget that medication can't do magic, it is important to learn skills that can help you how to work with that fascinating brain of ours. ADHD is NOT about an inability to focus, ADHD is about an inability to regulate that focus. There are ways to (better) regulate our focus!

I take vyvanse too! Going off the meds for me personally isn't bad - the first day off of them I'm more tired/groggy than usual but that's a normal "withdrawl" feeling I've been told. When I had an academic coach paid for by my uni who works with adhd and other neurodiverse peeps, I learned a lot about how to actually focus, take breaks and *do* the thing. Still learning about what my brain needs in order to *do* but I thought I'd add the importance of peepol support in addition to med support when it comes to ADHD. In short, the easiest way for me to feel accountable is when people are involved; they help me feel accountable by checking up on me or working on my weekly schedule with me. Not everyone feels supported by coaches tho so, diff supports for diff brains - also only could afford it cause it was paid for, so not always an option ~ The coach helped me work with my brain, work with for ex. demand avoidance that comes up when faced with a task :) While it isn't "intrinsic" motivation and I started out by relying on a coach, eventually I learnt skills to help me when accountability helpers aren't available.
To be clear, stims (like adderall) are just sort of in the same chemical family as meth, they aren't the same thing. Plus, you are taking a much smaller dose than the kind that would be necessary to get you high, and to top if off, they work differently for adhd brain than neurotypical brain, and are non addictive.  This far too much misinformation about stims for adhd, and unfortunately a lot of doctors are just as misinformed on the subject. To be absolutely clear, stims are considered by health authorities such as the NHA to be the primary treatment for ADHD. In other words, if your psych recommends you try non-stims first and starts talking about 'drug seeking behavior' you can rest assured _they_ are the ones going against the recommended treatment based on pseudoscience. It's like, a step removed from homeopathic rememdies, but it's still very much a red flag that you need to find a new doctor.

I think one of the weaknesses of ADHD treatment right now is that many patients are given medication without accompanying therapy. Things like CBT have been shown to vastly improve outcomes for ADHD patients when paired with appropriate medication. The brain chemicals matter, but there's also tons of stuff you can do to modify the environment to help with executive functioning. Russell Barkley's channel has some excellent videos on this kind of stuff, but you gotta play 'em at 2x speed, which I think is highly ironic. xD

If you want to improve your ADD/ADHD then you can‚Äôt expect a pill to do all the work for you. Working with an therapist or coach and learning coping/organizational/time management skills is a must as well.  The meds will give you the fuel your brain lacks(Dopamine) and the skills you gain from a therapist/coach/books will give you the direction so you know where to put your new found energy towards to.

Plus I have never felt less focused than when I was on vyvanse. It took me 6 hours to read 6 pages and I had to ask my mom to act it out to process it.  Adderall works but having adhd medicated is like eating soup with a spork. At least you don't have a fork like you do unmedicated but you're not eating as effectively as the people with with spoons. And it doesn't even last all day so I have 6 hours of having ADHD under control and the rest is just chaos.

Vyvanse and Adderall are both amphetamine-based. Maybe a medication that's based on methylphenidate instead (such as Ritalin or Concerta) would work better for you. I hate amphetamine-based meds but I like the methylphenidate-based ones. Plus, there is a generic version of Ritalin (in Canada at least, not sure about elsewhere) and it's much, much cheaper than Vyvanse.

The funny thing is Vyanse's active ingredient is Lisdexamphetamine, which is just Dextroamphetamine with a lysine molecule that gets stripped away when it's in the gut. Adderall is a combination of Amphetamine and Dextroamphetamine.

Please make a video about ADD
Something you should mention is that dosage is extraordinarily important. For person A, 50 mg Vyvanse might feel like a cup of coffee. For person B, that same 50 mg dose will hit them like a truck and feel like 10 coffees. (In this example I'm using coffees as an analogy, not an equivalent). Some people truly do have slower metabolisms. To compound this, certain foods will also affect the rate of absorption. Citrus will decrease absorption; antiacids will increase the rate because amphetamines break down in acidic environments.  Imo you could've titrated down unless you were already at the starter dose (10 mg).

I just take instant release focalin, it lasts like 3 hours and I can take it up to 3 times a day. I just take it when I need it and don‚Äôt take it when I don‚Äôt. I don‚Äôt even always take the full dose, more often than not I take 75% or 50%. With these particular meds, it‚Äôs honestly not that big of a deal. With a lot of psych meds it absolutely is a big deal to not take it exactly as prescribed. But you don‚Äôt have to take these (stimulants) every day if you don‚Äôt want to. And with instant release, you get even more flexibility.  Edit: I should add some clarifications to this. With extended release you only have flexibility with taking it or not taking it. You‚Äôre pretty much restricted to taking it in the morning so it wears off in time for bed, and you can‚Äôt split the pill because it interrupts the slow release mechanism.   With instantly release you have much more flexibility. You should never take more than your prescribed dose, but it is okay to take less. You can take it at whatever time of day, so long as your previous dose is worn off, and you will not be planning on going to bed until this dose wears off. And you can take it anywhere between 0 and your max number of times per day prescribed by your doctor.  And you should first double check with your doctor that the particular drug you‚Äôre taking is one that can be taken more flexibly.

yeah.. this video sounds like how I am. like right now, I should be working. but instead I watched this video. This is a regular occurrence. I have a hard time staying focused on work. So I actually know how these meds work and the nuerobiology of it all. Adderal enhances the part of your brain that is supposed to inhibit your actions. People with ADHD have the task inhibiting part of our minds underdeveloped, and adderal enhances that specific part. Allowing you to more easily control yourself and inhibit distracting thoughts. But that doesnt directly translate to focus. If I were you, id either lower my vivance dosage or find another focus med, while also taking adderall. That way you can achieve both focus and task switching/ self control.  Also, meds are just a tool to help you retrain your brain. You can legit train ADHD out of your brain with nueroplasticity. But it takes a lot of work and meds helping speeds that process up. I reccomend looking at andrew hubermans videos. Hes one of the top nueroscientists of our time and he does amaaaazing podcast videos that are so insanely helpful that each one basically shatters my worldview on the mind.
