Bruh, as someone who has been on a sushi belt of different adhd meds over the years, honestly, the best is legitimately desoxyn, which is literally just straight up methamphetamine. Like, the second I decide to get something done, so long as I actually know how to do it and am able to do it, it's getting started and I can focus on it for hours without any distractions.   Meth taken orally as a pill, and crystal meth smoked as a recreational drug, are like, two completely different drugs. Oral medications are less addictive due to them not hitting instantly like smoking/vaping, and provides a much more consistent effect throughout the day, which leads to less urges to redose, and not getting all "tweaky" for it.   Commentor note 1: If anyone has ever bought and taken an adderall pill from someone that wasn't directly from a prescription, that was basically guaranteed to be meth, as meth is more similar in effect to adderall than clandestinely produced amphetamines.  Commentor note 2: Taking any medication without doctor supervision is risky business. While oral meth is generally less addictive than smoking crystal meth, it can still be abused, and you can still go overboard with it. This goes double for pressed pills, as you can't know the exact dosage in each pill, you could very well be taking twice as much as you thought you were and end up as a sweaty mess that can't get out of bed because the second you try to stand up the dehydration kicks in. If possible always go through the proper channels to acquire your medication!

Th good news is there‚Äôs a ton of stuff to try with ADHD. Adderall works great for me when really need to focus or get something done. Like driving to pick up art supplies. Otherwise, exercise works in a similar way, but makes me feel better. I feel calm and good, and I can *choose* what I want to do. AND, I can switch tasks. My whole life I thought I was lazy, turns out I‚Äôm not. It‚Äôs just hard to start tasks and keep doing them. Sleep is also SUPER important to my brain function, with or without meds or exercise. Without sleep, my brain doesn‚Äôt brain. Keep trying stuff, and keep in mind that you can do multiple things at once, like meds and exercise.
Only Azstarys has really helped me. [Azstarys is combined Serdexmethlyphenidate & dexmethylphenidate.] Ritalin (methylphenidate) helped but it gave me high blood pressure. Adderall (mixed amphetamine salts), Vyvanse, Strattera (a non stimulant med) were all no good. The first two i was similar to you but also trouble sleeping. Ended up allergic to the atomoxitine(straterra).  But since starting Azstarys my life has really gone in a positive direction. Ive made more progress in therapy than ever. Imagine therapy is a toolbox full of tools to help life, well the right medication was my key to the toolbox. Now I'm learning how to use the tools.   All these stimulants are similar but their different structures as compounds and the way they are absorbed by the body really changes how you respond to them. Non stimulant meds vs stimulant meds is kind of the difference between your brain making more neurotransmitters or limiting reuptake instead, bith witht the goal of increasing the milage you get out of them. That's an over simplified explanation, but it works.  I highly recommend trying different meds until you find what works for you. Focalin is another one that helps people, it is dexmethylphenidate like Azstarys but without the other component Azstarys has, the prodrug serdexmethlyphenidate. Another non stimulant is Quelbree but it is basically Straterra but more common for kids. And non stimulant medication is usually recommended for people who either dont respond to stimulant medication or cant have it due to other health issues. The data basically says if stimulants help you nonstimulants probably wont help as much, and if nonstimulants help you its likely stimulants don't.   Goodluck!

My both dad and my older sister have ADD and it was clear that I had it too. I struggled to do homework in Middle School. I eventually went to a therapist to get an official diagnosis and started medication. I definitely got more focused on completing my homework. It felt like I had laser vision or tunnel vision and all I could see was my assignment. It was insane and I got work done. But I felt super melo and life felt super grey and I got depressed. Taking the medication brought all my extreme feelings and numbed them. I hated life and this wasn‚Äôt the kind of life I wanted to have. I ended up trying out 3 different medications and they had similar results. I stopped taking medication all together and I have managed to get by through high school and now my bachelors degree, but with many struggles. I luckily can focus and remember extremely well when in class or at work. My biggest problem is when I‚Äôm left alone to do a boring task just as chores or writing an essay. I can never seem to start it and my brain makes me avoid it at all costs. I think my biggest issue is starting and then continuing to carry out the boring tasks. I usually felt like it was a motivation issue, and if I‚Äôm motivated enough I could do it, but people tell me it‚Äôs the ADD making me avoid it

When I was kid, that's when I got diagnosed. I think I was in the 3rd grade. My mom finally decided to get me diagnosed, because I was so distracted with everything, all the time, and couldn't focus on doing school work, to the point where I was failing everything but the common core tests. (I was apparently also a genius, I just didn't like doing the school work.) Adderall was the first thing she tried, and it was down hill from there. My body was so fast at adapting to medicine, that at one point, my medication that i was on, couldn't be given, because I was on the highest dosage, medically allowed. After that, it was tests where they pay you to take the medicine for a week or so, a study of sorts, and then see what happens, and how effective it is. I stopped taking adhd meds in the 7th grade because IT ALL STOPPED WORKING. So, maybe I'll go back and try medication again, because I might need it, but, for now, we cope.

This guy‚Äôs voice has changed a lot in the last few years. He‚Äôs doing this cutesy voice now.
Just as a heads up, there is an extended-release variation of Adderall, which I take. I also find it problematic to say that you are essentially taking meth. I suppose compositionally, this could be true. But the effect it has on you is not the same. Talking with another friend with ADHD, I learned that there are some who expect the medicine to to fix learned skills. Like when we talk about focus, it's not just the ability to sit down for an extended period of time. There are skills that you now have to develop that you couldn't before being medicated. So for anyone taking meds for the first time and finding certain tasks still difficult, this could be the reason and you may want to learn about what the common skill deficits are that you can begin to learn with the newfound ability to focus. For example, learning to break down tasks and write out steps so that they become concrete and grounded was something that I had to develop once I started meds.

Just so you know GOING OFF YOUR MEDS WHEN YOU EXPERIENCE SIDE EFFECTS IS ALMOST ALWAYS BETTER THAN TAKING THEM FURTHER. Best case scenario you call your local hospital, just tell them what you're taking and your symptoms and they can tell you if you can safely stop taking it, 9/10 times it's a big "yes".  The hospital doesn't generally need your whole medical history, although it's better if they do, in any case it's better than idk getting heart problems because the medication is thinning your blood, and ending up in the hospital by ambulance.

You‚Äôre not clouded by anything.‚Äù It felt like a fucking lightning bolt. I realized I had the ability to just do things that I wanted to do and focus on the things I wanted to. It felt so right.

a couple of reflections on your video: 1. you will become more focussed on whatever you are doing (math, dishes, watching videos about cats) when you take stimulants because you are flooding your brain with dopamine, and that just makes anything and everything infinitely more interesting. 2. You seemed to have rubbed up against the bigger problem here: how we define productivity in our society. Achievement in our modern, capitalist state is fright with many problems, and meaninglessness is probably the biggest. Good luck on your journey!

I was like ‚Äúexcuse me?‚Äù And everybody called me an idiot who couldn‚Äôt get anything done, they said I procrastinated all the time and that I was the definition of ‚Äúlazy‚Äù it makes me mad considering these were random idiots from middle school who pick their nose too much to know what ADHD is.¬†     So I‚Äôm like. ‚ÄúHmm. Ok I‚Äôm gonna practice my clarinet at the last hour of the day.‚Äù I go on with my life for 4 hours binging adventure time. It‚Äôs 7:00, at this point I‚Äôm like ‚Äúpsshhhh I‚Äôll do it tomorrow.‚Äù The cycle repeats for 17 days. And I‚Äôm like ‚Äúwait I didn‚Äôt practice my clarinet.‚Äù And my productive side is like ‚Äúyour 17 days in the past right brain.‚Äù   ‚ÄúOk what‚Äôs two plus two?‚Äù  Left brain: fo- Right brain: hey how many pickles can fit inside aaa ummm a a aaaaa a *pause* PICKLE JAR!  ‚ÄúUhhhh‚Äù LB: if you‚Äôll let me speak dear sir- RB: hey have you seen that new Fortnite update? You took both meds of mostly the same working ingredient. You should go to psychiatrist and try something else. There are also non-stymulating meds. But I guess, the most important - you should start with planning your day. Then you take a pill and try to follow the schedule
Hello, I take Venvanse daily, and its a feeling of filter that i have. Filter of what should i think about. But i have experienced other medications. ADHD medications, in my opinion, are important! 6:05 but  as you said, you had the focus, you solved the problem, the task is now to you. And I think its interesting to see others opinions about it.
I was diagnosed as an adult. For me, task A is always create a to-do list. Then that extreme focus is completing that list.
What i learned _(with no help from the doctors)_ is that orienting yourself to be on-task when the meds kick in is only part of the battle. The best thing you can do is monitor your own behaviors and take some time to learn how it feels to be focused. Then practice those behaviors when not on the medication. For example, I learned that my memory becomes DRASTICALLY better when I _verbally tell myself_ what I'm trying to remember. So I made a habit of doing that for everything I could until it became an unconscious task like tying my shoes. Then the next time I took the medication, I could use that improved short-term memory to accomplish other things! And memory-retention isn't the only benefit! I kid you not, my dyslexia started getting easier to manage! It wasn't "cured", rather I was able to recognize when it was happening so I could take the necessary steps to recover the information it obscured.  I took Vyvance for the last 3 years of high school then stopped for 10 years. Got one job for ~3 months at a grocery store before covid hit, so life really decided that I should start over. So I did. I hit up my insurance, got ahold of a doctor, and now I'm taking Vyvance again! But 10 years without it hit hard, so I'm still recovering those good habits.

try atomoxetine it's a fairly new drug but i heard it's actually preetty good. i haven't take it myself but from what i've read and heard from other people with a fucked up mind like ours it seems to work really well.
I have some important advice for those with really bad ADHD such as myself who were once prescribed medication for it.  A lot of the time ADHD meds (in America) is just some sort of legalized low dose psuedo meth. In rare cases its outright literal low dose meth... Best to do your research on what you take. And then take into account your doctor's reason and use your new knowledge to best utilize it for yourself. It's best to ration out your pills for days where you absolutely need focus. Personally, I just learned to live with my bad ADHD. The real medication is discipline and control. Deprive yourself of impulsive needs and utilize the meds to train you to focus. When your off your meds remember the feeling and do everything you can to focus. Let it be work or someone talking. Through discipline I am able to control my ADHD.  Don't rely on meds forever as they can cause problems for you and change you. Just thank America for your legal meth and use it responsibly to instill discipline, get things, and to avoid procrastination.

idk how this works in the USA, but in where I am in Europe I am allowed to take my ADHD meds whenever I want to... and not whenever I don't. They don't stay in your system, you don't have to ease them out like antidepressants. So stopping them, or taking them only sometimes is an agreed on thing with my doctor and completely fine.

Imma do a quick talk about meds and dangerous drugs. Its random,, but bear with me. The Adderall and meth thing, I'm not a pharmacist, but I take a med that is a borderline hard-core drug. And its so weird. A part of me is annoyed that we got two meds that are supposed to help you, and then someone says "hey ya know its like taking this/its ingredients are just like that." I'm just all "why yes, and we share a lot of the same 'ingredients' with bananas." And another part is like "well, at least there's a doctor who is hopefully monitoring your progress." The medication i take is OTC Midol. And I was told again and again that Midol/Acetaminophen is like crank/has the same ingredients as crank/is used for crank. And crank isn't crack. I have no idea if this is true. But if it is, I dont care because I don't have choices when it comes to menstrual pain. Even if the first day, I feel numb/tired/high as a kite, I rather that than a pain that makes me wanna die. I know ADHD and pain are vastly different, but some people need lighter meds or stronger meds, and then saying its like this dangerous med feels... harmful? Makes ya turn paranoid a bit. Yes it can be helpful, but it really depends I guess.

Stopped that, currently on Adderall and don't really know what to do bc I'm desperate to make it work. They help but it's more like I have physical energy not the mental motivation sometimes.
7:24  "Is ThAt A mAsK rEfErEnCe?"   I hate myself for that one don't laugh....
I also have adhd and I take concerta. It helps but no one listens when I say they don‚Äôt work for me(I have a lower dose because I‚Äôm not the ‚Äústereotypical‚Äù adhd so they alway think it works because i don‚Äôt fully show symptoms that others do).
My ex also has ADHD and one day he came over to help clean and rearrange my room because it was a thing I had wanted to do for a while. He suggested I try his Ritalin while we do this because it was a quarter of the normal dosage to act as a "take as needed" type of prescription, we'd be in my home and he would be present if anything went wrong.  Before the Ritalin kicked in, I was *so apprehensive* to do anything. Like I had to *force myself* to do the bare minimum because my body and brain was that incapable of helping with *my room.* But then when it kicked in, I suddenly took charge with everything, I was going from task to task with 0 issue, and my ex had noticed and he went "How are you feeling? Are the meds helping?" And I just stopped in the middle of what I was doing and tried to "turn my thoughts off" and it *worked.* And when I went "Okay, thoughts back on" I knew *exactly* where I had left off on the task and continued about the project.  It was so funny near the end too, because his dosage was wearing off while mine was at the peak and my surge protector (florida) crapped out when moving it to a new outlet, and I needed it for my computer. Non-medicated me would've been like "Oh dang, I *guess* I can make it work with two outlets...Just gotta unplug the lamp or something. But Medicated me went "Oh, it's like 6pm. There's a hardware store 5 minutes down the road that's open until 7, lets go get a new surge protector" and my ex did the "Do we *haaaaaave* to???" And then I started going "Oh, I also need screws to fix the bedroom door hinge, and while I'm there we could get some new tools I've been needing for a hot minute."  I haven't had a chance to see a psychiatrist about medication due to being between jobs, but that experience was incredibly vindicating.
Yeah, ADHD meds were by no means a silver bullet for me.  Adderall can help me with focus, but it usually works better for motivation.  Changing my environment helped more with my focus than Adderall.

Shortness of breath like that can be a sign of a significant cardiac arrhythmia, which stimulants can cause. Not that this is medical advice, but anyone that has those symptoms when taking meds for ADHD should definitely talk with their doctor

I'm narcoleptic and have tried pretty much all of the stimulant meds, which are also used for ADHD. It's so random how they interact with each person's biology. Like, Ritalin is supposedly milder than others, but even the lowest dose made my heart feel like it was gonna explode! I currently take a medium dosage of Vyvanse and barely notice, aside from being awake. And my friend had the exact opposite experience with those 2 meds!   Finding the right med feels like playing darts blindfolded, hoping if ya just keep throwing, eventually something will land.

First time I took ADHD med (Concerta before the shortage hit), I had soo much mental clarity and focus... It was strange not having strong impulses or intrusive thoughts. It felt... freeing..? I cried because I realized that's what I'm apparently "supposed" to be like to function "normally". It took 27 years for me to understand fully why I always struggled academically and generally... all because I had undiagnosed and un-managed ADHD and ASD.  Now I'm on Vyvanse. Only issue I had on medication is the lack of appetite and the resulting fatigue from not being able to eat more than a few small bites. But my psych prescribed me to use a allergy med off label to help boost my appetite again so now I'm functioning at my best with the Vyvanse.

4:45 I heard that was a lie/misconception made up by neurotypicals/a Netflix "documentary" to prevent the ADHD uprising.
Adderall and Vyvanse are not available in my part of the world, we have methylphenidates (Ritalin, Concerta) or (lis)dexamphetamins (Tentin, Elvanse), which both sadly didn't work for me. Methylphenidate worked fine in the beginning, but I needed higher doses as the medication wore off sooner every day, somehow my body got resistant to it, and higher doses shot my blood pressure to dangerous levels. Elvanse (I think it's the same as Vyvanse) caused severe sleep deprivation and subsequent depression, and I couldn't legally drive a car while taking it, as it would turn up positive in a drug test. So I've decided to quit medication and cope with my ADHD. Which isn't easy, but since I've got diagnosed at age 52, I've been coping for a very long time.

Vyvanse is just the equivalent of time released adderall. Basically the active ingredient is still an amphetamine, but it is a kind of precursor. It is synthesized into the amphetamine salt dextroamphetamine inside your body. Basically it doesnt burn off in a couple of hours. Everyone is different but 5 mg is a low dose. It is also interesting that your doctor started you on the adderall first thing. I only know what you have mentioned here but it sounds like you are more inattentive type. Adderall will make people without hyperactivity or hyper, and people without adhd almost behave like they have adhd in my experience. You might find Ritalin more productive too. Worth a shot. Also, no medication is going to take you all the way. The meds are half the battle and then therapy

while it may be difficult to comprehend (and afford), many people with severe adhd (which requires medication AND therapy) also require a 3rd or 4th medication as well.  An important role therapy and journaling can help with is identifying obstacles which can (and often must) be overcome WITHOUT medication (as in, treated with "therapy" or "healthy habits").  A quick google search into gratitude journaling, fear locating exercises/activities, mood trackers, meditation as well as some research into the average humans circadian rhythm and metabolism should provide some useful tips and guidelines. However, when practicing good attention/focus, always keep in mind the "why".  As in, "why am I doing this?" and "is this really making me happy?" are important questions. Evene question the questions!  as we say in certain circles, "release that which does not serve you".

When you're on Vyvanse, you have to make sure to eat food and drink lots of water. It will make you feel anxious with symptoms kinda like what you described. When I say drink water, I mean actually drink a healthy amount of water. Like 8 glasses a day, plus any extra needed to account for things like salty snacks, water loss from exercising or sweating. Stuff like that.

An easier solution to symptoms if adhd is to stop mass consuming media and just focus on menial tasks that are quick to complete. Di that for about 3 months and you can start to reset your dopamine loop.   The dopamine circuit is not supposed to be constantly stimulated it is a reward mechanism to make you feel accomplished after a task and it ends with a shot of epinephrin upon completion, which releases serotonin.   So if your brain has trouble right now maintaining proper balance if dopamine, it is likely you have fried your brain with overstimulation.. social media, entertainment and whatever. 2 weeks of detachment should start the process. You ought to see gradual improvement as time goes by.   The way i see ir, adhd is a coping mechanism to stress.

what the, this is literally my story verbatim. I took Ritalin for a long time, switched to Concerta (longer lasting medication similar to vyvanse) and started to feel feel super out of breath, jittery, shakey, manic, generally horrible, and my social skills were shot dead after like 2 years of taking it with not much issue. Unlike you tho I didn't stop taking it and spent my entire first year of college living in a medicated fog before I decided to stop before starting my sophomore year. I feel great now but my ADHD is stronger than ever so that's great.  Edit: I quit Ritalin for many of the same reasons I weaned of Concerta (safely), it made me shakey, manic, and out of breath
Just recently got diagnosed but haven't gotten my meds yet, so while I wait I figured it'd be a good idea to go around actually looking at real accounts of how ADHD meds work for people and I'm honestly so discouraged because 90% of them are "oh I was taking them for a bit and they worked great, and then problems happened so I'm not on medication anymore." My whole entire life I've just been dealing with everything collapsing around me because of all of these symptoms, and then I'm told I can get medication so I spend literal years trying to get an official diagnosis and when I finally get one it's just like "yeah there's a big chance this medication isn't going to really help long term"???? I've worked so hard to get to this point, and the only thing that's been really getting me through it all is knowing that by the end I'd be able to get medication that will make me actually function the way I'm supposed to for once in my life, and now I'm hearing from so many people that it might not even do that or it might even make things worse. If meds don't work, what am I even supposed to do at this point?? I can't carry on like this, I'm too tired.
this video is so validating <3 i'm twenty and i was diagnosed with adhd this summer after failing/withdrawing from multiple classes in college. originally, i was put on strattera and had VERY very adverse mental side effects. eventually i was put on adderal and it's WILD how much change there's been. my room's cleaner than it's been in probably ten years, i can actually sit and write an esasy, and the strange dissociated haze i've been living in has become clearer. the stigma still makes me overthink and question if taking "m3th" is worth it in the long run, but it's going good for now :)

You may not have adhd bro. All the stuff you described on the meds is  how it is to have adhd. The hyper focus from the second pills and the task focus is just regular meth focus. I go through cycles of both without the meds. In the meth meds, I can act on my mental plans. They are no longer separate processes and my memory/time recognition get a lot better.
that is such an apt description of how adderall works though it's. the effect is very understated compared to other stimulants.
Yeah, cold turkeying your meds is bad. I blacked out while driving over a rail bridge on a corner. I'm lucky it only lasted two seconds and I didn't side swipe the barrier or the bus beside me. Heck I didn't even go cold turkey, I had bad rapport with my psych, then I lost trust after being coerced into taking antidepressants after a mental breakdown he caused, so I took my meds, halved them, then took half of them and halved them again. Still wasn't a slow enough reduction in medication to prevent side effects and it still took another 30 months to return to "normal".  Spoke with an in training GP and she said it was most likely caused by a sudden blood pressure drop, which is a common thing when cutting off antidepressant meds.
This really reminds me of a lot about my experience with ADHD, but instead I decided to not take meds for the first few years (I was diagnosed as an adult, and the doctor I was working with didn't press meds after I first tried them and decided against them) In that time, I tried other ways of helping myself focus like biking and exercise, eating properly, etc. I was also just spending a lot of time reading the articles and literature that was out there to find about studying and forming habits with ADHD. Exercise, like 30 minutes of cardio exercise, would put me in that "to-do" state of mind, where I could just "do". And it would last up to 4 hours or so. It was the best time to read all the stuff at that point, because it was easy to study. Cleaning wasn't as easy after a 7k run though. Also, while heavy exercise can have benefits, it can come with its own longterm problems. I like having something I can take now that's mellow and helps me clean, but having it combined with the knowledge of how to take care of the body health stuff has been great. Tunnel vision is a bitch though, don't be afraid to explore what the options are out there.
Adderal contains Dexamphetamin and Lisamphetamin, each in two different forms. Vyvance only contains Lys-Dexamphetamin, which is Lysin (aminoacid) bound to Dexamphetamin. The Lysin gets metabolized off the dexamphetamine which takes a while, so vyvance takes a little longer to flood in. good for dosing purpose. good for longer lasting effect. But the substances are working the same. Lisamphetamin is activating another receptor stronger then Dexamphetamin, but Dexamphetamin is over all the most potent Enantiomer of all amphetamin. Methamphetamin is not effectively adderal and if we want it to bring it on that level then all Amphetamin-based medication is effectively speed. But its not. Methylphenidate for example is a Dopamine and Noradrenaline re-absorption inhibitor. While Dexamphetamin also has the ability to actively cause a release of that neurotransmitters. I like Methylphenidat better than Dexamphetamin but everybody needs to know their best working drug as their treatment.

Yea so Vyvanse _is_ adderrall.. It's just the "prodrug" version. Its' little balls inside are half metabolized by your liver for the "delayed" and "slow burn" and the other half of those balls are essentially aderall IR. I also felt way too focused/zombified on Vyvanse and at the first with Adderall too. It took many weeks to get past that side effect. But if you're having cardiac/pulminary issues then.. yea.. don't do that. xD  Wellbutrin (non-stimulant) has worked the best for me but I can't deal with the side effects. Best grades I've ever gotten and was more "in the pilot seat" than I've ever been in my life.
Can‚Äôt IMAGINE someone calling Vyvans ‚Äúmellow.‚Äù That stuff hit me like a truck and made me feel horrible. ‚ÄúToo much focus‚Äù sounds about right really. Like, brain still going at ADHD speed, but in one single direction so it‚Äôs like a free-fall.   I know I lost at least an entire day to planning a house. Like, looking up incline angles for stairs and everything. I do not own a house or have nearly enough money to ever own one.
I do all the things that you said are symptoms, does that mean I have adhd?
Vyvanse helped me start tasks, complete tasks and focus. Having alarms set as reminders, having a checklist and routine plus my Vyvanse made all the difference for me. Only problem is I had to significantly reduce my caffeine intake because I would get significant chest pain that would radiate through my back into my shoulder up to my jaw which symbolized a heart attack so I talked to my doctor and we did  blood work, EKGs, X-rays,  we did an Echo(ultrasound)of my heart, and I wore a ZIO patch (heart monitor) for like 3-4days and all came back normal especially and so he asked me to reduce my caffeine intake to see if that helped and it did so I just have to be careful about my stimulant intake (caffeine).
stopping meds that are harming you isn't bad
If you hadn't found out, vyvanse and adderall are the same drug, just in different forms. But they both turn into dextroamphetamine in your body and that's what has an effect on your brain, neither is meth but they are similar in structure and effect. It seems like you were on too high of a dose of the vyvanse or your bodies metabolism didn't mix well with that mechanism of delivery and it starting building up in your system. There are other drugs like wellbutrin that aren't explicitly stimulants  The thing a lot of people don't understand about adhd(even profesionals) is that it's not just about treating the symptoms. The symptoms of adhd also lead to bad habits, behaviors and thought patterns. Just because you remove the reinforcement of those things with meds doesn't mean the resulting issues get immediately fixed too. And most importantly it takes work, if you don't try to behave differently you probably won't, meds or no meds, counseling or no counseling. The flip side is that kind of change often takes years and is easy to give up on because the results are hard to notice.

Alright, slight disclaimer for Vivance as someone who took it while they were young.  Vivance is a depressant, the best way to describe from my experience is that instead of catching you up to your brain it slows your brain activity just a tad to make it way more manageable and allow you to focus as Ice Cream states in the video, and like he states it's sometimes WAY TOO MUCH focus on what can sometimes be the wrong thing. This doesn't only include physical/external tasks but psychological ones as well and as such I recommend ensuring you or a loved one you know who is considering taking Vivance to make sure that they're in a good place mentally before taking it on a regular basis as it can cause you/them to spiral further into a depression by hyper fixating on horrible shit.  Lastly it may sometimes also causes you to feel exhausted/apathetic which Ice Cream touched on in the video, so yes it was a side-effect.
Vivance has a side effect of decreasing your appetite so you don‚Äôt eat you might have not had enough energy and that‚Äôs why you felt like that cus you weren‚Äôt eating u just didn‚Äôt realize. And I go  the whole day without eating and I won‚Äôt even realize.
For me (every ADHD person is different) building habits and using tricks as ringtones and a lot of planning was enough for many problems, but atomoxetine (which I take daily) helped me with indecisiveness and metylophenidate (which I take sometimes) helps me with concentration and makes all ma social anxiety disappear which is AWESOME. All these different meds didn't do shit and therapy helped a lot (especially with borderline), but there were still things I couldn't beat and here it is - ADHD medication <3

One thing that helped me was to sit on my desk doing something I want related to the thing I have to finish and after I sit down take the medicine. When I feel it kick in is when I switch to what I really have to do. In this way I have an easier transition. You definitely have to have techniques to channel the focus to take the most out of it.
I was diagnosed with ADHD and tourretes when I was 8, and forced to take meds. I can't take meds anymore because they make me super anxious and make me feel like I'm someone else, and I never wanted them in the first place. Part way through college, I remember deciding that I had to figure out how to live without meds, because they were making me miserable. Since then, I've only tried meds again when whatever company I worked at complained about productivity, which just made the anxiety worse when I took them. The problem is I've never seen a problem with me, and I don't think it's a weakness that I only focus on things I care about. It helps me to determine what's really important to me.

For those who don't like the idea of pharmaceuticals: look into microdosing Amanita Muscaria. (yes, the red and white mushroom). I've been microdosing it for other reasons, and to my surpise, i could _enjoy work_ all of the sudden. Lost the endless thinking over and procrastination too! Of course, do good research! Often times natural medicines are a bit more 'kind' to our bodies compared to the mass produced ones (no heavy withdrawals or long term damage when used correctly).   And remember: the reason a doctor will probably reccomend advil over chamomile when you have a headache is because it's very hard to make money off of plants (you can't patent themü´†).  (some background from me: i believe in both the modern medicine and the traditional plant medicine world and think they should go hand in hand. No crazy 'you broke a leg here drink some tea' from meüòÖ)

I have ADHD
I have these symptoms
Meds (Ritalin) have ruined my brain for real. I feel more stupid than I was. Slow thinker, my sleep schedule got DESTROYED ASF As a kid, prior to taking Ritalin I had 160 IQ measured by the government's requirement back then.  I feel like I've lost huge chunk of my intellect. (The Ritalin was banned later).
My biggest issue with having ADHD mostly involves how other people react to it/treat me for having it. When unmedicated, I am viewed as lazy, spacey, and people always think I am mad/closed off. When medicated, I do great around people, until they *find out* I am medicated. The stigma behind ADHD medication being on the same level as a certain hard-drug (we all know the one) creates such an ignorant view in some people. My family gets inpatient when I am unmedicated; but when I am medicated, they call me a "tweaker", even though I will literally just be doing laundry finally, or cooking a full meal, or finally trying that game i bought last month. Its hard because I will go long periods without taking it just because it hurts so much to hear them say that. just  sometimes i dont have the mental capacity to hear them say that and be fine.
The meds have helped me focus a lot but the good news is that the voices and internal council remained for me
Recent told I have ADHD. Somethings ti note for others in thr comments is ADHD affects women differently to men, ie women suffer depression from ADHD so if you start taking meds it may improve things like depression rather than give you focus. You also need to be having therapy to learn how to manager your symptoms. Ny doctor explained meds are only half fhe battle, others things like managing symptoms and accepting symptoms is the other half of the battle too.

Stimulants (like Adderall, Vyvanse, and Ritalin) aren't the only options for medication. There are also non-stimulant medication possibilities.  For example, you can try Strattera, guanfacine, Wellbutrin, or clonidine.
Quick comment to note that those symptoms at the end very well could have been serotonin syndrome. Not diagnosing, but rather stating because serotonin syndrome is, like, go to the emergency room level bad if left alone and more people should be aware of it, especially when taking stimulants.
So I know this video is 8 months old and don't expect any reply but I  just watched this and wanted to say when I was diagnosed in March this year with inattentive type ADHD at fucking 30! I was started on Vyvanse first at 30mg which after a couple days had a significantly positive effect on motivation, focus, impulsiveness and memory (seriously a fucking goldfish had me beat here!) But knew there was still room for improvement so I get put on 50mg with... Some more improvement but still thought I could improve myself more. So I go up to 60mg, but when I got to 60 I had the same side effects you described and a few more for two weeks, so I went back down to 50mg and everything is fine. Oh wait... Nevermind, psychiatrist that diagnosed me also said he's fairly certain that I may also be autistic but would require several visits to a behavioural specialist to confirm diagnosis.   Edit: I also wanted to add, all the side effects you mentioned you experienced on Vyvanse (especially the hyperfocus) are clear signs of your dose being too high, did your psych even explain to you to before they prescribed it to look out for these side effects?! If not I suggest you find another psychologist (he/she is a fucking idiot) and give Vyvanse another try but at a lower dose. The goal is to find the highest dose you can tolerate not to reach highest dose available to that medication.
I, too, have ADHD. I began taking medication when I was about 12. I began on Vyvanse, which really helped me with focus and productivity. It was great, except for the fact that I constantly had no appetite,  intense mood swings, and just general personality changes that made me feel like I was a different person on Vyvanse. The thing with Vyvanse is it does it‚Äôs job, but the effects lessen over time. So, you can either choose to increase the dose that you take, or you can choose to not take it on the days that you don‚Äôt need to be productive. (I wouldn‚Äôt recommend this with most medications, but it‚Äôs usually okay to do with Vyvanse.) Unfortunately this means increased side effects every time I did take it, causing me to just not eat for days until I was hungry enough to lower my standards to what food I want to eat. So after a few years, I stopped taking it, which made me feel like myself again. However, my procrastination and inattentiveness came back. Since then, I have started on Journay. Journay sort of helps motivate me, but it doesn‚Äôt make me productive. It just kinda makes my inside voice tell me to do something, but it doesn‚Äôt make me want to do it. It just kind of feels like a watered-down Vyvanse, if you know what I mean.
All the medication gives me depression and sleeping problems all of them

My experience with ADHD meds has been pretty mixed. The first one I tried cased an immediate difference that my middle school teachers noticed instantly.  But I kept getting pretty back migraines, nausea, and motion sickness.  My second one (a patch I‚Äôd put on my hip every morning) was working fine at first, but I lost my appetite completely and even ended up loosing weight. On top of that, it slowly stopped helping with my ADHD.  Taking bigger doses helped that, but the effects would fade away. Eventually, I was taking the largest offered dose with minimal impact on my ADHD. Then I tried taking caffeine tablets (I don‚Äôt like caffeinated things. I can‚Äôt stand the taste) and that just made me sleepy. Now I‚Äôm taking Aderal, and while it seems to not have any side effects, I‚Äôm having the problem of being locked into whatever it is I‚Äôm doing when the meds kick in

protip: both the act of chewing + the act of eating releases mega mega mega dopamine and since we ADHDers have to kind of hack our dopamine, it's a great way to help you focus. gum is one method a lot of people use without even realizing it, but consider little snacks (especially something like pistachios that are high in protein ((bc apparently we need more of that too??)) and has a process to open it up so our hands are busy) while you're working on anything particularly difficult to focus on

Suddenly stopping certain meds can cause withdrawal. Have a few friends who for whatever reason, dealt with this- from stopping due to a side effect to just running out, to going on vacation and forgetting them. It‚Äôs not fun. I‚Äôm glad you didn‚Äôt have any issues, from what it seemed you were having much worse physical health symptoms and tbh your medical doc should have stepped in- at the very least to contact your psychiatrist, while not their specialty primary docs should understand at the very least the symptoms, side effects, and how to get a patient off any psychiatric medication.
Be careful because adhd medications especially adderall and a lot of times is used when not necessary. It is a very powerful drug and should only be used in the most severe of cases.
Can't believe it took me this long to find this, but god damn is this the shit for me. I've been dealing with a new ADHD diagnosis for the majority of this year, and BOY does this cover a lot of big points.  I think the big thing to note is that in my circumstance, I was already seeing a therapist specifically to try to help identify and control some of my ADHD tendencies. So not only has that been a guiding principle, but it's also helped frame medication as PART of the solution, instead of THE solution. For me, I've been on Adderall (XR, for those curious) and that's been working well for me.   The whole Problem A, B, C, D, E... so on thing was one of the biggest things it helped solve, but more than that I found the whole being able to do things a MASSIVE improvement for me, even when it came to mental tasks. A lot of that wasn't because of the meds, but because the meds helped me break through enough of the other barriers in my life that it gave me the confidence to commit myself to more mentally taxing chores and things. Which, especially because I'm a programmer, is nice.   It's still a struggle, and I'm realizing I kind of need to re-learn how I learn things as growing up with undiagnosed ADHD meant I never really developed study habits or means to learn through struggle all that well, but that's what the therapy is for.  I know this video is getting old by this point, but I wanted to add my story to the list of comments because everyone can have a very different experience, and sometimes when you're looking for help, following one example can lead to frustration, especially when it doesn't work out the way you expect it to. In my case, medication with targeted therapy has been a godsend. For someone else, they might be totally useless. Or, there might be someone receiving medication, but still struggling to make use of it because they don't have that extra step of therapy to help them figure out how to.  I just hope this can help someone out there, even if it just gives them a little more perspective, or even just validates their experience a bit. Much love to all my neurodivergent fam out there <3

Fun fact: Adderall, chemically, is a mixture of Amphetamine salts and Dextroampetamine, making it chemically similar to Methamphetamine (Meth). In addition, Meth technically falls under Schedule II of the Controlled Substances Act meaning it can indeed be prescribed by a doctor to treat, you guessed it, ADHD (and Narcolepsy) since it‚Äôs a Central Nervous System stimulant like Adderall

But soon after, I found out through my dad who is a youth counselor, with the Concerta it could cause you to focus so much on certain things that it can cause you to have anxiety attacks. Which happened to me constantly, which along with my nana passing, caused me to stop eating and I became Hypoglycemic. Which amplified the attacks up to 11. Im on 2 anxiety meds with the ADHD meds and I am all good. I still have eating issues though.

I used to take vyvanse, but it made me unable to sleep since i took it right before work. It made me want too work too much. Also, the sudden side effects is because you are taking metabolizable meth. It makes you dependent on the medication, which is the top risk for Vyvanse. I do not recommend these meds.
Not a doctor, but I do take Vyvanse, and some other psych meds, and your symptoms sound more like an anxiety attack, related to the anxiety around the unproductivity, versus an actual side effect of Vyvanse.  Again. NOT a doctor, but I am pretty familiar with anxiety, and ADD like symptoms, as I have combat related PTSD, and a traumatic brain injury (the latter being the reason I take Vyvanse, as my ability to focus is impaired). I'd probably consider talking to an actual doctor, about either switching meds, or adding an anti-anxiety medication to your regimen. Yes, taking a bunch of meds sucks, but the quality of life, if you need the meds, going without, feels like lost time, in the long run.

i describe my Adderall as a kindergarten teacher corralling all my thoughts into an orderly line. its more effective than complete anarchy, but kindergarteners can only be organized for so long before they lose it. plus it takes a LOT of energy. im exhausted by the end of the day with an XR. my psych writes me an instant release Adderall script every 3 months, and I take those short terms instead of an XR on days where I might only have a couple errands to do instead of a whole work day. and on weekends where i dont have to do anything? I dont take my meds :p it's refreshing to have those days when I can just let my brain work how it does naturally. but also, being able to function is increible.

I'm currently taking medication for my migraines and (if you wish to know details, the backstory will be below) I've been just pushing through the side effects that are starting to wear on me because it feels like 'well its better than without the medicine and its better than what the last one did to me'. But your final comment makes me really realize that I need to have a talk with my doctor about it. You're right. There's more to taking medication than results only.  Backstory: I've always had chronic migraine (inherited through my mother's side of the family. None of the entire family on that side has escaped the migraines). I was diagnosed with it when I was 7 and was able to manage them with over-the-counter medication as needed. Things changed a little when I started my period, but the migraines were still manageable. Now, when I got married. That. Is when everything changed. I started taking birth control and suddenly whenever I got a migraine, it would last for a week. To my own mind, it wasn't super crazy since I did get them for days sometimes, but they were manageable. After a while though, I began to realize that as soon as one migraine ended, a new one would start by the next day. So finally I went to my doctor and she prescribed me a medication at a low dose that seemed like a good starting place. And for a week, it worked great! Then I was supposed to up my dose ever so slightly. Which is where I almost went blind. O.O Needless to say, I was told to immediately stop taking that medication. So now I've got a new prescription that I take as a rescue medication when I feel a bad one coming on. I'm supposed to be taking it anytime I need it, but...sometimes the side effects are worse than the actual migraine. To the point that I end up just...dealing with the migraine instead of taking my prescription.  So yeah, all in all, I think I'll take your advice and see what my next steps are with my doctor üòÖ

Junior neuroscientist here with unmedicated ADHD. I choose to be unmedicated because I feel like society needs to change. It‚Äôs somewhat futile but I don‚Äôt think we should be so focused on everyday steam-train output  and medicating children and adults. Instead I think we should diversify school, learning tasks and work to remain interesting, engaging and go off of people‚Äôs individual strengths. I really believe ADHD is considered a ‚Äúdisorder‚Äù only because we have such a narrow perspective of what should be normal and how we should operate as humans when in reality, why WOULDNT we have phenotypically different brains? Our genes vary naturally and humans have specialized in brain power- of course there are going to be vast differentiations as a result. It‚Äôs actually awesome and we shouldn‚Äôt have to medicate ourselves at the expense of our health just to be able to produce constant results. Adhd people are awesome and have our place in all disciplines. We just have to be able to do it OUR way.

ADHD treatment requires extensive cognitive behavioral therapy WHILE you have medication. A therapist should work with you on creating good habits, improving your organizational skills and executive function WHILE you take meds. The meds themselves won‚Äôt solve the problem.   Been on meds and in therapy for about 1.5 years now, made HUGE strides.

I wasted 3 years trying every alternative for my kid because I was really scared of meds "changing their brain" and whatnot. I had to hit the lowest of lows before I begrugingly said "fine... I guess we have to try it. Sad face." And omg we should have done it sooner! They're finally making friends, thriving in school, it's been fantastic and they're so much happier. We did have to go through a process of increasing the dose a few times until it seemed to hit a good spot, and we take weekends and summer break "off" so they can reset their tolerances to the medications. But to me it sounds like your 5 mg just wasn't a high enough dose? (obligatory not a doctor here) My kid's on 20mg.  Yes it's basically "meth" but basically your brain is going ten million miles a minute and they need your body to catch up with it. It's *balancing* you. I don't see that as a bad thing, my body needs other medications so I don't bleed to death and I'm sure as heck not going to stop taking them even if a normal person taking the same thing would be bad. We're not normal. We need medical aid to do normal body things. =P

TLDR; Talk to doctor about stopping your adhd meds cus you could get uber depresso if you just stop  One of the most important things about using ADHD medication is to make sure you talk to the doctor if you're going to stop taking it. If you've been medicated for a long time continuously then stopping can cause you to have severe depression. Many kids graduating high school and stopping their meds will find themselves extremely sad and depressive, and sometimes even worse than standard depression. My brother graduated high school 7 years before me and was still taking mood stabilizers when I told him I found out why I was such a mess coming out of school and he went, "oh that sounds like what I dealt with."

My ADHD was caught VERY early, and I got extensive therapy for it, so much so that my dosage hadn't been increased since I was in kindergarten because I mainly lean on the coping mechanisms my therapists taught me since I was 6 years old.  My dosage was so low that I was able to come off them immediately recently without any side effects.   I'm an example of the luxury Gen Z has when it comes to their disorders, which is that ours are caught early and are treated early.

I can focus on things that I am interested in with incredible focus, but the moment I am required to do or learn anything I don't really want to, my brain is like "Time to focus on a billion different things and be as unproductive as possible!". I took ritalin as a child, aka, methylphenidate, but eventually I just straight up stopped taking them. I hated these meds. They did exactly what I wanted them to do, but I felt like a gun that was put a suppressor onto, or a water hose that someone was stepping on. I was everything everyone wanted me to be, but I was still not in control. Unfortunately for me, something that me and my family realized a few years ago, is that I may also be somewhere on the autism spectrum. Not straight up Asperger's, but I am most probably somewhere on the spectrum. So I don't know how that is affecting my ADHD or the meds I was taking for it. I thought about getting meds again, but before I do, I should probably get myself tested for autism spectrum disorder.

Stimulants were a miracle for the first 3 days and.. then a nightmare. I took Vyvanse and Concerta (SEPARATELY, ON DIFFERENT OCCASIONS) and it was like the fog in my mind had finally cleared. I hyperfocused on work for hours, but so hard that I had limited interactions with others because I was so impatient to work more. This made me Really Depressed (though I think the meds also did that). Why is this vid so goddamm quiet compared to all the other vids
vyvance and adderal are very closely related. Adderal is made of two drugs, amphetamine and dextroamphetamine, while vyvance *lys* dexamphetamine. The thing is, lysdexamphetamine gets turned into dextroamphetamine. The lys gets removed pretty much. Your still taking drugs chemically related to meth, but if you watch NileRed (you should, he‚Äôs great) you should know that chemicals used to create plastic gloves can be slightly changed and can be used to make hot sauce. So just because they‚Äôre slightly similar, doesn‚Äôt mean they do the same thing at all. (Im serious though, he has an entire 1hour long video where he goes through the process of turning a chemical used in some forms of plastic gloves into a chemical used in a lot of hot sauces. And then he does a taste test to see if it was spicy. Im not joking)  Also, I‚Äôm not a medical professional (I‚Äôm still studying, and I‚Äôm studying *para*medicine at that), but if you decide that you want to try medication again, I‚Äôd say that you should ask your doctor about trying out non-stimulant medications or non-serotonin medication such as Strattera, as the symptoms you were describing sounded a lot like serotonin syndrome.

I had the same out of breath problem you had with vyvanse! My issue was with focalin, but it turned out that I was having heart issues from it. (Nothing life threatening or anything, it was ok). I recommend SSRIs, or selective serotonin re-uptake inhibitors. They‚Äôre a type of antidepressant that can be used to treat ADHD because serotonin helps with stabilizing mood and with focus (much like dopamine!) and SSRIs prevent your brain from cleaning up serotonin as quickly, meaning you have more of it. However, they can cause drowsiness, so I‚Äôd recommend taking them in the evenings before bed. Sorry if this was too nosy lol, I also have ADHD and struggle with social boundaries. I just wanted to put stuff out here for people who are struggling with ADHD. A great channel for help is How to ADHD!

My favorite thing about ADHD is hyperfocus. I‚Äôm interested in a wide variety of things, so hyperfocus often works in my favor and I learned to wield it pretty well. Also, hyperfocus has made me into a kick butt Mario kart machine! (And it resulted in getting left behind at a water park on a field trip ‚Ä¶ that one wasn‚Äôt great :/)
Adderall is NOT meth! They are both stimulants, as is caffeine, but they are NOT the same. The main difference is that Adderall is taken with the guidance of a professional, and you take it regularly without stopping suddenly. In fact, Adderall makes some people less likely to get addicted to meth, because meth is often a form of self-medication people try when they don‚Äôt have prescription medications! So no, Adderall is not meth. This is one of the many myths that actively harms people with ADHD. Can it be a problem if you abuse it? Yeah. So can literally any medication. That doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs meth.
I‚Äôve been diagnosed with ADHD when I was really young, but I thought it wasn‚Äôt right, turns out it‚Äôs Autism and ADHD üòÖ
When I first got diagnosed with adhd I started taking concerta. It boosted my attention span massively. Where before I could study for 45 min I could now study for 2 hours straight without a break. But as time moved on and my dose got higher I started getting side effects‚Ä¶ I lost all appetite and as a result lost 7 kilograms. At this point I was underweight I could focus anymore, had constant headaches and lots of panic attacks. Fortunately we switched to stratera which works so much better for me and I have zero side effects.   Adhd meds do help, you just need to find the right ones for you.

Dude this is so real, when I first got diagnosed it was basically just finding what worked right for me. Adderall worked great for me and I was both productive and focused but it was so hard to get where i live that i had to try a alternative. I tried Straterra or however you spell it and it had a really weird reaction. When the chemical was more in my system after taking my day's dose I went into this hyper relax airhead state and felt one of my senses be like hyper mode like one day i felt everything that was touching me in super detail and another was taste or smell. But overall it made my depression wayyyyyy worse so i had to stop that. I've been taking Methylfentidate now which has been working pretty good for the most part with most of the same benefits of addreall but also felt a bit more natural like if I were to have a moment where i relaxed adderall would like make me an airhead again but the new one just felt normal. Overall great video though and its interesting how different people react to this stuff while dealing with ADHD.

I don‚Äôt know if I have autism or ADHD
Take guanfacine, Guanfacine is an ADHD medication that helps you focus enough to be able to do normal physical and mental tasks, AND you have an appetite using it! Meaning you eat normally AND you do everything like a normal person! Unlike SOME medications, like Concerta and such. Guanfacine makes you have low blood pressure and makes you sleepy, that is why you take it at night.
Yeah ADHD meds can be pretty tricky to find the right one for you. I was lucky enough to briefly work with a psychiatrist who had literally spent decades researching ADHD medications, trying to figure out if there is some sort of indication as to what medication might work best for a certain demographic or people with certain traits. And turns out, they have found NONE. All they have found is it is SUPER unique to each person as to what will work for them or not. You literally have to just try different kinds and at different dosages (working with a medical professional ofc!) until you find which one you feel works for you best. And yes, the process can be tedious and long. But it can also be VERY worth to find what actually helps you most!   For example, two people can react very differently to the SAME ADHD medication. Like for me, Adderall worked in the sense that I could FOCUS on a given task and get it done. But the problems with it for me were that I couldn‚Äôt really control WHAT that task was‚Äîit was just whatever was in front of me to do. It also made my anxiety works, gave me chest discomfort/feeling of palpitations, numbed my emotions, made me feel less myself. I was then switched to Concerta and Ritalin, and it has been AMAZING. I actually have control over WHERE my attention goes, my emotions feel more regulated, and if anything I feel more like myself. The things that I have so long wanted to do or things I just need to do, I have MUCH more of an ability to actually follow through with them now. It‚Äôs amazing.   Medication is not a cure, though. I still have challenges because ADHD is literally a difference in how the brain is structured and its neurotransmitter systems. But it is a VERY helpful tool for many people with ADHD, often in combination with other things like talk therapy, building habits, planners, calendars, etc. For me and many, medication makes it much more POSSIBLE to actually USE these other tools!   Best of luck to everyone out there on their own medication/treatment journeys. Don‚Äôt give up, you got this <3

Hi üòÆ
The super sticky focus is precisely my experience with Vyvanse. Thankfully, I did not have many side effects that were totally debilitating (aside from complete lack of appetite for the first 1-2 months) but the sticky focus...... it's like having hands covered in syrup, everything you touch sticks... but it's focus. I think the important thing to remember is that meds don't mean you no longer have ADHD, they just alter how your focus works in a way that, in the right environment, would be more productive. Occupational Therapy, adjusting your work environment, social media timers on you phone etc. is absolutely critical with these things.  ALSO - on a side note, I have heard on numerous reports and forums that the formulation changed slightly and effected people differently.  I certainly had an impact off of this change, I went from being quite comfortable on 50mg to it practically putting me to sleep.

i would segest bifenton it helps me foces and it is a short time one so you can also feed like yourself
Taking meds has gotten an interesting experience for me. When I used to take meds for ADHD it would always work good in the beginning but would trickle down. And for most of them actually made me feel weak. For example not hungry when I haven‚Äôt eaten for a while, feeling nauseous, etc. eventually I took a med that I thought would do something but ended up not doing much but without the side effects. It made me realize I don‚Äôt need meds and unlike most people could still get work done, yet slower than others, but I could understand people and learn and when thrown with info I can take it in. Part of that I blame of being young and my neurons are still being made so I‚Äôm physically taking in information and keeping it in my mind. But I still see it as me being ok without trying to stop this ADHD.
I truly hope you're able to find something that works for you. Whether that be the right medication which lets you focus on what you're doing while also aiming that focus where it's needed or if you're able to find other methods of managing distractions, you deserve to live your life in a way that you don't feel like your own brain is working against you.

I just went to the hospital yesterday because of withdrawal from my medication (my pharmacy had a communication issue with my doctor) and Lemme tell you withdrawal is no bueno
In case anyone else struggles with being eventually worn out by adhd meds: talk to your doc about taking regular breaks. They leave your system quickly and for most ppl withdrawal is mostly tireness/fatigue - but this makes it possible to sleep, rest and recharge. Personally I need about 1 med free day a week, and it might be something to try before throwing the idea of meds completely out the window

I was taking the wrong meds for about 7 years until I just quit. They made me feel like a zombie and I kept getting used to them and upping the dose. By the time I quit I was taking 35 grams of something and was suffering from extreme anxiety and due to the high dose I ended up developing a tic disorder that I wouldn‚Äôt have had otherwise. I took a much much lower dose for a while after my doc told me that the meds could cause the tics and I eventually just quit. Only thing I regret is the fact that ‚Äúfeeling like a zombie‚Äù on adhd meds is a sign that you need to a) lower the dose or b) change meds and when I was a child I had to deal with that everyday. I took me one google search to find this out so I know both my doc and parents didn‚Äôt care enough to see if something was wrong. My meds helped me go from Ds to Bs and As but I could have been doing so much better mentally. Always google your and your childrens meds, understand all the symptoms and know what shouldn‚Äôt be a symptom. Listen to yourself and you body and listen to you kids. Don‚Äôt tell them ‚Äúthey‚Äôre not themselves‚Äù when they‚Äôre not on their meds especially if they complain about them. It‚Äôs crushing to hear that the you that makes you feel horrible is the you everyone loves.

Just to let people know (as someone who took Vyvanse for most of their school life) those symptoms are very common. This is because Vyvanse is an appetite suppressor, and a stimulant. It makes you run on more material while also making you have less material.   Ex: a microwave needs more electricity than your old one and a power line went out.  I do agree with him though for getting off of the meds, but yes, unless you are actually getting physically sick from being on them, stay on the meds until you are told to go off.

Hii there. I think it is really cool and great from you to talk openly about this topic. A lot of people are really scared of meds and to talk about adhd in general. I also have ADHD and i was diagnosed when i was in first grade. i took meds from a young age already and i have expierience with different types of meds. from my personal experience: i startet with Ritalin and it worked for a while but my body started to feel weird when i was a teenager. then i changed to Elvanse and i'm still taking it until this day (I'm 22 now). Elvanse starts slowly and leaves slowly, so you don't really feel a hit. and a really good tip from my side: only take the meds on the days you need them, so on weekends or holidays you can easily skip them, so your body can do it's normal stuff again. If you have any questions otherwise, just let me know. i studied a lot about ADHD and also did a looooot of research. hope this could help you or others :)

Okay so I know that basically no one is gonna see this but it's fine. So I'm 14 and I have adhd and prescribed medication for it. To help me focus I take methylphenidate in the day and at night I take clonidine. The night medicine works fine and the day medicine worked for a while, but it always made me feel weird. Like 2-3 years ago my family started to notice that I act differently when I'm on the medication and that's when I realized that the medication would give me really bad anxiety. The problem is, I needed the medicine to focus but when I'm on the medicine I start worrying about everything, but at the same time it makes me feel happier kinda? When i told my doctor/ the person who prescribes my medication, he asked if it effected my everyday life and when I said yes, he straight up told me "No it doesn't because if it is then you would have noticed it before" . So I stopped taking that medicine after 8th grade year and went all of 9th grade without it.  Surprise surprise,  I couldn't focus on my schoolwork and procrastinated everything and failed. So yeah. Sorry for this kinda vent I'm on it right now and I felt like I needed to get it off my chest lol.

Vyvanse is Lisdexamphetamine, it's just Dextro isomer Amphetamine with a lysine molecule added to it. The lysine molecule has to be cleaved off by your liver on its first pass through your metabolism. Releasing Dextroamphetamine which is one of the primary ingredients in Adderall. The dextro isomer is responsible for cognitive effects (euphoria, concentration), the levo isomer is more physical effects (racing heart, vasoconstriction/the shitty effects) Vyvanse is just basically fancier purer meth. Adderall has that levo isomer Amphetamine left in to make it less abuseable as taking too much makes you miserable. Amphetamine by weight is about 1/3rd as potent as methamphetamine. All stimulants really do is release norepinephrine which triggers release of adrenaline, which causes a temporary (during the duration of the drugs action) fight or flight response, and they release fuck tons of dopamine, which makes you think everything you're doing is great and that makes you want to continue with even the most mundane tasks. It also creates an illusory sense that whatever you're doing is absolutely great due to the dopamine high, when it typically is somewhere between garbage and what you were capable of before taking stimulants.

polish cow.
I was diagnosed pretty early as a kid, like grade school 7th grade. I was first put on Ritalin, and it was so many pills every day, multiple times a day with different amounts each time. So I eventually moved to Concerta. It worked and I only had to use 1 pill per day, as opposed to Ritalin of 4-5 pills per day.   For my results, it was good, mostly. I really had to listen though, and I could really tell when the medication was wearing off, so I had to get stuff done before it ended. Sometimes I would take a Ritalin before late homework, but that was a mistake. There is no sleeping with these meds.   Also this is something that they won‚Äôt tell you, but most of the time behavioral symptoms of ADHD will still persist. If you were still forgetting people‚Äôs names or tasks, you‚Äôre still likely to do it again, just slightly less often.   I eventually weaned off of it in college when I found that my stress was shooting through the cracks, and the meds did not help me think through my problems. I didn‚Äôt study, I didn‚Äôt adjust, I could only stress out and become paralyzed. Once I went off my meds, it actually got better. Without my meds, I stopped stressing myself out about my grades or anxiety. It sounds weird, but it was my stress that was causing me to be paralyzed and unable to work through my problems like homework or studying. You wouldn‚Äôt believe how useful it is to not focus on your stress.   After that, I adjusted to living without my medication. It brought out a lot of my social issues, like speaking with no filter. I‚Äôve had to build that filter manually from scratch. (Which is also why I don‚Äôt like getting high, my filter goes away and I hate that feeling). But I am a functioning adult with 2 dogs, a house, and a full job as an engineer. I haven‚Äôt been on medication for about 10 years now, and I wouldn‚Äôt go back.

Funny how Desoxyn is literally brand name Methamphetamine.
I struggled with making good habits around my ADHD meds as well. A couple things that really helped my meds to be more effective for my particular situation were: 1. taking my meds earlier in the morning. I was previously taking them around 9:00 AM, but then switched to taking them at 7:00 AM (when I woke up), and found that their efficacy drastically improved. This is probably because in general I'm a morning person, and so taking the meds in the morning helped me get the most work done. 2. worked on my habits with a therapist. I was already going to a therapist, and one of my goals was to improve time management and get better at tackling difficult tasks. This is generally not a habit that can be formed instantaneously, but rather takes practice and discipline, two qualities I had a lot of anxiety around. Working on that anxiety and building new habits around how I approach the problems of practice and discipline really helped the med to do its work.

awesome explanation of adhd ‚ù§
just to add to the meth thing, actually adderall has amphetamine as its active substance. amph is much much weaker than methamphetamine. vyvanse is lisdexamphetamine which is an artificially made prodrug that has no effect at all, that is until metabolized and converted to d-amphetamine which is active. essentially vyvanse and adderall have the same active substance, the difference lies in the need to metabolize vyvanse before it is active, this makes it take longer to kick in and prolongs the effect.

In my experience with Adderall, it did opposite of what you said. I started out with Riddilin (might be spelling that wrong) to help me focus on my school work since my grades were subpar at the best, but it caused MAJOR side effects with how my brain processed emotions and made me depressed. We moved to another medication that for some reason doesn‚Äôt exist anymore, and it did‚Ä¶something. It didn‚Äôt do good or bad it just, mad me realize, ‚Äúoh yeah, I‚Äôm a thing that exists in this world, but why though?‚Äù After fiddling with that, I finally moved to Adderall and it finally worked. Mind you, this process took three and a half years to finally complete. I now take a generic form of Adderall known as Amphetamine. Every time we feel like the effect of the medication wears off we just up the dosage. I also started out with 5 milligrams every morning, and now I take 15 in the morning and a booster of 10 at noon. It helps me focus on getting tasks done, including things like schoolwork, although it has to be intriguing to work it‚Äôs best. I‚Äôm glad I found the video. I take adderall for my adhd, but I forget it sometimes. After I started taking it, I also started having depressive episodes. Talked to my psych, and come to find out adderall is also an antidepressant, and my depressive episodes ‚ú®coincidentally‚ú® coincided with the days I was forget to take my meds. So yah, set reminders and alarms to take your meds. Medisafe is an app that's great for that cause you can share it with friends and family and you can ~~bully~~ gently remind one another to take your meds. Also please do not take your adderall with coffee. That's like 6 cups of coffee at once, even if you're only having one cup. At least space them out by an hour.

I wonder how common non-stimulant ADHD meds are in the US. I was diagnosed in Romania and was told that it's the usual procedure to start with non stimulants (Adderall and Vyvanse being stimulants, the active substance in my meds is called atomoxetine). This turned out to be perfect, it allows me to just DO stuff when i want to, but also to stay focused without having to constantly come back to my initial thought. As a medicine student, the lack of organization and the inability to study (ADHD paralysis) triggered intense anxiety and suicidal thoughts. I'm now going through my first exam session with meds and it has singlehandedly saved my life, and sanity. I do wonder how different it would have been with stimulant medication though

4:29 - 4:47 "You're effectively taking meth"  Adderall is amphetamine salts  Vyvanse is ... dextroamphetamine  Both are amphetamines, lmao. Both are basically ""diet meth"". Also thankfully - truth be told - they both aren't even comparable to meth in terms of potency and risk of addiction.   A bit of misinformation there by overgeneralizing, but it is a common misunderstanding with all of the typical confusing drug names for the sake of branding. x.x

Hi :) I want to start with saying I found this video and the regular adhd one not only very helpful but comforting in a way to know people have similar experiences yadayada but I am 22 and I got diagnosed with severe adhd when I was 5 years old (2006) and I have been taking vyvanse literally since I was 7 and I do have to say I do NOT RECOMMEND high dosages so be careful of that. When I was in hs I was up to 60mg and I literally could go the whole day without eating and then what was also really bad and sucha weird time was for I guess my child doctor you could say who was in charge of my meds had instructed that I didnt need to take my meds except for when I had school but bc of the high dosage and like obviously hs lasts for months but there is breaks and weekends but I like developed a dependency on vyvanse which is really bad especially if it makes you underweight, whenever I didnt take it I would I swear eat like an animal, my mom used to say I ate like a football player when I didnt take them. But I took 2 years of a break from it and tried other things in substitution after a year and now im back on for 30mg and its epic againüòéüßçüèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüí™üèº
Having ADHD is so difficult when everyone else around you doesn‚Äôt understand how it works. For many years of my life I was labeled as lazy, unproductive, a huge procrastinator, etc. but I physically couldn‚Äôt help it. Everyone around me told me to change and stop doing said things, but I felt as if it was uncontrollable and that something was wrong with me. Fast forward a few years and I‚Äôm going through therapy and my therapist goes ‚Äúyou have ADHD‚Äù and I was stunned. She explained to me that every symptom listed in this video and your previous one was a symptom of ADHD, and all of them applied to me. I finally felt that I was heard, and I‚Äôm forever thankful.

you know im a hardliner against meds but that comes because i have been wrongfully medicated in school.  I got ADD without the H in it which is basicly the same but not the hyperactivity part. Like i have the same chaotic stuff going on in my head but even as a kid i didnt jump around, screamed randomly and had to be working with my hands all the time to keep chill (which many kids in my school did) but i was more the thinker always.  So when i got medication like the others it revolved in me being even less attentive and couldnt even focus less. It was so bad i couldnt stay awake at school because these meds made me so tired, i was front seat row and teacher litteraly saw me struggling with keeping awake on my desk. She soon stopped it because obviously it was too much. And i myself had no idea why i was so tired, i didnt think it was the meds because somehow it just didnt come to my mind.  So moral of the story; it should be always discussed with the kid about their meds, explaining them what they do and what they are for, and most importantly telling them to be aware if something is wrong. Ofc most kids dont want to take meds anyway but i feel that would change if you really like.. Include them in the decision making process, at least to some extent.  for me it was just like "hey your medication just got changed." "oh, ok cool. Actually i dont care its the same right?" "yeah they are the same just from a diffrent production" "so nothing changes."   And next day i was like "man why am i so tired? i didnt stay up late yesterday." < this kept going on for a whole week so yeah.. If meds help you, go at em, no shame in it. But i feel sometimes its a little overused for children today.

I take Vyvanse, but its in conjunction with other medication. My psych told me this: Vyvanse suppresses your diet, increases your agitation, and is a constant stimulant so it can be hard to sleep. I would have recommended melatonin to help sleep at night as it wares off and if you struggle with anxiety look into getting compatible medications. For reference I take Vyvanse, Sertraline every morning and then I have some melatonin to sleep. Works a treat.
Vyvanse is just slow release adderall. Vyvanse is amphetamine with a lysine amino acid attached to it, which breaks down in the blood via an enzyme. It‚Äôs literally, the same thing as adderall.

And I started cleaning up. Apparently not only did I have a bunch of old tags from clothing, I had used batteries on my desk, one of which was corroded. I don't know why I kept used batteries on my desk in the first place, but I'm glad I cleaned up because I had literal battery acid from the corroded battery leaking onto my desk.
