I have taken many prescribed ADHD meds in my life. And what I have learned is that people tend to have to switch between different meds before they find the right one. For example, I took Adderall until I was on such a high dose that I was withdrawaling each night, so I moved on to concerta. Concerta helped until I was in high school where it didn't help with focus. So now I am on Vyvanse and that works for me.
Everyone has ADHD nowadays, I believe it‚Äôs less of a disorder and more of a personality problem. We have diluted the term and now we have taken away from the people who have the REAL ADHD. Not this, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve played games and watched TV now I have adhd because I can‚Äôt stop thinking about that.‚Äù  I was diagnosed with ‚Äúsevere‚Äù ADHD and I was put on medication because of it. Then I grew up and just stopped taking it. I can focus just fine without it. I was just a hyper child that never paid attention, Just like every other normal child. The US is over medicated.   Point of the story, just cause you don‚Äôt WANT to pay attention, doesn‚Äôt mean you CANT. REAL adhd is being unable to drive today because you are to wrapped up in that leaf you stepped on while getting in the car yesterday and the crunch noise it made, and the fact that you could FEEL crunch.  It‚Äôs debilitating, not entertaining.

I think it‚Äôs important for us who are unmedicated to be aware of our habits and to notice the signs that keep us locked in our unfocus and be kinder to ourselves and to remind ourselves that improving ourselves does not take an immediate affect. Polish cow is really fun ngl
I'm not taking ADHD meds, mostly because I'd rather learn to understand my mind, so I can use strategies to manipulate it myself. I feel more in control that way.  It requires a lot of research, reflection, and strategy, but the more you learn about how your mind works, the easier it becomes to work with it, rather than work against it. Think of ADHD as a very unique tool. It can actually be very useful, I find, but you need to learn its technique to properly wield it. For example, I find my ADHD causes my mind to spontaneously generate ideas. I use this to workshop stories, fictional worlds and D&D campaigns. I've trained my mind to workshop ideas whenever I'm bored. Who needs phone games, when my own mind is all the entertainment I'll ever need. So, being bored will always lead to a new cool concept In my journal to use later.  New problem: sleeping is harder because I start thinking about D&D.  After some reflection, New solution: watch YouTube videos that pull my attention away from random thoughts, but don't interest me enough to keep me awake. A delicate balance, but ive found the content that works. See, I channeled what my ADHD is good at into a more useful skill, then I was able to solve any further problems created in the process.

My experience was with ritalin. I took it and like you said for a time it was fine. But after some it declined quick. I noticed how i lost my ability to feel a lot of things. I couldnt differ from right and wrong, i had big mood swings and i had no thoughts ever during my medication. Yeah i got tasks done but the side effects have made me a robot with lack of empathy because my head on this meds was just empty void. I was basically a zombie on ritalin.  From my experience this stuff is dangerous
I had a similar experience, ESPECIALLY with the Vivance. What is currently working for my inattentive ADHD is Atomoxetine (Straterra). The fact that it's not a controlled substance or a stimulant also helps a lot with my sleep issues. It's a both a slow buildup and a slow burn. At first, I could feel the medicine whenever I took it, but after a few months, things leveled out. After about 6 months, I started drinking coffee again and had reached peak "normality". The medicine isn't a "I am totally fixed now" type of feeling, but more of a "it's easier to manage my symptoms, and I am able to be moderately productive." It makes it easier for me to recognize when I'm being distracted, and makes it easier to slip into focus when I need to. It also doesn't affect my personality as drastically, which was another medication concern of mine.

So around third grade I started taking Intuniv (bad idea), but that would just keep making me fall asleep. So back to the Vyvanse I went. Everything worked just fine for a while.  A few years later, in 8th grade, the Vyvanse started to lose effect again. So I started taking a different medicine, I think Concerta. This just made me crazy depressed. So we noped off that train real quick. and went back to Vyvanse.  Just a few months ago, we realized that the Vyvanse was causing severe bouts of mood swings. One moment I would be doing homework, cool as a cucumber, and the next, I‚Äôd have my hands around someone‚Äôs throat or punching a hole in the wall. This was the first time I myself said I should try something else. I‚Äôm now taking Azstarys, and it‚Äôs the best one I‚Äôve taken so far.  Medication has been rocky for me, but I think it‚Äôs finally smoothing out. Glad to know I‚Äôm not the only one that‚Äôs had a rough go of it with their meds. One of the adverse effects of the lisdexanfetamine (venvanse) is tachycardia, which means your system is working a little bit overload. It can cause dizziness and shortness of breath, so it's advised to keep an eye out on your heart rate. If you show such symptoms, you should seek a different medication and orientation. Sometimes they recommend a blood pressure medication as well, to reduce the strain on the body

Vyvanse ultimately releases the same compound as adderall. Vyvanse is lisdexamphetamine, which is metabolized by the liver into dextroamphetamine, and that metabolism slows down the release

What I think is interesting is how ADHD and its symptoms can be so different from person to person, but with such a common thread. And meds can affect people differently too. For me, my antidepressants and my birth control which help my hormones to just be so much more regular are two of the most important meds for my brain. I have Adderall, but honestly, it works just like caffeine for me, and I don't really have that much of a dependency on it if I keep up with the same amount of caffeine everyday. I found out that I had a lot of caffeine withdrawal symptoms because when I would take a day off of my Adderall, I often didn't have the energy/focus to make coffee, and relying on coffee in the first place meant that if I brewed it a little bit different, it would have more or less caffeine than usual. And I wouldn't use the same cup, and I used heavy whipping cream cuz I'm trying to do keto stuff, and Splenda, and it kind of sat really heavy in my stomach most of the time. So I moved to energy drinks, which I only did after researching and testing to see how my body and brain would react to them, because they not only have a consistent amount of caffeine per can, but they also come with B vitamins and other supplements that help with focus and energy. In the end, I've been feeling so much better after just regulating my caffeine intake, and so many of the caffeine withdrawal symptoms have been so much less. For anyone wondering, this is the article, and these are caffeine withdrawal symptoms. https://www.caffeineinformer.com/caffeine-withdrawal-symptoms-top-ten
I really feel like I need to be tested/medicated for ADHD, but I only want it for driving. I'm scared how it would effect me throughout the day.

But then again from what I understood CBD and coffee might work for me and for others not, just like adderall can help some people more than others.

Wait your telling me people actually look at a task, say they should do that task and without the Extremely Frustrating urge to do literally anything else they will do it? I‚Äôm not diagnosed with adhd.
If youre wanting to stay off meds, there are natural ways to mamage it. I dont use meds either, but I've got it mostly under control. (Mostly)  For example, there have been loada of studies jndicating that diet has a massive part in adhd symptoms. When I was a kid ky kum would just call it "the numbers" and tell ke not to eat food with "all the numbers". What she meant by this was all the preservatives and artificial flavourings they add to foods and drinks, which dont have names. They just show up in the ingredients list as a string of numbers or sometimes letters. But since I was a kid, she didnt bother explaining that and just told me to look out for the numbers.   So when I became a teen and knew everything about the world, in my years of experience and wisdom, and decided to go against my mother and eat cheap, packaged food with "the numbers".  And MY GOD my adhd symptoms went THROUGH THE ROOF! I couldnt focus on anything. I would literally bounce on the spot if I was forced to focus on one single thing. I immediately began falling behind in my classes, struggling with relationships because I couldn't even focus on a conversation... And bear in mind this is all before i even knew I had adhd. I had no idea what was going on until I finally went back to the simple diet I had been raised on. Primarily fruit, veg and meat, all the sweets like biscuits and cakes were home made, we even made our own marshmallows so that it wouldnt have all the chemicals to preserve and enhance flavour. They're pretty good too!   So that's something to try. Really works for me. To this day, if I go for a while eating packaged and preserved food, I go haywire. I have ti save those for Emergency meals, or special occasions.  Hardest part of that qas admitting my mum had been right... In hindsight, as the only neurotypical person in a family FULL of adhd and asd, and add, AND and medical professional, she probably knew what she was talking about...
Thank you for making this video!!!! It means so much!!!! I got diagnosed with adhd combined type officially and autism unofficially. I tried adderall xr and shortened realse of adderall and hated it so much. 30 mgs of the xr and 25 of the shortened release. The xr was great! It helped so much!!!! But the shortened was a nightmare. Turns out i was metabolising both of them too fast. So i switched to Vyvanse and i love it so much! I have no side effects. Lose of appetite. Nope. Still got a big one. Head aches and other things. Nope. My current dosage is 70 mgs. And while i love it. I am intimated by the fact that once it wears off for the day. Nothing will get done. But seriously thank you for this it makes all of us feel seen and heard!!!!

hi hi Ive been on ADHD meds (Strattera) for almost three years now. This is very true about medication. the Strattera has always worked well for my symptoms once I got to a High enough dosage, which is great, but I have other issues and medications as well and they've been constantly changing for those past three years. Meds arent an instant fix and they dont makes things easy, at least in my case, they make things possible. getting a genesight testing is one of the best things you can do. it made things so much easier for my perscriber to figure out what works the best. I highly recomend.

I switched to Sertraline it‚Äôs also an anti depressant but it works very well. Anyways I think you should try to switch over to non stimulants because it seems like something that would work for you,p.

Honestly I see ADHD as my superpower  There's pros and cons  Cons for me were Thnx to Adderall as a kid my kidneys and liver are still on recovery  since my blood pressure was raised, and I wouldn't eat causing me to loose 30% of my weight and a 10 year old kid that's on the smaller side that's bad and I have chronic dry eye were I need eye drops because I didn't blink ever and I never could think I just do and when I didn't just do I'd sit and stare into space and I couldn't poop cuz it was giving me horrible constipation   Pros for me  I did what I was told mostly, I was quiet and honestly my mom forgot about me most of the time drugged up in the corner   Honestly ADHD is a underrated super power. You have a hard time focusing and get bored easy so you try many hobbies to regain your attention until you get bored again then move on and start a new one and maybe come back to it  Think of it like a puzzle, your bored with it and there's another shiny colorful puzzle  Move on and start the new puzzle and eventually you'll get bored with the new puzzle and go back to old one or start a new puzzle  It's hard to consitrate but I feel people take the lazy route of I can't focus so I won't do anything  I tend to have many hobbies to choose from and the big one for me is my dog cuz he can go with me almost everywhere  Funny enough he's a Dalmatian and he's got the same attention span as I do so we be Vibeing  Try many hobbies and activities for yourself and you'll find that ADHD is just a underrated skill  That it really can be a skill worked with  I write things down and I find jobs that are fast paste work best  I currently work in the hospital as a tech and it's go go go and it works great getting fir my low attention span cuz it's go go go  Work with your strengths to help with your weaknesses

Aderall is not "basically meth" there is a big difference between Amphetamin and Methamphetamin. Hence the different names. Even the street names are differen: Speed and Meth. Also Vyvanse is just as much Amphetmin as Aderall, it's just slower release. Moral of the story: Don't listen to your dumb friends, talk to a doctor.

I am someone who has struggled with adhd as a kid and I was put on adderal and had to hop off bc addy is terrible for the side effects and the worse one I have recollection of is lack of appetite and suffered malnutrition and it was just terrible. I became disconnected from friends kinda turned into a shell but from my understanding of adhd people like myself is that we have a much much greater need for discipline than people without adhd. I have been able to push through stuff that what most adhd type of scenarios cause productivity. First mindset you adopt is that your tasks you‚Äôll do you‚Äôll never have to do it again for the day and then reward yourself with leisure time like video games or whatever makes your adhd go into intense focus mode. People with adhd do much better with hobbies because it‚Äôs things you like while it‚Äôs difficult to do things you don‚Äôt but you gotta try and understand that it will be for the better in the long run. It‚Äôs not a easy process but it helps you in the long run in life. Their are other works rounds you can do. Such as I don‚Äôt like getting up in the morning at all but I make it semi entertaining by listening to videos that keep my interest. Personally I try and keep the videos insightful bc I want to listen to useful information to start my day off. But adhd isn‚Äôt impossible to over come and I don‚Äôt think you need medicine at all for it, doctors just tend to throw medicine at you bc they get paid more and it‚Äôs easier than suggesting other forms of help aswell as the aforementioned drugs however I believe taking it can help you understand what it is to be calm and focused to some degree. But all in all drugs should not be your first option and should be used as an example in a way then ween yourself off and try and hone discipline and understand/create a system for your adhd so it knows what to expect. Think of it as a second Brain in a way they needs some sorts of necessities fulfilled to be satiated. I hope my info provided was helpful this is from years of self awareness and trying to understand it for myself thank you for reading.

I got diagnosed with ADHD as an adult about 3.5 years ago, but didn't take it too seriously until over the past year when I realized that, when talking to coworkers, I was paying wayyy more attention to my efforts to pay attention to them than I was to what they were actually saying. Anyway, I got put on Vyvanse, and for me, it certainly curbed my impulsivity (another huuuge ADHD-related problem of mine) but didn't do as much for the focus. Also, if I understand correctly, Vyvanse is also meth, but it's the parts of meth and your body puts them together once inside, unlike Adderall which is the pre-assembled meth. In my experience I think it's pretty common to need to switch meds around a few times before finding the one that actually works. I was on Ritalin and then Focalin first, and both just wrecked my appetite and made me super nauseous (though on Ritalin early on I definitely had your vyvanse experience of SUPER FOCUSED ON THING when it kicked in which sometimes was unhelpful depending on task). Eventually got on adderall which has actually worked really well, the only issue is the shortage keeps randomly leaving me with a break between prescriptions. I'm also someone who needs an afternoon booster, which is apparently pretty common but weirdly not a thing a lot of psychiatrists will ever bring up unless you specifically ask them for it. XR doesn't actually last all day even though they get treated like they do, so it's pretty common to need a smaller afternoon dose to help keep up the effects.

That's the *exact* experience I had with vyvanse!! If I could muster the initiative and self-discipline to be On Task when it kicked in, I could easily power through a week's worth of work/school/cleaning/etc in a day. But if I happened to be, say, scrolling through Reddit? Welp, that's it, that's the day. I ended up going off of it because while it *did* help on the good days, the lost productivity from the bad days made it no more helpful than just bare-knuckling through it unmedicated

I was prescribed Ritalin(Methylphenidate). It was...odd. I was super productive and hyperfocused, but a very...bad...side effect. I mentally cannot recall a single memory from the time between 2011 to 2015, the time I was medicated. It also...made it harder to remember memories for the first few years after going cold turkey. It also just nuked my personality into oblivion.   Instead, I took a far more difficult route, *finding coping mechanisms*. I've found it to be far more effective, at the cost of overthinking myself to death at every conversation. I'm still not..."cured". I still have a lot of tells, a general aura of awkwardness, near permanent RBF syndrome, a difficulty to connect with people, a hard time comprehending the idea of "Thinking what to say next without lagging mid word", and a small issue of "symptomatic breakdowns"(Instead of having a complete breakdown and returning to 5 year old, I just get really quiet until my brain knocks on my skull to check if I'm still alive). I...also have a really bad habit of over explaining... I also used to have a bad habit of interrupting people, cause I'd forget what I was going to say rather quickly. Well, time to return to...doing whatever I was doing before

1:08 - 1:26 these are my exact thoughts on things
I'm a little late to the party here. But I will offer my own experience. Medication changed my life after diagnosis in my late 20's. But more beneficial was layering therapy and counselling on top of my meds. I usually like to repeat the mantra "Pills don't build skills". The medication only works so well because I have spent the time in therapy to gain the skills needed to help me navigate life with ADHD. The medication then makes it easier to utilize the skills I have learned. The big catch is.... Building the skills sucks and it's hard work. It takes a lot of practice, patience, and willingness to screw it all up but go try again anyways.

I spent a couple decades in various spurts working with different doctors till I found what worked for me. I learned you not only have to find the right medicine for your specific body/brain but also the right dosage! Thankfully I eventually had a doctor who understood this and now I'm on Vyvanse and with a dosage that works for me. By the way, in case you ever see this @icecreamsandwich from the moment you first described vyvanse I mentioned to my husband that sounded like too high a dose and when you started talking about the side effects it confirmed to me so that might be something to consider discussing with your doctor if you haven't already.  But basically why I wanted to chime in is that I've spent the majority of my life feeling guilty and like I'm just not trying hard enough and that I shouldn't need or rely on meds. Well, I've broken away from the stigma (mostly) and feel better about myself and love how much I am able to do when I work with my meds and even arrange things in my life that help me to work with my adhd rather than try to fight it and be like a neuro normal person.  I was a little scared clicking on this video from the title. I'm so used to people saying I shouldn't take meds and while I think it's up to every individual wether they do or not, I've chosen to because it makes a huge difference in my life. So thank you for addressing this topic in the way you did without ridiculing either side.  And to anyone else watching, if you think the medication route is good for you, please don't give up. Find a doctor who will work with you and knows what they're doing. It has made a night and day difference in my life just having a physician who I can trust and who knows me. Tis all and best of wishes on your journey/adventures everyone!

i just want to contradict the bad medical advice here. if you are having trouble with fatigue after starting a stimulant medication, or are experiencing severe symptoms, please absolutely do stop your meds if you see a doctor immediately. ice cream sandwich here probably saved his own life by stopping his medication. fatigue like that is because of heart issues, and they are no joke. that's why good doctors monitor the heart when prescribing stimulants.

I was Diagnosed with ADHD when i was like 10-12 and was prescribed Adderall to help me with schoolwork and chores, it worked wonders for a while after we found the perfect dose. Then my doctor upped the dosage again... and then again. She did it 4 times in total and by the time my mother realized this was not a good thing to do I was a walking zombie who constantly felt ants in my shoes (Dunno why, it just felt like something was crawling in my shoes whenever I took the medication). Luckily the dosage that made me feel that way was given to me in the summer so I didn't deal with this sensation in class. My mother ended up just cutting me off the drug and I slowly returned to the energetic and highly distractable kid I was. My grades did dip slightly though because I was no longer focused, so that was a shame. I'm 23 now and still as distractable (Maybe even more so) as I was as a kid.
What's funny is, I quit Adderall 60mg cold turkey, and I had no adverse effects. Like none

Speaking on my own experience and absolutely not offering any advice: My own psych told me that ADHD meds are the kind of thing you can take on an as-needed basis, just take them on the days that you need to focus but skip em when you want to chill. They have a short-term effect and it‚Äôs not the same as an antidepressant where you have to build up a therapeutic level of medication in your system and maintain that level, whereby quitting them suddenly will cause severe symptoms. I AM NOT A DOCTOR THOUGH! Just a mentally ill guinea pig regurgitating what I‚Äôve been told!  I‚Äôm glad to hear of someone else experiencing the carousel of different ADHD meds, it‚Äôs so frustrating that none of them ever give the intended effect. Adhd with meds that work for you is like having a bunch of hyper-intelligent squirrels running computers. A few get done things done, but most are just running around. The meds are the new supervisor with a net who is strict and determined to get these squirrels to behave. Initially, most of the squirrels are spooked and cause havoc, but a good portion gets with the program. Eventually, most of the squirrels are working on the computers, and the ones that don't get with the program sometimes distract the workers, but it's usually manageable.

meth‚Ä¶
Great video, but I always feel the need to correct people when they refer to meth when speaking about stimulant ADHD meds. Medications such as Concerta, and Ritalin (Methylphenidate) have "meth" in the name, but it is not Meth.  Methamphetamine as a street drug is different and they have entirely different molecular make ups. They are both stimulants but not the same. Adderall (dextroamphetamine) and Vyvanse (Lisdexamfetamine) are amphetamines, as is crystal meth, but they have important differences and are made of different amphetamine salts.  It's an easy mistake, but it does a disservice to those needing medication for the ADHD or for trying to decide if meds are the right path for them when it is compared to street drugs. Also, many(not all) medication for ADHD is time released, meth is not. Time release options make it difficult to abuse these medications if non ADHD people get their hands on them, and lowers the risk of negative side effects
Wait, what? The doctor gave you adderall on the first try? You might be lucky because I‚Äôve known people who have faced huge hardship in trying to get effective medication (basically having to try every other medication). Hoping this works for you long term! ‚ù§Ô∏è
Vyvanse is great for me.... except the lack of creativity. I can't take it if I need to be creative.  The reduced hunger thing is fine, I needed it. I tend to do emotional eating and fog eating, so it's cut that down to nil. I just have to be more intentional with eating lunch.
Im using ritalin, is really good :)
On the contrary dude, you SHOULD stop taking the meds (Stimulants only) when you don't need them.  Stimulants are a dopamine load, you have twice the dopamine today, but tomorrow you'll have nothing. You have to pay the dopamine debt in order to reduce resistance. For example, don't take it in the weekends, you' are going to sleep a lot, but you'll feel like new on monday.  If you don't take a rest you'll go into bankruptcy once you stop taking it because it doesn't work anymore, the withdrawal symptoms are going to be very bad.  Stims works immediately, they doesn't have to build up in your system like antidepressants (Those are different, you should never stop taking them during treatment, the withdrawal symptoms are going to show one week or two later and you'll never know what happened).  Just use stims them when you need them to be productive and you'll be fine for a longer-term. But that's what I have.  That, is truly something you should never do, one bad step and you go to jail. :D  But I take rhe risk, it saved my life, gave me a lot of friend's √±, experiences, 2 raises in my job, I had the motivation to go to the gym and box and now I'm strong AF. The problem with ADHD isn't that we have a DEFICIT of attention: it's our inability to REGULATE our attention. Our brains learned at an early age that "if you stop thinking about the painful thing and pay attention to something else, you don't feel as bad" and this became our MO for the rest of our lives.  Habits do help, if we make them cozy enough: I basically give myself full permission to "waste" the entire first hour of my office job by getting comfortable, checking email, putting on music I like, journaling, etc, because I know that throwing myself into climbing Stress Mountain first thing in the morning will make me lose all hope of being productive for the rest of the day. (Trying to escape feelings of shame is one of the biggest triggers for my distractibility, so I've tried to make my experience as shame-free as possible. And it has actually helped. I'm also lucky enough to work for a supportive company.)  Regarding meds, Dexedrine works for me. Adderall made me feel and act like a robot. (I know they're essentially the same drug. This is just what I found.) Between good habits and effective meds, I'm... most of the way there ;) but I'm always interested in learning more.

Concerta extended release has done me well for the past 15 odd or so years. I then discovered thc. which was able to help reduce the anxiety from concerta, as well as learn how to refocus. I never take them at the same time, as suggested from my therapist, but I now am able to be mindful of myself and observe the world around me, and more importantly, observe myself - how my body is reacting to medications or other outside influences on myself. Still in a bit of an inbetween, where the adhd meds can make me hyperfocused, but it takes experience to disassociate on command. I now have a semi-happy balance of focus and distraction. when there is a high priority I make sure that comes first - but sometimes I optimize for time. like I am right now - but realize that in of itself causes me stress, so I'm back and forth a bit. BUT beyond that - I think concerta is a good one long term. only major downside is slight loss of appetite, but the mental clarity is good.

I really want to stress to others that ADHD medication will not work the same for everyone. The friend's heart was in the right place, but what could be mellow for one might not be so for another. Keep in mind what you want for yourself, and ask your medical professional what could get you closer to that result. And like he said, if something isn't working, or making you feel bad, please get that looked at.
What I learned since I had adhd diagnosed as a child then stopped and went back on was you still need to participate in doing productive things. As a child you don‚Äôt get it without supervision you don‚Äôt know you need to learn how to be productive, and learn an actual genuine interest in something is what will drive you.  The medication helps you stay alert on a task, but it won‚Äôt make you do it. The headaches could also be that you had too high of a dose too.

I got something called Atomoxetine... very passive... literally so passive that ya gotta wait like 6 weeks for full results... but that also means there's no spike and crash in attention span or focus. If you forget your meds once, it's not noticeable ... AT ALL!  and its effects.. for me.. are basically as if someone told you: "We noticed you got chaos there... we'll get that away.. okay?"  I've got 18 mg and have had experience with 25 mg... so I know what it felt like to overdose on it... not good.  Like... I don't just have 'pure' adhd... I got a combination of adhd and autism! And while atomoxetine removes ALL the adhd, it sorta amplifies the autism with increasing dosage.  At 25 mg, I could easily get launched into overstimulation.. the full package. - hyperventilation - stress to hell - trembling - sweating - eyes moving chaotically - crying my eyes out - inability to communicate - tunnel vision, stuck in my head screaming - sensitivity to touch (if anyone touched me I'd just collapse on the ground) - needing music, darkness and a lot of time to regain control over my body  unfortunately, the most intense overstimulation came during a job training ... which my instructor couldn't handle... and eventually ... I got terminated for reasons based entirely on autistic and adhd symptoms >:/

I had taken Concerta when I was a child with no bad side effects and then eventually outgrew the need for it, or so I thought. In 2017 I was prescribed 60mg methylphenidate PD and started to get Heart Palpitations and Headaches. I stopped using the medication and a week later I had a Stroke Event. While it was shown that there was a non-Cancerous Vascular Tumor located in the motor cortex was a major factor. I believe that the even was brought on cause of the initial reintroduction of ADHD medication. Since then as of January 9th I had brain surgery and all has been going well. Recovery is going well. Make sure you know the risks as well as the benefits.

Hey, 17 in Junior year with ADHD (technically what used to be ADD) and I‚Äôve been taking Vyvanse I‚Äôd like to say since I was maybe 10??? And that whole exhaustion thing, way too real, it would specifically happen to me at the end of the day before I went to bed, though this might‚Äôve been just due to a combination of this sleep medication I used to also take, (Which I decided to stop taking because it was terrible for me bc the sleep meds wouldn‚Äôt wear off by the time I woke up in the morning) But then later, when I was going to get my Driver‚Äôs license, my therapist suggests Adderall, and the idea is that I‚Äôd take it whenever I really needed to focus on something that day. The first few days I took Adderall, it just felt like a wayyyyyy stronger version of my normal Vyvanse, until the side-effects; anytime that tiredness from Vyvanse happened, I think I would describe it as a ‚Äúbone-deep tiredness.‚Äù When that side-effect happened with the Adderall, it was combining that bone-deep tiredness with suddenly turning the bones in my legs into titanium and turning the gravity up from a 3 to a 6.5 or so; and my sleep meds did not play nice with it since mixing things *with* Adderall essentially doubles whatever you mixed it with. I can‚Äôt even speak for its effectiveness, because we stopped the pills before I could really compare them to Vyvanse, and I did tell my therapist about the terrible tiredness. Though the way I thankfully don‚Äôt have that tiredness with Vyvanse nowadays is by having terrible memory and just forgetting to take it sometimes. So side effects from long-term use don‚Äôt often have the time to begin.  Also, to expand upon that one comment about not caring for your needs because of Vyvanse, also very true! It got so bad for me at one point that in 7th to 8th grade my parents had to threaten to ground me if I went under 100 lbs because I literally just wouldn‚Äôt eat pretty much anything during the day. (For context, Vyvanse may cause loss of appetite and I unhealthily feed into that loss of appetite by ignoring my stomach growling.)
I was diagnosed at 7 at took meds till about 15  1/2. I'm now 17 and the biggest difference that I can tell is my lack of motivation to do anything. I also stutter more because my thoughts are faster than I can talk, but I don't think I'll ever go back to meds.

ive been diagnosed with adhd for like 9 or 10 years and ive taken almost every common medicine out there; ive been on focalin, ritalin, and vyvanse. ritalin was my favorite out of all the meds ive taken but my doctor stopped prescribing it, im currently on vyvance and it doesnt work amazingly but its better than being unmediated. the only similarity of all of the meds ive taken is that they all destroy my appetite and i havent seen many people talk about that. i never feel hungry when im on my meds even tho my stomach will rumble and stuff, but if i eat i will get so sick to my stomach that i can function. most of the time my first meal of the day is dinner.

I have AdH... Ohhh look a bird!!
The whole meds debate is very interesting to me. Personally, concerta has changed my life. Before, school made me stressed, upset, and bored. I couldn't focus enough to learn, even though learning was my passion. Concerta has been my saving grace. Now, I can finally focus and I've gotten my passion for learning back. Be warned that medicine isn't a fix for everything - even with meds, it took me 2ish years before I cemented good habits in my life. What it comes down to is making the choice that is right for you and your body - it should be your choice to take them, not anyone else's.

Hey, globally this is a very good, informative and useful video as someone with unmedicated ADHD but yeah the comment about meth seemed judgy as in, a lot of addicts have undiagnosed issues and the addiction often happens by attempts (conscious or not) to self medicate. I understand why as a personal choice using basically legal meth might not sit right with you and that's fine, but having a thought for all the stigma addicts face would be nice, using, often out of desperation of getting their symptoms (that they might not recognize as such) dealt with doesn't make them intrinsically bad. And we all must be mindful of how we talk about substances use and abuse because it impacts real people.
I just need to say that Adderall is not meth. They have similar names, but they are different compounds. Meth is called "meth" because it is short for methamphetamine, but adderall is just amphetamine or dextroamphetamine without the "meth" part. It's kind of like the difference between carbon dioxide, a non-toxic gas that we breathe out, and carbon monoxide which is a poisonous gas that is flammable. Adderall and meth are technically both stimulants, but adderall has very mild side effects and is given in moderate doses. The other big difference is that adderall as a prescription has gone through extensive quality control, unlike illegally made meth that can have additional harmful ingredients in it.   I have ADHD and I take an extended release form of adderall. Having the extended release has made a huge difference because it is like taking micro doses throughout the day. When I've taken a regular instant release pill, it felt like a crazy roller coaster and I hated it. The extended release feels much more tolerable and helps me feel grounded.
The most accurate representation of adhd ive seen lol
Having been prescribed concerta in high school and having taken both adderall and vyvanse to finish papers in college, I found my experience to be quite similar to yours. I know it's REALLY not that rewarding in the beginning, but I recommend that you try to establish a daily meditation practice if you want to actually increase your focus. There is a wonderful and easy to read book called The Mind Illuminated which has been an indispensible guide for me ever since I found it a few years ago. It was written by a meditative master who ALSO happens to be a neuroscientist, so it demystifies the practice and makes it more understandable from a western point of view. Check it out! My only advice though, be careful with your knees. Sitting cross-legged can and will damage your knees if you're not being careful!
Adderall is not meth.  They are chemically similar but at most are cousins.  Meth is much more addictive and dangerous.    It is also exponentially cheaper and easier to obtain than Adderall.

i think growing up not really knowing if you do or dont have it like i did (both my parents have it etc etc) coming up with a structure in general is really helpful. i have a non-dated daily planner that i write out the day before. yeah, some days i forget to look at it at all, but i still get pretty close to everything i need to get done, getting done. ive never wanted to be medicated (edit: because of financial reasons, the fact i dont have health insurance and also because working through my struggles is important to me even if it gets bad)- so i think its really interesting to see everyone else's experiences in the comments, and obviously the video
With ADHD, Intuniv has worked best helping me focus, do my tasks, and get through my day pretty well.
I only got diagnosed last year and decided to try meds to see if they made a difference or not. I'm on Elvanse (lisdexamfetamine) and once I'd been through the titration phase and stuck with a dose for a few months, the daily side effects wore off mostly (dry mouth, lack of appetite which has been great for weight loss lol, racing heart when the meds kick in etc). I find that I can focus on getting physical tasks done from start to finish (washing up, putting laundry away, cleaning etc) but also at work I can focus on admin/paperwork/research much better without being super distracted. I do share the same problem of if I focus on the wrong thing, that's all I spend my time on, and all I can think about. But that could also be part of the potentially undiagnosed ASD which is a work in progress.  Unfortunately my prescriber/pharmacy have been rubbish at keeping me topped up with meds so sometimes I have to self regulate and drop to half a dose to avoid running out, or recently I did actually run out for 5 days which was not great. Once I started taking them again the side effects came back and I wasn't very good at functioning.

I like that this is someone saying "I tried it and it didnt work for me but it might work for you" I have ADD and I tried meds but quickly learned NOTHING pharma worked for me. my body burned through it too quickly or it made me feel sick or it made me feel like a passenger in my own body. I‚Äôm 16, a sophomore in highschool and I take vyvanse to help with my ADHD as well. I can‚Äôt recall what my first medication was but I DO remember hating taking my medication because I didn‚Äôt feel like myself. While yes it helped me focus it also turned me into a zombie. I was unable to express emotion or act the way I normally did. Conversations with people while on medication was weird. I‚Äôve been so used to being hyper and being funny but while being on medication Id feel like a cranky old man. Eventually I told my doctor about how I felt and they switched me to vyvanse which was a LIFE saver. Unlike most ADHD meds that I‚Äôve tried in the past Vyvanse does not kill your appetite so you can, for the most part, eat normally! It also allows you to switch your focus off and on as you‚Äôd like! While focused I may occasionally still get that zombie feel but it‚Äôs only when I‚Äôm HYPER focused and I want to complete something that I‚Äôm actually interested in.  TLDR: I love vyvanse. If you don‚Äôt like the Zombie side effect of other ADHD meds I‚Äôd def talk with a doctor about Vyvanse.
Adhd is a roller coaster with and without meds, meds make it easier for me in school and I‚Äôm ‚Äúnormal‚Äù, but on the weekends if I take my meds I‚Äôm bouncing off the walls with anxiety. There is really no cure to adhd, some people (like me, I‚Äôm very grateful) just have access to a tool that can make it easier to manage

You must do the physio therapy (learning to focus in ADHD case) yourself by going on frequent but short walks. That is how you learn to focus, eventually your short walks of focusing on important (and possibly boring) thing will get longer and longer because you are building the stamina to focus AND get the rewarding feeling of tasks being complete!

Just going to throw this out here - both Adderall and Vyvanse are amphetamines, they're not identical but they're both loosely related to meth. There are ADHD meds that aren't amphetamines, some of them aren't even stimulants (although most are).

I've been on adderall for over 20yrs now and have a few tips if you wana hear me out: -  accept the fact that you will now have two minds..  medicated and not (they're both you, they're both great and useful, and they both have strengths and weaknesses). -   make/construct/code/clean on-meds, design/art/brainstrom off-meds..   or to put anohter way, think about all the cool stuff you can make when off meds (creative) so that when you are later on meds you'll have a todo list.   If you leave the todo list upto your medicated brain, it'll just look around and do what's closest (that's just how it is).. -  yea it's an amphetamine, but it's nothing like (street) meth; that's just silly..  It does give you a sort of "on-speed" effect, but that's normally a sign that you're overmedicated.   -  don't take meds everyday..  try to skip at least one day a week..  otw you'll build a tolerance (if your body is anything like mine.. so yea, take that with salt)

"that sounds a lot like me-wait a second"
Amphetamine and Dexamphetamine are not even close to "doing meth", methamphetamine looks at the blood brain barrier and LAUGHS, meaning the potency is far stronger than others and a much higher abuse potential. And even then, either way you're still taking a stimulant which just gives free dopamine, which makes doing 'boring' tasks more rewarding. Also the guy who told you than vyvanse, which is lisdexAMPHETAMINE, was LESS like meth was completely wrong. As someone who is sensitive to stimulants but not diagnosed with ADHD, it's not just sufferers of your disorder that get wild productivity benefits from them, EVERYONE gets those benefits from them, it's just someone with ADHD **may** need those benefits more.

I guess Ritalin is like the best of all meds you could potentially use. But there are two, they got the hardest backlashes from all and one is addictive. The breathlessness could be a psychological instead of physiological. Paranoia, whether it has a feasible basis or not can cause this reaction. But if changing meds fixes it, it doesn't really matter if it's psychological or not. If different meds yield similar results, there's 2 and a half options. One, keep trying different meds and hope it gets resolved. And it totally might work. Or use therapy to find the possible cause and fix it mentally, or add another med that counters the anxiety. Combining meds to counter side effects of one another isn't uncommon.

I‚Äôm so curious about the other factors that led to your negative symptoms on Vyvanse. It is of course important to make an effort toward regular eating, sleeping, & hydrating habits when on any of these drugs, as your usual internal cues for these things will change. (appetite and sleepiness may be supressed) So, I find that sometimes when my friends or I have negative symptoms, it‚Äôs actually because we forgot to eat, or had too much caffeine (supposed to have little or none), etcetera. I was diagnosed with ADD at a time when it seemed like that diagnosis was being slapped onto any and every kid that didn't act the way they were "supposed" to act, which meant something was "wrong" with them. The doc put me on Adderall when I was 8 or 9, but I absolutely *hated* it and the way it made me feel. It stripped away my entire personality and turned me into a weird, robotic version of myself. so I told my mom that, and she was like, "Alright then, we're not doing that." Foolishly, we just stopped taking it and never saw that doc again. (NOTE: DO NOT DO THAT. ALWAYS CONSULT YOUR DOCTOR BEFORE STOPPING YOUR MEDICATION.)  As I've gotten older, I do believe I was misdiagnosed. I don't present with enough symptoms to feel comfortable wearing it, so I don't, out of respect to people who truly have it and live with it. And I don't blame my mom for being concerned about me. Some kids (and adults) are just kinda weird, and that's okay. Just be yourself, y'all. And if you feel that it is something that is actively affecting your life, talk to your doctor and work on finding the right thing for you. Your feelings are valid and you are loved. I also quit taking my meds and it worked out. Here is my story :D  I think I started on Adderall, 2nd grade, eventually it changed to concerta, then finally, last year of highschool, a very small dose of vivance, a new drug at the time. Then I decided, after graduation, and on my own, to just stop taking meds.  This was my own decision as a functional adult, and I am very aware of my own self. I lost a lot of creativity taking medication and I don't think I would have survived art college while on any medication.  In fact, I did much better in college overall, than I had been doing since 6th grade.  The meds just weren't for me.  But! There are plenty of people who can't function without medication, and that's okay! I'm genuinely happy for those people!   But yeah. I didn't consult a doctor or my therapist about it. In fact I just stopped seeing the therapist who prescribed me the vivance. Shrug.

I have ADHD without hyperactivity, but with impulsivity and performance anxiety instead... I tried Concerta and it was pretty much a mix of both your experiences with Aderall and VIvance. I was completing a lot of low importance tasks with very high focus and felt like shit after a few days. I ended up taking half the dose only on weekdays for a while and it was ok, but then my insurance decided to cut my coverage because I wasn't following the recommended posology (even though my doctor had approved it). So I learned to live without meds and I'm fine now (almost).
Vitamin d deficiency
as someone who took vyvanse for years, that is pretty accurate to what it was like. i didn't have those side effects thankfully, but i did often have the issue of making sure i was doing the right task when the meds kicked in. it worked really well for school bc when they kicked in, i'd be *at* school, surrounded by learning & classwork, & everything would be poggers. but after i stopped physically going to school bc of lockdown, i was no longer in that learning environment, so i would often take my meds, & then end up writing something completely random on a Word doc for 5 hours straight. i stopped the medication when i graduated college, since school was the only thing it really helped with, & i was learning ways to stay on top of housework on my own just fine. adhd is an interesting & finicky beast, & all you can really do is try to dissect why certain tasks can consume you, while others are like Evil Bad No Fun Times for your brain. from what i know though, having separate environments alone for "work" vs "play" can be a big help! (i.e. separate rooms or different corners of the same room)

I'm sure this doesn't work for everyone, but this works for me: Using podcasts as background noise.  Get a nice 1-2 hour podcast that you don't need to listen to every word of (I like basketball podcasts for this) and then turn it on and start work. I find the background noise stops me from overly focusing on anything external and this allows me to go down my to do list without it feeling like I have to 100% focus on my hardest task of the day.

I recommend concerta as I was on it when I was wrongly diagnosed with adhd as a kid
Okay but have we considered the possibility that you aren‚Äôt the problem at all. Maybe the problem is the societal expectation that people are supposed things and stuff, like every day.
I'm not a doctor, take what I say with a grain of salt. But doctors tend to generalize how often you should take certain medications. Your body isn't some computer that processes medicine exactly the same way each time you take it. With ADHD meds I've seen that there is usually insane results the first time you take it, but then diminished effects and negative effects if you strictly follow the "daily" recommendation. The doctors are not wrong btw, but the "daily" amount they recommend can also be interpreted as "you can take it this often without dying". I haven't seen any compounding effects with ADHD, all the effects are practically independent of previous doses similarly to advil(my non-doctor observations). That being said, taking it often without monitoring your body is bad. It's like squeezing a sponge before it reabsorbed enough water, you strain your body for no reason to get less and less out of it. My recommendation self-monitoring, pacing!
I have adhd (diagnosed in highschool) and took meds for a little bit. Unfortunately even the rx aderall at like 30mgs i had no affect (also no side affects, thankfully).  I learned to use tricks that work for me (not saying its excellent or will work for anyone else)  i constantly wiggle my toes (so other people dont call me out for moving too much, and to have extra stimuli while seated and working)  i also eat coffee beans (3-5) when i need to force focus(not sure how caffine affectsother people but i have yet to experience the joy of artificial energy, i just find its calming and often drink coffee just before bed with no issues gettingtosleep.  Exercise helps too.  To anyone struggling with it remember its not all bad, we often notice details others miss, and in some occupations like chef the adhd has helped me be able to task switch on a dime and return a few minutes later right where i left off. (Found out this was hard for other people, and was like whoa this bs actually helped me)
I have those symptoms and explained to my shrink. We talked and she asked a lot of questions and finally she said I have bipolar ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è 10 years of those meds and my wife is still saying I do 10 things all at once‚Ä¶
All the medication in the world can't help ingrained negative behavioral patterns. You have to break them with or without medication and you may even realize that the problem is something else. (i.e. people with other mental health issues that can show ADHD symptoms)   I was undiagnosed, and I literally strapped myself to a chair as a kid to get my work done. When I was diagnosed much later in life, I kept on being asked how I managed for so long. The answer was : I burnt a pattern into my head that I needed to do XYZ first, and anything outside of that will just prolong XYZ. I always had a reminder in place. For a while it was the chair I used to study on - eventually it was a notebook or binder.  When I finally got diagnosed (I was originally in for something else), I was fine on the lowest of the lowest doses, because my behaviors and habits prior to medication were just that ingrained into my thought process that it became a routine.   This isn't a hokey pseudoscience "YOU DON'T NEED MEDICATION" message, you very well might - but a lot of my colleagues and friends (some self-diagnosedüòí) went into the process thinking that the medication was a magic bullet and they wouldn't have to work hard at getting to normal and then continually kept on upping their dosage when it didn't work. Don't be like my friends - get help and then work at it.

So I gave up the meds and felt better about my life, I felt more alive and things got a little more messy, but now i just live with the feeling of crying while doing everything
If possible smoke weed
Fun fact: Vyvanse and Adderall are almost exactly the same thing. Simply put, Adderall is dexamphetamine and Vyvanse is LISdexamphetamine. The ‚Äúlis‚Äù part makes Vyvanse inactive until it is metabolized by your liver. When it‚Äôs metabolized, it turns into Dexamphetamine, or effectively, Adderall. Because of the need to be broken down first, Vyvanse lasts way longer but is also perceived as way ‚Äúsofter‚Äù than adderall. It‚Äôs just adderall but stretched basically.  As a side note, this goes to show that a simple structural change can wildly change a chemicals properties. While Meth and Adderall are both amphetamines, saying that adderall is basically Meth is a bit of a misconception. Using that logic, so is Vyvanse.

I had similar experiences like you, I took Methylphenidate (idk the brand name in the US) and now switched to Lisdexamphetamine (Vyvanse/Elvanse). What you describe is very accurate. Unfortunately, the medication cannot magically fix anything. It's a very powerful tool that you have to learn to use. Elvanse (Vyvanse) helps you focus, but it doesn't know what's the right thing to focus on. When you are focusing on the wrong thing, you must realise that and shift your attention willingly.   Medication makes you go in a straight line, but you still have to steer yourself.

People often just suffer from mental illnesses and long for the press of a button to make every bad thing about their illness go away. In this case meds. And I don't blame them cause I've been there. Sadly things don't really work out that way, at least in the majority of cases.  In general it takes a combination of meds and also therapy. Meds don't make any problem vanish, they just help you to achieve progress in your recovery and healing in a more supportive way.

I took methylphenidate in University when I was diagnosed. My biggest symptom wasn't even distracted thoughts (although I did have that). My biggest symptom was extreme fatigue. I would get so tired and always need a nap. Now I can function throughout the day. If I forget to take my medication, a few hours into the day I'll know because I'll feel incredibly tired. My first thought would be "why am I tired?" not "did I forget to take medication?". Then I realize that I forgot. I think it's just really tiring to force myself to focus. I recently tried to cut down on my medication but found it really hard. It's not that I was craving it. It was the tiredness that was incredibly hard to deal with. I think I'd rather just go through the rest of my life on medication. I don't want to go through life tired all of the time.

I am getting Bupropion because of my lack of drive. It also makes me more focused and I read that it is sometimes used to treat ADHD. I got a lot of things done since I got the prescription 4 months ago ... which weren't imaginable for me in the state I was in before. The effects of Bupropion feel much more subtle and less obtrusive than what I experienced with Methylphenidat (Ritalin/Adderal/Medikinet etc.). I don't think that psychotropics are a definitive answer to most of mental health issues but they can often be a useful aid as long as they are applied carefully.

Surprise surprise 5 years later and I get diagnosed with ADD/ADHD, Autism and OCD. And at this point I'm at my last school year with really low and terrible grades cause I haven't been able to focus or get any work done both at home and in school. I now take one 18mg of Concerta pill everyday and it lasts for around 12 hours, it helps me focus a LOT LOT more in school, but also makes me continue having that focus after school which leads me to becoming really tired cause I focus on a lot of unnecessary things and accidentally write entire essays to my friends about simple things that can be said in a single sentence and another leading cause to my new tiredness is that it has a loss of appetite side-effect.. that lasts for 12 hours and makes it really hard for me to eat anything. Your problem isn't ADHD. Your problem is a total lack of discipline. Too many people pin this on ADHD because americans get diagnosed with this and that for a yes or a no, as this means more money for big pharma and more money for psychiatrists. A LOT of people have symptops of ADHD, and maybe 1% of these people have "unfixable" traits. The rest are people who simply do not know how to be efficient. Start small, build up. You don't need to be the next Bill Gates, only to do enough for you to be happy about your progress. You mentioned 0 attempt to self-improve in the video - which is an ESSENTIAL part of medicating - only stuffing yourself full of meds hoping for all your problems to go away. Keep in mind that even people who don‚Äôt have ADHD struggle with distractions. I might be a little obsessed with productivity and you‚Äôd be surprised how much of the ‚Äúproductivity meta‚Äù so to speak is centered around minimizing potential distractions. To the point of physically separating yourself from them like having a dedicated office or even separate phones and computers just for work. Even the people I look up to who seem to have a superhuman ability to produce work readily admit that something as small as a text can lead to a distraction that can derail an entire day for them. That‚Äôs not to say that those kinds of measures would be a solution for people with ADHD because they don‚Äôt stop you from distracting yourself, but my point is rather that you should have realistic expectations about what to get out of medication and not think that it‚Äôll give you a superhuman ability to focus.

This is a bit misinformed. Vyvanse is effectively the same as Adderall, but it's processed in your liver. The same medication is coming out the other end, the same medication is doing dopamine things in ya brain. Adderall is also not 'M'. That's a dangerous misunderstanding of the medication and this notion is used to perpetuate the stigma surrounding people who rely on meds to just do life things.

For those watching. The advice about "do not stop taking the meds" applies to meds that you are supposed to take daily, old school standard "not-meth" Adderal is recommended not to be taken every day.
I  was lucky enough for my particular ADHD brain to do really really well in a school setting. I'm an inattentive type rather than hyperactive, so I would just go to class and sit down and absorb information like a passive sponge in a near-catatonic state. I had ADHD really bad as a kid.  My dad didn‚Äôt believe in things like ADHD and thought I was just acting out and needed to be straightened out while my mom did believe in medical conditions like ADHD and took me to the doctor who referred me to a specialist to get diagnosed. ( amusing enough I ended up going to 2 doctors with one diagnosing me with bad ADHD and other saying I had ADHD AND ADD, but to this day I‚Äôm not sure if they meant I had both or if they were using the term interchangeably)  They put me a medicine call Stretara (not sure if spelling it right and to lazy to look up the correct spelling) and when the child dose didn‚Äôt work on my hyperactivity they put me on adult dosage  (I was about 8).   My grades by that point were average aside from reading comprehension, but the meds turned me to a complete zombie.  No energy at all.  It got so bad my dad even got freaked out by it, and my parents agreed to pull me off cold turkey.  I was barely on the meds  a few months but I can still remember it very well.    Fast forward 20 years and I graduated top of my high school class and very high up in my college for a 4 year degree in business administrations and managerial finance all without meds.   My ADHD didn‚Äôt go away, but as I got older I learned how to direct it towards tasks rather than control it.  To this day my wife still says I should get medicated because I still have all the signs of ADHD, but to tell the truth at this point it‚Äôs an integral part of who I am and I‚Äôm afraid I‚Äôd lose all my creativity if I took meds to suppress that side of me.    It does still drive me crazy from time to time  (especially when I try to do something but end up doing something else, and never being able to complete a project) but I just chalk it up to being who I am.
it sounds like your vyvanse dose was initially way too high. it's one of those medications that can work well even if you lower it by 10mg-20mg for your next try, and imo it becomes more effective if you take it at roughly the same time every day give or take half an hour. vyvanse can be a little exhausting for your body, especially if it exacerbates insomnia. which is super hard if you have ADHD, but phone alarms definitely help.

If you can make such a video , I doubt you have adhd ;)
I am not trying to dissuade anyone from treating their ADHD with stimulants, I take vyvanse and it works great for me. However, as a pharmacy student I have to point out that all stimulants on the market in the USA are basically meth. Meth is short for methamphetamine, Vyvanse is the brand name for lisdexamfetamine. (dex)Amphetamine is the active ingredient that produces the effect in both drugs. The lisdex- part of the name has to do with isomers and prodrug formulations, and can be really complicated to explain without pictures.  As with most medications (drugs) it's important to use them for the right reason. The drug itself is not inherently evil it is a tool, it can be used to help or to hurt. Adderall is a combination of different forms of amphetamine.  Drugs do not cure ADHD, but they can help you put other measures in place to help manage the symptoms. I know that my friend who has ADHD wakes up an hour early to take their meds, then just lays in bed/falls back asleep until they kick in. That way they aren't already distracted when they kick in. For me, Vyvanse mostly doesn't produce hyperfocus, it just lets me control what I focus on. Sometimes it does make my hyperfocus but it also makes it easier for me to switch out of hyperfocus mode. Mostly it helps/lets me do really boring things, such as read a scientific article and analyze statistics (which I hate), or cook a recipe (which used to be too overwhelming if I wasn't hyperfoucsed on it at the right time).
The thing you said about being out of breath is the same thing that happens when you‚Äôre coming down from MDMA lol
I got started on Ritalin after being diagnosed with Adhd as an adult. It really did help me focus and calm me down enough to DO work like i needed to. It was really a strange emotional experience though. Reeeeally fucked with me psychologically, depressive episodes, disassociation, sensory overload once it wore off, etc.   I remember cooking chopping some mushrooms or something, no music, no background video, no distractions and it felt so calm and peaceful. It was amazing! I could just do the thing i needed to do. But other days i felt like i couldn't eat, couldn't sleep, i felt uncomfortable in my own skin and like i wasnt even in my own body to begin with.   Stopped taking it after I graduated from Uni cause I didnt need to focus on writing papers and studying anymore. Not worth the mental strain. Thankfully my job now is very adhd friendly

tips: Take a break from entertainment and time-killing activities. Use computer only for work and then turn if off and walk away. Try meditating and purposefully slowing down. Try sitting on the floor on a soft surface like a blanket or some grass. Lay off the sugar. Sleep 8 hours. Regular exercise. Circadian rhythm. Try fasting, optionally start with intermittent fasting. I mean don't drink or eat anything besides water. No smoothies, no soups, no tea or coffee. These may not work for you, but they definitely can for many people. Don't do meth. If those don't work, look into natural herbs. If you have enough income, do lab testing for brain chemical imbalances and nutritional deficiencies. Good luck!

I... need to be honest. I've been dancing between Concerta and some other adhd medication during I think like... Elementary or Middle School. I've been off of it since College and while I think there's more of a freedom without it... but then I just *forgor.* It's not on purpose, I swear. I just forgor while forcing myself to follow my self-imposed routines to work around my ADHD. But all these routines have made me so exhausted that I just... go prone during my days off. Space out, focus on something in the background. Makes uh... driving a *little* difficult for me.

I was diagnosed with ADHD-I when I was 7 (and it was just ADD). My parents didn't medicate me until high school for reasons, most of them money related. When I got the meds, It was like someone switched on my auto pilot, it was like I had turned into a robot, programmed to follow every command given. Which lasted for about 8 hours. And once the meds wore off, my robot brain would short-circuit, my eyes turned red and I was ready to destroy all of humanity if any human so much as breathed near me as my body crumpled into bed or onto the couch. I HATED it. In my senior year I told my parents not to refill the prescription, why I needed this to happen and they agreed. And I have been a mostly functional adult human for 11 years.

I'm from Germany and I have ADHD (ADHS in german) and I'm taking MPH (Medikinet retard 30mg) and I had a really tough time with them, I didn't wanted to eat and didn't had the hunger feeling, got depression and didn't follow any of my hobbies anymore and didn't wanted to go out, even to school, which are side effects of this medication, my grades got really bad in school that I nearly lost my graduation But then I put them down myself, I told myself that I could do it and after some time I learned how to handle my ADHD and my grades got better I'm not really happy with my graduation because it could be better but I'm happy I'm happy that I don't need that medication and I'm happy that I learned how to handle my ADHD ADHD is scary and so are the medications, if you feel like it's going down because of MPH medication, try to put them down while summer break and work on yourself, if it won't help and you don't see any progress in your behavior then try different medications of MPH that are made for you But if you can do it and learn how to handle your ADHD then you will maybe happy and I will be proud of you It's a really big and hard step, but once you get it then you can do everything

Here in Finland many adults who get diagnosis for ADHD will not get the medication for it. The doctors try to find all the excuses not to start ADHD medication.  For example if you have high blood pressure then no. Which is strange because in many other coutries you can have much worse heart problems and still get ADHD medication as an adult.

That out of breath feeling is likely from the long term adrenergic effects of amphetamines. Your friend says vyvanse is different, but they are both amphetamines. One dexamphetamine, and one amphetamine salt. This effect at first raises heart rate and blood pressure which you won‚Äôt notice until an acute kidney injury occurs because of the long term adrenergic effect of this med. If anyone else experiences this problem, it‚Äôs likely your kidneys are not working properly which is just about as bad as your heart not working properly. So I would agree to not take it if this occurs. Not medical advice, just personal.
My experience was similar, I'm taking vyvanse. I got diagnosed last year and started medications. I've realised that you get the symptoms described in the video when you take the tablets everyday. I've got a strict no more than 3 days in a row rule and now they work as desired. You need to give your body a chance to return to baseline and to get quality sleep. Also I found that writing a todo list for 'crackhead me' as I call it, works really well.
As someone who‚Äôs not on meds and can get things done try caffeine. If you have a similar version I do, stimulants can help fill holes in your preverbal wiring. It may not work for everyone, but it helps so so I suggest it to others.

My fucking computer
Vyvanse is an amphetamine too. Adderall, Vyvanse, and meth all are. Adderall is 75% dextroamphetamine + 25% levoamphetamine. Vyvanse is lisdexamfetamine, which is a prodrug of dextroamphetamine (i.e. it's broken down by your body into dextroamphetamine which is the real active drug). As for meth, well if it's pure pharma grade stuff or Walter White stuff it should be 100% dextromethamphetamine (not to be confused with dextroamphetamine). But street meth might have some levomethamphetamine mixed in as well as who knows what other crap (cutting agents used by dealers, leftover crap from the manufacturing process, etc.).  Don't worry about prescribed amphetamines for ADHD though. At small doses like the kind used for ADHD, it's fine. Recreational meth users take MUCH higher doses, they may smoke, snort, or inject it, and also street meth is impure, which is where the real problems come from. People taking it for ADHD don't do any of that (or shouldn't at least).

Look at 3 factors: 1. Environmental design; is it simple or distracting?  2. Trauma, especially in childhood- which means developmental damage.  3. Gut microbiome and diet.   Dr. Gabor Mate recently has talked about ADHD being caused by trauma, or more broadly, a hostile or depressing world that we constantly escape from, because it's too easy to escape into intense fantasy and dazzling spectacles.   I used to think ADHD was diagnosing the school system and pathologizing kids' natural needs or responses to a nonsense system. (See: Free to Learn by Dr. Peter Gray).  I stopped paying attention to it for a while. Now in the last 2 years, with how common it is plus the madness of the 2020s, it looks stupidly obvious. So much of the modern world drags people in so many different directions. I now think ADHD is diagnosing the environment, but placing fault on individual human beings for being damaged by it.
This is off topic but WHY is the brain so cute
Another thing, there's two subclasses of ADHD Stimulants. Amphetamines(Adderall) and Methylphenidate(Ritalin). Both work differently and people can react to those two very differently. I've heard online that some people are more social and not as focused on Addy vs more focused on Ritalin and less social-able. There are also people who feel like zombies on Ritalin. Basically, you can have different reactions on each drug so trying out various ones is usually better imo to get a feel on what it does.  Also, one thing I learned about these Stims is that since they suppress your appetite and drain more liquids your adverse reaction could be due to that, and you're dehydrated and/or not eating enough, which burns up your bodies resources. I'd recommend drinking at least 2L of water when on it. Also, high amounts of protein since these contain amino acids which are precursors to Dopamine which makes the medication work better.

I quit Adderall because it suppressed my appetite to the point that I wound wake up in the middle of the night crying because of the pain. It has the same side effects as meth because it basically is meth.
So...a "fun" convoluting fact can be that many ADHD-associated symptoms can also be found in CPTSD and/or undiagnosed adult autism. There is a lot that goes into understand your own brain PLUS understand the wacky way things get convoluted by being tossed around and redefined based on what country, economic situation, or even particular healthcare providers you're working with.  Personally I had to go the route of having my heatlh absolutely collapse in my midtwenties, thinking I had some mystery illness turning me into a purple chronic pain tinnitus bed-ridden zombie. Steroids and adderall, as well as some less by-the-book approaches, turned things around from the very close to grave situation I was in - and it's been annoying to deal with the plateaus in figuring stuff out because, by contrast, the first spark of hope was SO bright and game-changing. And the complexity of really figuring out what the heck happened to get me here and how to go anywhere meaningful going forward is still...woof, it's steep and tangled.  But it's still so very amazing and has given me the kind of optimism that I used to bitterly mock as my young body and mind was turning into a raisin despite all my best efforts and "self-control" and "healthy living" because - yeah. I just figured life was a bunch of lying fake people because, turns out, the same advice doesn't work for everyone - and in fact can have very opposite effects on health, sooner or later - sometimes severely debilitating effects.

ADHD Assuming Disorders Hurts Development.  I can confidently say that the damage to my self worth after being diagnosed with ADHD had far more negative impacts on my life than the ADHD itself.  Yes ADHD is real, no ADHD is not an accurate or fair characterization. In fact it was likely characterized that way for the exact purposes of destroying a child's self-worth and giving the pharmaceutical companies another avenue to create lifelong customers. (Wouldn't be the first or last time they did that)  Ironically ADHD oftentimes is a trauma response or coping mechanism to "check out" when reality is too stressful or hard. When we medicate, we are not addressing the underlying causes of stress or self-worth issues that can play into it.  Another important point is that many people don't realize these symptoms can start manifesting as a result of childhood circumcision.  Data actually shows a significant correlation between boys who have been circumcised and diagnosed with ADHD.  By all means, if you found a system that works for you that's great. But as long as people are still calling it ADHD, they're addressing symptoms and not what this phenomenon actually is.  If you have ADHD, I challenge you to find something that you really love, and see if it's really as much of a struggle to focus on it. Or if it is just hard for you to do tasks that you don't care about. Even if you do feel like it is something that gets in the way of you living your best life, Don't let it affect yourself worth, and don't let people tell you that only one kind of intelligence matters.

Just a general PSA: Adderall inst basically meth. Its amphetamine (both the right and left handed isomers). Meth is meth-amphetamine, which has an additional methy group which changes a lot of properties. Vyvanse is lis-dex-amphetamine. lis means lysine which is an amino acid, that basically is how it gets its extended release since the body first has to chop that off. dex means it is the right handed isomer of amphetamine, which also is in adderall, and is more potent in most of the effects you want from an ADHD med. There are many more meds for ADHD, not all amphetamines or even stimulants.  You can legitimately get meth (if none of the more common meds work for you, and its bad) for your ADHD; its schedule 2 which means unlike weed its federally legal to be used for medicine.

Was diagnosed with ADHD at 8 years old. Took Concerta from 8 to 12 years old. At 12 years old, I was more conscious and really started to feel the effect medication had on me. It would control my brain and I knew exactly what it was doing. It would push me to concentrate on, let's say homework,  and I get be annoyed at anybody who would try to distract me. I was not hungry during the day but when I got home from school I would have a burst of energy and eat everything. I felt like emotionless zombie.  I stopped taking the meds and said screw it I will do this on my own. I finished highschool and some higher education without meds. Still not taking meds to this day, trying my best to manage. Honestly, at this point, I feel like if I do not feel like doing something, it may be more of a motivational question rather than executive dysfunction.  I'm still a student and as much as I want to avoid taking meds, I still wonder if it would help me. I've been thinking of writing this assignment with a head start and I literally cannot get myself to do it. I wrote one page at the beginning of the week and didn't do anything the rest of the week. I had so much time to do it but instead I am here writing a huge paragraph on youtube :D

üòÇüòÖ umm yeah‚Ä¶ I haven‚Äôt even heard of that last med you took but yeah‚Ä¶ I have quit my meds frequently (and yes I know that‚Äôs not good but brain is a bad place sometimes). Anyway! I have been taking medication for my ADHD since like 2004-5(? Idk exactly when I started) and while I have gone on and off my meds over the years, there have been times where my reasoning was nearly identical to yours. I think there were only two or three times where that decision was actually really good for me to make (two of which were in the middle of college!). One time started mainly because I was too overwhelmed to make sure I was still doing everything I was supposed to (aka taking meds) and I knew that I had a new doctor coming in only a few weeks, so I stopped all meds. That was actually pretty good for me because my mind and body had adapted so well to the type of meds I had been taking (which was nearly 10 years at that point) that I couldn‚Äôt take more to help increase their effectiveness because I would overdose (yeah that was a scary thing to find out). But because I had been off of medication for so long when my new medication came in, it took me far less time to feel it‚Äôs effects and to know that these were good. The second time in college was when I was trying a new dose of the same medication but within a month of taking it consistently, I was developing migraines around 1 pm that wouldn‚Äôt stop until the next morning even with migraine specific painkillers. I dropped that dose like it was hot coals and was able to get the previous dose back. I have been at that dose for nearly 5 years now and while it is effective it doesn‚Äôt last as long as I need anymore‚Ä¶ then again I work starting at 7am and when I double shift at my jobs I don‚Äôt end until 8 or 9 pm‚Ä¶
