As somebody with ADHD who took Concerta (Which is also a variation on meth, yay), BE CAREFUL. I woke up two days in a row with the same symptoms you describe, and found out my resting heartbeat was clocking in at 180 BPM. It got so bad that I couldn't even go to school, and had to stop taking the medication as a recommendation from my father (Who is a doctor). ADD medication helps your focus, but at the end of the day, most of them (if not all) are stimulants, which will make your heartbeat go faster, something you want to avoid if you have ADHD because your heartbeat is already naturally faster, I think.
I‚Äôve been on concerta since I was around 6 and in my experience, it‚Äôs like glue that holds my brain tgt when I‚Äôm doing something I don‚Äôt particularly enjoy and increase my processing speed

I'm taking Vyvanse and it works wonders for me!! That's my experience at least :)
Adhd meds simultaneously saved and ruined me. The malnutrition and growth stunting made for ruthless bullying until senior high. The hallucinations on Adderall have stuck with me for over a decade and I still have crippling arachnaphobia.   I was a very difficult child for the authorities around me, basically from the start. I ended up starting with I believe 10mg Adderall XR at the age of 4, so yeah no wonder I didn't grow at all.  They would usually help for a while, along with the side effects but family complained that my parents were making me a zombie and from pictures around this time I certainly wouldn't call my demeanor lively. The tolerance part sucks, I was always rollercoastering between starting a med and that massive initial hit and it fading as I grew a tolerance and them having to take a med holiday and deal with the fallout of my bad behavior until starting the ride over again with either resuming the previous med, upping the dose, or changing brands or whatever.  I was always expected to handle my meds myself once I was old enough for my parents to assume I could do it without (probably) choking to death and I'd often forget and miss my morning doses until they'd give me my booster dose at school. My family would often equate being medicated with being good, and bad with needing meds or assuming I forget them. Later in gradeschool I started to severely struggle with home lift and interacting with other authority at school. I became very depressed and often felt broken or useless, especially when I felt my medication fading with tolerance. I unfortunately began abusing my meds around 6th grade onward, taking more meds before school until I felt my tolerance building and I would pull all nighters to suppress my energy level during my unmedicated days.  The out of breath thing is crazy, I had the same issue around the time I started Vyvanse. I was diagnosed with overreactive airways and given an inhaler that seemed to help.   I've taken other meds for adhd, can't remember the names off the top of my head rn but I've been off adhd meds for a few years now at 21. I honestly don't get a lot done sometimes, but im way less anxious, more emotional and present, the insect phobia isn't as debilitating, and I just feel happy and more energetic as a baseline.
What is happening? Those are literally the meds I went through when I was first diagnosed, same order too. Still hasn‚Äôt found one that works for me and I‚Äôve been trying to find one for the majority of my life.
Adhd is genuinely such a terrible experience. Having absolutely no agency with my thoughts and constantly feeling dissatisfied with everything is genuine suffering. Before I got diagnosed, I would wonder if I would ever make it through adulthood, and my answer was no.  But thankfully I got meds now, and my mental health has improved so much. I have agency over my brain. Its like having a broken bow, without the string you can‚Äôt shoot. Taking the meds provided me a string, so I could actually aim to shoot at the ‚Äúfocus‚Äù bullseye. My life is so much better‚Ä¶. I have control over myself, I finally feel like‚Ä¶‚Ä¶. Me :D

Hello! I've discovered my ADHD in the beginning of 2022. Like, my psychiatrist had already told me I had it, however none of the med I took worked with me (I took Ritalin, which put me in a zombie like state and Velija, which just... didn't change anything). So, when we suggested me to try another med, I was onboard with it. Turns out it was Venvanse. AND OH GOD VENVANSE MADE MY LIFE WORK The first two weeks were awful, I had constant headaches and diarrhea. But then... I could just... do things? Like, I'm still lazy and a procrastinator, however, now I can do things I know I need to do, and I can deliver my things on time!!! Having ADHD is a experience, trying out meds is another experience. Anyway, I hope you find the med that works for you soon! (If you want it, of course)
For me personally the key is cycling on and off them and only using them as needed. I don't always need to be productive, my rule is I never take them Friday-Sunday, and I try to take a full week off whenever I can. I've been of 5mg for 5 years now and have never even considered needing to up the dose. Also, no coffee on med days, or I can get that weird breathless feeling.

Struggled with ADHD my whole life. The meds help focus, they don't provide discipline. The non-stimulant ADHD medications are very new, not very well proven and simply don't work on a lot of people. You should really try and find a stimulant that works for you. I take Dexedrine, it's a little less intense and jittery feeling with the focus and issues you described with adderall. You really shouldn't give up so easily, trust me when I say it will begin to slowly eat at you living like this without help.

I tried meds, basically experienced personality death levels of depression out of them, and then learned to thrive without, as in *the hard way.* Essentially I ended up   e x p a n d i n g   m y   m i n d   to accomodate my issues. Not sure how I did it. I still have trouble with loud unrelated noises drawing my attention away from the things I'm doing, but I've gone so big-brained with how I've harnessed my problems that I can be doing entirely different things across several devices, and keep track of every single one of them. I can be sitting at my desktop, with three different things fullscreening all three monitors, my phone in front of the keyboard, my tablet off to the side, and while I'm not actively working on it all at once, I'm keeping tabs on it all, whether it's related to something else on another screen or not. In turn, as a result of becoming able to work with my issues in such a ridiculous way, I have ended up gaining the ability to bypass the issues completely and focus on singular things. If I had to make a guess, it would be that I'm just able to process everything around me now. It would certainly fit in with the number of conversations I've accidentally snooped while doing the things I do. Medication isn't always the answer, depending on the person mental training may be an option. Though, as I understand it, there are some people who have so many focus issues they can't even hope to start trying to train to process everything they recieve or think.

I do too have ADHD
What I believe meds are best for is for allowing you to function (or survive depending on the severity) while you learn new skills and tools to help yourself cope, they can temporarily help keep you functional while you work on yourself (this goes for depression and anxiety medications too). For ADHD (and this info is all from my hyper-focus research into it after being diagnosed) these skills include learning how to plan and other executive functioning skills, finding tools to take some of the executive functioning load off (IE: lists and schedules), taking care of your physical body (sleep, exercise, diet), mindfulness, therapy (CBT and DBT are especially good), and spending time outdoors. I'm still working on the first two things on that list, I was doing therapy for a bit, but it was too much at the time... I plan to go back to it once work lets up a bit. Ideally once you've got your life mostly "under control" and you've learned some coping skills, you can start to wean yourself off the meds. Of course, there's no rule saying you can't learn these skills without meds, but it may be easier if you first lift some of the load off with meds (if you're able to take them and they work for you). Personally, getting an adult diagnosis and getting medicated (took a couple tries to find the right one) was eye-opening, it really helped my self-esteem because I realized that I wasn't just lazy or stupid, but that being said, I do plan to continue to work at it. Interesting point on the adderall and action-based activities, I hadn't noticed that, but now that you point it out... yes, I feel that too. I wonder if that's part of why I spend my one office work day every week puttering around instead of answering emails (here I just thought I hated answering emails.. which I also do, but it's like LITERALLY ANYTHING is better than answering emails, I will FIND things to do).
Solution, stop watching tiktoks all day.

Kids should be allowed to be kids, we can't expect them to sit in one spot for 7 hours a day staring at a whiteboard and papers and not want to goof off. ADHD meds turned me into a zombie when I was a kid. In 3rd grade, they put me on Adderall to begin with and it started making me fall asleep in class, so they put me on Ritalin to keep me awake. I spent every day completely zoned out with few thoughts in my head and unable to focus at all. I was made fun of by other kids because I was actually drooling while staring off into space, barely conscious of my surroundings. Days were all blurred together, I was antisocial and all I wanted to do was hide in my room when I got home and then I couldn't even sleep at night. By the time I was in high school, my parents allowed me to choose to no longer take the medication, but I think the damage was done, not only socially, but also cognitively. I barely remember my childhood, only school breaks when I wasn't taking pills.  I will tell you this, ADHD never really goes away, but as you get older life experience and necessity will help you manage and block your ADHD tendencies. If you choose to take ADHD meds or have your child take ADHD meds and you see a complete change in personality like sleeping problems, monotone speech and antisocial behavior, throw the pills in the garbage because becoming a depressed zombie with no thoughts or emotions is not worth it.

I don't know but all I know is I really like the video with the cow at the beginning
Medications are used to treat ADHD because one of the root causes of ADHD is a dysfunction of dopamine production and uptake in the brain, which this video briefly animates. Medication effectively solves this. Medication does not solve ingrained behaviors, which take time and energy to correct. Anecdotal experiences like this shouldn't be used to determine whether medication for ADHD is right for you or not. A lot of the issues in this video could be solved with:   -Therapy -Habit training and goals tracking -Finding the correct medication  Having shortness of breath while on a stimulant medication warrants a visit to a doctor to assess the health of your heart. Videos like this are somewhat irresponsible to release, because the life expectancy of a person with untreated ADHD is up to 20 years lower than a neurotypical person, because untreated ADHD often leads to other avenues of getting that dopamine spike, or other darker things like suicide.

I was taking Strattera, I don't recommend it at all, it suppresses your appetite and causes thoughts of suicide to be more frequent with those who think such (like me.) I really wish there was just something that wasn't a medication that would actually help, like a drink or a food or something.

I only recently started taking ADHD meds and I'm not sure if I love the results. I only take it as needed because my symptoms are mild since I've spent most of my life trying to brute force my way into better patterns. However the days after I take it I usually feel very unfocused, like a bad rebound. (plus forgetting to drink while on it makes my dehydration worse and acts as a mini hangover. yea!) I'm trying an experiment this week where i take it every day, and I've been hella productive for the first few days, but now that I don't have anything to do I'm just spinning my wheels. And the bad vibes go away when I take it in the morning after I wake up because it restimulates my brain. Doesn't seem like a viable long term solution, but worth exploring.
I think whats going on is the context in which you are experiencing "lack of productivity." Like, id imagine as an animator and youtuber, you are on crunches to make content, meet deadlines and "be productive" but in the ways your career WANTS you to be. I certainly don't recommend taking drugs if they make you feel like that but also keep in mind that some countries (N. America) rely on drugs for a quick fix. Ive been contemplating my own medication and while it helped me improve my grades, the other part of that work was coming from my insistence that it was helping at all. As in i was placebo'ing myself with real medication. All in all 80HD and ADD is a case by case thing just like other neurological conditions.
There is an extended release or ‚Äúslow burn‚Äù version of adderal for what it‚Äôs worth. Just there‚Äôs also a huge shortage for it.  Also for those saying adderal is basically meth, if you look at the chemical name for basically all stimulants, they share part of their name with methamphetamine  typically. This has to do with how naming works in biochemistry but is not the same as them being basically meth (even vivance has amphetamine in its chemical name).  While the names are similar because aspects of their chemical make up are similar, they aren‚Äôt the same drug obviously, hence how each can affect one differently (and also why they don‚Äôt have the same affects as meth for those who benefit from them). Those parts of the chemicals are most likely what binds to the parts of the brain that affect dopamine like most stimulants although how any psych med actually works is pretty unknown since researchers can‚Äôt exactly cut peoples heads open to check so it‚Äôs often their best informed idea as opposed to a certainty of what‚Äôs happening.

I want to thank you for being the catalyst on starting my own journey with ADHD meds.  I was diagnosed with ADD originally when I was around 8 years old. However, this was around the peak of kids getting diagnosed because ADD/ADHD was the "hot new diagnosis" for kids (particularly young males) and many doctors walked back a few diagnosis' because there was talk of an endemic of over diagnosis of that condition. I was one of those kids who was "misdiagnosed", but 19 years later, guess who has ADHD (rediagnosed from a doctor)?  Now, I'm 27 and after working with a therapist for over 2 years (who also has ADHD and has been treating those with it for going on 20 years), I decided to ask about medication as this video kind of inspired me to take a look at something that might help me. The line "I just want to have my hands the wheel for once" really stuck out to me as oftentimes, I really do feel that way. I am simply a victim of whatever my brain decides to do any given minute. Sometimes its a really productive task, other times its something random that I saw  I will say, I showed my therapist the video (He is an SME on ADHD medication), and he suggested that your dose of Vyvanse may have been too high. That level of focus and the inability to switch off a task coupled with your symptoms of shortness of breath and general yucky-ness, It definitely screams of an above effective dose. I am not a medical professional, but taking another look at different meds at lower doses may be the ticket you need.  Best of luck!

Having ADHD meds is like just one of the skills you'll need to level up. If you don't work on the other stuff too, you might end up hitting a wall and not being able to get any further.

The actual problem is that work hours, productivity objectives and society in general are thoughtout to be compatible with an average brain An adhd brain in a vaccum is not better or worse than an average brain : the society is just less adapted to it So yes drugs can help to drag your brain towards the average but i'd advice you to journal for a few days to understand better how your brain works, and then organise your environment, work balance, etc in order to adapt them to your specific brain It may not be easy but that's the most healthy way to achieve your objectives, cause drugs can be good but can also be damaging sometimes  Basically the world works with 4 hours sessions for every job but if you think 5 min sessions work better for you, go for it Or may be you can only focus on tangible stuff so you need to write or draw anything you want to work on, or may be you need to be talking out loud about the subject.. anything can help Basically : figure out what's best for you and roll with it (and good luck to you)
Like many things, ADHD and ADD are a spectrum. I have ADD myself and I take medication. I don't feel the effects at all, but I do notice the results. For me, it is like a lever is being pulled which half of my brain is to prioritize. Without meds, I have many creative thoughts but my focus on logical tasks is low. On meds, I become hard working and very focused on logical tasks, but I can't think creatively. Each case of ADD and ADHD is unique. For some like me, only meds work. For others, therapy and paying attention to your thoughts works. And then of course there are also plenty of people who need the right mixture of both the right medication and the right therapy. I suggest that if you have either or suspect it, explore the whole bandwidth of options while medically supervised and find out what works for you.
I have found that using what little focus you have, un-medicated, to write a to-do list before taking a stimulant is extremely helpful.

I liked your video for the most part. Especially how the drugs subjecively impacted your executive fuction. I can relate to those experiences!  Since you have a huge amount of subscribers so this is going to be buried, but I hope another one of your viewers reads this...  1) It sounds like your friend is not into pharmacology, since Vyvanse is a prodrug to the d-amphetamine, which is half of Adderall (the other half being L-amphetamine which is very similar as well).  There's a good chance you were not on equivalent dosages of the two, which is why they felt so different to you.  2) Shortness of breath and anemic symptoms can be caused by higher doses of stimulants, especially when other bodily stressors are happening like lack of sleep, hydration, etc etc etc. Your body probably needed more oxygen since your heart rate and metabolism were being accelerated, and your blood oxygen may have been at risk of falling behind depending on what activity you were doing, thus your body kicked itself into a sort of aerobic mode of respiration, which probably felt pretty unnatural since you were not engaging in exercise. It's a gross feeling to be sure, but probably not overly dangerous, and more of a sensory thing.  This also seems indicative of a panic attack, and certainly stimulants can lower the threshold of acute anxiety! Still good to be cautious with re-medicating, since having anxiety all day is not going to help productivity either.  3) I think that you made the right call to stop taking your meds, so I find it a little bizarre for you to tell everyone to "NEVER, EVER DO THIS, EVER". Many doctors will suggest regularly taking a day or two off from ADHD meds, actually. Feeling like you can't breath when you do something is a great reason to cease doing it, and in the absence of an actual practicioner, we all need to make the best choices we can for our health. Best to take your own advice and don't provide it to others when it comes to treatment, though.

üíó  Hey kid, you need to start your day with an executive function task - like you said in the beginning.  list out all your tasks, don't just keep them in your head.  externally remind yourself what is most important.  if you're distracted, identify why.  is it because you have too many distractions and can't keep your eye on the ball?  there are many physical fixes for that.  Are you overwhelmed in a task because you have too many options or maybe not enough resources?  Break this task into smaller parts to make it easier to accomplish.  Routines are also helpful for me.  But that's Mayne the third thing I'd look at if the first two don't help.

Oh man this was me‚Ä¶ I took adderal and a couple other meds, I was experiencing a lot of physical side effects. I had a talk with my therapist and she recommended I take a Gene-Sight test which is a swab to test how your body reacts to different meds. It turns out my body broke down all of the stimulants style meds at 1/3 the rate of normal people so essentially I was taking 3x a normal dose. I now take gaunfacine, which is a non-stimulant medication that helps in smaller ways.

I take Focalin (extended release) but I definitely do still have problems with task management. For me, I always take my meds because otherwise I'm basically guaranteed to have a completely unstructured day. I think the problem is partially that I only started meds as an adult. While other people have been learning how to manage tasks with the regular dopamine levels for their whole lives, I'm basically a baby at it. There is no miracle cure. For this or anything. But it does get better the more you work with it.   Any therapist can help you organize your tasks/schedule and a really *good* therapist can teach you some effective life skills. I know some people feel like they souldn't go to therapy for "simple" everyday problems but most people really should. Best of luck to you and to all! <3

Watching stuff like this makes me realize I'm not very mature because there's people out here who have things that need to get done everyday and they actually want to prioritize those things. Meanwhile here I am... my mom always complains I have the wrong priorities, but I think I just prioritize the here and now... because you can touch the here and now. Like the clock is made up of twelve parts, which are each divided into four youtube videos, which can also be divided into 3 music tracks, which is basically no time at all, so each time I listen to a song or watch a YouTube video, basically no time has passed. So whatever priority I need to do, I can do after this really easily, because there's all the time in the world, and that's why I don't really understand why people get upset or get motivated about not having gotten things done. If there's anything you got to lose, it's daylight, and that's why light bulbs were invented. I set alarms and reminders as I find I do better on tasks with deadlines so I set them myself and move them up if the given task already has one. I was diagnosed late and immediately started on Adderall. This was the start of my time in college, so I was struggling, A LOT. However, I'm a musician and generally a creative person, so my ADHD hyperfocus sessions were insanely deep and I loved it. I explained this to my psychiatrist and he was super chill and understanding. My prescription says I'm supposed to take a low dose twice a day, but my psych basically said I can take it as needed so long as I don't feel any adverse effects. Basically, when I'm in class all day, I take 3 or 4 doses but weekends where I have freedom to do creative things, I may not even take my meds. It took me so long to get diagnosed but having a team of people who understand my brain better than I do while still understanding my personal wants has been so helpful. The biggest thing that has helped me is to understand how and when my brain tends to hyperfocus on complex tasks vs. want to be a vegetable. It can take a while but as you start to understand your brain better, you can start to work around the strengths and weaknesses that ADHD causes, maybe then medication might be necessary to try again.

I would like to experiment with meds, but I'm so ridiculously sensitive to their side effects (the ones I've tried so far at least) that the effective dose and freak-out-anxiety-inducing-effects-dose are about 0.0004 pills. I was on 5mg Adderall (as a 225 lb grown ass man) and had to break them in quarters. Not fun.  But then my friends tried the stuff (tooootally through legit channels and in no way had anything to do with my leftover bottle of the stuff at all) and found out it was life changing in a good way, and is currently doing the best they have in their entire adult life with a regular prescription. It's wild how people can be so different.
The worst thing about ADD (and by extention ADHD), is that we treat it as a disorder, when really you're just an explorer. People who got ADHD are the people throughout history that made perilous journies across the ocean in tiny ass boats like Eric the Red. The issue is that in modernity we treat anything that doesn't want to sit in a chair and push widgets for 8 hours, then go home and veg out on tik tok as someone who is broken, when the truth is that everyone else are the broken ones. I seriously think the mental health industry is suppressing greatness in the same way that religion suppressed greatness in the middle ages up through modernity. I'm not saying that people don't legitimately have mental illnesses, but a lot of it has become tools to oppress the traits that others were previously jealous of earlier in history. If you have ADD, or ADHD, I think you'll find if you just stop trying to pursue what others tell you to and start listening to the voice in your head about what you find interesting, thing start to magically fall into place. Suddenly, the "chaos" in your head becomes an ordered dialogue that actually makes sense to what's going on in front of you, and you can follow your own logical reasoning in your head. You just got to trust that you mind is working for the same thing you're wanting to work to. I would be so much further along in my life if I just would have accepted that its society that has the problem, and not me, and just went to focus on how to improve myself, rather than figuring out why I'm so "broken" and "distractable."
You‚Äôre putting my experience into words and animations! Vyvanse is like canned focus, and it honestly packs a ridiculous punch. I only take it on some days because yeah, the side effects suck and the results are basically gambling. Hope you can figure out a solution that works for you!
Hey there! I'm on vivance, and I experienced the same "whatever it is that inspires me at that moment will be my hyperfocus for the day", and for me, the best way to avoid that is to plan my tasks before the vivance hit. When the medication hits and I'm working on a to do list, or a plan for a paper, I will for sure nail it. I think with vivance it's especially important to plan what you'll be focusing on while it hits, because that usually dictates how the day will go. Hope this can help someone :)

There‚Äôs one huge misconception about adhd meds that I‚Äôd love to bring to the table: it‚Äôs only half the solution.  It‚Äôs effectively the ‚Äúengine‚Äù for your day. But it doesn‚Äôt magically solve your executive dysfunction. You have to work on that part. For me, I was trying to work on my organizational skills long before finding my medication. Vyvanse just gave me the energy and focus boost to actually accomplish these things routinely.  It‚Äôs like building your own car. You have to put all the parts together yourself. And it‚Äôs the engine that finally gets the thing to move lol
My Issues with the medication was the side effects. The appetite suppression was awful. I lost 10 lbs just because I didn't eat anything. It was awful.
Tldr: 450hp semi truck>adhd meds  For me "ADHD" is people being mad at me for being so stubborn that I'll only do things I want to do. I then get a job as a trucker because that's something I want to do. And to the surprise of only my psychiatrist who just wants me to take more meds so he gets more money, I'm really happy :)
Type of meds and dosage are extremely important for ADHD.  1. The first type did not help and left me foggy.  2. Second one  helped some but the side-affects were no bueno. 3  The third I had a doctor suggesting 20 mg but I found I had a moderate benefit with 5 mg and no side affects. Better benefit at 10 mg, but moderate side affects. So 5 it is.      Your doctor may very well be prescribing you a HIGHER does than you need. Keep that in mind. One of the meds I found out the doctor was prescribing me the HIGHEST dose he legally could. Thus the side-affects were AWFUL.  I asked that doctor if we could start it at the lowest dose. He said he is the professional and took offense after I explained how awful it made me feel.      I moved onto a better doctor who did not try to force me to have the highest dose.

The key with ADHD and especially medicated ADHD is get enough sleep, fix your bad habits and come up with a daily and weekly schedule you can stick to. I have ADHD and what works for me is a holistic approach. Incorporating some strategies to cope with the symptoms and supplement it with medication. For example, I tend to put daily necessities more accessible than distractions (like work apps are front and center in my devices vs leisure/social media apps). I find ways to optimize tedious or routine things as opposed to powering through them. And I only use meds strategically. Like, if I'm doing a presentation, or doing a big project, that's when I take it. But if my work/tasks for the day is manageable and requires minimal bandwidth, or if it's a day off, I don't. That way I don't lean on it too much, or have it used on less critical things.
I am rewatching this. What weird kind of doctors you have there? One of first questions I get asked when something weird is happening is "are you taking any meds?". This is both to rule out possibility that whatever is happening is and adverse effect of drugs, and to avoid bad interactions between drugs if I need something to cure whatever got me.

im sure the comments are a dumpster fire and this may have already been said but... vyvanse is the same active ingredient as adderall.  adderall is a patented mixture of levo- and dextro- amphetamine. your generic brand may be some similar mixture, but it is probably pure dextro-amphetamine.  (without getting too into it, levo and dextro rotary chemicals contain the same atoms with the same connections, but in different "handedness" very much like your left and right hand. the difference in the effect of levo and dextro amphetamine is documented, but small. thats besides the point because most people on generic "adderall" are taking pure dex anyway)  vyvanse is lysdexamphetamine which means lysine- dextro- amphetamine. theyve taken a dextroamphetamine molecule and bonded it to lysine (an amino acid). your body breaks down this bond, and your brain recieves dextroamphetamine. this means the release of dextroamphetamine is controlled by the rate at which your body's enzymes can break that bond, rather than the rate at which a time-release shell dissolves in your digestive tract (as is the case for XR adderall), but they are the same once they reach your brain.  I think vyvanse is great, I think there are a lot of differences between vyvanse and XR adderall, and I think a lot of people on XR adderall would do much better on vyvanse, but theyre the same active ingredient. it's just not true that any form of normal amphetamine "is practically" methamphetamine. just because its "one carbon (and three hydrogen) away from meth" doesnt mean its the same thing.  the difference between 5-hydroxytryptamine and 5,7-dihydroxytryptamine is  just one oxygen (and one hydrogen), yet one is serotonin and the other is a neurotoxin  (btw if i could highlight a major difference between meth and adderall, it would be the difference in neurotoxicity)
I took Vyvanse last year for a week or so, it basically made me depressed and stop eating so I don't recommend üëé
ofc i get this recommended during a shortage and i can't get my adderall :,)
I have a routine or a checklist for basically everything. And everything has to be planned and timed out, or it wont get done. I have to set alarms for starting tasks, or I'll just be distracted all day, for days. And I need alarms going off throughout that task to remind me to get back on-task. Music helps too, cuz as songs begin and end it helps me keep track of time in a "ball-park" manner (like "Oh shit, ive heard to 3 songs since I started this side-quest.. So ive probably spent 10 or 15 minutes off in la-la land"). Everything I own has a specific place where it is stored, and when i take stuff with me, everything has a specific pocket or place in my clothes or bag. No medication here, but these are tactics ive learned to use over my entire life to keep me relatively productive, and most of them work most of the time. And when they dont work, the whole "shit i have ti get this done NOW" thing takes over and I get it done anyway... But panic mode isnt my default motivation for completing anything since ive implemented these tactics.

Owh Great & Interesting video
Recommendation for anyone looking for how to manage ADHD without meds: Journal I refer to as my "parking lot". I jot down things I think I need to do before finishing what I'm doing, and then I re-visit it later, and try my best to prioritize. I use highlighters and stickers so my brain will focus a little better, but you can also do it with just a pen. It's taken me a while to figure out what works, and at one point it was hard for me not to get lost in the lines of the pen and paper, but I think I've managed to get it to a point where at the very least, I get the most important things done. Best of luck!

From my own experience, ADHD synergies with Autism in an incredibly strange way. Since most symptoms of both are some times opposites of each other, your brain will be in a constant state of either Nirvana or unquantifiable struggle. It is either all or nothing. You either understand and finish a project in one sitting or not at all. But, in the rare moments where all the benefits of the two line up, you become an unstoppable cognitive machine. You can think about as many topics with as much focus you want. Ever been able to process and plan for every single lesson for all your subjects at once, while maintaining full coherence on all of it, while at the same time planning the objective for your next gaming session? Yeah, it‚Äôs kinda like that. TLDR: the ADHD-ASD combo is either complete chaos or transcendent levels of cognitive control
You probably won't see this, but if you do, I can't recommend ADHD life coaching enough. I started it about a year ago, and it has helped me immensely.

6:50 (my opinion as a mentally ill person) this sounds like the medication causes you to have increased anxiety.   Medication for your brain is weird and complex. For me, adderall seemed to fix me almost entirely. But what it really did was give me the energy and dopamine I needed to complete tasks, but it made my anxiety much worse while also causing some form of denial. I guess my dopamine deficiency became a constant level of too much dopamine, so I always felt like everything was totally fine and that I had everything under control, when in reality everything was falling apart and I was basically in forced denial by my brain.  After that, I tried a bunch of other stuff. I have taken anti-psychotics, antidepressants, adhd medication, etc. and none of it fixed me. It would make one issue go away and intensely increase or cause another issue.   I'm also trans. It sucks. But here's the weird thing, when I'm actually on the hormones my brain tell me I need, I am much better off than I was on any amount or combination of psych meds. And I'm not saying that transitioning is the magic key, it was for me *specifically*. The only thing that will help you overcome all this junk is long-term therapy (I started therapy for the first time when I was 24 and it has helped me immensely in all aspects of my life) and trying out all kinds of different things that could help your mental state.  This is also not a suggestion, but for some people recreational drugs give them the balance they need to function. For me, changing my eating and sleeping habits while also being on HRT is the only thing that works. The only way to get better is to experiment as much as you can (safely) until you find all the little things that make it so you can overcome your issues. HRT gave me the overall brain chemistry change my body needed to start to realize what other things I needed to change. HRT and therapy caused me to be able to recognize that I needed to change my eating habits, so I started obsessing over it until I found ways to convince myself to eat healthier. After I started eating healthier, it compounded with the other things helping me and I was able to start noticing other small issues that have been adding up to make me able to actually function every day.  It's taken my whole life to figure this out, and it will probably take a long time for you too, but the only way to get better is to keep trying things. Every person's brain chemistry is different, you just gotta find what helps you make it through the day in the way you feel happy with.

So i got started on ritalin, and the first 10 mg were a revelation. After a month my gf, my boss, my friends all said that i wasn‚Äôt really any different, but better at being myself, essentially. So then ingot switched to concerta because plain ritalin has this short kick when i tale it i didnt like, and my skin got bad from it. And i have been on that wver since.   So, i didn‚Äôt notice it anymore really, i was just doing ok. Exhausting stuff became just regular exhausting, attention span got just normal, emotional regulation just went into cruising mode. I was on medication from 3rd grade to roughly 8th grade + the occasional time I really needed to focus on high school for like an exam or a project, because I eventually went to a lot of summits in high school. So, I was on it from the age of 8 to about 13. I took a few different medications mixed with different dosages. But my experience was all the same. It helped me A LOT especially when I was younger with my grades, focus, etc. but I never ate and I never actually felt like a human being. Even with lower dosages. So eventually i started hiding my pills/throwing them away and my mom discovered that so I told her, we got a lower dosage and repeat. So when I got yelled at again because granted it was a lot of money I was wasting, I asked my mom if I could stop taking them my freshman year of high school and see how my grades were. We‚Äôre they lower? Usually only by a grade point but I was finally happier and I ate food and joined clubs and had hobbies. Now I‚Äôve been off of it for the last 10 years and I‚Äôm in med school. Sure sometimes I struggle to focus or my stories somehow always get mixed together but I always think back to younger me who would be so proud to see where we got and how much we‚Äôve accomplished without being on ADHD meds
I‚Äôm happy I have adhd

My best friend and I call our Ritalin ‚Äúbaby meth‚ÄùüòÇ Funny as it is I am wildly aware I could get hooked on small doses of the meth. Not sure what to do about that though because I wasn‚Äôt functional before anyways üòÖ And no one really acknowledges that aspect of it! What if the drug DOES work? What if your symptoms without the drug are just‚Ä¶ as bad as before not even necessarily worse after a day or two of minor withdrawal that feels kind of like a cold? And now you can tell how much you‚Äôre struggling even more obviously bc now you know what it feels like to not struggle more than the average person? What then??? When it comes to ADHD meds a lot more nuance and sympathy is needed when people talk about risk of addiction bc some of us were already effectively as bad at life as being in withdrawal WITHOUT the drugs in the first place. Not everyone, but for me, yeah. So I‚Äôm kind of coming to this place where like‚Ä¶ Even if I am reliant on the meds, so what? That‚Äôs the point. To be able to rely on them for the deficit that was already there.

Hello fellow adhd person just info for the sake of it, I'm on 27mg of concerta (pronounced kun-ser-tu) for the most part of a year and I would describe it as It makes it feel like adhd lite it's just less adhd but it's still there for example I had a decent problem with impulse control specifically speach, i still had a natural filter yes but no words or sentences were being approved before being said and the meds made it all less including the impulsiveness and I now have a decent filter to my speach but when adhd gets smaller and becomes adhd lite but something needs to take its place for me it is autism but for you is your knowledge not mine and side affects for me it started with 3 minor side affects that would change and replace each other then 2 then 1 slowly over months now I only side affects I get is feeling hungrier slightly earlier and if I don't eat for to long I get realy tired and mentally slow it's like my body thinks I have less energy than I actually have so it diverted some from my brain it sounds way worse than it is literally half a snack bar wakes me back up. Lastly relapse whenever I miss a day or stay awake for to long after meds run out it says in normally just before mid day, the next day and all that really happens is I become un productive, lack of motivation, self Loathing, self hatred and the main thing is every system and felling of depression but a understanding that its artificial and not real and just the meds and the felling is correct. I had taken Adderall for a while when I was younger but the side effect I had was I was loosing weight due to not having an appetite and I wasn't sleeping well, so I just stopped taking it and ive been fine since. I have learned to just embrace my ADHD and Autism and work with them instead of trying to find ways to fix/nullify them. I have always thought of having ADHD and Autism is like your own super power and to embrace it.
I think the issue is medication is always framed as a ‚Äúsolution‚Äù to adhd. It‚Äôs not. They are a TOOL. Also, it can take FOREVER to find the correct molecule IN THE CORRECT GODDAMN DELIVERY to process for you as an individual. It‚Äôs entirely genetic. Luckily some gene research might be able to take your genes, sequence, and find out what the correct meds are for you in 20 years. But that‚Äôs in 20 years.  Also, VERY important point: MOST adhd meds are like meth but IF YOU HAVE ADHD YOU ARE FINE. you brain binds to these chemicals TOTALLY differently (not for bad meth tho it bad) than for a neurotypical person. That‚Äôs why people who abuse adderall have horrid side effects. You may have noticed you drink caffeine and you can fall asleep after unlike ALL of your friends. There is some anecdotal examples of what I mean. So the whole ‚Äúmeth scary thing‚Äù is bs and don‚Äôt listen to it. If you truly have adhd your body is going ti metabolize that stuff way differently than someone without adhd.  Lastly, you need to treat these medications as a tool. Figure out what meds work for what specific tasks. This is why I like adderall more. That easy one step? That‚Äôs how you START your day. That vivanse issue you had? That‚Äôs just raw dawg adhd hyper focus plus some focus juice. When you think something is interesting enough, with ZERO medication you can absorb that knowledge for hours on end and it feels like 15 minutes. Or anything you are enjoying for that matter. I think these are important things to know when taking adhd meds. It will NOT nullify your symptoms. It WILL, however, enable you to direct them in a way that is productive. The vivanse ‚Äúsymptom‚Äù you experienced is what leads people with adhd to actually be the top performers in their fields.  Personally, I take my addy to start focusing on shit I don‚Äôt want to do, then if it wears off I take another, but if I‚Äôm focused on a task already I just ride it out unless I need to take one soon to fall asleep on time. I treat adderall as a tool to start my focus day and not as one to drive it. I have to drive it. That‚Äôs for my studies tho (coincidentally is rocket propulsion and orbital dynamics). For boring shit I just pop the pill and do it bc that will NEVER be done willingly or else it takes up the ENTIRE day.  Me and all my adhd friends agree that laundry is the bane of our existence
The brain scene is literally my life lmao.

I've always found that therapy and coaching are the main things that help me manage my ADHD, and the meds are more like the thing that gives me the edge in doing the things I decided with my coach or thinking about things the way I decided with my therapist. I've also read quite a few books about self-management with ADHD, and taken some very detailed, step by step productivity courses to help me learn general self-management skills.   My favorite book about self-management is "Your Life Can Be Better", by Dr. Douglas Puryear, who is a psychiatrist who also has ADHD. It's the first one I recommend to pretty much everyone who asks me about getting help for their ADHD. I also really like "Getting Things Done", but that is a book that is more for people who enjoy things like meditation, karate, or archery, and who don't necessarily have ADHD.  Hope this helps!

Each different ADHD med have semi different effect on every person.  And those meds are not maid to be used everyday forever. You should use them when you need them. I am currently studying in Uni, so I take them everyday.  I have tried around 4 different medications, and indeed each one felt different from the other. Personally, had side effects to Retalin that forced me to switch to something else. Currently there are 2 different pills I am using: One is active for 6h and the other for 10h. Personally I also found them very helpful in social gathering as well (like a family holiday dinner with 10+ people). I used to think all the time "I just want this meeting to end" over and over and over again in those kind of situation, but with the pills I can actually enjoy them instead.  The meds are a great tool to have in your disposal, I would advise you to keep trying different types

I was put on it because I was getting sleepy in class and it did perk me up at first, but my body got used to it after a few years and it started making me more sleepy instead. The lesson here is that adhd meds are not a "solution", they are a "tool." Yeah, it can take some time to find a medication and combination that works best for you, just like trying to find the right tool that fits your work style. So work with your doctor. Also, the tool won't magically do the task for you. You have to learn how to use it. You don't just point a hammer at a pile of wood and nails and say, "Build me a cabinet!" You gotta actually do the work!

Vyvanse is hardly any further from "meth" than adderall. Both are amphetamines and stimulants. I hate how comfortable people are to villainize a drug that many people depend on to function better.
I have Autism, not ADHD, but I very much relate to your distinction between tasks that involve simply 'doing' and ones that require actually 'focusing.' Intrusive or otherwise distracting thoughts are unfortunately common for me, and while it's easy to be productive in, say, moving things or bouncing around on the Internet, my pace is much less consistent when it comes to reading for assignments, putting together my written thoughts (ties into the typical Autistic communication issue), or creative writing (which is a field I've been seeking to break into right now). With the former, I can set the disruptive thoughts aside or ponder on them *during the task*, but with the latter it would be a juggle between two parts of my mind!!

This works for my ADHD, (not everybody) but when I need to focus and be productive...Caffeine. Not a whole lot, just about 100-150 mg a day. The kind of caffeine you drink is important. When I'm at work, I'm on a crunch to get a lot done in a limit of time. So I drink a Monster energy and V8 energy. The caffeine helps me focus and the speed helps me get a lot done. When I'm at home, sitting at my computer. I just drink good old coffee. Helps me focus on my computer work without the hyper zoomies.   Again...Caffeine is not for everyone. Some people easily get caffeine withdrawal symptoms like headaches or nightmares... But it's a cheap alternative that can really help some people.

Getting medicated it's your choice, just be aware that Adderall and Vyvanse are NOT the only possible ADHD medicines. Just to give an example, most ADHD people react very well to methylphenidate-based medicines like Ritalin, and there are even non-stimulant medicines based on bupropion like Wellbutrin (even though its effectiveness is controversial as ADHD medication: note that Wellbutrin is an anti-depressant).  Of course I'm no doctor and I can't give you specific health advice, but have you talked to your psychiatrist about other possible way of treatment?

I have ADHD and I‚Äôm not medicated. I‚Äôve find that doing mindfulness meditations has really helped me over the years, as well as drinking matcha instead of coffee when I need to ‚Äúfocus.‚Äù Everyone is different, but I think meditation is a great place to start and being mindful of your actions. Another trick I like doing is putting a timer for 20 mins (with an applause sounds at the endüòÖ) for focus and productivity and only dedicating that time for one task. Or setting bells to go off at random times, and I know when I hear the bell I have to be mindful of what I‚Äôm doing. If I‚Äôm on task, great, if not, then I need to change the task. Hope some of these tips help with anyone struggling. It‚Äôs a lot of trial and error ü•∞

Try priming your brain by watching content related to your tasks before you start doing it. Your mind will catch interest in what your watching or reading, and then the hard part, when inspiration hit on how you're doing these things, just switch to the work and go. Then you can easily reach hyper-focus on that thing. If you ever lose interest in it, take a break and start priming your brain again by thinking about the problem or consuming more things related to it. Works for me, but I also have lower adhd symptoms. The barrier to just watching something about what you have to get done is like the easiest task, so you brain will mostly accept it compared to starting the hard work right away.

I'm sure you've got this advice or read it online already. but just incase if you haven't I hope this helps. Try getting something to fidget in your hand or when you recognize your off task ring a bell. You'll train yourself to either fidget with an item to keep you focused or you will constantly hear a bell go off in your head to focus you back up. I've been diagnosed  ADHD for over 20 years. It can be hard to train and it will not work perfectly, but it has helped especially when I am at work. Also sometimes a quick break can help, but I'd stay away from tv. Maybe just go outside and take a breathe

I tried vyvanse, and other meds, only med that doesn't have bad side effects (like never sleeping, jaw clenching and unclenching, etc) or that just doesn't do anything at all, is Concerta. I can't take the off-brand. My insurance forced me to for a while and I broke down crying to my primary when I was 17 and a senior in high school. See, I'd been on brand name concerta my entire life. When I was about 15, I talked to my doctor and we agreed I could discontinue it to properly learn to drive as it was preventing me from being able to as I'd only focus on one aspect of driving. (I can now drive with it in my system just fine.)   Well, when I went to get back on it? My insurance said "no" and put me on vyvanse only for those negative symptoms I had. And in my records, it says I can't take Adderall (likely something happened while I did when I was young, too young to remember). My doctor when I said the off-brand concerta (all my insurance was willing to cover) wasn't working, even with a second, smaller dose half-way through the day and I was failing my senior year and potentially wouldn't be able to graduate, said we could try a different med. But it would take weeks to build up in my system and start working.  I broke down and said I don't have weeks. I need Concerta, it's all that I know works on me and if I don't get help, I'm going to fail and be unable to graduate. I was literally crying.  She calmed me down and said she'd get me my med.  My insurance has never denied me since. Only issue is it has to be written "dispense as written" or pharmacies give me the off-brand version and I can't get the proper version without my psych writing to fill to order. I even tell them "I can't take this, I need the brand name, this doesn't work on me" and they just tell me to talk to my psych.   I hate that my insurance was allowed to put me through all that simply because they didn't want to cover my medication that in the past they'd covered pretty much my entire life. (I don't know when I started meds but I got diagnosed at 2 according to my mom, and I was taking meds when I was 5 or 6 and been on them since. I can't function without them.)  Apparently off-brand concerta just doesn't work at all on some people with ADHD and I was unlucky enough to be one of them. And my body doesn't take to the other instant ones well. I've never tried the other version of meds, but I also can't put my life on pause for months just to try to see it works and if not, try again with other meds, and have none of them potentially work when I have one I can take, only have the side effect of my leg(s) bouncing when I'm sitting, and work within a half hour to an hour after taking them.

I'm glad to hear you're not on the meds right now. I had taken dextro for about 1.5 years after my diagnosis and I feel like I almost lost all of that time socially and spiritually. I got a lot of stuff done, but it made me so damn anxious (even with lower dosages) that I approached life in such an unproductive way. I stressed about stuff I didn't even find important normally and it made me worry so much about making friends that I was literally reading books about how to. The biggest benefit of all this was it made me aggressively read ADHD books and reputable self help books which now have armed me with the knowledge to curb some of the ADHD behavior that occurs off my meds. It's a tough journey and everyone has different experiences, but I just suggest you at least be aware of any changes in your personality. I'm so much more passionate and bubbly without drugs and the drop in productivity is a sacrifice I'm willing to make.

I do not have ADHD, but I have some other mental health problems that required medication.  It took me a couple years to find a combination of meds that helped and didn't make things worse or give me really bad side effects.  I ended up taking a DNA test thing and turns out all the meds they had been putting me on were in the same class, and my brain really really didn't like that class of meds.  After the DNA test it only took a couple more tries of changing around meds for things to get better.  All this to say, of you have access to the resources to do it, I highly recommend the DNA tests to see what sort of meds will work well for you.  It would have saved me years of trial, error and suffering.  I hope everyone on the medication journey is doing well and finds the meds that help them <3

i was diagnosed with ADHD about a year ago now. for me, my biggest issue was lack of energy/motivation, and they gave me focalin which boosted my mood a ton, which helped me be more productive and generally happy. i didnt notice any bad side effects except for mild loss of appetite, but i did notice that it made background noise MUUUCH quieter, even super loud hallways/rooms, which was pretty good for my focus too. i‚Äôll probably need to raise the dosage soon though since my misophonia and energy has been getting worse lately. hope this helps anyone who‚Äôs considering it! of course, i also have other tools, such as a big to-do list i use literally every day and screen time reminders on my phone to circumvent my time blindness. so medication definitely isnt a cure-all, but it really helped me!

This is just my experience with me.., er.., adderall; your mileage may vary.  I'm 37. I've been on adderall for 24 years. It is my experience that the ability to focus isn't something you magically gain from the right medication, but a skill you develop. For starters, learn to be bored. You are of a generation who is more connected than any other before. Try disconnecting for increasingly longer periods of time. No electronics for an hour, 2 hours, 4, 8. Take a weekend off and go camping with no electronics.  It's like any addiction. Except instead of pain killers (for example) you're addicted to dopamine. And just like painkillers, once you detox, it takes a lot less to dopamine to get the same high. If you're brain isn't constantly seeking out those hits of dopamine, it's much easier to focus.

A while ago, I was given vyvanse a few times. Once at a low dose for a little which made me not notice a difference since it was during summer but the second time I tried them, my doctor gave me a ‚Äúhigh‚Äù dose she called it but I don‚Äôt remember what. She wanted to see the results quickly but it prolly wasn‚Äôt a good idea  At first it worked, I was cleaning my room n stuff like that but I was also just dead focused on YouTube and philosophy which I was never interested in before that point. I basically got no actual work done but it made me deadly focused on things I liked. I also noticed how it calmed my anger when it came to video games which I had a big issue with. Idk if I have ADHD, but I have at least problems concentrating.  One thing that has made my days better and easier are lists and "Special Stuff"   I have lists for everything, things to do, friends to message, emails to send, what exercises to do, etc... That helps me with discipline and memory.  By "Special stuff" I mean that everything has a special function and purpose and can't be changed or modified, for example, my Laptop is for School Work exclusively, I can't download anything that is not school related; my phone is just for Me stuff, nothing school related goes in there, save for really important stuff or if I don't have my laptop.  I do this with almost everything, and it has worked for at least 10 years!
To anybody is struggling with medications, have you asked about Strattera? It's not a stimulant, and it's worked wonders with me. There is far less static in my brain. I can get more done, I'm able to focus better and even emotionally I feel less likely to get upset over things. It's like a lightbulb turned on. "Oh, this isn't worth raging over...take a deep breath and move onto the next thing." If the dose is too high, you can go back down to a low dose easily. Prayer for all you wonderful people, God bless and I sincerely hope you find the therapy/medication/life changes you need!

As a fellow animator with ADHD, meds are only 60% of the solution. Everything else has to be your input. Think of it like this: The meds help you focus. YOU have to choose what to focus on.  It‚Äôs also important not to hyper-focus (like you did with literal rocket science, which is somehow impressive), because that‚Äôs a recipe for disaster. You start neglecting the world around you and forget to do things like take out the trash, or do the dishes, or‚Ä¶ eat. Food. Before the day ends. It always sucks to pull yourself out of a stream of focus, but it‚Äôs important to be able to.  (Side story: I personally take Concerta, and that‚Äôs been working pretty well for me for years. I‚Äôve only ever tried one other medication, but that one started having the opposite effect we wanted. I was basically the same as if I didn‚Äôt take medication at all, but with a free DLC of *heightened anxiety!‚Ä¶* which got to a point where I started having anxiety about having anxiety.  ‚Ä¶ I was on that prescription for like, two days.)

i've got diagnosed with ADHD at 5 yo. I've took Ritalin from 5 yo to 16 and its the worst thing ever.¬† it made me ultra depressed and tired all the time. My therapist said it was his first time seeing a depressed 6 yo with no major trauma. just chronically depressed. My psychiatrist was really an asshole and didn't really care about the side effects, so he really just gave me stronger and stronger doses. I remember when i was 12 and taking the highest dosage available on the market.¬† Since technically there wasnt any stronger dosages available, my psychiatrist just told me to take 2 pills. ( one stronger then the other)  at 16 I couldnt handle it anymore and i switched therapists ( since the last was compliant to the psychiatrist)  Told the new therapist my situation and we first began working on taking less pills and then figuring out my ADHD from within.  I started undertanding how my brain works and how to strategize my focus.  Im now 21 yo and stop taking any medication at 18.  Honestly , im the most productive and happy in my life. As someone who has had ADD (now ADHD) since I was 8 and in my 30s now, medication was the worst experience. I never felt like me while taking it, felt more like a drone. Recently been doing a lot of research and come to find out parts of the world like India use natural herbal treatments for ADHD, not the stuff we use here. I encourage to do look into these yourself. I've noticed a huge difference just taking the right supplements and exercise. ADHD people typically have very low zinc, iron, and vitamin D. Also Omega-3 fatty acids is huge. Other than that, I take supplements which include Ginko Biloba, Bacopa, and Gotu Kola. These are all natural herbs. So with a doctor's help keep zinc and iron in check, plenty of regular exercise and sunlight to help with Vitamin D and Dopamine, fish oil for the fatty acids, and the above mentioned supplements have been working wonders for me. Ive noticed almost an immediate improvement in my life. Again do your own research and consult your doctor to be safe. This is just been my experience.

I personally have been taking adderall and it works great. BUT i only take it when i need to. Like if im doing a big focus thing for the whole day i take my long release and when im just doing homework i take the short release but when i dont need it and can get the task done without the meds i try to do it without the meds. That way i get that extra boost of dopamine when i need it but im not reliant on it or taking it every day. Its been really helpful for me personally and whenever i go on my meds i can feel the effects more in focus. Plus for the whole thinking issue it sometimes helps to have the overlapping thoughts since i get through the work quicker. Overall ADHD is a unique experience and learning how to deal with it in the best way possible is a lifelong journey that‚Äôs different for everyone.

I'm hoping that with psilocybin looking like it will get legalized, or at least taken out of the category it is currently in, there will be more studies on it. From what I have heard of research done so far, it has been very helpful for people with addiction. I feel like the impulsiveness of my adhd is one of the worst parts, and its too easy to get addicted or at least spend way too much time on games, shows, YouTube, entertainment things in general. With psilocybin making new connections and blocking others in the brain, I have a feeling that this could be another form of treatment for adhd, and may be something that some people won't have to take long term. From the little bit I have looked into it though most current studies seem to be focused on depression, anxiety, addiction, and ptsd. I feel like the pandemic and the lockdown specifically eroded my executive functions severely, my adhd feels so much worse now. My medication helps but medication alone isn't really the solution for adhd, you need good habits and solutions to whatever specific issues adhd causes you. That is one of the reasons I hope psilocybin is helpful, since it can help with talk therapy. Because for me my adhd is so bad, like in the video I can only reliably get physical tasks done, mental ones have been very hard to get done consistently. I have a good amount of experience and knowledge with software development, enough that on paper I should be able to get a decent job. I just haven't been able to get myself to actually make things, both to have portfolio pieces and to practice the skill. This has gone on so long that I worry if I can get myself together long enough to get a job in the field or if I am doomed to settle for some other more hands on jobs like carpentry. Also nothing against carpentry, I just don't want all I have put into my skillset to have been a waste. If psilocybin therapy opens up to me I see it as either helping with my adhd or helping me come to terms with my condition.   also Idk if you'll actually see this, probably not, but based on the video it sounds like you only went to a psychiatrist. The place I go that specializes in adhd does both psychiatry and therapy. I feel like the therapy is a very important part of the adhd treatment. Especially being able to get help from professionals that also have adhd, if that is something that is in your area.

4:44 both adderall and vyvanse are amphetamines. They don‚Äôt work the same way as meth you‚Äôd buy from the streets. However, there is an official drug that has methamphetamine as the stimulant, it‚Äôs called desoxyn but its uncommon for doctors to prescribe this particular adhd medication due to the stigma.
The important thing to remember (that I wish was more emphasized in this video) is that everybody has a different reaction to these medications. For some people one pill is the magic bullet that fixes all their problems, for other people that same pill causes more problems than it solves. It's a very personal journey of trying different options and seeing which is the best fit for you.  Also, the whole "adderall is meth and meth is scary" thing is a bad take perpetuated by america's fear campaign against drugs. Mind altering substances can be abused, but when prescribed by a medical professional they can be extremely powerful tools to improve your life.

I got lucky with getting ADHD meds. My sister was going through the process of finding the right meds for her when my mom one day realized that I might have ADHD too like my sister and father (later on we found out that pretty much everyone in my family had ADHD, lol). I think I either tried taking one of the pills my sister was currently using for one day or I went to my sister's 'doctor' (can't remember the actual name for medecine doctors) and ended up taking the same pills as my sister was taking at the time (15mg of Biphentin). I tried it and got absolutely excellent results with it, it was only 3-4 years later that I tried to up my dose because I didn't feel concentrated enough in class by 5 mg and it might have also been a different medication. From the moment I tried the new medication I lost all appetite and only regained it 2 weeks after I stopped taking the med which it didn't take long for me to stop taking it and to go back to my old medication. In high school I just decided by my own opinion to stop taking it (I can't swallow pills so I had to open the pill and put the pellets on a spoon of peanut butter. Now I gag at the sight and smell of peanut butter) and everything was fine. My mom didn't even notice I wasn't taking it until like the next year cause I didn't have much difference in my grades.

My main problem with societies method of dealing with "adhd" is you need to stay on the meds or you'll have a reason to not "feel right". Pharma got you by the balls. Ten years pass and your "normal function pills" are now twice as expensive, good thing the pills keep you productive enough to pay the bills. A stroke at 40, what a great life it was. Concentrated. Just write down what you need to do, count down from five before your task to kickstart you into focus. People did this for generations before pills existed.  If you feel your brain is pulling you ten different ways, sit down and let it. Contemplate. Who knows, you might just realize your "adhd" brain is totally normal but its society which is so bonkers it keeps messing with your head as it keeps distracting you to avoid depression. Also stop using screens to fill this void. You need actual physical interaction with the world.  You can concentrate, just not in the way society wants. Sit in a chair and stare at a screen for eight hours typing words and numbers for money.  Your brain is screaming "this is senseless" and people wonder why the brain protests.  When I was ten I worked at a slaughterhouse like my father. Killing the cows left me feeling weak and sad so I ask the veteran anti-veterinarian how they dealt with it. They gave me a pill at the start of shift and suddenly I couldn't care less, feelings were put down. It even improved my hammer swing. When I became twelve I switched to a carpenters job for better pay and suddenly I didn't need the pills to get me through a work day. Who knew?
From  experience: meds help, but to make them work (to make yourself work) we need to apply working/ learning techniques. Pomodoro works great for me. Try it out.
You should try Ritalin if vyvance did not work and if yur looking for a different option
the thing about ADHD meds is that, in my opinion, they're not a silver bullet, they don't magically make you do stuff. They allow you to focus, but you still have to focus on the right thing. And when you've spent most your life not focusing, it's incredibly hard. Which is why - I believe - the meds should be combined therapy, such as cognitive behavioral therapy, in order for you to be able to focus and have the tools to focus on what you need to.  At least that's what worked for me. But then again, this will surely vary from person to person.

This video is both useful and frustrating.  It‚Äôs useful because you have a great way of explaining the lenses and the impact on you.  However there‚Äôs a lens that‚Äôs coming up which can be a little counter productive.  ADHD Meds don‚Äôt give focus. They instead reduce the impact of the barriers which prevent a focus tunnel.  The key is to structure life around the tunnels. It sounds very odd, but when I moved from thinking about tasks and time‚Ä¶ to thinking about tunnels and flow‚Ä¶ my life got much easier.  A lot of social norms are based on the idea that folks are ‚Äòpolytropic‚Äô. Swapping between a task is a low cost, flow states are handy but not critical.  However a lot of folks are ‚Äòmonotropic‚Äô. We work best when we have a small number of things and we get into flowy attention tunnels.  This change of lens was massive for me. Rather than aiming to do a specific thing, instead I needed to aim to get into a tunnel in the right place and with the right structure that the thing I wanted to get done was the thing I flowed into.  This approach lets me work with my flow states rather than fighting to redirect them. Structuring life to work this way took a while, but since then things have been much smoother and I‚Äôm a lot happier.  The role of the ADHD meds became a way to help me tunnel in places where I otherwise couldn‚Äôt. They reduce the impact of the barriers in the environment.  I‚Äôd super recommend looking up ‚Äòmonotropism‚Äô. It‚Äôs not magic, but it‚Äôs a handy lens for seeing different ways to approach these parts of life.   (Ps: feel free to message me if ya fancy a natter about it. My site is http://jamieandlion.com and contact details are there)
as someone on vyvance my biggest issue is just constantly feeling confused and out of it it'll work for like, a peak period of 3 hours, drop off and leaving me feeling, confused and unable to focus on literally anything and while usually with unmedicated ADHD it's I need to be focusing on 5 things at once instead I get, i need to be focusing on five things at once, but focusing on even one of those things makes me overwhelmed. I loose the ability to multitask and forget a lot. and my hands never stop shaking. And I feel like I need to be constantly doing things and Being Productive even when I'm unable to focus on one task. I sweat even if it's cold. and any amount of heat makes me feel like i'm going to explode. The meds used to really work, like Really work, first day I took them, I could sit down and do math in class just like everyone else, hell, better then everyone else because I was smart AND focused. Also I could just! Do things! but then, around exam time, they just started being a distraction by themselves on account of the painful side effects getting suddenly worse and now, outside of the 3 hour window of bliss, i've lost a lot of weight from not eating, my sleep schedule is fucked, and the only thing they're good for is keeping me awake when i'd otherwise be exhausted due to the insomnia they somewhat caused. Oh and I guess fixing my social anxiety, I don't overthink as much, just do things.

Adderall is a mix of d-amphetamine and l-amphetamine. Vyvanse and Dexedrine are just d-amphetamine, with Vyvanse having a version of the molecule that only activates after it passes through your liver. You didn‚Äôt try anything other than amphetamines, which your psyche should have realized. Try Concerta next. It‚Äôs more mild and tolerated better. Also, fun fact: Desoxyn is literally meth.  Source: I am a pharmacist

ever since 3rd grade ADHD has been a struggle to deal with, and I have been through many types of medications. The one I use now since the beginning of 7th grade is something called focalin. It helps with staying on task, but also allows me to be a social human instead of a workaholic robot. Not only that, I refused to eat when on previous medications because I was so focused on work. But focalin helped me get a good balance of focus and normalcy which has been a godsend in highschool. What I've done when im not on my meds is pretend that i am, maybe eat something that looks like a pill to get a routine in. Its normally a matter of routine that helps me get on track, and a predictable pattern could help focus just a bit better until you remember you didnt take your meds and get all scatterbrained.

This is such a perfect video, it really encapsulates the experiences I've had with ADHD and with medication.  I've been diagnosed since ~4th grade but we (my parents) suspected it long before that. I started on Concerta when I was formally diagnosed and took that until I graduated high school, but it had the same problem for me that Vyvanse had for you. I was plenty focused, but I was focused on things I shouldn't be. It didn't give me a choice. That, paired with some other negative symptoms like extreme changes in mood (read: sudden and very deep depressive spells) led me to eventually stop taking it. I felt that I wasn't struggling with ADHD anymore because I really only understood it to be what media portrays it as: fidgety hyperactivity. That wasn't my experience, so I thought I'd basically grown out of it.  Fast forward to two-ish years after undergrad and I became aware of the "ADHD iceberg". I started to realize that a huge majority of the issues I was struggling with in life were noted symptoms of ADHD. I'd managed to get an engineering degree off meds but could barely hold down a job, couldn't keep my house in order (literally and metaphorically), and was very forgetful.  I decided to get back on medication, specifically Adderall. And the change was night and day. My life was made immeasurably better by it almost overnight.  The last few months have been really hard because I started a job as an investment banker and the shortage of Adderall has made it impossible to get. I feel I'm barely scraping by, despite knowing I have the knowledge and ability to do my job when medicated. It looks like I might finally be able to get some delivered and I couldn't be happier about it.  I'm sorry the drugs haven't seemed to work for you, maybe it's a matter of trying another new thing. But for me I've had an incredibly good experience with medication and I'm stoked to (potentially) have access to it again.
ive been on concerta since i was 12, can say it works
I'm speaking as a person who has taken multiple ADHD meds- it's a complicated process. For a background, I'm a college student, who's been previously diagnosed with autism and anxiety, and only got the ADHD diagnosis after I started anxiety meds and realized I couldn't focus because I no longer had my severe anxiety pushing me to stress so much about getting my stuff done well/perfectly. Oopsies. So, I started with methylphenidate, which sort of did things? But the issue came when I was watching this TV show for my German class, and I got unreasonably angry with the main character's sense of... entitlement, I want to say? I texted this to my mom, who agreed that this was both unreasonable and out of my normal behavior. So, after talking to my psychiatrist, I stopped, and once I was back in my hometown, we switched to Adderall. It's been working better (I've been on it for about nine months by now), but it's still not perfect. I can do things better than I could without, yes, but I'm still very easily drawn off the path of doing important things, but at least my schoolwork gets done. I did have a scare back in October when I had extreme headaches to the point I had to take a trip to the ER (twice), and I still get them from time to time, but it hasn't gotten that bad since. Then again, my body's used to giving me weird stuff I just have to deal with. Scoliosis, extremely lacking muscle tone, low lung capacity (which is worse because I'm a singer...), general difficulty sleeping (I've taken melatonin as long as I can remember), all sorts of funky little things. Or maybe it's the meds meaning I forget to do things like eating. That's probably also a part. There's so many factors to worry about, and I don't know what's load bearing in my mental infrastructure.

I used concerta 25 mg ... Am i worse?!
I've been on the maximum dosage of Vyvanse for over a decade, as a working adult in a boring computer science field, and based on how you have described it, I question whether or not you have ADHD or if it's worth treating; overall, what you are describing is a lack of mental discipline. The medication was never going to force you into doing meaningful, productive work; that part was always up to you, especially when you were medicated. And the fact that the behavioral problems you are experiencing magically disappear between physical and mental tasks is another sign - there are no "do meaningful, purposeful work" pills, and if the difference between medicated and unmedicated is hardly observable or worth it or it fades over time, I think you should really question whether or not you have ADHD/ADD or if it's worth treating.
