Well damn! This video came at the perfect time. Got diagnosed and started non stimulants a year ago and just switched psychiatrists since I moved, and I think I ought to bring up different meds as a try. I always thought every med did the same thing with the exception of non stimulant vs stimulant, and I never thought some of the things I might be experiencing could be due to the meds. I also did the big bad mistake of just‚Ä¶ stopping my meds. I was feeling off and like my mood was uncontrollable and wild and like they weren‚Äôt working, so I went on and off a few days before cutting it off entirely for about 2 weeks. Learned the hard way that I definitely needed them, and that the reason I was feeling that way was *because* I wasn‚Äôt taking them regularly. My parents gave me a good stern talk afterwards lol.   ADHD has only been something I‚Äôve been able to even *begin* understanding and working with as of late. Before I was addled with depression and severe body dysphoria, as well as difficulties eating. So while I‚Äôve been medicated a lot longer, it‚Äôs only just now that those issues have subsided to the point where I can actually start using my meds as what they were meant for, a tool, not a solution. And boy is it hard.  Really thankful for your videos man, your animations are the only thing that put a smile on my face without fail. Good luck on your ADHD journey!

While it did help with focus, it made me feel like a watermelon that someone was slowly adding more rubber bands to. Needless to say, meds didn‚Äôt work for me personally. I don‚Äôt take any meds now, and it‚Äôs‚Ä¶. I manage. As a fellow ADHD person It definitely is a rollercoaster trying to figure out the meds that work the best. The one's I take now are amazing. I don't really like talking about it much, but I have tourettes as well and adderall effected my tics in a bad way. Even the lowest dosage made them more frequent and violent. My doctor thought it might of been the stimulant in it so I take Atomoxetine which doesn't have the stimulant and has been working so far. I can actually accomplish what I need to during the day lol.

This is so relatable, I started on meds recently and it's been strange adjusting but I think it helps
I had somewhat of a wild ride with my meds. As a kid it kept me calm and allowed me to actually grasp what‚Äôs going on at the moment, so it was pretty helpful. But now if I try to take it, it just makes my skin crawl my eyes dart around anxiously and less aware more forced anxiousness to make me more aware. Sadly now that my brain was more developed it doesn‚Äôt work. Now, instead of taking medication for it I actually managed to wrangle it myself and even turn it into a straight up superpower pretty much. So you know how you‚Äôll get an insane amount of ideas in a short amount of time? Well basically all I did was slowly make myself realize the situation, I started to realize what was going on when it was going on. And I like the interpretation you made with the several people talking at once inside your brain, and basically all I did was when the situation was happening (again I had to actively try to be aware about it) I‚Äôd basically force my brain to go silent, then head out one idea by focusing on one specific thing in the clutter if that makes any sense. And soon I trained my brain to be able to understand the whole thing and now I am able to double task without a sweat and able to create college level essays in a matter of minutes. I simply need to be in the right headspace and focus my attention toward one thing and doing it enough is basically training your brain to take advantage of it. So yeah you basically have a superpower, you just have to harness it. I hope this helps man.

When I was a kid they started me on adderall I don't remember it much the one thing that stands out is my teachers said it gave me: "irritable and violent tendencies" so I obviously had to stop that, concerta was next and my parents said it was like I was a zombie, I wouldnt talk id just sit in my room "in a void" my mom called it. We finally landed on stratera and I took that for like 11 years. Didnt know it was an appetite surpressant so I was underweight pretty much my entire life. I learned what it was doing to me as an adult and quit cold turkey havent been medicated since. Sometimes I think about trying it again until I hear videos like this and it just reminds me why I quit in the first place. I hope you have better luck then I did!
I'm not sure if Sandwich realizes the dancing cow song is about drug addiction üíÄüíÄüíÄ an interesting choice (or coincidence) for a video about medication  Edit because there's always gonna be that one person (or group of people): those with ADHD taking their prescribed medication in proper doses do not get "high" like those without ADHD would with the same dose (because ADHD is marked by lower dopamine levels at baseline than the neurotypical population, which creates the various symptoms of executive dysfunction).

Oh man you described ADHD brain perfectly. That sucks that you had a bad medication experience, I wonder if maybe lower dosages, might help? Because everyone metabolizes the medication in their body differently. This is anecdotal but I've noticed a lot of my male friends/ppl I know have negative experiences with meds compared to female ADHDers, which is interesting to me. I hope you find some strategies or meds that help with the mental focus struggles. Though even knowing you have ADHD is super helpful, I've found, because now you at least understand WHY your brain is choosing to play trumpets at the same time instead of doing the thing. My executive function is the thing I struggle with the most, the first time I took meds, I was really nervous that I'd be 'high' or weird but I just sat down and just... wrote a shopping list. Without having to stand in front of the pantry and fridge, I could just - remember - what was in them. After I did that I cried, thinking 'is this how easy it is for 'normal' people? They just... Write the shopping list?!'  We play life on hard difficulty, going through it with an ADHD brain. Thanks for these vids, they're spot on.

whats the cow song name i like
I had to try three different medications before landing on Vyvanse. Vyvanse feels fine for me, but Adderall and Medidate (sp?) made me feel crazy. Intriguingly, my friend (who also has adhd) did best on Adderall out of the three. Medidate gave me the ‚Äúmarathon breath‚Äù, like what you experienced. Biochemistry is nutty, man. It VARIES.  One thing that cannot be cured with adhd tho is accountability and routine. The medication makes tasks easier, but you MUST will yourself through the occasional MEH periods/energy lows. Aka ‚ÄúI feel like shit but I‚Äôm gonna go through the car wash and I‚Äôm going to get some groceries, dammit,‚Äù or, ‚Äúok I hate this but it‚Äôs ONLY 15 minutes.‚Äù Reverse psychology your ass. You already do these thought patterns when you‚Äôre running late. The ‚Äújust one more thing,‚Äù thing.  Also, those moods can be resolved by exercise (or a can of Coca Cola, in my case, bc caffeine)   There‚Äôs also the classic, start with something small, like wiping off a counter top. Or reward, like placing something to look forward to later, after the grunt crap is done. For me, this is dessert. Or a game I wanna play very badly. Or perhaps some MJ.   On that topic‚Äîsometimes, AFTER WORK, I may indulge in a low dose MJ, which gets my good vibes going and then I‚Äôll hyper focus on the ‚Äúdoing‚Äù tasks, like cleaning.  TO CLOSE: in my experience, you will never cure‚Äù adhd, only manage it. Release the idea of perfectionism. Some days are gonna be hella productive. Others won‚Äôt. Meds still make those productive days possible, which I will take over having NONE. My rule is, I know I‚Äôm gonna fall off that horse, but I‚Äôm not gonna fall off that horse for long.   HELPFUL THINGS: timers bc time blindness is fucking REAL/ (Also using the pomo doro method with these timers),  occasional bullet journaling, telling others my plans (so I‚Äôm motivated to do them before I see them again), regularly working out (improves and regulates mood/how alert I feel), water, etc.  Something I‚Äôm considering : ‚Äú body doubling ‚Äú or‚Ä¶webcam work buddies. It‚Äôs going live with other distractible peeps quietly doing their jobs‚Ä¶ like on tiktok? There may already be a live channel for this, but I think it‚Äôs kinda cool. It‚Äôs like the person you gym with to keep each other accountable.  SO! Good luck dude, and thanks for reading this essay of response.

Please stop spreading the harmful myth that ADHD meds are Meth. Tell this to your friend, too.  Most of them are Amphetamines, which *sounds* a lot like Methamphetamine, but it's missing the very important Methyl group that makes it Methampethamine - and if you know anything about chemistry, just a *few* fun little atoms can make a *really* big difference.
Some of you that meds don't work for or have bad side-effects want to look into Autism next. Unmasking Autism is a great (Audio)book to get started, as is the Autism subreddit
You‚Äôll find the right one! Keep trying!
I'm mexican so the meds i take are slightly different, tbh they work great for me! it really can be all about getting better habits and building dicipline when it comes to that, one brand that we have in common that I only hear good things about is Concerta ! i take the off-brand version, same formula just weaker, cause im quite poor haha, but the formula concerta uses is pretty great imo! Totally recommend :) helps witch focus and tasks! of course, also practice using that focus on things that are important, i have been taking meds for two years but still tend to get that epic focus power wasted on other things cause i just like those things better than working haha. but its all about habit building !! good luck! :D

This is a really great video, but the 'adderall is just meth' thing is one of my biggest pet peeves when it comes to ADHD medication. Yes, pharmeceutically, that's completely correct, however why is it that we condemn a drug that can help people like this? We don't morally judge people for taking opiod painkillers for being 'heroin addicts,' and adderall can be a really useful drug when properly prescribed and taken.

Tylko jedno w g≈Çowie mam Koksu piƒôc gram Odlecieƒá sam W krainƒô zapomnienia  W g≈Çowie mysli mam Kiedy sko≈Ñczy siƒô ten stan Gdy ju≈º nie bƒôdƒô sam Bo wjedzie bia≈Çy wƒôgorz  Tylko jedno w g≈Çowie mam Koksu piƒôc gram Odlecieƒá sam W krainƒô zapomnienia  W g≈Çowie mysli mam Kiedy sko≈Ñczy siƒô ten stan Gdy ju≈º nie bƒôdƒô sam Bo wjedzie bia≈Çy wƒôgorz
Just going to throw out there that Adderall is not like meth. Saying they are alike because they seem chemically similar is like saying H20 and H202 are similar because H202 just has one more oxygen atom. (h202 will kill you)
Make sure y'all remember, regardless of if you medicate adhd or not, remember that all adhd medications are NOT meant to be taken for a lifetime, and if you do take them for a lifetime they have horrible health defects. The point of adhd medication is to teach you how to live properly, not to make it happen, they're not antidepressants, they're stimulants. And the reason why I argue to just not medicate at all is because like this guy, you may end up back at square one and you still have to learn to live without medication anyway, (though now you have a hole in your pocket from the expensive medications) and on the worse end you may become chemically addicted to it and suddenly you "go crazy without your adhd medicine" when your adhd was never that bad before, as I experienced. And the issue with talking with your doctor when you're having problems with medication is that THEY NEVER EVER recommend you to stop taking the meds even when the meds are CLEARLY the problem, why? Because they can give you something else to get you to go away for a few weeks and they get more kickback for every prescription you fill. Currently adhd is both overmedicated, and most people find more success in treating it nonmedicinally. If you need adhd meds to function that's fine but for most people its just not the way to go!
I take ADHD meds too, they seem to work for me. If you haven't taken these maybe try? Aripiprazole, clonidine, and methylphenidate. Actually, I take (I think, don't test this) In the morning a whole methylphenidate and whole aripiprazole, then at night half methylphenidate and half clonidine Up to you and your doctor

Ritalin helps me so much so to do work for university and I'm thankful for that. But I also wish I could do those things without medication. Luckily I only have to take it when I study for an exam. I learned to do the other chores without it. Just slower than others.
My ADHD meds started at 10mg. Methylphenidate. I'm now up to 40mg. Don't notice anything being different. Thankfully I've found some coping things for it to help. Such as seeking my phone and earbuds into my welding lab, so I actually stay in my booth. I also forget to eat, repeatedly. Would get hungry, but instead of getting up and making food, I just say I'll do it later. Spoiler: I never do it.

no Idea why I'm here but I was once on ADHD meds that turned me into basically a zombie incapable of doing tasks myself I had to be told what to do. there was another one that lowered my blood pressure to a dangerous level and some just didn't work. man I wish there was one that just made my brain shut up so I could work but they all have side effects and weird things they do. :/ These days I'm not on medication and it's a nightmare struggle to get by but I prefer it over playing the medical lottery of medication effects.
adhd is when every topic in your head is a hyperlink to more topics also Hyper focus? NO thats a misnomer its more like tunnel vision. combine those two and you get a very weird sort of spontaniety.  new topic to tunnel into. hard to leave the new topic until the next one just pops out of no where.  i found like. i don't really have willpower and self control. so i instead like work better if i do preperations like mental rituals before hand or even the day before. after the mental prep physical prep. like actual traps and setups to put myself into a position where i MUST work.  know your triggers, know your habits. cause they are pretty bad. yet pretty consistent. i get sleepy focusing on seminars that i realized i can basically watch tutorials to bed. music helps me focus. and google chrome triggers me to mindlessly opening up webnovelsites so i uninstalled chrome.  adhd is like playing a bugged videogame character the bugs are pretty consistent, but its annoying early on.

I take Vyvanse, and personal It helps me out a lot! Especially in school. I usually just write on myself for reminders incase I get sucked into something so deeply from my focus being on only that, and at times I will randomly look at my arm and see I have to do other things and check it out, and do it. Of course, you dont gotta write on yourself, you can use sticky notes, or create your own little system that helps you out the most. Though, with Vyvanse it doesn't not help with my other symptoms whatsoever. Only focus. Which sucks since with my ADHD I can have these moodswings, which is mainly toward extreme levels of anger, especially if someone touches me or just something weird feeling I dont like touches me. If not that, takings someones words differently, which can enrage me as well, but right now I am on some mood stabliers, though they dont help me all that much, but ADHD is a weird thing to experience, medicated or not. It can be troubling, and we all have our bad parts of it.
As a kid and teen I experienced some *hardcore* ADHD. Apparently I was one of the most extreme cases the psychologist had seen up to that point. So they prescribed me Ritalin.  And nowadays I‚Äôm just - fine. Probably more distractable than the average still, but it‚Äôs not an impairment.   And that‚Äôs all there is to the story, really. If other medication doesn‚Äôt work out, I‚Äôd recommend Ritalin. It just increased my overall focus, but without taking away my agency or playing weird tricks on my mind.

You can have two people that are having the same problem with the same condition give them the same medication and then they can have the same effects from that medication for one of them that could be great and the other one that could be terrible, even if they having the same results of the medication

Haven't been diagnosed (bc it's not that easy in Poland to get to the right professional for diagnose), but both this and the last ADHD vids felt extremely relatable. I struggle to focus, but when I need to make sure I accomplish ANYTHING during the day, I follow Pomodoro technique using simple alarm clock to help me. I know this concept has nothing to do with ADHD, but even when I get distracted by something, I get an alarm every now and then to remind myself to get up, drink some water, then another alarm to get back to work and that kinda resets my focus for some time. It's far from perfect as I still get distracted, but it helps me regain focus for a while, letting me finish a task.

I found my way with dexamphetamine works really good for me
This is why meds alone aren't a great treatment for ADHD, the best results come from a combination of meds and CBT. Having a counselor of therapist who can help you target your most debilitating symptoms and formulate ways to work around them is hugely helpful. It's easy to get too focused on making things "right" and being "normal" but when you have ADHD you just can't expect yourself to do everything the "normal" or straightforward way, it will just make you miserable because adhd brains are inherently not straightforward. But if I could "cure" my adhd I wouldn't, it makes me a much more creative problem solver. I wouldn't think the way I do without it, which is why I don't think of it as a disability but rather my brain's response to society's Maximum Productivity Bullshit.
lol i had a similar thing happen to me cuz i have adhd. i was taking meds for a year and then my first year of high school began and one day i felt out of breath constantly with a tight chest and everything so i was taken to the hospital to be evaluated for 6 hrs and they came to the conclusion it was the medication. and i was supposed to slowly quit it but i one day just said fuck it and went cold turkey.  my learning ability increased 50% by being off of it.  medication is complicated for adhd idk why.

1:20 My brain going wild be like:
The absolute worst thing about having to take Ritalin for most of my childhood is that even though I took a low dose with breakfast and lunch, it was still in my system at bedtime and  so so so often I would hyperfocus so much on my own heartbeat that I could *never* get to sleep. I swear, when I stopped taking it in high school I must've slept like the f**king dead that first week.
Haha funny sandwich man make relatable content hehe
Yo, I stopped with meds a while back and started exercising a lot. Good leg workouts/moderate cardio helps restore blood flow to your frontal lobe. Also jogging your brain for a bit helps too but that hard when your not actively trying all the time. The 2 together or in sequence is great as well. The main thing for me is screen time, this one is prob the hardest but of course the most effective, I've noticed that when I've been absent from my phone/computer for a while I can be "normal" for a day or 2. Its really a great feeling but it's really easy to fall back. If you have a passion, your ADHD should deem that "efficient" enough to keep you interested. For instance I love astronomy and I could read on that shit for hours but you can't just _start_ reading and expect to stay on task. I like to do if I'm relatively distracted that day is read all the "Juicy" information first and sometimes that gets me hooked or at least when I go back to read it I have info already and don't have to put much work in.
Its the same for autism and antipsycotics. Yes they definetly can help but there are always downsides from the meds. Its not always a win win. But its also not always bad.

nonpyschedelic mushrooms genuinely changed my life, theyre a lot less volatile than prescription meds i take straterra 100 mgs daily and have for 5 or 6 months, before that i was on adderall for 6 years. i dont recommend most prescription medications for adhd, theyre extremely hit or miss and theres always something you dislike, for instance mine works well and stays in my system without having an active effect that burns out and i feel much better all the time rather than having a productive period boosted artificially.   nonpyschedelic mushrooms can be taken daily and theyre great for your health, i use something called om master blend bc it has a bunch of different mushrooms for the body, but lions mane would probably do wonders for you :]
Dr. Tracey Marks has some very interesting and validating content on ADD/ADHD. I was inadvertently doing many of the things that she recommended prior to working up the courage to try medication. I did everything in my power to keep myself organized. I write notes all over the place, I put everything on my smartphone's calendar, and I set reminders for everything that I am supposed to do. I bought a smartwatch in November, which helps me set reminders without having to get my phone out. I treat the meds as another tool. I purposely don't take them on weekends and often go 1-2 weeks without them to make sure I don't have any dependency on them. I've forgotten to take them on numerous occasions, and it doesn't dramatically impact my day. I definitely notice a difference in my ability to focus, but I don't let it control me. It definitely helps to have a doctor who will work with you.

I took ADHD meds most of my life, then stopped around 5 years ago. I believe it did help me focus in school but screwed up everything else about me over time. I used to be hyper and loud, now I'm usually calm and extremely shy. I used to scream and want to break things when I was mad for a long time, now I almost cannot express feelings at all. Maybe it wasn't the medication and just a change with age but I honestly think it was at least some part of it.
Wow
As an ADHD and Autistic person, I did Vyvanse for 10+ years, and it was...NOT FUN, Turned me into a full on Zombie and just Angry non stop, While I did focus, it was at the rest of my expence. Currently Unmedicated for years and as I grew older I managed to grab a hold of most of what I can.
I feel like the loop also means you are subconsciously looking for every reason to procrastinate and avoid the big task. Even though you want to get it done, a part of you clearly doesn't due to knowing how much time it'll take out of your day, and it's easier to do literally anything else except that.  I should know. I have struggled with this my entire life. I end up spending way more time overthinking about how long it's going to take, what a pain cleaning is, and make a million and a half excuses to put it off or do it "tomorrow." I spend way more doing this than actually completing the task even as slow as i do things. The dread, anticipation, and just getting yourself to move towards getting started is the hardest part.  It's really hard to motivate myself. But i finally understand why that is after so many years. A part of me is waiting and waiting for someone to scream at me and to make sure i finish whatever it is. Getting yelled at to do it would trigger a very begrudging "motivation." This became routine at some point during childhood and a terrible habit.  For me, it's purely psychological. I recognize this an awful habit i developed, and now, on my own, i struggle with self motivation because i never had to force myself. I got used to waiting out my parents or making excuses that I was doing another task that seemed just as important until someone else finally did the chore i was avoiding.  Just make sure to ask yourself: is it truly adhd, or are you waiting until it resolves itself, goes away, or for someone else to do it for you? Are you waiting for a conditioned "motivation" from childhood to push you out of habit? It's important to recognize that you are spiraling when you start making excuses to avoid it or doing something else instead.

I'm a grown-ass man who very likely has ADHD, but for me the problem is basically that I'm always in your "vyvanse mode": I will hyper-focus on one thing to the detriment of everything else. And not just because I ignore everything else, in fact it's almost sort of intentional due to the fact that anything else coming up WILL distract me and I know it. I'm not very comfortable at all with the idea of medication, because it's understood that ADHD is more of just a nuerotype, a certain kind of brain, than a disorder. But the way that our modern society works isn't very compatible with that nuerotype, and so THAT conflict creates disorder. I'm like "Why do I have to take the medication? Give society the f**king medication and let me enjoy my hyperfocus!"

I take Vyvanse and yeah that's about my experience. It's great for focus, but it's a conscious effort on my part to focus on the RIGHT task. Basically it feels like a constant state of hyperfocusing to me.  Originally I was instructed to take it every day, but I only take it on mornings of days where I know I will need the focus, like work days.  If you tend to have caffeine, it's not usually the best idea to have it with Vyvanse in my experience, because it is a stimulant. Makes my heart do funky things and also gives my body shakes. I also have to take it after I eat something because it affects my appetite and my stomach tends to feel gross if I don't (and I've learned that to be basic common sense with a lot of medications unless instructed otherwise), and I have to take it early in the morning or else it will keep me up at night.  But this is all my experience, it might be different for everyone, so take it for a grain of salt.

I had a lot of adhd issues when I was a kid. Couldn't focus in class. I was put on various medications as a kid and none of them I felt helped so i refused to take them. Not saying this is the case for everyone but what seemed to begin helping me to better manage symptoms was:   - Find a focus: my parents put me martial arts, which acted as a medium to put my energy into and allowed me to begin finding ways to practice and develop my focus and intentions that resonated with an interest.   - Practice focus: I got a program called holosync which is essentially  meditation with calming noises. However, I believe it was the way I would use it that helped. I noticed that depending on my life exposures, the more neurotic and unfocused I would be. During my holosync sessions I would force myself to focus on my breath. Whenever I had a thought come into my head (distraction) I would recognize and identify it, let it go, and go back to focusing on my breath. I believe this practice helped me practice focus because i was reinforcing the act of holding my attention on one thing, for a long period of time, that was something I chose, without distractions. Breathing is a passive activity that creates the illusion that you are doing it. For an otherwise healthy person, breathing is the easiest "thing you can do" which you can practice your focus on. It's just hard to do because we are being bombarded with our neurotic thoughts, expectations, and cravings. Part of this practice is learning to recognize them and be able to put them aside.   - Move with purpose: Set up goals and always question what productivity does a task provide and does it serve your intents and purpose. Is what you are doing productive? Does it serve your best intentions? To serve purpose mindfulness must be practiced. All of these things are like muscles that can build or atrophy. What we do is what we choose. What we practice is what we become. Also, like muscles they need trained and maintained.   - Journal: Create awareness of yourself and document your interactions, feelings, thoughts, and motivations. Aim to be as objective as possible when doing so. Reflect on moods, things that influence you in your environment (foods, people, lack of exercise, etc.), what activities serve you, what activities don't, what has interface with you and what shouldn't, what is your best intentions, what is your purpose, what do you value,  what is meaningful to you, what philosophies do you subscribe to, do you have any conflicting beliefs and if so why do they conflict? Taking inventory and create dialog with yourself so that you can better direct yourself to align with your best intentions. Knowing ourselves is what helps develop our self confidence as well as provides context to hold ourselves accountable to ourselves.  I'm not trying to simplify anyone's symptoms. I'm not claiming this is how you, "fix" ADHD. This for me in my case is what seemed to aid me in finding more focus and capabilities and to keep tabs on self-defeating practices. If medications aren't working for you like they weren't working for me maybe trying these types of things can help?   I believe the meaning of life is to have meaningful experiences. I believe there are no "appropriate interest". However with that being the case, I also believe we need to recognize how some of our interests may not serve our best interests to experience what is truly meaningful to us. Some engagements don't serve us because they don't have productive means to our true intentions. I believe the more we practice being in line with our true intentions the stronger that muscle gets and the easier we can do it. However, I also believe having fun and being spontaneous and adventurous is also a necessary element to all of this too. At the end of the day it all boils down to a simple word, "balance".

I've never done that before but I figured it out! I also learned how engine's work and fixed my car!! Holy shit my adhd was so bad but I can THINK NOW

I doubt you‚Äôll see this. But I started TM(transcendental meditation) last year and it‚Äôs honestly changed my life with battling adhd symptoms. I get the best of both worlds of being able to focus on physical tasks, and it helped me improve concentration on my academics. Scientifically speaking it‚Äôs got a lot of robust evidence for being able to help adhd symptoms, and anyone (including kids with the disorder) can do it because it‚Äôs an effortless practise. Unfortunately it requires a tutor to learn it, and if you live in a big city that can be expensive, but the amount it‚Äôs done for me, I don‚Äôt grudge the fee whatsoever. For me it feels like it‚Äôs added 4 hours to my day with how much more I‚Äôm able to get done, I sleep better, I‚Äôm not stressed out nearly as much, and my working memory has improved greatly.   Anyone in here who thinks they may have adhd, or even just have symptoms of adhd from the technological tik tok world we live in, I urge you to look into it.

Been diagnosed as well and am currently on Ritalin. I will say that for most, the initial taking of the pill is amazing. It was the first time I WANTED to remove my noise-canceling headphones at work... but that goes away. The biggest problem from there is overcoming the bad habits that have occurred due to adhd (among other things like the environment, social, other mental health, etc). And that can take time, which sucks, but it took time to create the habits too.   I like the explanation of how it helps. I have always used this analogy: Neurotypical folks run at say 70% focus during an average day (give or take) while adhd folks run more at 40%. When NT takes the meds, they run at 80%. For adhd folks? 70% if we are lucky! It isn't to make us super smart or have the hyper focus like movies depict, we just need to function in a world where we have troubles doing that.

I have ADHD and i take methylphenidate, or in other words "ritalin" (I couldn't find the direct translation of it, but it's like methylphenidathydrochroride). In Denmark it's almost free so you know that the doctors don't just try to sell something. It have helped me much even though i can hardly "feel" it. It lasts for 10-12 hours and it just clears up the mind. Tasks are generally easier, but you have to get yourself started. Many of my friends take the same thing and it has the same affect on them. I have it and the only thing I‚Äôve found helped is establishing habit patterns with locations and consistency. You want to write each day, pick a specific couch cushion, a specific genre of music, and start small. You wanna meditate. Pick a specific time, spot, and practice. You wanna do yoga or go shopping or remember to do your homework, tie these things to locations, music, media, or any other stimuli. You can use operant and classical conditioning to hack your brain and get around the fact that your car burns fuel and drives way to fast.

My experience with meds as a late-ish diagnosis (early 20s) has been okay, but a bit of a ride.  I take ritalin, and my doc basically told me to take them as needed, my dose is 3 10mg per day, but I rarely take it all, usually 2 are good for work days, 1 for busy weekends, 0 for lazy days and vacations. I really like the options for good and bad brain days  It really helped with executive disfunction, I can start, stay on and end tasks more easily, but I do have to stay aware of the highs and lows to keep productive for long periods. Also internal hyperactivity was a big problem that is really better now. The side effects are minimal (the day you stop can be drowsy, the moment it hits my heart gets a bit fast and high doses decreases my appetite), but I have noticed the emotional dependence - a couple of times I couldn't get a refill and it felt like the world was going to end, a lot of emotional disregulation for a couple of hours. It feels like I won't be able to do anything without the meds. But I am capable, I lived without them 20 years and it was alright. I am working on it. (Not taking them is fine, not having them was bad)  Baseline, meds really helped my work life (and mental state) post college, but are kind like a wild beast.

Being stuck and locked onto whatever task you happened to be pointed at when the meds kick in is SUCH an exact description of my own experience on Vyvanse that it‚Äôs kinda wild. I used to make the mistake of doing something for myself in the mornings before work but then I realized if I did, my day would be completely shot. I had chronic fatigue before I started meds so for me, it‚Äôs worth it, but everything you described is SO real.  Also, for what it‚Äôs worth, ADHD meds (at least the stimulant ones) are one of the few medications you usually CAN just safely decide not to take anymore. The half-life of these meds is quite short, so not everyone will even take them every day.
I always had some issues growing up. I could focus on some tasks, and really struggle with others. But it was never really caught because I did pretty well over all. I managed, even if some simple tasks were an absolute fight because I couldn't get my brain to work without the right stimulation. I think having lots of routine made it easier for me to not having to focus on remembering events or to do things, because it was all part of a routine. Now I'm older and I don't have those same routines anymore, and I've noticed more and more symptoms that have always been there, but just in the background. I manage now as well. But sometimes it's so frustrating and difficult to not understand why I can't just "do" something, and I've begun to wonder what if it doesn't have to be like that? It does feel a bit like "everyone" have ADHD today, and I don't wanna be one who uses "I think I might have adhd" to be special. I can deal with my issues by knowledge and better habits even if I don't get a diagnosis, but maybe it would be easier to accept not to feel guilt for struggling with certain things if I got it checked out. So drug schedules are a relatively new thing in ADHD meds, the thing is if you use the meds everyday you build up tolerances and strange habits. So taking a few days break everyone in a while could be beneficial provided that you are on a low dose talk to your doctor if you want to try it, some doctors might not want to take the risk on the newer research. Also Adderall is like the nuke of ADHD meds, always consult your doctor about starting with the lighter stuff like Ritalin.

Adderall works for me. But I don't need it for distractibility, though it did help with that. I need it for awareness. Without it, I live more in my own mind than in reality. It's not that the world is less "real" feeling, but more like my internal monologue never shut up. Imagine going through life with a narrator that talks over everyone and everything. With adderall, I still have a pretty talkative internal monologue, but now it (usually) takes its turn, and more often than not talks about what's going on outside my own head. Tends to repeat what people say, for example, which helps me remember things. The downside is that it makes creativity, self awareness, and time perception kinda "tuned out". Like it's still there, but it's background noise, so I have to have an external representation of something to be able to focus on anything introspective.

The animation at the start of the five people is the most accurate example of adhd
As someone who also has ADHD and has taken meds for it, I can relate to your struggles with side effects. I started taking medication in like 1st grade and continued with it all throughout elementary school. I forget what I took but I know it was a stimulant. I also experienced getting focused on the wrong tasks, but for some reason for me, that task always involved picking at things. I would mainly pick at my skin, hair, and even eyelashes. I would literally just pick at my hair all day long, and it got so bad that I actually started balding in some places on my head. the front of my head only had baby hairs for a while, and I had to get weird-looking bangs to cover it. I also would sometimes pick my eyelashes so much to the point where it was noticeable, and I would be so embarrassed when people asked me what happened to them. Eventually, when I got to 6th grade I wanted to take a break from medication during a sports season (the medication also made me very tired and it was hard to play sports) and after a while, I just stopped picking at things so much. I honestly didn't even connect my weird picking addiction to medication before that point, which I feel super dumb about now. but after taking a break from them I just noticed not only was I not picking things anymore, but I was also just feeling better all around, so I convinced my parents to take me off medication for good. I've only experimented with medication once since then (it went pretty much the same) but I have never really taken any medication seriously since. I truly believe that I am a much happier and healthier person off medication, or at least stimulant ADHD medication. I hate to bash medication because it can work really well for some people, but I guess the moral of the story is, if you are taking medication for the first time, do not disregard the side effects and know when they outweigh the benefits.
Just quickly, while Vyvanse does work slightly differently from adderol, it is still an amphetamine based stimulant, part of the same class of drugs and ultimately similar to Adderal, Ritalin, Dexedrine, etc.  With that out of the way, I had a similar problem with stimulant medications, where I could focus, but could just as easily focus on entirely the wrong thing and blow the whole day. What ended up working for me was actually a mix of 2 different meds. Adderal, which as a stimulant, allowed me to maintain focus. But the critical discovery was finding that I could take it in conjunction with another medication called Guanfacine, which is an alpha2A agonist, and allowed me to more easily direct my focus (basically, the stimulant quiets down the overactive back half of the adhd brain, and the a2A agonist "stimulates" the underactive front part of the brain, responsible for executive function.)   While this combination worked really well for me in terms of actually getting things done, it was ultimately unsustainqble, as after about 2 or 3 months of continuous use, I would start having unmanageable physical side effects (one of the potential side effects of guanfacine is a motor control issue in the muscles of the tongue and throat, so I would have trouble swallowing and eventually would start waking up in the middle of the night, choking on my own tongue.. no fun.)   So now I am unmedicated and as unproductive as ever lol.
As someone with unmedicated adhd (by choice) this video hits home. Most days if i need to do something and i don‚Äôt have the immediate time to do it i‚Äôll say ‚Äúi‚Äôll do it later,‚Äù but that just means i‚Äôll forget. My parents tried getting me on a few meds when i was young but i was a walking zombie when on them, i‚Äôve grown up learning to work with and around my adhd and not having to rely on medicine to chemically change who i am is freeing. Not saying that taking meds is bad tho if it works for you i‚Äôm happy :)

This really highlights what my psych doctors always made a point to emphasize. Not every med works for everyone, let alone to the same degree or in the same fashion. It was always really heavily impressed upon me that it could take a good amount of time to find the meds and dosages that would work for me. A few people get lucky and the first medicine they try works like a charm. But SO MANY MORE do not get that lucky, and have to try a ton of different meds at different dosages and in different combinations. The big important part is to keep trying new approaches until you find what's right. Don't just give up because the first thing didn't work. You just need something different, and that's ok.

Just BTW dont mess around if you feel out of breath all the time while on ADHD medication. Most ADHD medication is a stimulant, which has a very real chance to effect your heart because it usually makes it beat faster. If its too fast it is called Tachycardia, which is not healthy for long periods of time. Breathlessness can be a sign that your heart is not pumping blood efficiently.

as someone who was diagnosed as an adult (additionally as a woman) with the hyperactive type of ADHD, Adderall has worked the best for me in terms of focus and not running into most side effects regarding my sleep and/or feeling way too wired. Concerta was the first that i personally tried & while it did work, for the first and last hour i would get extremely drowsy which is a major problem as i take my meds right when i wake up and before i had to get to class. However if you have no where to go, it would be perfect to keep taking. With adderall i do get a lot done and my focus is pretty okay, i'm better off on it as it also regulates my mood and energy pretty well. THe way you describe the ability to just DO whilst on them is so accurate because now i realize off of my meds there were just days i would stare into the void, lost to my thoughts for HOURS, or like my fidgeting would get so bad and my energy would spike so high i felt like i could run a mile one moment and then feel exhausted the next or either feeling could last for hours back to back. it's so refreshing to see someone talk about this so openly and with experiences that are so accurate. Honestly though, ADHD is a wild ride for all those who have it.

this sums up my life with ADHD pretty well. Can comfirm this man is a certified ADHD club member
Funny that your friend calls adderall "meth" because Vyvanse is just a prodrug for a type of amphetamine already inside Adderall (one of Adderall's ingredients is dextroamphetamine, vyvanse is "lisdexamfetamine" - it's a prodrug for dextroamphetamine). It will affect you differently 100%, but I'd say both are equally meth-like. Because Vyvanse is a prodrug, though, it has to be processed by your liver which makes it slower acting.
Meds taught me what is and isn't in my control. I tried a lot of them, and by senior year in high school, i just quit. I started working, living, completing my normal chores. Evenrually, i had it pretty much handled. I didn't feel stunted, distracted, or impeeded. I just, did. Not effectively or as efficiently as I hoped, but when i took matters inro my own hands, getting distracted wasn't a terrifying prospect to run away from. I caught myselft, reeeled in, and refocussed..  Then, i discovered alcohol and drugs. Which made that worse. So. If you have adhd don't get high and only get drunk once you've completed your tasks for the day. Otherwise, if youre like me, youll get hypersensitive to little changes in your body and fucking lose it.

God, Meds don't work for me. I've never found a med in my twelve years of being diagnosed with ADHD. Strattera made me throw up everyday, Focalin caused me to manically pick at my hair, Adderall did the same thing that you said the last pill did to you to me, and vivance gave me violent mood swings.
As someone who refuses to take meds, I just stopped trying to function like everyone else and instead function how "I" need to in order to succeed at anything. I write everything down, follow the instructions I created, break large tasks down into smaller sub-tasks, arrange my office, room, phone and even my desktop folders in a way that makes the task at hand hard to ignore and even multiple alarms to set deadlines for each task and to limit social media and TV/youtube time(there are settings for both btw). And I now perform work better than my coworkers(and I have the statistics to prove it) and I'm significantly less stressed and feel like my life is together. Everyone is different but if you can find a way to work WITH your ADHD, you can turn your weakness into a super power. I can even learn things faster that those around me by sticking to what works for me.

I take vyvanse. Imma be real redirecting myself was a major hurdle. And yeah, side effects are common. I got lucky üòå. But uh, learning how to redirect yourself is a lowkey really important and often overlooked skill. My adhd kinda encouraged me to let whatever direct my focus. Like a leaf flying through the wind, i really had no control because i knew my brain would 404 focus not found anyway. On medication, i had to learn how to do what normal not incredibly impulsive people do, PRIORITIZE AND KEEP YOURSELF ACCOUNTABLE. it wasn't easy, but i figured it out, and honestly, there's no guide or Kindle ebook explaining it. Learning to prioritize tasks and keep yourself accountable is a skill, much like drawing or arithmetic. It's a learned process anyone with time and patience can learn if they take the time to.

baby meth, performance allowing drugs, brain suppressors. I started off with adderall for a couple years and was on a fairly high dose, was able to function pretty well but got angrier more often and had BP/heart rate issues. tried ritalin for a month, didn't get anything out of it, then started taking focalin. focalin has been a solid balance for me, no major side effects, no issues sleeping or getting overly stressed, and I'm able to focus enough to get stuff done, and still be able to swap tasks if necessary. as someone who didn't start taking my diagnosis seriously until I was 27, I definitely recommend trying at least a few more medications to find one that clicks for you. untreated adhd is 100% bullshit all day every day lol

I was on concerta for a short time, and OH BOY did it give me mood swings.  I would cry over nothing and then when my friends approached me _(cause you know- If a friend is crying - you want to comfort them)_ I would get really angry and yell at them for it.... It was awful.  The next med I tried -that I can't remember the name of- were very helpful. They made me able to both do things AND focus - however, every few hours or so, I would get muscle spasms in my cheeks that would cause me to yawn, over and over and over again.   Just rapid yawning every ten-ish seconds for almost half an hour, every few hours. I even got those yawn attacks while I was talking. It felt like someone physically pushed my mouth open to a point where my eyes would start to water.   Even though the meds worked great - in my opinion -, my doctor did not like the yawn attacks.  The one I have been on for the past seven years works great too, but only when I have something to do. It's super hard to relax, and my heart feels like it's beating more _(but it actually is not - cause I have monitored it and my bpm literally does not change - it is at a consistent 61)_ but feeling and hearing my heart is really annoying and makes me feel stressed even when I don't have anything to be stressed about.  And it also makes me unable to feel hunger.  I can hear my stomach growling and I can feel my energy dropping, but I cannot feel the hunger itself, which is both really good and really bad.  It's interesting how different meds give different side effects.

I had ADHD growing up and when they diagnosed me, they immediately put me on adderall.  I was laser focused all the time. I had no issues completing tasks, doing work, studying; however, I was also practically a zombie. I had no social skills to speak of. I barely talked to anyone, or did anything outside of that. I lost passion in most of my hobbies and started on to a slope of depression, which is really rough when you're only ten.  They took me off it and never put me back on anything else. I've learned to cope with it over the years for the most part, but lately I've been thinking about speaking to my psych or doctor about looking back into it. ADHD Medication has the highest efficacy of any psychiatric medication we have - but the solution is not just medication. I have adhd and learning how and why my adhd affects me the way it does helped so much! I still need and benefit from my meds, but I don't know that they'd work that well without understanding what ADHD is and how it works. Look into the lectures of Dr Russell Barkley - he talks about how the way you manage tasks and tackle problems needs to be different than people without ADHD in addition to medication.
For me, caffeine helps but isn't a full solution. Granted, I don't drink coffee or anything, just strong tea. Lots of tea.
I made an appointment with a psychiatrist after years of going to therapy and trying to manage my symptoms by myself. I‚Äòve gotten pretty good at understanding my brain, developing good habits and most importantly, noticing the moments in which I‚Äòm more capable of doing things and using those. I‚Äòm also using caffeine to self medicate which has helped me so much but the downside is it‚Äòs not very reliable (some days I barely feel it, others I get heart palpitations and anxiety). But overall, caffeine is a huge help. I still wanna talk to this doctor and maybe try some meds to see if they work better for me but I‚Äòm honestly scared that they won‚Äòt work cuz then it feels like my last resort is gone. :/
Never been diagnosed   But my brain is speedb  I am him
Hi, I work in the Behavioural Health field. If you can convince your psychiatrist, I recommend everyone ask if they can take a GENESIGHT or similar test. It's just a cheek swab and the lab will compare your DNA and make a really handy dandy list of common Mental Illness related meds that are more likely or less likely to treat you effectively, mainly ADHD meds, Anti-depressants, and anti-psychotics, but also some interesting information (Like how well your body metabolizes) that will help not only your psychiatrist narrow down meds for you to cycle through until you find what you need, but also future doctor visits for non-behavioural health medication management. Also, new meds are coming out all the time that don't always get TV spots so it's good to be honest about your issues and concerns early with your med management system, about this time last year a non-stimulant ADHD med developed for children was starting to hit the market. It's not approved for adults yet, but the implication that this could help people with heart issues/addicts is there and it's exciting.
I feel like another thing people don't understand about ADHD with meds (in my personal experience) ADHD doesn't only affect work skills but also social skills. With meds, I'm not as antsy and I can focus and work well, but I still struggle with social cues and changing behavioral habits. A lot of the time I am hyper-aware of people's reactions to my behaviors, I know when I am doing something that bothers someone but I struggle to change the behavior because often times it's a habit that I've developed to mask other parts of my ADHD.

man adhd sucks. i take focalin and i just dont . eat ever,, in the day ill eat like nothing and at night ill become shrimp god monster,,.... its a difficult thing to live with. my thought process is just boyoyoyoing zip zowie boom bang pow or bllhhfffrrbgh or both at once . my diet is just really messed up because of my meds unfortunatelt :( a while ago after having been diagnosed with adhd since i was like 9 i realized that there are also a lot of other symptoms that are not just "woah haha what is that" and actually explained some of my behavior ,, like "hey wait theres a reason why i act stupid like this and im not jst a horrible person" . its certainly an experience and nto one id like to live with but thats just how it is ... but its nice to know that there are way more people out there with adhd than i originally though t .
imo some people with ADHD can live with meds but some can‚Äôt. and some people‚Äôs biology works differently/better with certain meds than others. it needs to be recognized more that not all ADHD is the same level of severity nor does it always ‚Äòbehave‚Äô quite the same  no matter whether you take meds or which ones you try though, the most helpful thing is to research a TON about ADHD and how it works- and be very aware of the brutal truth that what works as motivation for others simply won‚Äôt ever consistently work for you. and on the other hand, things that mean nothing to other people might unexpectedly be motivating for you, like changing the room you‚Äôre in, adjusting the lighting/temperature, or reading your textbook out loud theatrically etc. finding a way to convince yourself there‚Äôs SOMETHING cool/interesting/fashionable/deep (to you personally) about the things you actually need to do is super helpful, especially with mitigating the common med side effect of hyperfixation on the wrong task. Your meds will actually work better in combination with research/therapy/general awareness
I was diagnosed as a child and around high school i decided to stop taking meds. (adderall) It's been many many years since then and I've figured out how to game myself into work. Pretty much all i do is make a list of things I need to do. a reasonable list. like 5 things. I have a list on my computer screen of things I can do and then a slightly different list on a notepad/planner that I always walk around with. That way if im ever distracted I can audibly ask myself "what do i need to do" or "what should I be doing" and I'll read one of the checklists and work on that. Then When its done I can check one of the things. It's liek gamification of work! Usually if i stay on task I can work fast enough to get some things done and then I can relax and let my mind run free for a little bit.

I'm increasingly convinced that ADHD and similar conditions are actually just various types of perfectly functional brains that are being subjected to a suboptimal environment for their particular characteristics, and that medication is essentially like trying to hammer in a phillips head screw with a glass bottle. Like, it works, sometimes, I guess? But it's completely missing the real issue; the brain is working fine, it's the narrow focus of society that is what's wrong.

I describe Vyvanse like Adderall, but on all the steroids. Hopefully you're more fortunate than me and live in a place with decent mental health services so you can figure this out. ADHD is better referred to Executive Function Disorder. In that, we know what we need to do but for whatever reason can‚Äôt pull the trigger and just do it. Adderall helps bc dopamine motivates you to do things. Simple as that. Moral of the story, stop taking the meds and learn to simply do things and begin organizing things so you know what you need to do and can track the progress.

Okay so i think it should be known why at the end Mr. Ice Cream Sandwich was saying not to stop taking meds, because it wasn't clear to me in the video. there's this thing that happens to the human body when there is a sudden withdrawal of a substance from the body. this happens for example, when you suddenly stop drinking coffee. I'm sure many of you have experienced this before. bassically your body reacts negatively to the sudden change in your system. with coffee its often pretty mild, but with DRUGS, it can sometimes be FATAL. FATAL. so yeah, if you want to stop taking a drug, talk to your doctor. pls.

This is an important message for ice cream sandwich and anyone else who is deciding whether or not to take a med for ADHD or something else. Please read if this applies to you but, please note that I'm not a doctor.  I have ADHD and I take 20mg of adderall. I had to start lower of course, probably at 5 as well. In my experience Adderall doesn't help with my focus that well either but I am able to actually get things done or at least get more done than I would unmedicated. When I tried a different med (I forgot what it was) I started getting headaches and it felt like it was draining my energy. So, when it wore off I tended to be burnt out and grumpy/emotional. And when I don't take any meds I'm barely able to accomplish anything. So, now I'm back on Adderall. While it doesn't help as much as I would like it to, it's the best thing we've found so far. So, my advice is that if you find something that helps, even if it's not as much as you would have liked it to, use it as long as it doesn't do more harm than good. Like if when unmedicated you get x amount done, but medicated you get more than x amount done and it doesn't negatively affect you, then you should take it but only if you want too and see progress. Of course, if you would rather stay unmedicated that's fine too. Or if a med helps you get things done but not focus, then maybe you could use the med and try something else to help with focus. Having said this, if you looked into it a bit you could find a lot of different methods to help with focus or tips for ADHD ppl in general. I hope this helps.  Also, please remember I'm not a doctor and this is just my experience and my advice based off of it. As well as, my advice goes for anyone who might need a med for something other than ADHD.
try deoxin heheheh litteraly meth
If you want to try medication again, I have to recommend Modafinil. It gives very good focus like Vyvanse, but without being overly rewarding.
On vyvanse, cannot emphasize enough, DO NOT STOP TAKING YOUR ADHD MEDS COLD TURKEY. I have had several instances where I couldn't get a refill in time, and I get these horrible crashes. Migraines, feeling sick, extremely fatigued, not fun.   Everyone's experience will vary, but stopping your medication without talking to your psych is a bad idea in general. You can get some NASTY side effects.

I'm under the impression adhd isn't just about taking the pill. I tried a full month on mine and honestly, I felt like a husk after. I get way better results when I workout and tend to my other basic needs first. Rest days are okay, even you have the zoomies. Resting can mean light excercise or other forms of motion, off meds (unless you are on a high dose or simply can't), things that re-energizes you. I was prescribed a very high dose in my early years that made me hallucinate, but now, I have a low dose of another one, enough to bridge the gap of doing, but not enough to overdo. Also, drink a lot of water. The meds dehydrate you and can cause kidney stones. Eating smaller and more frequent meals along with water can alleviate the sensation of complete deflation.

I got on adderall this year and it‚Äôs been amazing so far. I hope it keeps being effective‚ÄîI feel so calm all of the time but I can still change levels as quickly as I want. I have been studying every day, 8 hours a day, for two months to prepare for my MCAT. I never feel tired of working, I don‚Äôt have to get up and walk around every 15 minutes and am completely self regulated.  It feels like my brain is scattered apart in a million directions without medication, and with them I feels like I‚Äôm all in one place. I can write out a calendar, I can stop myself from playing video games because I‚Äôve habituated a work ethic, it‚Äôs changed my life.  Tl;dr don‚Äôt let arrogance or fear stop you from trying medication (like I did). ADHD meds across the board show consistent QoL improvement for so many people.

I currently take Vyvanse to manage my ADHD, and before that Adderall.  The most helpful advice I have been given is plan out your day before you take your medication, write it down and keep it on you at all times, and check it often. I fell into depression after stopping taking my Vyvance back when I was a kid. Back then there was no follow up after stopping medication. I'm so happy when I learned about it later in my life. Most ADHD drugs work by letting dopamine and noradrenaline circulate through your brain for a longer period of time. When you stop taking the pills, you effectively stop the flow of these chemicals that are responsible for making you feel more "happy" and concentrsted.

Ya I feel that. I started with concerta and started to get terrible headaches to the point where I had to lay down as it wore off. Switched to a different one and boom: fixed. Luckily there are many different types. I hope you find one that works for you :)
I have to say this about any psychiatric medication: be involved, take an active role. Seriously. Your doctor does not know how you feel on a daily basis, does not keep a daily journal, can't actually tell what you feel beyond what you describe with words, and can't know how meds work for you beyond what studies say. At first, this approach won't be working well, because you have no experience, but slowly, you will start to gain it and get closer to finding the right medication

I've taken Vyvanse for I think 7 ish years now? I found the key to be, whenever you have a task you know you need to do that day, take the meds. If there is a day you don't have stuff to do, just don't take them. *In my case* Vyvanse has been something I take occasionally and fortunately don't have adverse side effects. I've found it to be worse actually when I consistently take it, like you were saying. *Edited: I am no medical professional, follow the advice of your doctor and be safe!

If you do take this medication, I don't recommend taking it every day, withdrawal symptoms are terrible. However, drinking coffee works greatly for getting things done in my experience, when the coffee wears out is when you can't think for anything. NEVER TAKE COFFEE WITH MEDICATION IF THE MEDICATION IS OVER 10 milligrams, THE HEARTRACE IS IMMENSE.

my personal experience with ritalin, since it wasnt mentioned: it started out good, i was more focused and could actually bare doing school work and shit, but if i got distracted i still was focused, but on the wrong thing. thats similar to the experience in the vid, with one change: the side effects.  it started out with no side effects wich was surprising, but a few weeks in it kicked in. i wasnt taking the med regularly, only when i needed it, so it might had an effect. but slowly i started losing my appetite when it kicked in and for the whole day even after it wore off. that was ok i guess, i could manage it although it wasnt ideal. the problem started when after the huge boost of focus when i was on the med, it got worse then usual after it wore off. i was unable to focus at all, unable to do anything, and i was extremely tired. having a conversation or remembering something was impossible, and i usually unintentionally fell asleep.  but the worse one was what i called "hyper-awareness". imagine the feeling of the blood pumping through your veins, every hair on your body moved by the air, every muscle working. i felt it all the time, amplified, and it was driving me crazy.  since then i stopped taking meds, i really dont like what it makes me and i just rather living my life differently.

My first experience with concerta was a trip man, i was awake for a full 24 hours until they wore off and i was have so many hallucinations it was insane, i'd go to sit down and it felt like the floor was melting, i'd lay down and it would feel like something is trying to rip my back open to get at me, anything i'd look at was my focus until the hallucinations kicked in again, at one point i saw a giant florescent yellow spider crawling around my room and almost had a panic attack. sadly nowadays it doesn't even work for me and im to scared of having another episode like that to swap to another medication, but when it did work you could visibly tell when it stopped working, i would just kinda flop and start doing whatever took my fancy
I'm in the UK  I just wish I could even get to the level of getting checked and getting a prescription, not the NHS, not even private and insurance wants anything to do with me, It's either a long waitlist or an endless circle of useless tasks to wear me down, It took me half a year just to find myself on another waiting list for a Private doctor  Pretty cringe innit

I tool ritalin for some years but i got used to it so the effect was gone, then i switched to methylphenidat sandoz retard, they really work great for me
As someone unmedicated with ADHD I found its better to have a task list of what to do prepared. That way, you can overload yourself with subtle distractions that are quick and get a habit formed of looking at the task list. If you are going to be distracted things like music and tabbing over to your task list circulates you back to the task at hand or at least distracts your with something you could be doing as oppose to not be doing. However, there may be curious times where you want to look something up and that always leads down a rabbit hole, but actively knowing this may lead you away from it.
My boyfriend who's got ADHD told me about his horrible experience with meds, he can't recall the name of the pill but stopped taking it by himself and some years later the WHO banned the meds because they caused long term neurological damage (he feels like he has problems with short term memory now which is even worse for his ADHD). He told me that being on meds, first of all, was a dependency. Forgetting the meds one day was painful, physically painful, withdrawal syndrome painful. Comparing some prescription drugs to meth is a valid comparison in some cases. He told me that his personality vanished under the meds, that he could focus on the tasks but was unable to have internal monologue. He had to be told what to do, he couldn't think of it by himself. The meds also messed up his libido and hunger wildly. That's why he is now free of meds and working by himself to solve the problems ADHD gives him by himself, although I have recommended him to visit a psychologist but money issues and all that (meds in my country are basically free, but public mental healthcare is just for show, you need to pay for quality there).  And this is not the case for just ADHD. I have generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) and I was on meds too until I stopped taking them all by myself because my psychiatrist was on vacation (leaving meds on your own is extremely dangerous but is quite common it seems). Which meds did I take? Xanax, literally prescribed Xanax, or Alprazolam if you don't want to sound like a junky, alongside a muscle relaxant and an antipsychotic drug because anxiety generated me paranoid thoughts. It was a toxic cocktail, my libido and hunger were nonexistent, I had severe apathy so I started doing dangerous things to find a bit of serotonin, I didn't feel like I was myself to the point that reflections gave me dysphoria because the me reflected didn't seem to be "me". The meds were making me go mad. I quit and with the help of a psychologist I have done much progress on myself, having some drugs for extreme cases to cut out the anxiety attacks, not for daily intake.  Bottom line, before considering daily medication try therapy and talking with people with your condition. Medication is quite strong and you should be use it alongside therapy or in the most extreme of cases were you can't do your daily life because of your condition  Edit: my boyfriend used methylphenidate (market name Concerta, Equasym, etc.) which apparently is the main substance of ADHD meds and the WHO in Oct 2020 declared it dangerous to long term health. My current anxiety meds are bromazepam which is a derivate of Xanax, I suppose that not taking it daily doesn't bring so many unwanted side effects. Still an addictive drug
Ok, so dealing with this issue for üò™many years. 1. 5mg Adderall is a baby dose, 20mg is the low dose for an Adult. 2. You may need a combination of meds, please continue to work with a professional to find a good stack. 3. Clean Keto diet helps, look up Bulletproof diet. 4. Exercise helps, just try to find an exercise that works for you. 5. Controversially, Nicotine is helpful as an ADHD medication, you can get 30 ‚Äúlozenges‚Äù from Walmart as a smoking quitting aid, I take 4mg when I need it, but you can start with 2mg.  It‚Äôs a pretty cheap thing to try (compared to meds) 6. Shop for a good deal on meds, brand Adderall for me is $250 at one pharmacy, generic was $120 at another one, and currently it‚Äôs $60 for a generic at a local pharmacy. (No insurance used) 7. The Adderall=meth thing, is technically correct but missing a huge amount of context.  So, any amphetamine will become methylated-amphetamine, aka methamphetamine, aka ‚Äúmeth‚Äù, because methylation is required to cross the blood-brain barrier.  This is a natural process that takes place over an extended period of time, which is the first big difference between Adderall and meth, meth is immediately available for the brain while Adderall is converted over time.  The second difference is the dosage, 60mg is the maximum prescribed dose of Adderall, meth-heads will use around 1 gram at a time, so about 17 times the maximum prescribed dosage.  Remember, ‚Äúthe dose makes the poison.‚Äù EVERYTHING is toxic in the right amount, even water.  Finally, for the love of God don‚Äôt do Strattera, the 2 weeks tried it I was focused on ‚Äúending it all‚Äù.  I‚Äôve heard it helps some, but in my opinion it‚Äôs not worth the risk.

Hi, I have ADHD too. Been on medication for a couple years too. My dad takes Adderall for his ADHD and it works great for him, so that‚Äôs what I started on. It made it easier to focus on things and do them, which was great, but it started making both my appetite and ability to sleep disappear. Neither of which were great in the first place, but it started becoming  a really bad issue. So I got off that, was unmedicated for a little while, and then started Strattera. It works okay I think, but it still has previous side effects (to a lesser extent). I have to take extra medication to mitigate the appetite loss effect still. Overall, meds are really weird. Great video:)
What you say happens to me too. I focus on the "wrong" thing or do more physical/immediate stuff. But that's okay to me. The meds don't cure everything, they only work in combination with other stuff. So I also have a mentor. And try to have study buddies because body doubling is amazing. On days where I get distracted and make fancy food instead of studying I try to still be proud of myself for making fancy food and doing all the cleanup instantly. Not what I had planned, but still important.  I did wonder for a while if I should switch meds to sth more useful but to me this is such an increase in general ability - I wait and see for a few more years xD
I'm sorry you went through that, but we already suffer so much persecution. Please don't call Adderall 'crack', it is amphetamine/dextroamphetamine salts while Vyvanse is lisdexamfetamine salts... Both are very close, and usually, if your body rejects one it will reject the other too (you should consider trying a non amphetamine based med). I tried Vyvanse and experience EXACTLY what you showed in the video, it was awful! But I can deal with Ritalin and Concerta (Both being methylphenidate) way better, Concerta being the best but I was crashing after it stopped working (8 hours).   I'm now on Wellbutrin (Bupropion) and it's... Hard. This med can take more than a month to stop collateral effects, and while it's not technically a stimulant, oh god you get accelerated! If it doesn't work, I will try Strattera (Atomoxetine). The thing is, my ADHD makes me completely dysfunctional and I won't stop until I find some way to feel less miserable. It's a journey; if you can work without meds it's great but if you can't there are still many options! Good luck, and your animations are always awesome!
I have ADD it's so crazy going through the switch between no meds to meds you don't know how you should feel

I also used to take Vyvanse, but it's only officially recognized as a medication for minors in my country, so I can't get it via public health insurance anymore. I have switched to Guanfacin, which I believe is sold as "Tenex" in the US (though the brand I'm taking is called "Intuniv"), and found that to work for me as well.  If you're still searching for something new, maybe have a look at it, I'd describe it as somewhere between Adderall and Vyvanse in terms of effect, though it doesn't pack as much of a punch as either. It pushes you just far enough so you can concentrate on your own effort rather than dragging you to that point like the other two do.  The thing with Vyvanse is that, if I'm not mistaken, it originally wasn't developed as a medication for neurodivergence, but for treatment of the heart. Thus, it can have pretty severe effects on your blood pressure. This is also the reason for why you have to slowly raise or lower the dosis you're taking when medicating with it, and why it can also have the side effect of making you feel sleepy.
The worst part about adhd for me was seeing everyone else in my class understanding the work and doing it so easily but for some reason I just couldn‚Äôt. That thought messed me up for a while bu
Ask about Non-stimulat meds instead!  Atomoxetine is what I'm on and it's a perfect balance, they take like a week to kick in but one they do and you're regularly taking them, there is no "waring off" its always working.
i had the same focus problem with my meds, and ironically for me so far, the solution has been both stimulant and non-stimulant meds. i've been on vyvanse for awhile now, and i think the worst part was being on 50mg and feeling like i'm on the verge of a panic attack all the time. now i'm on 300mg of qelbree and 30mg vyvanse. the qelbree gives me just enough umph in the "base executive function" department that i can better utilize the stupid focus powers of vyvanse. so far it's been a good combo. less anxiety, way more productivity at work the past month or so since i got the meds adjusted.

Also a thing to consider - medication is just part of a regimen. Things like therapy and such (if you can afford it/have coverage for it) should also be included in a mental treatment plan. Otherwise, you're just smacking one hole that all the whack-a-moles could get out of while ignoring the rest entirely.  Also, my ADHD sucks without an internal dialogue. I can't imagine how it'd feel WITH an internal dialogue - other than terrifying, because the concept of an internal dialogue kinda scares me.

So, I guess I have ADHD then...  All my half finished projects... But I also hyperfocus on the wrong things for hours.... And if I have to be among other people I always wear my noice cancelling headphones, or I will get owerwhelmed and fatigued... Never diagnosed, never medicated, just living with it...
So pills didn't work that great for me BUT I found another way to work. If you know ADHD, you'll know what hyperfocus is (I think, I assume everyone gets it but I'm not 100% sure). So you wanna learn your triggers for it. For me it's a specific tempo. It can be music, it can be commentary videos. But if you can't focus, go around youtube until you find something that works. On thursday, LGR's Sims 4 and Sims 3 reviews hit the sweet spot. When you find your magic tempo (which can change daily, or sometimes multiple times a day) then it literally feels like magic. All the noise in your head just goes _poof_ and you're only thinking about the one thing you want to work on.  Two weeks ago it was the background music for FFXIV's final Endwalker boss' 2nd phase. Had that on loop for about 4 days straight, did insane amounts of work.  Give it a shot! Higher maintenance than pills because you need to find what works each day, but I found that I only have like 8 "sound moods" I go through, so after going through them all you can have playlists set up for any tempo you need. Near-instant hyperfocus.

I had a conversation about ADHD with my boss recently. He was really surprised to hear that I had it, because of the misconception that people that suffer from ADHD are hyperactive all the time and I‚Äòm a pretty calm guy. I took medication for it for a really short time when I was in Kindergarten, but stopped because I didn‚Äôt like how they felt and my mum accepted that decision and sent me to therapy instead. That didn‚Äôt really help my focus, but I no longer flew into fits of rage and threw things at my parents. Today I‚Äôm pretty happy that I don‚Äôt depend on meds to do what I‚Äôm doing. I managed to get through school and university (barely) and now work in marketing with a great team that can deal with my tangents and distractions. ‚ò∫Ô∏è
