why is this video so much more quiet than your other videos?
As someone who has ADHD, this is relatable. I originally wanted to be a policeman but then got reminded by my parents just how much concentration that would take as I need to have an absolute eagle eye when out on patrol, so that idea went in the bin and I‚Äôm glad I didn‚Äôt waste time on that route because I can now see just how stressful that would be. I knew that my adhd really likes my Xbox, I mean *really* likes it, but that is hit and miss of whether I could turn that into a career, because e-sports is the best of the best and Let‚Äôs players have to put in years of work and have to rely on the YouTube algorithm to get  enough viewers to even make 50 quid, so that was also in the bin. But then I stopped and looked at myself, and concluded that something that takes as much coordination and engagement as playing Xbox would be good, so I turned to music. I picked drums as I thought drummers were cool, and within a few months I was addicted, and now coming up to a year later, I have my own E-kit that I can practise whenever I want, whether I have medication in my system or not.  So my advice to people with ADHD, look at what your brain likes to engage with and see if you can make a career out of it, if not, look for something else that takes roughly the same skills as that and try it. Don‚Äôt make your brain do something it clearly doesn‚Äôt want to do, as that just leads to frustration. For me, I used my gaming skills to find musical talent I didn‚Äôt even know was there before.
My experience with taking adderall in for the latter half of highschool and then switching to Vyvanze in college was that they‚Äôre Exactly the same (because they chemically are, Vyvanze is literally just adderall but with the amino acid lysine attached to it) but Vyvanze lasts longer throughout the day, which makes it better for long class days.  But also they straight up just turn off my emotions and my appetite so I don‚Äôt take them when I‚Äôm not in school.
I think everyone on the world has ADHD.  I don't know a single person who doesn't fight with that issue.

i think its funny how over time his legs got shorter
I had a similar experience with feeling sick and exhausted when I was prescribed Ritalin. It turned out it was me crashing when it wore off. When I mentioned it to my psychiatrist she was like "oh yeah you're experiencing crashing like with caffeine" she asked when I took it and when I started to feel sick and I said I took it at 9am and felt sick around 1pm. She just stared at me like I said something crazy, then she said something along the lines of wow, you're 9 hour medication is only lasting 4 hours... I guess since I'm young and have a strong liver, I was metabolizing it too fast. So she had me try Adderall and that fixed the crashing problem for me.   ADHD medications are definitely not perfect, for me I always get a mixed bag. Like I can focus better on some things and I talk way slower (much needed improvement) but I can also struggle to think clearly sometimes too. Hopefully you find the right fit for you if you continue with the medications

I've been diagnosed and undiagnosed soooooo many times from adhd. Currently I'm categorized as "undiagnosed" (well kinda) and back when my doc n I were experimenting which medication was right for me I had lost 20 kg in less then 1 week! I had become so weak it wasn't until we kept trying over and over again that I then landed on anit-anxiety medication (Which is kinda being used to calm my hyper-fixations on things and as well as for my adhd) though it does work great but it has certainly made me a lil "tired/lazy" but it does work. We are still experimenting and seeing how much I should take etc and what not. But my doc has truly helped me a lot! Point is make sure you are in hands of a good doc and you discuss the important things with them and work together and not against your adhd!  PS Move to Canada we have free health care yall! Also just moving to canada won't solve everything for ya but still the health care system is deff better then it is in America! (Ofc do ya research before making rash decisions ya doofus <3)
When I took Concerta with a big enough dose for the first time, I remember sitting down in the kitchen, taking out a comic book and asking for my husband to make himself a sandwich or something (to check how I react to noises). I remember having this really odd feeling of "numbness" hitting me. It wasn't a bad feeling. It just felt funny. Kinda like when you have just woken up and you aren't 100% awake yet. A certain kind of tension-free state if you will. I mentioned it out loud to my husband and he said "That sounds like... relaxation?". And while I was processing what he meant by this, I realized that I had been able to follow up the story of the comic without getting distracted by the noises around me. I can still visualize the scene: me sitting in a chair holding a comic book, looking like the "is this a bird" -meme, but instead of a bird, the "obvious thing" was the relaxation. Relaxation feels insane (quote of the millenia).

It might help to look at other medication too, for ADHD there are stimulants and non stimulants. If stimulants are wonky non stimulants could help! Id also recommend some kind of edition to medication though (like some kind of therapy). I avoided stimulants because they‚Äôre kinda like meth lol
His description of the vyvanse focus problem is on point. You can focus really well if you are directed at the tasks you want to perform. For me in kicks in just as I want to go to work so it can help a lot. But it was also a hard medication to adapt to. I got face twitches, harder to regulate emotions for a time, and I take a low dosage. Even now I've tripled my dosage from *my* starter dosage (10mg) and its the level at which most people would have for a starter dose(30 mg). I'm also 220lbs at 5'9".  The out of breath thing did happen for a while, but its not a problem I ever seem to have anymore. Also, I've never had a hard time coming off of it. I can start and stop as I choose and it does what I need it to do with the lower dosage so long as I make sure I'm on target when it kicks in. It can be pretty uncomfortable, but it can also feel really good too. I've also used it as a stimulant to recover from a transplant and it has a double edged sword. You get more energy but you lose touch with how worn down your body is getting. Being able to take a lower dosage and go off and on the medication withdrawal free has been what has made this an excellent tool for my ADHD. Oh, watch out for the lull that happens for an hour or so in the afternoon between 2 and 4 (most days).

I was young when I was told I needed to take meds for my ADHD, about 10ish, and boy howdy did they mess me up. I would hyper focus on the wrong thing, I would even go the whole day without eating because it would be just THAT focused. I do not know how many different types of meds they had me try. I feel that because of those meds, it shifted my mental state into the depression that consumed 6 years of my life. I pushed myself to stop taking them when I was 18, at the tail end of my lost years, and learned to take control of myself. I have accomplished much since then. I am 32, months away from 33, Finished my GED, depression had made me flunk out of high-school, went to college for game design, got married, bought a house, and am about to be a father to my first child in April. It takes a lot to keep reminding myself where I am and what I have to do. My wife has been fantastic in helping me keep on task on days where depression or my ADHD creeps in, but as the years go on, it becomes much more manageable. I wish everyone well who goes through life, especially those with feelings like they can not do even the simple things. Take life one breath at a time, judge what you can do, write up a plan, and find ways to reward yourself for the tasks you manage to accomplish, even if small. You can do this! As Red-Green would say, "we are all I this together."

Hey, as someone who was on medication for my ADHD for most of my life, its possible that the dosage for the Vyvance wasn't tuned properly. Also, what worked for me was Strattera (Atomoxetine). Long term, slow burn, cumulative. Easier to tune the dosage.
My experience with meds was somewhat different, though I followed a similar trajectory when coming off them. I was diagnosed early and started medicating early; from what I can remember, we messed around with a few drugs and then Ritalin worked like a charm. I took that from 3rd grade through high school (with some minor changes and dosage ups b/c growth) and it really helped me focus and be productive, I rarely missed homework or things like that.   In high school though it really started to not work. I didn‚Äôt feel physical symptoms like you describe; instead, it felt like I was‚Ä¶ too focused? Essentially, when there was The Thing I needed to be doing, I was constantly *aware* of the fact that I was supposed to be doing the thing, and it that sense I was fully focused on it- like, if I started to get distracted by something else, I would remember that I still needed to do The Thing and would steer myself back - but I still couldn‚Äôt actually bring myself to DO the thing. I was left in a kind of limbo, usually filled by just watching videos on my phone (oh hey) because at the time it felt like a non-thing that I was getting distracted by: not reading, not playing a video game, not applying my brain or using my full attention, just‚Ä¶ there.   Eventually this started to really affect my productivity (and also depressive side effects!), so I also quit my medication cold turkey :) I then didn‚Äôt tell anybody about it for like weeks, but it luckily turn out fine for me as well. It‚Äôs ironic that continuing to take the meds almost feels like another Thing to focus on, and I remember quitting feeling like an act of defiance against the meds (like you said, bad idea!)

Ok, sorry if this is already here, but Vyvanse is really close to a time released Adderall.  Especially if you've been taking generic Adderall (dexamphetamine) instead of name brand which also has some levoamphetamine (effectively left handed dextroamphetamine).  Vyvanse just adds a lysine to dextroamphetamine so it can't get into your brain until your liver strips the lysine off which takes time.  Ritalin and Concerta are in the methylphenidate group and, while all of these are stimulants, it might be worth taking to your doctor about this stuff.  I believe there are also now some non-stimulant options, they just aren't front line treatment options because they aren't effective for as many people.  Also, Adderall is related to meth, but not the same.  Adding a methyl group to a molecule significantly changes how your body responds to it.  Just look up mercury and dimethyl mercury (when you aren't supposed to be doing something else).  One is poisonous in high concentrations over time.  One will kill you with a single drop which passes through latex gloves.

I personally take Concerta for my ADHD (which is predominantly inattentive) and it works great for me since it isn't a stimulant like Adderall and is a slow burn medication. I find myself actually able to get started on the things I need to do at work without having to fight the urge 24/7 to do anything else that isn't boring to my brain. Problem is that it only lasts around 6 hours at most with a medium morning dose so anytime after that I can just say goodbye to getting any art done after my job is done for the day. I don't have adhd (at least not diagnosed) but i do have really hard time focusing on some types of work. My solution to that problem was to write all the stuff needed to be done on the week and break them into smaller tasks. For example: you need to write essay; i would break down "write essay" into "write plan for essay", "write first/second paragraph", "check spelling" and so on. I personally find smaller tasks more manageable, and it feels more rewarding. I hope my experience will be of help to someone.

I have ADHD and meds never really worked for me either, so at some point I realized I would just have to do everything differently. Like for remembering things, I have (kind of) five or six different ‚Äúcalendars‚Äù to help me function so I am surrounded by reminders of what I need to do. So there‚Äôs the monthly calendar, the daily calendar, the bulletin board, the online/yearly calendar, the alarms set on my phone through the clock app and the sticky notes on my desk, and these are just all surrounding me while I‚Äôm at work so that if I look in any given direction, I‚Äôll probably see at least one of them, which will remind me to look at the others. And it works pretty well for me, even if it sounds excessive.   Another aspect is that I realized I would space out if there wasn‚Äôt someone else in the room who I felt might notice, so I made a recording of a busy day at the office with everyone typing and then when I‚Äôm alone I play the audio and it tricks my brain into being productive because it thinks other people are present.  Anyways yeah, kinda bizarre solutions but better than meds in my case. It sometimes feels like I‚Äôm trying to outsmart my own brain.

Finding a good medication is hard. I personally take Ritalin for my ADHD, and in my experience it helps me stay focused and on task. Although it can make you have no appetite so you need to remind yourself to eat and drink sometimes.
Think of ADHD medication like this: people with ADHD have been procrastinating their studies their whole lives. Once they take medication, it‚Äôs like they‚Äôre sitting down at the desk for the first time to study. But that does not mean that you are now good at studying just because you‚Äôre at the desk. It just means you‚Äôre able to sit down at the desk where the textbook is. You can still do a million different things while sitting down at the desk, like any normie could, including not opening the textbook. this discourages a lot of people with ADHD from continuing medication. we have been chasing thrills and good feelings for so many years. for some people with ADHD, seeking out medication was just another good feeling or thrill. ‚ÄúSurely the medication will just naturally lead to being a better person!‚Äù we think. well, it doesn‚Äôt. it just means you can sit down. now you have to learn emotional restraint, you have to learn how to absorb information, you have to learn that menial tasks matter, patience matters, discipline, and that is no easy feat.

I use 30mg methaphenidate
person with ADHD here! The worst part about being medicated is realizing that once you begin treatment, you‚Äôre starting at square one. your whole life you went without learning basic organization skills, risk, and reward, or impulsivity versus longevity. You have just been doing things that make you feel good to get you to do the next thing hoping to God that it all works out in your favor.  But once you‚Äôre medicated, you are literally starting from square one and a lot of people get discouraged because they think the medication should GIVE them those abilities. but if anything being medicated just means you have to teach yourself those abilities. people with ADHD tend to focus on their desire to have control over their lives, but a lot of the tools they need are emotional tools, not just practical, and that can be really confusing for someone who, for the past few decades, has relied on chasing good feelings and thrills only to be told, ‚ÄúNow you just need to learn how to not be an impulsive normie‚Äù.   medication is definitely super difficult and it has taken me two decades to figure it out but people who start medication with ADHD need to realize that once you begin, it‚Äôs more than just ‚ÄúOK now you‚Äôre better‚Äù it‚Äôs actually like ‚ÄúOK now the real journey begins.‚Äù

ADHD meds aren't really intended to be taken without some kind of cognitive behavioral therapy. You need the therapy learn to guide your thoughts towards doing those productive things you're intending to do. With that said, once I figure out how to book a therapist I and
Meds are useless without therapy. I cannot express just how much therapy aided me. My ADHD medication would have been near-pointless without ADHD-specific therapy to teach me coping mechanisms, how to tap into self-awareness, etc. I can now recognize when I‚Äôm being distracted, and know a variety of ways to get myself back on task. Please, seek out therapy, and I hope it helps you as much as it has helped me. üíô

I‚Äôm just trying to do things anyway, because I want to be able to do it myself and every medication has some kind of side effect. As a diagnosed ADHD person let me just say. Both those meds were horrible for me. I had the exact same problems you did. I was thrown around to like 5 other meds but ended up with one called Methylphenidate. It worked perfectly for me. I was able to make a list before the meds kicked in then go down that list easily without loosing creativity and even stay social which was another problem I had on the other meds. I also didn't feel stressed or depressed on it. You take them 5 days a week and rest on the weekends and it works perfectly. Just start low dosage and work your way up until you find a good dosage that works well for you. I am 25 now and I still take them to this day on and off when I have a really busy day where I need to get a lot done. I'm a business owner like you so I know there's a lot of sperattic and different tasks to get done in one day so what's nice with this med is that you don't get locked on one task and can work on all of them by working through your list. I am no professional, but I have had adhd for my whole life and have been taking meds since 3rd grade (I'm 33 now). And Vyvanse is basically meth too only with a controlled release function. Yes Vyvanse is definitely a better medication than Adderall. Adderall is more like taking one big puff of meth to start your day whereas vyvanse is more like taking small ones periodically throughout the day. In that way, I can be productive with reaching my goals while also taking breaks. ADHD people can be focusses. Tons of food additives cause ADHD symptoms.  Vaccines can cause neurological issues that can seem like ADHD symptoms.  Some ADHD medications have been proven to halt brain development and even shrink brain tissue.   Adderall is an amphetamine.   Tibetan Rhodiola may help with ADHD.
2:18 I actually went on medication just recently for my ADHD and this is EXACTLY what it felt like! I've been describing it as "My brain just started working". It's wild how much of a huge difference it makes. But yeah the ADHD medication scene is hard to navigate sometimes, there's a lot of different options. Adderall worked for me for a while before I realized the side effects were making me miserable since I could neither eat nor sleep. It's a matter of just kind of trying things to see what works.
Vyvanse is still dexamphetamine (dexadrine, dextroamphetamine), but it has lysine attached, so your body can't use it directly. However, once it's been in your blood-stream for awhile, your body goes "hmmm, lysine ... I'll take that off and use it to make something else" then the molecule becomes ordinary dex again and starts to work as normal. The chance of this happening for any particular molecule in a dose of medicine is random and follows a bell curve over about 12 hours. that is what makes it come on gently, peak in the middle of the day, then tail off (hopefully) before bed-time. That is some clever chemistry right there!   I have not checked this but someone told me the patent for this will run out soon. If this is the case, there will be some cheaper equivalents to Vyvanse in the near future. Also, because it would be highly impractical to use recreationally (am I wrong about this?), it is possible some governments will change its legal status/schedule etc.
I think your shortness of breath was chronic hyperventilation due to heightened focus and thereby accidental awareness of breathing. This caused co2 imbalance which causes your headache and feelings of shortness of breath (choking).  Hope it was that, actually.

Psychoactive ADHD meds tend to be stimulants, and for the most part you‚Äôve got drugs similar to those two illegal substances‚Ä¶ well, technically you can be prescribed meth.  Might be worth trying Ritalin or Concerta or something similar since they‚Äôre not similar to adderall or vyvanse. Might be that a change in diet and increase in exercise is as helpful. It‚Äôs funny I have adhd and I clicked off the video because I got distracted üòÇ
(I'm not a medical professional, so ... grain of salt etc.) Executive functions get a bit scrambled by not having the right amounts of dopamine and norepinephrine in the right places in the brain. Stimulant medications help sort that out but ... In my experience, getting diagnosed later in life, there is a lot of stuff you need to learn, relearn and unlearn. Some of those books about how to get your sh*t together that you read and threw out might actually work with the meds in action.   Imagine you never learned to read for your whole life then someone figures out that it's because you need glasses. You put on your new glasses and suddenly you can clearly see all the text on the page. You still can't read it though ... It's the same with executive functions. You have to learn all that stuff from scratch. you also need to question the assumptions and thought patterns that help you get through life with ADHD, such as "If I leave this to the last minute, it'll just take a minute, right??" "If I don't set goals or make plans, I can't fail" etc.  If you are in a country where meds are expensive and stimulants make you feel bad (they did in my case, but that went away later), there are off-script non-stimulant ones that show promise. I found Modafinil helpful. It's a bit like an anti-anti-histamine often used for narcolepsy. Because it is not a stimulant, and would be a lame recreational experience, its legal status is more permissive and you can (in Australia at least) get a GP to prescribe it without needing a Psychiatrist. Also, you can order cheap generics from India etc. (with the usual caveats) without getting a visit from the police. Anyway, ask real doctors for advice. Modafinil (and its variants) works via Histamine pathways, so there is a chance you can get a rash or other allergy-like from taking it. This happened to me once, but these particular tablets were past their use-by date and may have changed chemically over time. (dispose of old meds even if it's tempting to keep them if money's tight).

What you experience is called Seratonin Syndrome. You are making too much seratonin from the meds. THIS CAN KILL YOU IF YOU DONT DO ANYTHING ABOUT IT. All you need to do is lower the dose or change to a medication that is mild. ALWAYS BE TRANSPARENT WITH YOUR DOCTOR. CALL EARLY IF YOU FEEL LIKE YOU NEED TO.

Hehe, Funni cow be Funni-ing
Every single thing when it comes to some sort of pill or medical treatment - especially those on the psychological spectrum - are a HUGE risk/benefit scenario. That, or they fix one thing and then produce 3 other things you DON'T want. Having tunnel vision is something I deal with a lot, and it's with results and lack thereof. After undergoing TMS therapy, I realized that no matter what it is in the psychotropic realm, it will never be a quick fix or a be-all-end-all type of solution. At least, for things such as attention, depression, anxiety, etc. It's so complicated and despite what people think, our understanding of this stuff is super super immature. It's not nearly close enough to how we understand things like the cardiovascular system, organs, etc. In any case, I find that more of the side-effects of all the drugs I've or my friends have been on are worse than the benefits it produces. I'm a firm believer in the social construct type of idea these days, just from being through the ringer of meds and treatment. We live in a very different and fast society now, and everyone is having to adapt at really crazy paces. A lot of what I find to help me is eliminating things that make things worse, as opposed to trying to find new things or ways to make something better. I watched a video Dr. K posted recently about positive deviance and how people tend to reflect more on what they did wrong and how that happened as to what they did right. I.e., if you focus on the things you did leading up to a good day, you may be able to look at those things and produce another good day as a result. I actually had a few breakthroughs in listening to this, and realized we all kind of do this without being aware to some extent. I'm attempting to do this with more awareness moving forward, consciously applying it that is, and I'm hoping to see some really good results. Good luck fellow 2d machination!

this is exactly why i stopped taking meds 5 years ago
I was diagnosed with ADHD when I was 16. The reason why we found out, is because I was a very diligent and dedicated student, always did homework ect. Halfway through the school year, I suddenly couldn't remember anything about math I learned that year during a test exam, and broke down. My teacher talked to my parents, my parents talked with the doctor and I went to a child psychologist. I think I started Methylphenidate. After a couple of years, the effect started to wear down, aka my body got used to it. So then I started on Concerta (forgot how to write the name) it went pretty well. But my body got used to it, and we couldn't raise the mg so now I'm on Elvanse. It's like the best ever. I'm also on the highest dosage of Elvanse, 70mg. In the past, I had to constantly eat something with lots of sugar and soda to get energy enough to get through the school day. After that, I was so tired I would just lay in bed. If someone told me a secret, there was an 80% chance I'll forget it. I also forgot so many things about my childhood, and my memory was horrible. I was constantly tired, and tried to focus by shaking my leg, drawing or just doing something while listening to the other. I'm surprised I even passed that grade. After being on medication, my childhood memories had slowly returned, I can remember better (but not perfectly), my stomach is not an empty pit, and I could actually concentrate on things. I have 3 times last two years forgotten to take my medication. I remember last time I forgot, but it was Friday and we got home early that day. One hour after I got home, I slept for 15 hours straight... Never doing that again...
meditation plus low any adhd drug equals perfection

Seeps into you and its very hard to control like karumas chakra then when you get older the seal and control gets stronger so your ADHD is much easier to control then when the seal was broken and Naruto joined with Karuma u are doing something like that but with ADHD YOU are in control of your own mind sure you might get a little shaky but its much better. I'm glad your doctor listened to your concerns. When I was a preteen I was diagnosed with ADHD and medicated with server different stimulants trying to find the best one. After a couple of years I started having heart palpitations and my doctor decided to take me of stimulants and we tried stratterra instead. This worked for me however I started having sudden outburst streaming and throwing things. My doctor then misdiagnosed me with bipolar disorder. After being medicated with lithium bicarbonate, which causes symptoms of bipolar disorder in people who *don't* have the disorder, I lost 10 years of my life due to various antisocial behavioral side effects. The outbursts and depressive episodes went away until one year I got a horrible stomach bug and couldn't hold food or medicine down for almost a week when all the issues suddenly.... just went away. Now I don't take any medications and just deal with the ADHD as best I can. I find that eating properly helps and I've developed some other tricks to help me focus with certain tasks but it's still a struggle sometimes.

I was diagnosed with ADHD ever since I was 7, and I've been lucky enough to have a genuinely caring therapist since then. I've hopped from medication to medication over the years and I now primarily take Focalin. It's not perfect, but it works well enough for me when I need it to that I don't feel pressed to change at the time. Different meds work for different people, and sometimes no meds is best for some people. I think what's most important is having that other human element who's willing to help you try things and find out what works for you.

took me like 2 and a half years to get diagnosed (not a normal situation, there were various complications), but i'm glad i stuck it out because my meds (Concerta gang whaddup) let me do new crazy fun tasks such as: - actually doing the readings for my degree  - showering without having a 15 minute argument with myself about why it's important first - following the plots of shows - listening during lectures/speeches/concerts/regular everyday conversations  - washing my dishes without crying  and so much more! medication is definitely not for everyone, but it's absolutely worth trying. i wish there was less of a tendency towards abuse with these kinds of meds because it makes them harder to get access to for those of us who benefit from them, and they've been life-changing for me.  (as a side note, Vyvanse and Adderall have very similar active ingredients, but the active ingredient present in Ritalin and Concerta is different, and there are also non-stimulant medication options available, so if you're happy to stay off meds that's great, but know that if it's still something your're interested in, there are more options out there and that it's definitely not a one size fits all sort of thing.)

ADHD is just a wild rideüòµ‚Äçüí´. At times your high on lifeüòÇ or hyper-focusedüßê on something that you find interesting, then at others, you feel like you just hit a brick wallüß±, no energyüòÆ‚Äçüí®, no motivationüòí, just a holeüï≥ that honestly, sometimes you literally can't get out of without waiting for it to pass‚è≤üòî.   My experience with ADHD has just been constant upsüìà and downsüìâ sometimes very frequent (~a few seconds) and sometimes really long (~5-8 hours) and it just doesn't stop. Its like a waveüåä your riding in a lil surfboard that you have no control over. And this wave is straight BOOLIN' manüòº, it can go from a got dam tsunamiüåä‚è´, to a spiraling whirlpoolüòµ‚Äçüí´, to calm watersüïä in a matter of minutes. So what I've learned is that you can't keep trying to control the wave, its a force of nature, its gonna do its thing and that's that.   So let it be‚úã, and start looking at what you CAN control. You're the surfer on the waveüèÑ, so what's kept you afloat thus far? What are you riding onü§î? What's stopped you from being swallowed by the wave, or if you feel like you are drowning, what do you need to at least keep your head above water?  Ice cream ü§§. Or maybe a SURFBOARD! A floaty! A lil boatüö£! Just something to keep you up. Then once you find/make that system in your life, refine refine refine it. Upgrade it, add new pieces to it. Build it up, let life test it by trial of fire üî• (And by god, will life humble you man)  then try again.   One piece (referenceü§≠) of my own and of many other people's systems is MEDICATIONüíä. If you're the surferüèÑ, medication is like foot strapsü¶∂ on a slippery surfboard, its the clarity of mind that a cup of coffee‚òï can bring, its like a steady handüëê that grabs your waist and helps guide you on the waveüåä and keep you anchored on the board. You still have to do the work of surfing and steering, but medication grants you a clear focusü§ì and control that we all try so hard for.  (Someone in this comment section had an analogy to a pair of shoes and that is a PERFECT comparisonüî•üî•üî•)  The hardest part of the process is the patience you need cuz it jus takes so much time. But, DON'T GIVE UP‚ÄºNEVER GIVE UP‚ÄºIt can and WILL get better‚úÖ. (The good endingüòÅ)  Your system will take your entire life to build, so try and enjoy the process and celebrate the little wins. Track how far you've come and reflect on it periodically. You can't focus on the end goal, you gotta focus on the process, Life will be more fun that wayüòÅ.  This comment is getting WAYYY to long, but I saw this video and got excited 2 share my own Slice O' ADHD Life w/ ya'll.  So the last thing below is my advice on getting started with your system using habits, if ya read this far, then VERY SWAG and I hope this helped ya. Love you guys, and keep on being yo' selves!!!üòÅü´Ç   Find a goal you want and break it down to its coreüçé. Ask yourself, ü§îwhy do I want this? and as you answer keep asking why until you've reached the core motive/want and start from there. If its a motive that stems from whatüëâüíÅ YOU want (and not what someone else wants‚ùåüôÖ), then turn it into your own way of lifeüòé. After all it is something core to you isn't it? So be it‚Äº  But how do you make this core_value/motive/lil_piece_of_you turn into your own way of life and identity?  (enter Mr. Habitsü§µ)  Keep them:  1) üëÄObvious (can't miss their cue in ur day2day)                    [Ex. Keep it in your line of sight]                       2) üòèAttractive (Add something enjoyable to it)                        [Ex. Listen to music/podcast while doing habit]                       3) ü•±Easy (Start with the smallest action towards it)               [Ex. If the habit is making breakfast everyday, buy freezer waffles & flop those üê∂in the toaster each morningü§§]                       4) üòÅSatisfying (Make the habit rewarding when you finish)   [Ex. If the habit is washing your hands, find a hand soap that smells AMAZING & use it!]  Start smallü§è and slowü¶•, then work your way up‚¨Ü from there. Be patient with yourself üëçand don't be too hard on yourselfüòÅ. Be sure to practice self-loveü´Ç (Make it a habit!)   Lastly, don't hate the wave‚ùåüôÖüåä. In time, I believe we each can build a system that works around/with the waveüèÑ‚úÖüåä, and I even think it can get to the point where that wild wave actually starts to help us more than it used to hinder usüåä ü§©and I think that's when we'll really start to shine‚òÄ

the polish cow üò≠
I only started taking my ADHD seriously over the last two or so years. I've been aware of my diagnosis since I was 6 I believe. I am now 26 and the last time I was medicated for it was at 10. I was taking Stratera and Concerta, with both making me depressed and violently ill. I quit taking them (bad idea I know) and it actually traumatized me to the point I couldn't take pills for a long time. Well at 24 I started on a routine of anti-depressants that are also used for ADHD. The pills worked for about a year, then I suddenly spiraled into depression and it was bad. I finally got switched to Adderall and I've never been better. My first dosage was too high but after an adjustment I feel super happy. I was able to get my bachelor's degree, the first in my family, and I have never been more productive at work. My advice to everyone, you are all different, there's no one treatment fits all. Talk with your psych and keep trying different options until you find what works best for you.
It took 6 long weeks to notice improvement, but it paid off. A Wellbutrin and guanfacine combo has been gentle and sustainable long-term for me, since stimulants took away my ability to sleep longer than 4 hours and didn't give it back. I actually do homework now, and all of it. Insanity.

Hi, ive been taking vyvanse for for 21 years now. Vyvanse can increase a person's anxiety and it sounds like that's what it's doing to you. These are either panic attacks or anxiety attacks, probably the latter if they come on suddenly and without warning. Talk to your doctor about possibly lowering the dose. It can take a few weeks to get used to the meds but once you pick up a healthy rhythm it'll take care of you. It would work, but then I‚Äôd develop a tolerance so quick that I‚Äôd up the dose, and by the time I was taking 60 mg, I was getting massive stomach pain, and that shortness of breath mentioned above. No fun.  Adderall, come to find out, I‚Äôm one of the few people who experience adverse mental health effects like auditory hallucinations. Turns out taking basically meth doesn‚Äôt fix your problem. Also no fun.  After a while, I kinda just decided to try and work through my problems with focusing the old fashioned way. If it takes me 3 hours for to finish a task that it takes other people 15 minutes to do, then I‚Äôll just spend as many 3 hour chunks as necessary.  Eventually, I learned enough tricks and trades to operating my own brain that I feel I can focus pretty well. I don‚Äôt think that everyone is capable of this, but I also don‚Äôt think medication is at all the solution to most people‚Äôs adhd. We need better mental health solutions for people with the diagnosis

Answers = Scattered by Dr. Gabor Mate
So, at the risk of sounding like every other "hur hur I have X Y Z condition", I've always thought I had at least some level of ADHD, I've just always been high-functioning enough for me to never really need to consider taking medication for it. The only things that really turn me full low functioning coast-brain are things so mind numbingly boring yet juuuust involved enough that I can't tune out. With that context, I'm honestly quite surprised with how well handled this video is. It could have easily turned into "hur dur american healthcare bad" or trying to find something to blame, but instead it really did just seem like an honest discussion of trying to find something that works.   This is probably a weird thing to comment but I've seen SO many of these videos turn into just blaming things instead of trying to solve the problem. It's the difference between an excuse and explanation; a lot of people self diagnose mental conditions, blame those conditions for their issues, and then blame "american healthcare" for not being able to solve them, etc. but this was clearly just trying to solve the problem. It's one of those things where, it's weird to praise, but it's also something that needs to be praised. Far too few people understand how to just, solve problems directly and honestly without trying to fit them to some narrative, and it's honestly a very healthy way to approach problems.   (*also for context on what I said initially, ADHD does run in the family, my parents explicitly said I do share many symptoms with them, and I have friends with diagnosed ADHD who I think basically identically to. So, again, at the risk of sounding like your average twitter tween girl, I do tend to believe I have ADHD and just manage to be high-functioning with it. I only have my own experience so I can't say why, maybe it's how I approach problems, maybe it's how I conceptualize things, maybe it's just genetic fate, but none of that is really relevant to my point. Frankly I doubt any person alive has the answers to those questions, so I don't find them very enlightening as a point of discussion, I just wanted to provide earned kudos for honestly trying to solve a problem and improve your life rather than trying to justify leaving it as it is and finding someone to blame for it which is all too common, it's a healthy mindset and one that I REALLY wish was more common than it is)
I take ADHD meds- and the whole like, "suddenly able to do ability" is so accurate! I mostly took them so I could do school work, and not just kinda sit in the same place thinking about doing hobbies and not doing them- but you know, I didn't have a hard wow this is what the meds are doing! I only realized it worked because of the results. And then realized more things when I would forget to take them on days- I realized I literally could not sit still. Literally- slouching, sitting up right, turning to the side, legs going everywhere- I thought it was hilarious- I also went back to googling things constantly when given information, like my teacher mentioning a restaurant or something! I would suggest you try Ritalin. It might possibly be better for you. There are also non stimulant versions such as strattera. I really suggest you try all existing option untill you find something that works. Everyone's body reacts differently. I'm on 70mg to 80mg of Vyvanse. I went on Adderall and Ritalin. Both gave me panic attacks. Vyvanse is the only one my body tolerates.  Talk to your psyc man and keep trying different options untill you find the thing that works for you. It's scary to thing your using body as a lab test tube but  I promise you these medications will not turn you into a drug addict. They have been on the market for years and have been rigorously tested approved by the FDA.

The manufacturer makes a huge difference when it comes to Adderall. If you notice a change in your meds check your bottle. It will list the shape, color, and the company that made your meds. If it's been changed to Lannett Co prepare for a rough month. Their generics barely work.
Also a lot of the meds give you depression, constant disassociation, and loss of appetite

At the end of the video I did the exact same thing. It was out of my system after 3 days. After 5 I felt fine and full of energy. After 2 weeks I realized I never needed them and 2 years later I'm a welder. Funny how things worked out. I also lost a bunch of weight and got real fit. After years on being medicated with vyvanse I realized coming off of it not actually needing it. My friends said I looked like a zombie while medicated and when I came off of it I looked like I had life in my eyes. I am so thankful for them. I'll never forget what they did for me. I was taking enough vyvanse to kill 8 elephants. Yeesh am I right? I came off the meds in the mindset like holy shit everything is so much more vivid and colorful. I felt like I missed out on most of my life. I was on the meds from ages 7 to 20 years old. I felt robbed of my life for a few months. After 6 months it was out of my bloodstream. I had the ability to focus on my own. I felt like the meds were a crutch. When I screwed up in social situations I would blame it on my Autism or ADHD. I didn't ever blame it on meds. I'm pretty sure I would of had a stroke by 30 if I continued taking it.

I guess ADHD really is different for everyone, because I got put on Adderall for mine which I'm still on. And when I took it, there was *ABSOLUTELY* a physical sensation with it. I literally felt like I had gained superpowers because I could focus on one sense at a time and completely tune out every other sense, resulting in what I would still describe as superhuman senses. And it very much also gave me the ability to focus. I was more productive in the first week of taking it than I had been for the previous 3 years total.  In short, there really is no one type of ADHD it seems. It's like a thumbprint, different for each person.

You are a god ice cream sandwich!
I'm currently having to be unmedicated because of med shortages thanks to the DEA applying very harsh restrictions that treat the disabled like they are drug abusers.  A month now without meds and my 2 primary symptoms are executive dysfunction and anhedonia. Executive dysfunction is the inability to start or complete tasks. It's as though your ability to be invested in something is a randomized dial that chooses either 0 or 11, while non ADHD people are able to choose their interest anywhere from 1-10. Anhedonia is a depression symptom but ADHD gives depression for about 60% of cases. It is the loss of pleasure in absolute. I often guilt trip myself out of every single thing I could ever be enjoying, sooner layig on the floor than even sitting in my chair.   A few critiques. No, it's not essentially street meth. It's an amphetamine yes, but it's the most effective treatment for this disorder. ADHD is different for everyone and every case. The way you spoke on some of these issues you had could easily deter treatment for those unknowing.  Taking ADHD meds is also a relationship with how your mental state is, you can do non physical tasks, I'm able to go to work just as easy as I am to paint while on my meds. You need to take steps to make better habits in ways that may not make sense at first with a fresh diagnosis because our reward center of the brain works really different compared to others.  If you are having complications with your medications often time the doctor at the point of prescribing them will say to ween off if there's issues. I had to ween down for the sake of not having withdrawals, and mind you as someone who takes Adderall, I'm not addicted, I have 0 seeking behaviors and an absolutely forget taking my meds even.   ADHD is hell and right now the DEA needs to lift it's restrictions on production on Adderall because it is only hurting those who need the meds as a form of victim blaming. "Oh these meds are addictive, you say you need them? What are you an addict?" "No I have ADHD/narcolepsy, that's the most effective and first form of treatment options. Shut up."
Strattera is kinda a combination of both, it focuses on the actual things you need to do, while also keeping you productive

God, I would kill for the ability to... do...
I was diagnosed with ADHD back in middle school, and I managed to keep it under control using planners, calendar reminders, and blocker programs I put on my PC. But during my senior year of engineering school I finally started taking Wellbutrin XL because the sheer load of tasks was too high to handle with discipline alone. (Originally my psych wanted to put me on Adderall, but my family's history with addiction threw that idea out the airlock). I stayed on a minimum 150 mg dose, and over the first few months my focus did improve a lot. But as time went on, my anxiety started to get REALLY bad. Like I was having panic attacks over not being able to handle 5-6 tasks a day.  Plus, after graduating from college, most of the work I had to do went from quantized, finite, scheduled tasks (HW, projects, exams, etc) to much more abstract, open-ended, and untimed tasks that I could not focus on directly anymore (looking for a job, planning trips, getting organized, etc.). So Wellbutrin went from helping me focus to causing me to panic over focus I could no longer obtain. So, when I moved back home, I found a new psych and had my medication switched to Strattera. So far it seems to be working out well and my abstract focus skills are improving a lot without any anxiety. But it hasn't been long enough to see the medication take full effect, or to notice its side effects at full strength. So hopefully it goes well, but time will tell to see if Strattera works out better or not

The things, it does to my heart rate and sleep, my Whoop is basically like "hey bro, are you alright?"   I know exactly what you mean about the "suddenky feel out of breathe and tired". Feeling. When I took Aderral last year, I would get the same feeling. My Whoop, from the first day to the last, would register my heart rate being about 15 to 20 beats higher than normal while on Adderall (because it's basically meth)  Whatever seems to usually be in these meds, puts a lot of stress on the body. My Whoop even started registering my days as having been as active on a normal day of work, as I am on a work day that includes a gym session afterwards. I would burn 1200 calories before even arriving to work in the morning.   So it's no wonder you eventually get that tired feeling, as your body has been in "go mode" for so long, operating at a couple levels above what is normal for it, for prolonged periods of time

I'm sure you've gotten many similar comments in adjacent flavors, but to share my own experience: I had a super not great experience with dextroamphetamines as a 13/14 year old and dug in my heels to refuse taking more, and developed a super anti medication mindset. Many years later as a FUCKING THIRTY YEAR OLD, I bumped up against the wall in a way I couldn't figure my way around and finally decided to figure things out properly which ended up in taking Concerta. I won't talk about the experience of taking concerta cause I haven't needed to try others and have no point of comparison, but I will say:  Coming to meds as an adult and with a very concise expectation from them allowed me to take a lot of ownership of my experience taking them. I knew clearly and articulately where I struggled and what I wanted to change, and in addition to taking meds I also did things like uninstalling all my games from my phone, uninstalling/deleting social media platforms/accounts, spending time in my day WITHOUT A VIDEO ESSAY PLAYING. This is all important because under the medication ***you are still the same idiot dopamine goblin***.  If you do not change your habits, the meds are just a temporary modifier and you will never progress beyond their effects, especially as your body acclimatizes to them and their effect naturally lessens over time. The analogy I like to use is that ADHD is like trying to climb a mountain but with a goofy issue like say your left hand can't quite grip right, or your right ankle tweaks funny depending on the angle you press off it. And like, everyone else can climb just fine, and you slowlylearn to build adaptive habits to accommodate your stuff like looking for routes where you can lean on your strengths and biting your lip to push through the stuff that sucks.  The meds? Think of them like a pick. They won't make every route easier, and you still need to be a good climber, but if you've got, idk, shit-finger-itis, it helps a ton. YOU still have to climb the mountain, this shit just helps you do it.  I say all this based on what you were describing with trying to set yourself up to be in the middle of something productive when the meds kicked in to be prepped for success, and to me, that's expecting the pick to do the climbing for you. YOU need to change your habits for any of this shit to work, and this stuff makes it easier to do that. It's kind of a beneficial chicken or egg situation, where both help the other.  Everyone's experience is different of course, I never talked to people about mine much because trying to communicate in an articulate way was a massive struggle with my internal headspace, and that's been my favorite part of my life since taking my ADHD seriously. I can express myself in a manner other than a joke I made, a script idea I thought was cool, a sick combo I landed in a game I love... because otherwise I felt trapped mentally and cornered myself further and further into the areas of my life where I felt able to express myself at the expense of areas where I felt suffocated.  You're a nearly 3m sub channel so you probs won't see this, and lord knows this is - at best - a wall of text that permanently goes in the "oh this looks good I'll read it later properly" pile that you never get to. I have my own, trust me. Regardless, if you DO read this, know you've got a lot of capacity to make the changes you need. They're hard, but they can be small and still work.  To whoever does read this: I believe in you. You are worth the work you need to do.

i was having the same issue of focus, so i was advised to take a mixed amphetamine for slow release. i was given about 20 mg, and it effected me badly, like after several hours, headaches, wanted to throw up, etc. emailed my doc, lowered the dose, problem solved. i don't need to take these meds everyday, mostly when I'm having trouble to focus because of uni-work, so I don't have any side effects during days I don't take them. adhd meds arent for everyone and they don't effect everyone the same way but I'm happy that I have that safety net to help me finish a string of thought when I'm writing an assignment of 20 pages about one topic
that is true us adhd struggle that is why i mainly failed year 1 +a bad teacher
I have been on vyvanse for over a year now. And it took a good few months for them to settle and work how they should. What my psychiatrist told me, that I use as my mantra,is the vyvanse is not going to take my adhd away, I will still struggle with a lot of the things some days, but it will help you or give you a little push in managing. I was on 20mg firstly then up to 30s 40s then 50s, 50s and 40s gave me horrible migraines and jaw clenching so I switched back to 30s. I still have low days I suffer with anxiety and depression too and it creeps ups put of nowhere sometimes. I still take my medication and monitor my side effects and progress. It's still a battle everyday but it's easier to fight.  If you are looking into starting medication just remember it won't magically take all your symptoms away. And it will take some trial and error before you find the right dose and right fit for you. Good luck to all my fellow neurodirvergants out there. There is nothing wrong in deciding to medicate ir not. Your brain is unique and you have to whatever works for you to be a happy healthy individual ‚ù§

Lmao "Adderall is basically meth" is a shit take by your friend. They're all amphetamines. Amphetamines work differently in people with ADHD. Also part of the reason meth is so bad for you is that it is unregulated and therefore can be created with a bunch of dangerous contaminants. Adderall is regulated and pharmaceutical companies are held to a higher standard generally.

I feel great when i take the meds and then do science or math assignments but if i take my meds and play a videogame i feel like i am half asleep and absolutely miserable... issue is, i also feel half asleep and miserable without them so i just sit there in utter disappointment because my meds don't do their thing instead of enjoying any hobbies i am participating in. i also don't go to school now because i developed some health issues that make it hard to walk or sit upright for long, so i am basically always on a weird up and down rollercoaster of getting pumped and focusing on something but then finishing the task within minutes and being sluggish again

Yo, so... I take Adderall. The "Adderall = meth" comparison is an extremely dangerous mindset that can demonize ADHD / ADHD medication and discourage doctors from prescribing it. It also gives the stigma to non-ADHD-havers that you're an addict or "need dangerous drugs to function" and can make them very very very anti-ADHD-drugs. Different people have different needs based on their brain chemistry and all that. Do what's best for YOU, but please don't stigmatize what doesn't work for you.

From personal experience:  - Ritalin and Concerta allowed me to work through mental tasks I already knew how to do, but absolutely fucked up my ability to learn anything. Basically, if I take it, math grades good, anything new bad. If I don't take it, math grades bad, but I can learn all about history. In the end I decided that maths don't matter.   For the non-traditional meds: - caffeine does work, once my trained coping wears off after about 2 hours of concentration. About 160 mg for about 1 hour. Up to a dose of roughly 500mg, after that caffeine side effects start to accumulate.  - alcohol does nothing for the productivity, but does wonders for the ability to follow a conversation or remember what someone said. I have more memories of what people said in pubs, than at game nights, despite the latter being five times more common. (But since I don't want an addiction to this, I don't consider it a good way to go)  - nicotine, does nothing for it  - weed: in the right dosage, THC and/or CBD do allow me to think straight, hold long conversations and remember stuff. But it is so hard to get it right, that only precisely measurable forms are usable, which I not have available. (Smoking or vaping wouldn't work.)
I take meds and also have the issue of some days being super productive and other days in which I‚Äôm a potato. Something that helped me out was understanding that when I‚Äôm productive I can do in 1 hour or less, what a normal person does in 3 or 4. I started trying to accept that I would have unproductive days and that productive days would eventually come. Accepting and working WITH my adhd instead of trying to control it too much at least gives me some peace of mind. Another thing that helps is to try to communicate with my unproductive self when I‚Äôm in productive mode (this is not as mystical as it sounds) by writing down in detail what are the next steps of the thing I need to do by the end of the day. That way it‚Äôs easier for my unproductive self to pickup where my productive self left off.  Ofc this doesn‚Äôt fix everything and I‚Äôll always have bad days in which I simply can‚Äôt do anything else besides researching why rabbit poop looks like crunchy chocolate snacks but it makes me feel better to know that a productive day will come and try to be prepared for it :D
Ritalin could fix this but I don't want to suggest you trying out another drug XD

If you end up seeing this comment look into non-stimulant adhd medication like Strattera. Its like diet Vyvanse, way less side effects and it helps with focus without going into hyperfocus

I could focus easier but it felt like it came at the exchange and of my brain working faster. I felt like a knife that had been dulled, or maybe a knife that wasn‚Äôt being swung fast enough?

I have been taking meds for about 3 years now, and I have what I think is some really valuable insights to share, especially for those with ADHD with little experience in meds, or those who take meds with little success.  My takeaways are this: there is a key difference between getting easily distracted, and not being able to pay attention. One you can easily treat, one you can't. I can tell you this from my experience; being able to sit yourself down to start working on your task, and actively avoid distractions by not picking up your phone, opening a new tab, etc., is something you can do without meds 100%. That *doesn't mean* meds won't help you do this, but they're not strictly necessary.  HOWEVER, the main issue that causes people with ADHD so much frustration is when they do eventually sit down, ATTEMPT to make progress, and cannot even read the first sentence. THIS is what meds will help THE MOST for you. They give you the stimulation needed for you to *want* or even be capable of reading and understanding your task. I know what it feels like to sit down and stare at your paper for hours. I know what it feels like to read the question, and not have the faintest thought come of it. This is what the meds are for. What ICS outlined is that he had problems with focusing on what needed to be focused on while he was on meds. This is very treatable. BUT, it's what requires the most change in your life. You want to know how to get over this? Simplify your life (delete social media or games), control impulses (don't reach for your phone, think twice). Slow. Down. Meditate (HUGE HELP). Meditating helps you slow down and take things calmly and focused. I meditated just a few minutes every day and it turned me from a manic, nervous wreck, to a grounded, laser-focused productivity machine. Yes it wasn't perfect, I had side effects and bad days. Yes it took at least 6 months for me to know how to really manage my dosage and routine. Yes, you gotta get sleep and food or else it'll just throw everything off. However, if you really want to improve and get somewhere, the more you put in the more you get out. You can't expect the drug that just stimulates you to force you to work. Here's what my history looks like if you're curious:  My personal experience went like this: started with 5mg adderall, made me feel like I could do anything, increased dose to 10mg because of tolerance, dose stayed 10mg 2-3 times a day for a while but I had several side effects that came and went, I started micromanaging my dosage (instead of 3 x 10mg doses I did one 5mg, then 10mg, then 5mg, this helped a lot with side effects), I never took the doses when I didn't need them, it was a very flexible schedule. Graduated, went to a typical university, stupidly busy, 3-4 doses a day working 8-16 hours. Dropped out and went to community college, started taking methylphenidate instead (concerta/ritalin), felt similar, boosted my concentration but not my mood as much (adderall really boosted my mood, heartrate, made me feel hyped so to speak), I take adderall and ritalin interchangeably, but never mixed in one day. 10mg adderall is my typical dosage, 5mg is my wind down.   All in all, if you set yourself up to succeed by eliminating all your usual pitfalls, meds can be insanely effective. If you have ADHD and are afraid of the side effects and such, try to keep your dosage as small as possible, don't be hasty to increase it. If you don't take other meds and keep a good routine (eat well sleep well etc), the side effects are usually very manageable if they're even a problem. No, I don't wish to be on meds all my life, and I don't like depending on meds, but when you really improve yourself in all these other ways, you can actually be reasonably productive without meds. Sure, it might not be easy, but it's way easier than it used to be. It might not take you 15 minutes, but it won't take you 2 hours anymore. I'm happy to answer any questions :).

I took vyvanse, same as focalin. Made me use the restroom A LOT, didn't let me eat, so I got super skinny while being on both focalin. I was diagnosed with a.d.d. as a child in elementary school, I didn't understand why I had to take focalin as a child, I just did because an adult told me to. When I took focalin I also had a hard time sleeping so they gave me clonidine to help me sleep at night, I got nauseous when ever I smelled food, didn't remember to drink anything also because I didn't feel like it due to the medication. So my health got so bad my blood work was bad that I was forced to drink more, I wasn't a healthy weight so they forced me to eat, it wasn't until they took me off focalin that I finally was healthy and happy. When I finally got to 5th grade I was switched to vyvanse because my psychiatrist said it was better and claimed I would be able to eat normally, which was a lie. Focalin and vyvanse had the same side effects. I fainted from lack of nutrition in elementary school focalin, and I fainted when my mom and I went to a grocery store while being on vyvanse. As I got older I finally realized that they both sucked and were expensive. So now that I'm older and no longer have Medicaid to take them, I feel pretty fine without them I still lose focus at time, but I feel better off without them.
As someone on Vivance, 200% accurate reaction. If it at all helps or is a warning to taking it (I am absolutely still taking it and my reaction was the same but that may vary don‚Äôt take my word as law I just wanna give my 2c) my solution to the focus issue if I‚Äôm always focused on work/study (depending on if a uni semester is on) then I‚Äôm always doing the right thing. If what I‚Äôm focusing on the most is what matters the most, and I‚Äôm always doing that, that‚Äôs better, not good but better. I just set up stop gaps for all the other things, like extra large hampers and many extra shirts/towels/sheets for once a month laundry, everything or a copy of everything in car so I always have what I need in case I forget or am running late (because it‚Äôs always both), learning to cook with anything left in the fridge because I didn‚Äôt buy food and making a lot of it to last at least 2-5 days ect.. Basically I revolve my life around the drug, and the focus it gives me to concentrate on the most important thing, and then one day a week/month or so I deal with everything else. Is it a good solution, no. Does it work for me, for now yes. On the drugs or off the drugs, make sure what you have works for you and don‚Äôt be afraid to evaluate it and sometimes barely coping is still coping.

In response to your experiences with meds, I too went from adderall XR to vyvanse, and now back to adderal immediate release 2x a day. The biggest thing for me, and it appears very strongly to be your case too, is that meds are only half of the battle. I was really irritable when on my meds, plus a few other things. I had to have the tools to understand how I'd feel on my meds and know what to do to work with the meds. So you stopping your meds because of the meds not doing what the needed to without any intervention on your behalf is a bit short-sighted.  The meds aren't a complete solution and with ADHD, there is never a single fix/cure for something. It takes many days and failed attempts at reinforcing new tools and skills learned in therapy to help yourself to get them to stick, which makes you more successful in managing your ADHD, with or without meds.  Once you've started to make progress on your coping skills with ADHD, meds become like a super weapon and make you unstoppable.  But you HAVE to put in the time on developing yourself and your tools for managing your specific flavor of ADHD.  I always keep a note pad next to me at my desk and any time my brain wants to jump to another task and dive into a topic that isn't what I should be doing, I write it down on the note pad "to do later". It satisfies my brain by thinking I'll get around to it (idiot brain doesn't know it's just gonna forget) and then I can continue on my regular work. Things like that.  Find what makes your ADHD really difficult and what things make it easy for you to do what you need to, and use those to your advantage to set yourself up for success. It's literally the only way I've managed to not get fired after working from home for 3+ years now due to Covid. It was literally impossible to get anything done, even with meds, without my personal development of ADHD management skills.

please, can we let the "iTs BaSiCaLlY mEtH" joke die? the meds are so different and don't even have the methyl- group that makes meth, meth. Adderall and vyvanse are both modified amphetamines, dextroamphetamine vs lisdextroamfetamine, just like methamphetamine is a modification of amphetamine. So if people wanna make the joke, at least say "it's basicallly speed" so you're at least accurate.
I have officially gone through 3 medications and have finally found what I needed in Azstarys. It's just been the most effective. That being said, I am a huge proponent of meds (where appropriate) but meds are not the only answer to ADHD. It still requires work and some therapy. Not like boo hoo woe is me therapy, but like hey you have the ADHD thing, what do you feel you struggle with the most? Let's find what works best for you and work on that together. My ADHD also aggravated mg OCD so as soon as I started taking meds my intrusive thoughts became much less frequent because my brain wasn't running a mile a minute at all times. It was great. Moral of the story is, just ask. If you have a good doc they'll work with you to find what you personally need.

I just wanted to share my own ADHD experience here. When I was a kid, I took medication for my adhd. Concerta and later had abilify add. I took the medications every morning with breakfast when my parents gave it to me. However, once I was done with high school, I stopped taking the meds. Not because my parents didn't think I needed it, but because they decided that it was time for me to take it on my own. They were right, but, guess what? I didn't. I would constantly forget to take my meds. Even if I brought them with me to college or to work in the morning, I would forget to take them. When covid hit, the doctor I had left medical practice and I wasn't able to get refills anymore. In some ways, I saw this as a good thing because I was wasting money and resources on meds I wasn't even using anymore. Now I've been trying to find alternative methods for my adhd without using meds. Currently, I've got white boards in my room for making lists on. I make my goal to scratch off as much of the list by the end of the day, which for me is 5 or 6 o clock.

For my experience, I got ADD, I did a 3 year Bachelor of Animation course unmedicated, and the issue i had with procrastination WAS IMMENSE. Like I thought it was just me being stupid, then I realized "wait, what if it ISNT just me being stupid." And started going down the loop to get ADD meds. Started with Ritalin 10mg, low dose, short acting, so i had to take 2 a day, then I started Concerta 36mg, medium dose, long acting so i only have to take it in the morning, and now I'm on Concerta 54mg, high dose, long acting, and its helped so bloody much like, I can focus on tasks, I can think clearly without so much noise. I can still get distracted, any human can, but its a ton better then before. If i miss it for a day, I can so bloody feel the effects of pre-med me.  My brother has ADHD and is on Ritalin, but was originally on Vivanse, which made him angry, so he had to change, and now he sticks with Ritalin and it helps him a ton too. So honestly, ask about Concerta or Ritalin, they're pretty similar and have a really good effect, some have had cases of addiction, but thats why you test

You aren't the only one with ADHD I do too it is terrible
I take concerta and it really helps me focus even on tasks I'm not interested in. Like I have to take an econ class and I major in psych and I can actually DO the readings and such. It's a slow release as well I still get really caught up in things I do like doing (video games, drawing) but I can better manage my reward path, ya know?
Only way I could get myself to actually do work was to take my meds in the morning, get a cup of tea, light a candle, play some music, throw my phone across the room and sit down in front of whatever i had to do. It works like a charm but fuuuuck is it hard at first
Also worth nothing for Vyvanse (or however you spell it) that he didn't mention (or he just didn't go through it), a big side effect is that it can kill your appetite. When I was taking them I had *a lot* of days where I barely ate anything at all because I was just never hungry, then the days after where I didn't take them (usually because I forgot) I ended up eating a lot more than I should have. It helped me focus, but at the same time my eating habits were completely shot
I think a lot of us, depending on the situation, need to just accept that we have ADHD and stop trying to not have ADHD. We struggle endlessly, and for what? Maybe it's ok to just.. HAVE adhd.

i forgot the medication i took for ADHD but essentially it just turned off my exited-ness as a child and made me listen more side effects where i basically felt like i had already eaten enough to last the full day when infact i had nothing this lasted for months as I would get horrible migranes and vomit without knowing why not to mention i could see pretty much every bone in my body like an extreme anorexic i eventually threw away the meds at the end of 5th grade suffering 2 years of that
Yeah the process with medication can take some time. It's kind of like tuning the suspension on a race car. You'll make a discovery that makes it way better and you go a little further with it and it's poopy town.  My psychiatrist is very adamant about using the least amount of medication, but also sometimes it's about balancing one other med with a primary for off-label means for the individuals needs.  You can put several dozen ADHD brains in a room (Don't ever actually do this, like ever) and every single one of them will have completely different medication compatibility or even just therapy styles that work best for them.
I've tried various meds my whole life and they all suck imo. They target things that aren't the problem and come with untennable side effects imo. I know they work in some ways for some people, and I thought that was me for a long time, but like it or not, there is (currently) no "stop having ADHD" medication.  In addition, adderall is dangerous if you're also bipolar.  Concerta is also just meth. The dose is fine, but doctors treat you like shit if they think you're drug shopping. I was abused and treated like a criminal for trying to be on concerta. They expected me to never miss a dose and to always show up on time to surprise pee tests. It was a nightmare. How the fuck can anyone expect someone with ADHD to get a perfect score hitting those goals?? Especially since adhd is rarely the only thing people have.  Anyway.  I've begun to believe, and this is something I'e heard from other people too....  1. ADHD is not the problem and you should go with it instead of struggling against it. 2. Medication is designed to make productive and quiet students and workers, not to improve the life of the person with ADHD.  Burnout is the real enemy.  Medication makes me burn out, and fighting ADHD without meds makes me burn out.  The only times I feel healthy is when I'm playing follow-the-leader and actually saying, "sure, today can be pottery-and-podcasts day, even though I wanted to hang out with friends and do the dishes".  ADHD sets the goal and I pursue it.  I live alone on welfare,which is the only reason I can do this. No scheduals, no deadlines, except the unavoidable stuff, so I don't have to bruteforce anything more than like twice a week. This prevents infinite stress buildup.  Plus, whatever ADHD decides is "acceptable" for the day, I'm better at than normal. So if I'm always doing what it wants me to do, I'm always in the bonus zone. And I stopped devaluing it! Getting things done, learning, resting, enjoying myself, is never "the wrong thing" just because I didn't plan to do it. I started APPRECIATING what WAS actually happening, instead of getting mad at myself for doing what are ultimately GOOD things to do! What I do is chaotic and not always what I need, but overall I do a lot more and feel a lot better.  I have had to accept that I'm disabled.  I will never wash enough dishes to be independant.  I can never remember to brush my teeth enough, change my clothes enough, take out the trash enough, take my medicine enough, or do ANYTHING enough, to live independantly.  I have stopped listening to the part of me that says "You CAN do everything yourself! All you have to do is stop having ADHD!"  Because I will aways have ADHD. The only thing that attitude gives me is low self esteem. It doesn't help. It makes me,overpromise and,underdeliver and then beat myself up for being "lazy" or for "not focusing".  There is no such thing as focus for us!!!!  What WE call focus is NOT the same focus that OTHER people talk about.  What WE call focus, is the happenstance of being allowed to absorb information, sometimes.  That is NOT focus.  Focus to everyone else is the DELIBERATE and FRUITFUL action of DECIDING to pay attention to something.  That is why we always "try" to focus and can't. It's not something other people try to do and fail at. They just do it if they want to.  That is why we need to stop beating ourselves up. It's a failure when other people don't do it. But for us, it's a disability.  We are disabled.  If you're like me, that thought will make you cry with grief, because you don't want to give up and admit it's not going to work. You've been told your whole life that if you just tried harder, everything will be just fine.  But how hard are you going to try before realizing that they have NO IDEA how impossible it is for you?  How hard do you have to try before it's more harm than good?  I have a caretaker. That's why I'm healthy. Because they can do the things I can't.  When I was able to admit to myself that I'm disabled, I asked the government for help, and they evaluated me and my daily struggles, and said "yeah for what you go through every day, you require 70+ hours of assistance every month."  Can you even IMAGINE someone telling you that you obviously need and deserve help?  I could barely wrap my brain around it. It was like I had been gaslit my whole life until now.  People will tell you ADHDers are neurodivergent, not disabled, and we just process differently. That ADHD is a gift.  It is a gift and we are neurodivergent, that's true. We can do things other people can't do. I'm proud to have ADHD.  However, it's not the condition that determines if we're disabled, it's the context.  A blind person among sighted people is not particularly disabled in a room with no light. In fact they may well be more able than the others.  But the world was just not built for us.  It's entirely hostile to many of us.  That is where disability comes from.  It is not shameful or admitance of failure to realize you are struggling.  Because I did, I can now be free to have a positive and useful relationship with ADHD, instead of constantly fighting it.  Rides the waves. Do what you can. Don't worry about what you can't.  If you're in a labyrinth and you refuse to aknowledge the walls are ever-changing, you'll spend most of the time smushing your face into bricks. Look around, find the actually open path, and follow it.  ADHD refuses to let you set your own goals. But it always gives you a path forward.
I have ADHD and used to take meds for it and it really help with school.

You say don't let it affect my opinion, but I started Vyvanse 4 weeks ago and thought the surge of artistic creativity and house cleaning to my academic expense (RIGHT WHEN I was finishing up some academic work starting semester 1 in uni) WAS MY BAD DISCIPLINE. It's the VYvanse!
I started straterra a year ago and it was like magic. I could suddenly focus on exactly what I needed to do. It came with a bunch of physical side effects that were annoying but I figured the mental improvement was worth it. A month later I found out during the follow-up that my blood pressure had gone from very healthy to stage 2 hypertension. I had to downgrade my dosage because my cardiovascular system really couldn't handle that much pressure. So now I still take the medication but at a dosage that doesn't feel as effective, and my blood pressure is borderline hypertensive and drinking even a little caffeine is enough to send it over the edge. But compared to having untreated ADHD, I feel like it's still worth it
