Well, i guess i gotta tell my story too, been diagnosed for a long time, since I was six years old, and i always was given ritalin, unfortunately later in life it was discovered that ritalin was affecting my heart, because i have a malformation and ritalin was giving me tachycardia, so diched it and gave me other meds that don't really focus on ADHD, but the withdrawal from ritalin was certainly something not nice, obviously having taken it for years made me almost dependant, then i switched from medication to medication constantly, never felt right with any of them, most targeted misdiagnoses of bipolarity, and a few targeted my anger issues but in a nasty way, i felt slightly calmer until i didn't had the meds then i was a ticking bomb, a visit to the psych ward and they gave me Other meds and at that point I was sick and tired of it, so I ditched it, I'm not someone with a ton of ADHD, i have more predominant Asperger's Syndrome, so i tried to calm myself, By making a bunch of exercise, running always i can, doing all kinds of tiring stuff, along with a hobby of carving wood and drawing really made the symptoms a lot more manageable, i no longer have constantly excess energy but i keep my creativity, and probably get fit too  that's how i abandoned meds and started to make exercise
So the downside to the meth ones is that, well, its meth. Which often has side effects. I would ask about bupropion, i was on that for a while and it really helped with focus.
I actually am about to take the plunge and go back onto medications myself. I was diagnosed with ADHD at 5 years old and was taking meds all the way from Kindergarten to 7th grade and by that point nothing was working anymore. So I just stopped. I refused to let my mom or dad buy any more meds. Said I wouldn't take them. And they agreed to let me stop cause it wasn't helping. And from 12/13 years old until 24 I was managing my symptoms. Not well but I was managing. Now at almost 25 I can't anymore. Nothing's working again. I know this was just way too much personal info about me but I felt like sharing. So if anyone else is in a similar situation they don't feel alone. K bye.

This might just be because I have had bad experiences with ADHD meds while having ADHD, but I really do not recommend using ADHD meds for overcoming ADHD. Some people I know who have ADHD or have a child who has it claim that med supposedly improves their situation. But my experience with meds was very similar to Ice Cream Sandwich's, where I either got sick, overly tired, had sudden mood swings, or just flat out did not work. Over time, while knowing my predicament, I have found ways to help my brain deal with this issue without meds. Now understandably, no two people's situation will not be the same, but unless you are intentional in taking steps to improve your focus, you will not get better meds or not. Sometimes, it just takes you intentionally focusing on one task until it is complete or finding ways to stay on task. In the end, it takes more perseverance to become more proficient when fighting against issues like ADHD than it does anything else. Yes, it is hard to beat it, but not impossible.
I'd recommend methylphenidate or anything in that family for focus, it makes me to feel like my brain isn't static filled anymore. ü•∞
I am medicated with it
My doctor prescribed me 20 mg of Adderall which is kinda a lot for a person my age/size and i've been taking it for like a year and half now. I would say the only tangible effect is just an increase in... motivation? Things like responding to a text, making my bed, or starting a homework assignment no longer seem like unconquerable tasks. It doesn't exactly improve focus, but I am much less likely to give up on what I'm doing. However, touching on the meth thing, I've developed a chemical addiction to it so now my brain makes basically zero dopamine naturally. When it wears off or if I dont take it I am a mindless depressed shell of a person and this is especially a problem bc currently there is a nationwide Adderall shortage. For the past few months, every time I go to refill my meds its takes them like two weeks to do so. I want to stop taking them all together it but also I need to participate in society and be happy so oh well.

I take vyvanse
ok ok ok so for those who don't know, the reason you don't just STOP taking meds is because you will go into withdrawal and that can make everything so much worse. usually if you need to stop meds your doctor will tell you to correct way to ease off your specific medication. for some meds for some people, going cold turkey works but for a lot of people and a lot of different meds it can cause problems as light as headaches to as awful as seizures or even coma. so PLEASE do not ever stop taking meds without talking to your doctor because it can be very dangerous depending on your body's general medicine reactions and the types of medicine you are taking.

this is how i feel
Oh my god. I remember vivance (sorry, probably misspelled but done fighting autocorrec). Right around when I was taking it I had my grandfather in a coma in the hospital and he had just woken up. Now a thing to know about me is that I have an actual, little spoken of, phobia of seeing loved ones in the hospital or in a way that is impossible for me to care for them in a way that they get better. A nuance but one of my really deep fears and down right phobias. It‚Äôs little known because I still force myself to see loved ones in these places or be by their side to support them or offer comfort. But my god, I‚Äôm freaking out inside and being triggered so bad the entire time. Another thing to know about me is that I also have Anxiety. I am mostly considered high functioning with it but I still get those lovely attacks. Well, after a day seeing my grandfather in the hospital looking still sick, but awake and conscious of everything, I was on edge. I was also medicated. It‚Äôs lunch time so the family, who had all gathered to see my grandfather, decided to meet up and go to a restaurant. Guess who I see at the head of the huge table talking to my grandmother? My grandfather‚Äôs older brother! Guess who looks like an identical but healthy copy of my grandfather? His brother! Yeah so I freaked the fuck out and couldn‚Äôt snap out of it because the meds had me focused on the panic attack I had and so it took me twice as long to get ahold of myself and my brother was freaked out (because he usually helps ground me during these if he is around) I had an ice pack, courtesy of the restaurant, on my neck, and was just sitting in the car in the heat of summer in the desert (is a desert town) just freaking out for maybe 30 or so minutes and not yet passed out from it. My parents and I immediately agreed to just not let me had meds on ‚Äúdays off‚Äù like that again, especially in stressful situations like that for me. This is also around the time I confessed to my parents about my phobia and they felt sorry about every time I had gone ahead and let myself be triggered in the past (other grandfather dying, great grandmother sick, my very sick and dying paternal aunt, my various dogs I had to see off when they finally passed at the vet, a friend who had a car accident and was very injuries and hospitalized, my dad nearly every year because he is accident prone, etc). This hasn‚Äôt actually stopped me from entering the medical profession though. I‚Äôm stubborn which is the only dang thing keeping my adhd, depression, and anxiety in line while I‚Äôm unmedicated. And yeah, for now, I‚Äôm unmedicated. Its difficult enough to get meds when you decide you need them in the USA, as was mentioned. But lately my depression has gotten bad and is triggering my anxiety with it which leads to worse symptoms of my adhd (what a lovely cascade effect). So I‚Äôve been discussing adding meds for my depression. I‚Äôm not looking forward to it. I‚Äôve been medicated before and‚Ä¶.well I rarely have it work well in my particular case, not to mention some very traumatizing instances I have had to face regarding their use or those prescribing them being the reason. It‚Äôs been a journey. So let me say my current unmedicated state is not from internalized ableism, it‚Äôs from trauma a series of bad experiences attempting to be medicated. That was my experience though. Thought I would share. I don‚Äôt want to say for anyone to not add medication as a toolset for themselves. This was simply my own experience. My brother for instance has had a very good experience with adding medication to his therapy and it‚Äôs definitely allowed him to lead a better quality of life with it. I would love an experience like his. It just wasn‚Äôt in my cards and now I have stuff to undo mentally if I want to make another attempt, which I‚Äôm trying to do. But I‚Äôll start with the depression since it‚Äôs being the worst one right now. Wish me luck!

How about instead of drugging yourself, read some philosophical books! I know it sounds silly, or even moralizing, but modern psychology fetishizes biology and medicine to a disgusting and distressing degree. Introspection and self analysis (you don't have to be a professional) can be really useful!   I would recommend Jordan Peterson (and before you start scrolling down: I'm a transgender moderate-left American. *No. Jordan Peterson is not some transphobic asshole.*) because a lot of his work centers around finding meaning in life, speaking honestly to yourself, and generally becoming more aware of who you are as a person. It can really help calibrate your senses and (hopefully in your case) maybe get rid of some of that distraction that's messing with you so much. I would especially recommend this if your medication has/is not working, because that might mean that your problem isn't a biological one, but a psychological or emotional one.

1:05 1:50 Racism lore
I also had the same experience with Ritalin when I first got it. My psychiatrist gave me the prescription because I was having the hardest time with college (failing every subject cough cough) and then I thought my problems would be solved! Nope! What Ritalin did instead was kick the hyperfocus in and I spent 10+ hours drawing instead of doing college work. So I thought welp this is useless to me! That was until I went to see a therapist who specializes in ADHD She was the one actually able to give me the directions in order for Ritalin to actually be effective, which was: routine. Following a routine was what helped me be able to accomplish things on my daily basis and no, it's not easy to follow a routine at all! Us ADHD brain have no capability of forming habits so everything we do is a conscious decision that we need to remember! So I got alarms and boards and sticky notes with reminders! Pomodoro is also the game changer on what helped me do college work as well! Simple app but makes a world of difference!   So basically, meds by themselves don't do anything if you don't know how to use it properly! I needed help because I had the superpower but no guidance on how to make it the most effective it could be! I absolutely still struggle with routine because one inconvenience that happens can absolutely break it but again, it's a forever work in progress for us! Writing the things you accomplished down also helps, breaking things into like: I woke up, I got out of bed, I prepared coffee, I sat down, I had breakfas, etc. Can make you feel like you're doing a lot, because you are! For us neurodivergent people things work different and the only standard we should hold ourselves up to is ourselves! Being able to accomplish what we want to do for the day is enough and even if we don't, there's always tomorrow!

My sister has a much more extreme version of ADHD than myself, I think I probably don't have it but I do have a lot of trouble doing one thing. I always have to multi-task but I'm still able to focus on multiple tasks at once and retain the information from them. BUT, my sister had it really really bad, still does. The first medication they gave her when she was 10, turned her into a different person, a complete zombie she was basically impossible to get to. It's like she went from having 100000% energy to -100%, so she stopped taking that within like a month and then didn't start taking a medication again until she was 23.   This one was Adderall, and I gotta say i'm so glad she doesn't take it anymore because keeping up with her is SUCH a chore. Now she takes something else and she's still a bit all over the place but at least she's able to function. I will say, I think her problem with Adderall was actually from Stress and Caffiene, like, waaayyyy to much caffiene.   Moral of the story is, keep trying until it works, everyone bodies are different and while the US System for medications is completely trash though.

once again, i cannot thank you enough for being so honest with this topic. obviously you didn't do it for me, or anyone in particular really, but you didn't just go ahead and regurgitate someone else' ideas or experiences, or some idealized version of your experience, or even just what people might want to hear you say. you gave a genuinely unique and informative recounting of your true to life, undramatized experiences, without the agendas that so often fuel much of the dialogue surrounding mental health. honestly, despite having been on adderall for ages now, hearing your story has made me consider things from a new perspective which is so incredibly refreshing in comparison to the generally cyclical or stagnating feeling that can come from trying to get treatment. i know i might be putting too much stock in an adhd video from the silly cartoon man, but it's like breaking through the surface of the metaphorical water and getting a big ol' lungful of that sweet sweet fresh air to see such a massive creator be so genuine and vulnerable for all the world to see. makes it seem a little less scary for the rest of us folks still figuring this all out. never change, andy ‚ù§
I used to be on Adderall and one night when I was 6, I had an adverse reaction to it and had hallucinations about spiders attacking me and my mom. We got switched to Concerta and it worked for a while until it didn't. We kept upping the dose until I was maxed, and it still didn't do anything. Additionally, it was making me sick. I was paranoid and anxious all the time, I'd never eat at all, and I never talked to anyone, so I never had friends besides my close ones. At 16 in 10th grade, I decided to take control of my life and figure out how to manage my ADHD without medication. It was hard and difficult, but I made it. I still failed out of high school, but more years of discipline and hard work, I managed to get my GED and managed to buy a house with my wife that I met in high school after getting off my meds and becoming social again. I still struggle daily like my dishes are always dirty and I can only catch up on a day of hyperfixation during the weekend and i have at least 30 unfinished pieces of artwork that I can't find time to finish and so on but at least I know the most important things are done. But that's my experience and it's definitely a hard and arduous journey. Find what works for you because what works for me won't for someone else. I'd also like to thank my wife for being so supportive of me and helping me through my struggle to achieve what I once thought impossible.

Heyo! I really related to this video. I also had similar experiences with ADHD meds. I took one type of med for awhile and it didn't do barely anything. Any medication prescribed for your brain doesn't do the work for you like a pain medication or a heart medication. Rather it allows your brain to relax quiet down the things that you're struggling with so you can focus. The issues will still come back, which is why Therapy is the only thing that can actually work when on "brain meds" (using the term loosely). It will allow you to build strategies and work through tougher emotions to better process them. It may take a while but eventually many people are able to get off their ADHD meds or their anti-depressant/anti-anxiety meds with the help of therapy, because they learned how to take the drivers seat

Sorry you had to go through that. Dealing with OCD myself. I took an SSRI and it sent me into a manic state. Found out years later that it's probably because I'm also bipolar (it's in my doctor's notes, but I don't think I'm formally diagnosed since I quit going to therapy before we came to a conclusion). If you're bipolar and take SSRIs then apparently it can send you into a manic state (I'm not a doctor. Ask them, not me). Anyway, years earlier while I was still taking the meds, the psychiatrist I was seeing wanted to up the dosage, so I also quit cold turkey (Like you mentioned, don't do this. Ask your doctor about your medication). Felt a lot of relief after I quit, but also back at square one with a lot less trust in mental health care ü•≥

I'm on Straterra It helps me focus for the most part, but it makes me drowsy at odd times and I don't always sleep well. Plus I got to keep an eye on my liver and drink a lot of water. Low dose is 10 I think and it's a none-narcartic. But it works for me. With meds it just depends on you and your body's reaction. No ADHDer is the same you may need a non stimulant on low dose to keep you productive and focused enough. Also be mindful that you have to keep meds in your system for more than two weeks and keep an eye on extreme side effects like pain in chest/abdominal and unusual/ dangerous thoughts.  Also with Meds they aren't going to completely erase your ADHD symptoms. They help you manage the symptoms so best to find one you can function with.

I have had you exact experience with both vyvanse and adderall, but it took me many many years to acknowledge the terrible side effects it was causing, because I needed it so desperately to do my school work. Vyvanse made me horribly nauseous, insominiac, and weak, and gave me heart palpitations and anxiety, but I was overweight and just blamed my eating habits for it, until I went off my meds for the summer one time, and my symptoms completely vanished. Unfortunately, I really do need meds to function, but I am now taking this weird liquid form of amphetamine called Dyanaval, that‚Äôs a much lower dose, and seems to be affecting me much less negatively, while still having a noticeable improvement in my concentration and focus. It‚Äôs usually used for kids who are just starting adhd meds, but it is working great for me, so I plan to keep taking it.

I took Concerta, Vyvanse, and Stratera. I wasn't really old enough to know the difference between them all. But... my body got used to them all at one point or another. Except for Vyvanse, which I took in High School. That... was an experience. It kicked my resting heart rate up to where an active one should have been. I'm pretty sure. same story as in the video. Doctors didn't know what was going on. I stopped taking it. And what do you know? my heart rate dropped into normal specs. I don't really take anything now. Haven't for several years. And I don't plan on going back on them. I don't trust them anymore.

medication alone will not help. you need to take medication in conjunction with behavioral therapy to see the best results. basically, you need to learn good habits so that youre able to then maintain those good habits though the use of medication. also, you should be learning how to manage things without medication as well.
The worst part about adhd for me was seeing everyone else in my class understanding the work and doing it so easily but for some reason I just couldn‚Äôt. That thought messed me up for a while but I‚Äôve learned to accept it and started getting better with focusing and doing my work most of the time. I still get distracted very easily and little things even as small as the lights being too bright can throw me off my flow of work. The worst thing you can do with adhd is let it control you. There are some days where it‚Äôs easier to get into the flow of work and there are some where you have to really force yourself to focus but as long as you keep fighting it you‚Äôll get through it. It took me until the last semester of my senior year of Highschool to figure out how to manage my work with medication but once you figure out how to work with it rather than expect it to do the work for you everything becomes 10x easier.

as someone who has been taking Vyvanse for awhile it sounds like you could of been on too high of a dosage. that's probably not the case if you have a competent physician though so id recommend not taking it every day, I rarely take Vyvanse on the weekends, I think this refractory period could help negate the side affects of taking Vyvanse over long periods. also while Vyvanse is really good at helping you focus on tasks its also can be detrimental to things like apatite and being able to sleep, so make sure you take it after eating but not too late that it would carry on past your bedtime. what I've found to help with redirecting focus is before doing a task I don't want to do or aren't currently focused on is setting a reward for completing the task or a part of the task as motivation and cheap dopamine to bribe my brain with, only problem is if you then get to focused on the reward. usually even if I'm doing something I don't want to do if I can stay on task for long enough I start to reel in focus from whatever was taking up the brain. honestly though doing drugs is a sort of skill, you eventually grow more and more tolerant too them and start to find equilibrium between the mind and the medication, both naturally and through learning techniques to help effectively use them. stay in school, don't do drugs, unless you need drugs to stay in school.

Adderall changed my life !! üòÇ Sad that I started medication as late as 25, but I lucked out that adderall-salt combo was my first try and its a perfect fit for me ! I have combined ADHD, so i'm either utterly exhausted (or occasionally ready to blast off) while simultaneously either hyperfocused/hyperfixated or just mentally not present enough üò¨ Adderall fixed the energy issue SO well, that while its active, its like my body can keep up with my brain (my heavy preference to a butt load of caffeine to make me awake should've indicated that in highschool üò¨) and I can work my job and do shit like chores without it all being so exhausting and boring. I did discover though that I ended up with the loss-of-appetite  side-effect üò¨ and that IT LITERALLY CHANGED MY PERSPECTIVE OF TIME AND SPACE. No joke, I noticed I had to ACTUALLY RE-TEACH MYSELF HOW TO DRIVE on the FRIST DAY I started the meds üòÖ.  But after getting a feel for difference between on & off meds driving, I know what to expect now, but I also noticed that I started perceiving time properly !! üòÇ  Time feels like it passes the way its supposed to instead of waaay too fast and slipping by me like usual !  I really wish I got diagnosed as a kid, a part of me thinks academics could've at least been less hard & that I might've had a better chance at the things I wanted to do ü•≤

All witch he had never done before, so I asked him to stop taking them. And when he finally listened and stopped he snapped out of this weird dream state that he was in while on meds, and realized what he had been doing.   And to be honest, if I didn‚Äôt stop him, I‚Äôm pretty sure that would have lasted for a lot longer. He is so much better without all that drug shit in his body, and I‚Äôm glad that I did stop him because I‚Äôm not sure if could have delt with him, acting like a weirdo, for to much longer. I started w/ vyvanse. It felt really miraculous at first. Now... I think it mostly helps w/ my mood regulation. Which is still great! but it doesn't seem to be helping with the "doing things" or the "stay focused" stuff as much if at all now... We tried upping the dose awhile back but it didn't seem to help at all, besides maybe increase my heartrate and possibly my anxiety, so we went back down in dose... and so yeah, I feel like aside from my mood being better (which DOES help, anxiety and depression are NOT helpful for executive functioning) I also feel like I'm back at square one.   I'm at least not having an adverse reaction, and I think it actually helps my energy levels--I don't have quite as major "booms" and "busts" in energy level throughout the day (i.e., WOW I'm ANXIOUS a/o HYPERACTIVE and then OH NOW I GOTTA NAP FOR 3 HOURS) ... but the "primary" symptoms associated w/ ADHD around executive functioning/task transitioning/focusing all seem to be pretty much back to how they were. I'm too worried about trying new meds middle of a semester though.

So, you stopped Adderall because it was like meth, but started taking lisdexAMFETAMINE.
I swear if I hear another video say that taking adderall is basically like taking meth I‚Äôm gonna lose it. This conflation of adderall and meth has been used to shame people with ADHD for taking it and say that adderall is overall bad because it‚Äôs chemically similar to meth. There was a joke my high school chemistry teacher told us, a man walks into a bar and orders H2O and the man next to him says ‚ÄúI‚Äôll have H2O too‚Äù. Later that second man dies because he was given H2O2, hydrogen peroxide, and drank so much it killed him. Just because adderall and meth are chemically similar doesn‚Äôt mean they are the same, they work in different ways on different people. Adderall is one of the most well know adhd meds that gets abused by people without adhd, which means it gets the most blame when it‚Äôs reported on as some college kids these days are abusing stimulants. Adderall works differently for people without adhd because it wasn‚Äôt designed for them, so for them it could feel similar to taking meth and could be addictive. When used by people who actually have adhd, it rarely is addictive. I have been taking adderall since I was diagnosed at 7 years old because they were about to hold me back in first grade, my ADHD was the that bad unmediated. Adderall helped me significantly improve and show that I didn‚Äôt need to be held back and was actually understanding the material and was really smart, just unfocused. It‚Äôs been 11 years of taking adderall and only within the past two years of starting to manage the taking of my own meds have I started to get in the habit of not forgetting to take them. I still often forget to take them when I don‚Äôt have anything planned for that day or   I am getting ready so fast that I forget. I often forget to take it because it‚Äôs not addictive for me but just it helps me focus. Adderall has been around for decades and was one of the early adhd meds invented, which means it has had lots of time to improve and is safe and not addictive for many ADHDers to take, unlike meth. So no, it‚Äôs not like basically taking meth, they may be chemically similar but the things that are important like how safe or possibly addictive it is are very different.

Welcome to our world. I‚Äôm on vyvance.
I was diagnosed with ADHD super early on and they tried medication with me, but it just made me really depressed. My advice for you is to review your coping mechanisms. You've likely developed a lot of them, but you should do more research into the exact symptoms of ADHD (doctor's won't tell you the important ones like executive dysfunction) and how to cope with them, and when you inevitably come across days when brain refuses anyway or you know you need a ton of productivity, then take meds on those specific days. Seriously treat it as a last resort, though; a super power you shouldn't use unless you have to or it'll lose effectiveness. I highly recommend dropping caffeine and using it as said super power unless you have a really high base tolerance. Edit: On a side note, are you sure it's ADHD and not autism? They're actually very similar and people often get diagnosed with both, but that's not always accurate. I recommend looking into it a bit.

I once had an experience with adhd medication. Concerta I think was the drug in the pill. Let me start off by saying, I don't think I have ADHD, I wondered in the past, but I've come to learn that I'm actually really good at studying and understanding (especially when I'm learning in my own time and things that interest me like working on programming projects). THE STORY: My friend owed me money for like a year and didn't want to pay me back so he gave me a few adhd pills (concerta) and said that these are pretty hard to get so he's doing me a favour. I didn't want to take them, I thought about maybe trying to sell them to some stoner kid at our dorm. One night when I was working on a project of mine I got curious and took one pill. I shit you not I sat at my chair coding for almost 10 hours without a single break or distractions. No checking my phone, no Spotify playing in the background, just pure focus and I got so much shit done. I felt this slight buzz, I felt ultra focused. Totally forgot there was the whole world, that I need to sleep. It was just me and what I wanted to get done. The work literally felt more rewarding that relaxing. I probably don't need to say that I took the rest, once when I was studying for a BIG test and the rest to help me on my projects. It took me not even an hour to study for that test and I got a 100%. I would've needed to study for hours if I didn't take that pill. I felt worthless that without this drug I'm not using my true potential and I still kind of feel that way. I'm glad that I didn't beg my friend for more of those pills but I have to admit that the pure focus I got thanks to those pills is something I'll always desire.

I have been living with ADHD for awhile, and while they're not POPULAR, I'd recommend giving a nonstimulant medication a try _alongside counseling._ It sounds like your body is NOT a fan of stimulants, and it also sounds like your meds are giving you the ABILITY to do stuff, but NOT to prioritize, which--ding ding ding, you have to _learn_ how to prioritize effectively. I stared out with Strattera/Atomoxetine, a non-stimulant 25mg capsule, and while I had mostly stomach/excretory issues in the first couple weeks and a weird week-long stint of Deadness before the meds worked, those side-effects were VERY short-lived and manageable, and once the meds finally started to work and I engaged in counseling focused on skill-building, I've been fucking golden. Almost zero side-effects and continual satisfaction. My experience might not be YOUR experience, but hey, giving it a shot is a win-win, as you'll either learn what works for you, or narrow down your search even further. Best of luck, brother.

my experience with concerta thus far has been life-changing in the best ways possible. but it is not all due to the drug.  1) i made a decision, the decision, to succeed where other will fail and let nothing deprive me of realizing my goals. so i gained the drive to let me display incalculable commitment psychologically.  2) my psychiatrist is great, i could be completely open and perform straight-forward monitoring of all effects of the medication, suggest dosage adjustments and receive proper feedback on the pros and cons of that suggestion until we got the dosage perfectly balanced. he helped me help myself, while also preparing me for all lifestyle choices that had to be changed/introduced/cut out and explaining to me in a detailed manner why those changes had to be made.  3) i am personally compatible with the medication, stimulants in general is something my body gets along with.  in the short span of a year of taking this medication, i have : `gained the ability to channel my focus to tasks that are boring but ultimately absolutely essential to do/learn. `gained the ability to demonstrate unwavering consistency to both begin AND complete tasks of many natures. `worked on and finalized personal projects that would otherwise go on forever with no clear goal in mind. `learnt c++ and python and made actual software that i and other friends of mine use to make our lives easier. `landed a job as an insurance consultant and so far i'm having a performance that is above standards. `learnt how to mix, master, and produce music on a professional level. `released 2 albums just for fun. `lost 40kg. `got into fitness and exercise. `can actually follow a healthy diet. `gained the ability to actually drive without being a literal ticking time bomb of "look -a bird is sitting on that telephone pole~ OH GOD WE'RE GONNA CRASH AND DIE" `got my life back. `helped 3 separate businesses get established, expand, and offer back to the local community. `gained the ability to comprehend the concept of "long-term gratification/working consistently instead of going off on motivation".   before taking this medication, this decision , this oath to myself, i literally had/made/provided/wanted/did nothing, never. i would think of a spectacular idea, and by the time i got to the point where i would even start to do something with it, i had found every reason there could ever be to not go through with it.   it is therefore my deduction from my personal experience that: `if you have made the decision `and you have a great psychiatrist `and your body is compatible with stimulants going through and taking this medication will without a doubt change your life for the better. but you need to take it early in the start of the day, cause it will str8 up keep u up otherwise, and sleep deprivation is the last thing you wonna mix with a stimulant.

I just wanna say since you last video I have gotten medicated and its been life changing. I found a lot of my faults were due to my ADHD being untreated for so long. The struggles I have with my college classes (4 yrs of it going on to 5th and 6th) all went away. The bad attention span, the seemingly impossible task of getting up out of bed despite being awake for 2 hours, the inability to set goals and attain them. I will say for people with ADHD you have a lot of motivation, more than most. What medication (and only medication) does is allows you to take that first step into completing your goals and tasks throughout the day. It will not force you to do anything but the meds help with you getting there. You still need to work but actually getting to that working step won't take forever, nor will it be minutes before a deadline.   No joke from starting medication I have essentially cured most of my depression/anixety, feel better about myself, do better in school, and hold responsibilites I never would have imagined myself holding years ago. Look into it I promise its worth it!

I feel this one ü•≤
There's some things that are important to understand that I think might've helped your experience:  1. Adderall is not meth. Amphetamine salts are not the same as methamphetamine. They're structurally very similar, but small structure changes in drugs can be very meaningful in terms of how they work. A mirror image of a drug, Tamiflu, can cause terrible birth defects while the normal version is fine. 2. Any ADHD drug you take has what's called a "therapeutic window", which is the range of doses where you can get benefits without the side effects being too bad. The therapeutic window can be really small. If you have the "overly focused" feeling, or difficult feelings of anxiety or tightness of breath, your dose may simply be too high. It doesn't necessarily mean the drug is not compatible with you. 3. Drugs may completely "fix" your symptoms, but they also may only partially help. This is normal. 4. It's normal to have to learn new habits and ways of working while you're taking medication. You need different things now (e.g., making sure you're going to focus on the right thing on Adderall by altering your environment to make it easily available). 5. It can take a long time and trial and error to find the right medication and dose for you, especially when you don't have a provider who tells you all of this. This is a long process, and it helps a lot to work with an ADHD coach or therapist to help you figure out all the non-prescription stuff.
as someone who has been taking Vyvanse for around 10 years, you NEED to take breaks from it. Not only will it stop working if you take it non-stop, but like you experienced it can have some bad side effects. not to mention that you can build up tolerance so you just have to keep upping the dose. give yourself break days where you aren't doing anything, like the weekends. let yourself just sleep and eat and recover from your week. try not to take it while you're on vacation or not planning on doing anything important for a while. also pay very close attention to how much you eat because vyvanse can make you nut feel hunger anymore and that can obviously be pretty bad if you don't notice it.

i have adhd and have tried many meds-
It's not "meth." ADHD might share the same class as METHamphetamines, but your ADHD meds are NOT COMPARBLE TO STREET METH. That's a terrible way to tar those taking adhd medication with an addict brush. üòï
I've been diagnosed since I was six, after which I started taking concerta and ritalin. It started out great, till it wasn't great anymore, and I was rapidly losing weight and showcasing symptoms of depression despite not even being 10 yet. I quit them, and due to that awful experience, decided not to try them again.   Almost a decade after that, I decide I'm going to take meds anyways. They first start me on Concerta again, but it doesn't even take two weeks before I want off. Yes, I can focus better, but the side effects were horrendous (nausea, headaches, insomnia, etc.). They give me a different medication: Atomoxetine, or better known as Stratera.   I've been taking that for about 4-5 years now. I started out with zero side effects, though it seems that I may have developed heart palpitation because of them. It's still unsure, but it's manageable. And it's worth it.  In high school, I suddenly started scoring higher on tests. My scores went from 6s and maybe an occasional 7 (5.5 is a pass here), to 8 and 9. That's a massive increase, especially considering I've changed absolutely nothing about my study habits!  Homework that used to take me 1-2 hours to complete, at least, was suddenly done in 15 minutes. I was able to memorize things, something I genuinely believed was impossible for me. And it was, before I started taking these meds.   Although concerta and ritalin certainly improved my ability to focus, stratera did it far better with much less of the trouble that comes with it. It was only after two years of taking them that I would occasionally notice my elevated heartrate, and although it has worsened, I don't want to stop taking these meds.   To outsiders, I was functioning fairly well before taking these meds. Before prescribing them, I had an intake for possible therapy to improve my coping mechanisms. After the intake, they said they couldn't help me. I already had a gigantic arsenal of coping skills to deal with my ADHD, and it was still not enough.  I'm so glad I'm on meds, despite my aversion to them initially. Stratera isn't commonly prescribed, and it can be a real struggle to receive it sometimes, but I'm so glad for the ways it's improved my life. For anyone who wants to know, they're a non-stimulant (which is uncommon for ADHD meds). That means they're also not an opiod.  If you're thinking about taking these, don't let the online stories of side effects scare you. They're rare. Although it takes about two months for these meds to fully settle in, I noticed the positive effect within two weeks (as soon as I started taking 40mg). I'd definitely recommend them if stimulants aren't working out for you.

i have tried pretty much every adhd medication. all of them make it so i cannot eat for 12+ hours, which... makes it hard to be productive. i have a very sensitive stomach and pretty much all medication messes with it super bad, i remember after taking one small starter dose of lexapro in high school i vomited nonstop for 2 days. i am more productive without stimulants because i can actually eat food to fuel my brain... (and no i cannot eat before taking meds, because i don't get hungry in the morning. i usually don't eat for 2-3 hours after waking up because it makes me nauseous if i try to force it.)  i am not on any stimulant meds, but i do take pristiq for emotional regulation which is one of my biggest adhd symptoms. i find having a partner to live with helps me stay on task because they can call me out if i am distracted and redirect me.

I got diagnosed in 3rd grade and started taking vyvanse soon after. the first time I took it I noticed a huge difference. we were going over our homework and I realized "wait...I'm writing down the answers...I'm correcting my homework...I know what we're doing??" the whole day continued like this. I could read, I could do math, I could write, all while getting it through my head. I wasn't turning around constantly and swinging my legs. I wasn't picking my lip (as much, I still need to fidget and it's a bad habit to this day) when I got home I was jumping around and telling my mom how well it worked. she was shocked that it worked so quickly. unfortunately the medicine isn't all sunshine and rainbows. it almost completely changes my personality. I go from hyper and silly, which I enjoy, to serious and more quiet. which I hate and just isn't actually me. the part that makes this hurtful is that so many people prefer me this way because I'm not so "overwhelming". I honestly cried tears of joy when my boyfriend said, "I'm glad you forgot your medicine today, that means you're going to act like the real you."  with school, vyvanse works great because when you switch classes you're forced to focus on a new task. with daily life, I'm not so sure. I don't take vyvanse out of school unless I need to focus on something. I've never had a bad reaction to not taking it, and my doctors have never told me to not do it.
So I was on Vyvanse and it was hell and what you described is exactly what happens and the shot days I focused on anime

I had the exact same issues as you, I still do with my ADHD, except when I was on meds (I tried adderall, ritalin and vvyanse). The first two completely suppressed my appetite and not eating was giving me headaches which, wouldn't ya know, didn't really help my focus, and vvyanse made me feel like I was constantly astral projecting with my physical body unable to emote or feel emotions but it did help me focus...on the wrong things, also got a minor panic attack from hyper-focusing on my heartbeat while working and it made me paranoid about the meds but I couldnt move so I was just trying to do stuff, emotionless which internally freaking out.  Also unmedicated right now BUT I found that cognitive behavioural therapy along with finding an adaptable schedule that fits in between work and school really helps, so like planning ahead to take into account other big priorities, most of my schedule accounts for my lack of focus/procrastination. But my brain never shuts off, sometimes its fun company other times is just wack. Vitamin D and staying away from too much sugar and going to the gym was soooooo key on improving focus, but some days are better than others lool

I‚Äôm currently trying out different ADD meds and for anyone else in the same situation, be VERY careful of what cold medicine you take, because it turns out that some ADD meds REALLY don‚Äôt like certain cold medicines. I found this out the hard way, so save yourself the pain and trouble!
When I take my adhd meds it kind of feels like when you read a book for a really long time. You know that feeling? One of my friends told me that‚Äôs how it feels to be high. My medication lasts for 12 hours. I take it once a day. That means that I am high for half of my life. If you see me on the street, do yourself a favor and avoid me. Thank you
Ok we begin this video with a song about drugs
Also, Vyvanse takes time to get used to. It can take you up to 2 months or so to actually start getting the effects in the right way, without side effects.  The breathlessness is extremely common, and does stop happening after a while. After a while, the only side effect youre likely to end up with, aside from a minor addiction, is some slight eating disorder, as in you don't eat enough.  Your vyvance side-effect is common, and happens with other meds too, especially early on. You just need to give it time. Its clear your psychologist probably didnt make the side-effect situation clear enough, but ALL ADHD meds have side effects in the beginning. There IS a transition period you have to get through. If you dont get the eating disorder issue, vyvance is extremely good for people like you and I, who have the lack of focus and attention most strongly. For me, the eating disorder got too bad, but Im soon going over to Strattera which is essentially the same according to a colleague, but without that one side-effect, and likely without the shortness of breath too, seeing as it's not a stimulant.

just so people know, adderall is absolutely not at all meth, and not the same as, and not similar to it. There IS a legal brand of actual methamphetamine which can be prescribed for ADHD in some cases, and it's the ONLY legal methamphetamine. However, that is a different drug entirely, and not adderall.

My man made me figure out I had ADHD
Best way to reduce side effects in my experience is to take break days and to schedule my days off my medication.  When I have a more firm schedule, things can work better.  In my experience, my medication can affect the *quality* of my sleep - which can make everything worse - and I can get a ton of fatigue.  It's pretty normal to take medication breaks for people with ADHD. Sometimes I can take a break off a weekday, and sometimes I'll just take a break off my weekend. I will sometimes really want results - which can lead to me not taking enough breaks.

why the video is so quiet?
The "Aderal is similar to meth" is actually only a half truth. Chemically, it is structured very similarly to meth, but as you saw with its lack of a sensation, it impacts the brain in radically different (and non-harmful) ways than meth. Even incredibly tiny differences in a molecule can cause its medical effects to change drastically, for instance the mirror image (enantiomer) of meth called "Levomethamphetamine" is even more similar structurally to meth, but is actually just a mundane, over the counter nasal medication.  Also, great moral to the story of it always being good to check up with your doctor/psychiatrist! They can be really helpful with helping you figure out what medications work for you! The med that ended up working for me was ritalin, which has a few annoying side effects (a little emotional when it wears off and I sometimes kind of forget to eat when its in effect), but overall has really helped me and many others with managing symptoms, so it might be worth talking to your doc/psych about that one!
Im trying out Medikinet. There are two versions: one works sooner and lasts for around 14hrs. The other one works slower but only lasts 4-6hrs. Second option is prefered by creative people and Im a creative person so I agreed to that. First week I didnt notice much, so time + higher dosis made me notice a change: my head wasnt constantly overloaded by all different kinds of things. I actually sometimes felt "peace" in my head.  Usually I feel like my mind was a small ship in middle of the ocean during an insane storm. The meds made me feel like my mind was a rift on a river with zero wind at all. Might sound weird but maybe some people can relate. However, ADHS/ADS isnt all bad. For creative people. Things we are really interested in cause a hyper focus. This helps me to learn things more intensively that Im interested in (like the rocket example in the video) and having to think about multiple things at once can help creativity and the process of getting ideas for different projects. Its just really exhausting and its nice to be able to shut it down every now and then with meds if its not needed for a few hours

Hey! Glad you shared your story! I thought I'd share my experiences since from the meds u mentioned we had similar reactions. I was diagnosed @ 8 yrs old and I immediately started Vyvance I had a similar reaction with nausea, but I also developed insomnia and lost my appetite tremendously, this led to my ghd diagnoses (growth hormone deficiency). So naturally I stopped and started adderall turns out adderall works best for ADD people not ADHD (yes there's a difference karens). So again I stopped that was when I found out about ritilan, its in the same family as vyvance just not as strong (that can be changed with a side medication {i take guanfacine}). Ritilan was extremely helpful and since it can also make you lose your appetite I don't take it on weekends and instead just take Guanfacine. This is MY experience though so I cant speak for you, but I HIGHLY recommend researching about the types of meds you might be interested in. Have fun exploring soldier o/

As I write this I‚Äôm in my daily ‚Äúslump‚Äù phase of vyvanse where I have had the first 3-4 hours of productivity and excitement to work on my ONE thing (usually whatever I started doing when it took effect: job searching, personal projects, studying, etc) and, while it hasn‚Äôt worn off yet, the burnout towards the task I was focused on all hits at once. I've got diagnosed with ADHD just something small of a year ago, and after trying a lot of methods with my psychiatrist and therapist, we decided to try out meds. So i started taking them, and my Grades have never been better. I was one of the worst students for years, i only ever had Ds and under, and getting a C made me more than happy. But it also hurt, because a lot of adults told me that i was really intelligent, and that they couldn't understand how i'd get such low Grades, so i should just try harder. When i turned old enough to (in my country) make my own medical appointments, i did, literally the week before my birthday i called  many medical professionals and asked for an appointment the following week. And i can tell you, that i am now an all As and Bs Student,  but the meds don't make me smarter, and i still take longer to process and understand many things than others do, but after 11 years in school and feeling like i was trying to fight for my life, i would never let this opertunity go to waste. My best comparison to meds would be shoes. It is more comfortable and easier to walk with shoes, but the shoes don't walk for you, and different people need different shoes that fit them and have different functions. Of course there are people who don't wear shoes, other people say shoes are comfy, and others need speciall orthopedic shoes. But no less, you need to move your legs yourself, and while teaching how to walk slowly to yourself, whilst simutaniously going through the pain of going over gravel without shoes, can of course be made easier through sole sollst, but  you still might just need to start heaving to learn how to walk only just now, after everyone has learned it decades ago. Sometimes we need to walk, jump or run, but we'll always have to learn at our own pace, one step after the other.  Edit: edited out a part about my medication. some replies may not make sense now. But basically: i take an amphetamin that would show positiv in a drug test for things like meth and speed. And yes i have to cary a permit for it, especially when driving.

bruh I literally cant stop staring at polish cow
I've been living with Aspergers Syndrome my whole life; think of it as "Autism (Now with OCD and ADHD)!" See, I started on Concerta back in Middle School, and eventually it just wasn't helping or something. I dunno why, but regardless I ended up on Strattera for a bit after I got a new Psychiatrist and that made me feel like shit. Asked them to take me off it, they instead raised the dose, and by that point my mom and I decided this psychiatrist is a quack and looked for new meds. Eventually, I began taking 10mg of Adderall XR a day, which takes similar time to kick in as you described Vyvanse to take. It worked for a while, but by High School I had to have the dose gradually raised to 20mg a day, and this is where the out of breath feeling came in...  ICS, you were getting sudden panic attacks from your body realizing it was so focused on what you were doing (my case was OCD combining with stress-induced perfectionism) that you forgot to FUCKING BREATH. That's what that out-of-breath feeling is, except in my case it made my face really numb, signaling me when it was happening and making me freak out. Whenever this occurred, I was effectively out of commission for literally the entire day. Every time I tried my hardest to focus, I'd basically start suffocating myself until I just had to give up and do unimportant, idle activities once I got home, like video games and web-browsing (and sometimes it'd still get me, though I could be wrong). Eventually insomnia started to occur, causing me to finally start taking Seroquel in my Senior year. I deferred graduation afterwards due to changing classes at a career-tech school I open-enrolled to, and the suddenly sour and mean mood that anti-anxiety sleeping aid caused resulted in me adding Lexapro (a fully-fledged anti-anxiety med) to the mix to keep everything balanced out.  At another psychiatrist's request, I tried lowering how much Seroquel I took due to its risk of nastier side effects, but the inconsistencies between how various psychiatrists handled the med made me just say screw it after I started taking too little of the sleeping aid and eventually got myself leveled out to where I am.

I miss my meds so much, but I stopped being able to turn the feeling into productivity and instead I would just panic

It's been working beautifully for me for ~8 years

When I was younger I was told I had "ADD" back when that description wasn't deprecated yet, later they told me I have some mild ADHD, certainly not bad enough to become debilitating from my day to day life so perhaps this won't help with someone that has a worse case of ADHD but my psychologist subtly suggested I try a small list of Nootropics instead of the typical long list of synthesized amphetamine/methamphetamine prescriptions.   Before we get into the Nootropics, first let's not get confused with what Adderall is. People like to closely relate it to "Meth" which is just about what anyone does with a lazy narrow conception on simple grade 8-10 chemistry. Adderall is of the class Amphetamine, it is not "Meth" which would be under the Methamphetamine class. People simply look at that and go "Yup, "Meth, and they both got 'amphetamine' so they must be the same!"   The truth to it is that Methamphetamine and Amphetamines are cousins, but more like 4th cousins twice removed, the difference in the two is the added molecular group of N-Methyl-2-pyrrolidone.   The two are considered same or similar because they  both derive from the same amine, but the addition of N-Methyl-2-pyrrolidone onto methamphetamine makes it completely unique in physiology. To compare the two are like comparing Banana's to Plantains, they are of the same genus, but not the same at all and individually are unique, just as Methamphetamines and Amphetamine are of the same Amine (think of it as a genus) but are completely different on a more recursive level and interact with our chemical physiology in incredibly unique ways from each other.   So fear not, you're not taking Meth, and shouldn't really be compared to it, as doing so is creating a laymen's for something that really shouldn't be laymened as it causes widespread misinformation.   Now, as for the Nootropics, I've been taking Adrafinil, noopept, Coluracetam, Pramiracetam, CDP Choline and Alpha GPC Choline complex since I was 16, I'm 23 now and I've only ever had improvements from it. One side effect from them is Headaches which makes sense, they are gonna utilize a lot of cellular energy so making sure to stay properly hydrated is best; but that's also what the Choline complex is for, it helps the cells retain proper electrolytes and assist in the protection of cellular membranes in the brain and assist in the prevention of cognitive decline.  That's my list, Feel free to do as much citation and academic research that's necessary, I'm sure you'll quickly see in how many regards these nootropics are used by society, mainly athletes, elderly and people with cognitive disorders.  In the long run they are cheaper and much more consumer available as they aren't prescription based products, they are classed as Nootropics.
ƒê R √ú G ≈†
Everyone interested in ADHD medication should look up the in progress research about the long term effects of it (almost all mental health drugs are still being assessed for how they affect us). ADHD involves hormones and when using meds, it can be harmful to your heart and other health issues. Adderall is a stimulant and has been found to long term increase risks in certain things. The same goes with hormones for HRT, it can greatly increase the risk of diabetes and heart problems because our bodies are a delicate interconnected ecosystem. I might have to get my uterus out at an early age (cancer risk) and they want to avoid it as much as possible because of the health risks associated with HRT (if I didn't take HRT after my uterus was removed I could have even worse symptoms, like bone fragility and more heart disease). I have mild combine ADHD and cannot take medication because I take daily asprin for my Lynch Syndrome, it would increase my risk of heart and bleeding problems way too much. As dumb as a it sounds, bilateral exercise truly helps manage SOME of the symptoms of ADHD. Depression and anxiety are closely related to ADHD and can make ADHD worse so by having a healthy routine of exercise and feeding yourself nourishing food (I know how hard it sounds, it is hard) you'll feel much better. Not cured! I still have bad days and panic attacks, but my daily struggles to transit to work and speak during meetings have greatly reduced after I started training for my first 10k race, taking up dancing and rock climbing again. ALL THAT SAID it's your choice to take the medicine, just be aware of how you can support your body when you are putting it in a vulnerable condition. Some people can't function with meds and that's totally understandable.

I have bipolar disorder, so my psychiatrist is super against putting me on a stimulant. She put me on Strattera, which worked great though my executive functioning was still shit. At least I could focus and sometimes hyper focus. But then it just stopped working at one point, and because of a throat disease I developed (dairy allergy), she hasn't wanted to try me on Qelbree for fear that another pill could worsen my symptoms or whatever. And oh boy, when I was studying for my last two finals, it really hit me how much I was struggling to pay attention and how exhausted my mind became by fighting for attention that just wasn't there. The only reason I have even survived two terms without ADHD meds is because I'm so far in physical therapy school that much of what's in the didactic part of our courses is review now and same with our lab portions (it's just really all about putting everything together at this point). But I hardly touch the lecture videos because I can't pay attention, and what has helped is finding Quizlets for this material. Otherwise, if I were at the beginning of my program, I think I would have failed out.

I think you might have been a bit overmedicated on the vyvanse. When I was taking 70 mg while doing online school, I was laser focused on on my school work, but when I was done, I was shaking *_REALLY BADLY_* and was just so bored. I had finished the task, and since I was laser focused on it my brain didn't want to focus on anything else. Ive moved down to 60, and the problem is still there, but it's mild enough to where I can just, force myself to do it. If you find the right dosage, the laser focus of Vyvanse can be a huge tool, rather than a burden. Though it's not for everyone. A lot of people hate ADHD meds, and I see why, but IMO the benefits outweigh the side effects. I've been medicated since I got diagnosed, and I hated it at first, but it's been so many years (about 9-10 years) that I can say with confidence, that once you get used to it, the medicine helps a lot. Again though, it's not for everyone.

As someone with ADHD, seeing videos like this are intensely frustrating. Meds or not, you are being irresponsible and seem unwilling to put any work in to improve your condition. You talk about being constantly distracted by different devices. This is not a symptom of ADHD. That‚Äôs just you being addicted to screens. Problem is that these activities which are easy distractions also sap all your dopamine, which as someone with ADHD, you already have very little of. If you want to be able to focus, you need to fix your addiction to going on your phone, checking social media, watching videos about stuff all the time, etc. You‚Äôre simply not going to be able to focus as someone with ADHD if you don‚Äôt address that problem.  Personally for me, this was a really difficult step, but this - along with getting into the habit of doing things that require focus and don‚Äôt sap any dopamine every day - have done more for me and my ADHD than anything else. Obviously it won‚Äôt make you‚Äôre ADHD go away. But ADHD is not naturally as debilitating as you‚Äôre making it for yourself.  Read a book. Meditate every day. Stop going on your phone.

I don‚Äôt remember what they were particularly but being without them for over a day started to make me feel just absolutely horrible. I had this weird stomach pain like someone was squishing their hand around in my guts, I couldn‚Äôt sleep, couldn‚Äôt and wouldn‚Äôt eat, throwing up, sweating, all while we were in California during the summer at Disney land with extended family. Little to say I ended up being told I was being dramatic and I sucked it up until we got back. My doctor was very unhappy
My experience - maybe some if it will help: (using ADD and ADHD interchangeability because apparently the hyperactivity dissappear in adults, so the modern idea is that they are basically the same)  I was on Ritallin when I was in middle school, and I had the same feeling of 'if I'm going to be distracted, now I'm distracted harder, didn't know if it was helping or not - however, ADD pills come in a few forms - primarily Stimulents and non-stimulents (also a lot of these are mixed with anti-depressents, more on this later)  However, I was also getting some weird tics - apparently the stimulent pills can bring out hidden/suppressed turettes in its users. My brother stopped, I stayed on, and now I have minor but permanent vocal tics (though they also used to come in the form of eye rolling, smirking and a few other things im forgetting) and he does not. I dropped the pills until after college, and I tried Stratera, a non-stimulent. So I took it in the morning, and I never felt worse in my life. It felt like I was swimming in my chair. I never used them again. Well, I still had problems at work, so many years later I paid boatloads of money to an expensive psychiatrists, and he put me on something that didn't really work. Now i'm on Sertralin -  which is also anti-depressant. Despite my objections, that my worries and frustrations were due to my poor performance from my add instead of from depression, alparently a lot of psyciatrists won't perscribe ADD medication that don't have some form of anti-depression drug in then as well because '90% of people with ADD also have depression' or it's tied in some fashion - however, that also is part of the reason why when some of us get on these pills that they can really really mess us uo. I don't even know if my Sirtralin  works or not. It was messing me up pretty bad- it wasn't until I met with my general practitioner doctor that they explained that I should probably take it at night, not in the morning. (The general idea is that you just need to take it at the same time every day, but it wasn't until my doctor said that it likely causes drowsiness, so it's best to take it at night. I think that may be helping. However, I'm also taking Modafinil - which apparently has a side-effect that may help people with ADD, is NOT also an anti-depressant, and has far fewer negative side effects than the other stuff I've been on. The one thing is that it's a prescription drug, and insurance doesn't cover it, so if you were to go to the counter and try and get some, it's 400+ dollars - that's why I use the goodrx website to get it for a far more affordable 8 dollars.   It's a challenge. And sifting good information from bad is a long hard process. I don't think what I'm on will be forever, I think I might drop the  Sirtralin and stay on the modafinil, but we will see what the future holds. (Note Modafinil is often taken by college students to help them study for tests - it's not it's intended use, but that's why it's prescription, apparently) Good luck in your journey.

I gotta say ive lived my whole like 31 years with a really hard case of ADHD. I think medications are really useful to teach you what the difference is between focused and constantly distracted. Here is my experience with my meds:  I was diagnosed with ADHD as an adult. All of the signs were there throughout my childhood, but my parents and I missed it at every turn. When I was in Middle School, my grades were horrible. I would just not do homework sometimes. If I didn't fully finish it, I didn't even want to turn it in for a partial. I felt like a failure a lot of the time. My parents and I both assumed my grades had become worse due to the loss of both of my(very close) grandparents within the same year, but it seems like that was wrong. It's more likely that the stress just made the symptoms more prevalent.  Even in elementary school, I would often forget to turn in assignments or forget to do them. I had difficulty focusing in class or while reading. I excelled at things that were tactile or gave me a dopamine rush like sports or challenges, while homework and other things where I didn't get more instant gratification always fell away from my focus.  In high school, we still didn't notice or change anything. I was getting bad grades, retaking classes, etc. Not because I wasn't smart, but because I couldn't focus or had no drive to try.  In college, I took a summer bridge course and one of the subjects we covered during that time was learning how to learn. It suddenly clicked while we were discussing this that I learned extremely well using tactile learning. Whenever I performed my best in high school, I was taking notes by hand or really interested in the subject because it was something where I didn't just have to sit and listen to a lecture or read a book. In college, I started doing much better. Luckily, I had taken on a major that had a lot of tactile learning, which was programming. Project based assignments made my life so much easier. I had a clear and defined goal. I was able to see the results of what I was doing right away, which gave me a dopamine rush that I needed to keep my brain interested.  Post-college I am a parent and working as a software engineer. During Covid, I felt an intense brain fog that I couldn't get out of. I'm not sure if it was due to the lack of interactions with others or what exactly caused it. As far as I know, I never had covid or any covid-like symptoms.   That's when I talked to my doctor. They asked more about my history and current issues with focus. After which, they had diagnosed me with ADHD. I did a lot of research and looked at what others had experienced with ADHD and matched a lot with my experiences in the past.  Then I was prescribed a drug called Adzenys XR-ODT, which is an extended release orally dissolving tablet. It makes me super awake within 5 minutes of taking it and gives me extremely good focus during work hours. I started at a lower dosage of about 9 mg(IIRC) and now I'm on 12 mg.  Things I've learned about how my body and mind interact with adzenys:   The lower dosage(9mg) made me feel focused. I never felt jittery(even with coffee) outside of the first couple days when my body was getting used to it. It makes me feel focused and energized. Each time I take it, it lasts around 12 hours. The energized feeling goes away and I'm still able to sleep.   Now, with the higher dosage(12mg) I've switched to within recent months, the drop off of energy is much more noticeable. I'll be good for 12 hours energy-wise, then fine for a couple more hours. Then, it just hits a huge plateau for a couple hours where I'll be exhausted and close to sleep, which sucks because that's usually around when I'm getting the kids to sleep. Another thing about the higher dosage is that I can really just take one every 2 days because my focus on the second day is still there(and there is no drop off of energy like the first day).   Here is what my day looks like when I take it:   First Day(taking meds @ 12mg) 7am take meds -> 8 or 9am work -> 7pm starts to wear off -> 8pm exhausted -> 9 or 10pm I'm no longer exhausted, but am still able to sleep -> 10 or 11pm Sleep  Second Day(not taking meds) 7am-ish wake up(energy is better than normal non-medication days) -> 8 or 9am work(with same focus and intensity) -> Rest of the day has no exhaustion or change in energy -> 10 or 11pm Sleep  For me, I don't feel like I over-focus on any one thing like he mentioned in the video with Vyvanse and it still allows me to fully focus unlike the Adderall mentioned in the video. Overall, this has been a great experience for me. I'm unsure if I'll ever try another type of ADHD medication, unless I'm forced to.   I use it only when necessary which for me is during work days. I take one early morning. You can take 2 a day, but I take one since it can become harder to sleep if you take one later and I've never needed to take more than 1 to get through the work day.  I take a break from it during the weekend or during vacations, unless I really need to think or focus during that time. The `take it when you need it` format suits me better than something I'd need to take every day.  Big No Nos when taking(for me):  - Don't take with coffee or other stimulants. It makes me super jittery, a little nauseous, and can sometimes cause anxiety or panic attacks(same difficulty breathing as mentioned in video). - Don't take it too late in the day. It's hard enough to sleep with ADHD, but this drug will make it harder. The good thing is that it wears off within 12 hours, so it's perfect for my work days. - Don't take it too early and don't use it as a crutch to wake up when you're tired. This drug is marked all over with the potential for addiction. I've definitely thought of using it this way, to just wake me up when I'm super tired, but building a dependency on that instead of getting good sleep is not a good idea. Focus on what helps you get good sleep, whether that be working out, melatonin, listening to music, etc. Whatever helps you get good sleep.  This one works for me and avoids some of the pitfalls I've heard about others.  Always talk to your doctor. Find a good medication and dosage for you that works with your body and mind. This is not a recommendation to take this drug, this is my experience with it and my experience with ADHD.  If you think you have ADHD, don't be afraid to bring it up with your doctor, your parents, or anyone else in your life. For me, being medicated has made my life so much easier. I only wish I had known earlier about myself, my learning style, and potentially had medication to treat my ADHD.
I feel like there's a misconception that ADHD medication is a cure all but after taking them for a while i've realized they are just a tool that calms your brain enough, so that you can learn time management for yourself. The medication doesn't magically make time management happen it just gives you some room in the brain to learn it.

TLDR; Elementary teacher gets mad when the meds she made my parents give me has adverse affects and are told to stop taking them, so punishes me by not helping me in class anymore...  What happend to him at the last part of the video happened to me when i was in 3rd grade when my math teacher forced my grandmother to get me on riddlen (cant spell it) cause she was so angry id never focus in math (but strangely i focused in all my other subjects)   so i took it and immediately i was finishing time table sheet of 30 questions before the whole class, hyper focused on my work but when i got home with NO tasks to do my body felt weird.....   id lay on my bed exhausted but not being able to sleep. Id hyper focus on the textures of my ceiling and felt my blood pull through my veins and hear the air push and pull out my lungs as i breathed...   i was only on this medication for 3 days but one day my gradmother came in cause she realized i wasnt being my normal happy, playing with dolls, and following her around self .   She opened my door and asked " are you alright?" And with that out of breath feeling and hyperfocused feeling pulsing over my body i simply replied "Momo.... I feel weird. Am I gonna die?".   My grandmother was horrified and said "Hell no we are getting you off those pills NOW". I completely understand now that a child has no business saying such morbid things after being on a pill, and maybe i lowkey scared her with how dead pan i spoke it to her.   Needless to say my teacher didnt give a fuck and tried to convence my grandmother to keep me on it despite the affects beacuse " we're making so much progress now." My teacher resented me shortly after and accused me of faking and "trying to get her in trouble" so now shes not "helping me anymore."   She literally helped the whole class and told me to "figure it out" all cause i wasnt doped up how she wanted anymore. Im 26 now still have ADHD but man that was a dark memory for me....
I'm currently in my car, outside of the place I voulenteer at weekly, watching this vid.   :D
.
I take Straterra and Concerta. This video is very relatable. Apparently ADHD medication is like a stream of dopamine. If you stop taking it altogether, your body experiences withdrawal symptoms. The higher your regular dosage, the stronger the withdrawal. My doctor recommended I take breaks from Concerta, but that I never stop taking Straterra. It's worth noting that the meds are appetite suppressant, meaning I frequently skip meals simply because I don't realize how hungry my body is. However, I found that if I am streaming my activities to friends, I am 9x more productive‚Äì but if my parents are watching what I'm doing, I'm 91% less productive.
Sometimes this month I'm being prescribed ADHD meds because it's severe enough I'm struggling with important tasks like you but on top of that I'm also being sent to a life skills coach for what I assume is that very reason you didn't like using Adderall & probably the over focus problem you had with the other med. So because of the meds the number of people I need to see went up from 1 to 3. Those being Therapist, Psyche, & Life Skills coach from just Therapist. But yeah Imagine they're going to help me be productive when I have my ADHD under control.
