I don‚Äôt know if this will help, but it may. I don‚Äôt have adhd, but I do have cPTSD which can give you very similar symptoms bc one‚Äôs autonomic nervous system, specifically the dorsal vagus nerve & certain areas of the brain that are sort of wired wrong.   I‚Äôm I retired research scientist (genetics) btw. On YouTube, look up ‚ÄúWim Hof Vice documentary.‚Äù It‚Äôs a few years old, but it‚Äôs the quickest way to understand.   He has a channel as well. The method is free. It is a 3 part method.. mainly two parts to begin with.  To add weight to his claims (although there already was & is from many many people), two medical scientists won the mi el prize last year for proving Wim‚Äôs  method actually works.  Best of luck to you.
I didn‚Äôt get officially diagnosed with ADD until I was 21 years old, and it was starting to take an effect on my mental health. It took 3 WHOLE ASS YEARS for me to FINALLY GET SOME HELP in the us school system.
I've been diagnosed with ADHD since the age of 4. And I've been taking various medications since then. Now I'm an adult and I take a daily dose of 108mg of Concerta. It's the maximum dose my doctor can prescribe and I've been taking it for probably at least 10 years.  Back when I was in college, one day I forgot to take my meds. I know I forgot because my brain starts feeling weird when it doesn't has its daily dose. I was already in the bus so it was too late to go back home to take it. And I had a very important math exam in the morning. I was panicking.  During the exam, I read a question, but only my eyes are reading. My brain is not working. So I read the question again. And again. And again. Until I finally answer it. Then the same thing happens with the next question and all the others. In the end, I was exhausted. That exam had totally worn me out. And the other classes I had in that day were all theory classes where you just sit down and listen to the teacher talking for hours. Even when I take my meds, I have trouble listening to the teacher for more than 30 seconds. Without the meds, my attention span drops down to 5 seconds. So I knew that it did not matter if I attended those classes at all, since I would retain as much information as if I did not attend.  So I went back home. My meds have the side effect of preventing me from sleeping. And since they are effective for 12 hours, taking them past a certain time would mean I won't fall asleep until very late and will wake up the next day very tired. So I didn't take them when I arrived home at lunchtime.  Since I had the whole afternoon free, I figured I could game a bit. So I take my laptop and press the power button. While it's booting up, I turn on the tv. I bring up the tv guide and realise that Mythbusters is coming up in 15 minutes. I tell myself I'll just wait for the current show to finish and then I'll watch Mysthbusters. But the thing when I don't take my meds is that my brain wastes way too much energy on trying to focus. It burns energy to attempt at focusing, but since it's incapable of focusing, all that energy is burnt for nothing. So I get tired really quick. And as a matter of fact, I fell asleep on the couch before Mythbusters started.  When I wake up, it's almost 5pm. I wasted my whole afternoon just sleeping. I missed the show I wanted to watch. I turned my laptop on for nothing. And I'm really hungry because my brain already burned all the food I had eaten up in the day. The only productive thing I did in that day was my exam. For which I got 95%. Or A+. Or whatever. I've no idea how my brain managed to ace an exam while it had no clue what it was doing.  So for me, the meds are essential. I couldn't do my job without them. I literally can't sit down in front of my computer for more than 10 seconds if I don't take them. Though I do think they had some bad effects on my body. It increases my heart beat, so I can't drink coffee otherwise my heart will want to explode. I was diagnosed with Benign Fasciculation Syndrome, which causes my muscles all over my body to randomly twitch for no reason. I suspect it's because of the meds, allthough there are no studies that proved that.   Finally, I think it's a personal choice to take meds or not. For me, I couldn't function without them. But everyone's different. I'll always applaud people who can do without them. I'll also applaud people who realised they needed them and took them with the advice of their doctors. Too many people decide to medicate on their own and end up in a worst position than where they started.

As a "recovered" medicated adhd guy I can say that probably half of your symptoms can be managed by hard work, and the other half are basically super powers. I know it seems difficult to tackle but I promise you, with practice you can manage a huge chunk of your own symptoms. I'm not saying everyone should go off meds, my case is probably pretty mild, but don't fall into the habit of relying on medications as a replacement for personal growth.
What my doctor told me when I got back on adhd meds is that I had to also put some work into helping the meds work otherwise it wouldn‚Äôt do much of anything. Things like making a general schedule for the start and end of each day so I have some semblance of structure really went a long way. The meds won‚Äôt do all the work for you it‚Äôs not an end all be all it‚Äôs more like a helping hand. But that‚Äôs just my experience

ADHD is really different for everyone. For me personally, I got lucky that my doctor prescribed Vyvanse first and I've never felt the need to change. It's not the cure to my ADHD it's just a tool that helps. And it helps A LOT especially because with being unfocused I also have really bad executive dysfunction (so before staring meds even STARTING tasks was DEBILITATINGLY hard). For people who may be concerned about the high heart rate, drinking water is CRUCIAL. Dehydration already makes you have a higher HR so I've found that drinking tons of water throughout the day keeps my heart rate normal. I also take an iron pill that has no issues on Vyvanse and I'm a pretty active person. If Vyvanse isn't for you tho, we live in a time where there are so many medications available and you can always talk with your doctor about what is and isn't working for you!

My fianc√© has ADHD. He was on so much medication for it that it messed with his body in a very negative way. But because he‚Äôs been off meds for a couple of years, he‚Äôs been doing a lot better. I can tell when he has ADHD moments, but it doesn‚Äôt happen often or difficult to deal with for him. I‚Äôm not against medication, but sometimes you don‚Äôt need it, especially if it causes more harm than good.
A few tips I got from my mom (she's a therapist that started specializing in ADHD when I got diagnosed): - meds won't help you without therapy (to learn how to use them effectively but also adress any other problems) - ALWAYS eat a meal (at best a fatty meal) directly before you take your meds! - ADDers* often need higher doses or very low doses - women with ADD often need VERY low doses - AFTER CONSULTING WITH YOUR DOCTOR you can lower your dose lower than the doses available (if the meds are capsules containing powder) by diluting the powder in water in a measuring cup or syringe and only taking a portion.  *I mean ADHD of the inattentive Type when I write ADD.  Edit: Before, I didn't explain that I meant the inattentive subtype and that you should talk to your doctor before changing your dose. Thanks for the remarks!
This is why medication management + counseling is important (good medication management).  Meds don't help fill the skill deficit. They are supposed to normalize the abnormal brain activity (Mainly in the frontal lobe).  People with ADHD use alternative strategies to best manage their  distractability and hyperactivity.  These don't necessarily translate into good skills for more normalized and stable behavior.  Then there's the problem finding a good counselor (Which very few people understand) and is often treated the same as finding a good doctor.

So I‚Äôve been on and off Focalin for nearly my entire life. It has its pros and its cons. Pros being you‚Äôre a lot more in control. It also only lasts for about three hours for a 10 mg pill. And it gives you that sort of hyper focus, but similar to Vyvanse where you have to be doing what you need to do as it kicks in or else you‚Äôre just gonna be distracted on something else. However, taking it nearly my entire life, I know how long it takes to kick in (40 minutes on an empty stomach). Now cons: it SKYROCKETS my anxiety. So I only take it as needed. My psychiatrist recommended get off caffeine if you‚Äôre going to have a day where you need to take the meds. So that‚Äôs what I‚Äôve been doing. I should also point out, and this could be the case for nearly every medication, but sometimes they‚Äôre duds. Meaning it won‚Äôt do anything. And I‚Äôm hesitant to take another within that three hour timeframe because what if it hasn‚Äôt kicked in yet and I‚Äôve got two in my system and my anxiety is through the roof. Other than that, great video!
I have been taking concerta for about 6 years now and I can absolutely say that it makes a difference. I have ADHD (without the hiperactivity but idk the name in english) and I always struggle in class and exams. My parents when they first heared about medicatios for this they first rejected the idea but after my psicologist and doctor insisted they agreed and the results were fantastic, but one thing you need to have clear is that the medication DOESN'T do the work for you, it's just a tool to help you, same as my therapy and school adaptations. The only problem my meds have is that i don't want to eat (which is a big problem), is like my instinct of eating just disappeared, and i always eat a lot even if im not hungry. Well idk if this helps someone or not, but feel free to ask me any questions you have about ADHD (which is not only hiperactivity or having a hard time to focus), I'll try my best to answer and sorry if this was too long haha  Edit: It was nice to see how many people liked this  comment and I'm glad that i could help in the comments, even if it was just a little. I also want to say that if you or someone you know is having a bad time, please, try to get help or talk about your problems/worries, Adhd as i said, is not only hiperactivity or the lack of concentration, it can lead to anxiety, depression, problems with drugs and many other bad things. ADHD, autism or other neurodivergents are not "mentally ill" or sick, they are PEOPLE which happen to function different as non-divergent people do, yes we kind of have our "superpowers" with hyperfocus or many other "skills" that "regular" people lack off but If I had the choice, I wouldn't want to have ADHD and feeling everyday that something is off with me or that im  dumb or not enough. You are enough, having ADHD or not and we need to start treating humans as humans.  I hope this also helps and if not sorry if it was too long üòÖ
Headfirst parents  https://youtu.be/TfpZGlosp1E
I have a love-hate relationship to my meds. Mostly because I have a lot of side-effects, but at the same time I can't really work effectively without them. So I'm constantly trying to find a balance between not getting anything done and having a dry mouth, elevated blood pressure and little to no appetite. The side-effects were even worse with Adderall so I switched to Yvanse.  A great tip I got was to lower my dose on low-stakes days.  Eg I might take 20 mg on a high-pressure day and 15 mg on the others. I split the doses by opening the capsule, diluting the powder in water and only drinking 150 of 200 ml.  Also, I noticed that I feel very depressed on the first day of taking my meds after I've gone without them for a few days, so my psych prescribed me a few pills of instantly releasing Adderall I can take on days I forget to take my Yvanse in the morning.
I've been diagnosed with ADD since the third grade (I'm turning 30 this year) and I swear by Vyvanse, but I know it doesn't help everybody. Adderall was the first medication I took and it completely altered my personality and destroyed my appetite throughout the other half of elementary school and middle school. You might want to try Strattera, it's a lot less dangerous and less expensive since it's a non-stimulant. You have to take it longer to feel the full effects but my friend with ADHD took it and loves it. Hope this helps!

My experience with ADD-- sorry, ADHD meds (I was diagnosed way before the two were merged) was with Straterra. It helped, but too much. I have both ADHD and autism and I can say that I‚Äôve had a similar experience with medication. I started taking medication to help with my focus back in 3rd grade. At that point, my parents thought I only had ADHD. This medication was helping me, and I started doing really well in school, but I needed more. Much later, I got tested for autism, and I was diagnosed. I‚Äôve changed medications a few times in the past, and they‚Äôve had different side effects. Some made me focus but not enough, some made me exhausted at the end of the day, and some gave me headaches. I did find one that works for me, and I‚Äôm still taking it to this day. I still struggle with it, and I can‚Äôt seem to focus on the right things, but I know that‚Äôs something a medication can‚Äôt fix and I need to work on that on my own.

I struggled with ADHD for the longest time in middle school. I tried medication too, but nothing worked. My mom did some research and it led to a diet change. We cut out gluten, artificial stuff and  preservatives, and as much dairy as we could. Studies shown red 40 dye is also a huge ADHD trigger, which is random but very very true for me xD It helped tons with my hyperactivity, as well as improved my focus. It's not a 100% fix, I still get flares and some days are worse than others, but its far more manageable for myself. If I were to take medication it might be that extra bit to further reduce the symptoms, but me and meds have a history lol. I always recommend this kinda diet to people who express struggle with depression, anxiety, and/ or ADHD, especially since overall it's just healthier in general
Adhd is not a disease or not necessarily a disorder even though it is in its name. It's simply a different kind of brain. It's something quite common and could be very good. It's society that doesn't fit with this way of thinking. So the best and necessary thing to do is actually understand yourself, your needs and learn how to control your brain and use it in a good way. Of course things like studying could be very hard but people with Adhd have many other abilities and perspectives. Medication is not something required and should be used when there are serious problems like neglecting oneself, in these occasions is probably not Adhd on its way. Love yourself amd understand and cherish your uniqueness, good luck with your "adhd" brain even though it' hard!

That tracks. The truth is that meds can't take the ADHD away. They are only a tool to help cope, and if you aren't better with them, it's not worth the risk.   Also be careful that fatigue symptom sounds like a heart issue. You should get that checked out because stimulants with a weak heart are really really bad.
My experience with ADHD has been a very long period of me just testing psychological methods to deal with the lack of focus since i was a kid, and eventually I simply had to realise that my focus just worked differently than the norm and instead adapted my work and mind to my focus. So instead of trying to hyperfocus on one single thing, I allow myself to have something else in the background going just to cancel out the noise in my head, and if i feel like i didn't catch the full meaning I simply have to resort to going through the material again. Eventually I just learned to reabsorb information when I needed it and ask people to reiterate when I didn't catch what they said, which has helped tremendously with just being able to function day to day.
This is me
What really buggs we are all the people that self diagnose because they have similar character traits. ADHD IS NOT a character trait. Its a chemical unbalance in the brain (ADHD brains have low levels of a neurotransmitter called norepinephrine.). In fact you CAN have all these character traits but not because you have that unbalance, but because its part of your character which you gained in many other ways. Hyperactivity is not the disease ADHD itself, it is just a possible symptom. Just like moles can be a symptom of skin cancer, but that doesnt mean it IS. It could just be part of you, which you gained in another way.

Number 15: Burger king foot lettuce. The last thing you‚Äôd want in your Burger King burger is someone‚Äôs foot fungus. But as it turns out, that might be what you get. A 4channer uploaded a photo anonymously to the site showcasing his feet in a plastic bin of lettuce. With the statement: ‚ÄúThis is the lettuce you eat at Burger King.‚Äù Admittedly, he had shoes on. But that‚Äôs even worse. The post went live at 11:38 PM on July 16, and a mere 20 minutes later, the Burger King in question was alerted to the rogue employee. At least, I hope he‚Äôs rogue. How did it happen? Well, the BK employee hadn‚Äôt removed the Exif data from the uploaded photo, which suggested the culprit was somewhere in Mayfield Heights, Ohio. This was at 11:47. Three minutes later at 11:50, the Burger King branch address was posted with wishes of happy unemployment. 5 minutes later, the news station was contacted by another 4channer. And three minutes later, at 11:58, a link was posted: BK‚Äôs ‚ÄúTell us about us‚Äù online forum. The foot photo, otherwise known as exhibit A, was attached. Cleveland Scene Magazine contacted the BK in question the next day. When questioned, the breakfast shift manager said ‚ÄúOh, I know who that is. He‚Äôs getting fired.‚Äù Mystery solved, by 4chan. Now we can all go back to eating our fast food in peace.

Instead of meds, I took about 3 or 4 years of therapy when I was in early primary school. From those days onward I have only failed 3 school related things in over 10 years. I still get distracted sometimes, but I've found that if all audio is absent or I'm listening to non-lyrical music when doing a task, I seem to focus way better.  There was a brief period before this were I was using meds, but as a result I was unable to sleep most nights, constantly feeling like I was drifting around in the ocean, I didn't take them anymore and instead got therapy, which worked rather well.

Im on concerta.. 18mg, for me  it makes me focus, and productive, but i fkcus on something else, then i get addicted to that one thing, then i get like, severly depressed... then i stopped taking them, got more depressed, started again, get less despressed... then it went downhill from there.. mpre depression and the thought of wanting to overdose because i think thatd help me get rid of adhd..
Medikinet works for me. A relatively small dose. Especially now that I've been on it for a good while I notice it doesn't really change that much. I still procrastinate and feel physical pain trying to focus on uninteresting things, it's just less intense. More manageable.  People like us just need to develop our mental fortitude and focusing skills, find methods that work yanno. I always work better if I have both an active and a passive thing to do. Such as listening to music (passive) while writing an essay (active), or scribbling (active) while listening to a professor (passive). Discovering stuff like that about ourselves and finding ways to use it to our advantage is how we can get away from the destiny of a confused blob.  Mental and physical health are also a big part of it. Meds will never solve all of your problems nor are they supposed to, they just give you a bit more boost to be able to work on yourself.
I have ADHD and had Concerta for at least 9 years. That shit is strong. I remember taking 1 hour to finish all the homework for the day that my classmates had to take from 2 to 4 hours. I never got lost in thoughts, seemed like I was a statue whenever I was not doing homework and the teachers told my parents that I always new what the lesson was about even if it seemed I was not paying attention. It was helpful in that. However it had major secondary effects. I almost did not eat, as I did not feel hungry; I did not find the need to talk about my problems or how was I coping with school and high school (I was being bullied, but never told anyone until I stopped using the medication because I didn't feel the need to) and whenever I forgot to take the pill on the morning (meaning I would have to wait till the next day because if I had it in the afternoon it will take away hours of my sleep), I would feel useless for the whole day, because I was incapable of doing the simplest tasks from the school. My mum always tried to make me stop taking the meds after I reached High School, because she was concerned by my "zombie" behaviour. I finally stopped taking them at the age of 15, as my mum convinced me that I could be a working person without them. Turns out she was right. I have now finished my translation degree and have been specialising in teaching to one day be a teacher and be able to give parents advice with ADHD kids. What worked for me may not work for others, but to have an opinion of someone who has experienced the same challenges tends to help a lot, as well as telling them the "good" side of using meds and the "bad" side.
I tried a bunch of adhd meds as a kid, and none of them worked/had good effects. In the end, we found that caffeine worked well enough as a depressant. I still had to/have to work at it to stay focused, but the caffeine helps a lot. Been 18ish years, and it's still all I take

for me ive found that lifestyle changes really help with ADHD if you don't have access to meds. body doubling is my best tool, having someone to help you stay on top of your projects and tasks is a big help! also 123GO! great method, basically the second you think of doing a task just go "123GO" and get up to go do it before your brain can shut the idea down
So. I was diagnosed with ADHD at a very young age. Like. At around 4 or so. I first got Placebos. Didn't work. Then I had medication that I just took because my mom said so. Tho it made me sleepy, very boring and I didn't really have any feelings. Not positive and not negative. I took this until I was 17. Only after I told my them Girlfriend of 2 years about how i felt she said I should go tell my doctor. Well. He said that it isn't good that this happens and you should have told me earlier. I tried a bunch of other meds that all just had weird side effects that brought me down a lot (so far that I now have severe socal anxiety). Well. I am 19 now, moved out and am struggling with my socal anxiety without medication because nothing worked for me.  Personally I feel better than with medication. Yes I do struggle I life. Yes I do have a lot of problems. But instead of feeling ill or feeling nothing, I feel good things. I only really felt love after I dropped my medication. I only really felt sadness after i dropped my medication. And I also only felt real self preservation after I dropped my medication.  To everyone out there who struggles with ADHD. You will never be able to get rid if it completely. Yes medication can make it better but it can also make other things worse or dissappear.  Work on yourself before trying to take a pill. If it doesn't work. By all means take em with medical advice.

Ask your provider for guanfacine (or methlydopa, or clonidine) you may be experiencing hypertension with adhd meds as they are CNS stimulants.   Adhd meds don‚Äôt help much with your intention and thus behavior. It primarily helps you achieve whatever you were trying to do before taking your meds.

I currently use a math derivative thingy, basically aderal but cheap. It does exactly what you say it does; it helps you get your stuff done, but it completely clogs and syrupafies your brain into being unable to think or be creative. Honestly, my solution is to accept that. I can't be creative when the meds are working, so I'm not. I do productive 'tactile' tasks like cleaning and grocery shopping. Then they wear off in the afternoon (because I forgot to take my second dose as usual). After that, I switch to thinking tasks. However, focus does still remain an issue.

For you Americans. You need to be VERY careful around medication for mental issues, you overdiagnose the shit out if everything so be well aware that your diagnosing standards are ridiculously low and you give false diagnosis just as often as not, do not medicate if it feels like just a label.
So so far I've only taken Concerta. When I first started taking it in highschool it worked pretty great I felt focused and I got things done. The only side effect was I had 0 appetite and lost a lot of weight...but hey people gave me compliments so that wasn't too bad.  But then in college the Concerta stopped working, or maybe I just went through so many stressful things my first 2 years of college that it didn't matter what meds I was taking, it just didn't work.   I developed BED and gained a whole bunch of weight. Much more than I ever lost. And so now body was totally different and therefor I needed a different medicine dosage.  I tried a higher dosage and it definitely worked but like waaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaay too much. It was exactly like the rocket thing he described. I just got super into doing one thing all day long.  Rn I'm unmedicated and I'm doing ok. I get good grades in school so I'm chillin. However, I do feel like eventually I should try another medication because I still don't feel super productive. I do procrastinate still even if it's less than I used to. I do still get distracted. I do still have tasks that don't get completed like...my laundry's been dirty for a week. I'm wearing my last clear pair of clothes rn and I need to do my laundry tomorrow or else im going to be wearing gross dirty clothes.   ADHD is a pain in the butt. I also have high functioning ASD so that's reaaaaal fun. Cuz the parts of my brain sometimes fight with eachother. I am somehow an extremely impulsive and an extremely cautious person at the same time. I am somehow really energetic and also have 0 energy at the same time. I am somehow super socially anxious and easily overwhelmed by people while also being a person who rambles on and on and really enjoys talking and writing at the same time. I somehow find learning new things interesting while also just having one very specific interest and having no desire to pick up new talents at the same time. My brain is fuckin wack...

I have severe adhd and honestly I cant bother with meds. everyone is different but they often seem to cause as much trouble as they fix. especially when taken from scratch as an adult as we have somewhat adapted to life with adhd and thus medicine can quite often result in hyperfocus when taken even before we account for side effects.

The problem I had with taking ADHD meds. (specifically Vyvanse off my experience). Is that I felt lifeless to everyone else around me. I would never have a good conversation with anyone just a bunch of "ok" and "cool" single word quotes. When I did activities I wouldn't be enjoying it with others. just a hollow emotionless shell that's good at focusing on what to do. personally couldn't deal with the meds anymore because I was unable to talk to people casually and enjoy experiences with others. Meds are helpful, but they don't help everything so be mindful when you take them because I feel like it shouldn't be a daily medication.
Thought from someone who is not a medical professional but who does have ADHD and has done a lot of learning to try and manage it. Meds are great if you need a short-term crutch. However, to really make things work, you ALSO need some good tactics and habits that don't rely on the meds. One gets you functional, the other keeps you functional, and more often than not, you'll need a bit of both.

A note regarding medications: Generally, it's best to ask your doctor how safe it is to go off-med when you receive the medication. Not just because you might want to, but that classifies your urgency for whne you forget to fill it.  As someone with your issues, ICS, definitely explore more options with your psych! Adhd on meds here. While the meds are there to help resolve the underlying cause of symptoms, the meds will not magically resolve the YEARS of ingrained behaviors that we‚Äôve developed while trying to survive in the world.  Say I‚Äôm the captain of a giant powerful ship who struggles to get to where I‚Äôm going because of a faulty rudder. Because if this the ‚Äúusual‚Äù way of sailing a ship doesn‚Äôt work for me, so I learn my own creative way of steering while working with the faulty rudder. If after years of doing this I suddenly have the underlying issue fixed, it will be physically possible to sail like everyone else, but behaviorally I‚Äôm going to have to relearn how to sail the whole thing.  Ergo, meds will help fix the hydraulics issue that‚Äôs messing with the rudder and making it impossible to steer. But I still gotta learn how to sail.  In cases like this adhd meds are best paired with behavioral therapy / skills training to learn how to steer the ship now that it‚Äôs working.

you might be able to cope with a B12 vitamin for physical activity, and Ginseng or Ginkgo-tea for focal-activities: it may also be worth remembering the whole brain-mind isn't the problem, it's just that dopamine is used by every organ-tissue in the body and each system uses dopamine resources differently and independently; bodies steal dopamine from brains to reduce pain, maintain normalcy, ignore irritations, but brains need it for every modern mental process and discipline.

Your friends comments on Vyvanse vs Adderall aren't entirely accurate. Vyvanse is also an amphetamine, it's just attached to an amino acid so must be metabolized/digested in the gut before it's available, that's it's time release method. Adderall has half instant release and half coated to be released around 4 hours later.  Vyvanse also has more central nervous system affecting amphetamine vs Adderall having half CNS and half that affects the peripheral nervous system, so sometimes it can be less extreme like your experience with Vyvanse.  Then we get into the non stimulant class like Strattera and off label use Wellbutrin. Works for some people, just bad for others.
I took Concerta as a child and the severe side effects made me suicidally depressed, but I started it at such a young age that I didn't know that wasn't normal  So uh...be careful, but yknow if it works for you that's awesome I'm happy for you
I just straight up stopped taking my Vyvanse cause it destroyed my gut lol
I will say‚Ä¶ Medication, a metric piss-ton of caffeine, and a hyper focus is amazing as someone who welds and does woodwork.   (Sorry for the language, it‚Äôs a vocal sting because of my ADHD)
why is stopping taking the meds bad? I use concerta and my doc actually recommended that I always have days in the week where I don't take meds. So I always make sure to not take my meds when I don't have much to do that day.
hey kids, random pharmacy tech here to simply say: a lot of adhd meds (that are controlled meds) are amphetamines, which are stimulants. adderrall's generic is amphetamine-dextroamphetamine, vyvanse's generic is lisdexamfetamine, ritalin/concerta is methylphenidate, etc etc etc. there is a huge variety of ADHD meds and that's why you gotta try things out. it's an unfortunate side to taking meds. it's like trying on a sweater, except that sweater is directly responsible for your health and wellbeing. it can be vvv difficult to find something that works but your providers should always be doing their best to find the right fit for you, including therapies and other non-medication options. a combination of consistent, coexisting treatments can do wonders. meds aren't always a fix-all, but they can be a valuable support in your treatment.
I take Focalin
Dexamfetamine is my jam. Helps me with everything. Concerta is the long working version of that stuff. Love it   Don‚Äôt use it every day though. Only 3 out of 5 work days or so.

As someone who wasn't diagnosed until their early 20s, I'm very lucky that I had a psychiatrist that was willing to keep working with me until we found the right pill/dosage for me. Turns out 50mg a day of Adderall IR works best for me, though I went through 4 others and a slew of different doses on each before I got here. It can be a long and tough journey, but honestly finding the meds that work for me has been pretty damn life changing.  Just want to put this out there for any of you that may be feeling discouraged and feeling like ADHD meds aren't for you. There are so many options out there!  Oh and also, for me personally IR and XR versions of the same medication had completely different effects. So even more options for ya!  But of course please don't experiment on your own, only do this under the guidance of a medical professional (which I am not, just a fellow adhd-er)

All the medications are just so finicky. Vyvanse is especially bad because it‚Äôll keep you up, and that vicious cycle you went into is all too relatable. Sounds like you probably got hit by the snowballing appetite suppression, dehydration, lack of sleep, plus amphetamine stimulation that hits so hard. I bet if you took a minute to get a good nights sleep, solid meal, and drank water, you‚Äôd see the difference and see how quickly it can spiral if you don‚Äôt take care of all that.  Despite your warning, for such a dangerous stimulant drug class, ABSOLUTELY stop taking it if you ever at any point feel that way, especially with heart problems. You can literally die just by doing normal things while on it if you don‚Äôt know what you‚Äôre doing. If you tried working out in that state, your heart could give out. Your body knows when somethings wrong, listen to it.  Like far too many students, I found my ADHD more and more debilitating with increasingly more absurd deadlines for mountains of dry textbook readings. I found myself reading an entire page, just to get to the bottom and not remember literally anything I had just read. For the sixth time on that page. Those crazy productive days make it so enticing, but it always ends up in that hit or miss cycle gambling whether you‚Äôre going to finish all of the semester‚Äôs work in one night or make overly long winded comments on a relatable YouTube video instead of studying and not sleep, showing up to your exam the next day looking super cracked out.  Hefty read, but I‚Äôm just so glad someone else touched on this. All of my friends who have been diagnosed didn‚Äôt get medication until higher education kinda necessitated it, but then we all had the same kind of fall out with it as the side effects got worse and it became more and more of like a weird addiction where the high we chased was being a functional, productive member of society, but all too often got meth head instead. Been without it for a year this month, and I definitely feel healthier and my behavior isn‚Äôt so sporadic, but I‚Äôll always hear that little devil voice saying ‚ÄúJust take some, you‚Äôll totally get the productive part and not the hyperfixate on why cucumbers are actually fruit part this time. You want to be productive, don‚Äôt you?‚Äù  Stay focused out there, boys. The day may soon come where they will need someone able to click on every successive hyperlink on Wikipedia until they‚Äôve visited every page on the whole site, and we‚Äôll be ready.

I have ADHD, and had been through a few different meds. Ive been on concerts, Vyvanse, and a couple others I don't remember the name of. (I was young when I went through this) but I 1000000% relate with Vyvanse. I had almost the same experience as you, so I'm glad I'm not the only one with said experience trying ADHD drugs. I've learned that doing things to manage my ADHD helps. Fidget toys for concentration, taking my time to answer important questions, and writing little notes and alarms for myself for certain things. Making rules that I stick by helps too. (Specifically, I'm not allowed to remove reminder to take my daily meds until I've taken my daily meds. I tend to forget if I've taken them or not)

I‚Äôm finally fully off vyvanse after slowly decreasing the dose by 5mg every few months for the last few years (I started off at 50mg). I decided to quit when I was having headaches and burnouts.  I also made the mistake of going cold turkey (From 50mg Vyvanse) on a camping trip. I was fading in and out for 2 weeks, couldn‚Äôt stay awake for more then a hour at a time. Turns out I had dangerously low blood pressure at the time. Check with your doctor and slowly decrease the dose.
Me literally zoning out when the nord vpn shit came on
I've done 5 trials of ADHD medication. I'm really glad you tried working on bettering your habits, and I hope you find a balance that you like.   Andy, if you ever want to try again I suggest Concerta, the rest is anecdotal, I tried Adderall but I got insomnia as a side effect üòÖ. I take Concerta which is like the chiller version of Adderall. It does take an hour to work but it should allow your brain to focus without being too focused. It's because Adderall is, usually, a short-release medication, meaning that you feel it quickly and everything is done very quickly. Vyvanse is, usually, an extended-release medication which means the effects are slower but more consistent, it's also a wholly different chemical makeup. Concerta is mainly Methylphenidate, as is Adderall, which is its active ingredient but depending on the release your doctor prescribes you can have something close to Vyvanse or something close to Adderall.  I know I said a lot, ADHD medication is a whole world on its own. I suggest doing a lot of research on releases and chemical makeup just to know what you're getting yourself into. This also goes for anyone who is thinking of trying ADHD medication.

So I was getting the effects of the meds but they where muted. Eventually I ended up catatonic. I couldn‚Äôt stay awake at all the T was horrible. I felt like I was constantly about to crash. I talked to my psychiatrist about getting off the medication but when I went to the pharmacy they gave me the same dose so I didn‚Äôt say anything and I just stopped it by myself. (VERY DUMB DO NOT DO THIS). It was the worse pain I had ever felt In my entire life. I had constant brain zaps and if someone even so much as brushed against me I would get an extremely painful zap. I couldn‚Äôt eat and it was hard to drink water. I felt like I was going to die. It lasted so long as well I developed a touch aversion because I was afraid of getting zapped. If you know anything about Paxil you will know that the withdrawal symptoms are absolutely brutal. I‚Äôm on new meds now and it definitely taught me to be more serious about my medication. This is my way of agreeing with his point. Please don‚Äôt play around with your meds it can be dangerous to yourself and and also really screw with your brain.

Tip: I recently discovered an app called Speechify. Reading is something I really struggle with too, but with speechify I can listen to a textbook (or any document) in like 30 minutes when it would‚Äôve taken me like 3x that if I was reading it. You just take a picture of the page and it will read it to you in whatever voice you want (even Snoop Dog üíÄ). It has helped me tremendously, only downside is that it‚Äôs not free unfortunately :/

This went on so much over my time in school, that now that I'm in engineering school, the only pills that work for me are amphetamines, which isn't ideal. On the other hand, it's a bit funny, cause my dietitian gave me some pills that would normally take away your appetite, your energy, your everything, but for me it's just the appetite given that I have such a high tolerance for pills, like it was a step down from my ADHD meds. TLDR: If you have a mental disorder/disability or whatever, don't get discouraged if the first round of meds don't work. Don't get discouraged if the 10th round of meds don't work. Keep going. Chances are, you'll find one eventually. You got this. <3   I can't talk specifically with ADHD, but I do know a thing or two about Major Depressive Disorder. Namely... keep trying. I've gone through like, five different medications. All the general SSRIs, and all the general SNRIs and none of them were really working. My doctor was like, "Well, instead of going to more specific SSRIs or SNRIs, how about we try a different medication entirely."  So they put me on a medication that is like...apparently can't be taken for people under the age of 18 cause it can cause sever homicidal tendencies. Good thing I'm not under 18 I guess. And, my depression isn't cured. Tbh, I don't think it'll ever be cured. But...Damn....I can actually get up in the morning. I can actually go shopping, I can hold down a job. I can actually live again. I'm still depressed and some days things are much harder than others, but overall, Damn, it's done wonders.

I do not have ADHD. I obtained some ritalin illegally that would last me about 12 days. That ritalin was a super power. I could do anything. I was so creative. I was so witty. Funny. Social. *smart.* You know how your brain sorta simulates a scenario right before you think about making a choice? Well I could do that so fast while talking to someone that I could simulate dozens of scenarios before I even chose the first word of my sentence and I didn't even have to pause. It was like, my mind is a foggy mess of random tasks that I must complete, and ritalin not only burns the fog away, but it also organizes my tasks in the *exact* perfect order that I need to do them in and gives me an unlimited reservoir of motivation to do them.   This is apparently not a typical reaction for someone with ADHD. When you have ADHD, ADHD medication makes you "normal." Without ADHD, it's a stimulant drug, just like coke, crystal, etc. It'd be like, taking a gram of caffeine, but without the jitters or heart arrhythmia. When I ran out, I felt so stupid and dumb and small and puny and lackluster that I could not function for the day. It took me a month to just get back to normal. That came from people who had meds for their ADHD, including atheists and gingers.

Vyvanse converts to dextroamphetamine in the body, which is one of the mixed amphetamine salts in Adderall. So, with Vyvanse you're technically still on Adderall. But 2 less amphetamines. It's all pharmaceutical grade meth.

It kind of kills me on the inside whenever someone says that Adderall "Is basically meth". Yeah, sure, they are both similar in their chemical formulas, but they behave completely differently in the body. Adderall has been proven to be one of the safest drugs you can take, with very little problems except for the chance of abuse and eventual withdrawal. There is actually real meth prescribed for ADHD called Desoxyn, but even though Adderall isn't at all meth it still gets the brunt of the stigma.
Gotta find that cow dancing video
I moved from dex (adderal) to vyvanse recently and found it went from dex being really good focus (when I remembered to take it, which was the problem) to exactly what you described adderal being like. Apparently it's a dosage thing. Chemically, vyvanse only becomes active once your body turns it into dex, so they're basically the same thing but with different dosages/release schedules

I literally JUST got diagnosed with ADHD 2 days ago, and the fact that this video showed up on my feed right now was perfect. I am having my first meeting with a psychiatrist in a few weeks to discuss medication, but I am glad that I have this video now to reference when talking with them!
Adhd is one of the most relatable and unrelatable things.  I play Tetris, speedsolve, and pen spin as distractions. I take vyvanse, gonna be honest, I have the highest dose they‚Äôll give me for my age and I can‚Äôt tell a difference with and without the meds.
For me Adderall isn't enough on its own I also need to eat well, work out daily, and plan things on paper Adderall just gives me the willpower to make those needed lifestyle changes.  That's the thing, the lifestyle changes are what you use to treat ADHD. You need to literally figure out what works for your brain. Forget to take the trash out? Tie it up and leave it by the door so you see it on your way out the next day. Forget what food you have? Write a list on your fridge with dates of expiration. Post it notes, everywhere. Routine.  The meds alone aren't enough you use the Adderall to make lifestyle changes! Now even when I don't take my meds I know I have my tasks for the week in my pocket notebook and I have a routine that works for my lifestyle.

My problem is more that I have trouble with actually starting tasks in the order that makes sense. Idk how many people have experienced large scale panic attacks but uh‚Ä¶ I mean it‚Äôs not really an ADHD thing at this point but it‚Äôs equally if not more disruptive when it happens. Imagine it being hard to breath, you can‚Äôt think straight, all while you‚Äôre freaking out over something, and sometimes you don‚Äôt even know what you‚Äôre freaking out about. They can last anywhere from half an hour to literally all day, and many have described it as feeling like you‚Äôre dying. Pretty apt descriptor in my experience.   But yeah I cannot manage tasks for a variety of reasons, and it‚Äôs not so much a lack of focus as it is a poor management of my focus. A lack of focus on the right things at the right time. I wish I could say ‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna do this thing that‚Äôs really important that I get done‚Äù and not somehow forget about the thing it just one more interesting thing is put in front of me. This is a really great perspective and I enjoyed your video. I have been on ADHD meds for probably around 15-17 years at this point. I‚Äôve tried all kinds of them. How I describe what ADHD medication does to people who don‚Äôt know is I explain that it‚Äôs like cranking the ADHD to 11 until it‚Äôs somewhat useful. When you have ADHD, lots of people can enter what I call ‚Äúhyper focus‚Äù, which is when you are singularly focused on one task at a time, but it‚Äôs kinda rare to control and hard to get the hyper focus to focus on the thing you want it to focus on. To me, ADHD medication just flips that hyper focus switch ‚Äúon‚Äù.   A really great medication to try is called Jornay. Basically you take it at night and it lays dormant in your system until like 7-8 hours later and it helps you wake up. It‚Äôs the right medication for me because I have trouble hearing alarms. My ADHD is so bad that I can‚Äôt focus on the alarm enough to wake up. It takes finding what works best for you

Started on Adderall at about 6 years old. I can still remember it. I wanted to feel like an adult and take it early (the night we got it), and I had to wait till the morning before school. Well, many years later, I had no personality. No apatite. A hatred for all breakfast food. I was underweight and bullied for being quiet and shut out of everything. I quit taking Adderall at 14 and slowly discovered myself again. I gained friends, became more outgoing, and now I'm regarded as the goofy fun friend. Fuck meds

Just wanna say that there is a light at the end of the tunnel for anyone still trying to find the right medication. I am absolutely useless without it- I constantly space out, permanently tired, can't focus on anything including conversations, the only thing anyone could be sure of with me is that I'd forget everything they tell me. 30mg of Dexamphetamine and I am a completely different person. Motivated, focused, reliable. I used to be afraid that I would never be able to hold a job that had any real consequences for failure or forgetfulness. Now I'm an A-level Automotive Technician. This stuff changed my life. For anyone reading this that need someone to snap their fingers in front of your face to snap you out of a trance like me, I hope you find your solution.

I'd just like to add and say that you don't *have* to take medicine for ADHD. I feel like a lot of people push for meds as a treatment to ADHD and while it is very helpful for a lot of people, medicine isn't a one-size-fits-all treatment for ADHD. There's a whole variety of treatment options to help with your symptoms and that can look different for every individual.

The difference between prescription medications and street drugs is whether you‚Äôre poor or not, it‚Äôs all class related.  Meth is simply easier to abuse and those who take it are more likely to be actively abusing it as well as other substances. Meth itself is not bad and we need to stop acting like some drugs are so much worse than others when it‚Äôs just class differencesz.

*HES JUST LIKE ME FR*
I was always on meds.... unless I wasn't. Back in school it was Ritalin, Adderall, Dexatrine, all that fun stuff. But it wasn't fun because the pills tasted bitter so it was infrequent. I found out later that my mom didn't really enforce the regiment due concerns about over-medicating children. (Doctors tried to put my autistic brother on lithium because this was the early 90s)   So one day I just stopped taking it. Since I was in high school and had stupid teen brains I reveled in the respect I got from being off meds. Turns out this was a bad idea and spent the next decade feeling fucking awful and turning to anti-depressants.   I'm back on ADHD meds now, following some research which may have included this channel. But I didn't want meth either so I started on Wellbutrin, combined with Zoloft. I'm... stable, but damned if I don't curse my stupid freight train brain.
Medication is great, but it's usually only meant to be a temporary assist. What people generally need is to actually be trained in how to handle their brain.  Think about it, like building a base of operations. Neurotypical people are taught how to utilize their brains in order to build that base, and because they're on solid ground, they're taught to build a foundation for a building.  ADHD brains are often not given the assist we need because we are assumed to be like neurotypicals. Like fitting a square block into a circle hole, it doesn't work.  And since our brains are 1000x more chaotic, it's 1000x harder to build it that foundation on our own because you're not on solid land, you're on a stormy ocean. You don't need a building, you need a boat that can handle the rocky seas.  Medication then acts as a way to stop the storm. It holds the water still for a while. But if you don't then utilize that time to try and build the discipline and skills you need in order to make your own vessel, then you'll either always rely on drugs or those drugs will stop working and you'll be back to square one.  This is why Psychiatrists are great but you want a Psychologist to actually help you master the art of surfing chaos.
Long time medication tester (or so it feels) and ADHD connoisseur Somehow, I learned to live with it without medication. Best I can describe it, is one day I woke up and just knew how to deal with it. Discovered that it would hyper-trigger with uncertainty so I just learned to actively avoid uncertainty.  I also hated every medication they put me on. Some zombified me (for lack of a better term), others put my brain "a few inches to the left". (some might understand that).  Realistically, I think I just hated that I understood and observed I wasn't really "me" anymore. Sure, the productivity and focus were nice but they weren't me. ADHD is goofy.  PS. Get something to mess with. Found Tom's Fidgets, there's one that's literally 2 sections of bike chain connected by keyrings and it is amazingly simple, small, easy to manipulate and easy to maintain my focus with.  Bless you for this video though. The thought train (1:07) is the best example ever lmao
For me, meds help, i had to lower my dose because of side effect (out of breath, hearth was pumping way too fast, etc). So me and my doctor talked about it and figure that by lowering it, they would still help me, but i also have to do more effort, learn to control my emotions, leave my credit cards in the car so i don‚Äôt buy anything out of impulse (i have time to think about it by going back to the car and the shop), use reminder (alarms, post it or object for visual reminder), forcing myself to eat at least a little something for diner even tho my meds make me lose appetit (protein bar for the win when i really don‚Äôt feel hungry, otherwise by 3 o‚Äôclock, my stomach is killing me and i have headache) and adapting my house for me and my brain. There is still bad days, where my adhd gave me trouble, but most of the time, we make a good team and manage to survive the day. Its not always easy to adapt ourselve to the world, but we kinda all have that strenght to adapt and be creative about it :)

Concerta did to me what vivance did to you. I ditched em too and am off meds now. Been needing the motivation to talk to my quack. TY <3
Having meds for the first time is...an experience.  I was on meds when I was younger. I knew something was different, but I wasn't capable of articulating what yet.  Than I had a big gap with no meds.   Than I had them again in High School...and HOLY SHIT did I notice the difference than. I could actually DO something without starting 97 other tasks  in the middle of it.  That it dropped off a little after High school and a couple of years later I got on Vyvanse (still am actually.) This stuff WORKS for me. I can process background info. Before I take it, I look at the bush (or forest, I don't mean bush as in shrub) outside my window and I just see bush. But when I'm on Vyvanse, I can see the individual trees and branches. I automatically see the detail instead of it being all blended together into one concept.  It's...nice.  Than there was that time I accidentally double dosed on my Vyvanse 70mg. 70mg is the max dose you're supposed to have at one time. (By the way, not recommending or endorsing this. There are potentially fatal side effects under the wrong circumstances.) Didn't see much at first until I left for work that day. But when I went outside with more stimuli...HOLY SHIT!!!!! EVERYTHING was smoother, even the feeling of turning my head from left to right to look at something. Colour also seemed brighter.  Than I discovered something amazing. Turns out that the quarter of a second it takes for my eyes to adjust to something new that I'm looking at wasn't what I thought it was. It turns out it wasn't my eyes adjusting as I thought it was. It was my brain processing it...I'd never questioned it before because it was always there. But now...THAT WAS GONE. That tiny fraction of a second that was always just there when ever I looked at something didn't exist anymore. I asked my mum and dad about this later that night and apparently they'd never had that...but my dad had noticed me doing it. The little pause before doing something.  All I could think of was....Is this what it's like for neuro-typical people all the time? I could finally understand how big the gap was. People like us can't make split second decisions because we have to take that split second to process what's happening. It turns out, for people like us (well at least for me), to get to even approaching the same level as a neuro-typical person, we have to take double the maximum recommended dose of our medication...which is pretty dangerous.  So yeah, I DO NOT recommend purposely overdosing on your meds just to feel this. It's cool, but not worth it given the potentially deadly side effects.

My psychiatrist was like "oh, you got a diagnosis? here you have the largest possible dose, don't take more than that" (this is, of course, highly irresponsible, but I was studied up on all the short and long term effects enough to figure it out myself anyway)  So I took a quarter of the max dose and I absolutely _tripped_ for _9 hours_ (which is double of how long it was supposed to last). I could focus on things, I could choose what to do, I could be productive, but I didn't feel like me. I didn't feel at home in my own brain. It felt like I couldn't trust myself to act in my best interest. Like if I were on alcohol or something, except I'm still very aware of being like that.  I tried an eight of the dose I was prescribed, and that was much more manageable. I had to actually remind myself to do things, but then I did actually manage to do them. But after a week or so, it started leaving me permanently exhausted, like mentioned in the video. It felt like I was pulling the life force out of my brain. It felt unhealthy. So I stopped. Which I could do because my psychiatrist had told me literally nothing at all.  From this experience, I learned what the "able to do things" state of mind feels like, and now I can just choose to go into that state of mind whenever I want to. It is somewhat exhausting, and taking the medication makes it effortless, but I haven't needed to take it in months and manage to be productive for a few hours every day, which is good enough for me.

I started taking Vyvanse at 7 years old. It actually worked pretty well, but after around 7 years of taking it, I realized that it wasn't helping much with high school and I was used to it. I switched to Concerta until my family's insurance stopped supporting generic Concerta and they wouldn't support name brand. Love this person man love them
I'm a person with ADHD and have been taking Vyvanse for as long as I can remember past Kindergarten (so, probably about 5 or 6). Vyvanse is definitely a good drug for making it past a day of school or long projects. It's worked for me, primarily because I'm used to it. I have two main theories as to why IceCream might've experienced problems with Vyvanse. The first is the huge dump of dopamine your brain gets from Vyvanse. Vyvanse is a stimulant, so it's essentially like swallowing the worlds strongest coffee. People with ADHD have a critical lack of dopamine-- and therefore their brain has to adjust whenever they take Vyvanse. This usually causes headaches and bad moods. Interestingly, the opposite effect is also true! My brain has been using Vyvanse for so long that I receive a headache if I forget to take my medicine for a day. It's just the brain's way of saying: "Hold on, this is different. I need to adjust." Which might mean they IceCream too high of a dose. The other problem with Vyvanse is that it numbs your ability to feel hunger, thirst, and sleep, and this is a trait that's shared with other types of drugs. It's enirely possible that while IceCream put himself on the medicine he also couldn't hear his body's needs-- which would explain why he had an unpleasant experience.  Sorry if I mixed up some medical jargon, but these are my best guesses!
fun lil pharmacology lesson: Adderall works by essentially not allowing dopamine to leave your system through its usual mechanisms, so that it's still around to be used by your body for good stuff like focusing, and also producing norepinephrine, which is ALSO good for focusing. its worth noting that, while Adderall is a mix of amphetamine and dextroamphetamine, it is not "like meth"; they are only in the same family of drugs. Vyvanse has a longer effect because it's what is called a "prodrug", which means it itself doesn't do anything, but it will metabolize into things that DO do things. Vyvanse breaks down, by an enzyme in your blood, into Lysine (an amino acid), and d-Amphetamine. it is stronger than Adderall because it is directly in your blood stream by the time it even begins to work, making it a longer and stronger focus

A lot of "helpful" things I've been told by doctors, haven't helped with my ADHD. What I learned that actually helped, is the understanding that medication is a TREATMENT not a CURE for ADHD. Yes you can focus, but you can't choose what you focus on. If you can't find ADHD meds helpful, or they kick in super suddenly, try a lower dose or an extended release dose. Obviously medication isn‚Äôt the only treatment, but I take medication, and it's a valid treatment. Stay safe everyone, and please make sure your doctors are all on board with your treatment plans, and if one thing doesn't work, there are other options and you are not alone!!!

I was on Concerta for a while and I kinda had the same problem where I could Do Physical Things but I couldn't Focus, so I went to my doctor and he gave me a very very slightly different med called Focalin, which is essentially the more active part* of Concerta. It works a lot better for me and I can sustain attention for hours now. If anyone is struggling with finding meds that work, see if the one that works best has another form -- it can really help!  *Basically in chemistry some molecules are twisty (also called "chiral") and methylphenidate (Ritalin/Concerta) is one of them. With a lot of substances, the direction of the twistiness matters and can have a huge impact on how your body reacts to it. So Focalin is dex-methylphenidate, which is the same as methyphenidate except there's only one direction of twisting. The crappy half gets filtered out in the manufacturing process so it doesn't clog up the receptors in your brain with the part that doesn't really help you, while the good half has easier access to the places it needs to be.

I have severe ADHD and I'm a pharmacy tech. I completely agree with this video, except for one thing. It might seem like a small or trivial detail, but it's important. Adderall is not meth. It contains no methamphetamine. It's a mixture of amphetamine and dextroamphetamine.   Vyvanse is also an amphetamine. Lisdexamfetamine to be specific. So one cannot be adverse to meth and stop Adderall just to jump to Vyvanse.   This isn't an attack or me hating in anyway. This is merely information so others can make an appropriate decision on their care.

I feel the need to point out that Adderall Is not meth. They‚Äôre a molecule apart but that makes a huge difference in chemistry. O2 is oxygen. obviously very good for us because we need it to live. But add another oxygen molecule and you get O3. Our bodies can‚Äôt process O3. We‚Äôd die if we tried breathing only that. One tiny change can make a very big difference.  Not trying to support or refute the effectiveness of medications. Just wanna clear the air on the misinformation about things like thatz
As a nurse who suffers from ADHD, let me reassure you that your response to medication is not at all uncommon. If you'd like to try a different approach to medication that doesn't revolve around overloading your system with dopamine, I recommend SNRIs.   Typically used as an antidepressant, these medications allow you to retain the norepinephrine already in your system and reduce the 'urge' to find stimulation in things without overwhelming your system.

Ritalin my dude. Been on it for like 20 years now, and the dosage is like... Customizable. Maybe it's just my system being so used to it, but I can take a number of pills depending on what I need to do the next 6 hours. Normal day? 20mg. Important class or got some work to do that's kinda boring but needs to be done? 40mg. Exam? Deadlines coming up on work? SIXTY MILLIGRAMS! Here's the thing though. 60mg was the dose I used to take when I started on ritalin. So I know my body can take it, but after several years of just 20, 60 feels like... Opening my eyes. Defogging the windscreen. Polishing your glasses. My eyes don't dart around and seek interesting stuff, they stay on what I want to focus on. It's really quite excillerating. And yet, it's not addictive at all. To such a degree that I regularly forget to take my medication on my days off, even though I'm supposed to be fully medicated "all day" so to speak.  All of this being said, I do not endorse actually not following the prescribed dosage as ordained by your doctors. Please listen to medical advice over my advice. But ritalin has put my life right, and it has helped my father, and my sister, who both got diagnosed with ADHD after I was diagnosed.

I have ADHD and this here is very correct
The way I describe thinking with ADHD is similar to how you described it.  The normal person has a a sort of train of thoughts that behaves like a laser. It's a strong beam that diffuses at the edges. They really only get one or two of these beams. In the ADHD brain, we get a cloud of those beams. They're all very strong but they go EVERYWHERE so we're constantly switching focus from item to item because they all seem to have the same priority in our minds. With practice, the unmedicated ADHD brain can focus SOME of that cloud of high powered beams to have some semblance of a laser.  When medicated however, all of those beams condense into a single MEGA GIGA SUPER DEATH LASER that we call "hyperfocus." When hyperfocus kicks in, it doesn't matter what we're doing, we lose all semblance of time and bodily need and can grind out a task so effectively and without stopping that it would make any normal person's head spin. This has a stipulation though: It's easier to apply hyperfocus to only some of the beams in the cloud.  Due to the fact that the ADHD brain is missing a neurotransmitter called "Norepinephrine", our superpower has an easier time activating if the task at hand doesn't require something called "executive function". In other words, that cloud of thoughts has hot spots and cold spots. We can make our ULTRA MEGA GIGA SUPER DEATH LASER of hyperfocus easier if the task doesn't require a high degree of critical thinking. Critical thinking requires executive function, AKA focus, which, due to the lack of norepinephrine in our brains, is very hard to do. To get around this, the ADHD brain looks for alternative ways of activating hyperfocus. Enter the greatest threat to the ADHD brain: DOPAMINE.  The common brain will use norepinephrine for executive function which allows them cast spells not natively known to the ADHD brain like Planning, Organization, and Foresight. ADHD brains will try to cast these spells but without norepinephrine, that becomes impossible. This is where dopamine comes in. Since the executive functioning part of the brain is basically starving, it starts looking for ANYTHING that will stimulate it. As it turns out, though we're missing norepinephrine, dopamine can stimulate that part of the brain. The problem arises when you realize that dopamine is the "feel good" chemical. So what happens when you're trying to focus on the 6 page essay you have to do by Thursday on why Hooke's Law is one of the most important concepts to mechanical engineering and you start thinking about what the most ideal build is to ensure success when solo-flawlessing dungeons in Destiny 2? Well since there's a lot of dopamine to be had in your theory-crafting in video games, the ADHD brain grabs onto that concept and hyperfocuses on it because that's where the dopamine is and that stimulates the prefrontal cortex which is where executive function occurs.  The moral of the story here is that there is... Well I'll admit that I got a little sidetracked by my own ADHD and don't really remember what I was trying to say but focus requires practice and strategy. It's not easy and it never really will be easy but medication is there to help if you need it. The medication won't do the lifting for you but it will make it way easier to activate your hyperfocus skill. The rest is just part of our daily grind. üí™  Good luck out there everyone. üíï
Whit medicine, can focus on what i want how hard i want. Whit out medicine, can't choose what to focus on and how much. For me if i noticed a bad side effect after 3-4 hours it would only get worse and worse the longer i took the medicin.

I paused this video to go watch polish cow
As a college student with ADHD, I feel your pain. I've been taking medication since first grade, and it's always a struggle. For me, it's worth it because my ADHD symptoms are far worse than the side effects and difficulties of the medication (to be fair I am studying to be an engineer). I spent nine years on Vyvanse, and bounced between medications before and after. It sounds to me like you were overmedicated on top of being not used to/comfortable with how the meds impacted your mental state. I have been told that some people need only a tiny dose to get the full effect, and others (like me) need a lot more, so you may want to start any future medications at the lowest dose possible, especially because you have only just started trying them out. As for getting used to how the medication impacts you, the laser focus of Vyvanse can be like being strapped to a rocket: it takes a lot of work and practice to be able to direct that attention. It worked for me because I started it while in middle school, so my attention was sort of guided for me, but homework has always been a challenge. I highly recommend you speak to a counselor or therapist (ADHD coaches do exist too) once you find a medication/dose that won't kill you, because developing the strategies and habits to take advantage of the medication efficiently can be extremely difficult to do on your own. Good luck, I hope your journey takes you where you want to go!

i still take adderall today ever since like...i was 13? i'm 20 now! while i am now thinking about trying other medicine, one thing that i was told by my doctor is that a couple of days of break on (at least adderall) is REALLY beneficial for you! in fact, i have it as a mandatory thing on my medicine that i *must* take one break day a week! of course contact your doctor, but it could be why you felt fine after taking a break on vyvanse!  as a BIG BIG warning, if the medicine is like...addictive to your body (like antidepressants, anti psychotic) DON'T DO NOT do that PLEASE.  speaking from experience, if i miss ONE DAY of antidepressants, i'm literally a mess. constantly crying, anxiety to hell, all of that. talk to your doctor and see if its safe for you to take a break though! i would wanna recommend just to see what happens, maybe retake the medicine for a day and see if you have that focus again?  and of course, for anyone reading, NEVER EVER EVER take more medicine that you've been prescribed! i've been down that rabbit hole before, *just don't!*

I have major ADHD so I know what you mean. I can be doing work than I‚Äôm in the bath watching a show, so I know.
The thing with ADHD and meds is that it's not a miracle fix. The meds help you focus and do stuff, but you still need to manage what those stuff are, because, as you said in the video, it can be very easy to focus on the wrong stuff (lol). That's why meds + cognitive behavioral therapy is the perfect match, the first one helps you with the brain chemistry focusing stuff, while the second helps you manage where that new focus is going to be directed towards. Obviously there are still days (perhaps weeks) where I will learn everything about game development instead of doing my tasks, but they are more manageable.   Also, stopping adhd meds suddenly isn't as bad as stopping antidepressants because it's not a long lasting medication. Most of its components are gone within a few hours (for Vyvanse I believe it's between 10-14 hours for example) and the whole thing will be gone after 3 days. It's different with SSRI's and other antidepressants because they are a long lasting medication, meaning they stay in your system for a lot longer and have to be slowly decreased overtime by your doctor. Sometimes when I want to sleep the whole day I'll just not take my adhd meds and be fine.
Meanwhile I take: Methylphenidate hydrochloride capsules So I can focus at school. :V

It made it worse and I whenever I tried to do anything my brain would just be like "Nope, not doing that" and just initiate sleep mode. I've been off meds for like 2 years now and my brain only goes sleep mode when I'm not stimulated enough, which is still bad.
Right now, there's a national shortage on several ADHD meds. I ran out last week, and can't get a refill. I'm a mess.

I was diagnosed at age 24 and it's changed my life!! Definetely relate to the experiences with the medication tho, it took a while to figure out what worked and what didn't. I'm still mad I couldn't make Medikinet work for me, as 60% of the time I had awful side effects ranging from shaking and headaches all the way to a 2-3h crash with intense migraine where I couldn't do anything but lay down with an ice pack on my head, unfocus my eyes and wait until it passed. When it DID work the way it was supposed to (40% of the time, completely unpredictable why) IT WAS AMAZING! I have never before or after experienced time as logical, linear progression where every activety I did and the amount of time it took made sense while it happened and in hindsight. It was unreal!! I cannot believe neurotypicals get to just live in a world where time is a reasonable and rationally plannable resource!! I was in full control of my time, in charge of all decisions in a way I have never experienced, so acutely *real* and existing in the real world instead of behind a soundproof glass wall and feeling every decision is like walking uphill.  Anyways, have been on Elvanse (Vyvanse) for a year which works reliably every day without side effects and while not making me feel literally Clearvoyant, it does so much to help me live a functional life. I've spent a year figuring out how to best help my brain and learned I still need outside structure, if I stay home I will still spend an entire day doing completely non-urgent things but with Focus(TM). So I set up my appointments and schedule in a way that forces me to leave the house every day. Once I'm out anyways, might as well go to the library/caf√©/co-working space to get a few hours of focused actual work in. Medication combined with setting up systems/frameworks that make the  good" choice also the easiest choice have really changed my life. The meds really help with getting things started. It's like all my life I've been wearing a weighted blanket or tried to move underwater. The meds take that away and I can simply... move. Without everything taking extra effort and energy.

It sounds like it was disrupting your red blood cell count. Your blood, having that little divot in the center actually holds the oxygen it took from your lungs to distribute it to the rest of your body. You sound like you weren't getting enough oxygen in your blood from a low amount of red blood cells. The hospital can do a red blood cell count, which would have been good to know. I am wondering how the meds did this to you. As if it was messing up the communication to your immune system to make more red blood cells or maybe it was literally destroying red blood cells. I am so glad you got off the meds. Who knows what long term damage that could have done to your body, especially your brain. Thanks for the intriguing video, new subscriber, big hugs from Oregon!üêø

great video loll have been on meds for almost 4 years now, and I take Wellbutrin which is normally used as an antidepressant. It‚Äôs an ndri which stands for Norepinephrine‚Äìdopamine reuptake inhibitor, which basically means the dopamine in my brain will actually stick around and not get sucked up by my cells. Since a lot of scientists hypothesize that adhd is caused by dopamine deficiency, this kind of med can be really nice. It is good -FOR ME- but might not work for everyone ofc

It's so interesting to me how diffrent everyone i know with adhd can be. For me I found Adderall worked really well but unfortunately like you I had adverse side effects (I started getting hives). I take Concerta which is just Ritalin but its in an extended release form, so its slowly dosing me throughout the day, which works fairly well although not as great as the Adderall. I also have additional regular Adderall to supplement the Concerta when I find it's not quite hitting as well as it could be. To me it really highlights the syndrome part of adhd. It's not a real thing per se but a collection of symptoms for classification purposes. Its like if you went to the doctor and you were like doc my foot hurts, and the doc was like oh I see, you have hurt foot syndrome here take this pill. Adhd is most likely a collection of neurotypcalities all being bundled together under this umbrella adhd term.
