1:06 it hurts how accurate this is
Adderall is NOT meth. It's not even close. And it's effects are nothing like the effects of meth. People need to stop assigning equivalencies between the two. It's like claiming that sodium pentothal is essentially sodium (salt).
Recently I got diagnosed too and after a 12 week program they helped me rearrange my brain but also got me on meds and learned me about them. This is my basic understanding (I am not a doctor)  So there are 2 types of ADHD medications, which each have 2 variants (so 4 chemicals in total).  *Stimulants:* Stimulants are stimulating the "break" of ADHD, or in other words, they slow down the speed at which dopamine leaves your brain, so you're not making more of it, it just stays in there longer. The two chemicals that do this are Methylphenidate (used by brands as Ritalin and Concerta) and Dexamphetamine (no clue what brands, google it yourself <3).  *Non-stimulants/anti-depressants(I think):* These work more on noradrenaline then dopamine, but also kinda on dopamine. The main chemicals here are Atomoxetine (used by brands like Strattera) and Bupropion (used by brands like Wellbutrin and Zyban).  From my knowledge, most doctors will start with prescribing Stimulants, here in the Netherlands specifically Methylphenidate based ones as these get covered by most insurances while others only get covered if the Methylphenidate is proven not to work on the person. The difference between brands comes from the additional helper chemicals they put inside the medicine which makes you react differently, also dosses plays an important factor.  That's about where my knowledge ends. Hopefully it helped someone to understand more about the medication.   Bonus: Stimulants can also be prescribed to people with Narcolepsy as a higher dosses of Dopamine in your brain keeps you awake. You didn't hear this from me but I have used my meds in the past to stay awake and alert for longer, mainly if I am the designated driver and need to drive people home at night.
Give link to dancing cow this instant
I have such bad reactions to various migraine medications, I'm scared to try meds for ADHD. My current bandaid fix is giving myself a bite sized candy and letting that tiny sugar high carry me through whatever task I'm trying to finish. I don't know why bite sized candies help me focus, but they do.
im oretty sure i have adhd but idk how to start the process of meds lol
Vyvanse permanently changed my brain. I've been medicated on high dose vyvanse since I was 8 years old. One of the effects on the prefrontal cortex is that it enhances top-down control of emotions. I used that control as a child to conquer fear, anger, anxiety, disgust, jealousy, and stress. I didn't realize at the time but doing so would permanently reduced my ability to feel those emotions because my brain was highly plastic (since I was a child). I didn't know it was the drugs, I thought it was just a part of growing up. Now happiness just comes way to easy for me. My friend call me "aggressively positive." It makes it hard to emphasize with people though because I've forgotten what it's like to feel those negative emotions. Anyways, I ended up developing amphetamine psychosis for a while, because little did I know but amphetamines develop reverse tolerance at a certain point. So the drug's effects becomes even more powerful by dose. And then the solution is to reduce the meds. That problem you had with the vyvanse might have been solvable if you tried less drugs.

I am also medicated for ADHD and I am currently on Focalin and it works GREAT for me! I take about 15 mg a day split up into 3 doses every 3 or so hours, and it works out really well. It gives me insane amounts of focus and energy to do things, but I also still struggle with the "latching onto the wrong thing" problem, but that's combated by me IMMEDIATELY starting the task I want to focus on after I take my meds. I do not experience any horrible side effects from this medication either, the only thing I could consider a side effect is so minor that it's not even a real problem (I'm not gonna say it here though because it's a lil too personal and I don't wanna put myself on full blast LOL). Focalin hits hard and gives you energy like Adderall (and I've been on Adderall as well so I know what you mean) BUT it also gives you energy to FOCUS. I've also found that pairing the meds with a simple stim toy also helps a LOT, I just bought like one of those lil spikey dog toys and it's literally perfect and helps me focus way more because i have something to fiddle around with using my hands while I try to pay attention to something else.

I was taking Vyvanse for 10 years and now it just stopped working. And I started having similar symptoms as you plus MAJOR anxiety.   It‚Äôs sucks because I am now floundering.   Life is hard.
I finally took the plunge late last year and went on adderal for my ADHD. They worked great at first, I was able to focus at work and actually get stuff done. After a couple months though I started to feel like my anxiety was spiraling out of control. I could focus, but I was constantly worried, and my heart was almost always racing. Then one day at work, I'm sitting at my desk doing paperwork, when I feel a spasm in my chest and back. My skin goes numb, my head feels warm, my vision went blurry, and I panicked. Next thing I know I'm on the floor with a blanket over me and my boss is on the phone with 911. I thought I was having a heart attack. I'm 30 and having a goddamn heart attack. Had to get an EKG and everything done. Turns out the combination of being stressed about my new job and being hopped up on both anxiety meds and doctor prescribed meth, had triggered a panic attack and a mild vasovagal spasm (a nerve near your heart that detects blood pressure spikes and triggers your brain to freak out and protect itself by shutting off blood flow, in turn causing you to faint). Shit was horrifying and I've been off adderal ever since. At some point I wanna try something else but I'm not quite ready.

The same thing happened to me with an anti-depressant where it was making me feel almost like I wasn't in my own body or I wasn't having any passion for anything I normally do. Although it helped me actually do things which depression was holding me back from I felt like it was making my mental state worse. Just like here the doctor was like "I dunno what's going on!!" lol  But yeah I did stop it, though with help from another doctor who put me on a lower dose and stuff until I could stop, because I requested that I wanted to stop. Good luck to everyone out there looking for good medications for a condition! Be patient, not everything works the same for everyone, and know it gets better! :)
if anyone is struggling with the same problems of adhd with medications, there are still options out there to try, like the one i take called atomoxetine sandoz. theres 2 different chemicals in you brain that you have less of when you have adhd, and while most meds like ritalin or concerta try to fill in for both, atomoxetine only fills in for one. it‚Äôs slower-acting needing to be built up over several weeks, its subtler, and it‚Äôs basically taken all of my adhd brain fog away - itll be different for everyone who takes it though.

Since you didn't cover ritalin in this video, I will try my best to cover my personal experience here: you get the ability of hyperfocus, like if you need to write an essay you can write four times the amount you usually would in one sitting, you don't get that feeling of procrastination, but you also don't feel much of anything, since one of the ways the meds work is cutting of your dopamine receptors. Your mood will worsen which I believe is the worst of the side effects. If you had a choice betwee ntaking Ritalin and not, here are some points to think over: Ritalin gives you the ability to work well, but gives you the big sad. Not taking it makes you poorly focused, but you can have the big happy :)
This is absolutely something to discuss with your psych, but if you ever want to - try out the other ones! Two of my other family members and myself take ADHD meds. For one, vyvanse is the only thing that works for him, for my parent, she did terribly with vyvanse and adderall, but does really well on a low combination dose of concerta and ritalin depending on the day. I take both concerta and ritalin at the same time and that helps me do the physical stuff to get to the point of the focus, but the wear off time is less harsh (very important for the autism)! I also tried non-stimulant ones but that didn't work out for me at all. ADHD is super cool - hope you're able to find a system that works for you, medicated or not!

I personally also take Vyvanse for my ADHD, symptoms are different for everyone. For me, Vyvanse takes 30 minutes to kick in and I only take it two days a week (when I work), i don't take it all the time or else I get in a severe depressive episode. It also cuts my hunger and makes me "numb". I don'y especially love ADHD meds, but they work when really needed. I'd recommend to take one of the formula that doesn't need to be taken on long term to work, and simply take it when you know you have lots of stuff to do.  But again, everyone's different! Focus on your mental health first <3.

despite being a healthcare professional diagnosed with adhd at age 6, it still baffles me to hear other people‚Äôs experiences are so similar to mine. it makes me feel so less alone. i had the same exact issue with adderall. i tried wellbutrin and gained 30 lbs (since lost!), tried focalin, tried vyvanse. same EXACT experience with misdirected focus and funky side effects! finally decided meds weren‚Äôt for me and i‚Äôve been working with my therapist figuring out ways to focus and quiet my brain without pills. i‚Äôve been making huge progress! sharing your experiences is so important for educating neurotypical people about the different mental processes different people have. people need to understand not everyone functions the way they do. thank you again for being so open about your experiences!!
i‚Äôve been medicated with my adhd for about ten years now?? it WAS ADD but apparently that‚Äôs not a thing anymore, so i have ADHD inattentive and i think i‚Äôve been taking the same medication throughout, tho i was ten wen i was first diagnosed so i don‚Äôt rly remember much about my experience becuz that‚Äôs what i thought everyone was going thru- N E WAYZ- i‚Äôve been using ‚ÄòFocalin‚Äô or Dexmethylphenidate and i‚Äôd say i have a pretty good experience with it. im able to focus on my schoolwork and tasks well once i get myself to start it and just. do it  id say the only downsides of my experience w focalin is that it does affect my appetite, like i have to get myself/remember to eat during the day (i set reminders on my phone often to deal w that). And sometimes sleep was a bit more difficult to come by, but then again this isn‚Äôt a problem for me anymore now, im pretty sure this was when i was not taking my medication regularly bc i was moving locations and couldn‚Äôt get it on time,  n e wayz, focalin is a bit more mellow- but (depending on the dosage- i take 15mmg) it lets me get my tasks done and doesn‚Äôt feel overwhelming when im doing a task or even when im not doing a task,  hope this helps for anyone!! <3
so, in my experience, Concerta is basically like Aderall, but if you combine it with something like Stratera, you can actually focus on something without the massive hyperfocussing issues of Vyvanse, (It's how I was able to survive HS) but it doesn't totally stop you from getting distracted nor help with the... related emotional complications.   Welbutrin (My current med) isn't an obvious change, but it stops things like the ADHD anxiety death spiral before going to sleep, can actually help with task paralysis, (though you need to remember the thing needs to be done in the first place) with Stratera helping with focus, I may throw concerta back in once the current shortage is done.

One point of clarification, Adderall is dextroamphetamine sulfate and Vyvanse is lisdexamfetamine dimesylate, both are amphetamine and are stimulant treatments for ADHD. They do have non stimulant treatments for ADHD.

Too much focus is like OCD I have OCD and ADHD and depression and social anxiety something is wrong with meeeeeeeeeeeeee
Wow this is almost completely parallel to the way things have been going for me, at least in terms of Adderall. But I also had all the bad side effects like feeling out of breath and my heart was constantly racing while on Adderall. Fortunately for me, Vyvanse has been working out really nicely. We did try going up on the dosage a little, but then I started getting the side effects again, but now I feel like we‚Äôre at a good level.   The worst it‚Äôs been for me is Vyvanse kind of makes me not want to eat food, which is a little annoying, but I can deal with it.
My advice for any ADHD-ers in the comments is this:  Don't expect medication to "fix" ADHD. It's the same principle as antidepressants: the meds help significantly, but you still need to do extra work to truly feel better.  For me, I take Adderall. Trust me when I say that it's not nearly as scary as it sounds. Yes, it's related to the drug meth, but it's always in very controlled doses and actually works differently in the brains of those with ADHD than regular people. It just helps fill the gaps our brains have.  On the note of habits, you still need to develop some new habits or work-arounds cause ADHD is more of a monster you can control but can't kill. All the meds do is make it significantly easier for you to do tasks and focus on them.   Finally: Adderall is definitely more expensive than other meds, but with a program like GoodRX, which is free, you can get a month's worth for $15-30. Trust me when I say it's worth the extra functioning power.

As someone with adhd, I feel this video so much. I know exactly what you're talking about when taking meds. I still struggle a lot with my adhd but I've started taking adhd coaching lessons with someone that knows how to deal with the goofy ahh adhd brain and helps me develop techniques to deal with the quirks. I've started to learn how my brain works, ex. When I know I have to do it now or it's game over, it's impossible, so I set the deadline earlier than the actual deadline so I have mental leeway.  As time goes on, I learn how to work together with effects of the meds and the things I learned about my quirky quirks. To summarize, meds aren't the whole picture, they can only help but in the end you still need to do something, as much as I wish meds were a magic cure-all, they're not.   I'm so glad you're on this journey and I wish you all the best on your future journey!

So my girlfriend and I both got ADHD... I learned to have a solid hand on it and stopped taking meds since I was 10-12 (idek anymore breh thats been over 10 years ago)... What made me stop taking them is that I didnt have anything with them... No personality... No emotions... No fun... I just suffered and one day I realised that if I accidentally didnt take them... That was different... Not entirely but I felt more and felt better... Also I got like 10 more diagnostics ranging from perception issues to autism to ptsd but thats all for another time... All in all my life after that also sucked for different reasons but I felt alive... Fast forward about 12 years and I meet my gf... She too has ADHD... She too is taking meds... She too suffers the same symptoms... But worse... I convinced her to quit the meds and of course she is less focused n shit but when given time and good guidance she also learned to control part of ADHD so far... ADHD is not the incapability but rather the Overcapability...  ADHD is pretty much an Ability, but learning how to use it can be tough cuz NOONE FUCKING EXPLAINS IT!! I didnt know I could learn like a maniac if I was interested in a topic until I met other people with ADHD that told me... ADHD is very interesting... Having it basically means you can do a lot of shit at once IF you dont lose your line which tends to happen a lot unless you practice it... I recommend trying autism therapy when you have ADHD (well sorry Americans I recommend moving to Europe or sth) because you can learn a f*ck ton in group sessions about how to do things... And all in all I havent met a single soul that had a good experience with ADHD medication (I have met a lot of people with ADHD... Lots and lots more during therapy), and it can be an absolute personality killer if not even a main trigger for depressions later on...   P.S. dont advertise scams such as NordVPN... Good VPNs dont need Ads plus Cyberghost VPN is proven on every end to be like cheaper, better, easier... NordVPN has been proven to sell your data after you quit their service... They save it localy and legaly on your device, because you agreed to their Terms of Use... I wished people would look deeper into sponsors before just agreeing to them :/

(Not a promotion of any substance, simply my experience with other remedies)  I had the same problem with adderall, I found that remedying with it weed and meditation worked well for me. I smoke enough to where the thoughts are 'visible' ('visible' referring to the intesity and depth of the thought), and from there just focused on my breathing to distract from all those thoughts and aim to achieve a sort of 'tranquil' state. Seeing all those thoughts so vividly was admitedly a little terrifying, but once I was able to settle down and let the thoughts pass, I experienced what can only be described as a matrix perception. Every bit of information I percieved was so well described and correlations and connections were made effortlessly, even if it what I was looking at was ambigious and even if it had no possible connections, I was still able to come up with something. It not only boosted my focus, but unrestricted my thoughts in an organized manner to allow for a better flow of thoughts. It is however important to note that it took me about 3 months of smoking / consuming cannibis almost everyday to see these results. I've also noticed to achieve this state faster, it's better to smoke alone, though many begginner smokers note that they get too paranoid to focus on anything (including me when I started), likely due to the intensity of thoughts.

3:18 lol
I've been taking Welbutrin (buproprion)! It's working very well for me. It's an ADHD/antidepressant kind of thing, but for me it has no feeling, just the ability to do stuff (called executive function by the way), and a general sense of being able to focus. I'm still ADHD, but it's waaaay more manageable and easy to deal with.  Unlike other meds, you can stop it cold turkey if you have bad symptoms, and it's not really something that can become addictive like the others. That was the biggest draw for me, Drs are too hard to reach when you need help.   I super suggest trying it out to anyone whose frustrated with other meds. It's new, so most none-ADHD specialist don't know about it, but it's pretty safe afaik. My experience was that the first couple weeks I felt a little wired and hyper productive (in a bad way) and spent the whole time cleaning, but after a while I just felt normal... But functional!

I'm being totally honest right now. Try meditation if you haven't already. If that doesn't work because you think "uh yeah how exactly do I meditate?". Avoid passive meditation at first (the kind of meditation that requires you to _empty_ your mind which can be interesting with ADHD)  Try active meditation or even simpler: The guides breathing exercises from Wim Hof.  Trust me, as someone who's also mentally at 5 different dimensions and or places at the same time, this really helped me calm my mind down and allowed me to control my thoughts or _emptyness_ way more easily. :)

I just wanna say that the song at the beginning isn't realy fitting if you consider the lyrics-
also one with ADHD, these meds are effective when the target is a child with no experience with the body. For sensible and educated adults like we are now, it's more about experience and "artifacts" that we developed over the past 20+ years to cope with our bodies. I use scheduling apps to run multitask when working. take enough caffeine to help with boredom issues, and try to autopilot tasks when tired.  These meds will make the brain burn more energy, but we are used to having a faster pace in general. So these things may cause serious burnout or overfocus, resulting in headaches and extreme fatigue.

I took ADHD medicine for a few years. Well, it had possible side effects such as: Instant death, organ failure, headache, nausea, stomachache, migrane, sleep disturbance and much, much more. Also it was (allegedly) not able to make someone addicted. Well, that turned out to be one of the biggest lies in the world of medicine. Everytime I didn't take it I felt like absolute trash. My head hurt, I felt extremely nauseus (sometimes I would even throw up) and I was unable to do anything. So I just stopped taking them. Which was advised against, since just stopping to take them leads to organ faliure in many cases. In mine it luckily did not, but I was honestly ready to take the risk, since dying was more compelling than taking those meds for one more day.

BROOOOOO i feel so connected to you I was on all these medications but I was diagnosed very young so I don‚Äôt remember most of them but yeah medication is a journey. I got sent to the hospital because of bad reaction to medication because I fainted lol
Thanks for sharing your experience! I also have ADHD and medication has definitely been a good tool in my experience thus far. Do you know if the you were taking an Adderall instant release? If so, you may consider asking your doctor about the extended release (aka XR) version. It spreads the dose out over a longer period, so it's more like vivance, but you can take it in smaller doses. I have more mild/moderate ADHD symptoms, and I take 20mg of XR. It's also available in a 10mg form if you wanted to try it out on a lower dose. Then, you can double up to see if you like the feeling of 20 more or less.  You mentioned the ability to focus was gained when taking vivance, but you weren't able to select what to work on very well. I think this is actually really common for people with ADHD, myself included. The psychological term for being able to prioritize tasks is called executive function. ADHDers (in my experience) tend to have a very low EF. I think it's because we never got the chance to develop it, due to our brains never being able to focus in the first place.  I used to work in a job where I was basically in charge of my day, and I found that bullet journaling/writing a task list gave me a physical tool to use for task management. If helped to combat my lack of a strong executive function, and get through my day.   Medication is an excellent tool, but it takes some time to figure it out. It's totally cool not to take it as well. I know that exercise and physical activity can really help aid some people with ADHD with symptoms. I have found that when I go running frequently, I tend to feel less disconnected meant mentally. I think that's actually why I got diagnosed so late in life (21 for me). I played sports all the time growing up, but I'm college that really slowed down, and my symptoms became more prevalent. Now I'm 29, and I medicate and try to be active semi often.   Best of luck with your journey. I know it's tough, but it sounds like you're on the right track. I hope you find what works best for you
I love having ADHD because what other people are able to do for free and very effectively, i have to pay for and can do far less efectively. As a med student this was very insightful!
As a person who was a ward of the state for 9 years with ADHD. They tried every drug on me. Learning and practicing self-control is the only thing that works. Now, 40yo and I have no problem getting shit done. Drugs are just masks.
I think a problem stems from a misconception about meds, when I was first given meds as a child one thing that my keyworker made sure I was aware of was the fact that they were a TOOL rather than a FIX. That they would help me do shit, but at the end of the day I still had to take an active choice to do that thing. I think alot of people I've spoken to in the past have mentioned that "they didn't see any results" and then when I asked them the environment they were trying to work in it was one where there were SO many opportunities for them to get distracted, they just assumed that when they started taking the meds it would be impossible to get distracted. In my opinion you have to know yourself and your limits to be able to work WITH your meds to achieve the best outcome which means not placing yourself in a place where distractions are prominent. It also just takes time (I mean it took me about 3-4 years of experimenting) to understand what you can and cannot do with meds.
Oh Hey, I had a similar experience with dexies (similar to vivance). Kinda. It just made me feel like I was having a panic attack like all the time. I lasted on them for a month. A month of panic attack. Wild. Word for the wise, I lasted a month on dexies & I lasted 3 days on ritalin. That turned me into a sad little robot man who craved death, and I worked in a big scary factory with lots of dangerous machinery. Be careful taking new meds guys.

I'm no doctor so correct me if i'm wrong but being a person with ADHD, i think it might have been an evolved trait because of the advantages it gives in specific conditions: the biggest/main symptom of ADHD is that you notice EVERYTHING in a 20ish meter radius, and i mean E V E R Y T H I N G, this is often misunderstoud as just a lack of attention span when really how can you focus on your math if your brain is at the same time keeping track of the football match outside your window. In a survival situation, being constantly aware of your surroundings is extremely useful, for example nothing can sneak up on you be it animals or weather. So obviously evolving that capability is not out of the question, especially when most of the downsides are minimal when it comes to survival. Where thinking is just a combination of noise and windows error noises. That in addition with the constant need to move some part of my body because . . . ‚îê‚Å†(‚Å†¬¥‚Å†„Éº‚Å†ÔΩÄ‚Å†)‚Å†‚îå who knows but yeah, I wouldn't doubt that some people on the outside think I'm crazy. It took me way too long to find the right medication for me. I had an abysmal experience with adderall,  then some other drug that made me a zombie,  then eventually concerta. About 9 years on concerta and I couldn't feel happier and more normal now, but it was definitely a long process to find what tools worked for me. Your video was spot on, very relatable!
Also a little tip for ppl with ADHD that can't decide what task to start with! It's something I started to do if I have a lot of things and can't find where to jump in: Write everything down in a numbered list. Or at least like, whatever you can think of you need to do, it's chill to forget some stuff if it's not life threateningly important. Use RNG to decide on a task. Do the task it tells you to do. If you start and there's an obstacle in the way that you realize needs to be done first, do that and then do the RNG task. Repeat as much as you can stand to do. Marvel at your progress, no matter how small afterwards.

I just reduced stimuli till I had no choice but to focus on what I needed to do.   It was torture but after around 20 to 30 mins I just finished the thing.
I! Use Ritalin! For a 1-2 combo punch against my ADHD and my Narcolepsy cause  S t i m u l a t i o n. It helps, I can at least focus on the right task (or wrong task. But I can focus) without my thoughts getting turned into tv static. And it helps with the energy part. Because while my first dose doesn't make me super energized, it DOES give me enough of a push that I can trudge thru the first part of my day doing Tasks at work without my eyelids feeling like dry heavy weights full of sand. My second dose tho zooWEE it wakes me up and I can F O C U S focus. Like excited rat dog vibrating and getting tasks done because look brain we have energy!! We're awake!! WE HAVE AN ATTENTION SPAN THAT CAN PIVOT A NORMAL DEGREE TO DIFFERENT TASKS.  But the downside is, if I don't have obligations on a day (like my days off of work) that I HAVE to get up for no choice if I want to say, keep my job, or like a dr appointment to... keep my MEDS... The very act of waking up just enough to take the meds is like the hardest thing in my LIFE. So much so that it's not uncommon for me to sleep literally a full 24 hours and miss... Both my doses. Luckily if I have back to back days like this, I can usually at least wake up on the second day for one dose at the VERY minimum. But if it's one day off and then back to work the next day, then that day off is effectively wasted. Nothing gets done. If i'm lucky I got up to grab a snack before going back to bed an hour later.  >:/  Edit; I described to my dr that ritalin felt like.... Imagine you're in a cubicle with a rolling office chair. There's exactly enough room for you to work at the desk, but there are 3 walls. In front and on either side, that block everything out and you have no real... contact or concept of what's outside of this. (This is what both ADHD and Narcolepsy feel like to me.) There isn't enough room to turn around in your chair, so the only option would be to wheel backwards out of the cubicle and then get up. But someone put a small ledge behind you. Like an inch tall "wall", so getting your chair over that when you don't even have room to stand is an absolute hellish fight.  Ritalin was like someone took that ledge away. Like yeah when i'm in the cubicle things are kind of hard, but if I need to wheel backwards to change scenery even if just for a bit, I can. I can get up and go do something else before I come back to the tiny cubicle for whatever reason. It's not a cure, but it removes that handicap that locks me into place, just that tiny little ledge being removed is SO helpful.

i think i was accidentally given a shout out
"What do you think it'd sound like if we played 8 different trumpets at the same time" is the most accurate sentence I could say to describe ADHD XD.  Think of it this way: everyone has a display of twenty computers in their head of things going on.  An ordinary person can tune in to one screen and focus on it, but someone with ADHD just watches them ALL at the same time.  So instead of focusing on what the teacher is saying at the front of the classroom, you're wondering who's out walking in the hallway during class and why their shoes are so loud.

Obviously ur body gets used to it being there so once it's not there ur body does stuff in response but I feel like it wouldnt be as important with brain based meds. I was on anti-depressants to increase my appetite but once I felt I was eating enough I went cold turkey on the meds and had no negative effects. Concerta works for me. It helps improve my focus so I can do one task at a time while also reducing my hyperactivity. Personally, it feels like I can follow one train of thought. I have the ability to do my homework and be focused enough to learn like a neurotypical ^^; it's a little hard to explain. It also improves depression and rational thinking
Okay techincally adderall isn't meth, it's just amphetamines. Really dangerous taken at high doses recreationally, with a high risk of addiction. Pretty damn safe taken at Rx doses under a doctor's care--every person I know with ADHD who is on adderall has forgotten to take it sometimes lol. Ritalin and Adderall have been used longer than the vast majority of psych meds out there, and *taken as prescribed* have an excellent safety record.  Also: Desoxyn (which was on your list)? Is in fact actual meth.  Anyway: I wouldn't give up after trying two meds. Concerta and Ritalin are both methylphenidate, Concerta is just a long-release version.  I like Adderall (I feel more like *myself* on it) but Concerta made me feel like a zombie. My partner is the other way around. You really just don't know until you try them.  I'm glad you gave them a shot at all, though!
Symptoms of ADHD:   Impulsivity  Concentration issues  Hyperactivity  Lack of motivation  Disorganisation  Rejection sensitivity  Poor emotional regulation   Once medicated on Vyvanse (from personal experience):  Higher motivation - I get the feeling that I want to do something productive, which, without Vyvanse, I would just feel like doing nothing all day. Significantly boosted concentration - I can focus on literally anything I want to. If I want to study, listen to music, talk to someone, I am fully present. I do not get easily distracted. I studied for 6 hours yesterday without having any distractions or boredom, and it felt natural, not like a forced focus. My brain literally felt so much more fresh. I also feel much more social and happy. Sometimes I feel like talking for hours. Sometimes I get a strong feeling of euphoria and high energy that can last for the whole duration of the pill (up to 14 hours), or for just a few hours, but if I wanted to focus and study or do whatever I wanted to, I‚Äôd be able to. Although I feel like no two days are exactly the same on Vyvanse. One day might be more euphoric while the next day might be calm and just a day of focus and productivity and the next day I could be talking non stop and the day after that it could make me feel agitated for a few hours before allowing me to focus. Anyway this is just my experience with Vyvanse. At the lower dose (30mg) it was making me feel sleepy, so I increased the dose to 50mg and it is significantly better since it does what it is supposed to. The focus is amazing, and I feel awake, motivated, and much better emotionally. Emotions have definitely become less intense on the pill, with the exception of times when side effects like anxiety or aggression can come in, but they don‚Äôt last long. Overall, this pill is wonderful. Lost 5kg since I started taking it 3 weeks ago as well since I don‚Äôt feel hungry at all.

4:45 Context as a vyvanse taker: Vyvanse' active ingredient is Lisdexamphetamine, which as the name suggests is a type of Amphetamine. Meth, full name Methamphetamine, as the name also suggests, is also a form of Amphetamine salt. tldr both meth and Vyvanse are Amphetamines.

First off I absolutely love your videos, its exactly the kind of chaotic wholesomeness I absolutely love. Your videos always make me feel warm and Goofy even when my days are dark and depressed. I'm not filled with overwhelming dread like every other minute of the day when I watch your videos lol so thank you for all you do. ‚ò∫Ô∏è  The "Meth" part of Methamphetamine is actually the only thing Adderall and Methamphetamine DO NOT have in common. But Adderall is just a pure amphetamine and Methamphetamine is just like it sounds, an amphetamine but with more stuff in it lmao. Adderall or amphetamine is basically a weaker form of it. It isn't exactly as simple as that chemically but essentially Methamphetamine is a Rambo version of amphetamines. But don't underestimate the severity of amphetamines on their own. Amphetamines are incredibly addictive and can cause lots and lots of bad symptoms and side effects. Those symptoms and side effects are just multiplied by 100x with Methamphetamine because it's so much more powerful.  Coming from someone that was prescribed Adderall all through highschool for ADHD and then became addicted to Methamphetamine directly after graduation and have still been using it daily since then. I honestly think giving a chubby depressed teenager unsupervised access to a huge bottle of pills that made me feel good lose weight and get shit done was a recipe for disaster and was probably a huge factor in my meth addiction as an adult. I definitely think Adderall needs to be controlled by a parent if given to minors because I started abusing it like only 3 months after I started taking it. I eventually was up to max dose of 40mg a day but was taking 3 pills a day. Giving teens unsupervised access to medication that strong should literally be criminalized. At the time I was super happy I didn't need my mom in the room or her to have control of my pills but looking back at it now I desperately wish the doctor would've talked to my mom about how serious it was and that she gave me my pill everyday. Amphetamines while they aren't meth are still very very dangerous to play with if you have an addictive personality. Not to mention that your perception of Adderall will stop helping your ADHD is you abuse it. A week of abusing a recreational substance or your prescription is literally all it takes to condition your brain to NEED it. I'm 24 years old and have been abusing amphetamines or Methamphetamines for 11 years.. 7 of which I was abusing my legal prescription. Sorry this comment was so long. Just please be careful to the people that actually read this far please. Don't make the same mistakes I've made please. I've ruined my life.

Crazy that seemingly everyone in the comments has ADHD..... I don't want to be that guy that gatekeeps disorders (that would be very cringey, especially since I don't think I have ADHD myself), but with everything being written here I think it should be noted that not being able to focus and having an active mind is not necessarily ADHD. With that in mind, it's probably also preferable to try to fix an issue through determination and hard work rather than just medication, if possible, especially since addiction can happen, and increased demand for these pills increases the price for those that truly need them.
7:18 Oh ADHD meds are perfectly fine to stop taking at any time.  You don't have to wean yourself on/off them, you can literally stop and start IMMEDIATELY.  Even when u change from one med to another - u can just take the full dose of one med one day then the next day take the full dose of a completely different med.  They're not like other psychiatric medications that u have to slowly increase/decrease.    I skip days all the time.    (Disclaimers:  Yes i have ADHD, no i'm not a doctor, my prescribing psychiatrist basically told me the above when i was changing meds)  Also yeah it sounds like your meds were maybe fucking with your sleep (thus your constant & growing exhaustion), it's a common side effect that psychs look out for. How I explain my experience with ADHD & meds: it was like trying to run a marathon but not being able to make any progress. So I would look online for advice, but even the helpful for-adhd-people advice started out with, ‚Äúput one foot in front of the other.‚Äù   Unfortunately, I am (metaphorically speaking) missing a foot. So all of that advice was simply not useful to me, even though it was good advice.    For me, medication is like a false foot. It will never be as good as a real foot, but at the very least now I can start to implement the other helpful advice and make a bit more progress.   Is it possible to run a marathon on crutches? Absolutely, and many have done it. But at this particular point in time, for my particular combination of needs, a false (if imperfect) foot is what I need.   PS- Just Work Harder is not helpful advice. Could I hobble along unmedicated? Yes, I tried that for the first 30 years of my life. All it did was make me extremely depressed. I hated myself because I was Trying Really Really Hard and I was still sitting at the start line wondering why my missing foot wasn‚Äôt working like everyone else‚Äôs were.   (I am now on Adderall and a mild anti-anxiety med. Adderall gets rid of most of the brain fog and gives me a little better motivation to do things, and the anti-depressant gets rid of the little voice in my head telling me that everyone else thinks I‚Äôm a terrible person. Remember, ADHD can cause a lot of side-issues like anxiety and depression, and it‚Äôs very reasonable to decide to try medication for those instead/as well, since both of those ALSO make it harder to initiate difficult tasks. ;>.>)
Ritalin on top üòé
As someone who has been taking meds for adhd on and off for almost 30 years I have some advice that the psychs don‚Äôt often relay. It take time to find what‚Äôs right for you. I went through 4-5 different meds until I found what worked and even then the negative symptoms lead me to taking a break entirely from meds for a few years. They also don‚Äôt often mention the power and necessity of supplements that counter a lot of the negative side effects. I used to have zero appetite and exhausted at the end of the day after being on Ritalin. But supplementing with b, magnesium and zinc I have almost no negative symptoms and have been more productive than ever in my life.
If medication doesn't help, or the side effects are too much for you, I've heard cognitive behavioral therapy can really help people with adhd

Got diagnosed as an adult. What I've learned is that with ADHD meds, if its a task that you're unmotivated to do then the meds does not magically make you do it. It just makes it easier to do the task when you are motivated or incentivised to do the task and stay focused on it. Found that out real quick.
I also take Vyvanse and I can totally relate to the experience. For me or better said in the intended way, the meds are only one of the many tools. Especially with Vyvanse it‚Äòs super Important to also use learned tools, like awareness of the moment and meditation. Adhd is extremely complex and the pills just seem to be the enabler for us to get stuff done but to ‚Äûgain control‚Äú of what to do other tools are needed. Structure is a pain but can really help aswell as accepting that Adhd has different needs than a neurotypical brain. It takes a lot of time to get used to and there isn‚Äòt a magical pill witch just let‚Äòs you be normal, but with therapy and the use of this many tools, medication or others, it‚Äòs possible to find a way

My experience w/ Vyvance. 1: Blood pressure approaches hudraulic press levels. Despite my being balanced fine w/ 3 other blood pressure meds to begin with and that not supposed to be a thing it can do. I tried this a handful of times. High blood pressure makes my skin feel funny, and changes how I perceive temperatures. No other documented short term effects, though the nurse taking my BP that first time might have suffered a very brief cardiac arrest. ü§î 2: ICS mentions the staying-in-focus deal, and this is true for me as well. My problem is that I "nope" out of focus of things sometimes with or without meds. Without sometimes I wander back but  w/ Vyvance, I derail smoothly into a different path and then just don't come back. 3: The withdrawal effects I recorded (again, a handful of different times) were crazy strong emotions of being rejection sensitive, and largely doing my best to verbalize and/or compose poems about the subjective experience thereupon (and/or argue with ppl, you know :P)
I use Concerta
I take vyvanse 30mg and you can tell when it kicks in. Your heart beats a little bit faster, and you start to focus a lot. Your palms sweat a little bit, and you sometimes focus too much and forget what you wanted to do in the first place. The task gets done, you are productive, but it just takes a really long time. At the end of the day, the meds wear off just enough to focus enough and still be productive. You also are never that hungry, so eat a really good breakfast before taking it.

The doctor had my sleep meds grow in Mg because it wasn‚Äôt working, but my morning meds started to hurt me and I started to have bad headache to the point where all my thought were so loud, mixing with the sounds of a busy school. I've had ADD (inattentive) as a child and grew up stupidly smart and have insane information retention but also graduated out of the bottom of my class and got academic suspension in my first year of college from pretty much doing... nothing. I've also suffered a ton with anxiety and inadequacy from having a ton of work but failing to find the executive function to do it. Adderall didn't help me as a child for that same reason you mention but what I've found has had at least some success for me, personally, is just drinking caffeinated beverages and keeping caffeine in my system as I work. Not a lot, mind you, but like, a mug of tea in the morning and two 20oz sodas (I've switched to Coke Zero to save on calories) over the course of the work day.  One of the things I hate about mind-affecting medications like ADD, alcohol, cannabis, and others is that I'm wholly used to having a mind that doesn't shut up, and I don't want the little guy up there to be quiet, because it doesn't feel right to me. And caffeine doesn't do that, but it helps keep inner Rob focused and motivated. I still get distracted occasionally but like, it's been enough where I'm actually able to hold down a job and not have as much issues as I used to with punctuality and workplace performance.

My ADHD medication literally almost gave me a heart attack. So I was laying down and suddenly I really a sharp pain in my chest. And so I check my heart beat and it was PUMPING FASTER THAN EVER. Next thing I know I'm laying in bed for 5 HOURS until it finally stopped. üò¨
I can't say whether my experience is common or not, but my doctor put me on Wellbutrin a couple years ago and it was life changing. I've always had problems with focusing, ignoring distractions, and saving money. I'm glad to say that I've got a job I like, I'm able to focus and plan ahead, and best of all I can save money for the future. Wellbutrin is a non stimulant, so the effects are much more subtle than stimulants like Adderall. That also means that it can't fix all my problems on its own. I know that doesn't sound good, but I really appreciate how I have the option to focus or not if I want to. If I had to explain the feeling, it's like I normally have 5 voices in my head at the same time. When I'm on my meds, 2 out those voices are taken out and 2 more are a little quieter. I still have to work to focus entirely on one thing, but since I'm used to dealing with 5, this is way easier in comparison. Again, I can't know if it can be good for anyone other than myself. But it is at least worth talking about with your doctor if stimulants are making you feel like you can't control the focus or if you feel like a zombie when you take them. I hope this helps someone

honestly, the more i hear about other peoples experience with adhd meds, the more thankful I am that me and my psych found a good match first try. granted, i was diagnosed with clinical depression, ptsd, and a major anxiety disorder way before being diagnosed with adhd so she recommended welbutrin because its known to help with anxiety as well as being an off label adhd medication. it took a little adjusting to it at first but honestly ive never been happier. i still struggle keeping thoughts in order and staying on task but its like a fog was cleared out of my brain. im not able to stay focused on one thing very well but i am able to manage how much distraction i allow myself. on top of that, things going wrong or being forgotten isnt the end of the world like it once was. If i forgot something, then whenever i eventually remember I'm not pinned under a crushing panic nor am i so scattered that the reminder gets lost again right away.   don't get be wrong, if you are able to manage yourself off meds then thats fantastic. but sometimes the medication is just that extra step people need and its just a matter of finding the balance that matches up with your brain juice. its just important to remember that the meds dont fix you, thats not what they are there for. they are just there to help you with some of the funky brain juices that we can't really control.   tldr: if you have meds, remember to take them. if you feel like you need them, dont be afraid to try. if you feel like its not working for you, thats perfectly fine you just need a different approach. adhd has no and does not need a cure. its just about managing symptoms and behaviors as best you can.

Man you've put a bunch of stuff that I couldn't explain into words.   A bit of advice, and take it as you might any off the internet, but you might wanna try giving the adderall another shot. I'm on Vyvanse myself and have been for about 3 years now, and I'm still learning how to adjust myself, how to apply my focus and all that jazz. Habits form slowly and learning how to *think* comes much slower. For example, I'm a university student and while I saw a noticeable boost in my grades the term I started the meds, that was just because I was able to consistently do the assignments. Years of self reflection and adjustment later and now I'm a honour roll student because I've since learned how to apply my focus to study, take notes, and even do independent research!  Whatever you decide though, isn't is such a damn relief to know that you're not just lazy?

It's also not so much a direct solution, but it helps me with executive functioning that has a ripple effect, like I'll be better at staying nourished and hydrated and taking care of myself which gives me a better foundation to work through other challenges like focusing on work tasks and keeping track of life admin and housekeeping.

I have adhd and I was medicated like him but instead of the amount he‚Äôs taking I was taking 80 milligrams of Vyvanse
As a medical student who just finished pediatrics rotation, I have seen MANY kids with ADHD. The key with medications is *~titration~* (AKA finding the medication and dose that works best). It's important to go in knowing that these medications won't cure but rather that they're designed to help. these medications will also have side effects (e.g. problems with sleep, lack of appetite, nausea, and dizziness). And, as you mentioned with Vyvanse, it may have an intended effect that's *too* strong. That's where a specialist doctor, like a pediatrician or psychiatrist comes in as they have seen HUNDREDS of patients and have a pretty decent insight into "oh, you're suffering this side effect, maybe let's change your dose to this" or "maybe let's add on this other medication" (e.g. melatonin to help with sleep) or "maybe let's change the dose timing" (e.g. having medications AFTER meals and long before bedtime so that the side effects of loss of appetite and difficulty with sleep is reduced). As you mentioned, Vyvanse works a totally different way to 5mg daily of Adderall, and it's a pretty hardcore transition. You basically went from the initiation soft-core medication to the other extreme without trying any of the intermediate options. I'm surprised your psychologist didn't offer up any intermediate options or try and educate you on the options available. The big moral of the story is to consult your doctor if you're not getting the intended effect and that medications will take a while to sort out which dose and schedule works best for you.   Finally, some NON-medical advice. Another anecdote from being a medical student is a lot of my classmates take these stimulant medications to help with their studies. This is regardless of whether they have ADHD or not. When taking a more hardcore stimulant like Vyvanse, the word of advice is to *be prepared* when you take it. Remove all possibilities for distraction except "Task A". Eat very well beforehand because God knows when the next time you'll be hungry again. Remove distractions that may come up between you and the water/toilet. My friends would create a "study zone" - they'd add a blocker to their PC to ensure no access to Facebook/games etc. They'd put their phone in another room/give it to me and turn off notifications. They'd sit in a dark ass room lit only by candles and with no windows. And they'd tell me "don't speak to me or even look at me on this day - it's my study day". This may help you stop having the 'peaks and troughs" when using Vyvanse.
I have ADHD and I've never medicated for it. I will often go through the day thinking of things to do later and when later comes my mind is either distracted or lost in thought about some trivial curiosity far removed from anything important (Like how do crab mouths work?) But I also tend to hyperfocus on tasks I am currently engaged in, and this keeps me very productive. As long as I start what I know I should do the moment it enters my brain, I'm good. Otherwise, it's a task for tomorrow me.

I was dignosed with ADHD 2 years into university and let's just say I had a Bad Time with schoolwork before that. I've been on Vyvanse for like a year and a half and wow...the ability to do things and focus on things...amazing. It's significantly helped with my schoolwork and ability to focus on doing what needs to be done and initiating chores and such. However, I find if I don't want to do something b/c I'm burnt out or tired then the meds don't really help or they focus me on something that I shouldn't be doing. Idk it's a rough trade-off, but so so so much better than sitting on my phone or computer all day thinking about all the things I need to do and being so immensely guilty and screaming at myself to do them and just not being able to do them. Yo, this is relatable. Been on ADHD meds since I was like 7. Currently working on a bachelors in Mechanical Engineering, and BOY OH BOY do the meds help. Been on something called Methylphenidate (NOT METH) for several years, it stops the physical stuff (unable to complete tasks) and helps with focus, a lot. IDK exactly how to describe it, bit off meds sitting in school felt like 15 hours, and on them it feels like time passes at a normal rate, so the classes feel shorter and it's easier to focus. Like, I can still tell that I have ADHD, but it feels less like I just drank 10 cups of coffee. More like 1 cup. That, and one of the things I do now is get a song stuck in my head for several days in a row. Consistently. Not really annoying, just strange.

I consider ADHD a super power for me. I alot time blocks for grouped tasks and allow myself to flow freely between these tasks until the time is done. I'm also very hyperactive so I work multiple "part time" jobs instead of one full time job.  If I have the correct environment to work in during the correct time block I'm super productive and can work much longer hours than anyone I know.
The "This is how its like to think with ADHD" Portion was well done. My brain never shuts up and constantly throws me for loops when I need to focus.   One of my key things I have found that helps besides meds is asking a friend to help. They can literally be just sitting in the room with you, or on the phone, and suddenly my brain goes WE HAVE FOCUS NOW LETS DO STUFFFFF WE HAD PLANNED!!  The only downside is that if the friend was there to actually hang out with you and not just to fix your executive dysfunction, you can potentially toss them aside with a "Oh yeah sure thing, let me just get this thing done real quick" and the focus takes over and you forget they are even there.

i have ADHD too and am currently on meds so here's some advice if you want it :D so i started out with short-acting meds, or meds that start working quickly but don't last that long and i was taking ritalin, which actually worked for me very well but because of school i then moved onto long-acting meds, which are meds that take a little longer to work but work for longer and i was and currently am taking concerta. both actually worked really well for me and have had little to no side effects so i recommend you try them if you're looking to go back on meds (though this is only my experience and it could be different for you)

this was uploaded on the exact day I got my first ADHD meds
Quick note on vyvanse, those symptoms you had are common during a loading phase, usually lasts a week or two and you eventually get accustomed to the meds, its your brain getting shocked as its not used to the proper amount of dopamine and norepinephrine levels you should have and now that you do have them your brain needs a little to get used to it. Think of it like a new pair of shoes, they don't ever quite feel right until you've worn them for a while.
So what you really need is someone constantly watching over your shoulder and forcing you to go back to work when you get unfocused

As someone who grew up with ADD and having medication, Adderall was a strange period in my life. Probably from elementary school (I‚Äôm not sure when I started it, maybe 2nd grade) till towards the end of junior year. Over the years, I would have to have the Adderall meds be notched up since I would get used to it and would need the medication to work‚Ä¶ well‚Ä¶ Stronger. and everytime I DIDNT take the meds, I seriously COULD NOT FOCUS. So distracted by everything. It effected my grades. And the medication DID help but‚Ä¶ it completely changed who I was as a person. Like‚Ä¶ personality wise and appetite. I‚Äôm a very outgoing person (even if shy or not that much of a people person). But the medication would make me just‚Ä¶ be there. Not really doing anything other than the focusness. I wouldn‚Äôt have any jokes or have fun or laugh or anything. And learning that Adderall could give me heart problems later in my life was a big thing for me to slowly take pills every couple of days in junior year and then just stop using it in senior year. (I agree ICS, do not just STOP taking it. Please see a doctor or something beforehand.) it Was a struggle for that final year but I pulled through. I don‚Äôt take anymore medication and I‚Äôve learned to get through the days a lot better. But that‚Äôs just my story on the matter.
-this is not hate or a lecture on anyone i just feel like sharing-  important to note that medication should coincide with building skills to manage your symptoms. that‚Äôs not just going to be taking pills and willing yourself to be neurotypical, you kind of have to learn how you learn and like work medication in or out however is best for you (consult ur psychiatrist before changing ur medication routine duh). an example of those ‚Äúskills‚Äù in my life is that i‚Äôve kinda learned how to divide my attention perfectly, freshman year i would listen to audiobooks for book assignments and play a videogame that i could kinda zone out of partially to take in the book. i don‚Äôt really get assignments like that anymore, i‚Äôm just expected to read for like 20 minute periods sometimes and my medication + focus music works well for that. but like u gotta try fidget toys and alarms and stimming and all that stuff and get to know what works for u. this process should be ENTIRELY about being your healthiest and being able to take care of/support yourself, not being normal enough for other people.

I am at a decent place with managing my ADHD now, and I'm largely unmedicated. I have Adderall (NOT XR!!) to take on days where I need to do a lot of reading or writing, but otherwise I have adapted by making lifestyle changes that accommodate the way I think.   I've taken Strattera and Adderall XR before (as well as a host of other meds for other conditions), and even though they were helpful in some ways, they were harmful in others. The meds didn't help in all the ways I needed help, and they really messed with my sleep, migraine frequency, and appetite. It was really frustrating, and I've definitely taken meds for longer than I should because I wanted them to work so bad. I don't know. I really appreciate this video ;_;

This is my exact current situation, except... the meds' most noticeable effect on me was absolutely killing my appetite. So when on meds, I would be slightly more focused, but bc I was barely eating, I always was tired and unfocused and moody anyway, on top of slight anxiety. So it just cancelled out any benefits. I recently stopped taking stimulants entirely and for the first few weeks was RAVENOUS. Like eating nonstop.... but I felt great. I had energy. I felt more present and balanced. My motivation and focus was about the same... but physically and emotionally I felt more stable. It's starting to even out now, and I'm returning to my normal weight, but I'm pretty sure the sudden overwhelming appetite was bc I was basically starving for years. So for me, being well fed is just as effective and healthier for my general health as taking meds is. I still have a few different meds I can try, but if they kill my appetite like the others I've tried in the past, I doubt they'll help me. So yeah back at square one.

Just to clear out, ADHD is an attention deficit paired with hyperactivity. Hyperactivity you have a lot of energy and it's hard for you to stand still. Most articles also state that you can't think about work, but that's not really 100% true. I personally just can't focus on tasks that I find to be irrational, or boring. That being said it is extremely easy to entertain me. I have fun doing chores, like doing the dishes.  Now let's set a scenario: I need to read a book for school, but it's just really boring and already starting to read the book, I know where the story is going and what kind of message it's trying to convey, so I feel stupid having to go through that shit. I'll keep reading for a bit and then I'll realize, I have been reading, but I have not been taking in the information, I have no clue what is happening, who these new characters are, what the main character is talking about, so I have to re read it and this time try harder to pay attention. But it pains me. It's so shit, after few scenes, without even noticing I start thinking about about something completely unrelated. And if you didn't kno, the attention deficit works for both ways. You can be too easily distracted, but you can also be too focused. I personally get hyperfocused really easily on things that are interesting to me. So pair my hyperactive syndromes with hyperfocus, and as a result in my thoughts I'm completely gone to another dimension. I forget what I was doing, I forget time, all I think about is that random mildly interesting thing topic that somehow just popped up in my head. Now I have spent 2 h with the book in my hands and still didn't read shit, except maybe the first page. So I'm to myself like: I can't concentrate right now, imma play some video games and read this later. So I start playing video games. Again, hyperfocuse. I completely forget everything else, all I'm thinking about is the game I'm playing. And oops, it's already 12 pm and I should definitely go sleep. And of course after my intense focus on something completely unrelated to the book, I have completely forgotten the books existence.  That is my experience with ADHD. Hope it was interesting.  Also just realizing, I took over half an hour just to write this comment, it is 1:21 pm I should sleep by now. Just another example of my hyperfocuse.
ain‚Äôt nothing like getting yelled at by your parents because you can‚Äôt retain information or focus on a taskü•≤

If I take less medication, my overall work quality is worse but if I take a higher dose there are huge side effects such as sweating and headaches. That's kind of where I ended up with meds and ADHD. I tried a bunch and they all helped in ONE specific area but it was different for each one. In the end I gave up on meds because I could either be sometimes sort of productive in all of the way without them or ONLY productive in ONE way EVER with them. I got the wormbo combo of anxiety, adhd, and autism, all giving different effects AND boosting each others
It's so interesting to hear your opinion on this.  I'm German and apparently ADHD medications are handled differently here. I can take them whenever I need them, so if I know I'll be studying, having appointments, doing important stuff I'll just take the meds in the morning - I have some that only last for half a day and some that last for the whole day.  It also is advised to use the meds mainly to establish routines that work for you. How long can I concentrate, what do I need for it? Do I need an alarm clock to help me remember doing a specific task? A visible clock and planned-out time management are helpful. Having ADHD, we tend to not develop these supportive mechanisms. When we take meds, we'd suddenly have the brain capability, but don't know how to utilize it. You can have the best machines available but still couldn't build a house if you just don't know how to use the machines. Medications are NOT the only solution. In the best case, you have therapy alongside to help you figure everything out.

i was put on wellbutrin for about a year (i also have bipolar) and it was fine, better than baseline, but it kinda felt like if too much built in my system after a while i would start seeing shit and feeling really off, like my vision would be blurry or my eyes would hurt, and the tinnitus was insanely loud. i've been on 150, 300, and 450. 300 was where i was at for a while, and then i noticed that if i took a break every few weeks and let my baseline kinda lower (i found this out by accident by forgetting to take it), i would feel a little bit better. today i am feeling like there might be something better for me as i still struggled to do things and the side effects were starting to effect me more negatively. i really wanted to try vyvanse.   if i had any advice it would be this: a lot of people will often need a combo of meds. that's why it's important to be consistent with seeing your psych. i would be curious if the combination of vyvanse with something else would have helped you. or a combination of adderall with something else. etc. that's the annoying part -- i'm a year in and still trialing different meds. abilify, prozac, seroquel. etc to help manage my bipolar and adhd.

Adderall worked GREAT but made me an irritable monster. Much like your description of really wanting the meds to work and ignoring symptoms, it took me a long time to realize I was being a monster AND that it was the meds. I don't have the best self-awareness, it turns out, and sometimes being a jerk FEELS like standing up for yourself. :/  Strattera gave me crippling stomach pains, that one was easy to figure out and quit. Vyvanse gave me the ability to focus, but I still had to choose what to focus on. It is a bit of a gamble, but by and large I still found myself much more capable of getting on task and completing tasks.  And then my insurance decided I didn't need Vyvanse. I've experienced the same thing with anxiety and depression meds. It was YEARS before I found the right combination of meds that worked with my body and allowed me to function.
Adderall is amphetamines, which is speed, not meth.  And Vyvanse is Lisdexamfetamine, which is basically an amphetamine precursor that your body turns into amphetamines at its own metabolic rate.  Both of them are drugs that can technically be abused recreationally, but most drug users think people who do speed for fun are a bit weird.

Vyvanse made me fixate on thoughts, but also helped the anxiety on those thoughts, so it made me super unproductive...Adderall gives me the boost to be proactive on adjusting my environment for productivity, so it works very well for me. Both of them sorta "quiet the static in my head" where the thoughts are clearer and more streamlined, so it's easier to control my train of thought.  When I was first medicated, my doctor prescribed me Focalin, and this was an absolute nightmare. My impulsivity control was somehow MUCH worse, and I definitely experienced a lot of paranoia, causing me to make SO MANY questionable decisions for my life. The worst part is that, because it also cleared the static, I had no clue how detrimental it was for my mental health. I thought it was helping because I could focus better, but had no clue how it affected my psychological state. I'd be really interested in hearing other people's experiences with Focalin tbh

Same hat! I‚Äôve been on adderall since early 2021. Half the battle is meds, the other half is re-training your brain. Your brain has gone it‚Äôs whole life not practicing sticking to things, so your neurons have gotten hard wired that way. I think of training my brain like training a dog. Be consistent (lol I know that sounds impossible, but you can get help from an accountability partner for that) Give yourself treats when you make even a little progress, and be kind to yourself when you make mistakes. It takes a while to get to ‚Äòfunctioning adult level‚Äô even with meds. You have to mindfully practice sticking to stuff.  Try problem solving when you have a mental block about a task. Ask yourself ‚Äòwhy am I avoiding this task?‚Äô If it‚Äôs boring, play music. If you think it‚Äôs gonna take forever, time yourself like it‚Äôs a race. You were able to do the chores and stuff, but not sit down and do work. That‚Äôs because the stakes behind chores are low. Work has higher stakes, and so to avoid the anxiety or pressure, you procrastinate because it‚Äôs a learned coping mechanism. You still have ADHD when you‚Äôre taking medication, so stuff like hyperfocusing on the wrong thing can still happen while on them, and that‚Äôs normal. You just have to learn how to catch yourself, or ask someone to help you keep from getting sucked into rabbit holes. You were so close when you said you just need to build your habits! It took me a year and a half to build a morning routine after getting on meds. And on average it takes people about two months, but up to over 200 days to fully form a habit. You also shouldn‚Äôt try to form too many habits at once because then they won‚Äôt stick as well. Also, that yucky feeling you got might be from having too high of a dose, which can happen if you‚Äôre not taking the meds at the same time every day, and accidentally overlapping. Also, are you drinking coffee or energy drinks with it? If so, stop that. I‚Äôve never taken Vyvanse before, but I have a friend (who is also an animator!) who takes it and it works for them. Everyone‚Äôs body reacts differently. You‚Äôd probably be fine getting back on adderall and just working on some CBT (Cognitive behavioral therapy) There are also ADHD life coaches you can hire specifically for this.

Insightful indeed! Weed tends to help me, but that's mostly with depression symptoms rather than ADHD. I am more productive if I feel good though, so it certainly helps that way. If you look into treating anything this way, you'll wanna try a bunch of different strains and methods of consumption to narrow down what helps most, but it's very worth it given I have never dealt with side effects to any noticeable degree. It's honestly surreal to be smoking like a chimey most days and feel no reduced capacity to run, hike and bike at high altitude.

30yo ADHD guy here. Some advice - find a profession or exercise routine that exhausts your body. When your body is tested the mind becomes clear, in my experience anyway. I do a lot of personal creative work, but my corporate job was tearing my soul apart because I would stagnate over all my very boring tasks. I never had mental power left for my own projects.  Switching to a physical profession allows you to destroy your idle thoughts and unproductive tangents. It‚Äôs much easier to gamify.  Good luck y‚Äôall.

I even get that shortness of breath, maybe once a day at ~3 hours after take my med.  It does miss the mark a tad on physically getting up an doing something like how the Adderall experience is described, but I've thankfully never had any real problems with Vivance.

I have found that body doubling has got to be the most effective way to do things for me without getting as harmfully distracted. However, that person needs to actually be somewhat helpful for the task at hand.  Some people have the impression at medication magically fixes everything, it doesn't work like that for most people though, it usually just reduces some of the symptoms of ADHD and the exact symptoms it helps and the strength of the help varies person to person. I found a good way to reduce the side effects of my medication for me was to sometimes have "cool down" days which I don't take it on and I'll just commit to not being committed. I will usually take vitamins on those days to help quickly restore my energy. I personally don't get withdrawal symptoms for basically any stimulate I have ever tried so my technique won't work for everyone, but it's what I do at least.
Great explanation of your experience! I used Concerta for 19 months, loved it, stopped for $$$ reasons, can't wait to ask for Vyvanse. I used it for one month and it was so great for me! Being off medication currently is so another eye-opening experience for me. Here's why: Taking meds will not change your habits, it helps you change them. Having a routine helps a lot, and it's hard to create one without them. You are not lazy, you just have low dopamine. Eat plenty of protein and PRIORITIZE SLEEP. Days where my sleep is great are easier to focus. 6 or less hours of sleep, I'm useless.

I got diagnosed in my early twenties and Adderall has worked for me, for the most part. I always describe it as the medication lowers the bar/threshold for the effort I have to use to complete tasks. It doesn't remove it but it makes it way easier to do anything at all. It also keeps me awake and alert during the day, which is extra helpful because without it I am sluggish and fatigued even if I haven't done anything. It hasn't solved everything but there's no one solution that fits every person so I'm still working out the kinks, lol.

Hi! As someone that had ADHD throughout my entire childhood I can relate to this video. At the age of eight I started taking Vyvanse. Vyvanse is also supposed to be a medication for people trying to loose weight, as well as focus. So in the early 2000's lil ole me taking it, I wasn't aware how bad it can effect you at a very young age. I took it all the way up to highschool. Where I stopped due to not eating. Because the medication made me feel like I didn't want to eat, I just focused. I went to the ER twice due to passing out and having convulsions. After being off medication after a few years it's been better. But it makes you a completely different person so please be wise for anyone who takes medication and do some homework on it.

This was very fun to watch, I've struggled with ADHD my entire life (as most ADHD people do ;p). I remember being on medication for ADHD, although I don't remember what they're called because I was like 12 when I stop taking it and I really never cared because my mom was always "TAKE THIS NOW" and my poop brain was like "Okay! ;D", it had a major toll on me growing up because I started taking it at a very young age, around 5 or 6 I believe, yes it helped me a lot to focus when I needed too but it also had a lot of other side effects. When I would take it, I would completely lose my appetite and this would affect my weight gain until I would have stopped taking it when I was 12 I weight at most 90 pounds, and as soon as I stop taking it, I gained around 30 pounds. A lot of people don't understand that this medicine doesn't just make you calm down and focus, it has a lot of side effects that come with it and can be different for everyone. I'm 24 now, so I've been off of it for over half my life and I'm glad to be off of it because I remember being on it, I would sometimes just become a zombie and have no emotions, or I said I'd lose my appetite. ADHD is a real struggle, but I've learned to live with it every day and try to control it, I don't need medicine to do that for me.  Idk why I wrote this, I felt like I had to? idk... potatoes.

Also went on meds. I was young (around 10) so I don't remember much but I remember some of the side effects.   First one was dry skin, and I mean dry. My lips would crack and my hands would peel much like when you put glue on them and they dry. Being young I didn't have time to lotion up each day or remember.   Second meds made me bloated. Lost a lot of weight in the two months I was on it and was taken off them pretty fast. Just didn't eat lunch and barely ate breakfast.   Last medication....I don't remember. Which says something because my parents said I was like a whole different person. I was better in terms of attention and memory. But I just wasn't the same. I have no memory of my time on those meds. They noticed it when they asked me if I wanted to go play out in the rain (something I love to do). I apparently made a face and said "eww why would I do that?". Which tipped them off.   I haven't been on meds since and just learnt ways to help myself, with help from my family and doctors. I still have problems with memory and focusing but it's gotten better as I've grown up.
Ok...I was in the middle of typing out a story explaining my experience a little bit when my browser crashed, and I really don't feel like doing it again so I'm just gonna say this. There's a DNA test that tells you what medications would be best for you based on your genes. It worked for me...after years of trial and error with my medicine-resistant depression. I would suggest giving that a shot. I really hope you find the right one for you.

I take both straterra and ritalin. You should consider trying both stimulant and nonstimulant medications, its what's worked for me and many others. Ritalin at too high of a dose gives me heart palpitations but I can take it with little issue at 10 mg while still having the positivie effects. The nonstimulant med meanwhile helps with regulation/consistency.

I was prescribed vyvanse around 5 years ago and to say that he‚Äôs right about too much focus would be an understatement but ADHD is about learning moderation, it‚Äôs half the battle to have control of the present. controlling your future through routines and good habits is the biggest issue most people with adhd face and there‚Äôs no cookie cutter solution you have to find your balance while also looking ahead, goals help! Little and big, they are what should drive you from where you are to where you wanna be
I have ADHD and pretty severe, this only my experience but Vyvanse sucked for me. It was supposed to keep me focused but it didn‚Äôt work, all it did was make me feel nauseous and not want to eat. Of course this shouldn‚Äôt keep anyone from wanted to try using it, but make sure to talk to a doctor and research how much it‚Äôs side affects might effect you. Vyvanse also doesn‚Äôt pair well with mood disorders as the medication can cause, extreme irritation and agitation, again, make sure to always talk to your doctor to see if a medication is right for you.

I think my dad takes Vyvanse and swears by it but I don't take anything.  From my unmedicated experience the best thing you can do it set up you environment to work for you. Try some different things and remember that just because some thing works for "everybody" doesnt mean it *has* to work for you.  Something I found that helps a lot is thinking of your brain not like a fish on a line that you have to pull it in with all your might but like a horse on a lead you gently nudge to the right direction. The horse can still say "forget you! I just want to watch youtube all day!" but if you loosen your grip and say "Ok what about youtube about x thing you need to work on?" and then you see it and you want to work on it. Idk if that make any sense but that's how i try and do it.
