I basically had the same experience. Ritalin worked for me. I was way more productive and could focus. But it ruined my mood and made my depression stronger. Didn't want it to be true as they were helping me to focus so I denied any negative symptoms until I could only focus on my depression ':D
I was diagnosed SUUPER late, and I'm very glad that I already either figured out a workaround or simply survived everything from birth to 30 without this knowledge because knowing I have ADHD was never a crutch: I just did what I had to do, even if I sucked at it. Now that I know, I have a much better understanding about *how* to figure out my workaround. I'm also working with a doctor of functional medicine to deal with the stuff that is physically contributing to how severe my adhd symptoms are. Picture a computer with a lot of dust inside it and which overheats, even though the fan is running, because the accumulative dust is trapping more heat and the computer was already performing on the high end of it's operating temperatures. I won't go into more detail here, but it's really helped! Subtly, but just like... my executive function has improved dramatically. My dopamine "MPGs" are noticably higher, too. I don't *feel* better, I just *do* more... like a standard healthy brain would. It's a wild ride.

Ok, so, I did take some medication for some time too (medikinet, if it rings a bell for anyone) but I had quite the same experience as what you had with the second drug you tried. Too much focus and heavy backlash afterwards (though it was heavy fatigue and weakness, to the point where I had shaky legs every day after work) so, I stopped that.  That's also when I found out, and that might sound stupid, that coffee had the exact same effect on me, but in a much more manageable way. The hyperfocussing effect is lowered and the fatigue diminished.   Talked about it to my doctor and he said it was believable that it could be a thing.   Now, I try to limit my consumption because the effects will wear out over time, the window of effectiveness has lowered from about 6 hours to about 3 or 4 after a few years now but it helps me and maybe it could help you too :)

i hate and love having adhd, cause it's literally a Russian roulette, you can have a day that you look through it and think: "wow, that was an experience* but then there's other days where you look to it, and you think: "what the fuck"
I was under Concerta during 3 years, because like our good youtuber here, I really need them at the time. And it greatly helped me stop dropping from school and have the diploma that I needed! But the side effects were sooooo bad at the end that I would never touche this... thing ever again. To speak only of the physical aspect : I was under twenty years old and it gave me palpitations (like some grandpa). But the worst of the worst was the "mental" aspect : I'm a little bit more sensitive then the norm, I always were like that. But this, THIS, totally boosted every felling and emotions. I wasn't happy it made me become hysterical, I wasn't stressed it make me paranoiac and that was in the good times. I couldn't even play video games anymore, my hands were shaking so much with a little bit of excitement I couldn't use a mouse or controller.  But by far the worst thing was this... feeling. That this medication changed me. That it deconstructed what makes me "me" by playing with the chemicals in my brain. And the more time passed the more I felt it. That I was losing myself. ... But I needed this medication, my doctor and family says. So I continued.    I stopped taking it four years ago and now, after tow depression and a big load of s**t that happened in my life I'm proud that I stopped it.  Yes, perhaps my life would have been more orderly during the tow years that it took me to re-learn to be an automous individual who don't need chemicals to fonction "normally"... Yes I probably wouldn't have suffered trough tow depression under the age of twenty five.  But all those problems and the fact that I surpassed all of them myself without chemical pigibacking and with only force of will!! Make me deeply convinced today that those type of treatments are good and beneficial when used to help an individual momentary learn a new way to work or even functioning. But shouldn't be considered necessary to continue on, one the long term.  It's only my perception on this subject, principally formed after a semi romantic experiment and I know that many other people are perfectly happy with taking those types of medications in the long run, and I'm also happy that it this way for them. Because I would never wish to anybody what appended to me.   By the way, excellente video Ice-cream sandwich! üòÅ
I remember functioning better without Adderal than I did with it. I then began taking Dextroamphetamine (Dexedrine) which SIGNIFICANTLY and quite radically worsened my depression symptoms. I stopped taking ADHD meds after that... It is a fucking struggle... You're not alone!

okay shit the cow song was on my mind this entire week thanks a lot andy - the guy that was asking on twitter thether you had adhd or not thanks for sharing your experiences with us :) best regards üòä
As someone who just got some ritalin, and did look into allll these wonderful options... (ok not *all* but a lot) Adderall is just not a thing in Switzerland apparently? Vivance is also some amphetamine salts, like adderall, buuut Ritalin is an entirely different molecule (methylphenidate). There's a few other molecules from the same category on the market. They're usually less... aggressive. They're not necessarily a good time either, to be fair. Ritalin made me pretty jittery, and past some point I was getting a bit too jittery to do as many things as when I started taking it. Thank fuck I only needed it to get out of some pretty bad burnout, but it felt me like punting me into the same state as before, but differently. Like those gauges where you have to hit the middle. Both ends of the gauges are bad, just, left or right. If I were to need to take it, I would cycle it ; take until I get a bit too jittery, stop until I get too limp, and repeat. It also made me less emotionally stable, and more prone to anxiety ; which is funny, cuz I just talked to another guy with ADHD who started recently, and he said that it helped him with emotional control! I guess what I'm trying to say, don't give up on meds, but do more research on what's out there, so you can better try something actually different and find what fits you. Discussing what molecule did not fit you and how with your therapist will also help. That and also how to take meds (continually, or cycling, etc). There's lots and lots and lots of possibilities out there, and you can be strategic in how you approach them, and based on past experiences, you can actually navigate them a little. I hope you find something that fits you, whether it be meds or other adaptations (or a combination of both)!
From my experience with ADHD, I‚Äôve been taking ADHD meds from when I was in 1st grade, and slowly upping the dosage as I got older. I never had the problems you experienced and I think I know why. Whenever I would take my medication, I didn‚Äôt feel hungry until it wore off So, instead of taking the medication EVERY SINGLE DAY I only take it on school days, and not weekends (unless I had a lot of homework I needed to finish). I think this helps a lot to keep my appetite and weight correct, because what I DON‚ÄôT eat during the week I can make up for on the weekends and in Summer when I NEVER take the medication. My weight DID start to get too low at one point, but eventually I learned I just need to eat the lunch school no matter what, even if I don‚Äôt feel hungry at all. Eating a snack when I got home helps too. And the other thing is the sleep schedule. The ADHD meds that I take last for 8hrs, and I take it at 7am in the morning and am able to get to sleep just fine. If your having trouble sleeping you just need to take the medication earlier or get a dosage that doesn‚Äôt last quite as long. There are also short-acting ones that I sometimes take after school and are only 5mgs but last 4 hours. If you take this too you shouldnt take it after 5 hours before your bedtime because then you won‚Äôt be able to sleep (this happened to me)  So from my personal experience, I wouldn‚Äôt take the meds every day as it could impact your appetite and sleep schedule too much. Take breaks from it on weekends or while on vacation, and take them early rather than later in the day.
I've had ADHD since I was a kid, and Ritalin makes me able to do my job of writing software. I tried going off of it in college, and I wasn't able to focus at all anymore.
you should really try Concerta, it's similar to Vyvanse, but way less severe in terms of side effects and long lasting effects
I‚Äôve tried three meds now and one of them worked well but I also just don‚Äôt feel like me as much or don‚Äôt like the side effects. Since I am in between school and jobs, I decided to just not take meds and see where my brain goes. It has been like following a cat around but that is kinda fun.
I am also adhd and back in school I would take focalin. It's a over time release that was at least able to balance me out. I would recommend a try at it at least.

I take methylphenidate, it helps but I‚Äôve tried other medications before getting to this one. Always remember. That not every medication is gonna work for you. When you go and try different meds and you‚Äôve gone through about 3 different ones. Don‚Äôt just stop taking it even if it‚Äôs not helping or you don‚Äôt get the desired effect or get bad side effects. I‚Äôve been medicated for adhd since grade school with plenty of meds that didn‚Äôt work but once you do find one that does it makes all the times the meds didn‚Äôt do it for you so much better and it makes it feel like a relief that you did find it. It doesn‚Äôt feel as frustrating as it did before. If you have tried medication before and it didn‚Äôt work for you that‚Äôs fine everyone is different. But just remember to understand while testing which medication is right for you it‚Äôs not gonna be easy but when you find the one that works it was worth it. At least in my eyes. If switching medication is something you think could help talk to your doctor. I recommend doing it when you don‚Äôt have school like for spring or summer break since it won‚Äôt affect school or other things you have going on. Then again I‚Äôm not a medical professional I‚Äôm just going off my experiences.

Meds for anything is really hard, I've been down that path and it took years to get the right combination. When my doctor finally threw in the towel after maybe 10 different meds and referred me to a psychiatrist we immediately did a genetic test and it was a miracle. I recommend everyone who has struggled with meds to ask about doing this gene test. It will tell you the best and the worst meds that interact with your genes and this is for anti-depressants, anti-anxiety, stimulants, and anti-psychotics.
(YT needs a comment search >:U)  Addy = Meth is a common misconception. Meth crosses the blood-brain barrier 1000x more effectively than addy.  Fun fact! There IS a prescription meth and while v uncommon, some ADHD peeps actually do well on it x3
I, at the ripe age of 30, am just recently figuring out ADHD meds myself. I've tried stims but they affected me the same way as you. I withed with my GP and she suggested a med called atomoxetine. I'm on that now, and I really like it because I really don't notice it except like... at some point in the day doing everything is hard/sucks again, and that's how I know it wore off. It doesn't feel like the medication is making me focus, it just feels like I am no longer being pulled in every direction at once mentally. Basically, it feels like a more organic focus. I recommend it.

I have adhd and i was diagnosed awhile ago, i dont remember how old i was, anyways point is i want to take medication but my mom wont put me on any bc shes just hoping it will go away and then she gets mad at me when i get distracted and forget thingsüò°üò°üò° i just need to know how to convince her its srs and i need medication
I dont know why but i actually kinda enjoy having ADHD, dont get me wrong its absolutely sucks when trying to do a test or listen to instructions but i find i didnt really need meds to stop it. For example when trying to listen to instructions i would just focus at something  nearby so my eyes wouldn't get distracted and then i could focus on listening. Or when i went to do something i would set in a reminder, when i was little i would always forget atleast one thing for school so i put a list on my door to help me get in the habit. Which is another thing i learned, repetition is your friend, when you learn to do something over and over you end  up find your self doing it with out thinking about it unlike before when you probably forgot to put on your deodorant. In the long and short of it, ADHD doesn't need to be countered with meds, i understand having meds can comfort people who generally dont like having ADHD and some cases it works but i find easier to just live with my ADHD and try to come up with strategies to help me focus.

Oh gosh, I was diagnosed last year in June-ish and was conflicted but happy that it came back with something i was suspecting for a long long time but kept going through a guilt-denial spiral for years cuz funny brain says everything bad in my life is my fault and i just need to change myself to make it better and i spent years trying so much effort with no results but a lot of tears. I could've knitted so many tears sweaters from Spongebob by that point.   Anyway, I started meds, Concerta 18mg first and i felt nothing. No kicking sensation or wearing sensation, nothing. I think i was focusing on that more than necessary because i was paranoid that if they're working then how can i tell if they are if i don't "feel" anything change within myself? ANd googling didn't help, I just got a lot of 50/50 thoughts from others who say the meds are supposed to be subtle or you are supposed to feel something OR "FEELING ANYTHING DIFFERENT IS A BAD SIGN!" which just made me annoyed. I even tried doubling my dose which you aren't supposed to do before asking your doctor but i was desperate and what do ya know? Still nothing. Sometimes i could feel like i was able to do stuff but only if i willed myself to start first so if i wasn't doing anything, it just felt like my normal adhd depression self. So it was inconsistent or i was feeling a placebo effect but I asked to try adderal instead. Same deal as the video, started on the lowest dose and felt nothing but slowly increased my dose until 20mg and suddenly i could feel like i actually could go do the thing i needed to do from chores to sitting and checking my email and HAVING A COMPLETE THOUGHT NOT LACED IN DREAD. BUt then, the effects got more and more diminished until i was having a really hard time at work and increasing my dose to 30mg only made me borderline sick and exhausted. I couldn't sleep, I couldn't eat because i wasn't hungry and nothing tasted good and i dealt with that for the whole month without any of the actual benefits they were supposed to give me.   So i just bit the bullet and tried Vyvanse and i knew it was going to be expensive but oh boy, handing over 200 bucks hurt. And for the first week, i couldn't tell if anything was doing anything which was so discouraging but then the second week, i felt like a more competant person! I could do anything and be productive like my executive dysfuntion was FUNCTIONING! And i had glowing reviews for my psych at the appt. I also could feel when they kicked in, I'd get woobly wobbley and ready to rumble. So now it's the next month and i hate to say it but it feels like it's diminishing again. It's really hard to get out of my chair and up to go to do my next task, I get sucked into trying to solve a mildly inconvenient problem or i get stuck. Just physically and mentally stuck if something isn't going right which adds to not being able to switch tasks and keep working. Sigh. I'm trying to think if maybe the meds are just wearing off sooner than before but idk and i'm just tired of feeling like I either finally found something that's working like it should or feeling like i got another dud and have to try something else again. Feels like i'm at the end of the medication rope and it sucks.

Medication for ADHD is a blessing and a curse for me. On one hand, when I do take it, there isn't much of a change in my behavior, and there isn't much of a shift in how focused I am. That could be from the amounts of times I just forget or don't take it, but the line between what happens when I do and don't take medication (In my case, Concerta), is getting more and more blurry. Unfortunately, I have also noticed when I don't take my pills, I have experienced increased anxiety, which has become a recurring problem for me, which I believe may be due to it being almost like withdrawal, and my body is reacting to the lack of Concerta with anxiety.
Ritalin worked for me for a YEAR (I mean, it made my hair fall out, but I had enough hair left) [to this day no doctor says they've ever seen that symptom before lol] until I started developing arrythmia from it. I totally feel you, it's scary. Especially when everything else WORKS - I got so mad at my body those weeks.  Luckily Adderall seems to be my solution! I would recommend trying Ritalin as well if you've the spoons and means for it - it does work very well for many. Hope you find your way, with or without meds. Every body is different and every brain chemistry cocktail needs different ingredients to be good. Take your time, reflect & be patient with yourself! :)

During the pandemic, for school, I was on 40 milligrams‚Ä¶  I DO NOT RECOMMEND THAT. It made me feel sick, like your describing.  It sounds like you might need to try going down in milligrams and it‚Äôs important to know what TIME you take the medicine. Got my ADHD diagnosis when I was 18, near the end of 2020 Been taking methylamphenidate basically daily since then and it's been a game changer for me, while medicated I'm able to very easily focus on whatever is needed. Should be mentioned that the medication is only part of the puzzle for me, it's basically "just" made my ADHD coping mechanisms way more effective. While I'm still unable to sit down for an entire day and for example study for a class, I'm able to study for a few hours, utilising my ability to hyperfocus by picking out interesting bits and pieces from the topics that I'm learning. As said, I've already had ADHD coping mechanisms before, medication just made the mechanisms more effective and made it easier for me to engage with them.  The takeaway that I'd like others to have from the video but also this post is: Try things out. If you're medicated but only on like half the amount that's technically applicable (like me) but you're still comfortable with the results, keep it that way. If you feel like you need better results, try more, try something different. Always communicate with your respecitve therapists. And also, coping mechanisms and learning to deal with ADHD are still just as important when medicated as they are without. Getting an engine swap on your car won't help if you can't drive, so to speak.

meds alone wont help everything, they help the lack of dopamine. but they cant fix the altered brain structure that develops during adolescence due to said lack of dopamine (this is why it's actually really important that kids with adhd get meds.they actually will promote healthy brain development https://youtu.be/HYq571cycqg ).  However, Meds do help you overcome the challenges brought on by those brain structures; i.e. they allow you to utilize skills you learn through (self)therapy that will let overcome them (e.g. reminders, calendars, CBT).   Personally, Im on stratarra and ritalin (short acting 3 times a day). i found the stratara really helped me with my emotions (every emotion i would have was magnified before and it was exhausting) and ritalin helped me focus on work. However, either alone I kept enveloping resistance too. I found papers that found that taking both in low doses was safe and effective for people like me (resistance development). Those papers did state that more research needed to be done but it was enough to convince my doctor.  ....ok back to work ^^;

Finding the right medication and dosage is definitely a journey. I had to try like 6 different meds plus different dosages of those meds for about 2 years before I landed on what worked for me. But I've also changed my dosage as I've gotten older and gone through different periods of my life. Unfortunately I think a lot of people give up on medication because they expect immediate results and that's just not realistic. I remember being on ADHD medication for years when i got diagnosed when i was younger. I remember accidently not taking the meds one day and i was happier than ever. So, I went years without being medicated, and i was essentially on square 1 of the ADHD problem. Almost half a year ago i decided to take ADHD medication again to see what would happen. I was much more focused, was doing well, but as a result i was more aggressive. I switched to a different ADHD med, but the same results happened. Im again off the meds, back to square 1, in a way similar to how you are Ice. However this is my experience of ADHD meds, and the same results aren't going to be with everyone.

When I was a kid, ADHD hadn't been invented yet. They put me on epilepsy meds with side effects ranging from depression to random psycho flip-outs. A new neuro-guy years later looked at the brain scans and decided it was basically just testosterone poisoning. Took me off the meds and I was back to my happy-go-lucky but daydreamy self. Nowadays, what helps most at getting things done is having accountability partners review weekly goals, rewards, and a well-deserved scolding when I don't stick to the plan.

Like, I'm working and I decide I need a cup of tea. So I go to the kitchen and start the kettle. But while I wait, I could empty the dishwasher! So I empty it, refill it with dirty dishes, wipe the counters, generally clean up the kitchen, and finally go back to my desk. :))  ....  :((  not only did I not make myself tea but also half an hour to an hour has passed where I was meant to be working. Not getting fixated on results is super important. I spent years trying different medications, trying to find one that would ‚Äúfix‚Äù me, even though I had been on Ritalin before and it had made me feel way better. It took about five years for me to realize that the point was for medication to *help* me, not *fix* me. So now I‚Äôm back on Ritalin and I feel‚Ä¶ ok. My brain works better, not perfectly, but better. I can focus on optimizing my life, and learning how to make things easier now. Which was the point the whole time. There‚Äôs no cure, just ways to make things easier, medicated or not.

Drugs should only be one half of ADHD treatment. Pair that with behavioral therapy by a specialist and you will have a much more robust and well rounded treatment plan!
Actionable (and unsolicited) advice time:  You WILL have to learn to adjust your habits when adjusting to a new stimulant for ADHD.  The meds won‚Äôt end your symptoms - they just give you new options to potentially learn to *wield* your symptoms in a productive/healthy way.  And there‚Äôs definitely a learning curve for gaining a new relationship to self.    Don‚Äôt expect to become ‚Äúnormal‚Äù when going on a med - because your ADHD is a fundamental part of who you are.  A good medication should just lessen the barriers your symptoms place on your ability to function in a world that isn‚Äôt built for people like us.    Other than that, listen to your gut about what works for you, and don‚Äôt let anyone scare you off from doing something that objectively feels beneficial!

Adhd medication gives me headache
hi hi!  My partner has ADHD, and he's found a balance that works for him (for the past year, at least).  He takes a medication called Wellbutrin.  It's nothing hardcore, and it's actually an anxiety reducer.  It takes a full month to have it be in your system and have it take any affect.  He takes this one everyday, and on work days he takes a baby amount of Adderall.  (He also is a remote worker, which is an A+ for ADHD brains, from our observations with friends lol).  He hopes to not be on Adderall forever, but he's on low doses for the time being.   Again, these are meds we're talking about, and a brain functionality that is different for each individual.  So, this may not work for you or others, but I think Wellbutrin (either on its own or in conjunction with something else more specifically for ADHD) is worth a shot.   Please ask your psych about it first.  I am not a trained medical professional. :> Great video, as always!  These little vids make me laugh and have a better day.  Thank you. :}

Been on concerta for few years.  Right dose helps my brain function more "normally" like guide my focus either to doing tasks or focusing on things and i can keep my thoughts more in order (feels like having only 1-3 ppl in my brain instead of ten).   Starting / increasing the dose side effects have been just the basic mild headache and/or dizziness that go away after my body gets used to it. Taking too much made me feel my pulse way too often (like after/during a workout but without the workout).   Regular side effects are loss of apetite for most of the day (very common, everyone i've talked with has this, some have it more severe than others. my solution is big breakfast and dinner with small lunch/snacks between them) and increased bowel function a bit after taking the pills (comparable to drinking coffee).   The best help with adhd for me has been occupational therapy focusing on executive dysfunction plus some other symptoms.  Also a common thing with adhd meds is that for some they just stop working after a while or the side effects increase way too much so they need to switch meds.   dunno if this helps anyone tl.dr concerta has worked well enough for me but it will take your apetite and run, plus therapy is a nice thing
I'm taking concerta, so far I have no bad effects, but it's more of an assistance thing so that I can teach myself to function without the medication eventually (note this is hard to do regardless and I possibly also have autism Wich doesn't help )
For some reason, cardio exerciselike long distance running has always increased my focus and reduced brain fog..and I feel more confident throughout the day. Maybe try that!

From what i've heard medication works with additional coping mechanisms. It's not a one size fits all duct tape for ADHD. That also means it doesn't work for everyone so it's wonderful that you're sharing your experience with it.
Diagnosed two years ago at 29, meds are a wild ride. Currently trying Qelbree, a nonstimulant adhd med, we'll see how that goes.   If you can (it's not cheap and insurance can get tricky about covering it), it might be worth it to look into getting an adhd coach? It's essentially a person who will sit down with you, look at the symptoms you're struggling with, and see if there's anything you can do either to your behavior, your mindset, or your environment to help ease those symptoms. A good coach will also help you pivot when whatever they suggest doesn't work, which will likely happen.   In lieu of that, I read "The Disorganized Mind" by Nancy Ratey which talks about some adhd coaching principles and that did help a little bit.

Your experience has pretty much been my experience. Meds that have Methylphenidate in them help manage your general ADHD symptoms (making you move around less, helping filter out distracting background noise) while meds that contain Lisdexamfetamine are better suited to help you focus and give you more energy to work with over a longer period of time. It‚Äôs just frustrating that there aren‚Äôt any meds that do both (as far as i know)‚Ä¶  But take this with a grain of salt, i‚Äôm neither a psychiatrist nor any other sort of expert on the matter

2:55 people without adhd will struggle to understand this but that‚Äôs so true.   most people with or without adhd will procrastinate a long essay for example. and having adhd feels like procrastinating smaller everyday tasks like cleaning a room or putting stuff away like with the essay, but imagine you never realised you started procrastinating and completely forgot you had an ‚Äúessay‚Äù to write in the first place until you stare at the ‚Äúessay‚Äù (task) right in front of you and you remember, or realise that you even made a mess in the first place because you didn‚Äôt look up whilst doing the task.  meds don‚Äôt feel like anything, they kinda just make everyday tasks FEEL like everyday tasks and so they are easier to complete.   the brain doesn‚Äôt need to stimulate itself with hundreds of thoughts to make up for the lack of dopamine receptors because we are on STIMULANT medication, so we can just kinda‚Ä¶.exist‚Ä¶. without entertaining ourselves in our brain? you‚Äôd think it would feel like something is different. but it just feels like a different mindset but the same mood level (for me)  comes at a cost though, because at the end of the day (in my case) on methamphetamine i lost my appetite.

Brain chemistry is some crazy stuff. I had a cousin who had impulse issues that were frequently violent. After a bunch of therapy and things they tried putting him on a medication for it. Don't remember what it was but it did fix the problem. However it gave him like every symptom of ADHD, which was weird because it was suppose to improve his impulse control but it apparently just redirected it into a less dangerous place? He wasn't getting into fights at school anymore but his GPA tanked. After about a year of fiddeling with doses and other things they eventually just took him off the medication and home schooled him for his last 3 years and everything was great. He went on to be an engineer for both tesla, spaceX, and disney at various times and is doing great. Now that he has a job where he's rarely dealing with more then a couple people at a time and is usually alone things are wonderful for him. So maybe it was some form of violent social anxiety or something? Who knows but at least it worked out in the end.

I've been taking Adderall for like.. 2 years now. And I keep thinking it doesn't do anything, then I don't take it for a few days, and enter the ‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñí‚ñí‚ñì‚ñì‚ñì‚ñì‚ñì and then I take them the next day and I'm like "oh I'm normal again"
When trying out different meds for ADHD, please remember that meds are only PART of the solution. Pills don't equal skills! Taking meds doesn't automatically make you do the things you're supposed to be doing. It's especially frustrating for some people because the initial effects of meds can be encouraging, but as their body gets used to it, it may not be as obvious that it's working, and they still have symptoms of ADHD. Remember that ADHD is considered a neurodivergence, so it's not going to be 'cured' by a pill. You can't cure autism with a pill, and ASD isn't something to be cured. Same goes for ADHD.  Also, while adderall does have a lot of similarities to meth (it's literally amphetamines), they are NOT the same, dosing is different, and the media has demonized stimulant medications as "zombie drugs," when they're a valid and effective form of treatment. Respect to ICS for being open and honest about their med experience- different meds work differently for different people, and some people may be better off unmedicated, but please keep these things in mind! If you want more info on ADHD, meds, etc..., I highly recommend @HowtoADHD. (I'm an RN and medicated ADHDer, I promise I'm not pulling this info out of my butt)

I used to take meds for my ADHD, but now I do what other ADHD people hate to hear.  I practice mindfulness. I learned to meditate when I‚Äôm feeling over stimulated or heavily distracted.   I‚Äôm often told that it‚Äôs really hard to meditate, and it is at first, but I didn‚Äôt want to be reliant on meditation so I had to figure out something that worked for me.
I was diagnosed with ADHD as a kid and taking medication helped me short term but I still had lessened control over anger and frustration, I could focus on things I was interested in but I would get frustrated if anything else happened. I took them until I got into my first year of high school then started lessening the doses and then got off of them all together. I still have some anger issues but I have found ways to route them into working out or pushing my anger into productivity in an almost "I'll show them" attitude.  What I found out during high school though was I didn't have that bad of a case of ADHD, mine was very mild with what should be next to no interference in day to day life, but it can get bad if I am stressed or confused. The doctor said that the usual reason why young kids show those symptoms is due to a stressful home life, which I luckily didn't really have too bad, or their teachers do a bad job at getting them engaged and often just don't help them because they make great grades but can't understand what the material is, which was 100% true for me.

I feel like one of the things that can really help people with ADHD is just‚Ä¶ an outside influence. Not trying to leave someone to their own brain to try to get everything sorted, but having a physical, actual other person help. Like ‚Äúhey let‚Äôs do [this task you were meant to do]‚Äù kind of thing. It‚Äôs easier to step over the executive dysfunction hurdle when you do it with someone else. Damn bro
I'm 22 and i have lived with the knowledge of having adhd since i was four so i have been able to build up some tools to help me navigate through the chaos. I write a lot and with that comes distractions, so i have to instill a lot of self discipline when I write. Even then it can be chaotic and hard to focus. I tend to use caffeine. Keeping my mind on the task at hand. However even with this my brain can sometimes decide to slow down and get tired. Unwilling to do the task. In this scenario i normally have to reward myself for the attempt with something stimulating like a video game. After a while of running off the chaotic mental energy. It can become easier to focus again. What i find to be a little troubling is a lot of people end up using Adderall to overcome the chaos of thoughts day by day. But as Ice cream pointed out you can build a tolerance requiring even more. Not only this but from the sounds of what he was describing, Adderall was turning the chaotic cloud of thoughts into one line of thought. Allowing him to fixate on the task, but not focus or create different strings of thought when needing to. From my experience learning how to navigate you brain and understand it, can be better in the long term. You don't need to punish yourself but just understand what is going on. It can be hard when moving a million miles a minute that's why its good to slow down and observe what is needed for you at the time. So then you can focus on the task you want later. Its a balance of what you want and what your brain wants.

so relatable...
Something that I feel is important to know:   Adderall is not meth. Doctors in the US actually can prescribe meth under the name Desoxyn but that's only given in very severe circumstances. Also, even Desoxyn is not the same as what Walter White makes. Crystal meth hits your system a lot harder and faster than Desoxyn.  Vyvanse is lisdexamphetamine. It's called a pro drug because the body converts it into the drug that actually helps with ADHD over time. It's why it's considered the more "mellow" stimulant. The drug that your body turns Vyvanse into is dextroamphetamine which is actually half of the amphetamine salt combo that goes into Adderall.

Lovely video
as someone who has been on meds for like 6 years it resonates with me. i started off with a dose of 5mg and over the course of those 6 years it went up to 40mg, with me feeling more and more like a robot rather than my actual self. my high school years are pretty much a blur to me since the meds i took made me focus on "normal" stuff more, and they lasted like 8 hours a day. i barely remember anything but at some point i realised that something wasnt right, and i found out that i had felt like that for a few years, i just didnt notice it until then because i just kinda ignored it because "the meds are working whats the problem" until the depression really started to hit. eventually i was like im not taking these meds anymore and just stopped, right before i enrolled into college. i had a really hard time adjusting to life and school without meds and im still not quite there yet, it takes time. but im trying really hard to do stuff without breaking down :')
It is ok to stop STIMULANT adhd meds, like the ones you took, without doctors help. They recommend you stop right away if you experience the kind of side effects you did. This is not the case for nonstimulant ADHD meds which regulate emotions via blood pressure like guanfacine, because it will fuck up your blood pressure

I think that's a USA problem because Adderall is an Amphetamine, in Europe they rarely use anything else than Phenethylamin. Vyvanse (Lisdexamfetamine) is also an Amphetamine.  I would recommend talking to your therapist about Methylphenidat (an Phenethylamin) i think its much saver.
Vyvanse is also meth. Just a little different
I'm a full-time mental health professional. If you think you have ADHD, you should see a neuropsychologist, not a psychiatrist for diagnosis. As an adult, ADHD is more of a neurological issue. Also bear in mind that "stimulants" are amphetamines or amphetamine like. They are schedule II meds per the DEA. That means they have a very high likelihood of causing addictions and being misused. When you are on meds, you risk becoming emotionally and mentally dependent on them.  ADHD symptoms are common to many mental health disorders, so don't jump to the ADHD diagnosis.  Remember too that lifestyle and diet changes - get exercise, put down the phone, eat clean keto - greatly decrease symptoms.
meds is always seen as the answer  however it only targets one thing, and its likely not the thing you want :/ They can work, but if you dont change your lifestyle its likely not going to. for example  It sounds like your problem isn't so much I need more focuse, but a case of bad habbits getting in the way  habbits take about 13 months to change fully. :( there is no quick fix but once you do a thing consistely for 13 months you likely wont fall back into the old pattern (sure you can fall back into it if the cause of the habbit is still there, for example if someone uses drugs due to pain, even when off they will restart if no alt is given)  It wont be easy, but I strongly recommend just taking small wins.  for example, set a time and place to do your work (an alarm clock can help),  clear the environment of desecrations  (set up your workspace in a cupboard if needed)  and just tick off a calendar day for each day you spend 20 mins working at that time in that place. It will start to build a habbit, but it does take time and consistency to do.   medication would likely work if you can get your habbits in order. however I'd be very carful of side effects :/  Personally, I dont even try taking meds anymore :/  to much of a russian runlet on side effects when its to do with your mind  (often feels like a cage, either you just cant think or remember how to read, or your body is affected in really bad ways :_( seems you had similar experience to me.)

In general, the "never stop taking meds (without consulting your doctor)" is right, but mostly if you're taking something constantly or that builds up. So stuff like antidepressants, or something related to heart problems, blood pressure etc. But ADHD drugs are more "situational", some people don't even take them every day (or are advised to take breaks, even as often as every weekend ‚Äì although this might be a backwards approach). And especially if it's evident that they're causing serious side effects ‚Äì it should be totally fine to stop taking them. Like, obviously discontinue if they're making you *worse*.
Yeah, I took just about every ADHD med possible .
As a Self employed artists with ADHD, I hacked my environment, I interchanged tricks, I read a lot even though at first I couldn't follow but for the reading part, it became easier than when I was at school because I didn't had that pressure of having an exam about it, feeling the need of remembering every sentence because maybe the prof is going to ask about it, I don't remember all pages I just read when I finish it but I stopped caring and weirdly I'm still perfectly following the story and got better focus the more I read, it also helps me kind of meditate because when I do I don't think about my life and whatever challenges I need to go through. Also working with partners helps me focus better than just working alone... I almost feel like I don't have ADHD anymore, I stopped trying to mask my behaviors, when I am with a bunch of people and can't really follow all the conversation because I know for a fact that I am better at one to one conversation or giving a one direction speech to a group, I just get my sketchbook or notebook and start scribbling, and by doing that I do follow the conversations way better. I write a lot about what I have to do even though I never read them again, it is still placing my ideas in a better order, I stopped punishing myself for the thing I don't do and have a better ground on those I did and congrats myself for them, focus on  the amount of task I did in a week instead of in a day. ''A little everyday, a lot every week''. things like that. I also discover a lot of pattern coming from my parents, the way they talked to me about things were the way my brain were still talking to myself (very negative and non productive inner voice) that I deconstruct and replace by better formulas. Because the formulas of the inner voice are the most important at the end!

I was diagnosed at 6 and some days i still feel like i haven't figured out how to stay productive. One med thankfully worked for me but if the past few decades living with it taught me anything its that the medication can only take you part of the way. Behaviors are a huge part of productivity with ADHD. I got my bachelors in programming and honestly not having a notebook to organize my thoughts was more crippling than not having a computer to write code on. You can work with your medication but keep talking to a therapist about how you can work on "executive function" and keep yourself productive. None of the medications will be a fix-it button but with the push they offer you can train yourself to ride the focus wave into a productive adult life. Boy howdy I was wrong. Anyway, long story short I realised a few years ago that this was a big issue in my life, did a lot of work to improve without medication with good results. Vyvanse is literally Adderall binded to a lysine molecule. That's it. It does what Adderall does but better through this mechanism.  Your psych should have also told you to take breaks from either medication. If your dose isn't right then weird things happen. Vyvanse especially tends to add up and wear you out over time.  Finding both the right dose and medication is part of the process, and I wish you luck.  Also stims you can stop taking cold turkey and be just fine. They're not SSRIs or NDRIs which require titration. So I wouldn't sweat quitting them.

Exercising before a long period of work, setting up tasks, using reminder apps, and ad blockers worked for me when I was learning remotely. Blueberries, eggs, salmon, and especially walnuts, are usually foods recommend to eat during test prep for big tests like the MCAT since they help boost memory and concentration.

Fellow late diagnosis ADHD-er here. Long post but stay with me because I identify with a lot of the struggles and funny relatable ADHD quirks you mentioned.  I have been taking the british pharmaceutical equivalent to vyvanse for a year now and although I have found it works for me with minimal side effects I would encourage you to not give up because it is a long road but a worthwhile one to find the medication that works for you.   Also worth mentioning, some of the best advice I got from my psychiatrist when starting the meds was to shift my expectations of what the drug can do for me from ‚ÄúThis is the miracle drug that will fix all of my problems so I can finally fUnCtioN nOrMaLLy‚Äù to ‚ÄúThis drug is simply a tool that can and should be used to help develop habits and discipline over time‚Äù. I know that may seem generic or obvious looking back on it but that really helped me stop thinking in terms of some days were wins and others as failures. It is still hard but I now am able to make a realistic plan for my week-to-week work schedule that also accounts for the low unproductive or wacky goofing off days while still overall feeling proud or fulfilled by the end of the week. All because I have realised that is just how my brain is hardwired and that doesn‚Äôt make me a failure.  Anyways much love and support to you from an online stranger and thanks for making this video. Creators speaking up and talking about these things on their platform makes communities of people feel less alone. So thaaaaaaanksüëåüèª

I was diagnosed when I was little. Like...1st-2nd grade little. They put me on an initial dose of 20mg of Adderall XR....bad...very very bad. I still had a lot of side effects after I was adjusted to 5mg twice a day. Lack of appetite, irritability, bad sleep, and occasional bouts of shakiness. I feel you on the "focusing on the wrong thing". But you also must take into account there isnt a very well defined boundary around the "wrong" thing. Years ago I was doing the "wrong" thing by learning to code instead of doing my school homework. That led me to getting a Computer Science degree, and to knowing that that is what I wanted to do way earlier than my peers. I also used to watch a lot of videos which were the "wrong" thing to do. But I was watching them in English, so I quickly learnt English on my own (I'm from a non-English speaking country). In college, I was doing the "wrong" thing by reading scientific papers on AI instead of studying for some classes. That led me to start working at a company doing AI research way earlier than my peers.  You do need to use judgement when doing the "wrong" thing.

4:42 Vyvanse is also "meth" if Adderall is meth (they're not.) Lisdexamfetamine is a pro-drug of amphetamine (in fact, by itself it is not even active,) when it is metabolized by your liver what is left in your bloodstream is amphetamine (the same thing in Adderall but just not in a salted form.)

My biggest struggle with taking my meds is to take them DAILY. It‚Äôs impossible for me to take them every morning bc I either forget about them or I wake up late and then can‚Äôt them. And it‚Äôs been like that for months now! I tried everything (putting my meds next to me with a bottle of water, I used to set an alarm to take my meds too but none of these tips worked) and I still go months without medication bc at that point I just totally forget about them. However I know it can be dangerous to suddenly go off meds but I just don‚Äôt know what to do atp
I think with all ADHD meds it's important to know, that they will not magically *fix* you. Ideally they will make the symptoms more manageable, but you still have a brain disorder. You'll still need a bunch of strategies to work around or with your brain and it's still a lot more complicated for us than it is for neurotypicals.  I started out with Retalin, which had absolutely no effect on me. I got the side effects, lost a lot of weight, but gained no plus in focus or less noise in my head. I'm now taking Elvanse (the European/German version of Vyvanse) and I think it's helping (?). The effect is not as strong for me as you describe it, but I have an easier time following myself at work (without meds I sometimes just do stuff and later have no idea what that was) and reading papers and that stuff. It's not ideal, I still get distracted easily, I start a task, and then another one, and another one... But I am able to keep an overview over all of it.   TL;DR: Meds are not a miracle cure, but they can be very helpful and sometimes it takes a bit of trial and error to find your brand

when i was younger and taking Vyvanse I ran into the same problem as you and  I found my solution was take the meds on the 5 work days of a week and dont take em on weekends
Since you're not on meds rn this is a really random suggestion that probably won't float to the top of the comments but:  I've always found it much easier to concentrate on what I'm doing when I talk to myself out loud about it- it sort of prevents me from developing multiple overlapping mental narratives before I realize they're completely off topic. Also, when you're talking to yourself about something you need to be aware of (like driving) it encourages you to look for more things you need to pay attention to because you want to continue your conversation w/yourself. Bonus: you feel like a five year old and get to grasp at your fleeting youth  Please note I don't have ADHD (probably) and I'm not suggesting this as some sort of "cure" but it's helped me a lot when I get distracted so I thought I might as well share

I have ADD and took Ritalin, weeeeelllll that ended in depression, so I stopped taking it and everything went back to normal. Now a few years later I am taking it again and have no problems.
I don't agree with the reasoning, but adderall is just as much "meth" as vyvanse is. They're both amphetamine. The difference is an amino acid, L-lysine, on the vyvanse that the body slowly cleaves off, "activating" the amphetamine evenly over a prolonged duration. You're still under the influence of the same drug. (also different is the ratio of left to right-handed enantiomers, not relevant to this discussion though)
is it just me or the voume is too low
I've got ADHD. Tried multiple things over the years. My side affects are lack of appetite, and occasional nausea. But I found work around. Like I eat breakfast before meds kick in, and I keep some tums chews on me at all times. But if medication isn't for you, and it's not for everyone, I'd recommend trying CBD if it is legal where you live. Now it's not weed. It is the thing in weed that makes you calm, but without the stuff that makes you high. I use CBD if I need to focus on something like paperwork after my meds wear off. But a 20mg gummy only lasts for about an hour for me, so it has its own drawbacks.

I take Focalin, but the problem is, when it starts to wear off, you start to get really really really REALLY out of sorts and depressed, not to mention it works as an appetite suppressant, so when it wears off you might as well be going from refusing a pizza, to eating the entire pizzeria.
It took so long between the last ADHD video and this one that in the time between those videos I was able to get medicated myself!  Don't give up your search, ICS. You listed 2 of the most famous medications on the market but there is a TON of different meds out there. I first tried adderall and when I did, it induced depressive moods in me. Not great for getting motivation to to tasks, and seemed weird that the #1 amphetamine on the market did that to me, but hey that's just how drugs work.  I ended up comfortable with Dexedrine, but you need to find what works for YOU. There are hundreds of options. Don't just take whatever name sounds the most familiar to you.  Also, the whole "meth" stereotype is a really bad take and you shouldn't listen to it. None of the amphetamines on the market are METHamphetamines. Much like adding sodium and chlorine creates table salt, it's the WHOLE chemical combination that turns it into what it is, meth. ALSO also, amphetamines straight up don't work on people with ADHD the same way it does with a neurotypical person. It doesn't turn us into tweakers, it just brings us up to normal. Look up stories online of people with ADHD trying cocaine for the first time. It's fascinating to read about so many people snorting the stuff and just saying "what's the big deal? I just feel a bit more normal." That's because (as depicted in the video) our dopamine receptors are so desiccated that forcing them open yields as much as the average person gets normally.

Something most people don't know about adhd medication that's really crucial it's the *time in which you take said medication* . Your brain has dopamine to reinforce it's neural pathways of behavior and every time you introduce dopamine before a task you don't like doing you train your brain to do that thing more easily. This step is crucial in medicating of adhd.

Not me jamming to Cypis
It seems like you're struggling with finding a consistent routine that helps you focus on your studies every day. But what if I told you that a monotonous routine could actually be the problem? When you get into a set routine, ADHD can kick in and cause you to lose interest or hyperfocus on something outside of that routine. This can make studying feel like a chore, and you might find yourself constantly trying to escape the routine.  Instead of following a strict routine, try finding a study method that you enjoy and switch it up from time to time. Maybe you can use a new method each week to keep things interesting. You can also use apps like Obsidian and plugins like Excalidraw and Latex to create interactive notes, diagrams, and connections between different notes. Changing how you structure your notes can also help to keep things fresh.  It's important to reduce stress while studying, so try writing down how many pages, lectures and projects you need to read until a specific date, and divide it by the number of days you have left. This will help you estimate where you stand regarding your progress (you don't need to follow it everyday if you don't feel like it), and you'll see that it's not as overwhelming as it seems.  Good luck in what ever path you choose Ice Cream Man!
Behavioral therapy + meds might be the strongest way to go for anyone still struggling despite medication! Good luck y'all!

In my experience, dealing with ADHD looks a lot less like getting rid of your symptoms, and a lot more like lessening and learning strategies to manage those symptoms.  It takes time and patience, but slowly you start figuring out how the 'game' works, even if you still have good days and bad days.

Vyvanse is a stimulant, meaning it only works on you when I take the pill. You don't have to CONSUME daily to keep it going like some others. So it was ok for Vyvanse. I'm recently taking Vyvanse after switching from 3 years Ritalin. It's been fine so far but I'm curious about your Vyvanse dosage.
The meds just kill the voices in your head and makes you focus
I have ADD (ADHD without the extra 'H'yperactive). The diagnosis for ADD was determined pretty early in my life. Around age 8-10. Over the years I've taken various different medications. The ones I remember before the current medication are Ritalin and Concerta, but I believe I tried 2 others with varying degrees of succes. Currently I'm using Dexamfetamine Sulfate and it's exactly right for me.  The main reason I take medication is to preserve my energy during the day. Before I got medication I came home from school and had to sleep for 3 hours or so to simply recharge. I was just unable to filter out all the background noise from general day to day life. I unintentionally payed some attention to every single noise, movement and sensation. This was just exhausting.  When I started medication I was suddenly able to focus a lot more. I got my afternoons back because the extra sleep was no longer needed. But there were some side-effects. Like loss of appetite and tendency to hyperfocus.  So I altered medications for some time until I arrived to what I use today. It's exactly whatI need.  My main point being. Don't be discouraged when the first few medications you try don't do it for you. Sometimes it's a case of getting the correct dosage, other times you just need to get past the initial startup phase. Or it could just be the wrong type of medication for you and you need to switch to something else. Or it could be a matter of changing your habbits and routine that fixes the problem.
This is why I don't take meds. Also most meds have long term side effects. Most meds are not good for the kidneys. I have just found ways to deal with the ADHDschedules, talkin to my sister, etc. If some meds help some people great, but no thanks fur me. Oh, also this was friggin hilarious, probably mostly because it was so relatable.

What's interesting for me is that my ADHD problems started with meds, I realized they did... not an extreme amount, and so I went off them.  Eventually I found meditation practices, mindfulness, self awareness and learning about dozens of different topics relating to mind and performance along with a practice called "apnea freediving" sort of forced me into learning habits that could control my ADHD. Hard to not make yourself focus when a LACK of focus can literally kill you.  So once I started to do all that, something changed. I basically created a NEW voice in my head that would tell the others what to do, and since the others kinda didn't care they followed along. It was like a babysitter finally showed up in my head that was of my own preference and making. So now I still have the dozens of silly random pointless thoughts, but I can sort of... herd them into the right direction, which is powerful in itself because if they're all doing sort of the same thing that means there's way more chances to get to solutions faster. And I while I can't fully multi-task, I can at the very least micromanage these voices in my head and then tell them which ones should do what and when.  My suggestion is meditation, self awareness training and general learning, but honestly freediving is probably the biggest contributor to my learning to control it.
Not meth, but it is Speed. Adderall is a racemic mixture of amphetamine and dextroamphetamine, and dextroamphetamine is more psychoactive. Methamphetamine is being trialed for ADHD as well, unsure what the state of it is in that realm, since I've been out of that field for a couple years. Vyvanse (lisdexamphetamine) is a prodrug of dextroamphetamine, meaning it turns INTO dextroamphetamine when metabolized by the body (including liver and serous mechanisms/pathways).  Vyvanse is working well for me, but it *did* take a while to figure out how to CHANGE tasks, much like you said, and also acclimate to it so that certain side effects (I was compulsively feeling the need to stretch the muscles in my legs, stand on my toes, point and flex my feet -- all likely associated to a sudden change in serotonin and dopamine levels) went away.  There are other classes of meds that might still be worth trialing. Concerta is just extended-release Ritalin (methylphenidate) at a certain dose that managed to fit a niche treatment so that it could have a brand name slapped on it for a bigger profit and then *also* still be used for ADHD. It's a stimulant, but different processes than amphetamine. And then there's non-stimulant options, like SNRIs; atomoxetine, or Strattera, was a big alternate treatment we gave when stimulants were contraindicated. And if the ADHD couples with anxiety, something like clonidine can also help and mitigate a stimulant medication.  It's a huge cluster, and I didn't enjoy working psych med management because it is so subjective, and full of trial and error. I hope you can find something, meds or otherwise, that does help your quality of life. <3
This video is... Surprisingly relatable... The part about adhd, not meds. Haven't been diagnosed... yet. Planning to visit a doctor. My mom isn't against it, but she says it's the lack of sport and too much computer. somehow. Well if it's adhd then it's a new excuse for me being lazy lol
Navigating medication can be such a pain but please don‚Äôt let it deter you from seeking out help. I‚Äôve done a lot of dealing with doctors for medication over my life for a lot of different overlapping issues. Sometimes meds help, sometimes they don‚Äôt. ADHD meds, unfortunately, simply do not work for me because my body‚Äôs biochemistry makes them work in reverse. The classic stimulant type makes me fall asleep at max dose and under its max dose it doesn‚Äôt do anything at all. Medicine for depression, on the other hand, literally saved my life. I will never stop taking Zoloft, fully of my own will, because I remember what I felt like when I didn‚Äôt have it. I lived with extreme compulsions that were not only causing me physical harm but ruined all of my relationships and dominating my day to day life with, y‚Äôknow, unspeakable horrors like hours of earthquake level trembling and vomiting every day from soul-crushing anxiety. Zoloft almost single-handedly fixed all my problems with depression and all of a sudden I could laugh again, cry again, foster meaningful relationships, and hop out of bed ready for the day with only minor changes needing to be made to my regimen to keep everything in working order. Meanwhile, a lot of people I‚Äôve spoken to to consider Zoloft a devil pill and wouldn‚Äôt take it even if you paid them money. So, medication is a very individualized thing that has a lot to do with your individual body‚Äôs chemistry. What works for you might not work for someone else and vise versa. You might have to be your own advocate to find results. You‚Äôll also sometimes have to make the decision on what side effects you‚Äôre willing to tolerate. Medication isn‚Äôt magic and no one solution is likely to be perfect for you. You might need an additional medication to help out where the first one fails in some area. Expecting a perfect miracle pill will set you up for disappointment when you realize that expectation is unrealistic. Even with Zoloft, which I love, some adjustments needed to be made and I needed additional medications to help with some unwanted side effects. For me, all of it was worth it. For you, it might not be. But if anyone reading this thinks they need help with their condition and wants to explore medication, keep these things in mind. There‚Äôs no miracle pill‚Äîbut there‚Äôs a ton of options that might bring you significant relief with tolerable side effects and it might take some time to work down the list. Don‚Äôt give up!

I don‚Äôt want to invalidate your experience and this is not medical advice, but as a fellow ADHDer I feel obligated to say this: meds are not the be all and end all of ADHD treatment. Actually, research suggest that a combination of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and medication is the most successful approach. I had an amazing experience with CBT. Please consult a professional.

The vast majority of psych meds and circumstances only reach their potential in conjunction with therapy - not just a psychiatrist, but a therapist to help coach you through the process of developing mechanisms to optimize your ideal plans and adjustments.

It can take a fair bit to find the one that works for you, as other commenters have said. For me, a different version of adderal, worked best. 2 steps further away from the "meth" side. It hit that sweet spot of self-starting and focussing. Too much of either you get what your video explained, there's a middle ground and its the best. Also the version I am on is a kind of "at will" med, I take a dose if I need a good day of focus, I take a day off if I am free to follow the whims of my noodle-soup-brain. And this is pretty common, too.  Its also worth noting however, meds will never magically fix stuff, cultivating your environment to give you controlled stimuli and basically making it work for you, is just as crucial as meds (or not-meds if you make that choice) HowtoADHD on YT has a wonderful video about how shes made her house fit her needs, and some tips and tricks to help herself function on days she elects not to take meds.  GL in your journey! <3

Hey you gave a piece of pretty bad advice there. :/  If your meds aren't working, pause them, wait and talk about it with your doctor and/or* with ADHD people with the same meds. A PhD doesn't turn people into encyclopedias, and there is no fit-for-all solution. Yes listen to the doctor to some extent, but don't forget that your doctor should listen to you first.  MPs/whatever they're called where you live are very important, especially in rural areas, but many of them have a tendency to not evoluate at all with times. Having just plainly wrong, outdated, and sometimes dangerous beliefs (ex : "everyone is like that" about neurodivergent stuff, refusing to listen to trans patients, etc)  For real it's like some of them don't know what the DSM-V is   * : Whoever access you have to
The bit where it cuts to the lil dopamine guy crumbled on the floor and the medicine just says "....oh my god,"....that rly must've been the scene when the Adderall got into my brain meats. I will say, though, in general the whole "it's basically meth/kiddie meth" thing is very silly to me, and I do wish that people, including other people with ADHD, would stop saying it. Vyvanse is also a CNS stimulant, even if it's not an amphetamine. Also, methamphetamine is a much more potent substance, as well as being muuuuch more toxic.
I legitimately believe micro dosing meth is healthier than adhd medications
Meds for me were not great at all at first, it took me half a year to find the proper meds and dose AND taking it for a while so it can actually become stable in your routines. Now, ALONGSIDE proper psycho education on my diagnosis, using a daily planner for each day, the meds really do help me do my daily tasks and be productive (and give myself enough time to chill out inbetween as well).   But meds definitely affect each person differently, so if you are thinking about it yourself, reader, do know there is probably a medication and dosis that works for you. That down feeling you had is probably anxiety. Its really common for people on adderall or other adhd meds to develop a sort of anxiety at some point. It happened to me near the start of my path with contramil(basically concerta). Where I had shortness of breath, I was super jittery, like my hart was beating at a million miles an hour but not in a good way. I actually take anxiety meds along with my adhd meds now and it works perfectly fine. I even got a bit of a reputation as the chill smart guy.

Get a water filter.  A good one. Either a pitcher if you live in an apartment so you can pour water into it, put it in the fridge and have some nice cool, crisp water that'll make you actually want to drink water, up to fridge or full house systems. Whatever you're comfortable affording, liking the taste of your water leads you to drinking more water leads you to feeling and functioning better. If you're drinking various soft drinks from the store cause it tastes better than your water, all that crap makes it suuuper hard to focus on anything.  Eat better. I'm not much of a cook, at all, so I found I could make breakfest bars out of oatmeal (3 cups) Peanutbutter (I got an all natural one, 1 cup) and Honey or Syrup (3/4th cup, I know it's sugary but it's natural in this case, seems to burn off fine with no crash). Mix the Peanutbutter and honey/syrup in a microwave safe dish, put it in the microwave for 1 minute but STOP every 10 seconds to stir it a bit. It should go from a mass of peanutbutter and honey/syrup to a fairly consistent goo of both. Now dump that into a dish with the oatmeal and mix it until they're mixed together well. Put down a parchment paper (less cleaning) into a large enough pan and pour in the mixture. Then pat it down evenly and put another parchment piece to cover it. Put it in the fridge for 1 hour.   BOOM. Easy, simple breakfest you can stumble into the kitchen to have a bite of that's filling and contains natural energy and ingredients.   Good food and water made a H U G E difference for me and it can for you too (Person who is reading this).   Other tips;  If you have problems getting things done through the day, get a notebook to carry on you and write things down. The act of physically writing it out will help you remember more than it being written on paper, given the focus it takes.   Set times for yourself for work, chores and play. During work times, put away distractions and check off things you get done, this will give you a sense of accomplishment and satisfaction as you continue to get things done!    Spend time doing something like reading a book, maybe 15 minutes a day. This FORCES you to slow down and remove other distractions and will build your ability to focus.   Music can also help distract your mind a little and allow you to focus on something without a major distraction.  Practice takes a while and you won't always get the result you want, but keep at it! Medicines only mask symptoms and make recovery easier, for something like ADHD it requires force of will (and a good diet) to use. And when you can use it, it's a gift! You're basically thinking 2x-4x faster than most people. I have to watch youtube videos on 2x speed to retain focus but still learn effectively.

I like being employed and present in my life too much to stop the meds right now. But I have been tempted in the past.

A problem I typically have with Vyvanse is that my body eventually develops a tolerance for it, causing it to be less effective. Surprisingly enough, I've found that a good solution is to get off the medication for a few days, rather than increasing the dose.
I was diagnosed with ADHD just before I turned 30 - similar experience with finding the right medication. Vyvanse worked really well for me, except it was a ridiculously crazy apetite suppresant. Those meds combined with the start of the pandemic and working from home/no gym, meant I lost 30kg in 8 months. My ADHD was a lot better, but I was basically skeletal (60kg at 186cm). Had to change and bounces around a few before landing on my current ones.  They aren't as good mentally, but physically I'm better and they do work and basically make it so I don't have the 8 trumpet orchestra constantly.  My (absolutely not a doctor talk to your own professional) understanding is that there are two kinds of medications that are common - meth for kids and speed for kids. If the Adderal and Vyvance (the amphetamine ones) didn't do well, maybe ask your psychiatrist about the stimulant ones. They don't work as well for me, but the side effects are less severe.   Good luck!
Honestly, I think that meds NEED to be complimented with therapy, particularly a type of CBT (I think, don‚Äôt quote me on that, could be another type). That way you can learn all the ways of directing that new-found focus the meds give you in the right direction, and all the skills of basic organisation and working and whatever that most of us with ADHD (especially late diagnosis) never learned properly in our childhoods. Of course, being in the US, I have no doubt that therapy will be 1000x the cost of the already hugely expensive medication, so it‚Äôs likely unfortunately out of reach for most people, but there‚Äôs some great books out there that work like therapy only your therapist is a book. One I used was ‚Äúhow to thrive with adult ADHD‚Äù. It‚Äôs short, teaches you about yourself and your condition in digestible chunks, has mini-exercises, and helps you adjust how you think and operate to actually be able to channel the boost the meds give you. Of course, I haven‚Äôt actually finished the book but I read most of it and it really helped!

Hey, but we know about everything.   We are ALLologysts. Asks us anything! We most likely know about it because we hyper focused on it once or twice in our lives while we were doing absolutely nothing üòÉ  We can also hyper connect things in ways normal people can. Want an awesome creative idea about a specific thing? Ask us! We very likely have all the knowledge necessary for that idea scrambled inside our brains and if we have enough IQ points we can come up with ideas that other will have but years into the future. This has happened to many of us waybtoo many times. We are ideas machines.  Also, if you are able to draw all this do you really have ADHD? or your symptoms are extremely mild. I cant even go drink water when im dying of thirst, let alone manage a freaking animation youtube channel, holy cow.
Something that I feel a lot of people don't understand is that ADHD meds are not a magic potion that cures your problems, they are a tool. As someone with severe ADHD, I had to rewire my brain to function normally. The medication just makes that achievable.     The way I did it was that, at the start of the day, I set a 5 minute timer, and for that amount of time, I make a list of all the things I need to do that day, and order them by importance.     After the alarm goes off, I start the first thing. After that thing is done, I take a break and set an alarm for 20 minutes.    After that alarm goes off, I move on to the next thing.     Every 2 hours, I get what I call my "checkup notification". Whenever I get it, I check to make sure I am doing what I need to do.  It seems like a lot, but I now do can do it without the alarms, and I am infinitely more productive because of it.
I think my brain works like that in a way I do a thing, go play video games, forget what I'm most to be doing, get distracted all day by playing games, honestly I might need to get this checked Lol  Oh, Great Video I guess

One thing that often gets missed in casual conversation about adhd meds (and sadly by a seeming lot of professionals, too) is that they're not a one-step solution. Sure, a fitting prescription basically unlocks your executive function - but that doesn't mean you know how to use it.  Gotta learn that ourselves.

For me with ADD (a form of ADHD but mainly just hyperactivity in your brain rather than your whole body and brain) it helps when people do tasks with me. They keep me on track with cleaning and make sure that the thing I get distracted by will not hinder my cleaning duty. And this is from a 28yo woman who lives all by herself. It is okay to ask people to help you out on the big tasks. Heck, it may even be fun to do these tasks with someone else. Just make sure that the person you do it with is a bit stern, so that when you end up in a conversation with them, that you don't both end up stopping with this task as the conversation is so much fun.  Oh and I heard from a few others with ADHD/ADD that music distracts them greatly when doing a task and that they do it without music (for me, yeah music distracts me, but without music I get bored and just give up, so this strategy doesn't quite work for me)

Also - and I can't express this strongly enough - it MASSIVELY makes a difference with what you eat and drink too. The med walking in and the concern for the guy (in charge) on the floor üòÖüòÇ
I was diagnosed in the 3rd grade, was told to take ritalin, and it definitely helped with me focusing on homework and paying attention in class, but it had bad effects on my sleep and caused me to not want to play with my sister at all and ended up being really blunt and mean-sounding to her. Then when the drugs wore off because I built a tolerance, the doctor kept encouraging my mom to up my dosage. To which she said "no" and gave me decaf coffee instead.  Been drinking coffee every day since (elevated to caffeine at the age of 12) and have been finding helpful ways to help keep me engaged and focused when I need to work. Background music helps a lot. And I find that for physical tasks it helps when I measure out breaks so I don't over work myself, but I also don't completely forget to stay on task.   For mental ones, lately, I've been noticing I focus the best when I have a long-ish video on (like a long let's play) and it's distracting me more from the task. So I pause it, and tricking my brain into thinking "I'm gonna pause this for a "short" period of time and come back to it after my task". And then the current task doesn't feel so long and then I could focus on it way better. And I've spent literal hours being able to sit and focus like this with only minor repeats of the process to break up the monotony of the silence and reengage my brain.
The thing is that many people (consciously or not) kind of expect medication to be a magical cure-all, which it is not of course. The best thing to hope for is that you function like a non-ADHD human. Who can also get distracted and work on the wrong stuff. Which is why it's good to go to a therapist or something who can kind of learn you how to use your newly unlocked powers
Something you might wanna look into is neurofeedback therapy! It's a type of therapy where the doctor will look at your brain waves and, through weekly sessions, will work with you to train your brain waves to... work better. If that makes sense. It works for a lot of mental illnesses/symptoms, not just ADHD. It takes a while to see the effects, but it can really help! I've been doing it for a few months now and my executive function has been improving a lot! :)
For me Concerta has been helpful but the crash from missing a day is really brutal and it took a while to get used to the side effects. I‚Äôm pretty useless without it most days though so I take what I can get.
I find that eating protein,and i mean like at least 2 eggs and some bacon or whatever for breackfast, helps with ADHD and ADD.
