I have not told my doctor I did this and at this point I‚Äôve managed without my meds so well that I don‚Äôt think it matters.
As a person with ADHD meds, this is so relatable ‚ú®I've only realised like 3 months ago but concerta works really well for keeping me focused on the right things :)
I was diagnosed about five years ago with ADHD. My symptoms sound very similar to yours, and the five guys talking all at once in the brain is so relatable! I have tons of thoughts:  I've been taking meds since I was diagnosed and I realized that although it helps, because I do need some help, it isn't a silver bullet, even if it's the perfect medication. Focusing on the task you need to do is something you might have to experiment with and practice like I did. While using the medication, I would also evaluate things like my work space, if clutter makes it worse (it does) and having instrumental music playing while only committing 15 minutes to total focus on one task at a time.   The 15 minute thing has helped me SO much because 15 minutes is very little commitment, so it's easier when I think "oh I should really cut this slightly uneven nail" I can say "Actually, I can wait to do it in 15 minutes." Sometimes I will do 5 minutes if I'm really having a hard time and it's still effective. A lot of the time, tasks that I needed to do would get done within that window and this would initiate the ball rolling to rev up motivation. Even if I didn't finish, I would feel good that I got at least something done.   I observed what times of day I would be more focused, and I do have a bit of a pattern. I tend to get more done in the morning, and mid-day/afternoon it's harder to focus, and at around 5 I'm more focused as well. Knowing this lets me be kind to myself if I'm having a hard time. I will let myself step away for a bit like taking a walk, getting coffee, or playing a game for a bit on my phone.  The other thing that really helped, (I know this comes up as a solution so much I slightly cringe having to type it) is truly, legitimately, getting your body moving until you're sweating and out of breath because it is so much more valuable than I realized. This can also be a 5 - 15 minute commitment. You get out energy which really reduces the hyperactivity, and since your brain requires the most oxygen than anything else in your body, you're encouraging optimal functioning by exercising.    I also have gone to therapy for a few years and addressed how I handle emotions, which is important to me since my mood can affect my symptoms. If I'm distressed, there is no way I'm getting anything done. If I'm doing well and taking care of myself, which is most days, then focusing is easier.  This is what worked for me so it may not be the same for you. But over time you'll discover what helps the most and what doesn't and it will get easier to manage.
I can relate the side effects are pretty bad. The side effects are difrent by each person. Im my case I feel very tired and unfilled, in particular when I'm not satisfied with my work. Partly you see the world with a other view and things that didn't bug you before are now a huge problem.
You've got this! Seriously though, it might take years to find exaaaactly the right med, but oh boy, it is night and day when you do. It is going to be VERY frustrating getting there, but it's worth it. Keep on pushing through the unhelpful days, and too helpful days, and you'll get there.

Finding the right medication (or coming to the conclusion that there is no right medication for you as an individual) is certainly a lengthy process. It's really important to remember that medication isn't a magical thing that will fix all of your problems. You have to have other strategies & skills to pair with the medication to really make progress. Meditation is important (yes, even though it's painfully boring for the ADHD brain), taking care of your body is important, managing your emotions is important, etc. Dani Donovan made the Anti-Planner that's full of hundreds of pages of coping skills & ways to manage your life in a way that works with your brain instead of against it that I highly recommend. You need a greater toolkit to manage your ADHD beyond just medication. There's also ADHD youtube channels out there that can help you as well when you need new ideas & perspective.
Ice cream, from one medicated ADHD person to another. I think you could also use Coaching. It's easy to do chores after a pill because they often have very few small steps. Working on your job or projects, have MANY small steps. So you just.... avoid those or get frozen.  Medication and Coaching, two sides of one coin. Often you need both to get your ADHD in check.

Methamphetamine is Desoxyn, not Adderall.  Also, Vyvanse is pretty much the same thing as Adderall.  It IS the same thing as Dexedrine.  Adderall is a mixture of Amphetamine and Dextroamphetamine.  Dexedrine is only Dextroamphetamine.  Vyvanse is Dextroamphetamine with a lysine unit bound to it which must be shorn off in the small intestine before the Dexam is available which is useful if Dexedrine or Adderall are causing digestive issues since they can be absorbed through the stomach and esophagus.   Your friend didn't know what he was talking about.  "Hey bro, you're pretty much taking methamphetamine when you take dextroamphetamine mixed with amphetamine.  You should only take dextroamphetamine."  It turns out sticking that extra methyl group on the amphetamine molecule does a WHOLE lot.

You know, the more I hear about other people's experience with both ADHD as well as how medication affected it, and the more I reflect on the circumstances surrounding my diagnosis...  I think I was misdiagnosed. Yeah, sometimes I still get the 1:08 situation in my brain, but I can just silence all that by stopping and imagining the dial up internet sound. It's a mental reset.  I've been off my medication for almost 5 years now and I've gotten better without it.
I have severe ADHD. After about 4 years of research, back and forth with my psychiatrist, this is what I take. 54mg of a long releasing stimulant like concerta, and 2 reuptake inhibitors, 1 for dopamine and 1 for serotonin. The stimulant is to get my brain to release more neurotransmitters like dopamine and serotonin, and the reuptake inhibitors prevent my brain from dumping the dopamine and serotonin too quickly. Now of course what I am taking is unusual even for an ADHD patient, but that's how bad it is for me because my body keeps resisting the change that the meds are supposed to do, 1 drug isn't even close to being enough so I need 3. Preferably I need like 100mg of a stimulant but that would be an overdose and illegal.... and it might kill me. So the reuptake inhibitors are there to act like that other hypothetical 50mg stimulant. SO how do I feel? Fine. Not amazing, just fine. My brain really doesn't want to submit to the drugs. So stubborn. What I'm taking could put others into a mad house, but that's just how us ADHD people are, we're all so different.

I'm actually kind of surprised you got diagnosed this late! Men with ADHD are typically diagnosed in early childhood. I'm honestly kind of glad, because that means you've had the time to develop some coping skills and management instead of being immediately medicated and depending on it heavily.  Now I really don't want to be a backseat doctor, but if anyone with ADHD/ADD is reading this comment and you're experiencing similar issues as IceCream at the end of the video, PLEASE speak to your doctor. As you get older, you will need lower doses of medication as to not adversely effect your heart. A very big risk factor with ADHD medication is heart problems. Tread carefully!   Also ask your doctor about slow release or fast release, and figure out what works best for you.  (I am speaking from experience. Twofold.)

im 19 and id been medicated for adhd(and gad) since like 6th grade. i was on so many different medications and doses that eventually i was so emotionally numb that nothing would do anything productive. the only thing that helped me was cold turkeying the four meds that i was on at one time. granted, i was also medicated for depression and whatnot, but yeah meds just arent for everyone.
the issue is that medication alone can't magically solve adhd issues. as you said, you were able to focus but on the wrong things (and also other issues). it can work for some but not everyone. that's why therapy accompanying it, is also important. you can learn lots of skills that can help you deal with the adhd symptoms, especially meditation practices.  also there are studies that show, that meditation practices and therapy have a longer lasting positive effects on adhd than meds do.

But before that I needed the magic french green health insurance card bc otherwise it would cost my dad money to take me there. I recieved the card yesterday (also my dad sent them a very mediocre picture of me to put on the card that will follow me my whole life, thanks dad) so now I just have to convince my dad to take me to a neurologist because there is no reason not to anymore. Also I don't get why I wasn't diagnosed as a child. For context I took an IQ test when I was 8, and I was above average. Though the symptoms they related to the IQ are also the symptoms for ADHD, and it was so obvious I don't get why I wasn't tested for that as well. And I had a big speed deficiency or irregular speed on the tests (faster in difficult tasks bc challenge and slower in easier tasks), that wasn't "normal" and they didn't do anything about it my parents and everyone else just told me "just stop being slow". ADHD meds are as varied as how ADHD affects people, you can either not take any and try to get yourself to work without em. Or you can try them until you find what works, for some people it's only a certain med, for others it's a certain med at a specific dosage. Adderall didn't work with me, but high dosage Concerta did help a bit, at times....ok not really, but uh....oh god.  The important thing is to have the right doctor that cares and knows this stuff. If you have a doctor that disregards your wishes because they don't like a certain med and they want you to take this other one, then that doctor doesn't care or potentially understand the whole picture of your problem.

I tried a bunch of different meds before I found that low dose Ritalin worked the best for me! :) I do the 4 hour fast release. You still sometimes get the ‚Äúhyper focus on the wrong thing when the meds hit‚Äù but super significantly less and after about an hour or two u can usually snap out of it. If u give yourself behavioral structure and alarms for these meds they can work really well (such as the meds by themselves are helpful in controlling my adhd, I also use alarms and multiple white boards with check mark reward based systems to help structure and visualize my day ‚Äî visualization is one of the best organizational things for adhd). I took Ritalin for most of my middle/highschool days to help me focus.  It did help, but not in a big noticeable way, I'd more so notice it if I'd forgotten to take it, cause then I just couldnt focus for shit. Also had a bit of the same issue of taking a while to kick in and then if it hit it could just worsen my focus on the wrong thing.  I quit taking it a few years ago though cause nowadays it really fcks with my throat and makes me feel kinda nauseous and sometimes puts me kinda on edge.  Ritalin is also apparently a very strong, very addictive drug if you take it thr wrong way, something I never did, but only found out about later.
This is such a mood, I've been taking meds for ADHD since I was a kid at first I was on Adderall and that worked pretty well, until I started gaining a tolerance because I had been taking it for 20 years. Then I started taking Vyvanse but the switch was mostly for my eating habits and hoping to control them better (side note, didn't work). What I've learned from taking medication for 20 some odd years is that it makes your heart rate higher which makes you hyper aware of what's going on with your body, withdrawal from not having them a few days absolutely sucks, and I honestly just don't fully feel like myself but rather what other people want. I won't say it didn't help, it definitely did but now I have less to focus on and don't really need it as much. It's a mixed bag when you're medicated but it's also a mixed bag of cat's when you're not. Really can't win

Hey guys I have ADHD and I‚Äôm NOT on meds. After literally a year of trying to find what works to focus, I figured out these tips:  - I have to write down anything I am working on because as I work obstacles come up and they turn into distractions. The writing helps me remember what my goal was.  - I tend to be OCD wanting things perfect. This becomes an obstacle to my goals because as I‚Äôm working, things don‚Äôt work as planned which sends me on a rabbit trail to get things to be as I personally planned. Life doesn‚Äôt work that way, and so I had to learn to ignore things that are not related to my goal, or meet half way to use a method that wasn‚Äôt my perfect preferred ways, but still gets the job done.  - I am a perfectionist, and have had to learn any project I want to ‚Äúturn in‚Äù will never be up to the ideal standard I had hoped for. It‚Äôs embarrassing to turn in ‚Äúunfinished work‚Äù. But the reality is I‚Äôm just a super tough critic.  - I had to learn how to break down large tasks into smaller tasks and make lists. Then as I work I stick to the list. I am not allowed to work unless I have a written plan first. This keeps my brain focused on goals and not small tasks.  - I learned there‚Äôs always a barrier to get started. Like I emotionally don‚Äôt want to start. So I set a 20min timer to force myself to start. Once I‚Äôm ‚Äúin the zone‚Äù and I see progress I naturally get focused in on the task.  - as Alex said, it‚Äôs easy to do physical work but hard to do mental work. I learned I have to verbally talk out my thinking as voice recording. And also use lots of office paper to write out my plans. Get your thoughts out in front of you on paper.

And if I don‚Äôt, I get terrible withdrawal issues where I throw up everywhere every 5 or so minutes. And I also can barely stomach down anything. Not even water. So uh- yeah

I know this is not what you intended, but talking about the positive effects of these meds can send of the wrong signal to a lot of younger viewers. I think the majority of people on the internet experience these "symptoms" of adhd, well you know because we're humans, and too often they conclude that they have adhd, which is kind of harmless until you start talking about meds. you might say that these are precipitation drugs so it's not up to you, and although you are right in a way, the truth remains that if someone believes that he have adhd he\she will get a hold on these meds, either by buying off from their friends, going to phony doctors or by exaggerating his symptoms to a doctor. I think this topic should be handled more carefully, especially because young people are often exposed to it and often assume that they have it.

Yeah don't ever just stop taking your meds. I used to take amitriptyline as a sleep aid but it is primarily an antidepressant. It worked alright as a sleep aid, but I also really didnt like the side effects it was causing. So instead of talking to a doctor amnd trying something else, I just stopped taking my meds. After a couple days I started to feel physically ill. I had stomach pains, headaches, etc. Definitely talk to your doctor before stopping your meds cold turkey.

as someone who's taken vyvance at the highest dose for years (70mg) I'd like to note that while yes. it does help you focus. you need to keep in mind it can only go so far to help you. you need to be able to tear yourself away from a distraction on your own and get back on track. in my experience its a god send when you get the train started moving. once did an animation that would normaly take me a month in 13 hours o3o was a great day (this has only happened once in 10 years of being an artist). (this might be more of a statement on my inability to focus rather then the magic of the pills but its not always like this. make sure to talk to your doctors and test the various medecines till you find the one that fits you. and don't forget different dosage levels will have different effects on you)  in my case. side effects range from insomnia if im not carful when i take the pill (time of day. it can last almost 10+ hours) to a lack of hunger (but still hunger pangs) and is fairly common any day i take it. also... make sure you have insurance for this stuff. a bottle of vyvance's street or individual pill cost is like 10 bucks a pill or somthing cause it has no generic version. stuffs crazy expensive. but thats meth for you. *wheeze.jpg*
Just for those who don't know- usually medication is paired with cognitive behavioral therapy (but like who has the money for that??) So the solution (if you want to be on medication) would be to find the right medication and try to behavioral therapy yourself for the best results

If you are struggling with ADHD, and are frustrated because you easily loose Focus, here is a trick that I have learned over the years:  If you cant seem to find your Focus, Take a deep breath, and try Not to Sense anything but that breath, Focus so hard in it that it becomes Impossible for you to Focus in anything else, then remind yourself what you are doing, why you are doing this and that it is perfectly fine to do that, and that it is Not boring, it is there to be done by you, and you are there to conquer this task, and If needed, make a Game Out of it (you can give yourself Scores for being on that Task, the more you do the more Points you get)  It will build up that disciplined focus and ignite fun in "boring" tasks Sometimes fast music without Lyrics, or slow music will keep that restless leg, that "i'd rather do Something else" bouncing Leg, calm and your mind busy in the backround Sincerely, someone who lives with ADHD for 28 years now  I Wish everyone in Here the best ‚ô•Ô∏è

as someone who has been trialing adhd meds for nearly 10 years, started with i was 9, the different ways the pills can effect you are crazy, the one i‚Äôm trying rn, when it kicks in, ur heart rate goes up INSTANTLY and u can feel it, which is pretty wack lmao üò≠
i got diagnosed with adhd at 15. i started taking well-butrin (bupropion) which is commonly used for addicts or alcoholics who are coming down from something as to not have withdrawls. it helped almost immediately (it pretty much supplied my brain with high amounts of dopamine) and it worked so well. my brain wasnt loud anymore, i was able to focus on one thing at a time, etc. people think adhd is just hyperactivity and not being able to sit still. but in reality a lack of dopamine can cause emotional instability, overstimulation, sensory issues, and can become disabling heavily as many people with adhd struggle with hygiene or tidying up spaces ESPECIALLY if undiagnosed or unmedicated/untreated.   fast forward to october 2022, turns out my medication stopped working in august (i hit a huge depressive episode..) and then got VERY sick. turns out your brain can get used to the dopamine intake, and that's exactly what happened. i had been taking 200 mg EVERY DAY. my withdrawals were really bad. they gave me anxiety medication to take alongside my adhd meds. its been working really well but eventually ill have to be put on different medication.  it takes a few tries with medication, or finding whatever works dor you. for me its been therapy, letting myself hyperfixate in healthy ways, and taking my meds. adhd is much much more than just being hyper for me, since i have other mental disorders and illnesses my lack of dopamine makes them all worse so i need to make sure i take my medications.   the only side effects of my current medication is, dizziness or drowsiness (i am not allowed to drive) and lack of appetite which is fine for the most part.   when im on my meds im very happy and productive and i dont overthink or struggle. without them, I LEAVE THE OVEN ON FOR 12 HOURS. or i'll like... go to take a bath and put the water running and forget i did that. or i'll start cooking wnd get distracted and the food will burn. etc. i also get extremely emotionally unstable when not on my medication, and my anxiety gets MUCH much worse.

I‚Äôm currently taking vyvance as my medication and previously I took adderal which had more or less had nearly zero affect on me and also Strattera which also had zero affect on me but that was not a surprise, but my first med I started on was concerta which more or less was a horrible experience from what I can remember from over 2 years ago though I can exactly remember everything that was bad about it but I would sweat, be extremely exhausted after the medication wore off which was after high school which more or less put me out of commission. Going back to vyvance it has the same affects that concerta had on me but it‚Äôs at a more manageable level and I can actually perform (kinda) in school which I couldn‚Äôt do previously which is very nice, the only advice I can give someone who is trying to find the perfect med is that it probably doesn‚Äôt exist and you just need to find the one that helps the most and has the least side affectsüëç

Hey Andy! If those meds didn't work for you, you may be one of many with treatment resistant ADHD! If I cna make any suggestions, Atomoxetine was a good one for my focus but I had major side effects. If you believe that you may have treatment resistant ADHD, therapy and CBT(not that kind) may help you build proactive solutions to get yourself out of the ADHD loops.
id like to say, this reminds me a lot of when i first was trying out meds. they'd given me too big a dose, and i ended up in the exact same zombie-like, focused-on-the-wrong-thing mode. i played one video game for about 12 hours that day, if that gives you any idea. i tried it again, without being in the middle of a hobby i enioy, hoping that would fix the problem- i also wanted to focus on the right thing! didn't work. tried again another couple of times but it really didn't help me any more than it over-helped me. went to my doctor, told 'em about it, already considering this might not be for me. they suggested lowering the dose, because that's a common experience for those with a dose that's too high, and i agreed to try it. ....and to my surprise, it actually worked this time. i could focus on tasks(homework) or chores(or actual work, like right now). i could think, hey, i should do this! and then id get up and do it! its really nice finding something that works, and for me in particular, finding the correct dosage was the key. talk to your doctors(there's an app called mychart that's incredibly helpful, i recommend it myself!), do your research, and it's always going to be something different for everyone, and that's alright! good luck to everyone out there trying and may you find what works for you ^^

I've been diagnosed with high-functioning autism as a child, and again as an adult. I've been diagnosed as not having ADHD as a child and as an adult. But it's hard to believe I don't have ADHD when all my ADHD buddies are just so relatable. I can't just do the thing I want to do. I live knowing there is something I should be doing, but am not. I do not have the will to change it.  But there's something uniquely eye-opening when ADHD and meds describes different kinds of brain function, in ways both more like mine and less. Your description of vyvanse sounds more like my brain than without it. But if something can sound more accurate to my experience than pure ADHD, then I am clearly experiencing something different.

I am not diagnosed or taking any ahdh meds but I had some methods which made my days like the second med for you. I combined My stimming habit with the focusing on a task i am not villing to do enought. So for example. I like to listen to the same song on repeat and thats kind of puts my head on autopilot while i am able to do chores which i don't wanna but have to do. Also i cant create in silence most of the time because my brain kicks into owerthinking mode. So before i start drawing or animating I turn on music on loop and then dive into the task. Theese days were the productive ones. But this caused burnout pretty fast. Because I forget to take care of myself. Ooops. But on days when i take good care of myself I get barely anything done. And feel grumpy about it. And I think its ok. Its a balance. Because I cant force Both for some reason. But life is a balancing act. I cant be perfect all the time. So does Noone else. Take a break before u need it. But try to do the important stuff first and rest later if u can. For me I know starting the day is the hardest and getting just put of the comfy bed. But thats also ok I think. Sometimes We just take small steps and its still progress.

I got diagnosed last year at 28. Up until then, I thought everyone had 1:07 - 1:36 happening in their head and had no idea that was not the norm. I'm medicated and doing well on it now, the cacophony is still there but it's more like its coming from behind a closed door now instead of being overwhelming. It's worth mentioning that I did therapy for a year and change and was fine until I hit my tolerance threshold between school and work. I also tried multiple meds and I'm very lucky that Adderall works for me with almost no side effects. My heart rate is slower when I'm on it, I'm not irritable or anxious, I have no problem eating, and any weight loss has been gradual because I'm snacking less. I'm very lucky and I feel for people who didn't get as lucky as me.

I have ADD (or I guess it‚Äôs ‚Äòinattentive ADHD‚Äô now), and it can be extremely hard for me to focus. I‚Äôve been taking Methylphenidate, and it was great for a while until I started to feel like I was just robotic and like a task robot. I was speaking with my doctor and family about it and suggested it was an issue with dosage. Since then I‚Äôve been taking an all day release kind instead of one in the morning and one in the afternoon, and whenever I remember to take my medicine, I get stuff done with an enjoyable day. On top of this, I‚Äôm still able to be creative and such. Sometimes If I have free time I‚Äôll doodle while on methylphenidate, because I have nothing important I can / need to work on. I don‚Äôt know if this is helpful to anyone with ADHD, or if I‚Äôm just rambling, but for me personally, I find that Methylphenidate works great for me. (Also yes, it does technically have a methyl group in it, which is a component to meth, but it‚Äôs a different compound, and has more pieces to it. Not meth, doesn‚Äôt act like meth, but has a component of meth. Not sure if that makes sense, but uh‚Ä¶ yeah. :/ )

TIL: these kinds of meds are supposed to make you feel good with yourself, but they don't work for everyone that way. If they don't, or you don't like how they make you feel, you should seriously consider looking for an alternative or think about whether it is worth taking them. (especially in places like the USA where this stuff is hella expensive)   I was really really sceptical about meds at first for my adhd, but the low dosis I started out on was great! Finally, I could FOCUS, and holding onto thoughts felt like holding rope instead of sand. I finally had a feeling of "hungry" again, which for me just disappeared until I was so hungry I was in pain - that pain was _my_ "hungry", and bc of digestive issues, it was a 50/50 chance of not even BEING hunger and I just had to test stuff out. Now, I can suddenly EAT again without having to force every bite down. It's also been an IMMENSE relief for me during the night. I hadn't been able to sleep before 11pm since 4th grade, but then I take my meds, bam, I'm out by 10, and can wake up in the morning with less struggle.  Eventually I got used to the dosis tho, and eventually talked to my doc about it, to adjust the medication. I'm already on different meds, so we didn't wanna go that high at first, but I noticed how much more better I felt when I accidentally took it double, so we decided to test it out and it worked out :D I feel like I'm much more ME with the meds, not just tired, distracted, anxious, with fits of depression. Therapy and self-therapy also helped a lot, especially learning about it, and learning ways to cope.   I know meds don't work for everyone, and the medical situation in the US can be a right shit show, so I'm really glad you didn't just make the devil out of medication that you easily could have, especially with the side-effects you experienced. Keep going dude, there's still a lot to experience ( -before the heat death of the universe lol- )

I do Not have fond memories of Adderall. I'm glad you pitched that ASAP. Personally I had them given to me while I was still in school. They'd work for the first day of the week that I took them and then I felt **absolutely fucking nothing** for the rest of the week. No matter how much we increased the dosage! And of course as an anxiety filled teen, I was freaking out that the doctors would think I was an addict or something. They made me incapable of wanting to eat- which I despised, I love eating- and I felt like my moods were out of control with it, despite my mother telling me otherwise. They also made me drop a LOT of weight, which I don't feel like is talked about enough when talking about Adderall. I hated every second of it. (And, also, when I got off the meds, my mother decided that she would take them for herself instead to help lose weight. Which is not legal. Nor good for you. Adderall is essentially meth. Stop that. Get some help.)

I'm 26 and I've been medicating for ADD for 10 years, and it took it's sweet time before I found the meds that actually worked for me (especially in the middle of puberty holy hell). I was never able to operate anything without my medication, and got really impulsive and aggressive. Today, with the help of medication, I've been able to learn about my difficulties and got the tools to be able to manage them. I've even started thinking about lowering the dose to eventually just not be on medication anymore. With the medication I could help myself, and my loved ones have never felt closer.

Oh, fuck. Dude. PLEASE spend some time on targeted therapy in addition to and üíØ at the same time as medication trials. Medication therapy is ONE type but should NEVER be the ONLY therapy, y'all.    Also, fuck what somebody tells you about something being similar to meth. If your brain doesn't react that way, then it's not an addictive substance for you. That's the whole point of BEING NEURODIVERGENT.   This video was hard to watch for multiple reasons: 1) omfg, was it slow for a person whose meds have worn off for the night. Love ya, but 2x was needed.   2) see above AND please be careful how you talk about what you "think is medication" before actually discussing with your professional if that's what it was. You went off of the med and happened to feel better, but you also weren't going to be feeling anxious about being on the med anymore. Mind-body aren't separated, so you cannot expect to take a medication for your mind that won't affect your body and some way and vice versa. There is no hierarchy on our bodily organs.  Edit: a medically retired Sped teacher for kids w/IEPs in gen-ed High school. I have ADHD, wasn't IDed til I was 28, I'm now 38 and balancing meds is NEVER done. Never assume it's a "oh! That's perfect!" üíú it'll drive ya nuts!  I just don't take nearly as much medication anymore because I'm not in a classroom every day. But he's nice about ADHD medication as you do not have to take it every single day. You'll learn what works for you and when you find something that doesn't, you'll take note, y'all.

i have narcolepsy, which causes me to be awake at night and asleep during the day. naturally. also due to genetics and a really unhealthy mom, i have naturally low energy and stamina. so, after a few visits to my doctor, she slapped adhd on my file and gave me adderall to take as a stimulant. i'm a frail excuse for a being so 10mg is enough to keep me up and active from 6am to 2pm: my exact school schedule. i still have to have a medically reduced school schedule (2 free periods no matter my schedule) to compensate for my immediate crash when I get home. (i usually sleep from 3pm to 6am the next day, with only a break for dinner). it sounds bad, but before my meds i would sleep endlessly, being awake for maybe a few hours at night. big improvement, haha! i've been on it for a year and am no longer failing school, so let's go!

I‚Äôm on Concerta and have been since I was 16. (I‚Äôm 29 now) so it‚Äôs been a LONG but wonderful journey. The side effects were: suppressed appetite, headaches if I didn‚Äôt eat. (Eating normally solved any  tired or out of breath symptoms I had too) and lastly, it would give me so much energy. SO MUCH ENERGY AND FOCUS. It unlocked my life. I wouldn‚Äôt be where I am today if I didn‚Äôt go through the process of trying different medicines in the beginning. Being able to focus on a task (maybe not as much as the average person but hey, I‚Äôll take what I can) is amazing. And after so many years of taking Concerta, my symptoms have disappeared. My biggest hurdle is remembering to take the medicine in the morning. And then making sure I don‚Äôt take it after 1:00pm because after that I just won‚Äôt sleep at a normal time later.   Anyway. Adhd can suck sometimes but I‚Äôm also kinda grateful I have it because I like how my brain works. Concerta doesn‚Äôt take that away from me, it just enhances my productivity and focus while I can still be my weird.. self.   Note: when I forget to take it in the morning, I have no adverse reactions luckily.. but I do immediately revert to normal adhd mode except I get HONGRY. concerta. so for me, my ADHD is a sort of this almost blindness to time. humans have a ''dont freaking do that, you are an adult/arent that stupid'' part of your brain that matures and grows as you age till about the age of 25 when it should be all good and you have stuff figured out(mostly) and you can do the good stuff and push down the bad, juvinile, and/or dumb with almost no issue. time is no longer this slippy unreachable, unplannable thing. the adhd however dampens the neural pathway to this part of your brain, to the point where you need a stimulant to get that pathway flowing like it should.  that medication was concerta for me. it stimulates that ''DONT DO THAT DUMB THING'' part of your brain that SHOULD be working, but isnt. hopefully this helps someone out there still trying to figure things out. i cant guarantee it will work, but this is the best that i have with my experiences and knowledge of the human mind:] best of luck.

My ADHD meds don't completely get rid of my ADHD symptoms, but they lessen their severity a large amount. It took some trial and error, and no med is perfect. I don't encourage people to try every single med searching for something perfect. On the other hand, don't feel that you're inconveniencing your medical team by trying a multitude of meds if you want to try to find something that will help you. I've changed my medications for various things so many times over the years, and I'm lucky to have a doctor that views medication more as a fluid tool to help your health rather than an all or nothing total fix or failure with no changes over time.

Keep going to your doctor. Like you mentioned, there are a lot of different meds out there. Keep going to your doctors, especially your primary care doctor. They can help you with your body's overall response to new meds. It can take a while for you to find the right one. Don't give up!
Vyvance is good for intensive studying such as people working on a science degree (undergrad or master's or even PHd). It's a little out of hand when it comes to day-to-day things, but I can say it had a similar effect to how Ice Cream Sandwich described Aderall; doing mundane/physical tasks was a breeze, and forcing oneself to sit down and do something like study or paperwork becomes... somehow magically possible. It really is like a sudden "ability" that pops into your brain. That being said, the side-effects of Vyvance are so brutal I would advise people to steer clear of it unless absolutely necessary.
Maybe ADHD isn't a disorder that needs to be fixed but it's a cause for a reevaluation of how we understand focus and  productivity. Why are we telling ourselves that being 100 percent productive is normal and any deviation should be "fixed" with meth or other medications? What if it's not us that's disordered but how we culturally approach productivity that is disordered.   Perhaps it's much more useful for us to reimagine how we navigate productivity and since it seems like a lot of us have this same issue, it's not something to be fixed but rather something to adapt with and seen as just another way of being. Same with autism and similar "disorders"  We aren't disordered. We are disconnected. Why do we have to adhere to someone else's metric of reality when reality is so vast and varied?

I take vyvanse and i definitely notice the side effects. Sometimes I get slight headaches, dizziness, increased heart rate, being thirstier, decreased appetite, and insomnia. I totally agree with the focus thing. When I am taking it I feel like I have so much more productive energy. Instead of wanting to sit around and watch tv or play video games I have a big desire to get tasks done. I want to finish chores or work on my business and I feel accomplished afterwards. So for me the side effects are worth the benefits I get. I also know if I need to stop taking it (if I get pregnant) than I know that I can also live without it.
Your brain after realizing that it had ADHD gave you more extreme versions of your daily symptoms. It makes you more aware but supposedly having it for your entire life, all of the sudden in just spikes out of nowhere??? You‚Äôre saying that happened after you got tested for it. I guess depending on the person can differentiate different kinds of low and high symptoms of the condition. I don‚Äôt personally think that all ADD, ADHD, and other conditions relating to a different way of experiences can always be solved with medication. I understand this isn‚Äôt true for everyone but in the past decade, 1 in 8 kids apparently have ADHD or some kind of symptom in that category. I‚Äôve had a couple of friends that do worse mentally and physically when taking medication but others who‚Äôve done really well. It really is a complicated subject with not many clear answers.

hiiii!!1!!!!2!!!!
I have the exact same problem and it took me a lot of work to be able to get results, I have trained myself to be able to work on or off medication. However, I took dexmethylphenidate, which is an extended release version of methylphenidate and it does exactly enough to get you to focus on something but also allows you to shift focus when necessary. I would very much recommend to talk to your doctor about trying that at a low dosage to see if it works for you because it was legitimately the only reason why I got through school and graduated with my degree cum laude. And I'm proud of myself for that.  Personally, Vyvanse made me throw up and made me feel nauseous frequently, but it was probably also a combination of that and low iron, which I had frequently as a child, and Adderall made me way too intense, like it was me and a good version of me but dialed up to 11 and my teachers couldn't stand me. Although I was actually able to do everything that I needed to do and pay attention in class.  I have not needed medications since I graduated, but it took me a while to learn how to be normally functional within society without medication since I was on at least one form of medication since second grade. And I legitimately think that the long-term effect of using, initially concerta methylphenidate and then later dexmethylphenidate after the family insurance changed in high school, actually changed my brain chemistry to be able to function about 50% of what normal people have control over with focus and by training myself with work, I've gotten to about like 75% focus efficiency. And once again mileage may vary with any of these. This is just my personal experience and I think it is important for me and for people that were diagnosed later in life that I give them firsthand knowledge and resources of my own experience living with ADHD.

I too was diagnosed with ADHD 2 years ago, at age 24. The only med I've used thus far is Ritalin, and that's because it works remarkably well for me. The only downside of it is that it has a really short action; it only lasts for about 4 hours, and then it pretty rapidly wears off, and I feel like a zombie for about 4 more hours. The amount of work that I can get done during the active 4 hours is staggering, though. I'm getting my PhD, and I'd never have been able to make it through my qualifying exam, write papers, or submit a grant application without it

ADHD is actually definitely like having a bunch of people in your brain but instead of disassociative identity disorder where they sorta like, take turns with the wheel and have different identities, they just all have control of the internal dialogue at once. And none of them are different people than you are. It's just a bunch of copies of yourself all slightly out of sync, and you're trying to follow instructions from a Twitch chat they're all shitposting in. I took concerta for years and at the start it was great i was excelling at everything i did but over time i felt it sucked all the emotions out of me. all i could be was silent and irritable and nothing gave me any sense of urgency. my body could be screaming for water and i would know i was extremely dehydrated and be very thirsty but would feel absolutely no desire to get up and care for myself or i simply didnt care. Meds aren‚Äôt a magical fix - they‚Äôre a tool. Finding good practices outside of meds are the best path to success.   Use meds yo help you establish those good habits. While on mine one day, I sat for like an hour planning out a weekly schedule and setting alarms on my phone to play throughout the day with encouraging messages. I don‚Äôt follow them, but they‚Äôre good reminders to pull my brain back on task.   To help control side effects of your meds: Exercise - even if it‚Äôs just a walk now and again, and drink a ton of water. Take breaks from them too if you can, I normally don‚Äôt take mine on the weekend. ADHD meds put strain on the heart - but so does the stress of not getting work done üòÖ.   Just like Icecream Sandwich says here though - meds aren‚Äôt for everybody. In this case finding a good therapist (if you‚Äôre able to) that specializes in ADHD would help tremendously.    You still have an ADHD brain no matter what. Our brains aren‚Äôt ‚Äúwrong‚Äù, we‚Äôre just existing in a world not suited for us. Meds help us do what we need to do in order to survive, but we have to make them work for us - not expect them to make us work.

I have ADHD but I just take... caffeine. Zipfizz, Tea, Coffee (if desperate), caffeine gum, and/or energy drinks can be the best friend of ADHD uhh... havers? Sufferers? Teh Adhuds (nailed it).  It doesn't *solve* problems, but it does make it a easier to focus. Your milage may vary, unfortunately. Caffeine is a pretty light touch compared to prescriptions. And depending on your body/brain, caffeine may make you sleepy instead of focused, maybe depending on combinations (or lack thereof) with B Vitamins etc. Also for some it can cause or exacerbate tension headaches. I try to sleep, nope, brain doesn't want that, time to lie on my back trying to force myself to fall asleep for several hours, give up, go on my phone, stay on that for hours, I have to leave for school, my brain now wants to sleep. I was on Concerta first, it did nothing. Vyvanse was a miracle drug at first, I was very productive, but as I got further into my teenage years I noticed I was getting more and more depressed. I'm not even sure it's on the list of side effects. But that was my experience. I also stopped taking my meds and my dad went utterly ballistic when he found out because apparently that can destroy your liver with this class of medicine! Fun.   These days I'm able to turn what was a crippling condition for a school environment where you're expected to stay on task and do *the thing* into an asset -- I don't think on one track like most people seem to, I can context switch and then pick back up where I left off with ease, provided it's something I enjoy, which overall I would say I do enjoy my job as I got lucky enough to end up working in the field of my life's passion. Get a support call while I'm working on a deployment script for a project later on in the year? No problem, how ya doin', what can I do for you. Then once it's over I don't even need to try to remember where I was and what I was trying to do. However I don't do well with deadlines just as before. So there's still that struggle.

Hiya! Totally random stranger here! I was diagnosed as a kid, I‚Äôm also a girl, and as we are generally harder to diagnose due to differentiation of symptoms, I suppose you could say I was an somewhat extreme case.  I took concerta for many years, though, now that I‚Äôm older, I can tell it messed me up pretty bad. Sure I could focus and get things done, but I had compulsory ticks like picking my skin, braiding my hair, or general fidgety nonsense I literally could not stop.  I was a young adult when I learned about a nutritional supplement called ‚ÄòEmpower.‚Äô This is also around the time I learned how diet affects your brain, hormones, and general well-being. Long story long, Empower really helped me, and though I can‚Äôt currently afford it anymore, it still helped me at my worst, and I‚Äôve become a lot more capable and healthier due to its support.  It also super super helps with your anxiety!! It‚Äôs crazy!! I was finally able to drive a car without wanting to cry.

hehe dancing polish cow
This video is crazy relatable, I got diagnosed with adhd a couple months ago as a first year uni student that struggled with keeping up with classes and my friends that studied with pointed out that I showed many symptoms of adhd. Got it diagnosed and was prescribed generic 18mg methylphenidate. Life changing, I could do things that I could never start doing, I cleaned my fricking room cause I only noticed how messy it was on meds. Although I only felt most of the symptoms for   2 days (time feeling slow and quiet mind) most of the negative symptoms (lack of appetite, increased heart rate, dry mouth nausea)remained as I went on taking it. I logged every day and the symptoms I felt on it and realized that I still have trouble focusing on lectures and conversations with my friends. I researched the different type of adhd meds there were so I wanted to try something different. I had an appointment scheduled with my psychiatrist a month after for a check up and I told her I wanted to try vyvanse. Another thing I found out was that my personality was a lot more muted on meds and even my friends would point it out. So often times I would not take it on days where I didn't have class or I knew I wouldn't require me to do anything productive and that has worked pretty well for me. It's also helped my habits when I'm not on meds bc of how frequently I go on and off. Haven't tried Vyvanse yet cause I'm been procrastinating on picking it up but was prescribed Vyvanse 30mg iirc.
So, I am on vyvanse and when I started out I was on 30mg and had headaches. Over a month and half they went away and my doctor upped the dosage to 35 and then 40mg. At 40mg I am at my productive and finally feel like a normal person. So, it might take time like it did for me for the adverse symptoms to go away. That being said when my pharmacy ran out of medication for a few weeks I did experience severe depression due to the lack of dopamine and was very tired.
First: excitement, at a new ics video Second: disappointment, my partner is asleep and I'll laugh too much and the bed will shake from me laughing and she'll wake up so I have to wait to watch it Third: anticipation, for tomorrow will have a high point predetermined
I use to take Vyvanse and I could focus but creatively I was restricted to my absolute minimal amount.

ADHD meds are a wild ride, I went through Estratera, Concerta and Tradea. Estratera worked for a while, but my psychiatrist died of old age and my new psychiatrist told me that that one wasn't good for me, so he prescribed Concerta. That one nearly killed me, it too made me feel as if I had covid, I was trembling all day, I couldn't focus because I flat out couldn't think, at some point I was struggling to articulate and the reason why I stopped taking it was because it made me convulse. So I called my therapist and said ".... my bad, take Tradea instead" and that one worked for me.
I've been medicated on concerta for a few years now and it has been very helpful, I just wish that I had found out when it wasn't 5 weeks before my GCSE's, lol.  I also know that when I was taking a higher dose to what I take now (we were seeing what was the best dose for me) if I accidentally forgot to take it in the morning, there was a chance I'd just fall asleep randomly at some point in the afternoon. This lead to me explaining to my teacher what happened while feeling stressed cause I had fallen asleep in class and was worried I'd be in trouble üò¨ Luckily she understood and I'm on a dosage that doesn't make me pass out, lol
As someone with ADHD and having to take meds to stay on task, you might get used to it.
Why is‚Ä¶ the ‚Äúsquare one‚Äù version of uhhh Andy? If his name isn‚Äôt Andy it‚Äôs Andy now. V1 Andy (no drugs) is literally me. Interesting. Anyways I‚Äôm watching this instead of doing schoolwork so. Yeah.
I never thought I could have ADHD, because I have always had this ability to hyperfocus on things. Like, if I get into an art project, I can go 17 hours straight without stopping to eat, pee, or whatever. (It is not surprising to also know I have been hospitalized with life-threatening dehydration several times, and now I have alarms on my phone that just go off randomly throughout the day, mostly to remind me time is passing and I should probably drink some water.) Under the impression that ADHD is just "One time and band camp I told m--WHOA, Squirrel! Lol."  Yeah, sometimes it is lol squirrel. But really, if I'm having trouble focusing, it's because my interest is not sparked. If I can generate interest, I can hit that focus. (The issue for me is the emotional turmoil that comes when I'm forced to disengage from a task--I get so angry and sad, it's so hard to stop.)  There are a couple of tricks I've found off medication that work. One genius trick is the 2-minute rule. If any task will take you less than two minutes to complete, do it immediately. If you change your clothes and drop them on the ground, but you know it will take a minute to either put them in the laundry basket or put them away, do it. Anything more than two minutes, schedule it. Putting away clothes is a couple minutes, but if you have to do a load of laundry, plan for it.   Which is a second great trick, journaling. If you have the time, fantastic tool. Before the hellscape of my current job, I was just getting into Bujo, or bullet journaling, because the biggest benefit was being able to write on any page in any order and just add it to the index. Plus, it was fun to get creative with it each month. But I haven't had any time to write down anything, help, I need an adult and a better workplace.   And finally, most recently, I saw a short where a gal explained to motivate herself in her depression slumps to do things like clean her space, she'd just "hire" herself as a housekeeper and roleplay it. She explained it more like a monetary incentive, where the money she would have paid a lady for a couple hours of work could be used for a treat instead. But I'm a broke ass bitch. No, what appealed to me was the roleplaying aspect. Turning it into a game. Literally acting out the scene to myself. I had a very active imagination as a kid and would often act out scenes in my head, playing different roles and dreaming up scenarios. To me, the thought of doing that again but as a put-upon cleaner was appealing. I haven't had a chance to put it to a test, but I imagine it could be very effective for the right person. Or, you  know, you could pay yourself for your chores too if you have expendable income. That's probably not a bad thought.   On a sidenote - I take Vyvanse, though I've had to juggle how I take it. I actually have an alarm to wake me up two hours before I'm meant to be awake and take it then, and then I can't oversleep (literally can't) and I can use the daily morning routine to plan out my day instead of getting caught in a task when it kicks in. I also refused to go up beyond 40 mg, but that's mostly because the pill capsule is super pretty and matches my room decor... But also because I do not want to make my sleep schedule even worse. Speaking of, the downside to this method is that if I sleep through my alarm, I cannot take my meds that day because they will keep me awake at night when I should be sleeping. So some days do be like that tho.   Still, it's good to stop taking it if you feel bad on it. I don't fuck around with SSRIs and SNRIs, and I had a bad reaction to Adderall because it floods all the monoamines, including serotonin. But I think the worst for me was when I was taking an SNRI and had debilitating responses. Like, seizures while sleeping and nonstop shakes that were so bad I couldn't navigate stairs and fell in the shower. My psychiatrist was convinced it was nothing, but my doctor advocated for me when I saw him. Bless him, he's the best, because Brenda was overbearing and a brat. If you feel bad on medication, do not take it! That's good advice. Of course, work with your doctor if you're able as it may need to be tapered. But if it's really bad, don't wait.   Adderall isn't really meth though.... As in, studies show that while they are structurally similar, their mode of action on Dopamine in the brain differs. One study (on rats, to clarify) showed methamphetamine essentially released far larger farts of dopamine, while dexamphetamine (Adderall) did not release as much. However, where meth was a stronger agonist of dopamine, dexamphetamine was better and slowing reuptake. Essentially, meth had really loud, noticeable farts, but they cleared pretty quickly, whereas dexamphetamine had some quiet, less impressive toots, but they really made the room stink in a way that lingered.  (In this metaphor, your brain has a fart kink, I guess?) Because the goal is to keep the dopamine in action longer, this makes it more effective for therapeutic use. And because the intense euphoria and highs of meth aren't sharted out in an explosive poot, it is far less addictive and has much lower abuse potential.   Don't let me teach science. It is a mistake.

I'm NOT in denial about having ADHD, I'm NOT, because I DON'T have it!  I just... get distracted easily, and get caught up in my own thought at the worst possible times. My thinking process goes a little something like this:  Man, I got a GREAT IDEA for this story! Let's write as much as we can today! How do we start though? Let's watch a couple of videos on how to set up story structure... 6 hours later I've watched 2 hours worth of literature based content, 3 hours gaming, and 1 hour of menial physical tasks. Each activity lasting no longer than 30 minutes before being swapped between. The day is then shot, I go to bed, and forget what I was even trying to accomplish in the first place. I have the focus of a fish.  I remember trying to be a plumber was taxing. They would teach us something, my mind would wander into something else, they would tell us to go do "it", I would pretend to know what I was doing, then come back half an hour later, "Yeah can you repeat that whole thing again?" JUST FOR MY MIND TO WANDER AGAIN. Then since it would be almost an insult to ask a third time because I am so thick headed, I would just be like "Thanks manüòÖ" and PREY I don't make too many people mad that day.

Hi man, ADHD meds work different on everyone, and each kind is a little different, so if you feel like it in the future there are still more kinds you can try. but meds dont work all by themselves either, working with a psychologist on coping mechanisms or whatever is helpful too. What I learned about Vyvanse the hard way: Vyvanse causes you to be able to focus incredibly hard, like hard enough that you don't even realize you've been working for 8 hours straight until you get hungry, however if you mess up you can focus on the wrong thing and it's near impossible to forget about that and go back to what you were focusing on
For me a big help has been learning ADHD friendly organization skills, cognitive behavioral therapy and being very open with my teammates and coworkers on my strengths and weaknesses. Pair-programming life with my partner and coworkers too, like, telling them what I plan to do in a day and checking if it's realistic can be really helpful. How to ADHD has been wonderful, also the Junebug method of cleaning, and Sunsama have all helped me a lof.

This wake-up then distracted b/c 'not focused on the right thing' feedback loop is common among much of the population.  ADD poster-child since I was born 45 years ago, and that aspect is less of 'medication not helping' than one's own discipline / self-awareness orienting towards tasks for the day.    ADD meds are not some easy fix.  Middle son of a psychiatrist here, yet even when I tugged at my mom's arm to ask if maybe I had ADD (as a tyke back in the 80s,) she was not able to see a "flaw" in a son so close to her face.  Was not until I was in college that a diagnosis happened, and me mom reluctantly confirmed.  So I think you are fortunate to have had the opportunity to develop coping mechanisms in the meantime.  Just my opinion.  Introduction of meds requires additional adjustment & self reflection.  They are just a tool.  Some of the most intelligent problem-solvers I have ever met have the same symptoms.  Now with portable technology overwhelming everyone on a daily basis the playing field is almost level.    Those cheating by taking ADD meds illegitimately generally will find side effects are worse for them, and that taking drugs to enhance performance is not sustainable.  Kind of like cocaine abusers.
Lol love the vid
for me concerta ( what ever the name is ) I litterly have head aches
I've been without meds for years. It is hard to focus a lot of the time, but I think I found something that might work for me.   I have this pair of earmuffs, the kind you wear to protect your hearing from really loud things, and it really helps to cut down the ambient auditory stimulation. When I do this, it's a lot easier to sit and think critically. It also helps to be in a good space that's conducive to learning/thinking. For me, this means: a table to sit at, good lighting, enough space, no videos to visually distract me, and no other people moving around that I would need to consider in any way.   If I'm trying to focus on physical tasks, a hat with a brim helps me block the visual stimuli of the tv that's always on in the background by simply looking down a little. My eyes are really good at picking up motion, so it's important I make it harder to do that.  If you read this, I hope this helps you find your own answer!

My experience with ADD medication started off what I thought at the time was great. My focus and grades improved, my thoughts felt organized and overall I was more productive.   However there were downsides I wasn't noticing enough. For one this newfound focus kinda eliminated my personality, I was just constantly zonked out. And my appetite drastically decreased. I got pretty thin.  Then during middle school step up day, a field trip where 5th graders take a day to experience what middle school is like, I got into an accident in gym class where I fell and hit the back of my head.  Went into a full blown unconsciousness seizure. Turns out the medication I had been taking lowered my seizure threshold, meaning I was much more susceptible to seizures from impacts to the head.   Haven't taken ADD meds since

One problem I've noticed is that there is a LOT of inconsistency in ADHD medication therapy. I only have a degree in biochemistry, but I'm also one of the very few EXTREMELY treatment resistant ADHD patients out there. STICK WITH YOUR MEDS AND FIND THE ONE/DOSE THAT WORKS. There are dozens of medications out there.  I will point out very strongly that all ADHD medications work the same fundamental way, pumping a specific part your prefrontal cortex full of dopamine and norepenephrine. "Stimulant" or not, the medication, none are "more mellow" or "more intense", what matters is the dose and the patient, you will experience a medication differently to other people with ADHD. That's why there are so many ADHD drugs. Your friend implying that "vyvanse" is "more mellow" is completely wrong and misleading. Vyvanse is an amphetamine. Lisdexamfetamine. Adderall is not meth. Literal meth is meth. And yes, methamphetamine is a pharmaceutical, on-label medication for ADHD.  Per the couple adult ADHD specialist psychiatrists I've known, Adderall is a stupid drug to start people on. The current data says that about 80% of all patients respond to Ritalin, 27% respond to ALL THE OTHER DRUGS COMBINED, and about 3% don't respond to any ADHD drugs.  Also, and this is only starting to gain adoption among psychiatrists, is to start every ADHD patient on a non ADHD medication called "clonidine" (alternatively guanfacine). These are (at high doses) alpha blockers for your heart. But at low doses, they work on the glutamate neurotransmitter and something that essentially all ADHD patients have: Sensory Sensitivity. Startle reflex, insomnia, loud noises being very uncomfortable, etc. By adding clonidine to whatever medication you're taking, you can both reduce the amount of that med you need as well as potentially take a medication that was causing side effects or wasn't working, and make it work. Clonidine is generally considered a "magic bullet" in adhd treatment right now, as it doesn't fix the ADHD, but it can REALLY help with the meds to treat the whole package.  Also, the formulation of the medication matters. My psychiatrist says he's been seeing some generic forms of focalin (racemic ritalin) to not be working as well as the brand name lately. Also, how the same medication is converted from the pill itself into the medication can impact how it works. Some convert it in the digestive tract, some through the liver.  Medications all affect different parts of the prefrontal cortex differently, which is why some drugs work and some don't for us. We have a problem with a specific area of the PFC, and until we get the right medication, all the wrong ones do is over-stimulate areas that already have normal levels.   Lastly, don't give up on meds. For me, I'm stuck in a circle of suffering because I accidentally stumbled into the wonder-drug that solved 100% of my symptoms (with clonidine) and had zero side effects, was affordable, and insurance somehow covered it, despite it being completely off-label. I never even failed a drug test with it (which is funny, because you always fail them with regular stimulant meds)  And that drug was hydrocodone. I was on it for five years, completely stable, no dependence, no side effects, nothing. Turns out that before antipsychotic medication, opiates were used, and in the RARE number of patients it worked in, it was called "the opiate cure". There's a case-report book written by a pain physician, Dr. Robert Cochran, chronicling how in some of his pain patients that had dopamine-norepenephrine disorders like ADD and bipolar, their opiate therapy for their injury also treated their psych symptoms. I had to stop it because my state has been cracking down on the opioid crisis and treating all prescribing doctors like drug dealers, and my psych and I agreed that it wasn't worth putting his license in jeopardy. So I've been suffering with basically zero relief for the last ~5 years, despite all the medications known.   I'm insanely jealous of people who get relief from normal adhd medications. I wish I did. Focalin + clonidine barely scratches my symptoms and I've been forced to just brute-force my way through my degree and into med school. I would love nothing more than to just go back on the stupid narcotic, it made me functional and normal, and even when I stopped it overnight, I had zero withdrawal. In 5 years I never developed a dependence or tolerance, my dose was so low. I work so insanely hard to get 10% of the results that 97% of ADHD people can.
Dunno if I said this on the last vid but my one allergy is riddilen with its wacky out of the way spelling, I took "normal" adhd meds until, well, I got dangerously underweight, and then I found out that "hey, i dont seem to have adhd anymore" so yeah, this has been nice

i also take Vyvanse for adhd. and in my experience, it works amazingly. when i have no meds, i'm very easily distracted and i get literally nothing done all day. i also flap my hands and move my feet a lot as stimming. when i do have meds, i can almost focus perfectly and i don't constantly stim all the time. and by the way, you are VERY lucky you didn't get any negative side effects from going off of it. because from what i've heard, the withdrawal symptoms are INCREADIBLY bad! so bad, you would wish you were dead! also, fun fact: Vyvanse is illegal to own and consume *UNLESS* prescribed by a doctor. because it's classified as a "narcotic drug" (meth and all those other bad drugs are also narcotic drugs). ANOTHER FUN FACT: if someone without adhd takes Vyvanse, it's basically the same as consuming caffeine. it would cause the person to become energetic and jittery. but for people with adhd, it does the opposite. it mellows them out and lets them focus.

Up until almost 2 years ago I was taking ADHD medication, unlike other cases I was diagnosed directly after symptoms started showing up. When I started my teenage years, I was sluggish and depressed all the time. So I just stopped taking them, didn't talk to my doctor, or my mom just when cold turkey after 12 years. "I don't know what HD is, by my doctor said I have 80 of them"
It sounds to me like while you were on it you never had a "release" from the meds. If you can, check if your dose was for 24hr or 12hr release. When I had 24hr release I developed anxiety while on it since I was in a constant state of artificially induced focus you won't realize it till the first panic attack hits. Taking a day off of the meds in my experience has helped a lot (consult doctor first before doing this). Additionally, you must eat - no skipped lunches or breakfasts - and you must drink a lot of water. ADHD meds are appetite suppressants and drinking water helps a ton with sustaining focus as well as giving you a reason to briefly separate from your work to think and refill your supply.

To focused on important or really stupid stuff that could've got me in trouble üòÖ.   Now a days I just adjust to my ADHD. It helps but me having depression doesn't help it alot. I got diagnosed with ADHD as an adult just last summer. I've only just started on generic concerta last month. I totally understand that sudden ability to *do* stuff that used to take me hours to work up the motivation to unmedicated. I have no experience with other meds so I can't comment on them, but for methylphenidate at least I found it helps me stand up and deal with a task, instead of dealing with the wall of executive dysfunction. Like a lot of folks, the effect can vary depending on the day, and sometimes I feel like my dose is too low and almost ineffective, where other days I can get mountains of things done. The unfortunate thing about these meds is that we really gotta just try them all until you find the one that works best with your brain chemistry, and I'm sure we've all heard that line from our doctors at least once. Also, to my fellow adhd peers who managed to read this far, you should go brush and floss your teeth and drink water. Maybe unclench your jaw and eat a carrot. Love you guys!

Very valuable video, I always enjoy hearing other people's experience with ADHD meds I've been diagnosed with ADHD when I was still a kid and I've only ever taken Ritalin, I stopped for a while during my teenagehood because I hated how it made me feel  I'm taking it again now for work, and I must say my experience with it is the exact same as yours with Adderall, worked splendidly the first couple of months, and ever since for nearly 2 years of taking it it's been about as much an hinderance as a help, I especially like how you put it, I can do physical tasks like cleaning around the house just fine and way more efficiently than I ever could off meds, but anything not that concrete I struggle to stay on task just like when I'm unmedicated, I learn programming and when I have to get a little creative about finding solutions is where I can stall my works for days to week even on medication; additionally in my experience I found that the meds still helped me with sitting still to learn, watching courses and lectures, and I can focus on work if I'm doing something completely new to me, but not when applying already mastered knowledge  I have two friends (adderall) and my brother (ritalin) who have had the exact same experience with their ADHD meds (super efficient and life changing at the start, then rapidly enter this state of not being able to do their job, they are all in creative-ish jobs, including programming and drawing, and the way I perceived it was always that creative endeavours or any task that is too open-ended giving me a lot of agency is what the meds don't help me do at all.)  Just felt like sharing because I don't know how many more people with ADHD struggle with their medication, know that you guys are not alone I'm going to bring up Vyvanse to my psych and give it a try after watching this, it might do the trick for me, thank you ICS for sharing your experience!

Finding the right meds can be a hell of a thing. I tried two as a teenager and neither worked or did much. I also was taking them for the wrong reasons. Luckily enough the first meds I tried as an adult have been very helpful for me  (which was Vyvanse and you pretty much nailed how it works perfectly lmao), but ADHD is such a broad condition that it's really hard to figure out not only the kind of medication but also the dosage that could do the things you want it to.  Hopefully if you're willing to keep trying medication that you do find something that works for you. The relief I felt in finding that for myself was huge and I wish it for anyone else who's exploring this avenue.
i had untreated (but diagnosed) adhd for two years and then i went to the doctor and she told me that i should become medicated i take methylphenidate and it has kind of just made the brain loud less loud (and i sometimes have the ability to do!!) but the symptoms are still there, just,,,,,,, muffled kinda i had a say in what i started taking, which was great because i didn't want to have really severe side effects or lasting effects, so we talked that through for a while and finally settled on methylphenidate i take 40 milligrams every day and it usually lasts through the school day but sometimes it does not work and i have a sad
I have a buddy that went through like 6 or so medications to find the right one for him, so don't be discouraged!  I remember the first time I took my meds (concerta), half an hour after I felt like my third eye had opened and I remember asking my roommate "wait, is this how everybody else feels *all of the time* and I've just been missing out?". I did have issues with tunnel vision on whatever I happened to have been working on becoming the most important thing but I actually was able to time when they kicked in pretty well, so I could start like 5 minutes before the kick and then be on the right thing. What eventually became more effective was using a notebook as a day planner and setting lots of alarms to make me check myself on what I was supposed to be doing. Eventually that built a habit (in a way I had never been able to functionally make a habit before) and helped me wrestle back some of the executive functions of my brain from the 5 man 8 trumpet band running the show.
I‚Äôve had ADHD ever since I started grade school, and took meds starting around 1st grade. The stuff works great up until I started high school. During my freshman year my body physically started to ‚Äúreject‚Äù (regurgitate) the medication shortly after I would take it. Im not quite sure why but if anyone reading this knows why or has had a similar experience I‚Äôd be quite interested to hear. Anyways, I figured that probably wasn‚Äôt healthy, so I stopped taking meds and have been off them ever since. In my experience, medication is a short term solution and it‚Äôs best to learn how to manage it. This is so euphoric
My turning point for ADHD was when I stopped looking at it as something to "get rid of". I have had it my whole life and I have been aware of it my whole life. This has allowed me to kinda pull on the reins a lot more than other people who also suffer with it. I view it as kind of a super power. You have to build a legit TRUCKLOAD of mental power to get yourself to do things but once you do... Hyperfocus kicks in. I can get WAY more done than the average person because I can just get lost in something for HOURS and HOURS and HOURS. There are still days where I just follow the dopamine and lose the whole day but I have learned to turn those days into kind of "reward days" for after I do something really hard. Im a musician and one of the hardest things I do is get a full song done. Once I do that, I will sit down for a day and just tunnel. It teaches my brain that if I do something productive I still get to do what my brain wants me to do and its a huge boost to make me wanna do the things that aren't the most desirable. Like school. Or work.   With this being said, ADHD is different for every single person that has it. This may work for me and it may be something worth trying for others, but don't get upset if it doesn't work. Everyones brains are different and require different means of attack for mental issues. Just know you're not alone.

Ask your psychiatrist to give you a trial of two weeks of Concerta, and while you wait for insurance to cover it, also get a two week supply of Adderall XR, that way if they deny it, you can at least continue getting the Adderall until the Concerta is either covered, or denied again by your insurance.
