Oh boy Vyvanse is fuuuuuun. Makes me feel bleh all the time, never hungry, and just kinda dull
I hope you figure out something that works for you. It can seriously be a nightmare finding something that works.  I was diagnosed during covid too, and needed extra support from meds. First, I tried Adderall. I hated it. It made me even more bounce from task to task, and where I normally had 10 browser windows open with 10 pages on each in my brain, it would force me to have a max of 2 total pages/windows. If anything else popped up, it would auto shut down another. It also mixed horribly with my PTSD and aggravated those symptoms. That sucked. I only took it for about 2 or 3 days. Then I tried Concerta. I had all of the bad side effects by the second day, including, over heating, sweating, flushing in the face, constipation, and extremely emotional. I cried for hours all the way up to exactly the 12 hour mark from when I took it that morning. I stopped it then and there. Next, we tried a non stimulant, Strattera. It sucked. I tried it for about a week. It lowered my blood circulation so my hands and feet would be freezing when they shouldn't, and I'd wake in the middle of the night to my arm, having fallen asleep. Even if that would've subsided, I wasn't getting any benefits from it, and I'd have random brain shocks. It's like someone ran an electrical pulse through your body to your brain whenever you stopped thinking about it. It would happen when you'd leat expect it and it would happen repeatedly. I couldn't do it. He wasn't sure what to do, so we tried some meds for 12 hour shift workers. It kinda helped, not a ton, but some. Not enough for the cost. I gave up and took a break from it all for a couple of months as my insurance changed anyway.  When I promptly flopped in school due to my struggles, I realized no, I really needed meds. So I found a new meds person who came up with a genuine plan with me and noted the need to address my ptsd too with some antidepressants. So I tried vyvanse and an antidepressant combo, and it works. It's been working for a year now. When I consistently take them every morning for at least 2 weeks, it's almost a feeling that my ptsd doesn't exist, and my adhd is manageable. It's wild. I can work now because of it. Honestly it's only after the support from the meds I realized just how bad of a place I'd been trudging through on my own for so long.   Tl:DR, some meds don't mix well with various mental health conditions, and you should check on that. My adhd meds weren't mixing well independently with my ptsd and I needed antidepressants to actually help balance everything out.
As someone with ADHD im currently watching this procrastinating
JUSTICE FOR COMPY.
Vyvanse made me severely depressed, killed my appetite, prevented me from sleeping and made me feel sick and out of energy constantly. Easy to say I no longer take vyvanse
Oh also, I'd give adderall another chance. I've been taking it since 5th grade, and it's just a matter of getting a feel for the focus it gives you. I've used it to write entire 2000 word essays in the span of an hour, read moby dick in a day, and ace pretty much every test I've ever taken. The meds only do part of the work, you have to do the other part
I took ADHD meds (first Ritalin, then Concerta, then Ritalin AND Concerta) from when I was five until my last year of high school. All throughout school, I was a genius. Straight-A's and B's (excluding Band, which I stank at but couldn't drop for reasons). My dad wanted me to "wean" myself off of ADHD meds before I was an adult, so I wouldn't need them as a "crutch". I stopped taking them and promptly scored a 33 on the ACT. "Great," we all thought, "[I] don't need the medication to be functional!" We all ignored the fact that I actually took them on the day of the test.  Thirteen years later, and my life is a mess. I dropped out of college twice, I am incapable of coherently applying myself on any subject. I have difficulty staying awake when I should be awake, and difficulty sleeping when I should be asleep. My mood varies from "suicidal depression" to "I can take on the world and win" on a minute-by-minute basis.  This is not a "cautionary tale". Correlation does not imply causation and vice-versa. This is simply my personal experience, and I can't help but note that the time when I stopped taking ADHD medication and the time when I started to become unable to hold my life together are about the same.

Fwiw, (I also have ADHD & went through getting meds) it sounds like stimulants are not a good option for you (both Adderall & Vyvanse are stimulants). I'm on Strattera, which is a non-stimulant ADHD med, & it's helped me focus & initiate tasks without getting so stuck in a single thing for an entire day like Vyvanse did to you. If you're still at all interested in finding a med supported solution with your doctors, it could be worth asking about non-stimulant options.
Some people are too quick to jump when you say you're on or off meds for ADHD. We're all individuals, and ADHD is a spectrum. When I got put on Vyvanse, I was already on Zoloft for quite some time. They started me off on a low dose and encouraged me to keep taking my Zoloft. I noticed a massive difference in my quality of life. My anxiety is no longer a disorder, and my depression is not what it once was. My thoughts stopped racing before bed, and I could not believe how easy it was to get up from bed in the morning. There are some drawbacks, and I think you nailed them. I also feel my time blindness got worse on the meds. I could go on, but in the end, it comes down to preference; these medications are not specifically tailored to you or me as individuals. You know what is best for you.
Medication absolutely is hit or miss. It took my sister many many tries and she still hasn't found one that works for her. I'm so, so much better on medication, but I also still have days where I'm. LOCKED. into something else. Like playing Stardew Valley when i should have been recording a thing that was due today that I've known about!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! For 3 months. :D

have a look at concerta i took that from the age of 4 till i was about 17. never had any problems. only issues i had is when i was 16-17 as i was starting to work and was leaving school soon i wanted to start getting off them as my specialiest told me that if i can try to it would make life alot easier to get off the medication for adult life. the problem was during the week ends i would stop taking them and i would hit almost what would be considered a crash. i would have 0 energy or motivation to do anything. during the school holidays i noticed this would only last a good couple days before i started to feel better it probably didnt help that during my teenage years i would only get about 5-6 hours sleep everynight lol. fixing my sleeping patern has helped alot though. anyways concerta worked for me especially in school. might be worth checking out. they have 2 dosages for it here in australia. the white pill and the skin colour one. cant remember dosages but the skin colour one is the higher dose and slower burn.
I personally take Ritalin as my medication! The kind I have, there is a long-acting and a quick-release, and in my experience, it's somewhat more on the "ability to do thing" side of things, but there's still a lot of use on the "focus" side of things. I have some advice for what I've experienced with it. In addition I have some general ADHD advice.  I am not a professional and I encourage you to take all of this with a grain of salt, but I figure it might be helpful to get some general advice that I have learned and adopted over the years. I'm mostly just sharing my personal experience. You don't have to follow any of the advice either, I'm not your dad, do what you want.  Pros with ritalin: - I have the ability to do!! - only takes around 15-30 minutes to kick in ish - long acting lasts around 6-7 hours. The short quick release lasts 2-3 hours. - my focus is pretty solid - I can switch and end tasks efficiently. Especially when I'm doing something I'm not wanting to do but am distracted by it, I can go "nope. End task now" and then do that. - helps with both physical tasks and sit down tasks!  They recommend taking it with meals. I usually take mine around lunch/brunch or so (so like 10/11am) and then when I think I need it, I take the quick release around 6/7pm, or whenever I eat dinner. I don't take it on the weekends, giving myself a 2 day break from it, but it's not bad if I were to take it when I need it.  Cons I have noticed: - if I overwork my brain, I will get a headache/migraine when the meds wear off, if not, a little earlier. Easily fixed by one Advil/ibuprofen and some water/a snack, so it's not too bad - quick release usually gives me a headache when it's finished, but again, nothing too bad and can be fixed with pain killer and/or food and water - this does not help procrastination. I still sometimes have difficulty prioritizing my tasks  With ADHD, it really is a struggle. Meds help a good amount, but there's still plenty that can't as easily be fixed. It's best to try and combine a number of different coping mechanisms. I've lived with ADHD for a long time so I have found that there's a couple things that help, even when I'm off meds: - to-do lists! Check boxes!!! Sometimes having something to physically check off really helps because it marks that spot in our brain as "done! Okay move on!!". You don't have to check every box on the list, but sometimes it feels good just to make it. - generic lists! Even if it's not a to-do list, I can write a list of things I want, things I'm upset about, things I plan to do. It gets it out of my brain - break tasks down into smaller and smaller tasks. It makes starting easier and honestly? Sometimes the seemingly simple things are so so hard. Breaking it down into baby steps is sometimes necessary. Ex: "stop scrolling phone and heat up leftovers to eat" becomes "close phone">>"stand up">>"open fridge">>"take container">>"close fridge">>"open container">>"put in microwave">>"heat">>"get fork">>"eat". - you don't always have to do the above, but this helps with both burnout and bad ADHD days where even eating is hard. - pacing/physically moving while talking/planning/thinking out something you want to write. Especially helpful for writing essays and other such things!! Also, record yourself to listen back to (on your phone or somethin) cuz there's no way you'll remember after the fact - keeping momentum!! Sometimes I get home and do a specific task (like the dishes) before taking off my shoes. I'm riding the momentum of the thought instead of interrupting it with another task (shoes) - visual learning and visual and physical reminders! Charts, pictures, doodles, schedules on your fridge, bright pink sticky note reminders, corkboards, etc. And then multiples of it wherever you are, even if it's in an odd place, but one that you see often. For me, I'm a very physical and visual person. If I can picture it in my brain, it's easier to remember. - make a place for things and make things convenient. My wallet and keys go in the exact same place. There's a pen already attached to my fridge shopping list, and it stays there because it has a string keeping it there. No need for searching for a pen, nor for losing it in the first place. No need to remember. - be patient with yourself! Sometimes ADHD can overlap with depression and burnout. Sometimes the best thing you can do is rest. - making a habit and sticking to it is nearly impossible. I have tried to be like "okay I will do this every day" and then after 3 weeks of solidly doing it, I have not made a habit of it and stopping for one day means it's dropped forever. Honestly, I don't have a great solution for this, but it's good to be aware/mindful of it. Forming habits does not come easy, so just be patient.  There's others that I'm forgetting, probably, but that's the most important kinda stuff. Again, I'm not a professional and I'm not your dad, so you don't have to do anything I say and you should take everything I say with a grain of salt and pick and choose the kind of advice you like. It's whatever works for you. Just wanted to share my experience both with ADHD and Ritalin.  I wish you luck working with and through your ADHD!!! Definitely talk to a professional about the various medication options and also the specifics of your symptoms. This is all stuff I have learned from personal experience and my own experience with going to therapy. Not everything will work for everybody (who knows, the advice that works for me might make your problems worse), but it's important to try and make something that works for you. I hope this helps, or at least gives you some insight! ^^

I'm not medicated for adhd, because I have chronic tachycardia-- that is, high heart rate-- and pretty much all adhd meds are stimulants to some degree, and even if they don't give the "energy" boost to adhd brains like they do NT brains, they do still increase the heart rate.   And... honestly, what you described sounds a fair bit like what happens when I'm stupid and have caffeine anyway.   So... not saying you have what I have, but talk to your PCP about heart health.

I've been diagnosed and medicated for my ADHD since I was 8 years old, I've never been on anything other than Adderall, though. The description of Vyvanse has me intrigued ngl.  a month ago my prescription couldn't be filled for over a month. I take a decently high dose every day because I've been on it for over ten years and over time needed little bumps in dosage to keep the same effect. I've been on my current dosage for about five years now.  The month long experience of deprivation from my meds was simply..... unmatched in anything I've ever had before.  One day without my medication is normally fine, I've ended up skipping here and there because of circumstances. A few days was when things started crashing and burning. Felt like all the ropes that were holding me together just snapped and came loose. It felt like I couldn't *see.* I could view my surroundings but nothing ever *soaked in.* I was constantly exhausted despite absolutely sleeping more than normal. Terrifying experience I never want that again.
I've been on Ritalin for about a year now and it has been super helpful for me! Especially in the ~focus~ department but I totally get the struggle with finding something that works. I tried two other medications (that I can't remember the names of lol) before I got to Ritalin and then we had to figure out the right dosage. It was pretty weird bouncing around meds but totally worth it in the end imo, so if you think that meds are the right option for you then don't give up the search!! They really can be life changing!! I can't tell you how incredible it was to actually be a functioning person for the first time lmao but I think you know what I mean. Having ADHD can definitely be hard, like really hard sometimes, but don't forget that you're not alone!! I'm sure you'll find something that works for you!!

I was put on medication for ADHD in 1st grade, and cycled through about every type of ADHD medication you can imagine by high-school. For me it isn't worth it. The medications stopped working after a few months once I developed resistance to each one, and the side effects were always awful, no sleep and no appetite, brain completely on overdrive all the time. Now as an adult I have an Adderall script but I avoid taking it unless I absolutely have to, its just not worth taking medical meth. Mindfulness and being a small businesses owner help me manage my focus issues. Having a small business that requires physical work, and living on a homestead with lots of stimulating physical tasks works for me. I think ADHD is not really a disorder, it just makes what society considers a "productive" or "normal lifestyle" less attainable for people like us, and thats ok. Not everyone needs to work in an office and focus on single tasks at a time.

Your experience with Vyvanse is what I had with Ritalin. Took it for a couple days and was fine, and then one day I got winded from walking up a few steps (not flights, it was literally 5 steps). I also called my doctor who said to stop taking the med (which was ok because I was on the minimum dose and it was only week 2). But then I did short-term Adderall. It was fine, until the lethargy from the withdrawal got to the point that I had a hard time staying awake after work, driving home. I then swapped to Adderall XR (extended release) and have been on that for a year and change. Genuinely helps me achieve a baseline level of focus and motivation to do my work and then some at home.  I hope you are able to find a good set of resources and tools to help! Medication is just another resource, not the end all be all

I'm on both the ADHD and Autism spectrum. I've always avoided medication because I was convinced that I could just handle it. It's gotten pretty far out of my control and this video has helped me get a better glimpse of how the medications could work out. Thank you. :)
Thanks for sharing. I unofficially have ADHD and have been on Adderall before (by prescription). I was also dealing with depression and anxiety at the time and found it really helped. Unfortunately, it was too expensive and I was too poor/ uninsured at the time so I had to learn to live without it. How? I did what I always do and studied it. I actually started off studying ASD (autism) as it somewhat fit, but didn't think I had the theory of mind issues, so it was back to ADHD. When I learned that my hyperfocus and lack of ability to multitask were not a moral failing, I stopped hating myself for it and was able to compensate-using fear. While I don't recommend it to anyone (it's not healthy), I used my fear of financial instability and homelessness to focus on education and complete 2 college degrees, get a job in an excellent company with great benefits and have even been promoted. One of the main things I did was to  first set myself up for success by limiting my obligations.  This let me concentrate on school instead of everything else that was going wrong since there was not as much to go wrong. I knew that I couldn't juggle much, so I made sure I didn't have to. It made all the difference.
As my adhd doctor told me when I was diagnosed at 36: if anything doesn‚Äôt feel what the average person might call ‚Äúnormal‚Äù, it‚Äôs not the right medication and we need to try something else. Concerta was pretty good but acted too fast and made me feel a giddy. So she moved me to Vyvanse, but it impacted my sleep. So, in comes quiet middle child Biphentin and - boom - perfect fit.   Also, as a Canadian, it‚Äôs WILD to me that a patient would tell a medical professional ‚Äúput me on this one‚Äù rather than deferring to their recommendations first. Like‚Ä¶ask about it, sure‚Ä¶but going from Adderall to Vyvanse without stopping by Concerta first seems‚Ä¶like. A. Jump. But you‚Äôve also got ads for prescription medications going on down there, so‚Ä¶*shrug*

i was diagnosed with ADHD in 1st grade, vyvanse didnt work as i got crazy bad anger, my focaline mixed with music works almost perfect with no side affects for me
I'll tell my med story because after 5 fun months of figuring out meds I'm at a point were I have finally found what works for me. Started with generic ritalin which is methylphenidate. This type is the least strong of the main stimulant compounds that are using in adhd meds and as someone who has done research into these meds I'm surprised most prescribers will write up aderall over this for a first try. I started at 20 mg and over the next weeks I went up in dosage and changed from 8hour LA to 12 hour XR and eventually made my way to 54mg generic concerta, what I am on right now. Each time i went up in dosage it would work like i mostly wanted it to and then it wouldn't work as well as i wanted it to and this cycle reapeted each 10mg add in dosage until my phyc suggested adding guanfacine. When started taking it i knew it was what i wasn't getting from just stimulents. the stims help me stay focused on the tasks I'm doing, keeping me from spacing off completely, but no meds are going to stop someone from having thoughts so introducing a medication that calmed down my impulsivity is what i needed. For me without meds it's no focus and no pause button, concerta gives me the focus and guanfacine gives me the pause button. so when I'm working on HW and a good idea for my dnd character pops in my head i can have the ability to stop, ask myself what is the most important task at the moment, and then continue with my math, when if i weren't on meds i would have that rush of adrenaline from a new idea, which would give me that rush of dopamine, and 30 min later i have written a five page backstory but have left my math homework from the second i had that knew thought. So if anyone with both inattentive and hyperactive or just hyperactive adhd needs some med advice id recommend talking to your doctor about trying stimulents + guanfacine(or an equivalent) because i didn't realise how much hyperactivity (impulsivity) was affecting me because i wasn't physically jumping off the walls, but my brain was.

This hits home hard.  I was diagnosed with ADHD way back in grade 3, was on Ritalin until my mid 20's.  I was down to 10mg a day in the morning and could no longer deal with the side effects (horrible jaw clenching and crazy anxiety), so I decided to stop taking it.  For a while, things were fine, I had coping mechanisms, and I was able to build a routine and adapt.  A few years ago, everything started to fall apart, I've been trying to manage, and find new methods, but nothing worked.  I decided to go back on meds, talked to the doctor and requested the absolute lowest dose of something slow or extended release, I was apprehensive about going on Concerta, as it's the same drug as ritalin, and I didn't want to go through those side effects again.  However, when discussing with my doctor, I felt it was the safer option as I already knew I respond well to it, and know what side effects I can expect and watch out for.  I took my first dose today.  I sat down this morning and started work, I managed to complete a task from start to finish without getting up and wandering, picking up my phone, or any of the other things that I would usually do that would interrupt me.  This kept up through the whole day.  I felt amazing, I felt accomplished, and I felt like I managed to do something useful for the first time in YEARS.  Keep at it, hopefully you'll find a successful treatment in some way.
This man saved me from my anxiety, and now he's saving me from my ADHD

Not to backseat doctor, but I think youd find value in looking for an ADHD-specialized therapist/coach. Ive found ADHD-targeted cognitive behavioral therapy to be extremely useful in teaching me how to better wield the tool that is focus both on *and* off my medication. It taught me the behavioral mechanisms I needed to take advantage of to work with my ADHD and not against. Obviously its not like it (nor meds) are a ‚Äúcure‚Äù, but us ADHD folk often ignore the reality that the Neurotypical world is very much so built in a way our brains hate with a passion. Learning the tools on how to build an environment that works for *our* brain and not the default brain is has genuinely changed my life.

I'm not sure what brand I have (cuz my parents pay for it), but the pills that I take are 10mg of methylphenidate. They help me focus and do what I should be doing, but they also make me not feel... right, I guess? whenever I'm doing something i shouldn't be doing, like playing a video game or watching a show, when I have schoolwork I should be doing. However, they also make me not hungry and make my introverted side come out more, so lately I've been cutting the pills in half and taking 5mg half-pills instead of a 10mg full-pill, and it works pretty well to keep me on task, and keep my normal personality. Thanks for the reminder, I've just ubsubscribed!
I was diagnosed with the trifecta at an early age: ADHD, dyslexia, and asperger's. And I've been dealing with that my whole life. Way back when I was a little kid, my parents had me on Ritalin, and they kept me on it right up until the night that I freaked out because my bed was melting. That sounds like I'm making a joke, so let me be clear: I'm not. My bed was melting and there were feet walking around the living room with nobody attached to them. Turns out that Ritalin is in the same general category of drug as LSD. And I was hopped up on enough of it to make reality go sideways. They immediately took me off of it, and that was that. Ever since then I have been dealing with life unmedicated. Or at least mostly. I've developed a dependence on Dr Pepper, of all things. My parents used to give me coca-Cola to calm me down (because with my screwed up internal biochemistry, stimulants and depressants tend to work the opposite way on me) and as I grew up, I leaned into that more and more. I eventually discovered that something about Dr Pepper kept me at least moderately mentally balanced. Maybe it has just the right mixture of caffeine to phosphoric acid? Dunno. Anyway, that's what I use these days: Dr Pepper. It's cheap, it's legal and I can buy it at any supermarket, assuming they have any.

I had a somewhat different experience. My first medication was Vyvance, and it was perfect for productivity, but also evened everything out, almost like anti-depressants. I was quiet in social situations, since none of my thoughts felt conversation worthy, I was bored by everything, with no excitement or enjoyment at all, and I was overall a black and white person. Every morning I had to choose between having a productive day, or a good day. I couldn't waste my teen years being a husk. SO I took Concerta for a while. It was mostly the same, but to a lesser degree, so I was a bit more willing to work with it. Unfortunately, it also gave me incredible social anxiety and by extension self-doubt and even body image issues. I think this was because already dealt with these things and so Concerta picked them up and put them at the forefront of my mind. Not fun. Now I take something else that I don't remember the name of, and it's working alright for now. Good luck to the rest of you ADHD folks!

I have ADHD and I actually am currently taking Vyvanse. So, I think when I have my meds I have increased focus but totally shot memory. And vice versa. I also stopped blaming my stupidity on my ADHD and started putting some real effort into changing myself. I'm not perfect (which some people are adamant on reminding me of every day) but I'm at least making some progress even if slowly.

From experience, I've found that my mindset at the time my meds kick in generally determine how productive I am with the work I have to do. It's also been helpful for me to have some strategies to help make myself aware of my focus (or lack thereof) and what I can do to center my attention on what needs to be done. Meds are generally helpful, but mindset and other non-med strategies can also go a long way

I used to take medicine for ADHD when I was in like 9th grade, because I couldn't focus and my grades were suffering. I started taking one in the morning, and when I got to my first class we actually had a test. I was able to hard focus on the test like I had never been able to before, but I was also twitching and moving my leg up and down like a lot. I noticed it and tried to calm down. I did, but then I couldn't go back to my test. Eventually we tried other meds, they all kind of did the same thing, and the doctor was like "hm...yeah meds don't work...oh well!" And I've never taken any since. I'm now on track to go to the air force to become a Fighter Aircraft mechanic, and since I took the meds it actually almost cost me my chance to get in. But it's all good! Wish me luck and thank you for taking the time to read my comment!
As someone who has diagnosed adhd and had the first medication I took not work very well for very long, this is super relatable. I thought it was gonna be like a button that just suddenly got my brain together and immediately turned me into someone consistently functional and productive, and then that didn‚Äôt happen and I thought I just sucked at being a person. Nope, just hadn‚Äôt been the right thing for me!   The medication I‚Äôm on right now, Wellbutrin(aka Bupropion) has been working really well, and I‚Äôll be coming up on a year of use pretty soon. It isn‚Äôt exactly an ADHD medication, actually being an antidepressant, but it has been found to help with focus and concentrating for folks with ADHD. This makes sense because the root cause for ADHD and depression is pretty similar and boils down to Brain Have Not Enough Dopamine; it acts as a reuptake inhibitor for norepinephrine and dopamine, meaning it isn‚Äôt a stimulant like Aderall and just lets the Good Chemicals‚Ñ¢Ô∏è hang out in your brain a bit longer. So basically instead of just giving you more dopamine it uses what your brain already makes, making it non-addictive but still effective for many people.   Obviously I‚Äôm by no means a medical professional, so take this with a grain of salt. I just figure maybe someone will benefit from hearing about it since it‚Äôs not something considered an ADHD medication and doesn‚Äôt really come up when looking for ADHD-specific treatments as a result. This was something my therapist brought up with me when I mentioned how what I had been taking originally wasn‚Äôt working well, and it‚Äôs worked wonders for me, so perhaps it could be worth looking into for you and other folks in the same situation?

Have you tried like focusing?
You do not want medication, you want mental discipline. *Dramatic pause for angry commenters who stopped reading already*  Two things to clarify before I go on. 1. Medicine absolutely has it's place. 2. Discipline means multiple things. I am not referring to the practice of punishing someone to correct their behavior, but the skill of self discipline which is something that you have to actually learn.  Ok. Now that's out of the way. It's important to remember that doctors are often like hammers, and medicines/treatments are their nails. Doctors WANT to help you, and their trades (and billion dollar companies...) teach them that a lot of problems, especially problems in the squishy tissue between our ears, can be solved with medicine. And I don't really blame them for thinking or practicing this.  However this video describes the sort of results you should expect with medicines. They can HELP you focus, they can't MAKE you focus. And even that only sometimes. Drugs are the equivalent of putting seasoning into a stew. You generally know what the seasoning will do, but every single stew is different and seasonings will effect each one a different amount and in slightly different ways. Maybe garlic will make your stew better, maybe it will make it worse, maybe it needs thyme instead? Even doctors don't know what seasoning your brain stew needs precisely.  What you really want is the ability to make yourself focus on the task that you want to focus on, and for this purpose you want mental discipline. What is mental discipline? Basically, it's the skill of getting your mind and brain to do what you want them to do the way you want them to do it. Just like martial arts is a discipline for your body, you need brain kungfu so that you can move your brain in precise ways the same way you move your body in martial arts.  Ok great but how does one achieve brain-kungfu... Well it's simple, but hard. Like a physical discipline, it takes time and LOTS of practice. Here is a really simple way to start: Imagine up your own vision of the term "Nothingness". This could be an empty void or space without stars, or whatever your brain imagines when you think of "Nothing" or "Nothingness". Then spend 5-10 minutes trying to keep that image in your head. Any time that a stray thought, or you inner monologue intrudes, tell it to shut up and focus again on the "nothingness". Set a timer and close your eyes, if you have to keep looking at a clock it will make it harder. Then practice this EVERY DAY, extending to 15 or 20 minutes when you can easily manage 10. Congratulations, you have learned how to meditate.  It will be hard at first, maybe near impossible. But the point is not to succeed, but to practice. Over time, like months and years, you will train yourself how to block stray thoughts and interruptions while forcing your brain to focus on the thing you want it to focus on. It's not a magic cure, it's not easy and it still takes effort to keep focused, but just like being able to throw a kick and balance on one leg, it will go from a daunting impossibility to something you can do with little effort.  I hope you enjoyed my text wall, and I wish anyone who read it the best on their journey to brain kungfu.

Hey bestie (friendly term that means I kno we're not besties but I would like to help out anyone who sees this comment) I'm on strattera and it works great! Works exactly how I want it to! And I felt the same way as Ice Cream Sandwich did on Adderall, and over time I also needed to take more for it to be effective, and sometimes that meant having small overdoses (this was my own fault bc I would forget to take it and then not be used to big doses, take a big dose, and be horrified all day as my heart beat crazy fast and I was worried I needed to go to the ER til it wore off-- don't be like me!) but strattera isn't a stimulant, and iirc it's the only ADHD meds on the market that aren't stimulants, that might not be true but it's what I recall. PROS: does exactly what I want it to! Thumbs up! CONS: It doesn't work for everyone, apparently it has about a 50% effectiveness rate, where it just Doesn't work for some people. ADDITIONAL CONS: It CAN make your liver bad. You need NEED to get blood tests as you take it to make sure it doesn't mess with your liver. If your blood tests turn up fine, great! If your blood tests come back with your kidney worse off, you need to stop, you can't take it. Your liver will recover if you stop taking it but you cannot take Strattera. Anyway! That's my experience! Good luck with your medication journey! It's ANNOYING! <3  EDIT: Also! My psych didn't really push me for blood tests even though I should have done them. Make sure you do them. You seriously don't want to ruin your liver & TL:DR-- Adderall had the EXACT same effect on me. I'm on Strattera, works great. Only works for about 50% of folks, and you need blood tests to make sure it isn't hurting your liver, but if it works for you and the blood tests turn out fine then it works great imo!

As someone with ADHD as well I just wanted to put my experience down as well. Meds honestly never worked for me, they just made my ADHD brain worse. I ended up doing about 5 years of physical therapy instead. When you do it young like I did (my mom having a psychology degree meant she identified me being on the spectrum pretty young, luckily), it can have a life-lasting improvement... Obviously not a cure though, nothing can cure Autism (don't let the anti-vax crazies tell you otherwise lol). Aside from that, I also got a sensory brush and use it when stressed, and I crew something oral like gum and use fidget toys to help focus... It might sound a bit silly but these physical things really do work, and without the side effects of drugs (said side effects were pretty bad for me and the drugs didn't even help that much).  And last but not least, set up as much of your technology as possible to piss you the hell off, on purpose of course! By that I mean create metric buttloads of calendar alerts, alarms, multiple devices with different alarm sounds because you WILL press snooze or cancel and be like "I'll get to it in 5 minutes" and then get distracted, so it needs to genuinely be a pain in the ass to make any alerts stop, and last but not least set up a bedtime mode/internet cutoff time/similar to make sure you don't stay up browsing the internet until 5 freaking AM. I have ADHD and used to take Concerta. I think I'm on something else now, but yeah. Everything you described is 1:1.
My doctor put me on bupropion first, an antidepressant, because he thought it was depression, but that just caused emotional breakdowns and didn't really work. Then he put me on adderall, 5mg did nothing, 10mg did nothing, then 20mg caused the ADHD to get ten times worse so I immediately slept it off and stopped taking it lmao.  Also side note about "basically meth", adderall is not like meth. methamphetamine is like way more reactive and even neurotoxic, taking too much meth can permanently damage your brain. But taking dextroamphetamine (or vyvanse which is the same thing) at prescribed doses won't ever be neurotoxic. Maybe it could be slightly addictive but it doesn't create a physical dependence or permanently damage your brain like meth does.  Anyway my doctor then put me on dexedrine, 30mg a day, and HOLY HECK did that totally work. Dexedrine is basically what vyvanse does and it's missing the levoamphetamine in adderall, and only has the dextroamphetamine instead. (vyvanse is lisdexamfetamine which gets turned into dextroamphetamine by the body)  For the first five days I was totally high and would do everything, hyperfocus on anything, moving the body felt like it took zero effort and I felt really good the whole time. For the rest of the week and next week it pretty quickly stabilized and I was getting distractibility under control. Had a few days gap where I didn't take anything because my prescription ran out, slept 15 hours straight and then 8 hours again. But today was my first day back on it and I don't have that uncontrollable hyperfocus anymore. Time doesn't fly by so fast that I don't get to enjoy the day. And yet I can still decide to just get up and do anything, and my ADHD is totally gone.    On dexedrine I was actually able to get rid of some OCD too!! and start drinking water every day instead of sprite. And also take a few showers. All stuff that I wasn't able to do unmedicated. And the OCD was still gone even when I had to stop taking meds for a few days. Like, I'm actually changing myself for the better with this medicine. It's great.  So it does work really well for some people~

If it sucks... oof Oh also, seriously don't stop taking the meds and then jumping back into it without slowing going into it. I ran out for a few weeks and when I got a refill it was for 20mg. I have ADHD, and throughout my entire childhood, I was prescribed a variety of different meds to treat it. Vyvanse >>>
Having gone through several medications over the last 12 years, I can confirm this is what it's like. A lot of people think that they just need to take "an antidepressant" or "an anxiety med" or "an ADHD med" and when that generally doesn't work on the first try, they give up. You have to follow through with your prescriber! And always keep that person up to date. I had to go off an anxiety medication because of my ADHD, because it was supposed to reduce my nervous system activity; since ADHD can effectively reverse stimulants and depressants, it was RAMPING UP my nervous system instead of calming me down, and making me MORE LIKELY to have anxiety. Prescriptions are a very inexact science and you have to do a lot of trial and error.
Please do not stop taking your meds, I ended up in the illest I've ever been after I stop taking concerta - my biggest regret holy moly still recovering. Doctors are really good about it so ask them, I promise it'll be okay :3

I feel this in the pits of my bones. I actually developed depression from my ADHD, which ADHD can apparently be the cause of a lot of other brain problems. I started on Ritalin and that made my face and tongue go numb. Then I tried Adderall,  which worked for me! Until my heart rate started increasing to dangerous levels and I had to be taken off of it. Finally, due to my depression getting to concerning levels, I was put on Wellbutrin. It's a two-in-one that can be used for depression and/or ADHD that can take up to 6 weeks to start working, but by god. The difference is... incredible. After years of struggling, I finally feel like my old self. And I'm still in complete awe that this is how everyday peoples brains function.

Hi Icecream,   So I've had really great luck with strattera. It's is a non-stimulant, meaning 1) you can get 90 day supplies (something incredibly helpful for ADHDers) and 2) it doesn't give you highs and lows. The best way I can describe it, is it lets me sort my thoughts better. I don't get that sense of uncertainty when confronted with a task. There is no issue with addressing complicated things that need specific order. It just makes me get my brain in check. In simple terms, my brain is usually cranked up to 11, this puts me at a cool 7.5-8. I don't know if you will even read this, but I hope you find a good strategy to help with your symptoms. Good luck!

methylphenidate is also meth. ADHD tips dump that I totally didn't steal from my dad: 1. If you start your day doing something like like watching youtube videos or browsing reddit or otherwise goofing off, it's not likely you're going to get to a very productive state that day. Don't start your day distracted. 2. Your productivity can change depending on the time of day, you may be more productive in mornings or evenings or some other time. 3. Changing your environment can boost your energy. Doing things such as dimming the lights or working in a different room can boost your productivity. Remember, though, that doing that same change every day will just make it the new status quo. 4. Change up your strategies. Like your environment, your brain can become used to and bored of strategies to focus and work. Having multiple strategies to use and change between at different times can help. 5. ADHD is a process. If you're struggling with ADHD, it isn't likely that the solution will just come in one sweeping blow tomorrow. It's a process of trying things over time, seeing what works and what doesn't.  6. I, for one, have been on methylphenidate, Vyvanse, and Adderall. They weren't the end-all be-all for me. Medications are different for each person. Just because it works for one person, doesn't mean it'll work for you. It can take months before you find the right medication.  7. Another thing about medications: Just because the medication is working doesn't mean you don't have to put in any effort to work. My dad told me that "medications won't make you want to work, or enjoy work, or prevent you from getting distracted or make you not want to get distracted. You will still want to spend your time doing the things that are interesting to you. All medication does is make it a little easier for you to escape or avoid those distractions." 8. Also, Don't multitask.
Ya, you might just need one that works JUST on the norepinepherine, like Strattera, because the adderall made you DO things due to serotonin (plus the dopamine and norep), and the vyvanse made you HYPERFOCUS with the dopamine (plus the norep), but both didn't work the best. That norepinepherine deficency is what makes the ADHD happen, so an increase in that alone might be the solution for you. But every brain is different.

I have depression and anxiety (ADHD too, but the other two are a far worse issue for me) so I got on medication. My mental health was extremely bad that I sincerely wouldn't survive any longer if I didn't get some sort of treatment. And this video is really accurate about these kind of meds; everyone is different and every drug effects people differently. I first took Zoloft, pretty popular med, but I had an immediate bad reaction to it. I was only able to take it for about four days until I had to stop. Then they switched me to Lexapro which was good at the lowest dose (anything higher back fired), but it wore off after less than a year. Then they put me on Trintellix which was AMAZING, best med I ever took, but my insurance was changed and the new one didn't wanna cover it cuz it's expensive so I was forced to stop taking it and had to suffer withdrawal (not fun). Now I'm on Duloxetine which is pretty good, not as good as Trintellix, but its still good. Never give up on treatment just becuz things don't work right away. Meds take a while to start working and some meds don't work for your specific brain and that's okay, you will find one that does. And meds aren't a cure, you're still gonna have some rough days or moments, you're diagnosis isn't gonna go away, but it's going to make life a lot easier to manage. It's gonna be okay.

So... While I think the PLETHORA of different medications for ADD/ADHD/Autism are... Great... because there is likely one that works for you and your case... Im kind of on the fence about it. Always have been. My initial diagnosis for ADD functions very similarly to ADHD (duh) and my later diagnosis for autism explains why I didnt seem to have found enough help for my ADD problems.  Now I tried A LOT of different ADD meds. None of them really worked the way I would have liked. Usually with side effects that were worse than the problem it was intended to help alleviate. All that said I think my therapist(s) were right in that... the best solution is Meds + therapy. Meds alone are usually not that great at solving the problem. I get that everyone's mental problems are their own to solve and are a journey only they personally can take though. For some therapy does nothing, for me, meds did 'nothing'. I really tried many of them but eventually I'd had enough and said: Look... I just want help with these things, forget the headaches all these pills give me and lets just try a different approach. Which is what worked FOR ME. Still could use more focus, but I suppose Im happy with the way things are for me now.
Good luck, dude! You will find a way to make it work for you. Cheers!

*Sigh...* 4:46 Adderall is *NOT* "street meth." Man, I wish you did a little more research..  Adderall is an Amphetamine. "Street Meth" is a Methamphetamine.  They're "chemical compound cousins." Rough example: Lemons, Limes, Oranges, and Grapefruits are all citric fruits. But a Lime is Not an Orange. Chemistry is COMPLICATED.

Pills != Skills && Skills != Pills. I've developed ~ c o p i n g   m e c h a n i s m s ~ over time, but it wasn't until I got diagnosed with ADHD that I was intentional about them. Atomic Habits is a good read. SYNOPSIS: Will power's for suckers. You brain do easy thing. Make the thing you want to do the easier. Make stuff you want to not do more difficult. Set yourself up to succeed. You already have habits/patterns, a lot of them chain together. Find a good spot to insert a new one in the chain.

Listen the cow is great
I feel like not enough people realize that medication isn't a cure-all, you still need to develop discipline and good habits. ESPECIALLY around sleep.   The shortness of breath you experienced was probably a mini panic attack. I'm very prone to this when I'm relying on medication to function because I didn't get enough sleep or had poor sleep quality.  Stimulants drastically affect your sleep quality too, even after they've "worn off." Just because you're sleeping doesn't mean the sleep you're getting is restorative. You get into this feedback loop of bad sleep, poor focus, more Adderall/Ritalin/Vyvanse.  Therapeutic dosages of stimulants should be treated like this:  If you don't need it that day, don't take it.
As someone with ADHD and a horrible history with Vyvanse.. bruh taking meds only helped me through school, and helped me do things I never had the motivation to do prior. However, after a few years, I was convinced that the only reason I could do anything remotely useful was because of the medication. Felt.. totally useless w/o it, and began taking more than I should've. I then got addicted for a few years after I was prescribed 80mg (two 40mg pills) which is above the highest single-pill dose, and then my parents suddenly flung me off the meds w/o warning. No tapering, no nothin', just cold turkey. I'm alive, but everything I feel towards medication now just terrifies me and I'll never want to take it again.

A lot of people don‚Äôt realize that the medications work differently for everyone and that they should talk to their doctor about changing it.  I was first put on Ritalin and it was horrible for me. The side effects were not good. Then I got put on vyvanse and I LOVE it. While yes, I have the whole researching rocket issue, I know I can pull myself out of it and get onto a task that I need to focus on. I don‚Äôt have the out of breath issue luckily and I actually use my medication to help me at the gym. I cannot do cardio at the gym without my vyvanse. I‚Äôve also noticed some young people (I‚Äôm a teacher) don‚Äôt realize that they aren‚Äôt supposed to feel a certain way when on medication. If you cannot eat and are losing weight because of your medication, the focus you may get from the medication is NOT worth it. You should still be able to consume food and hold it down. A lot of doctors don‚Äôt seem to care and don‚Äôt want to deal with the trial and error. They write it off as ‚Äúwell that‚Äôs what happens.‚Äù And it‚Äôs not what should happen.  I couldn‚Äôt eat on Ritalin. I can eat on vyvanse. They don‚Äôt all work the same.   It‚Äôs also okay to choose to not be medicated as long as it doesn‚Äôt harm you or others.

hi i don't know if you'll see this or if you even need advice but i've been taking adderall for most of my life and i've always experienced the same situation you had with adderall where i can only finish physical tasks (unload dishwasher, do my laundry, etc.) but i couldn't even start properly on mental tasks (math homework, reading hamlet, generally anything school related).   what helped me was i found out that i can do these mental tasks when i'm in a different environment. it has to be quiet and work-orientated, like a library. trying these mental tasks at home just does not end well at all! if i really have to do something at home like for instance i need to turn in a paper by 12am i lock myself in the bathroom until i get it done. this is how i got my college essays done on time.   i'm so glad i'm not the only one who has had the same experience on this. adhd is a tough one for sure üòÖüòÖ

If you have ADHD or any sort of issue on not being able to focus, I promise you that reading through this entire comment will help you DRASTICALLY since most of you guys don't have the attention span to do so.  Meditating will drastically help with ADHD, it might even be better than medication. I'm not a doctor, so I can't confirm that it might be better than medication, but meditating could improve your focus, as it helps you be present and clears all your thoughts when doing something important. My brother has ADHD, meditates, and his focus and everything have become way better. I have started as well. There is this guy who really pushes for better mental health in this generation, his name is Hamza, and he discusses meditation and its benefits (more focus, better attention span because social media has destroyed it, etc.) in a video named "How to meditate in plain English"   If I made one person with ADHD or focusing issues read this entire thing and watch the video, I am proud of you, and myself, and I have don't my job here.  link is here:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vlFqgrg3OeU  Note: This WILL take time, but it will only change your life if you dedicate that time to doing it daily, even if you won't have ADHD, it will change your life anyways.  Go change your life

okay, it's not METH, adderall is an AMPHETAMINE meth stands for methamphetamine, so yes they are similar chemically, but any chemist will tell you that minor changes to any compound will drastically change it's effects. (I am not a chemist lol, but I am a nerd with adhd who takes adderall and i've done my research)

LMAO ACCURATE
For anyone, PLEASE talk with your provider first before starting or stopping meds.   For context, I'm a nurse and a pharmacy tech, currently In school to be a pharmacist. ADHD sucks. I'm on Adderall myself. But it's important to do things safely. The way a medication is picked out for you is based around your symptoms and your other health conditions and medications you're taking. So if Adderall doesn't work for you, and your provider chose Methylphenidate, there's a reason for the choice. It's dangerous to start and stop meds before consulting the provider first. I see it far too often...   If a med doesn't work for you, there will be another that will. It's all based around your genetics. It's like finding a peace of a puzzle and fitting it in. Don't force it if it won't work, but working with your provider to find the right med will, in the end, help that peace of the puzzle fit just right

I‚Äôve been taking concerta since i got diagnosed with adhd and this only now made me realize that different adhd meds have different affects. idk why i didn‚Äôt realize that sooner. either way I‚Äôm a slug without me drugs.
I remember the first time my doctor put me on adhd medication. I had gotten into this habbit of obsessively planning every second of the day in a desperate attempt to keep up with my wandering brain. It worked but it was exhausting. Plus it was made around the assumption that I wouldn't follow it very well, so every so often I have to move things around. The day I tried whatever it was for the first time, I had been looking at a whole week's schedule of homework and thinking about getting started on it (*thinking* not *doing*) I took the pill with lunch and suddenly I was doing homework. Not just the stuff for that day though; I managed to get done 7 days worth of homework in the span of 6 hours. One of those hours was spent just obsessing over how CLEAR everything was. cannot express just how true that whole "I could able" bit feels.
My ADHD cycles between bouncing around tasks and barely doing anything and hyper focusing on something I find interesting. One day I decided I wanted to make a handheld gaming device (like a DS) and now I‚Äôm designing smartwatches and cellphones. I found a thing and hyper focused but then all of the sudden I go back to bouncing around tasks for a while. Then I revisit an old thing that I hyper focused on and it happens again and then it cycles again. Basically my brain is like 30 people each reading a book about a random topic aloud at the same time and some monkeys bouncing around in the corner.

It doesnt matter if I hadnt eaten for hours, i will physically be unable to bring my self to put any type of food in my mouth. Yesterday I took one pill and I think it's the best I've ever felt in my life. Today was the first day taking two pills and the first was also amazing, the second had me focused, but foggy. I'm aware it's /only/ day 2 but even if it settled out to me feeling half this good, it's so worth it.

I had a higher heart rate and more anxiety with them, but SSRIs (a specific type of antidepressant) work really well for me. the thing about adhd meds is...they're NOT the end all be all solution. It's like you said: they WILL help you "do" or "focus", but then ya gotta learn and develop habits and strategies and stuff to work WITH the medication. Don't be discouraged bc your medication didn't turn out to be a magic pill that "cures" the adhd all by itself; it's gonna take a *bit* more work than that.  All of this being said, adhd medication is a personal choice, and whether or not one uses adhd meds is their own business. My experience is basically yours but...combined. I take ritalin, either 1 or 2 pills per day, 20 mg each,  depending on how long the day is (or when i wake up). When it hits in like 15 min or so, i suddenly feel like the mental fog of not being able to focus gets lifted and i get motivation to do stuff! I'll feel sluggish, mentally foggy, etc like i always did before, but no side effects, thankfully

My son takes Adderall and Intunive. It took a few tries with Adderall RX and Concerta as well, but the winning combination was Adderall overall. Adderall helped my son to focus, but would make him severely tired near the end of a school day. So, his neurologist had us go down a list that they said were compatible with him. Intunive ended up helping him along with Adderall. While this combination might not be good for other people, it definitely helped my son. I noticed he had ADHD when he was 3 going on 4. I just, saw how his brain was functioning, and how he was getting jumbled up in his thoughts. Took forever to get him properly diagnosed.
This was very similar to my experience with ADHD meds, though I was only ever on one that I can recall. I eventually stopped taking them around the time I was 15 because I felt like they were holding me back from doing things that I wanted to do.  I‚Äôm not saying any of this to say that ADHD meds will cause this to happen, because they do affect people differently, I‚Äôm just saying this to share my personal experience.  If you‚Äôve read this far, follow the Ice Cream man‚Äôs advice and do not just stop taking meds. Talk to your doctor first and see if it‚Äôs what‚Äôll be best for you.

Adderall has been a godsend for me personally, but I can *definitely* relate to how it worked for you. I only want to do what I love to do off my meds, but Adderall allows me to get the shit done that I also need to do in order to be a functional human, like doing laundry, taking out the trash, doing dishes, prepping my meals, doing homework, making flashcards, studying for exams in topics I don't necessarily enjoy, etc. Honestly the best way I can describe it is putting the stuff in my brain on a level playing field with what I want to do.

How are there already 2k comments when the video was posted 1 hour ago
Pharmacologist here: Adderall is normal Amphetamine, not Methamphetamine; The two have a different strength and duration of effect. Vyvanse is also regular old Amphetamine, but as a prodrug. It's the fancy way of creating a new sustained-release form of an existing med and allowed pharma to patent it again;  So basically, you tried Amphetamine twice and it didn't quite work out for you; A milder stimulant may be more suited and can help better with focus in particular without having as many side effects, i.e. Methylphenidate (Ritalin) or Guanfacine (Intuniv). Alternatively, there are also antidepressants that share the effect of norepinephrine reuptake with ADHD medication: Bupropion, Venlafaxine and Nortriptylin.  No matter the choice, some additional coaching or development of skills in order to direct that focus may be necessary though. Meds can't magically solve all your problems, but they can get you to a point where you can competently handle them yourself with some effort.

The fix that I use that does work is honestly just brute force it. As someone who has been trying to deal with ADHD for a while  now, I'm surprised nausea wasn't bought up at all in this video. I've taken several over the years and I've always had issues with that side effect to each of my meds. With all meds I've taken I've either had a feeling of something at the back of my throat making me gag all the way to actually throwing up afterwards. The only thing that helps with this issue is eating a lot when I do take the meds, but even then I'll get a weird feeling in the back of my throat sometimes that makes me think I'm gonna be sick. Its not as bad anymore since I moved onto new meds since I left school at a lower dose, but I still get that feeling when I talk. I think the meds I'm on are called delsomart or something like that. Also, your friend is a total knob... Lisdexamfetamine is still an amphetamine. Go look up the chemical difference between the two. Any medication used to "treat" ADD or ADHD... is just meth. A different variant...sure, but still meth. Lab grade amphatemine is cheap to produce, and it can be mass manufactured.  Woudl you be surprised if I told you the street stuff comes in just as many experiences?  If you are struggling with ADD or ADHD, he might not convince or disuade you, but I will. Don't take pills. If your parents have you on pills, make a concerted effort to have them take you off the medication, or do not take it. You are bombarding your system with a chemical that alters the way your brain receives dopamine.  When you complete something while on the medication... that satisfaction you feel, is only going to increase the dependency on the medication.  ... the pharmaceutical giants are there for profits, not your health, we mastered general health  long time ago, now the game is;   1. think of a new group of symptoms we can train kids in college to identify.  2. pay for studies to make it look like a problem,  3. when the students graduate they can start diagnosing. 4. you can start "developing a drug" now and then have it ready to pump out 5. after that just let some of those college kids go on to write books that will change the curriculum to where this is the new norm. 6. Profit.  ADD/ADHD don't exist. You lack discipline, and I will asy it as many times as I need to. It's truly incidieous for a doctor to tell someone they have a mental disorder based on physical properties they felt qualified to diagnose even though there was no propper scientific measurement applied.  It's called, "the placebo effect", the longer you go on telling yourself, "I have this and I'm struggling with it", the longer you will struggle with it, and the longer you will have it. This is one of the reason smokers find it so hard to quit smoking.

I was diagnosed with ADHD in like 2nd grade (12ish years ago) so I started taking a medication. I don't remember what it was (I probably never knew in the first place, I didn't pay attention to most things), but after upping the dosage a couple times over the next few years, I eventually got to a certain dosage that would make me feel EXACTLY like the out of breath, tight chest, can't breathe, feeling-of-impending-doom. I've only met one other person who had had that same reaction. Interesting.  Also, It would always happen like mid-afternoon. I would be totally fine for the whole day, and then around 5ish I would have a panic attack cause I couldn't breathe, and then like half an hour later, I'd be fine again.

As someone with ADHD and have taken both Adderall and Vyvanse, I must say this. The medications are tools, not a solution. They both allow you to essentially take control of the hyperfocus aspect of ADHD and direct it somewhere else. HOWEVER, it will not do the job for you. You yourself (in the general sense) need to have the willpower to prioritize which tasks need to be done. Making lists and having schedules are still needed even if you're medicated. The medication helps you focus, but you have to choose where that focus goes.  As for the sickly feeling. Idk, yo body don't like you I guess.
I had the same thing with way too much focus on Concerta, it turns out I just need a  really low dosage to have a normal brain ability to both move and hold my focus as needed

i have meds and they dont work
Medication isn't the solution for everyone. At the very least, it can be a tool in your tool belt in order to set the foundations for success. Another tool includes accommodating your habits. (Have trouble remembering a basic task? Put an object related to said task physically in your way. Things like that.) A great resource I'd recommend is "How to ADHD" here on YouTube.
In my experience meds are hit or miss and dependent on who you ar, if your not comfortable with how you feel on the meds don't feel like you shouldn't try anything else. If you dont like meds there is a thing called psychotherapy, from what i understand its learning to deal with it with the help of a phycologist.  Ive taken Vyvanse for about a year now, one of my biggest suggestions is to eat a good bit before taking it, how much i eat effects how hard and quickly the meds hit.            When it comes to all the meds ive taken they have never done what people say they do, as in making it easier to do whatever you want, i find they more so keep you on track to whatever your doing. That said you relly have to be vigilant of what your doing and why, getting yourself to change tasks to do what you need can be hard but once you get through the beginning its all about keeping it going.             Im pretty Shure the out of breath thing is cause by the body producing norepinephrine, wish is why your hands and feet can get kind of cold (this can also cause your little fella to get even smaller temporarily). If you have serious effects like what he said in the vid you should talk to your doctor.  If you are gonna take a new med look into its effects look up other peoples experiences/ask people you know who take it to give you tips on how to handle the effects.  Im not a medical professional so this is all from experience.

I take clonidine for tourettes. It just calms your nerves a little bit and it's a super mild drug. when I first started it my doctor told me there might not be any effects because it's primarily used as blood pressure medication for pregnant women, that's how safe it's considered. Might be worth looking into for all y'all with tourettes and ADHD, definitely can't hurt unlike most other drugs that are basically anti-psychotics, which are pretty much never good for you.

this video was made with and without Adderall ((:
Some of the analogies you make in these ADHD videos really resonate with me thanks for the good content
I take Adderall XR. For me personally, when I started taking it (both times), I initially got a surge of physical productivity like you mentioned. So much cleaning got done. That rush mellowed out into less physical productivity and more mental focus. It's not perfect, and not a cure-all, but it really helps me to be generally functional. I still have bad days, and I still have to rely really heavily on habits and other tricks. The medication doesn't fix my problems, it just helps me manage them.   However, finding the medication and dosage can definitely be a pain, and it really does depend on the individual. Even certain off-brands can have wildly different effects. Pharmacy gave me a different off-brand without telling me and it made me feel horrible. I got all the side-effects and none of the benefits. After I figured out what it was, I happened to talk to someone else with ADHD that experienced the same thing, but where off-brand A treated me well and off-brand B made me miserable, the opposite was true for him.   I hope you find something that works well for you, whether it is or isn't medication.

Just a story, don't let it affect your personal perception of Adderall: I got diagnosed in 2nd grade with ADHD, and they decided the best course of action was to medicate me. They decided to use Adderall, which I can understand in hindsight. I mean, if my problem is that I'm doing nothing in class then a pill that enables doing is a perfect concept. It would have been great...if they didn't start me on an adult dosage at 7 or 8 years old. I felt absolutely miserable whenever I took it, and my dumb baby brain didn't have the ability to articulate that bad feeling to anyone who could affect change. It also gave me unaliving ideation. Perfect for a 2nd grader, right? Anyway, after about a month of trying to find a way to not live without inconveniencing anyone I had the actual literal best idea; STOP TAKING THE MEDICATION THAT WAS MAKING ME WANT TO NOT LIVE. So I did. And now I have  *T R A U M A*  and don't trust brain medication. Long story short, don't give kids adult doses of brain altering chemicals. That's a bad.

I just started taking medication for my adhd today (Ritalin to be specific) and I‚Äôm a bit nervous since I‚Äôve heard that everyone reacts a little differently to it, and it‚Äôs not as efffective as adderall or Vyyanse. I‚Äôm currently a high school senior and I‚Äôve always struggled with procrastinating things until I panicked, and then hyper focusing on it. That, along with being very forgetful, head in the clouds, and having auditory processing issues (as well as being very emotional, although I‚Äôm less now), convinced me to seek a diagnosis. My pediatrician screened me, and told me I definitely had adhd. I still have doubts about it sometimes, but when I‚Äôm sitting in class and cannot for the life of me pay attention and my mind blanks out when working on anything, I remember why I seeked a diagnosis in the first place.  I‚Äôm very glad my parents allowed me to get medicated since they were very skeptical about any non-natural treatments. Just to clarify, even when medicated, it‚Äôs important to make sure you do other things that will also help, like sleeping (which I really should be trying to get more of myself), drinking water, and exercising. The worst part is constantly feeling like you aren‚Äôt living up to your potential, and realizing that you will never have the same ability that neurotypicals have to just do basic stuff on the daily. But I‚Äôm learning to accept it more, and viewing it as a different way of processing the world around me :)
As someone who has in the past had to deal with nasty medication side-effects leading to a need to promptly discontinue those meds, as well as difficulty contacting prescribing doctors in a timely manner, I'd highly recommend trying your luck in such circumstances with contacting your pharmacist, if that's an option for you. The options available to a pharmacist aren't necessarily the same as those available to a doctor, but they're usually pretty knowledgeable and, in my experience at least, willing to help the best they can.  Tell them your situation (you're on med X, experiencing negative reaction Y, and believe that you need to stop the med), and ask for advice on how to proceed safely. Some meds are fine to stop cold turkey.  Some aren't.  Your pharmacist should know which are which (and I've had some doctors who didn't), and the general shape of a safe path off the difficult ones.  And even if you do end up needing a prescribing doctor to sign off on a new prescription to smooth your path, your pharmacist _might_ be able to help make that happen.  YMMV, not-a-doctor, etc

"Adderall is essentially meth, try Vyvanse instead. It's not quite the same thing as meth, so it's ok." So, they're both amphetamines, and powerful ones at that. With similar structures to meth.  I am on Vyvanse, and was pushed from multiple medications to Vyvanse over a long period of years. Vyvanse is what works best for me, but it sure as hell has it's drawbacks. In my situation, the downsides of ADHD are worse than the downsides of the medication.
Yeah, meds never worked well for me, but everyone is different - and I found out when I was older that I was autistic as well, which doesn‚Äôt help matters üòÇ
ANOTHER ANOTHER FUN FACT!!!!  ADD and ADHD people have something called, specific memory forgetfulness. Despite its name, it actually means quite the opposite. We have trouble remembering events with generic things, but we can remember specific minute details of those events.  For example, I could forget what happened during a concert, but I can remember that the concert was on a Tuesday, that it had 2 songs that drew a really loud applause, that there was a guy who flipped out of his seat and no one noticed, and that there was a guy with an actual candle.  Another example is, there was a murder in the neighborhood. I forget what happened during the day, but I remember that there was specifically 4 loud shots from a .45 ACP. (Yep, i identified the bullet type by the sound it made.)  Cool stuff when you think about it.   Also, we can comprehend extensive subjects that range from many things, to something super specific.

Honestly I've found meds generally involve trial and error before finding the thing that matches your brain. Being on guard for negative side-effects is also important, and like... if you start thinking thoughts/having moods that are out of character + detrimental.   Seen a couple people be like 'I tried two med types and they weren't right, therefore no medication could possibly help me'. I think it took me 4 tries, changing doctors, and genetic testing before I really figured out what was up. Even then dosage has shifted as understanding got clearer. Doing buttloads better, but it's been a process.

Wanting desperately for something, anything to work is unfortunately relatable. Not just for ADHD but for a lot of things. My desperation in particular was depression, specifically the exhaustion caused by depression. It was so bad that I felt like I could collapse and die in my every waking moment. I tried literally every medication and I even took this genetic test to inform my psychiatrist how my body processes various medications for various mental illnesses (the one I did was Genesight if anyone was curious). Thankfully after 7 years, trying 15+ medications, and going to a different psychiatrist I FINALLY found one that worked. Is it perfect? No. I still have side effects that I have to contend with and I'm still tired most of the day. But it's a huge step up from my nearly debilitating exhaustion.
I do have to ask, what was your eating habits while you were taking the Vyvanse? It's a appetite suppressant, just as much as it's a ADHD medication. The symptoms you described sound like potential malnutrition, due to the previously mentioned side effect. Not saying to get back on the medication, but to look back and see if that potentially could be the cause.
I got diagnosed with adult ADHD a few years ago, and am lucky that taking generic Adderall has really changed my life for the better. Thank you for sharing your experiences!
Meds, in my personal opinion, are not fun. It's like lightning trapped in a bottle. You feel as if you need or want to do this and that and that and also this, but you're too timid to try anything. It makes a normally loud and excitable person very quiet and conserved. To its benefit, it makes the person EXTREMELY productive, especially when it comes to (like you said) physical and like logical things (math, problem solving, etc.) but during free time, you don't really know what to do with yourself. You kinda try to have fun, but it all feels hollow and fake. There's too much on your mind. Also, that thing you said about sitting down and actually thinking about things is INCREDIBLY TRUE. It's as if all the creativity has been sucked from your brain. They kinda helped me get where I am. I took them throughout elementary and middle school, and now, as a high school student, I'm performing very well.

I have recently started with ADHD meds, taking a variant of Adderall. I have had a really similar experience. I have found that I also have a great ability to focus, both on physical and mental tasks, but I have not gained a matching discipline to focus on the correct tasks. I often find myself researching a ton about a topic I find interesting. One day when my mechanical pencil broke I spent 3 hours researching what replacement I wanted.   There was one day when I took my morning dose too late, and my afternoon dose to early (each one lasts 4-6 hours). The overlapping doses gave me so much focus that I started to get anxious.  Over the last few months I have been adapting to this new kind of focus, and now focusing on the right task feels like switching tracks. Going from one task to another is difficult, but once I arrive actually focusing on the task is easy.  Generally just stopping a medication is not a good idea, but specifically with Adderall, and probably most other ADHD meds, it's not a problem. Adderall does not permanently alter any brain functions. Instead it acts as a stimulant, similar to caffeine. So suddenly stopping taking it is not an inherently bad thing.

This seems like a similar experience to when I first began meds for depression and anxiety. They worked, until they didn‚Äôt. Then we upped the dosage. That worked. Then it didn‚Äôt. Tried a different type. And it worked, then stoped. Rinse and repeat. Having a brain that does things differently is like a never-ending roller coaster. Boring days don‚Äôt exist.
5:46 that doesn't seem like a problem with the medication and how it works for you, it effectively did its job and helped you focus. The medication isn't going to help you focus on the correct thing, it can't really discriminate that way it just helps you FOCUS on the task you're doing. Which happened to be space and rockets. This is why therapy is also incredibly important to do alongside taking medication, since it can help you learn mechanisms to better direct yourself bc the meds aren't going to do that inherently. It's still also part self control and understanding how to direct your attention with the help of the meds quieting down the rest of your brain. It's tough!  Especially if you've gone your whole life without having this level of focus and clarity and having developed mechanisms to cope without meds. You have to learn to work with your meds, they unfortunately cannot do all the work. As you even said, they worked great as long as you primed yourself to be doing the task you needed, which is a great! But the meds weren't not working if you focused on the wrong thing, that comes down to self control and discipling yourself. Which ik sucks to hear when its constantly thrown at ppl with adhd, but there is some level of self control we have to exert even when on meds. Just like neurotypical ppl also have to learn to self manage.  When I take my meds there are def days I get distracted and then bc I'm on my meds I get distracted VERY intensely and go down rabbit holes until the meds wear off. I have to learn to be able to catch myself doing this, and sometimes I can catch myself earlier than other times! Sometimes I can tell myself we're putting a pin in this and I have to focus my attention on what I need to do.   It sounds like the Adderall helped remove alot of executive dysfunction for you, as you said it allowed you to DO things, but not exactly focus on doing things you wanted. That also goes hand in hand with learning to self direct yourself with the meds, but Adderall also tends to just do that from my experience and others. Its great for executive dysfunction but not always the best choice for people who want to sit and study, since the Adderall can then just make them anxious to be not moving and doing things (the meth talking lmao).
Hope you figure it out and get the right meds.
