I got diagnosed with it when I was I think like eight or nine? Had never had to take a pill before then so I couldn‚Äôt even swallow it right, had to put the pellets into applesauce for months until I figured out how to down it with water or milk or hell even yogurt Raised the dosage over the years as I got further through school, finally ‚Äúgrew‚Äù enough in the latter half of high school that I more or less phased out of the main problems with le brain and could stop taking the medicine for good
1 month supply of adderall XR for me without insurance was $890.  With insurance was $10.  In 2019, my insurance company no longer covered my medication.  I had been on it for almost 10 years.  I was suddenly cut off cold Turkey from medication.  I confess, that was a very long and painful first few months.  It took almost 6 months for me to feel somewhat ‚Äúnormal‚Äù.  I still struggle at times to stay focused and remember what I read (I‚Äôm an engineer, reading and remembering is critical).  ADHD is a manageable issue but it takes time and understanding about how your brain processes information.   Good luck out there.

ANOTHER FUN FACT!   The ADD and ADHD brain is actually more productive than any other brains. The problem is is that it either over focuses or has trouble multitasking. It also doesn't like doing tasks that can be seen as a minor inconvenience or interruption as to what it wants to actually do.  For example I could play video games all day long, but I have trouble focusing on making videos about those games.  It takes time and conditioning, but eventually you can operate with meds. It just takes time.

Ohey I take Vyvanse! It's pretty wacky but also pretty cool. It did help me realize that not only my mind was wacky but so was my body.  I totally relate to being super hyper-fixated on whatever you are doing when it kicks in-- that's normal. I didn't realize that's what it did until I realized that I was watching seasons of a show without getting up. But I found scheduling my day and setting alarms for new tasks I needed to do was enough to get me going and peel myself away from what I was working on.  I have moderate ADD / ADHD, and my record was enough to warrant getting it, but my psychiatrist suggested it for how effective it can be as an anti-depressant. It works pretty well in that! I would often find that whenever it actually started it's effects, I would feel extremely happy like I couldn't do anything wrong, and then I was just left with a positive feeling throughout the rest of the day, kinda like I was really light on my feet. That is until it's effects went away and I went back to feeling blue again, oftentimes feeling worse.  (That's normal for a lot of antidepressants too-- The return to normal often feels worse than some remember)  The kinds of negative feelings you described, like the running and stopping feeling, headaches, and inability to sleep, those are common, too! I found that when I'm on Vyvanse (since it's also a medication that can be used to treat binge eating), I feel zero need to eat, rest, drink. You need to drink a LOT of water when on Vyvanse because it will dehydrate you really quickly. Just because the need for it isn't felt, doesn't mean it isn't there. Eat your meals at the right time, take breaks, drink water, and they tend to go away.  I also found that taking breaks from the meds was also beneficial-- Taking them too many times in a row nullified the effects, and would make the time not taking it feel significantly worse. I would often take them once on a weekday, and on the weekends. Preserves the pills (because they are immensely pricey, even with really good insurance), and makes it so the kind of discipline I felt from having it would remain for a little bit. I always wanted medication that showed me how to work with my problems, rather than just getting rid of them.  This shouldn't also be taken as a universal truth to how meds work. They have patterns, yeah, but a lot of the time, the functions are very personal and it's up to your own judgement to determine what's best!

Listening to this made me cringe from the relatability. This is exactly how my brain works. One thing to be careful about - Adderall is similar to meth in that it is an amphetamine, but the amount of damage meth causes cannot be comparable to the stimulation and benefit Adderall has at the prescribed dosage. Meth is just bad news all around and can really cause some real damage to dopamine regulation. Don't let te fact that they're in the same "family" scare you away :) just make sure if you do consider taking Adderall to have a regimented intake so that you don't build up tolerance.
I hope this doesn't come off as pedantic, but I've found the channel How to ADHD to be an really great resource for strategies to work with yourself with, or without medication. I've yet to scrape together enough executive function to navigate ~*The System*~ and get a doctor to look at my stinky little brain, but in the meantime her videos have helped me understand how my brain functions and find ways to work with it. It's nice. :) Anyway, thank you for your funny little anecdotes, your videos are always really fun. <3

Try having ADHD and schizophrenia, with just the methylphenidate I was able to focus on the psychosis. So now both me and my psychiatrist are walking on eggshells to see if I'll completely be lost.  Also, I hate to break this to you, but ADHD medications have the highest success rate, of any classification of medication our species has discovered. If you have ADHD, untreated will lower your live expectancy by 13 years, assuming the executive disfunction does cause something sooner

Thank you for making such an honest and helpful video! Like many of the other comments I also have ADHD and experiences with medication. Everyone is different but I had the same experience with adderall, it was fantastic for helping me do things but those things would be just as random as my train of thought. It also gave me chest pain and increased anxiety. I switched to Ritalin during the adderall shortage and it‚Äôs been way better! It‚Äôs a much better fit for me, I get things done normally and not in an all over the place way. I will say that for me when I stop taking it I get my usual depression symptoms, so it‚Äôs also been a mood stabilizer as well. If you also have depression that might be a great bonus, but I don‚Äôt know how that would effect someone who doesn‚Äôt have it.  Obviously it‚Äôs all up to what you want and need, no one should be forced into meds or no meds, and plenty of people are happy just living their life with ADHD as is. I would just encourage people to above all else listen to their minds and bodies, don‚Äôt be scared to try the medications (lots of different ones if you need to!) but also don‚Äôt feel pressured to be on them.   With a ‚Äúlate‚Äù in life diagnosis for me personally it‚Äôs been a huge relief and extremely helpful to be on medications that help my brain function as opposed to feeling like I‚Äôm just a failure. In my case just about everyone I talked to really didn‚Äôt want me to be on medication because of that pushback against over diagnosis and medication. The thing is by the time I was asking for them I had already tried literally everything else and couldn‚Äôt get basic life needs done like groceries, paying bills on time, or working in general. It was thanks to my friend who said how much better their life was on meds that I pushed for it and I‚Äôm so thankful for it! I valued the experience of someone who also had what I had over ‚Äúhelpful‚Äù tips like ‚Äújust write it down in a note‚Äù

magik
Likely something called PVCs or atrial flutter induced by the Vyvanse which is a stimulant. Vyvanse and Adderall are both amphetamines, neither of which are meth. Methamphetamines are neurotoxic while amphetamines are neuro-protective. Vyvanse has an amino acid (lysine) bound to the d-amphetamine molecule. In theory, the lysine must first be digested off of the drug to be active. This would then create a more stable release of the medication as well as lower it‚Äôs propensity for abuse. Sorry to hear neither medication worked. There are some that are non-stimulant like Atomoxetine aka Strattera.

What was really happening however was serious depression, all of good results happened, but only because my emotions were completely muted and inside I was dying, this went on for years and it was in my teens so I beloved it was for the better.  It wasn‚Äôt until I reach my 20s that I realised it wasn‚Äôt good for me and stopped taking them, however the depressive dark thoughts are just part of me now AND I still suffer from ADHD.  Like the good man says, don‚Äôt focus on results and trick yourself that things are down when they aren‚Äôt.

Adderall and Vyvanse are basically the same drug with different release methods. Neither is meth. Your friend isn't that bright. Adderall is 85% dexteo and 15% levoamphetamine, Vyvanse is just dextroamphetamine attached to a metabolite that everyone processes differently and can lead to a buildup of unused meds causing an effectively higher dose being used each day if you burn off the metabolite slower, thus leading to the shortness of breath and sleeping issues. Either only listen to doctors, or verify everything you here with valid sources. Even this.

I trusted the adults enough to not even consider they might be harmful. I forget what I was prescribed, but it never felt like it helped. It made me a prime target for bullies, so I was relentlessly made fun of as a kid. It took me until I was 18 to realize what was going on. okay I'm going to be honest I have ADHD too and it is the exact same thing as you are describing and the solution was also drugs
Just to clarify, Adderall isn't meth. It's Adderall. The chemical structure of each is similar, but tiny chemical differences have huge effects. Adderall is structurally as similar to meth as psychedelic toad venom (5-MeO-DMT) is similar to melatonin!  Meth releases five times as much excess dopamine as Adderall does at the same concentration.[1] Meth destroys your brain,[no citation needed] whereas Adderall helps your brain function better over the long term[2][3] and actually _lowers_ your risk of addiction.[4]  (Also, Vyvanse is just extended-release Adderall.)  ADHD stimulants are "among the most effective and most studied psychotropic medications" of all time.[5] Roughly zero medications treat any psychiatric condition as well as stimulants treat ADHD. Stimulants are "considered first-line treatments for ADHD" because they're "supported by decades of research and a history of robust response, good tolerability, and safety across the lifespan."[5] Stimulants treat ADHD _way_ more effectively than therapy does.[6][7]  Also, when I say "effective," it's easy to think I mean "improving test results" or something, but to me the most important measure of effectiveness is how much it helps you live the life you want to live.  Stimulants may not work for everyone with ADHD. Opting for some other treatment instead is totally valid -- whatever works for you works. In some rare cases, what works best is no treatment at all. But stimulants are, short-term and long-term, statistically the most effective known ADHD treatment. They get a bad rap imo, especially when people pretend they're something they're not.  References (go to doi dot org slash each one below):  1. DOI:10.1074%2Fjbc.M805298200 2. DOI:10.1093/cercor/bhs345 3. DOI:10.1017/S0033291716000350 4. DOI:10.1038/nm0102-24 5. DOI:10.4088%2FPCC.12f01472 6. DOI:10.1016/j.cpr.2007.10.007 7. DOI:10.1001/archpsyc.56.12.1073

Dude, you need to do some research.  I was on Ritalin in the 90s, I take a 27mg dose of concerta in the morning and a 17mg dose at noon.  SSRI'S HAVE A BAD EFFECT WHEN YOU STOP TAKING THEM. Stimulants are, in general, pissed out within a day or two. They pass through your system fast enough that a morning workout changes the timing of my second dose!  YOU NEED TO TAKE BREAKS. These drugs modify your behavior but an integrated approach involving behavioral adaptation is the path to success and that means letting your normal headspace back in sometimes. For me I have only taken medication like this once. It didn‚Äôt work and then we didn‚Äôt try any more medicines. Which I am very happy about.  I have PDDNOS high functioning autism. My school want to put me on medication and my mom said no. So I learned how to live with it and I have a better understanding of how my autism works and how I tick. This is why I don‚Äôt really understand why people with ADHD or autism are OK with taking medication that is basically a type of psychedelic, because it alters your way of thinking. I can understand if it‚Äôs something that no matter how hard you try you have to rely on it. That‚Äôs fine. But if you just take the lazy way out and take personality suppressant as I like to call them, then that‚Äôs an issue.  Edit: to be absolutely clear. The only reason why I am the way I am today is because of the people around me and having a really caring mother who never made me feel lesser than what I am just because I have autism. When I was a kid the doctor said I wouldn‚Äôt be normal and be able to do certain things. Well who‚Äôs laughing now. I‚Äôm in community college right now studying animation and digital art. All because my mom made me do things that I didn‚Äôt like. She took me to the museum, the shed aquarium, and the zoo. Do you wanna know what those three places have in common. Loud and constantly changing. Two things that autistic people do not like. Guess what I love the museum and all the other places I‚Äôve went to now. And I‚Äôm OK with change now. I actually also just got my adhd diagnosis and I'm on the path towards medication now. But I HAVE been taking head meds for depression and anxiety for the past 5 years or so and here's the thing: it took 4 or 5 different meds before I figured out what was right for me. It took like...2 years of switching up doses, switching meds entirely before I found something that fit. Sometimes the meds would have awful side effects, some would do nothing at all. Some would take weeks before I saw a meaningful impact at all. When I finally did find the right type it still came with a slew of physical side effects that I had to make the choice to stick with. I call taking meds for the first time or changing them up, "the circus". You're never quite sure what you're going to get going into it.  But even despite it all they're never going to...FIX anything. Hear me out, I'm pro meds but they're a crutch. They're not going to walk for you they're just gonna HELP. It's important to go into this with good therapy, good outlooks, knowing this isnt going to completely solve an issue, its just gonna make it a hell of a lot easier for YOU to solve. I hope I'm making sense here, to whoever might be reading this. The road is long and it's hard and it sure as hell ain't linear. But it's worth it to search for the best version of yourself. And TLDR, finding the right meds takes a lot of experimentation and time. But it's worth it to keep trying.
Maybe try concerta, it‚Äôs what I‚Äôm on and I can do math well, so it may solve your focus problem.

So imagine having undiagnosed ADHD... everyone thinks you're insane, hyperactive, really dumb and bad at the ACT who enjoys fidget toys a BIT too much with absolutely no excuse. Fun.
Yes absolutely DO NOT STOP TAKING YOUR MEDS BEFORE TALKING TO YOUR DOCTOR. There are so many medications that have withdrawal effects that can feel worse than the side effects they can cause, so you have to have to HAVE TO know if you need to be weaned off of the meds or whatever. Sincerely, someone who learned this the hard way with anxiety meds. Dear god.

Thank you for putting into words the experience I had with adderall, I knew it wasn't working for me in the way how I intended but could never put it into words. That helps a lot!  I used to take adderall when I was younger and then switched to ritalin - ritalin also didn't help me focus, but instead it just kept my mojo going - so for example if I had homework and was able to get started on it, I could finish one assignment and feel comfortable starting the next, and then the next until it was all done. I think that was great, but the greatest help I've had is actually my organization. If I find that I'm always at a desk, I'll have a physical inbox with everything I need to do in that inbox. That way, when I get distracted, it's one of the first things I get distracted toward and I can still get things done.
The Adderall I take for my ADHD takes away my appetite :(  It was so bad at one point I got underweight and you could see most of my bones I had to just stop taking it on certain days entirely and it worked
Last year my therapist congratulated me for coming to the absolute closest to the bountry-line of ADHD *and* autism he'd ever seen without actually having either. My brain chemistry won't respond to medication and I have to helm this wrinkly egg myself with Cognitive Behavioral Therapy. It works, but progress is slow and requires self-discipline.

I have actually Used Both Adderall and Vyvanse for my medication(currently on Vyvanse). I had a pattern of Taking the meds during the weekday, but skipping them on Saturdays and Sundays. I've noticed that on higher dosages of Vyvanse(40-30mg) My energy would crash harder on the days I skipped them(Especially noticeable if I took a nap), but those energy crashes have been mostly absent since I switched back to 20mg. I've also noticed that the Higher dosages would affect my appetite a lot more(which was a horrible problem since I weigh less than 90lbs).  As for my experience with Adderall, I don't remember as it's been a little over 2 years since I last used it, but I recall it being extremely effective at getting me through school.
Edit after listening: try "medication holidays". Basically, 4 or 5 days on, 1 or 2 days off. I try to make my 4 week Adderall last 5 weeks. And I warn my wife beforehand "today is a med holiday, sorry in advance." I get super distracted and random ‚Äî not in a cute "lol so random :P" way, but in a "watching a movie we've wanted to see for months, get up to pee, and don't come back for 3 hours" kind of random. It really, truly helps the brain not increase the dopamine gateways that are broken in ADHD.  ---  So to ADHD gang: TRY DIFFERENT MEDS. As a kid I was put on Ritalin. Probably wayyyyy too high of a dose. I felt like a zombie, so I refused to take it. Then right before I took the MCAT, I begged for a few months' worth, because standardized tests are my Nemesis. Literally I will solve for B, then circle C. I don't know why, I just always do that.  This time I got Adderall. The difference is/was indescribable. Instead of a brain full of 23 favourite song lyrics on repeat, 15 TVs replaying cool bits of past shows, 14 radios chatting, 32 people yelling at me ‚Äî all while I try to hold a conversation, it's... 1/8th that noise. It's like I was given a master remote, and now can just press "power off". Yeah some noise is still there, but it's... So quiet in comparison.   Try different meds.

Maybe try some non-stimulants like strattera or reduce the dosage of vyvanse. When my vyvanse dose it to high I get reeaaaally hyperfixated on stuff. I tried ritalin (medikinet), vyvanse and attentin (similar to vyvanse but short acting). Now I'm testing a non-stimulant, because I still can't get my work done on vyvanse, with works best for me. Its only my second day on strattera, so who knows how it will go. It needs to build up in your system for a couple of weeks before the full effect are there.  So far no big side effects, only slight dry mouth and maybe some sleep problems (that I have anyways). But I seem to be a little bit more focused, calmer and less irritated. We will see how it goes. If strattera doesn't help, wellbutrin is next on my list.
Meds side effects were not worth it for me unfortunately, so I stopped it aswell. But I coped with ADHD my whole life anyway. Knowing that I actually have ADHD, improved my coping mechanism aswell.   Still sucks but I know why it sucks which improves overall life quality somehow...?

I used to be on Adderall for my entire elementary and middle school life, and it just made me like a zombie. Along with completely killing my appetite to the point where I pretty much stopped eating breakfast and lunch, although I would make myself eat lunch given I know I needed to eat. Then sometimes I would get dizzy spells briefly, would not recommend BTW, so now I am off any sort of ADHD medication.  I've learned to manage it for the most part, yet it's just hard to find some method to keep it completely under control, medicated or not medicated, as both have their problematic pros and cons, and from my experiences neither seems like a good solution, yay. I have thought about going back on the meds from time to time, yet the side effects are what keep me from doing that as it really messed with me at times. Which I did not like at all, and is why I have been going unmedicated for a bit now.
Maybe adding cognitive behavioral therapy and restarting with a new medication might help? Usually multimodal therapy has better results than just medication or therapy alone

Everyone reacts differently, for me meds have turned my life around, helping me manage not only my ADHD but also symptoms of depression and social anxiety. So keep trying, its a long process, took me like 4 tries before i got to a med that really worked for me, now im just honing the dosage. For anyone with a similar experience as him... Ask your psych about a lower dose! The 'out of breath' feeling and 'too much focus' both come from having the wrong dosage. There is probably a couple lower ones you could try. Also, try to have a day or two off the meds every now and then, I do that on accident by just forgetting to take them lol, but it helps with fighting off the negative effects. Making sure you are eating well and getting a good bit of protein can help too!

So I feel I have to say this. The majority of people do not have ADHD. Everyone has symptoms of ADHD. At all ages. The problem is the severity and occurrences of said ADHD. For me I am have trouble driving, watching TV, playing First person shooters or other hobbies that require any amount of prolonged attention. Secondly ADHD is considered one of the most overly diagnosed disorders out there. I genuinely don't tell people about my ADHD because so many people say they have it, and on top of that have people have so many preconceived notions and beliefs that are just wrong. It's like it's cool to have ADHD, it's not fun. I've been fired from 15+ jobs, some that I could have made well over 150k+ a year. Real ADHD affects everything, other than problems woth work which aren't behavioral but just the stuff I say, I have no filter and sometimes can't concentrate enough to prevent myself from saying stuff I should not have  Another big one is interpersonal and just plain relationships, it's extremely hard to maintain relationships and other stuff. I'm genuinely sick and tired of seeing stuff like this. It sucks.

49 minutes ago
Honestly this vid hits home for me. I got diagnosed with ADHD at age 17 and started taking meds for it soon after.  (The following are my personal experiences with these meds and for example only. Medication options are vast for a reason, because everyone's body requires different things and will respond differently for any reason, and sometimes no reason at all. My word is not gospel, my experiences are not universal and should not be taken as such):   My first one was Intuniv, a nonstimulant med that also doubled as a blood pressure med. It was supposed to help me focus while not tripping off my anxiety. And it did! For a bit. Then I started feeling like passing out every time I stood up or did a physical activity. The blood pressure med was then thrown out... I had previously experimented with (and since then become borderline dependent upon) caffiene, and found that it chilled me out and helped me focus. I was less fidgety (unless I overdid it). In fact, it would frequently put me to sleep.   Upon hearing this - rather than having me pop Midol Complete like tictacs - my med doc put me on good old Concerta as my morning med. It's a stimulant likened to Ritalin and it set my anxiety off so those meds had to get upped too. After that it was okay. I still had some issues with focusing, though, and was still very fidgety, so we tried to up the dose a bit... Bad idea. It was too much for me and I had the Too Much Focus problem. It was like entering hyperfocus but instead of pleasantly entering the zone, or doing an anxiety speedrun of a task, I was. Locked in? Held captive by the task I was doing and all my thoughts were still rushing and loud but ONLY about that task. And it made me... Angry, I think... Just, wound up tighter than a spring. Yeah. That's how I handwrote 18 pages worth of notes on Slavic folklore and Czech history/customs (in anticipation for an admitedly lackluster fieldtrip, in retrospect) in about 3 hours before I crashed. That lasted for the full week I was on that dose. My doc lowered it back and told me to keep her updated because it sounded like a hypomanic episode but couldn't be defined as that because it was caused by drugs.   So, back to normal Concerta levels and slightly not where I want to be, but better than nothing... And now for the story of night meds. Because even with extended release, my ADHD comes out to play again a lot sooner than my doc initially thought, and with a vengeance. All thanks to a fast drug metabolism I inherited from my mom. So this stuff burns through me in about half the time (for reference, Concerta is supposed to last about 12 hours and I feel it noticeably leaving my system about 8 hours in). So my mind is awake again and suddenly I couldn't sleep. Add that I am suddenly stimulation-deprived from a day of being uncharacteristically responsible, and I get a not-small-at-all case of the ZOOMIES. Clonidine Extended-Release is supposed to help with that. It helps me sleep, because it's another blood pressure med and that's a side effect I rely on. But it is also an ADHD med that makes me even more cool-headed than in the day. This is the time of day where I'm most focused, by far. Also, this one doesn't make me headachey, dizzy, see darkness, and/or cause my knees to buckle like Intuniv did. But if I can't get it refilled for any reason, the headaches and restlessness I will feel for the next many days¬† will make me question my sanity. In the end, it's all about balance. And that's it! Med history and experiences. Thanks for reading!
As someone with ADHD, the only real thing I could find to help with it was doing tasks that kept my interest. Problem solving like tasks are no issue for me because they are kinda like puzzles and there‚Äôs that euphoria feeling after you solve them. But other tasks that are necessary but bored me to death, I have a hard time to be bothered with them.  I never liked the medications because they make my head fuzzy and I feel that I lose a significant portion of my cognitive abilities which is not good for trying to figure out an issue.  I‚Äôm just glad the career path I took is IT and it‚Äôs almost all problem solving. The only issue I have is doing research or studying or trainings.

well... as someone with adhd, it took me about 6 tries to find my curent best fit, ritalin. i would recommend going back and trying more types of medication--ritalin and other methylphenidate based meds are COMPLETELY different from the amphetamine group that includes vyvance and adderall. However, I will caution you that there is currently a massive adhd medication shortage, and many people are reporting that the meds that they have gotten in the past month or so haven't worked for them anymore--tested negative for amphetamines on urine or blood tests, appetite and sleepiness came back, focus totally gone. But, eventually, maybe once the shortage is over... I would recommend trying something from the methylphenidate group. I think Concerta is the long release version most similar to vyvance within that group. Best of luck; i hope you find ways to function!

I remember I was on vyvanse for a while, and during covid, my Psych couldn't record my weight, pulse, blood pressure, etc. So I lost weight. The dose stayed the same and I started having what felt like absent seizures, (auras, strange feelings like nothing is real, staring off into space while paralyzed) Fun stuff. Turns out, vyvanse had raised my blood pressure to an average of 153/100 which is very NOT normal.   Certain medications work for some people, some don't. As a kid I was on methylphenidate. It was fine until middle school / early high school where bullying became relentless for me and I fell into my first experiences with depression. The meds made me feel nothing all day, just a shell of a human walking about with no soul, but as soon as they wore off each night I would bawl my eyes out until I fell asleep. I eventually kicked the meds, and with therapy, the darker days of my depression, but I prefer to live with ADHD and have a personality, even if it means I have to feel and experience everything, good and bad. It's hard to focus and stay on track, but I'd rather suffer through that than ever consider the meds again.

So, I've been through the ringer, I ended up on Vyvanse after a million different things over many years. Just a note that a lot of people don't know, Adderall and Vyvanse are basically the exact same **ADHD** medicine. Adderall just has some extra fillers because it was originally developed for weight loss, which didn't work. But someone saw that one of the compounds in it was known to treat ADHD so they just changed the patent and did that instead. They are both dexamphetamine, which, yeah, is very similar to meth. Vyvanse is just "uncut", Adderall still has all those random attempted weight loss drug additives. Which is also why it has a very interesting effect on a lot of people, while genuinely working for others.  Edit: If you want a legit recommendation, the one that worked for me by far the best before I tried Vyvanse was Daytrana. It's weird as hell, but it works. It's a patch that you can cut to size based on how much you want that day. You just stick it on and then peel it off when you're done. I was on it for about 10 years.
Adderall has been a huge help for me academically, but it also feels so restricting. I‚Äôve been told to workout before taking meds or after it wears off, you have to minimize caffeine (self medicated pre diagnosis), and since I‚Äôm out of shape, it‚Äôs easy to get my heart rate up.
I used to take vyvanse as a kid.  It got rid of a lot of my emotions lol.
I took Vyvanse for a bit but eventually stopped after being woken up from HORRIBLE stomach pains 3 days in a row. Switched to something called Azstarys and it‚Äôs been treating me pretty well so far!
So you're saying I shouldn't just be taking it for classes? Oh god I'm about to become even more of a worthwhile human being

Dude, this is my story! When I first took ritalin fast acting I found myself able to due so much...but not always what I wanted to do. I describe it as if I'm a fireman with a super powered fire hose, I can spray so much water but I struggle to be able to direct that water to the fire. The power is too high too suddenly.   Funny enough for my sister it was the other way around, she thrives on the fast acting ritalin, other ADHD meds gives her alot of mood symptoms. Brains are so diverse, I'm thankful to walk this journey with someone else so I can compare experiences.   Anyway--  I then took slow acting ritalin, this helped alot. It was a slower fire hose that went on longer. I had the ability to get that extra mental clarity while being able to control and direct it's direction. And with clonidine for a sleep aid, it was perfect.   Now I find myself in college and need a little more medication then I think I will when I'm out of school. So for now I'm taking vyvanse, which can go higher then ritalin. I found that same exact symptoms, for me my jaw started hurting so bad because how much I was clenching it. I went down a dose but it was not enough. Today I just went to my psychiatrist and he said there was no in between, so I've decided to combat the symptoms of vyvanse by take one ever other day.   Since it stays in your system for awhile, not taking it for a couple days isn't that big of a deal and actually has helped me. It keeps the symptoms from stacking up. That's just me, all brains different, talk to your doctor of course.  Anyway, my dude, I understand this so much. I hope you the best as you figure out your ADHD. It's a struggle to not feel inherently incapable, stupid, or lazy. But you are doing great, keep rocking it! Oh-and a good research I had been listening to is Dr. Russell Barkley. He's really good and entertaining to listen to his lectures. Hope you find a good balance for you and your able to hit your potential! All the good vibes your way and anyone else struggling too, or has a love one struggling!! Keep it up!! <3 <3   Oof...I...i should go study for my Chem test...might have hyper focused on writing this comment. Welp, it hope it helps someone feel more understanded, wish me luck!

My ADHD daughter is on her third medication‚Ä¶. Vyvanse worked well for her, but costs way, way, way too much. She‚Äôs now on methylphenidate (aka Ritalin), and it is working well enough that she can do college. It costs like $100 with insurance, but self-pay is about $44, so that‚Äôs what we do. I can‚Äôt believe how expensive meds for ADHD are.
2024 edit: I didn‚Äôt begin *seriously* questioning my symptoms and looking into care until your videos. They really helped me put into perspective what real ADHD looks like, and it turns out I‚Äôve been undiagnosed all my life! Over a year later, I‚Äôm diagnosed and am on Vyvanse. Yeah talk to the psych about Ritalin and Concerta. They have the same affect as vivance for me (at least, what you described) but not as focused, and without thos side effects. I've been taking them for years, and the only problems I've had are them wearing off too soon or the tolerances building up. When that happens you just TALK TO YOUR DOCTOR and up the dose a tiny bit. Like 2 MG each time.
I've actually been told by multiple psycs that you can go on and off most adhd meds whenever. Its actually good to take medication vacations because sometimes your brain will get used to them and they'll get less effective. Of course always ask your doctor before doing stuff, but they aren't like SSRIs.

I‚Äôm writing a paper about ADHD management and Im figuring out medication is one of the most difficult parts about having ADHD. Managing our symptoms is difficult and the honest truth is there‚Äôs no one fix solution or cure. You have to work everyday to pick and choose how you want to work with your disorder. The best thing you can do for yourself is do some heavy research about ADHD (diagnosis, symptoms, etymology, social issues, and medication / psychosocial therapy) and then figure out a plan from there with a good support system to hold yourself accountable. At least, that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm trying to do after 8+ years of knowing my diagnosis but not understanding it.

I've been doing so bad lately with productivity that I never thought it could be ADHD from what was described, and would still blame myself. Don't get me wrong, I still need to take the initiative to do stuff, but to have someone so accurately mirror my symptoms kind of feels validating for me. It's great to know I'm not the only one out there like I still thought I was even after the diagnosis. It's kind of hard to explain, but I'm thankful for this video. I know you aren't a doctor or anything and this isn't very medical advice, but that's kind of what I needed. I'm tired of medical explanations for things and pretty much just wanted to know that what _I've_ been doing wasn't just me being lazy. I've always summed it up to: "I have poor time-management skills, and it's a problem only _I_ can fix." I'm on Adderall right now (slow-release pill, though), and I agree with what you're saying. I feel like I have energy to do things, but I can't focus on anything. I can do but not think. Even the energy stimulant part of it is starting to wear off, I think. Polish cow dancing
Few things to say. 32 years old, ADHD diagnosed since childhood. Just information for anyone who, unfortunately, forms opinions based on YouTube comments. So... a lot of you.   1. Adderall is not meth. It's not "effectively taking meth." This is simply not true. It's funny, but Adderall is a really useful medicine too. Adderall has a similar chemical structure to meth (surprisingly similar, and it is a stimulant) but it's not meth. And it doesn't behave like meth. So don't tell people that it is. I've had it described to me that the stimulant is stimulating the ~restraint~ in your brain. So we don't get all energized or hyper, we just regain self control.   2. ADHD medicine, if you get a good version of it that works for you, will help you get stable. When you are stable, you need to learn to do the things you're not good at. Those don't just come with the pill, unfortunately. Like if you're bad at focusing, Adderall will remove your ~obstacles~ to being focused. But it can't teach you to focus. But the great news is that many of the skills you learn while stable, you still have access to when you're off your medicine! It helps a lot.  3. Yeah you might not react well too your first medication. Keep trying, it's so worth the trouble if you find something effective. But even then, remember point 2. You need to train yourself in the new, necessary skills while the medicine is working. You don't get focus in a pill. Personal growth is still required, but it's way, way easier.  And for the love of God talk to a professional. Why are you listening to any of us? This is YouTube. The YouTube comment section. Run away, get to a trained professional.

Is it just me or is this video super quiet? I have it at max volume both in youtube and main volume and its still hard to hear.
Hey IceCream Sandwich and everyone! I have been recently learning in my Abnormal and Clinical psychology class that most pharmaceutical drugs addressing mental disorders and illnesses(ie. psychiatric drugs, antidepressants, etc.) have been very ineffective treatments for treating them(in the long term run) since it doesn't really address any underlying causes of your disorder/illness but rather sort of "treats" your symptoms(mainly in the earlier phases of taking the medication). The reason why medications are prescribed in the first place is because a HUGE a false belief that mental disorder/illnesses are a result of a "chemical imbalance in the brain" so the drugs would consequently usually inhibit or produce more of the certain neurotransmitters believed to be "out of balance". HOWEVER, there have been NO studies that prove mental illnesses are even RELATED to/AFFECTED by "chemical imbalances" of the brain. SO NOW, what happens is that the the drugs are just messing with the communication system in your brain and your brain due to homeostasis(tendency of body to return to a natural state) will do the opposite of what the drug has been doing to adjust to the changes its been making to your brain. That is why most people can end up relying on drugs and getting worse symptoms because if they use it for too long and suddenly stop, they'll have awful withdrawal symptoms since your body had been so accustomed to a system that runs on drugs.   Note: I cannot really go into depth of how problematic and deeply ingrained the pharmaceutical drug industry is with prescribing drugs that aren't really effective at treating issues with unknown causes(other than its symptoms/label) so if you want to learn more about it yourself feel free to read "Anatomy of the Epidemic" by Robert Whitaker. He goes into a lot of depth about these issues and has no conflicts of interest!
I watch your videos while doing my studies while i think about commenting on this video. This is not ADHD its just me.

Finnaly a new vid
Adhd kid on meds here, QUICK NOTE: Concerta and Ritalin are both the same thing, methylphenidate. I take both. The only difference is that Concerta is an extended release capsule and is normally in larger doses but takes longer to administer, as it dispenses over time. It is called long acting methylphenidate by pharmacies. Ritalin, on the other hand, is legit just a pill made of packed methylphenidate and it absorbs instantly. It is Called short acting methylphenidate by the pharmacies.  Keep in mind that these are both the same medication, and they are both stimulants. If a normal person was to take them, you would be bouncing off the walls. If I was to take them, I space out. Apparently adhd makes stimulants act like depressants (drugs that slow you down, not cause depression) and vice versa. If I drink coffee, it causes me to feel more tired. If I take benadryl, I go freaking insane. I haven't had it in a while tho, so idk about now but when I was a kid it was unbearable.  The cool part about adhd is it is literally galaxy brain like it is in the memes. You are great at thinking about multiple things at once non stop, it just gets a little confusing if you don't know how to manage it.

Neurofeedback is a kind of therapy where they measure your brainwaves first and diagnose from which part of the brain the adhd comes from (its mostly the prefrontal cortex). After getting the data you get into kind of a training that enables your brain to produce new connections and arteries for better bloodflow and focus.   it literatly changes the brain instead of just inhibitng dopamin receptors etc. The training is not complicated or difficult but on adhd it has maximum impact. Im from switzerland and i needed and additional insurance. But pls check this out.   There are other things like raw cocoa powder which enhances cognitive performance plus the whole spectrum of so called ,,Nootropics" <--- brainenhancing substances, natural or otherwise. Your not stuck with adhd, you can get better <3 much love from switzerland

I had taken ADHD medicine for most of my life, I took 75mg of Risperdal (almost) everyday for 9 years and only stopped taking them once i moved out. Its horrible, they either kill your mental abilities or kill your soul. I felt like a ghost possessing its own corpse. My parents were convinced they could tell when I was or wasn't on them. Little did they know I constantly faked taking them when i got the chance. but I did take them everyday consistently for about 3 years between 6th and 9th grade. I've been off them now for 3 years and I'm better then ever. Yes the mind is chaotic so work with it instead of against it. work a hectic job that constantly keeps you engaged. I work as a technician where i constantly thinking about parts and problem solving for a rapid mind helps fix things sooner due to having multiple things going on simultaneously. if there is a perfect drug that has no side effects then great. But i can say the give is not worth the take. sure school was easier but i was depressed, sure i could focus but my actions had no heart, i felt like i was on auto pilot with no real sense of self. Learn how to deal with your adhd that doesn't rely on a external source of artificial motivation. Have some discipline and take care of it the hard way because its the only way that lasts. Its also cheaper as no drugs.

Adderall is amazing rec drug, turn to powder and snort, easy upper
The thing about meds is that they don't do everything for you. So if we go back to your experience with adderall, just because it didn't let you fully focus doesn't necisarily mean it isn't helpful for you and you shouldn't go with it in the future. Sure, you might still have trouble sitting down and focusing, but if it's a step in the right direction and nothing is any better, than that's just because meds don't fix everything when it comes to adhd. I take concerta which I think is decently similar to adderall (I'm not a doctor, but the way I understand it they're both the type of adhd meds that are similar to meth, although I didn't know there were adhd meds that weren't like that until now) and I understand what you mean about sitting at a computer and not being able to just focus. But in my experience I've noticed I am still more productive on a computer with them, even if I don't feel anything and just notice I've finished my work faster. There's also other organization things that help with that, like having a to-do list and the thing I find very helpful is closing discord and taking out my headphones when I don't need them. And after doing that, I think your meds will actually help you finish your work faster. You might not feel a difference, but if you compare the amount of work you get done with vs without them even on a computer I think you'll be surprised by how much more work you've finished. You also may not react this way, as everyone reacts to adhd meds differently but I also think this is a possibility. Plus, you've only tried it on a low dose, so that could have something to do with it.

Amazing vid!
This is gonna sound way too simple to be true but sometimes simple is better! Meditation has been scientifically shown to help with ADHD symptoms, specifically the issues with focus, thoughts overlapping and task coordination. Just start with meditating 5 minutes a day - and that can be anything. It can be intimidating to start with the ‚Äúclassic‚Äù type of meditation where you‚Äôre sitting there with your eyes closed, ‚Äúmind empty.‚Äù You can start with a simple breathing practice such as square breathing (breath in for 7 seconds, hold for 5, breath out for 7-9 seconds, hold for 5, repeat) until you start to get the hang of it. Then once you feel like you have it, start focusing on what it feels like when you meditate and try and consciously bring that into your daily life. By doing these simple tasks with zero pressure on yourself, you can make major improvements in a surprisingly short time! And the beauty of this is it works whether you‚Äôre medicated or not, it will be beneficial no matter who you are. And it‚Äôs free!!!

I got my ADHD diagnosis recently and I asked my doctor for a non-stimulant ADHD medication because I knew about the variability of Adderall and Ritalin, so he put me on Atomoxetine. I've been taking it for the past month and I've been feeling more motivated and interested in actively doing Stuff, when before I would just be a lump overwhelmed by all the Tasks I needed to do. Might be worth an ask to your psych about non-stimulant medications.

Hi Andy thank you for posting this video. Like my other is in the comment section here I too have ADHD and I'm medicated. On the whole it sounds like you're just dealing with how to manage the focus on a more fundamental level after being medicated. Using drugs to help achieve focus still requires learning the discipline over time. I encourage you to keep trying if you are willing and if not cool. To those in the audience is important to understand yes ADHD medicines are basically meth. The real important difference here is how much the dosage is and the slight difference in chemistry. Right away the important thing to realize is actual meth junkies consume is literally tens of thousands of times the dosage of what people with ADHD typically take. Even with that in mind most are regulated as a controlled substance. Meaning if you're taking this you have to not only get a prescription, but are not allowed refills until the amount of days it takes to consume based on direction. This might also entail other sensible measures. Using ADHD medicine is not for every person with ADHD. For me I cannot fathom living without it. There is a night and day difference in my behavior activity and cognitive focus. Love you Andy!

i'm fairly certain none of the medicine works as advertised. It all comes with nasty side effects and none of it really seems to help even if it doesn't kill you. It mostly just replaces one problem with another. Bottomline, i don't think anybody should be on adhd meds. Partly because i don't believe adhd is a real thing. It seems more like something big pharma made up to make money with. Obviously, it didn't bother people a hundred years ago. So, i doubt it just spontaneously appeared one day. The other reasons involve all the bad side effects and the fact that over 70% of all Americans are on some form of prescription medication. Seriously, either we're the weakest nation on earth or some people are being tricked into taking meds they don't need. The latter seems the more likely case.

I took Ritalin & it made me numb. I couldn't express any emotions like sadness, happiness, anger, etc. I couldn't cry for 2 years. Now, I'm happy I can cry again ü•≤
I was fortunate enough to get diagnosed fairly young (10-11) & I also took medication for a little bit.  Thing about medication is that it helps. But, that's all it does: help. Everything else comes from you. Focus? You. Direction? You. Yes, these things are harder, but *you* are so the one to do it.  It's kinda like being short, & needing a ladder. Yes, the ladder is going to help you get what you need, but you still need to put the ladder in the right spot. Or you can be like me & just start climbing to get what you need because you find the ladders to be unreliable. (The metaphor's breaking down a bit, but you get the idea.)  Point is, do what you feel is good for you.  2 side notes:  1. Being online all the time feels A LOT like having ADHD. Log off for awhile, & if you still feel like you have symptoms, consult a doctor. 2. ADHD meds are actually a really good indicator if you have it. If they make you high, you don't have it.

Yeah my first med was Adderall. It helped a SHITTON with doing tasks and being able to exist and do things without excess stimulus but it did nothing for *the rest of it*. I still had issues with switching tasks, managing priorities, getting myself awake and out of bed, and most severely, my EXTREME emotional disregulation and depression. I switched to Wellbutrin (generic for Buproprion) and suddenly it was like my depression all but disappeared. I had a lot easier of a time noticing and managing my emotions. I could properly articulate when I was upset about something and why. And coupled with my sleeping meds, I was suddenly awake and alert in the morning, a feeling I had never experienced before in my ENTIRE life. Unfortunately I no longer have the task starting and finishing ability that I had when I was on Adderall, but I rely on other people getting me started on tasks and that's worked out pretty well for me so far

one thing that helps me with procrastination and incessant adhd (not sure if I have it), but just being honest with yourself about what you want. people or soceity or family put a lot of expectations on you to be good or do good things, so when you don't feel like working on the thing you NEED to work on, instead of playing racket ball in your head of "i have to, but i don't want to, but i have to. ooo new ice cream sandwich video" just make the decision to NOT do the thing. and then later you'll come back in a better headspace after that new ice cream sandwich vid and be like "oh yeah... i still gotta do this, i forgot about it. eh, whatever, I'll just power boot through it."

I would like to mention that there is an actual ADHD medication that has ‚ÄúMeth‚Äù in the name
One of the side effects of Adderall that no one tells you about is that you stop /feeling/ your emotions. You still have them but they are detached and distant from you like watching your life on a screen rather than actually experiencing it. I once put it that you are sitting at your brain console and your emotions are the controls and displays, but you are in a straight jacket and can't interface with them. You can see what you are supposed to be feeling, but can't actually touch it.

ADHD, or Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder, is a neurological condition that affects many people worldwide. But did you know that ADHD can also be funny? Here are a few examples of how ADHD can be both hilarious and entertaining:  The hyperactivity: One of the classic symptoms of ADHD is hyperactivity, which can result in a lot of physical movement and restlessness. Imagine someone with ADHD trying to sit still during a boring meeting ‚Äì it's like watching a jack-in-the-box on steroids. They might tap their foot, fidget with their pen, or bounce their leg up and down so much that they start to look like they're auditioning for a role in Riverdance. The distractibility: Another hallmark of ADHD is distractibility, which can lead to some hilarious moments. For example, someone with ADHD might start a conversation with you about a topic, and then suddenly get distracted by something shiny in the distance. Or they might forget what they were saying mid-sentence and start talking about something completely unrelated. It's like watching a squirrel trying to cross a busy road ‚Äì you never know where they're going to end up. The forgetfulness: People with ADHD often struggle with forgetfulness, which can lead to some comical situations. For example, they might forget their own birthday, or show up to work wearing two different shoes. Or they might forget to turn off the stove and accidentally burn their dinner, only to realize it when the smoke alarm goes off. It's like watching a goldfish trying to remember where it left its keys. The impulsivity: ADHD can also lead to impulsivity, which can result in some hilarious moments. For example, someone with ADHD might suddenly blurt out a joke in the middle of a serious conversation, or decide to go bungee jumping on a whim. Or they might impulsively buy something they don't need, like a life-sized cutout of their favorite celebrity, only to regret it later. It's like watching a toddler on a sugar high trying to make responsible life choices. The creativity: Finally, ADHD can also be funny because it often leads to creativity and out-of-the-box thinking. People with ADHD might come up with some wacky ideas that others would never have thought of, like a toaster that also makes smoothies, or a hat that doubles as a portable air conditioner. Or they might come up with hilarious puns and jokes that leave everyone in stitches. It's like watching a mad scientist at work, only instead of a lab coat they're wearing a t-shirt with a silly slogan on it. In conclusion, while ADHD can certainly be a serious condition that can have a significant impact on people's lives, it can also be incredibly funny and entertaining. So the next time you're hanging out with someone who has ADHD, embrace the chaos and enjoy the ride ‚Äì you never know what kind of hilarity might ensue.

Me on minecraft lol
As someone else with (pretty crippling) ADHD, I can only offer the other side of the coin to those who are thinking of trying medication: it allowed me to actually be a person. I don't sleep for 16 hours a day anymore, I don't hyperfixate on things I don't even enjoy anymore, I'm not always starving, I can actually find the words I'm trying to summon in a conversation, etc. ad infinitum. Some people don't react well to certain drugs, some people might not react well to any, but some people need them to function properly. Don't base your decision to seek medication on any one person's experience- see a psychiatrist and find out whether it would be a good idea for YOU.
